{"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cSurgeon General Urges Americans to Carry Drug That Stops Opioid Overdoses\u201d (news article, April 6):\n\nThe surgeon general\u2019s aggressive and necessary initiative to make naloxone more available to the families and friends of people at risk of an opioid overdose will assuredly save lives. Empowering drug treatment agencies, with their experience and expertise, to play a leadership role in bringing naloxone training to the business world takes this call to action a crucial step further.\n\nSmart business leaders are recognizing that addiction is an equal-opportunity destroyer that affects their employees and their families.\n\nIgnoring potential stigma, business leaders understand that their employees are susceptible to witnessing an overdose at work, at home or in public places. By inviting agencies like ours to train them and their staff members in administering overdose reversal medication, they are acknowledging that this pernicious epidemic can be defeated.\n\nPETER PROVET, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is president and chief executive of Odyssey House.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cOrdering Five Million Deaths Online\u201d (Op-Ed, April 6):\n\nAs a physician who specializes in pain management, I believe that Richard A. Friedman raises a number of important issues regarding the overuse of opioids in this country. But he appears to conflate two very different patient groups.", "title": "Opinion | Treating Opioid Overdose, on the Ground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "China said on Wednesday that it wanted to play a positive role in formally ending the war, in which an estimated three million Chinese soldiers fought. But it stopped short of endorsing the idea of a treaty, which is likely to involve extensive negotiations and would require the recognition of North Korea by the United States.\n\n\u201cChina\u2019s attitude is open and supportive to any peaceful means to resolve the Korean Peninsula issue through consultations,\u201d Hua Chunying, spokeswoman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, said when asked at a news briefing in Beijing about supporting a possible treaty.\n\nChina has promoted the idea of a peace treaty from time to time over the past two decades, to little avail. This time, analysts said on Wednesday, Beijing\u2019s enthusiasm for the idea is likely to be tempered by rising tensions with the Trump administration over trade and Taiwan. Chinese officials are livid over Washington\u2019s move this week to prevent American suppliers from selling parts to the Chinese tech giant ZTE, they said.\n\n\u201cIf the two countries cannot settle the trade issues, that will have a significant impact on China\u2019s attitude toward helping the United States on North Korea,\u201d said Cheng Xiaohe, a North Korea expert at the Beijing-based Renmin University. \u201cThe ongoing situation with trade is complicating and undermining cooperation.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Cheng said, China\u2019s relations with North Korea have rapidly warmed in the wake of Kim Jong-un\u2019s surprise visit to Beijing last month. That could give China leverage with North Korea against the United States as Washington works out the terms of the meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSouth Korean officials said on Wednesday that they hoped Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon, during their meeting next week, could jointly announce a willingness to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula and ban military hostilities there, as a precursor to a peace treaty.\n\nBut Mr. Cheng and other Chinese analysts expressed skepticism that a peace treaty would be signed anytime soon. \u201cIf the United States is to sign with North Korea, it needs to do several things,\u201d Mr. Cheng said. \u201cIt has to talk to China, and the United States has to recognize North Korea diplomatically.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOnly countries with diplomatic relations can sign a treaty, he said. \u201cA treaty is not a memorandum or a communiqu\u00e9.\u201d\n\nWhat the Conditions Might Be\n\nSome analysts in South Korea have suggested that Mr. Moon and Mr. Kim could agree to withdraw weapons and troops from the 2.5-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone, which was created with the armistice and still divides the Koreas. Despite its name, the zone is the world\u2019s most heavily armed border. Although the armistice allows only rifles and pistols within the area, both sides have deployed much heavier weapons and operate guard posts inside the zone.\n\nIn the past, the North\u2019s conditions for its denuclearization have included the withdrawal of the 28,500 American troops stationed in South Korea, a demand that Washington and Seoul have adamantly rejected. But Mr. Kim has recently indicated that he could be more flexible about the American military presence in the South if his country no longer felt threatened by it, according to officials and analysts in Seoul.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe think that North Korea is more realistic about the security environment on the Korean Peninsula,\u201d Mr. Chung said on Wednesday, referring to Mr. Kim\u2019s decision not to object to recent joint military exercises between South Korea and the United States. The North has typically used such drills as a pretext to conduct weapons tests and reject dialogue.\n\nIn 2000, Mr. Kim\u2019s late father and predecessor, Kim Jong-il, told the visiting South Korean president Kim Dae-jung that he could support the American military presence as a peacekeeping force in the region, according to South Korean officials who attended their meeting.\n\n\u201cI am quite sure that if relations between North Korea and the United States improve, the North will not demand the withdrawal of American troops in signing the peace treaty,\u201d Lee Jong-seok, a former South Korean unification minister, said during a forum on Wednesday.\n\n\u2018There Could Be a Partial Withdrawal\u2019\n\nFormally ending the war would not necessarily mean that Mr. Kim would demand that all American troops be removed, said John Delury, a professor at Yonsei University in Seoul. \u201cThere could be a partial withdrawal,\u201d he said. \u201cRemember, all this maneuvering is going on while the United States and South Korea are conducting joint military exercises.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nStill, Mr. Kim seems likely to demand at least a major reduction in troops, said Hugh White, a senior military strategist who worked at the Australian Department of Defense and is now a professor at Australian National University. One outcome, he said, could be a substantial troop withdrawal in exchange for Mr. Kim\u2019s scrapping his intercontinental ballistic missile program.\n\nSuch an agreement could appeal to Mr. Trump with his \u201cAmerica First\u201d perspective, Mr. White said. From that point of view, \u201cit could make sense to withdraw from Korea if in return Kim Jong-un scrapped the ICBM program and thus ceased to threaten the continental United States,\u201d he said.\n\nThat, Mr. White noted, would transform the American military presence in Asia. \u201cIt would be a big win for China,\u201d he said.", "title": "Treaty to Formally End Korean War Is Being Discussed, South Confirms", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun", "Jane Perlez"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. But he lamented the idea that Congress could not be expected to make its own decisions, free of corporate influence.", "title": "Trevor Noah Hammers Congress for Dependence on Facebook\u2019s Cash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\nForgetting Why They Were Fighting\n\nPresident Trump is moving forward with his plan to meet with North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un. Trevor Noah said he didn\u2019t quite know what to make of the news \u2014 but he was willing to give Trump credit for diplomacy.\n\n\u201cI know our first instinct is to hate, and it\u2019s also weird that Trump makes it all about himself, but Trump is right: If it wasn\u2019t for his craziness, North Korea would have never come to the table. That\u2019s what he did. Trump is like the near-death experience that makes people forget about why they were fighting in the first place.\u201d \u2014 TREVOR NOAH\n\nThe C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, went to North Korea earlier this month, but news of the visit didn\u2019t emerge until weeks later.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t believe Trump kept something this big secret! How did he do it? I mean, the only possible explanation is that Michael Cohen paid him $130,000 to stay quiet about it.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nSamantha Bee Takes on Sean Hannity\n\nSamantha Bee thought this week was the right time for a \u201cFull Frontal\u201d attack on Sean Hannity. Bee gave a rundown of the recent revelation that Hannity had been a client of Trump\u2019s lawyer, Michael Cohen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen she decided to use some of what she called Hannity\u2019s own dishonest reporting techniques against him: She did an elaborate segment accusing him (sarcastically) of being a serial killer.", "title": "Trevor Noah Is Cautiously Optimistic About Trump\u2019s Talks With Kim", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you\u2019re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.\n\nWhite House of Cards\n\nPresident Trump called the hosts of \u201cFox and Friends\u201d on Thursday morning. Before he lit into a nearly unbroken 30-minute monologue, they asked him what he\u2019d gotten for his wife, Melania, who was celebrating her birthday. He admitted that he hadn\u2019t bought her a present, but got her \u201ca beautiful card.\u201d", "title": "Trevor Noah Jabs Trump for Not Buying Melania a Birthday Gift", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "NORRISTOWN, Pa. \u2014 Judge Steven T. O\u2019Neill, who is presiding at Bill Cosby\u2019s sexual assault retrial, ruled Tuesday that jurors could hear the defendant\u2019s previous statements about obtaining quaaludes, powerful sedatives, as part of his efforts to have sex with women.\n\nProsecutors say Mr. Cosby\u2019s statement about the quaaludes bolsters their contention that he drugged women, including Andrea Constand, whom he is charged with molesting in 2004 after giving her three blue pills. She has testified they incapacitated her.\n\nMr. Cosby\u2019s defense team had tried to block the introduction of his statement from a 2005 deposition in a civil suit that Ms. Constand filed against him. Becky James, an attorney for Mr. Cosby, said his remarks about his past use of quaaludes had nothing to do with the current case.\n\n\u201cUsing quaaludes on the party scene in the 1970s just doesn\u2019t have any relevance,\u201d she said on the eighth day of the trial.", "title": "Trial Judge Rules to Admit Cosby Testimony About Quaaludes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Tribeca Film Festival is known for its crowd-pleasing programming. The crosstown New York Film Festival has an illustrious history of highlighting foreign and art films. But on Thursday, the two institutions seemed to align when Tribeca gave its top award, for best narrative feature, to Kent Jones, the director of both the New York Film Festival and the drama \u201cDiane.\u201d\n\nMr. Jones, whose forays into filmmaking have included documentaries like \u201cHitchcock/Truffaut,\u201d also won for best American narrative screenplay. \u201cDiane\u201d tells the story of a woman (Mary Kay Place) dealing with a dying cousin and an addicted son (played by Jake Lacy).\n\nThe festival also handed out acting awards to Jeffrey Wright, who stars in \u201cO.G.\u201d as an inmate about to be released after 24 years in prison, and Alia Shawkat, as one half of a couple determined to spend 24 uninterrupted hours together in \u201cDuck Butter.\u201d\n\nOther winners at the Tribeca festival included:\n\n\u2014 Gabrielle Brady, best documentary feature, for \u201cIsland of the Hungry Ghosts,\u201d which examines the refugee crisis against the backdrop of Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean.", "title": "Tribeca Film Festival Award Goes to New York Film Festival Director", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Generally it\u2019s assumed these viruses originate on the planet and are swept upward, but some researchers theorize that viruses actually may originate in the atmosphere. (There is a small group of researchers who believe viruses may even have come here from outer space, an idea known as panspermia.)\n\nWhatever the case, viruses are the most abundant entities on the planet by far. While Dr. Suttle\u2019s team found hundreds of millions of viruses in a square meter, they counted tens of millions of bacteria in the same space.\n\nMostly thought of as infectious agents, viruses are much more than that. It\u2019s hard to overstate the central role that viruses play in the world: They\u2019re essential to everything from our immune system to our gut microbiome, to the ecosystems on land and sea, to climate regulation and the evolution of all species. Viruses contain a vast diverse array of unknown genes \u2014 and spread them to other species.\n\nLast year, three experts called for a new initiative to better understand viral ecology, especially as the planet changes. \u201cViruses modulate the function and evolution of all living things,\u201d wrote Matthew B. Sullivan of Ohio State, Joshua Weitz of Georgia Tech, and Steven W. Wilhelm of the University of Tennessee. \u201cBut to what extent remains a mystery.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDo viruses even fit the definition of something alive? While they are top predators of the microbial world, they lack the ability to reproduce and so must take over the cell of a host \u2014 called an infection \u2014 and use its machinery to replicate. The virus injects its own DNA into the host; sometimes those new genes are useful to the host and become part of its genome.\n\nResearchers recently identified an ancient virus that inserted its DNA into the genomes of four-limbed animals that were human ancestors. That snippet of genetic code, called ARC, is part of the nervous system of modern humans and plays a role in human consciousness \u2014 nerve communication, memory formation and higher-order thinking. Between 40 percent and 80 percent of the human genome may be linked to ancient viral invasions.\n\nViruses and their prey are also big players in the world\u2019s ecosystems. Much research now is aimed at factoring their processes into our understanding of how the planet works.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you could weigh all the living material in the oceans, 95 percent of it is stuff is you can\u2019t see, and they are responsible for supplying half the oxygen on the planet,\u201d Dr. Suttle said.\n\nIn laboratory experiments, he has filtered viruses out of seawater but left their prey, bacteria. When that happens, plankton in the water stop growing. That\u2019s because when preying viruses infect and take out one species of microbe \u2014 they are very specific predators \u2014 they liberate nutrients in them, such as nitrogen, that feed other species of bacteria. In the same way, an elk killed by a wolf becomes food for ravens, coyotes and other species. As plankton grow, they take in carbon dioxide and create oxygen.\n\nOne study estimated that viruses in the ocean cause a trillion trillion infections every second, destroying some 20 percent of all bacterial cells in the sea daily.\n\nViruses help keep ecosystems in balance by changing the composition of microbial communities. As toxic algae blooms spread in the ocean, for example, they are brought to heel by a virus that attacks the algae and causes it to explode and die, ending the outbreak in as little as a day.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile some viruses and other organisms have evolved together and have achieved a kind of balance, an invasive virus can cause rapid, widespread changes and even lead to extinction.\n\nWest Nile virus has changed the composition of bird communities in much of the United States, killing crows and favoring ravens, some researchers say. Multiple extinctions of birds in Hawaii are predicted as the mosquito-borne avipoxvirus spreads into mountain forests where it was once too cold for mosquitoes to live.\n\nWhen species disappear, the changes can ripple through an ecosystem. A textbook example is a viral disease called rinderpest.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Italian army brought a few cattle into North Africa, and in 1887 the virus took off across the continent, killing a broad range of cloven-hoofed animals from Eritrea to South Africa \u2014 in some cases wiping out 95 percent of the herds.\n\n\u201cIt infected antelope, it infected wildebeest and other large grazers across the whole ecosystem,\u201d said Peter Daszak, the president of Ecohealth Alliance, which is working on a global project to catalog viruses likely to pass from animals to humans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe impact was not just on the animals. But because they are primary grazers and they died off in huge numbers, vegetation was impacted, and it allowed trees to grow where they would have been grazed away,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThe large acacia trees on the plains of Africa are all the same age and were seedlings when rinderpest first came in and the wildlife died,\u201d Dr. Daszak said. In other places, far less grazing created a hospitable habitat for the tsetse fly, which carries the parasites that cause sleeping sickness.\n\n\u201cThese kinds of ecological changes can last for centuries or even millennia,\u201d Dr. Daszak said.\n\nCombined with drought, large numbers of people died from starvation as rinderpest spread. An explorer in 1891 estimated two-thirds of the Masai people, who depended on cattle, were killed.\n\n\u201cAlmost instantaneously, rinderpest swept away the wealth of tropical Africa,\u201d wrote John Reader in his book \u201cAfrica: A Biography of a Continent.\u201d\n\nWith intensive vaccinations, rinderpest was completely wiped out, not only in Africa but globally in 2011.\n\nThe beneficial effects of viruses are much less known, especially among plants. \u201cThere are huge questions in wild systems about what viruses are doing there,\u201d said Marilyn Roossinck, who studies viral ecology in plants at Pennsylvania State University. \u201cWe have never found deleterious effects from a virus in the wild.\u201d\n\nA grass found in the high-temperature soils of Yellowstone\u2019s geothermal areas, for example, needs a fungus to grow in the extreme environment. In turn, the fungus needs a virus.\n\nTiny spots of virus on the plant that yields quinoa is also important for the plant\u2019s survival. \u201cLittle spots of virus confer drought tolerance but don\u2019t cause disease,\u201d she said. \u201cIt changes the whole plant physiology.\u201d\n\n\u201cViruses aren\u2019t our enemies,\u201d Dr. Suttle said. \u201cCertain nasty viruses can make you sick, but it\u2019s important to recognize that viruses and other microbes out there are absolutely integral for the ecosystem.\u201d", "title": "Trillions Upon Trillions of Viruses Fall From the Sky Each Day", "authors": ["Jim Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Let\u2019s take 67A, which runs through the center of the grid, as another example. \u201cNovice parasailor\u2019s fear?\u201d is the TERROR OF BAD GLIDINGS. If you scramble up that odd phrase you\u2019ll get a much more common and pleasant one \u2014 \u201cBearer of glad tidings.\u201d\n\nThis does seem sort of complicated, but all of the phrases are super straightforward and lend themselves well to this endeavor, and the spoonerisms are cute and read well themselves. The only one I didn\u2019t quite get was at 114A; it\u2019s based off \u201cFeel right at home,\u201d but I\u2019m missing something, I think, about the clue. It just doesn\u2019t check off that box, if you know what I mean.\n\nThere are actually a lot of examples of spoonerisms in comedy; there\u2019s a funny sketch by Ronnie Barker and a cute (but ribald \u2014 you\u2019ve been warned) routine by the Capitol Steps. There\u2019s also a George Carlin quote: \u201cDon\u2019t sweat the petty things and don\u2019t pet the sweaty things.\u201d \u009d\n\nOne tricky aspect to the themers is that they\u2019re done with respect to the sound rather than the spelling of their three words, which is apt since Reverend Spooner\u2019s foible was in his speech, not his writing. So for letter swaps, like one I used below, it would be sweater \u201clops\u201d rather than \u201claps\u201d to rhyme correctly with swap.\n\nTricky Clues\n\nSince the theme answers required deduction and deciphering, I think Mr. Berry went pretty easy on us with the rest of the puzzle. But of course no Sunday is truly a walk in the park. One thing to note is that the question mark was used on the spoonerisms, so if you\u2019re expecting to see one as a clue to any shenanigans elsewhere, you\u2019re not going to get it.\n\nThere was an interesting downward progression of SITAR to DOBRO to SIMBA to SNARE (although a \u201cSimba\u201d isn\u2019t a musical instrument, there are \u201cbaakisimba\u201d dances in Uganda so I call musical pattern). Other clues of note:\n\n28A: This clue refers to baseball. When a player tosses a ball in the air, then hits it with his own bat sort of like a tennis serve, it\u2019s called a FUNGO. The term has been around since the 1800s and is attributed to many sources, including a shuffling of \u201cgo have fun\u201d or an Americanization of an old Scottish term, \u201cfung,\u201d for fling. The fungo enables two people to practice, essentially, without a pitcher and catcher as well.\n\n37A: Most of the clues that stopped me today were tricky rather than out of my realm of knowledge, and I suspect that this punny clue intentionally has a twin among the downs, although it could be a coincidence. \u201cChill in the cooler\u201d doesn\u2019t mean put on ice, here, or not literally; it means to DO TIME, sit in the slammer, serve out a sentence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n74A: I got a bit sidetracked by this very general clue, \u201cCoarse,\u201d as \u201cgrainy\u201d fit well and seemed to make sense. In this case, coarse implies bawdy, or RIBALD, a fairly uncommon entry but a great word that seems very au courant these days. It can feel wrong to laugh through the pain sometimes, but it\u2019s good for us, even if we\u2019re not all dirty joke people.\n\n112A: I\u2019m including this fairly straightforward entry, \u201cBishop\u2019s headgear,\u201d in the hopes of saving people a few seconds on their solve times. I was more sure that the answer here was \u201cmitre\u201d than I was of both of those down crosses (FETA and ARABS, it turns out); the spelling called for here, MITER, is Americanized, but the two are pretty interchangeable, it seems.\n\n83D: \u201cRules for forming sentences,\u201d combined with the theme, put me down a grammatical pathway, something to do with objects, subjects and predicates. The sentence referred to here, though, is a punishment meted out by the PENAL CODE. This clue is a throwback, unused since 1960, and sort of goes hand and handcuff with 37A.\n\nThe Sunday Sherpa\n\nAfter all these sweater lops does your drain feel breeze-fried? Foot your peat up and take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the Crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Triple Spoonerisms", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNobody has been tougher on Russia, but getting along with Russia would be a good thing, not a bad thing,\u201d Mr. Trump said this week. By Friday, according to a White House statement, he had dropped any qualification. \u201cWe cannot allow those seeking to sow confusion, discord and rancor to be successful,\u201d Mr. Trump said.\n\nFriday\u2019s list targets Mr. Putin\u2019s inner circle. It imposes sanctions on a family member, his son-in-law, Kirill Shamalov, who has had close business ties to one of Mr. Putin\u2019s longtime friends from St. Petersburg, Gennady Timchenko. It also penalizes people like Vladimir Bogdanov, the director general of Surgutneftegas, a large privately owned oil company that has long been rumored, without solid evidence, to have given an ownership stake to Mr. Putin.\n\nThe list is an assault on one of the oligarchs\u2019 favored tools for avoiding sanctions, which is to pass assets to their children.\n\nIt targeted the oil executive Igor Rotenberg, the son of Arkady Rotenberg, who is a former judo partner of Mr. Putin and whose companies have won a host of state contracts, including one for the construction of a bridge from the Russian mainland to Crimea, the Ukrainian Black Sea peninsula seized by Moscow in 2014.\n\nAlso on the list is Oleg V. Deripaska, who once had close ties to Mr. Trump\u2019s former campaign manager, Paul Manafort. Altogether, the Trump administration targeted seven oligarchs, 12 companies they own or control, 17 Russian government officials and a state-owned arms export company.\n\n\u201cThis list sends a very clear signal to Putin himself that we\u2019re not afraid to go after your friends and their children,\u201d said Alina Polyakova, a Russia expert at the Brookings Institution. \u201cThere is some real thinking in this.\u201d\n\nRussia\u2019s Foreign Ministry promised a \u201charsh response\u201d and described Washington\u2019s increasing use of sanctions as economically anti-competitive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe sanctions have been under consideration for some time. A senior administration official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity said that they responded to Moscow\u2019s continuing and increasingly \u201cbrazen pattern of malign activity\u201d worldwide \u2014 especially against Western democracies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe Russian government operates for the disproportionate benefit of oligarchs and government elites,\u201d Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said. \u201cRussian oligarchs and elites who profit from this corrupt system will no longer be insulated from the consequences of their government\u2019s destabilizing activities.\u201d\n\nThe sanctions come just as investigators working for Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel looking into the possibility of collusion between the Trump campaign and Moscow, have begun to question Russian oligarchs about possible financial links between those in Mr. Putin\u2019s orbit and people close to Mr. Trump.\n\nFriday\u2019s penalties could be particularly painful for Mr. Putin\u2019s regime.\n\nWhile Russia\u2019s oligarchs make nearly all of their money in Russia, many stash their families, their lovers and much of their wealth in places like London, New York and Miami, where they are believed to own hundreds of millions of dollars in property. However, the economic strain is likely to be delayed, given that most on the list have already shielded their assets.\n\nTargeted sanctions against the oligarchs are seen as a particularly good way to punish Moscow\u2019s aggressive moves while sparing wider Russian society, which is already suffering under Mr. Putin\u2019s thumb.\n\nThe sanctions come just three days after Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, in his final speech as Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser, warned darkly about the growing Russian menace.\n\n\u201cFor too long some nations have looked the other way in the face of these threats,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cAnd we have failed to impose sufficient costs.\u201d\n\nThe new sanctions stem from legislation passed by Congress overwhelmingly last year and designed to limit Mr. Trump\u2019s ability to lift sanctions already imposed on Russia. Lawmakers in both parties feared that the president would suspend sanctions imposed by President Barack Obama as he pursued warmer relations with Moscow as promised during his campaign and first year in office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Trump administration opposed that legislation but quietly acceded to it after it passed with a veto-proof majority. Within that law was a measure requiring the administration to create a list of Russian oligarchs. Lobbying around the creation of the list became intense as Russia\u2019s wealthiest citizens feared punishing sanctions to come.\n\nThat is exactly what happened on Friday.\n\nThe sanctions list will only hasten the slide of Washington-Moscow relations. This week, 60 American diplomats left Russia as part of a tit-for-tat series of expulsions that followed last month\u2019s nerve-gas poisoning of Sergei V. Skripal, a former Russian double agent, and his daughter.\n\nMr. Skripal\u2019s poisoning on British soil prompted more than 20 countries to expel more than 100 Russian diplomats and intelligence officers, the largest such coordinated action ever. British officials believe that Mr. Skripal\u2019s poisoning, which occurred after an assassin smeared a nerve agent on the door handle of his home, was such a risky operation that it was unlikely to have been undertaken without approval from the Kremlin.\n\nRussia has denied involvement in the poisoning.\n\nBut the attack is seen as part of a pattern of increasingly aggressive moves by Mr. Putin, including the seizure of Crimea; military interventions in Georgia, Ukraine and Syria; tacit support for President Bashar al-Assad\u2019s chemical attacks on his own populace in Syria; a direct attack by Russian mercenaries on American troops in Syria; and the hacking of elections in the United States and Europe.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s responses to Mr. Putin\u2019s needling have been uneven. Although Congress gave the State Department $120 million in 2016 to counter Russian hacking efforts, the department has so far spent none of it. And Mr. Trump said this week that he wanted American forces to leave Syria soon, an exit that would benefit Iran, Russia and one of its allies, Mr. Assad.\n\nBut the administration has also imposed considerable economic penalties on Russia, with Friday\u2019s action the latest in a string of similar moves.\n\nNATO allies are now thinking anew about more coordinated responses to track and impose sanctions on Mr. Putin\u2019s cronies. Both Congress and the British Parliament are considering legislation that would require that the owners of companies and properties be disclosed.", "title": "Trump Administration Imposes New Sanctions on Putin Cronies", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "The new rules also move away from a requirement that most organizations receiving federal money choose from a list of approaches that have been shown in at least one rigorous evaluation to be effective at changing some sexual behavior, such as reducing pregnancy rates or rates of sexual activity.\n\nUnder Obama administration guidelines, organizations awarded most of the grants had to use curriculums that were on an evidence-supported list. Under the new guidelines, they simply have to comply with more general requirements like \u201csupport personal attitudes and beliefs that value sexual risk avoidance.\u201d\n\nJon Baron, vice president of evidence-based policy at the Laura and John Arnold Foundation, a nonpartisan foundation, said the new approach is like \u201cstarting from ground zero as if nothing has been learned. Until you have an evaluation of an actual program that people are showing up for and an actual curriculum and actual people teaching it, you really don\u2019t have reliable evidence.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAbstinence programs have often failed to change teenage sexual behavior. A 2007 study of four such federally funded programs, for example, found \u201cnot even a hint of an effect on sexual activity, pregnancy or anything,\u201d Mr. Baron said. Still, the Obama administration\u2019s menu of \u201cevidence-based programs\u201d included three abstinence programs.\n\nLast summer, the Health and Human Services Department told the 81 organizations that were receiving a total of $89 million a year from the agency that their five-year pregnancy prevention grants would end in June 2018, two years early. Several of the organizations sued to keep their funding, and last week, the first judge to rule on any of the cases decided that the South Carolina Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy was entitled to receive the rest of its five-year grant.\n\nProjects sponsored by the South Carolina organization, like most of those begun under the Obama administration\u2019s Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program, teach about contraception and sexually transmitted diseases in addition to abstinence, and at least one of the South Carolina programs received federal permission to supply condoms in places like a bowling alley and barbershops.\n\nOn Monday, Beth De Santis, chief executive of the South Carolina Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy, said she hopes the new rules will allow for the types of comprehensive sex education programs that her organization has found effective.\n\nFederal officials are now \u201cvery much into avoiding sex altogether,\u201d Ms. De Santis said. \u201cThat is something that has been very clear from this administration and they\u2019re not making a secret of that.\u201d\n\nBut, she continued, she hopes her organization\u2019s programs will comply with the new administration\u2019s definition of \u201csexual risk reduction.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur next step will be to work with them on whether or not they agree that some of the programs that we already have can be approved,\u201d she said. \u201cI do think they have given us an opportunity to find a way to continue to do the work we do.\u201d", "title": "Trump Administration Pushes Abstinence in Teen Pregnancy Programs", "authors": ["Pam Belluck"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Delays in delivering weapons systems have long been an irritant to foreign governments and domestic manufacturers, and almost every administration in the modern era has tried to fix the process. Top aides in the Trump White House have frequently called officials at the State Department and the Pentagon to try to hurry things along.\n\nBut the deals can pose an array of challenges, involving not only national security issues, such as the transfer of sensitive technologies, but also economic ones. India, the world\u2019s largest weapons buyer, often requires defense firms to build weapons in India in partnership with Indian firms, the kind of requirements that the Trump administration finds objectionable in China with regard to cars and other products.\n\nThe biggest change announced on Thursday involves the sale of larger armed drones like the Predator and the Reaper, which have been the workhorses of the fight against insurgents in Afghanistan and the tribal regions of Pakistan. President Barack Obama embraced the weapons but was also so troubled by such remote warfare tools that he placed unusual restrictions on their sale.\n\nThose restrictions have allowed drone makers in Israel, China and Turkey to capture a large part of a market that American manufacturers had pioneered, something the Trump administration wants to reverse.\n\nThe new drone export policy \u201cwill level the playing field by enabling U.S. firms to increase their direct sales to authorized allies and partners,\u201d Peter Navarro, assistant to the president for trade and manufacturing policy, said in a news briefing on Thursday. He added, \u201cThis will keep our defense industrial base in the vanguard of emerging defense technologies while creating thousands of additional jobs with good wages and generating substantial export revenues.\u201d\n\nMr. Navarro noted that at last year\u2019s Paris Air Show, Chengdu Aircraft Industry Group of China showed off its Wing Loong II, a medium-altitude long-endurance drone that he described as a knockoff of General Atomics\u2019 Reaper. He said the market for such aircraft was expected to be $50 billion annually within a decade.\n\nUnder the old policy, only Britain, France and Italy were approved to purchase armed drones, according to Dan Gettinger, co-director of the Center for the Study of the Drone at Bard College.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs more countries are approved, \u201cthe risk is that countries may be more willing to use military force when they can do so without risking their own people,\u201d Mr. Gettinger said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSales of smaller, unarmed drones have fewer restrictions, and American manufacturers dominate the market for those, Mr. Gettinger said.\n\nThe newly announced changes in the policy governing which countries can purchase sophisticated American-made weapons, known as the Conventional Arms Transfer Policy, instruct the government to take domestic economic concerns into greater account than it has in the past.\n\nThe new policy also says that consideration should be given to minimizing civilian casualties. That could potentially justify sales of \u201csmart\u201d bombs, which are easier to direct to specific targets.\n\nBut experts said that the changes are not likely to have much effect on sales.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s political posturing,\u201d said Rachel Stohl, managing director of the Stimson Center, a think tank focusing on foreign policy. \u201cWe already sell to almost everybody in the world. Are we really going to open markets to places like Iran and North Korea now? I don\u2019t think so.\u201d\n\nHuman rights advocates denounced the changes as loosening rules they viewed as already too permissive. John Sifton, an advocacy director at Human Rights Watch, said that some of the changes were intended to make questionable arms sales easier to conduct.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be easier to give licenses in cases like Saudi Arabia, which has a history of launching military strikes that harm huge numbers of civilians,\u201d Mr. Sifton said.\n\nThe Obama administration was also enthusiastic about foreign weapons sales, which soared during its tenure. Direct weapons sales declined in the first year of the Trump administration from the year before and are now roughly half the level seen in 2011, the first full year of the Arab Spring.\n\nThe policy changes were announced two days after a hearing on Capitol Hill during which senators from both parties expressed anguish at the vast humanitarian crisis in Yemen, caused in part by Saudi Arabia\u2019s use of American weapons.\n\n\u201cMaybe part of the humanitarian answer is supplying less weapons to a war,\u201d Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said during the hearing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA bipartisan group of senators has proposed legislation that would require the State Department to routinely certify that Saudi Arabia is taking steps to end the suffering there, the sort of review that slows weapons purchases. The Trump administration opposes the legislation.", "title": "Trump Administration Seeks to Expand Sales of Armed Drones", "authors": ["Gardiner Harris"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cNow we could \u2014 the easiest thing for me to do would be just to close my eyes and forget it,\u201d Mr. Trump said on WABC Radio\u2019s \u201cBernie & Sid in the Morning\u201d show.\n\n\u201cIf I did that, I\u2019m not doing my job. So, I\u2019m not saying there won\u2019t be a little pain, but the market\u2019s gone up 40 percent, 42 percent \u2014 so we might lose a little bit of it \u2014 but we\u2019re going to have a much stronger country when we\u2019re finished. And that\u2019s what I\u2019m all about. We have to do things that other people wouldn\u2019t do.\u201d\n\nMr. Mnuchin said on Friday that a correction was normal after such a long stretch of rising stock prices. He insisted that Mr. Trump\u2019s trade policy would be good for economic growth and that he was not concerned about daily declines in stocks.\n\n\u201cI think these are all long term positive things that the president is willing to defend our interests,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said.\n\nHe added that he continued to be optimistic that a mutually beneficial agreement could be worked out.\n\n\u201cI think this could be good for us and good for them,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump, in a tweet on Friday, criticized both China and the World Trade Organization, saying that the Chinese \u201cget tremendous perks and advantages, especially over the U.S. Does anybody think this is fair. We were badly represented. The WTO is unfair to U.S.\u201d\n\nThat followed another early morning tweet, in which Mr. Trump boasted that the new metals tariffs he has put into effect on China and other nations had not hurt American consumers as his critics predicted.\n\nThe price of aluminum per pound has been falling since February, a decline that started before the tariffs were imposed. Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to exempt Canada, which supplied more than half of America\u2019s aluminum imports in 2016, has also helped to soften the blow from tariffs, companies say.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president\u2019s criticism of the World Trade Organization is not new \u2014 many of his top advisers have complained that its process for reviewing and resolving trade disputes has put the United States and Western countries at a disadvantage.\n\nBut the United States has said it will take its complaint about Chinese trade practices, including the tactics it uses to gain access to American intellectual property, to the global body as part of the sweeping trade action the White House announced last month. That White House investigation found that China cheats the United States out of $50 billion annually through pressure and other coercive measures aimed at gaining access to American technology.\n\nOn Friday morning, the White House issued an additional statement defending the president\u2019s actions.\n\n\u201cYear after year, China continues to distort global markets and harm U.S. businesses and consumers with unfair trade practices,\u201d the press office said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe president is for free trade, but it must also be fair trade. Addressing unfair trade practices and ensuring that global trade is free, fair, and reciprocal will have a significant positive long-term impact on the U.S. economy,\u201d the statement said.\n\nBut the approach has come under swift and stinging criticism from lawmakers of both parties, as well as industries whose businesses depend on access to China\u2019s markets.\n\nSenator Heidi Heitkamp, a Democrat from North Dakota, called Mr. Trump\u2019s actions \u201creckless,\u201d saying in a tweet that 60% of her state\u2019s exports to China are agricultural products. \u201cChina\u2019s unfair trade policies need to be reined in but this isn\u2019t the way to do it.\u201d\n\nIn his statement on Thursday, Mr. Trump said he had instructed the agriculture secretary to implement a plan to protect farmers and agricultural interests. It is unclear what that plan could entail, but Chad Bown, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said that if the president chose to subsidize farmers, he could spark a wider conflict with countries beyond China, which would object to unfair competition from American agriculture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhite House trade advisers have described the tariff threats as a long overdue action against a pernicious cheater in global trade, saying China has long engaged in pressure, coercion and outright theft to gain access to valuable intellectual property. Yet the escalating threat of a trade war between the world\u2019s two largest economies has unnerved many American businesses that depend on China as a source for goods or as a market for their own products.\n\nGlobal markets were cautiously lower on Friday, following a volatile week in which markets plunged on the president\u2019s initial trade threats, then recovered as his advisers said the trade move was mostly a negotiating tool and might not even go into effect.\n\nChina was celebrating a national holiday Friday and did not immediately announce any concrete action against the president\u2019s threat of an additional $100 billion in tariffs. A spokesman said the Chinese Ministry of Commerce had \u201ctaken note\u201d of the White House\u2019s statement, adding that \u201cthe Chinese position has been made very clear. We do not want to fight, but we are not afraid to fight a trade war.\u201d\n\nIf the United States follows through with its threats, the Chinese \u201cwill follow suit to the end and will not hesitate to pay any price,\u201d he said, arguing that the United States initiated the conflict.\n\nIn the meantime, the trade measures ignited a swift response from manufacturers, retailers and politicians from states whose economies depend on agriculture. Although China exports far more to the United States than it imports, China is still the United States\u2019 third largest export market after Canada and Mexico, a vital destination for American-made goods like Boeing airplanes, luxury automobiles and soybeans.\n\n\u201cHopefully, the president is just blowing off steam again, but if he\u2019s even half-serious, this is nuts,\u201d Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, said on Thursday. \u201cLet\u2019s absolutely take on Chinese bad behavior, but with a plan that punishes them instead of us. This is the dumbest possible way to do this.\u201d\n\nThe National Retail Federation criticized the new round of tariffs as a dangerous game of chicken ending with the United States on the losing end of a trading relationship that has benefited American companies and consumers.\n\n\u201cThis is what a trade war looks like, and what we have warned against from the start. We are on a dangerous downward spiral, and American families will be on the losing end,\u201d Matthew R. Shay, the president and chief executive of the retail group, said in a statement. \u201cWe urge the administration to change course and stop playing a game of chicken with the nation\u2019s economy.\u201d", "title": "Trump Aims New Threat at China as Mnuchin Warns of Trade War", "authors": ["Ana Swanson", "Eileen Sullivan"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump has said far less about the situation with Ms. Clifford. His first major interview, with ABC News, is scheduled to be broadcast Sunday night, though the network began airing clips Friday morning after the book leaked out.\n\nHe will have several other high-profile appearances in Washington, followed by events at bookstores in Chicago, Seattle, San Francisco, Miami, Los Angeles and other cities. At each, Mr. Comey\u2019s observations about the president\u2019s behavior and character are certain to generate headlines.\n\nThe Republican National Committee is organizing television and radio bookings for people appearing to rebut Mr. Comey during the tour. But there\u2019s a lot of people I know who don\u2019t agree with me on that.\u201d\n\nAnger from Democrats toward Mr. Comey cascaded across social media on Friday. In an extraordinary day of testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee the next month, he foreshadowed many of the themes of his book, describing how Mr. Trump had tried to derail an investigation of Michael T. Flynn, who served briefly as national security adviser and accused the president of lying and defaming him and the F.B.I.\n\nThe former F.B.I. chief\u2019s much-anticipated 304-page memoir is the first major memoir by one of the key characters in the Trump administration.\n\nSome of the moments that Mr. Comey describes in the book were already publicly known: He describes a January 2017 dinner where he said that Mr. Trump asked him for a loyalty pledge, an episode that was reported by multiple news organizations last year. Shear", "Alexander Burns"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Jackson called the allegations false and had the support not just of Mr. Trump but also of some former aides to President Barack Obama who said they had never observed the alleged behavior while they worked in the White House. A search of government databases turned up no incident that matched that description, the White House said.\n\nThree cases were found involving Dr. Jackson and a government vehicle, according to the White House: In one, he was rear-ended. In another, a bus sideswiped a mirror on his car. Nomination", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump was at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., last year when he ordered missile strikes in Syria in response to a chemical attack by government forces. And in 2011, President Barack Obama went ahead with a trip to Brazil while American forces were striking Libya. But White House officials argued that Mr. Trump felt strongly about remaining on United States soil as the situation in Syria unfolded.\n\nThe decision appeared to have taken even some senior White House officials by surprise. Mr. Trump\u2019s top economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, was unaware of the president\u2019s new plans when he told a conservative radio host on Tuesday morning that he would be traveling with Mr. Trump to Latin America this week. He said Mr. Trump would be able to \u201ccompartmentalize.\u201d\n\nThere were plenty of reasons for Mr. Trump to dread the trip to South America, which promised to include considerable behind-the-scenes friction and little of the flattering pomp and ceremony that he relishes \u2014 and to which he was treated during visits last year to Saudi Arabia and China.\n\nThe president\u2019s approval rating in Latin America is extraordinarily low, and leaders there have been insulted by his anti-immigrant talk and alarmed by his threats to use military force in Venezuela. The White House had already scaled back Mr. Trump\u2019s trip, trimming what was initially intended as a five-day visit to one that involved fewer than three days on the ground.\n\nMr. Trump had planned to use that brief time to seek consensus on how to handle the crisis in Venezuela and press his case for better trade deals with Latin American nations. The president\u2019s advisers had played down expectations for major advances during the trip, including saying it was unlikely to produce any breakthroughs on the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nThey had left open the question of whether Mr. Trump would meet with President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto of Mexico, with whom he has had a stormy relationship. The two have clashed on the phone over Mr. Trump\u2019s promises to build a border wall and force Mexico to pay for it, and the latest such altercation led them to cancel a tentatively planned visit by Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto to the White House in March.\n\nMore recently, Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto has taken umbrage at Mr. Trump\u2019s decision last week to send National Guard troops to patrol the southern border.", "title": "Trump Cancels Trip to Latin America, Citing Crisis in Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "But the president\u2019s speech gave no indication that he will in fact respect his decision last year to remain faithful to the 1973 law. Worse yet, in his follow-up, the defense secretary, James Mattis, advanced a much more aggressive position, asserting that \u201cthe president has the authority under Article II of the Constitution to use military force overseas to defend important U.S. national interests.\u201d\n\nThis is precisely the view notoriously advanced by John Yoo during the early years of President George W. Bush\u2019s administration. If Mr. Trump fails to notify Congress, as required by the 1973 statute, he will be repudiating his own precedent and embracing an extreme position that even Mr. Bush rejected during the second term of his administration. To be sure, Mr. Yoo made his sweeping claims to defend the commander in chief\u2019s authority to torture terrorists, while Mr. Mattis is making Yoo-like arguments to support the noble cause of suppressing chemical warfare. But once Mr. Mattis\u2019 sweeping assertion of presidential power is accepted, it will be used as a precedent by Mr. Trump to ignore the War Powers Resolution whenever he, and he alone, is persuaded that \u201cimportant national interests\u201d justify future military adventures.\n\nDefenders of presidential war-making back up their position by claiming that Congress has abdicated its constitutional responsibility to serve as the ultimate arbiter over war and peace. But this is false. In passing its omnibus appropriations bill only last month, Congress was careful to provide that \u201cnone of the funds made available by this Act may be used with respect to Syria in contravention of the War Powers Resolution, including for the introduction of United States armed or military forces into hostilities in Syria.\u201d\n\nCongress even more recently responded to Mr. Trump\u2019s military escalation in the Middle East by reinvigorating its authority under the War Powers Resolution. Its reassertion of war-making power was provoked by Mr. Trump\u2019s unilateral military support for Saudi Arabia\u2019s war against the Houthi rebels in Yemen. Earlier this month, a bipartisan senatorial coalition invoked a special provision of the War Powers Resolution to force a floor vote condemning Mr. Trump\u2019s action. While this motion was returned to the Foreign Relations Committee by a margin of 55 to 44, it was only after the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Bob Corker, promised to consider legislation this week that could limit the president\u2019s war-making authority against Islamic militants.\n\nMr. Corker should rapidly follow through on his commitment if Mr. Trump fails to provide Congress the required notice under the War Powers Resolution. If Mr. Corker hesitates, members of the Senate and the House should fill the gap, and follow the example recently set in the Yemen case. This not only allows them to invoke a special provision of the resolution to force a timely vote on Mr. Trump\u2019s Syrian campaign; it also prevents any efforts to filibuster or delay their initiative, since the War Powers Resolution requires a final vote \u201cwithin three calendar days\u201d after members have forced their motion onto the floor of each house.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Can\u2019t Make War Whenever He Likes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 Lawyers representing the Trump Organization in a bitter dispute over management control of a luxury hotel in Panama City appealed directly to President Juan Carlos Varela of Panama to intercede.\n\nIn the March 22 letter, the Panamanian law firm Britton and Iglesias told Mr. Varela that it was writing \u201cto request in an URGENT manner\u201d his intervention in the clash involving the Trump International Hotel and Tower.\n\nThe letter acknowledged the \u201cseparation of powers\u201d in Panama but cautioned the president that the matter \u201chas repercussions for the Panamanian state, which is your responsibility.\u201d\n\nAt the time, the Trump Organization\u2019s hotel management team had been evicted from the hotel but was still fighting to regain control. Several days after the letter was sent, an arbitrator ruled against the Trump company\u2019s request that its management be reinstated.", "title": "Trump Company Lawyers Asked Panama President for Help in Hotel Dispute", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Trump could have been referring to OPEC\u2019s cutback in exports to increase prices. Saudi Arabia and other oil producers in the region have also made an alliance of convenience with Russia, a non-OPEC member heavily dependent on oil revenues to finance its government. Together they have restrained production since 2016, reducing global stockpiles.\n\n\u201cPrices are high,\u201d said Rob West, an analyst at Redburn, a London research firm. Noting that Mr. Trump may have a point, he added, \u201cI do see some artificiality in the prices we see today.\u201d\n\nOPEC and non-OPEC producers gathered Friday in the Saudi city of Jidda in an effort to continue the policy even as the price of Brent crude, the global benchmark, has climbed above $70.\n\nNot long ago, as prices plummeted from over $100 a barrel in 2014 to below $30 in early 2016, inventories were so high that tankers were needed to hold excess supplies. Now, even as United States oil production continues to grow, worldwide inventories are declining, increasing the pressure on prices. The International Energy Agency reported that global oil supply eased by 120,000 barrels a day in March.\n\nThe price of crude is the major reason American drivers are paying more at the pump as the summer driving season approaches. The average price for a gallon of regular gasoline on Friday was $2.75 a gallon, according to AAA, up 19 cents over the last month and 33 cents from a year ago. It is the highest level since the summer of 2015.", "title": "Trump Criticizes OPEC, Calling Oil Prices \u2018Artificially\u2019 High", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump on Saturday criticized a report by The New York Times that described his years of poor treatment of his longtime personal lawyer, Michael D. Mr. Trump concluded that they were unnecessary because Moscow\u2019s response to the airstrike was mainly bluster, the official said.\n\nRussia analysts said the whipsaw policy shift once again highlighted an administration struggling to find a coherent and consistent voice in dealing with Russia, which in the past four years has annexed Crimea, intervened in eastern Ukraine, sought to influence the American election in 2016, allegedly poisoned a former Russian spy living in Britain and propped up the murderous government of President Bashar al-Assad in Syria.\n\nMr. Trump has mostly spoken hopefully of his efforts to forge a friendship with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, including congratulating him on a re-election widely denounced as a sham and even suggesting a White House meeting. At the same time, the Trump administration has imposed two rounds of sanctions against Russia in the last month, expelled 60 of Moscow\u2019s diplomats and closed a consulate in retaliation for the poisoning attack in Britain.\n\n\u201cTrump seems to think that if he accepts what his advisers recommend on even days of the month and rejects their recommendations on odd days, the result will be a strategy,\u201d said Stephen Sestanovich, a scholar at the Council on Foreign Relations and Columbia University who served as ambassador to former Soviet states in the 1990s.\n\n\u201cBy and large, other governments don\u2019t know whether to laugh or cry at all this,\u201d Mr. Sestanovich said. \u201cBut in Russia, laughter is getting the upper hand.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump was annoyed with Ms. Haley for getting out in front of the policy, the administration official said, and the president\u2019s decision to reject sanctions left her hanging in public with her credibility on the line.\n\nMs. Haley has been one of the strongest critics in the administration of Russia\u2019s behavior around the world, often speaking far more harshly than Mr. Trump would, but she has rarely been reined in publicly this way. She made no comment on Monday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAdministration officials said new sanctions could still be imposed at some point if Russia takes further action justifying them.\n\nBut absent such a scenario, the officials could not explain how Mr. Trump would make Russia pay a \u201cbig price\u201d for enabling Syria\u2019s use of chemical weapons, as he promised to do last week after a suspected gas attack killed more than 40 people and sickened scores more outside Damascus on April 7.\n\nThe strike against Syria that Mr. Trump announced late Friday in Washington was limited to a single night and to three targets linked to chemical weapons facilities. It sought to punish President Bashar al-Assad of Syria for the suspected gas attack but avoid provoking Russia into a response.\n\nRussian forces stationed in Syria have helped Mr. Assad gain the upper hand in the country\u2019s seven-year civil war.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Comey, the former F.B.I. director fired by Mr. Trump last year, in which he said he thought \u201cit\u2019s possible\u201d that the president had been compromised by Russia. A protester waiting for Mr. Trump in Florida on Monday held a large banner that read, \u201cRussian stooge.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump has heatedly and repeatedly denied any collusion with Russia during his 2016 campaign, calling such suggestions a \u201choax\u201d perpetrated by Democratic sore losers desperate to explain an election defeat.\n\nRussia did not respond militarily to the Friday strike, but American officials noted a sharp spike in Russian online activity around the time it was launched.\n\nA snapshot on Friday night recorded a 2,000 percent increase in citing the hashtag #isupportsyria on Russian troll networks, according to a senior official at the Department of Homeland Security who was not authorized to discuss the issue by name and spoke on condition of anonymity. Additionally, the official said, the known Russian hashtag #SyriaStrikes had a 4,443 percent increase in activity while another, #Damsucs, saw a 2,800 percent jump.\n\nIn hitting the Barzah Research and Development Center, a chemical weapons research lab in greater Damascus, and two storage facilities and bunkers near Homs, Pentagon officials insisted that they dealt a critical blow to Mr. Assad\u2019s weapons program. But Friday night\u2019s strike, delivered via 105 missiles, was not quite double the 59 missiles used last year when Mr. Trump ordered the military to strike a Syrian airfield from which planes engaged in another chemical weapons attack took off.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis pushed hard to limit the strikes to proven weapons facilities in the hopes that a more limited strike would not prompt retaliation from Russia.\n\nThe lab at Barzah, in Damascus, was on the receiving end of the biggest barrage \u2014 some 76 missiles, a combination of Tomahawk cruise missiles and Joint air-to-surface missiles. The rest of the bombs \u2014 29, fired by American, French and British warplanes \u2014 struck and destroyed the Him Shinshar chemical weapons storage facility near Homs, and the Him Shinshar chemical weapons bunker facility around five miles away.\n\nSyria tried to hit back, but by the time its air defense system was deployed, the American warplanes were on their way home and the war ships had completed their mission, military officials said. They disputed Syrian claims to have shot down dozens of American missiles.\n\n\u201cWe assess that over 40 surface-to-air missiles were employed by the Syrian regime,\u201d Lt. Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie, director of the Joint Staff at the Pentagon, told reporters on Saturday. \u201cMost of these launches occurred after the last impact of our strike was over.\u201d\n\nHe called the Syrian retaliatory missiles \u201clargely ineffective\u201d and said they \u201cclearly increased risk to their own people based on their indiscriminate response \u2014 when you shoot iron into the sky without guidance, it will inevitably fall to earth.\u201d", "title": "Trump Declines to Add Sanctions Against Russians, Contradicting Haley", "authors": ["Peter Baker"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration, which has been on the verge of a trade war with China, opted on Friday not to label the country a currency manipulator, breaking a key campaign promise by President Trump to punish a government he has called the \u201cgreatest currency manipulators ever.\u201d\n\nThe Treasury Department, in its biannual currency exchange report, scolded China for its lack of progress in reducing the bilateral trade deficit with the United States, but did not find that it was improperly devaluing its currency, known as the renminbi.\n\n\u201cTreasury is strongly concerned by the lack of progress by China in correcting the bilateral trade imbalance and urges China to create a more level and reciprocal playing field for American workers and firms,\u201d the report said.\n\nIt was the third time since Mr. Trump assumed the presidency that the Treasury Department opted not to accuse China of improper meddling. China has long maintained a strong grip on the value of its currency and, for years, weakened it compared with the dollar to make Chinese products cheaper to sell in the United States and other countries. More recently, China has made a big show of gradually loosening its grip, an effort meant to mollify critics like Mr. Trump and experts who have long urged Beijing to let markets fix financial problems in the world\u2019s second-largest economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChina had a $375 billion trade surplus in goods last year, the largest of any of America\u2019s trading partners. That gap has become a frequent target of Mr. Trump\u2019s, who has cited the trade deficit with China as a main reason for his administration\u2019s aggressive approach, including the tariffs and investment restrictions he has threatened.", "title": "Trump Declines to Label China a Currency Manipulator as Trade War Brews", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport", "Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The president\u2019s comments on Thursday could create a predicament for him and his legal team. By saying he was not aware of the agreement, Mr. Trump appeared to confirm that argument, which would mean neither party is legally bound by it, thus potentially paving the way for Ms. Clifford to break her silence without consequences.\n\nMs. Clifford\u2019s pugnacious lawyer, Michael J. Avenatti, quickly issued a statement to respond to Mr. Trump\u2019s claim. That move was a direct reaction to the tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods that the White House detailed on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cRather than remedy its misconduct, China has chosen to harm our farmers and manufacturers,\u201d Mr. Trump said, adding that he had instructed the United States trade representative to determine whether tariffs on an additional $100 billion in goods were warranted and, \u201cif so, to identify the products upon which to impose such tariffs.\u201d\n\nThe announcement came one day after some of Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers tried to calm markets and tamp down fears of a trade war between the world\u2019s two largest economies, saying that the tariff threats were the first step in a negotiation process. Mr. Trump said in his statement that the potential for new tariffs would not preclude discussions with the Chinese \u201cto protect the technology and intellectual property of American companies and American people,\u201d but any new tariffs are unlikely to make that already tough task easier.", "title": "Trump Doubles Down on Potential Trade War With China", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump has instructed his military commanders to quickly wrap up the American military operation in Syria so that he can bring troops home within a few months, senior administration officials said on Wednesday. He dropped his insistence on an immediate withdrawal, they said, after commanders told him they needed time to complete their mission.\n\nThe president\u2019s decision to keep the 2,000 troops on the ground in Syria for the immediate future came in a meeting of the National Security Council in the White House Situation Room on Tuesday, hours after Mr. Trump had told a roomful of reporters that \u201cit\u2019s time\u201d to bring American forces home from a conflict that has been a crucial battlefield in the fight against the Islamic State.\n\nAt the meeting, Mr. Trump\u2019s top military advisers told him they had drawn up plans to pull American troops out of Syria immediately. But they also presented a plan for the forces to stay longer to clean out the residual pockets of Islamic State fighters and to train local forces to stabilize the liberated territory so that the group could not regain a foothold.\n\n\u201cHow long do you need to do that?\u201d the frustrated president asked Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford, according to an official present for the exchange.", "title": "Trump Drops Push for Immediate Withdrawal of Troops From Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe United States has never been closer to potentially having something happen with respect to the Korean Peninsula, that can get rid of the nuclear weapons, can create so many good things, so many positive things, and peace and safety for the world,\u201d he declared during a joint news conference with the president of Nigeria, Muhammadu Buhari.\n\nMr. Trump added a familiar caveat that the whole effort could still fall apart. But as talk of a Nobel Peace Prize for the president has begun \u2014 stirred both by South Korea\u2019s president, Moon Jae-in, and by chanting supporters at a weekend rally in Michigan \u2014 the president clearly senses that a history-making achievement is within his grasp.\n\nHe briskly dismissed a question about whether ripping up the Iran nuclear deal \u2014 as many believe he will do when he faces the next deadline of May 12 to act on it \u2014 would jeopardize the prospects for an agreement with North Korea to give up its nuclear weapons.\n\n\u201cI think it sends the right message,\u201d he said.\n\nThe president acknowledged that some on his staff had qualms about holding the meeting in the Demilitarized Zone. For weeks, the White House had played down that option, in part because aides did not like the optics of Mr. Trump traveling to Mr. Kim\u2019s doorstep. Instead, they have discussed sites as far-flung as Singapore, Vietnam, Mongolia and even a Navy warship anchored in the Pacific.\n\nBut all that was before the vivid images last Friday of Mr. Kim greeting Mr. Moon at the line of demarcation between North and South, and then sitting down with him in the Peace House.\n\nSouth Korea built the three-story, gray-stone edifice in the border village of Panmunjom to hold meetings with officials from the North. For years, American officials, including Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, have stopped there during their visits to the Demilitarized Zone. But Mr. Trump missed his chance to visit it during his trip to South Korea last November when heavy fog forced his helicopter to turn around shortly before he was to land.\n\n\u201cSome people maybe don\u2019t like the look of that, and some people like it very much,\u201d the president said. \u201cThere\u2019s something I like about it, because you\u2019re there, if things work out, there\u2019s a great celebration to be had on the site, not in a third-party country.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Demilitarized Zone has other advantages. The Secret Service is used to securing the site for presidents, and security could be an issue in other countries, like Mongolia, while there are questions about Mr. Kim\u2019s ability to travel long distances, given the rickety condition of his aircraft. Singapore is safe and politically inoffensive, but it is still 3,074 miles from Pyongyang.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
