(LAT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChina hits back at U.S. tariffs\n\nThe Chinese government said on Monday that it would place tariffs on the imports of 128 American-made products in retaliation for to President Trump\u2019s tariffs on steel and aluminum.\n\nBeijing appeared to go a step beyond its initial threat, Chris Buckley reported. On the list is pork, an important moneymaker in many states that voted for President Trump.\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Mr. Trump tweeted on Sunday that there would be no deal to protects thousands of young immigrants brought to the country as children and threatened to walk away from the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\n\u2022 The FirstEnergy bankruptcy could be an important moment for the Trump administration and its commitment to the coal industry. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Ties to the White House have proven to be a wellspring of trouble for the Kushner family. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Are undersea cables used to communicate around the world under risk of attack? (AP)\n\n\u2022 The bankruptcy of Remington, one of the country\u2019s oldest gunmakers, has stalled a ruling in a lawsuit by family members of those killed in the Sandy Hook shooting. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Would firing special counsel Robert Mueller lead to impeachment proceedings? (NYT)\n\n\u2022 John Bolton, the incoming national security adviser, has argued repeatedly that the United States should engage in cyber warfare. (Politico)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Live Nation flexes its ticketing muscles\n\nWhen the Justice Department allowed Live Nation to merge with Ticketmaster, it tried to assuage concerns that the deal would cripple competitors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut critics have reason to be skeptical. Here\u2019s how Beau Buffier, the chief of the New York Attorney General\u2019s Antitrust Bureau, described Live Nation:\n\n\u201cIt is now widely seen as the poster child for the problems that arise when enforcers adopt these temporary fixes to limit the anticompetitive effects of deeply problematic vertical mergers.\u201d\n\nThe Justice Department is looking into complaints that Live Nation has used its control over concert tours to pressure venues into contracting with Ticketmaster, a possible violation of antitrust law.\n\nThe inquiries come as the department is reviewing two more mergers, between AT&T and Time Warner, and Disney and Fox.\n\nThe department\u2019s new antitrust chief has said that the Live Nation deal and several other deals posed problems because they relied too much on the federal government\u2019s ability to police corporate behavior.\n\n\u201cEven if we wanted to do that, we often don\u2019t have the skills or the tools to do so effectively,\u201d the antitrust chief, Assistant Attorney General Makan Delrahim, said in a speech.\n\nMore for your playlist\n\nSpotify\u2019s shares begin trading on Tuesday with a valuation that could exceed $20 billion. But the company still hasn\u2019t turned a profit, and its direct listing could spook investors. The streaming service also is looking to take on music labels directly by \u201cbuilding a two-sided marketplace for users and artists.\u201d\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Walmart\u2019s takeover of Humana isn\u2019t guaranteed, but hospitals are already worried that the deal could hit their bottom lines at a difficult time. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Protectionist policies are increasing barriers to deal making. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Looking to merge asset management divisions, UBS is asking for discounts from fund managers. (FT)\n\nThe speed read\n\n\u2022 The corporate raider Samuel Belzberg has died at 89. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Steve Schwarzman has discovered that $25 million doesn\u2019t necessarily buy naming rights for a public high school. (The Philadelphia Inquirer)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The South China Morning Post has long been Hong Kong\u2019s English-language paper of record. Alibaba has made it part of Beijing\u2019s efforts to project soft power abroad. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The accrediting council at center of a for-profit college fraud scandal is looking for a comeback. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Coffee sellers are trying to fight a California judge\u2019s ruling that would require the beverage to carry cancer warning labels. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Bill Gross is struggling to attract investors to Janus Henderson. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Nike is reviewing its human resources department after employees raised concerns about pay equity and corporate culture. He told reporters that federal authorities had \u201cbroke in to the office\u201d and he called it \u201ca disgraceful situation\u201d and \u201ca total witch hunt.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Trump told Mr. McGahn in June to have Mr. Mueller fired, the president cited a series of conflict-of-interest issues that he insisted disqualified the special counsel from overseeing the investigation. Among the issues Mr. Trump cited was a dispute Mr. Mueller had with Mr. Trump\u2019s Washington-area golf course years earlier. Mr. Trump told Mr. McGahn to tell Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general and Mr. Mueller\u2019s superior, that the time for Mr. Mueller to go had come.\n\nMr. McGahn believed those issues were not grounds for Mr. Mueller to be fired and refused to call the Justice Department.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOver the next couple of days, Mr. Trump pestered Mr. McGahn about the firing, but Mr. McGahn would not tell Mr. Rosenstein. The badgering by the president got so bad that Mr. McGahn wrote a resignation letter and was prepared to quit. It was only after Mr. McGahn made it known to senior White House officials that he was going to resign that Mr. Trump backed down.\n\nThe articles that provoked Mr. Trump\u2019s anger in December \u2014 which were published by Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal and Reuters \u2014 said one of Mr. Mueller\u2019s subpoenas had targeted Mr. Trump\u2019s and his family\u2019s banking records at Deutsche Bank. Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers, who have studied Mr. Trump\u2019s bank accounts, did not believe the articles were accurate because Mr. Trump did not have his money there.\n\nThe lawyers were also able to learn that federal prosecutors in a different inquiry had issued a subpoena for entities connected to the family business of Mr. Trump\u2019s son-in-law, Jared Kushner. The news outlets later clarified the articles, saying that the subpoena to Deutsche Bank pertained to people affiliated with Mr. Trump, who was satisfied with the explanation and dropped his push to fire Mr. Mueller.\n\nThe White House did not respond to an email seeking comment.\n\nAcutely conscious of the threat Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation poses, Mr. Trump has openly discussed ways to shut it down. Each time, he has been convinced by his lawyers and advisers that taking the step would only exacerbate his problems. In some cases, they have explained to Mr. Trump how anything that causes him to lose support from congressional Republicans could further imperil his presidency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s statements to his advisers have been significant enough to attract attention from Mr. Mueller himself. Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have interviewed current and former White House officials and have requested documents to understand whether these efforts show evidence the president is trying to obstruct the Justice Department\u2019s investigation, according to two people briefed on the matter.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s frustrations have tended to flare up in response to developments in the news, especially accounts of appearances of witnesses, whom Mr. Trump feels were unfairly and aggressively approached by investigators. They include his former communications director, Hope Hicks, and his former campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski.\n\nThe venting has usually been dismissed by his advisers, many of whom insist they have come to see the statements less as direct orders than as simply how the president talks, and that he often does not follow up on his outbursts.\n\nOne former adviser said that people had become conditioned to wait until Mr. Trump had raised an issue at least three times before acting on it. The president\u2019s diatribes about Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Mr. Rosenstein and the existence of the special counsel have, for most of the White House aides, become a dependable part of the fabric of life working for this president.", "title": "Trump Sought to Fire Mueller in December", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Michael S. Schmidt"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. He issued an executive order late Thursday creating a task force to \u201cconduct a thorough evaluation\u201d of the Postal Service\u2019s operations and finances, including the \u201cexpansion and pricing of the package delivery market.\u201d\n\nIn repeated jabs on Twitter, Mr. Trump has accused Amazon, the e-commerce giant that is the Postal Service\u2019s largest single shipper of packages, of being a drain on the 242-year-old agency.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut on a single day in December \u2014 Monday, Dec. 18 \u2014 the post office delivered more than 37 million packages, a record.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Total mail volume, which has been slipping for years, depressed in part by email, was down by 2 billion pieces, or 5 percent.", "title": "Trump Targets a Postal Service Rainmaker: Package Delivery", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Trump Tower does have a system of smoke sensors, and they activated an alarm that automatically was routed to the Fire Department, according to a department official.\n\nA sensor in the building\u2019s ductwork detected smoke and an alarm was sent to the Fire Department at 5:35 p.m. Saturday, according to the official, who asked not to be named in order to talk about an investigation that was still in the preliminary stages.\n\nFirefighters arrived at the Fifth Avenue building, where President Trump has a triplex, four minutes later. Investigators believe the blaze may have started as an electrical fire in the apartment bedroom, the official said.\n\nIn the meantime, the building staff saw the alarm had been triggered and one or more employees went to the 50th floor to investigate. They noticed smoke coming from apartment 50C and opened the door, the official said, but the smoke and fire were already too intense for them to enter the apartment and try to save the owner, Todd Brassner.\n\nThe official said that there was no working smoke alarm in the apartment, such as the type of battery-powered alarms that homeowners typically install.\n\nMr. Brassner, 67, died from burns and smoke inhalation, the official said.\n\nThe head of the Real Estate Board of New York, an industry association, pushed back against the call to retrofit older buildings with sprinklers. \u201cThe City\u2019s Building Code has proven to be effective at significantly preventing fires in high rise multifamily housing or limiting their impact to a single residential unit in a building,\u201d John H. Banks, the board\u2019s president, said in an emailed statement. The statement listed obstacles to a blanket order to retrofit, such as cost and lack of adequate water supply in many buildings to operate a sprinkler system.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Brassner was an art dealer and a collector who had become something of a recluse in recent years, according to friends. He had a collection of about 100 vintage electric guitars, 150 ukuleles, and artwork by artists such as Andy Warhol and Robert Indiana. The official said that all the contents of the apartment were destroyed in the fire.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fire was contained to Mr. Brassner\u2019s apartment, but there was significant smoke and water damage in the building as a result of the fire and the efforts to fight it. The official said that smoke reached the building\u2019s upper floors where Mr. Trump\u2019s triplex is, but did not cause damage.\n\nResidents of the building said that no alarm went off to alert tenants of the emergency. Miles Fisher, an engineer who designs fire alarm systems, said that is standard protocol. He said that residents in fireproof high-rise apartment buildings like Trump Tower are instructed to remain in their apartments in case of fire elsewhere in the building and place wet towels at the base of their doors to keep smoke out.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMiriam Light, 67, a commercial and residential landlord who lives on the 39th floor of Trump Tower, said that she learned about the fire only when her father called from Florida while watching it on the news. She said that she left the building and returned later to find no damage to her apartment.\n\nShe praised the Trump Tower staff but said that it was time for the building to improve its fire safety system, including the addition of sprinklers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the 21st century,\u201d Ms. Light said. \u201cNobody has to lose their life. The system should be updated. Whatever it takes, it should be improved.\u201d\n\nMichael Tobias, a mechanical engineer who works with fire safety systems, called for a law requiring older residential buildings to install sprinklers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very big gap in New York fire safety,\u201d he said.\n\nYash Dongre, 27, said he lives in an apartment directly under Mr. Brassner\u2019s unit.\n\nHe said he was home at the time of the fire and when he smelled smoke he decided to rush down the 49 flights of stairs. He said that he heard an alarm from the floor above.\n\n\u201cI could see the smoke filling up in my apartment because the building has a central ventilation system because the windows are sealed. The smell came through the ventilation system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think every apartment should have sprinklers but I also understand this is an old building.\u201d\n\nMr. Brassner bought the apartment for $525,000 in 1996, according to city records. He had financial problems over the years, and as early as 2003 the building\u2019s condominium board placed a lien on the apartment for failure to pay common charges, according to city records.\n\nIn 2013, city records show that a lien was removed from the apartment after Mr. Brassner paid $21,668 in arrears and fees.\n\nFriends said that Mr. Brassner wanted to sell his apartment, but there is no record of the apartment having been listed with a broker.", "title": "Trump Tower Smoke Sensors Alerted Firefighters to Deadly Blaze", "authors": ["William Neuman"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mexico\u2019s Foreign Ministry and Interior Ministry, in a statement issued jointly late Monday, said the authorities had already deported 400 participants in the caravan since the event began more than a week ago, but confirmed that they were offering protections to the migrants \u201cin cases where this is appropriate.\u201d\n\n\u201cUnder no circumstances does the Mexican government promote irregular migration,\u201d the statement said.\n\nMr. Mensing said that processing details were still being worked out between government officials and the caravan organizers, but warned that should the process take too long, \u201cit\u2019s very possible that the caravan will reignite.\u201d\n\nThe migrant group left the southern Mexican border town of Tapachula on March 25, at that point numbering about 700. Most of the participants were from Honduras and many of them said they were fleeing violence and poverty in their home countries, organizers said. Some say they were inspired to flee Honduras following the violent suppression of political protests that erupted after last year\u2019s presidential election.\n\nOver the past week, the group grew in size, to about 1,200 by the time it arrived in Mat\u00edas Romero.\n\nBut organizers said that contrary to the vision of a migrant onslaught on America conjured by Mr. Trump, most participants do not intend to travel as far as the border of the United States.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s trying to paint this as if we are trying to go to the border, and we\u2019re going to storm the border,\u201d Mr. Mujica said.\n\nMr. Mensing added: \u201cWe\u2019re definitely not looking for some kind of showdown.\u201d\n\nIn an interview Monday, before negotiations between the Mexican immigration authorities and the caravan organizers began, Mr. Mujica predicted that at most 10 percent to 15 percent of the participants would seek asylum at the American border.", "title": "Trump Transforms Immigrant Caravans in Mexico Into Cause C\u00e9l\u00e8bre", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The president later told reporters aboard Air Force One that he intended to deploy 2,000 to 4,000 National Guard troops to the border with Mexico. If Mr. Trump sends the low end of his proposal, it would barely exceed the 1,200 sent by President Barack Obama in 2010 to support other border agencies. Even if Mr. Trump sends 4,000, the top end of his proposal, he would be dispatching fewer than President George W. Bush did in 2006.\n\nIn a statement on Thursday, the Pentagon press secretary, Dana White, said that the National Guard troops would focus on engineering, logistical support and vehicle maintenance among other things. The statement did not mention the troops taking part in law enforcement.\n\nRepublican leaders have urged the president to sell the tax cut that he signed in December, and have tried to make economic growth and low taxes the central theme of 2018 as they move toward a difficult midterm election season. But Mr. Trump has refused to keep to the script.\n\nInstead on Thursday, he opted to blast immigrants and the country\u2019s immigration laws, including a practice known as \u201ccatch and release,\u201d in which migrants who present themselves at the border are released from custody to await an immigration hearing to determine whether they should be allowed to remain in the United States.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re toughening up at the border,\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cWe cannot let people enter our country \u2014 we have no idea who they are, what they do, where they came from.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t know if they\u2019re murderers, if they\u2019re killers, if they\u2019re MS-13,\u201d Mr. Trump went on. \u201cWe\u2019re throwing them out by the hundreds.\u201d\n\nHe boasted that he had described immigrants as rapists when he announced his presidential candidacy, saying that he had recently learned that during the journey north made by a caravan of Honduran migrants, \u201cwomen are raped at levels they\u2019ve never seen before.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump also said his administration had cracked down on MS-13, the transnational gang with links to El Salvador, detailing its brutal methods.\n\n\u201cThis is the kind of stuff and crap that we\u2019re allowing into our country, and we can\u2019t do it,\u201d Mr. Trump said.\n\nHe also repeated his false claim that millions of people voted illegally in the 2016 election.\n\n\u201cThey always like to say, \u2018Oh, that\u2019s a conspiracy theory,\u2019\u201d Mr. Trump said. \u201cNot a conspiracy theory, folks. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s remarks drew enthusiastic applause from an audience of about 200 in a state that he won with 68 percent of the vote, his largest margin of victory in the country.\n\nBut it also drew rebukes.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump is insulting American voters by making up lies,\u201d said Jason Kander, a former Democratic candidate for the Senate and now the president of Let America Vote, a voting rights group. \u201cPresident Trump\u2019s lies cause the American electorate to lose faith in our system of elections and take our elections less seriously, which is one of his goals. If people don\u2019t trust that their vote counts, then they won\u2019t vote.\u201d\n\nThe round table on taxes was a lovefest for the president, in which attendees took turns praising him and recounting the ways in which the tax measure and Mr. Trump\u2019s agenda had helped them and their families.\n\n\u201cThis is a big deal for our family,\u201d Jessica Hodge said, choking back tears after her husband told Mr. Trump that their family had saved $2,417 because of the tax cut. He said they planned to spend it on a kitchen renovation.\n\n\u201cThank you for listening to us. Thank you for fighting for us,\u201d she added.\n\nThe president grinned and nodded his approval.\n\nEvan Jenkins, a West Virginia House member, and Patrick Morrisey, the state\u2019s attorney general \u2014 who are competing in a May primary to run for the Senate \u2014 flanked Mr. Trump and took turns showering him with praise.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re a man keeping your promises,\u201d Mr. Jenkins said. \u201cThanks for keeping your promise.\u201d\n\nMr. Morrisey chimed in. \u201cYour policies really have made an incredible difference in our state,\u201d he said, adding, \u201cWe had the bull\u2019s-eye on us until you got here, so thank you for that.\u201d\n\nAs he wrapped up the event, Mr. Trump asked the audience to weigh in on which man should win the primary next month.\n\n\u201cShould we do a little test?\u201d he said. \u201cWho\u2019s voting for Patrick? Who\u2019s voting for Evan?\u201d\n\nThe applause was loudest for Mr. Jenkins, who represents the district that White Sulphur Springs is in.\n\nMr. Trump also attacked Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, saying that he had opposed tough immigration laws and the rest of the president\u2019s agenda.\n\n\u201cI thought he would be helpful because he talks,\u201d Mr. Trump said of Mr. Manchin, a centrist who is known for seeking compromises with Republicans. \u201cBut he votes against everything, and he voted against our tax cuts.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Trump spent little time promoting the tax measure he had come to celebrate, he seemed to feed off the adulation of his crowd and relish his detour off-script. Speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One as he returned to Washington, the president asked how the event had gone.\n\nGreeted with silence, Mr. Trump answered his own question, saying he was \u201cvery happy.\u201d\n\n\u201cThought it was really great,\u201d he added.", "title": "Trump Veers From Tax Script to Blast Democrats on Immigration", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Ever since Donald J. Trump began his improbable political rise, many pundits have credited his appeal among white, Christian and male voters to \u201ceconomic anxiety.\u201d Hobbled by unemployment and locked out of the recovery, those voters turned out in force to send Mr. Trump, and a message, to Washington.\n\nOr so that narrative goes.\n\nA study published on Monday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences questions that explanation, the latest to suggest that Trump voters weren\u2019t driven by anger over the past, but rather fear of what may come. White, Christian and male voters, the study suggests, turned to Mr. Trump because they felt their status was at risk.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s much more of a symbolic threat that people feel,\u2019\u2019 said Diana C. Mutz, the author of the study and a political science and communications professor at the University of Pennsylvania, where she directs the Institute for the Study of Citizens and Politics. \u201cIt\u2019s not a threat to their own economic well-being; it\u2019s a threat to their group\u2019s dominance in our country over all.\u201d\n\nThe study is not the first to cast doubt on the prevailing economic anxiety theory. Last year, a Public Religion Research Institute survey of more than 3,000 people also found that Mr. Trump\u2019s appeal could better be explained by a fear of cultural displacement.", "title": "Trump Voters Driven by Fear of Losing Status, Not Economic Anxiety, Study Finds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Thomas P. Bossert, Mr. Trump\u2019s homeland security adviser, said he and the rest of the president\u2019s national security team had been in talks with Mr. Trump late Saturday and early Sunday about how to respond. Asked specifically about the possibility of a missile strike, Mr. Bossert did not rule it out.\n\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t take anything off the table,\u201d Mr. Bossert said on ABC\u2019s \u201cThis Week.\u201d \u201cThese are horrible photos; we\u2019re looking into the attack at this point.\u201d\n\nThat raised the prospect of a strike along the lines of one that the president ordered almost exactly a year ago after a sarin gas attack in Khan Sheikhoun that killed more than 80 civilians. In that strike, the United States military dropped 59 Tomahawk missiles on the Al Shayrat airfield, where the chemical weapons attack had originated.\n\nMr. Trump may be considering such a strike even as he has expressed his desire in recent days to pull American troops out of Syria, where they are seeking to eliminate the last vestiges of the Islamic State. White House officials said Mr. Trump would have a meeting and dinner on Monday at the White House with senior military leaders.\n\nNikki R. Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, announced an emergency meeting there on Monday to demand immediate access to Douma for emergency workers, urge an independent investigation of the massacre, and \u201chold accountable those responsible for this atrocious act.\u201d\n\nThe assault on Douma and the president\u2019s response also showed how Syria has bedeviled Mr. Trump just as it did his predecessor, repeatedly presenting them with grave challenges and few good options for confronting them.\n\nIt was not clear on Sunday whether his tweets reflected serious planning for a military strike, or if the suspected chemical attack had changed the president\u2019s calculation about the necessity for a rapid wind-down of American military involvement in Syria. A White House official said he could provide no guidance beyond what the president had said on Twitter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut some Republicans urged Mr. Trump to act, saying his talk of pulling United States troops out of Syria had telegraphed to Mr. Assad that he would pay no price for brutalizing his own people.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump last week signaled to the world that the United States would prematurely withdraw from Syria,\u201d Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said in a statement, adding that Mr. Assad had been \u201cemboldened by American inaction\u201d to launch the attack in Douma.\n\n\u201cThe president responded decisively when Assad used chemical weapons last year,\u201d Mr. McCain went on. \u201cHe should do so again, and demonstrate that Assad will pay a price for his war crimes.\u201d\n\nSenator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said Mr. Trump should make good on what the president appeared to be threatening.\n\nIf the president \u201cdoesn\u2019t follow through and live up to that tweet, he\u2019s going to look weak in the eyes of Russia and Iran,\u201d Mr. Graham said on \u201cThis Week.\u201d \u201cThis is a defining moment.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou need to follow through with that tweet,\u201d he added. \u201cShow a resolve that Obama never did to get this right.\u201d\n\nIn his tweets, Mr. Trump also criticized former President Barack Obama for failing to take military action against Mr. Assad\u2019s government when it used chemical weapons in 2013. Mr. Obama had threatened that any use of unconventional weapons would cross a \u201cred line\u201d for the United States.\n\nAt the time, though, Mr. Trump argued fiercely against American intervention in Syria. In more than a dozen messages on Twitter in 2013 and 2014, he argued that the nation\u2019s civil war was \u201cnot our problem\u201d and that American troops should \u201cstay out.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday, Mr. Trump\u2019s tweets came not long after a report on Fox News about the massacre in Douma, in which an anchor said that \u201call eyes\u201d would now be on the president\u2019s response, and that the airstrikes last year had \u201cgarnered praise\u201d from American allies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe timing of the tweets alarmed some progressives who warned that Mr. Trump might make military decisions based on commentary on his favorite cable news outlet.\n\n\u201cIf Trump should launch missiles, it is because Fox and Friends told him to,\u201d VoteVets, a group that focuses on military issues and is aligned with Democrats, said on Twitter. \u201cWe cannot possibly overstate how insane and disastrous for command of our military that would be.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn a statement on Saturday night, the State Department called the situation in Douma an \u201calleged chemical weapons attack\u201d and said the reports about it were \u201chorrifying and demand an immediate response by the international community.\u201d\n\nThe statement took Moscow to task, saying it had breached international obligations and calling into question its commitment to weapons nonproliferation.\n\n\u201cThe Assad regime and its backers must be held accountable and any further attacks prevented immediately,\u201d it said. \u201cRussia, with its unwavering support for the regime, ultimately bears responsibility for these brutal attacks, targeting of countless civilians and the suffocation of Syria\u2019s most vulnerable communities with chemical weapons.\u201d\n\nBut while members of his administration have often been harshly critical of Mr. Putin, Mr. Trump has in general spoken warmly of his Russian counterpart.\n\nAmerican officials said the process was underway to confirm whether the Syrian government had used chemical weapons and, if so, what kind.\n\nSince last April\u2019s strike on the airfield, the Pentagon has updated lists of potential Syrian military and government targets should Mr. Trump order another strike.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA senior Navy officer said on Sunday morning that Navy warships capable of firing cruise missiles were in the Mediterranean on routine, long-scheduled deployments but had not received any orders to prepare to move closer to Syria or to prepare to carry out any strikes.\n\nBefore last year\u2019s strike, American commanders at the sprawling Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar \u2014 the United States\u2019 air war command for the region \u2014 gave their Russian counterparts a warning of no more than 90 minutes before striking the Syrian airfield. The Americans did this under a \u201cdeconfliction\u201d agreement with Moscow to try to prevent an unintended confrontation between the two countries.\n\nAt a daily operations briefing on Sunday at the air command center, there was no indication of an imminent operation, said one official who was briefed on the meeting. \u201cThings can change pretty quickly, though,\u201d the official cautioned, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal deliberations.\n\nIndeed, only 63 hours passed between last April\u2019s chemical attack and the American cruise missile strike.", "title": "Trump Vows \u2018Big Price\u2019 for Syria Attack, Raising Prospect of Missile Strike", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "I asked Robert Sampson, a sociologist at Harvard, about the link between Trump\u2019s roots in Queens and his policies as president. Sampson replied by email: \u201cMy immediate reaction is that it was no accident that \u2018All in the Family\u2019 was set in Queens,\u201d Sampson wrote, just as Steve Bannon used to say about his former boss, \u201cDude, he is Archie Bunker.\u201d\n\nSampson pointed out the connection between Trump\u2019s roots in Queens and the themes he has stressed as a candidate and as president:\n\nThe explosion of immigration and the racial change in the makeup of Queens might have left an especially deep imprint, because his constant references to making America great again evoke an earlier time that was considerably less diverse. Indeed, building walls and stemming the tide of such change seems to be at the heart of Trump\u2019s appeals to a remembered national past, and in this case, of his childhood.\n\nSampson cited the\n\nstrong link research has found between perceptions of disorder and the presence of immigrants and minorities \u2014 independent of actual disorder and crime \u2014 provides another clue, one that applies to neighborhoods and arguably up to the level of societies.\n\nJennifer Richeson, a psychologist at Yale, emailed me about her perception that \u201cshifting demographics of one\u2019s town can certainly engender more negative intergroup attitudes and perception.\u201d\n\nIn a forthcoming paper summarizing research on the effect of growing diversity on white attitudes, \u201cThe Pitfalls and Promise of Increasing Racial Diversity,\u201d Richeson, Maureen A. Craig, and Julian M. Rucker, psychologists at N.Y.U. and Yale, write:\n\nWhites for whom the changing national diversity is salient express (a) more support for conservative policies, including those relevant to race; (b) less support for diversity; (c) more racial resentment and support for the Tea Party; and (d) more support for Donald Trump and anti-immigrant policies.\n\nTrump has long since departed Queens, along with more than 900,000 other whites, many of whom became recruits for his presidential campaign. His administration is in many respects an attempt to restore the Queens of his early childhood.\n\nAnthony Scaramucci, a friend of the president\u2019s who served 10 days as the White House communications director, grasped Trump\u2019s outer borough appeal to many voters. In a recent interview with Ed Luce of The Financial Times, Scaramucci argued that Trump understood that \u201cAmerica\u2019s \u2018aspirational\u2019 working class had become \u2018desperational\u2019.\u201d\n\nDuring the campaign, Scaramucci recounted, Trump \u201cwould say to us: \u2018That tweet\u2019s not for you. You\u2019re probably offended by it. I don\u2019t care. That tweet is for the guy in the flyover states, at the steel plant. If I lose some of the effete Republican elite, what difference does it make?\u2019 \u201d\n\nLuce reports the story of Trump telling foreign investors that his casinos would be flooded by \u201cwhite trash.\u201d What did he mean by \u201cwhite trash,\u201d the investors asked.\n\nTrump replied: \u201cThey\u2019re people just like me, only they\u2019re poor.\u201d\n\nTrump is nothing if not consistent in his appeal to this constituency.\n\nAs recently as April 5, in an appearance in West Virginia, Trump repeated his description of migrants from Mexico as rapists and alleged that \u201cmillions and millions\u201d of undocumented immigrants voted against him in the 2016 election.", "title": "Opinion | Trump Wants America to Revert to the Queens of His Childhood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m not sure he\u2019s really being well served,\u201d said Fred P. Hochberg, the most recent chairman of the bank, who departed in 2017. \u201cIf you want to be able to reduce trade deficits and you want to be able to export more, particularly capital goods, that\u2019s what an Export-Import Bank does.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, the bank has been barely functional. According to its most recent annual report, Ex-Im authorized just $3.4 billion of mostly short-term export credit in 2017. That is down from the $20 billion that it authorized in 2014, the last year that the bank was fully operational. The report points out that China provided $34 billion in medium- and long-term financing for its exports in 2016, underscoring the competitive disadvantage that the United States faces.\n\nThe bank\u2019s crippling has been costly for both companies and their workers, including Boeing, which Mr. Trump has hailed as an emblem of American innovation. In the last two years, two deals involving the sale of its commercial satellites have been canceled and one was significantly delayed given the lack of a quorum at Ex-Im. The stalling of these deals alone has cost the company hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\n\u201cRestoring the Export-Import Bank to full strength is the single best thing Washington can do right now to build on the economic momentum of tax reform, shrink our trade deficits and level the playing field so American workers can win,\u201d said Tim Keating, Boeing\u2019s executive vice president for government operations.\n\nIn 2015, General Electric said that it would stop manufacturing certain gas engines in Waukesha, Wis., and that it would instead build a $265 million plant in Canada, which was offering financial support through its version of Ex-Im, known as Export Development Canada. G.E. attributed the move to the lack of United States export financing, saying in a statement that the company \u201cwill secure access to Canadian Export Finance to fill the gap from the lapse of the U.S. Export-Import Bank.\u201d", "title": "Trump Wants to Close Trade Gap, but Leaves Export Agency in Limbo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Heavily backed by Russian air support and Iranian ground forces, Syria is in a different league than adversaries in other places where the United States is at war. Unlike the Islamic State in various parts of the Middle East, the Taliban in Afghanistan or the Shabab in Somalia, the Syrian government has extensive air defense and missile systems capable of shooting down foreign planes.\n\nSending bombers and fighter jets, with American or French pilots, to strike Syrian airfields or other facilities is considered risky because it could deepen the conflict if a pilot was shot down. That is why the Pentagon is looking at the same sort of retaliation used last year when two Navy destroyers unleashed a fusillade of 59 Tomahawk cruise missiles at Al Shayrat airfield that was believed to have been used to launch chemical attacks.\n\nBut less than 24 hours after that strike, Syrian warplanes were again taking off from the damaged airfield, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, a monitoring group. Beyond Al Shayrat base, Syria still had numerous others from which it could launch flights. While Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers argued last year that the strike affected Mr. Assad\u2019s calculations, in the end its limited nature ultimately did not thwart the Syrian government\u2019s ability to launch chemical attacks.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a tension between the desire to do something bigger than last time and the president\u2019s clear desire not to stay engaged in sustained operations,\u201d said Mich\u00e8le A. Flournoy, an under secretary of defense under President Barack Obama. \u201cConceivably, they could design a larger one-off strike or a series of smaller strikes.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut at the end of the day, it\u2019s sustained pressure on Assad that\u2019s going to change his calculation about whether to use chemical weapons,\u201d Ms. Flournoy said.\n\nDavid F. Gordon, policy planning director at the State Department under President George W. Bush, said Mr. Trump was almost certainly looking to punish Mr. Assad more severely while limiting American engagement.\n\n\u201cWhat they\u2019re probably searching for is: What can we destroy that weakens this guy?\u201d Mr. Gordon said. \u201cHe has to do more than he did last time, and I think he does want to disrupt their capabilities. But I think it\u2019s basically still the one shot \u2014 it may be in two waves or something, but I don\u2019t think there\u2019s an ongoing response to this.\u201d", "title": "Trump Weighs More Robust Military Strike Against Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 As trade tensions with China escalate, President Trump has found new appeal in a regional trade pact he once called a \u201crape of our country.\u201d\n\nThe pact\u2019s members \u2014 including some of America\u2019s most stalwart allies \u2014 might not make it so easy to come back.\n\nOfficials in Japan, Australia and New Zealand reacted coolly on Friday to Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks that he would be interested in joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership after rejecting it so publicly just a year ago. While the United States would significantly bolster the pact if it signed up, its entry would require intense negotiations \u2014 and current members will expect significant concessions from the American side.\n\nComparing the multicountry trade agreement to \u201ca glasswork,\u201d Yoshihide Suga, Japan\u2019s chief cabinet secretary, cautioned against any efforts to change it to accommodate Mr. Trump.", "title": "Trump Weighs Return to Trans-Pacific Partnership. Just a few hours after the announcement on Friday, the president tweeted about the \u201cFake News Media\u201d and said, \u201cso much of the media is dishonest and corrupt!\u201d\n\nAmid his and his press office\u2019s antagonistic relationships with the news media, the president did not attend the annual gala last year either. But Mr. Trump pressed his complaint that the trade relationship between the United States and Europe was \u201cunfair,\u201d and Ms. Merkel made clear that the president had not made the commitment she was seeking \u2014 permanently exempting the European Union from the steel and aluminum tariffs he imposed in March.\n\n\u201cWe need a reciprocal relationship, which we don\u2019t have,\u201d Mr. Trump said, standing beside Ms. Merkel at a news conference in the ornate East Room of the White House. \u201cThe chancellor and I have discussed it today at length, and we\u2019re working on it. Advisers urged him to hold off, and he gave them five to six months to complete a withdrawal.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. mission has not changed \u2014 the president has been clear that he wants U.S. forces to come home as quickly as possible,\u201d Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said in a statement Sunday night. \u201cWe are determined to completely crush ISIS and create the conditions that will prevent its return. Giuliani dressed down the owner of a ferret.", "title": "Trump to Skip Correspondents\u2019 Dinner. But Talk Radio? He\u2019s In.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The law was meant to protect the state\u2019s natural resources, Mr. Becerra said. \u201cOur public lands should not be on the auction block to the highest bidder,\u201d he said in a statement.\n\nThe administration\u2019s legal arguments are substantial, drawing on the Constitution and the law under which California was admitted to the Union.\n\nArticle IV of the Constitution, which is concerned with the relationship between the federal government and the states, includes the Property Clause: \u201cThe Congress shall have power to dispose of and make all needful rules and regulations respecting the territory or other property belonging to the United States.\u201d\n\nAnd the 1850 law admitting California to the Union, making it the 31st state, was explicit: \u201cCalifornia is admitted into the Union upon the express condition that the people of said State, through their legislature or otherwise, shall never interfere with the primary disposal of the public lands within its limits, and shall pass no law and do no act whereby the title of the United States to, and right to dispose of, the same shall be impaired or questioned.\u201d\n\nProfessor Levinson said her preliminary assessment of the suit was that \u201cit looks like the federal government has quite a strong argument.\u201d\n\nBut Prof. Michael Blumm, who teaches at Lewis and Clark Law School in Portland, Ore., said \u201cit isn\u2019t clear why the federal government claims it\u2019s not possible to recognize a right of first refusal and carry out its other obligations.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cIsn\u2019t there some irony in a D.O.J. headed by an ardent states-rightser, Jeff Sessions, arguing for federal pre-emption of state authority under the Property Clause?\u201d", "title": "Trump v. California: The Biggest Legal Clashes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nSome of President Trump\u2019s attacks on the justice system are well-known, like his firing of the F.B.I. director and his angry tweets about federal judges and the Russia investigation. But others have stopped getting much attention, because of how common they\u2019ve become.\n\nTrump is treating the Justice Department in a way that no other recent president has. He is repeatedly trying to undermine the rule of law. Again and again, he has shown that he views the law as an instrument of power rather than justice.\n\nMy column today tells the story of our modern rule of law \u2014 how it came to be in the post-Watergate period, thanks to two stellar attorneys general, and how Trump is threatening it now. I hope that the rest of us, and especially Trump\u2019s fellow Republicans, will respond with the appropriate alarm and strength.", "title": "Opinion | Trump vs. Justice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "To a large degree, he appears to be making policy from the podium, responding to the propaganda organ Fox News and bouncing ideas off a small circle of loyalists. His cabinet and the White House are left to respond to what Trump says on the fly and develop that into a quasi-coherent policy.\n\nThis is no way to run a country, unless your intention is to run it into the ground.\n\nThis is now the American quandary: The wheels of government are being forced to turn on the erratic whims of an egomaniac.\n\nThis is a man relying more on emotion than government intelligence or personal intelligence. Everything with Trump is about grit and gut, sensing the energy of the room, the crowd, the aching masses, and saying whatever he thinks will energize and animate them, anything that will cause them to suspend disbelief and vest faith in a sham.\n\nNothing need be true. Nothing need be effective policy. Nothing need be rooted in data. The only requirement is that he says whatever he says with conviction and that he commands unending fidelity from those who have already abandoned all principle to stand with him.\n\nBut a man with Trump\u2019s gaping insecurity and consuming fear is not a person who can be a stable steward of the national trust and the national interest.", "title": "Opinion | Trump, Driven by Fear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump on Friday hailed the historic summit meeting between the leaders of North Korea and South Korea, and declared that in his own planned talks with the North he would not be fooled the way he said his predecessors had been on dismantling its nuclear weapons program.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think he\u2019s playing,\u201d Mr. Trump said of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, speaking with reporters in the Oval Office before a meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.\n\n\u201cThe United States has been played beautifully, like a fiddle, because you had a different kind of a leader,\u201d Mr. Trump went on. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to be played, O.K.? We\u2019re going to hopefully make a deal; if we don\u2019t, that\u2019s fine.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump spoke after a groundbreaking meeting between Mr. Kim and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea in the Demilitarized Zone between the North and South. The two leaders agreed to work to remove all nuclear weapons from the Korean Peninsula and, within a year, pursue talks with the United States to declare an official end to the Korean War, which raged from 1950 to 1953.", "title": "Trump, Hailing Korean Talks, Says He Won\u2019t Be Hoodwinked by North", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "While the service has consistently reported net losses for a decade, much of its financial woes are the result of a prolonged decline in the volume of marketing mail and first-class mail. The service makes money on packages, and Amazon is the service\u2019s biggest single shipper of packages.\n\nBut the president has refused to believe those arguments, insisting in a tweet as recently as March 31 that \u201cthe U.S. Post Office will lose $1.50 on average for each package it delivers for Amazon.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat amounts to Billions of Dollars,\u201d he continued.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s repeated attacks on Amazon have focused in part on the company\u2019s billionaire owner, Jeff Bezos, who also owns The Washington Post. People close to Mr. Trump have said the president\u2019s tirades against the retailer often come after The Post has published negative articles about him.\n\n\u201cThe #AmazonWashingtonPost, sometimes referred to as the guardian of Amazon not paying internet taxes (which they should) is FAKE NEWS!\u201d he wrote last June.\n\n\u201cIs Fake News Washington Post being used as a lobbyist weapon against Congress to keep Politicians from looking into Amazon no-tax monopoly?\u201d he wondered the next month.\n\nAt one point last month, Amazon\u2019s stock price tumbled after Mr. Trump\u2019s tweets and a suggestion that he might direct the government to take action against the company.\n\nDrew Herdener, an Amazon spokesman, declined to comment late Thursday.\n\nBut until Thursday night, Mr. Trump had limited his attacks to ones on Twitter. The White House had said the president did not have immediate plans to take any action against Amazon and had given no warning that the executive order was coming.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the order, the president calls on the task force to examine various parts of the Postal Service\u2019s business, including ones that appear to directly involve large parts of Amazon\u2019s business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat includes the \u201cexpansion and pricing\u201d of the package delivery market and the service\u2019s role in competing with other, private delivery companies. The task force should look at the decline in mail volume and the implications for the service, Mr. Trump said.\n\nThe order also calls for the task force to look at the service\u2019s \u201cuniversal service obligation,\u201d which requires the service to deliver to everyone in the United States, given changes in technology and e-commerce.\n\nSome parts of the order appear to hint at further privatization of the Postal Service, indicating that members of the task force should examine \u201cthe U.S.P.S. role in the U.S. economy and in rural areas, communities, and small towns.\u201d\n\nIn the order, Mr. Trump said that the longstanding financial problems at the Postal Service demand some kind of action.\n\n\u201cA number of factors, including the steep decline in First-Class Mail volume, coupled with legal mandates that compel the U.S.P.S. to incur substantial and inflexible costs, have resulted in a structural deficit,\u201d Mr. Trump says in the order. \u201cThe U.S.P.S. is on an unsustainable financial path and must be restructured to prevent a taxpayer-funded bailout.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear how quickly the task force will be assembled, or when its review might result in changes at the Postal Service that could directly affect Amazon and other shippers.\n\nIn May, Mr. Trump created a similar commission to examine what he said was evidence of large-scale voter fraud in the 2016 election \u2014 a claim that was repeatedly debunked by election experts from both major political parties.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he dissolved the commission in January after several legal challenges and a lack of cooperation from Democratic and Republican election officials in a number of states.\n\nIn the case of the Postal Service order on Thursday night, Mr. Trump demanded that a report of findings be delivered to him by summer\u2019s end. He urged the task force to recommend administrative and legislative changes that could be made.\n\nThose recommendations could take into account previous studies, including a 2017 analysis by Citigroup, which concluded that the service was charging below market rates for package delivery.\n\nThe report estimated that if the service increased its parcel rates, Amazon\u2019s shipping costs would rise by about $2.6 billion. Some of that money would presumably go to the Postal Service, which in 2014 handled 40 percent of Amazon\u2019s packages, according to one 2015 estimate.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s task force does not address the president\u2019s other complaint about Amazon: that the online retailer fails to pay sales taxes, giving it an unfair advantage over brick-and-mortar businesses.\n\nIn fact, while Amazon used to benefit from tax-free sales, it now charges sales tax on the sale of virtually all of its own products. Many third-party merchants who use the service to sell their own goods on Amazon\u2019s sites still do not charge sales tax.", "title": "Trump, Having Denounced Amazon\u2019s Shipping Deal, Orders Review of Postal Service", "authors": ["Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nAnother day, another dizzying array of Trump news.\n\nThe president glibly tweeted about bombing Syria. He talked about reversing a centerpiece of his own trade policy. The contents of the James Comey book began to emerge, with new details about the \u201cpee tape.\u201d And news broke that the National Enquirer apparently killed a story about President Trump fathering a child with his housekeeper.\n\nGiven all of this craziness, today seems a good day to tell a story that I\u2019ve been wanting to share with you for awhile:\n\nFor a recent column, I did some retrospective reporting on last year\u2019s Alabama Senate campaign. During that race, the progressive group Priorities USA came up with a series of political messages and then ran online surveys to see which advertisements resonated with voters. The goal was to see which were most and least likely to motivate African-Americans to turn out and vote for Doug Jones, the Democrat running against Roy Moore.\n\nPriorities USA had a long list of potential themes to choose from: Moore\u2019s history as an accused molester; his ties to white supremacists; his opposition to Obamacare; Doug Jones\u2019s endorsements from civil-rights leaders; and more.", "title": "Opinion | Trump, Trump, Trump: A Losing Strategy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pence\u2019s very presence at the Summit of the Americas this weekend was just such an effort: Mr. Trump had abruptly withdrawn from plans to attend, citing the run-up to the military strike in Syria. But the cancellation came as Mr. Trump was also consumed by personal and political drama, and it was the first time a United States president had avoided the summit meeting, which occurs every three years, in its 24-year history.\n\nMr. Pence has increasingly stepped in overseas for a president who appears not to relish international travel. This was his third foreign trip and his sixth country so far this year \u2014 after multicountry swings through the Middle East and Asia \u2014 while the president has made a sole trip outside the United States in 2018, to Davos, Switzerland.\n\n\u201cIt would not be surprising to see Pence taking a larger international role in advocating Trump administration foreign policies on the international stage,\u201d John R. Bolton, now Mr. Trump\u2019s national security adviser, wrote in an op-ed in January. Mr. Bolton said Mr. Pence had proved \u201cadept at navigating the complexities of Middle Eastern politics,\u201d and provided a \u201creassuring contrast\u201d to partisan bickering at home.\n\nIn Lima, armed with a thick binder of briefing materials, Mr. Pence delivered meticulously scripted statements printed on cards that he toted around the summit meeting site and read from faithfully, hitting on his main theme of preserving the region as a \u201chemisphere of freedom,\u201d a phrase he repeated at least three times in his closing remarks. The vice president hailed the military action in Syria and denounced the crisis in Venezuela that has led to a humanitarian catastrophe there, calling upon the assembled nations to support tough measures against the governments of both countries.\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s disciplined delivery of the American message after the Syria strikes stood in contrast to the presidential tweet, which recalled an earlier president\u2019s premature declaration of victory in Iraq and prompted a spate of bitter criticism.\n\nWhat the president had meant by his tweet, Mr. Pence explained to reporters traveling with him on Saturday, was that the mission that Mr. Trump had given American forces, \u201cto go in and destroy key elements of the chemical weapons infrastructure in Syria, was completely and professionally and swiftly accomplished.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut that was not the only issue on which Mr. Pence worked to modulate Mr. Trump\u2019s pronouncements here. In a meeting with President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto of Mexico, the vice president said, he steered clear of talking about funding for the border wall that Mr. Trump has long demanded Mexico pay for. Mr. Pence chalked up the disagreement \u2014 which recently torpedoed plans for a White House meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Pe\u00f1a Nieto \u2014 to two presidents with \u201cstrong personalities.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen you have two people with strong personalities, they occasionally have strong differences,\u201d Mr. Pence told reporters. \u201cWe talked through those differences, some of which we set aside for a later date.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInstead, Mr. Pence accentuated the positive: namely, progress in the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, which he said had a chance of being successfully completed within weeks.\n\nAs Mr. Pence taxied for takeoff on Air Force Two on Friday for the trip to Lima, the president appeared to be focused elsewhere. He tapped out a tweet branding James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director whose forthcoming memoir paints him as a liar and Mafia-style bully, \u201can untruthful slime ball.\u201d Privately, Mr. Trump continued to seethe over the F.B.I. raid days earlier on his personal lawyer in a wide-ranging corruption investigation that he views as a grave threat.\n\nAt the summit meeting in Peru, Mr. Pence spoke in loftier terms, trying to reassure the other leaders that Mr. Trump meant no slight in failing to show up for their gathering. Mr. Trump, he told President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia, was \u201cdisappointed\u201d that he could not make the trip \u2014 which was to have included a stop in Bogot\u00e1 to meet with Mr. Santos \u2014 but, he added, \u201cI can assure you that the relationship with our country has never been stronger.\u201d\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s attendance at the summit meeting was not without its sharper moments. In his closing speech, the vice president denounced the Cuban government as a \u201cdespotic regime\u201d that had impoverished its people and abused human rights, prompting the country\u2019s foreign minister, Bruno Rodr\u00edguez Parrilla, who sat listening several chairs away, to demand the chance for a rebuttal. As Mr. Rodr\u00edguez was recognized and began to speak, Mr. Pence abruptly stood and strode out of the summit hall.\n\nBut the vice president labored in a way his boss does not to avoid creating controversies. Mr. Pence called elections scheduled for next month in Venezuela a \u201csham\u201d that would not fool the world, but when a reporter asked whether the United States would refuse to recognize the outcome, he deferred to John J. Sullivan, the acting secretary of state, who was traveling with him, to state the official policy, so as not to risk diverging even slightly from it.\n\nMr. Pence\u2019s presence as a stand-in for Mr. Trump may have undercut the United States\u2019 goals at the summit meeting, taking some of the sting out of the fact that President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro of Venezuela had been disinvited and raising questions about the United States\u2019 commitment to the region.\n\nBut the vice president also defused some of the tension that would have attended an encounter between Mr. Trump and the leaders of Latin American nations who have been insulted and angered by his talk on immigration and other topics, said Richard E. Feinberg, a senior fellow in the Latin America Initiative at the Brookings Institution.\n\n\u201cA lot of leaders probably were preparing two sets of remarks: one if Trump behaves himself, to focus on the issues, and one for if he misbehaves and says something offensive,\u201d Mr. Feinberg said. \u201cWith Trump not being here, they can discard the second set. Pence behaves himself.\u201d", "title": "Trump, Twitter Fingers Flying, Exclaims. Pence, Note Cards in Hand, Explains.", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "The declaration comes as Mr. Trump has been in discussions with South Korea about peace talks with North Korea and as the president hosts Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at Mar-a-Lago, where they are expected to discuss trade, among other issues.\n\nWhen Mr. Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership last year, he proposed a bilateral trade deal with Japan in its place. But Japan\u2019s deputy prime minister, Taro Aso, ruled out that possibility in March, saying that such a negotiation would lead to unnecessary pain for Japan.\n\nInstead, Japan forged ahead with a deal among the accord\u2019s 11 remaining members, which they reached last month. Japan maintains that this agreement is still fragile, and that negotiating another pact with the United States could put its success at risk.\n\nJapan has said it would be willing to enter a one-on-one deal only if it would serve as a bridge to the United States\u2019 re-entering the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\nOther countries have also been cool to the idea of giving any ground to the United States after they spent months reworking the deal after Mr. Trump withdrew.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the stem-winding deliberations about the pact have added another dose of confusion to Mr. Trump\u2019s trade policy as anxiety grows that the Trump administration is on the verge of starting a global trade war.\n\nIn recent weeks, Mr. Trump unveiled sweeping tariffs on global imports of steel and aluminum, only to announce generous exceptions for several American allies. He also announced stiff tariffs on up to $150 billion worth of Chinese imports, before his economic advisers suggested that this might have been a negotiating tactic.\n\nAfter striking a new bilateral trade agreement with South Korea last month, Mr. Trump suggested that he might hold out for a better deal down the road.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Mr. Trump regularly muses about ending the North American Free Trade Agreement, even as his advisers say publicly that negotiations with Canada and Mexico are proceeding in a positive direction.\n\nThe mixed signals have put the president\u2019s economic advisers in an awkward position and raised the hopes of many Republicans in Congress who have been optimistic that he would seek ways to ease trade tensions. Farmers and business groups have been fearful that retaliation from other countries on trade will stall the recent strength in the economy.\n\n\u201cThis whole trade thing has exploded,\u201d Larry Kudlow, the director of the White House\u2019s National Economic Council, said last week, explaining that he was pulling together a team to begin renegotiating the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\nWhile rejoining the pact would please some Republicans, it would have been a significant breach of a campaign promise and an embrace of a policy that the president has described as a \u201crape of our country.\u201d For that reason, many of Mr. Trump\u2019s closest aides have been quietly playing down the prospects of re-entry.\n\nOn Tuesday morning, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said that Mr. Trump made a \u201cbig announcement\u201d this year when he said he would consider rejoining the trade pact. However, he cautioned that the United States would only do so if it could cut a much better deal.\n\nAsked on CNBC about the chances of the United States rejoining the pact, Mr. Mnuchin demurred.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to handicap it,\u201d he said.", "title": "Trump, in Another Apparent Reversal, Says Trans-Pacific Trade Pact Has \u2018Too Many Contingencies\u2019", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 You can hear those heads exploding from here to Oslo.\n\nRepublican lawmakers are pushing Donald Trump, the most combative man in the universe, for a Nobel Peace Prize.\n\nHow unimaginable is this?\n\nJust picture a wildly hirsute cartoon figure with a hair-trigger temper festooned with a medal of Alfred Nobel reading \u201cPro pace et fraternitate gentium\u201d (\u201cFor the peace and brotherhood of men\u201d).\n\n\u201cThe guy who said he could be as presidential as any president except for Abraham Lincoln is instead about as presidential as Yosemite Sam,\u201d says his biographer Tim O\u2019Brien. \u201cI really think of him as Yosemite Sam \u2014 just hopping around in anger, firing his gun wildly, sometimes at his own foot. He was so unhinged and ranting in that call to \u2018Fox & Friends\u2019 this week that even the hosts couldn\u2019t wait to get him off the air.\u201d\n\nYet Lindsey Graham, who once labeled Trump \u201ca kook,\u201d \u201ccrazy\u201d and \u201cunfit for office,\u201d told Fox News on Friday: \u201cDonald Trump convinced North Korea and China he was serious about bringing about change. We\u2019re not there yet, but if this happens, President Trump deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Trump: Our Cartoon Nobel Laureate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Much of the planning for Mr. Macron\u2019s arrival on Monday and the Tuesday dinner \u2014 components of the most prominent affair a first lady can pull off \u2014 has fallen to a small East Wing staff of 10 people. They add up to 14 if you count the four aides in the White House Visitors Office and 15 if you count the first lady. Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, a former Vogue operative known for marshaling the annual Met Gala in New York, and whose official contract with the East Wing ended earlier this year, did not comment when asked about whether she had offered a hand, except to say Mrs. Trump \u201chas got this as always.\u201d\n\nIn interviews, several of the first lady\u2019s media-skittish East Wing aides, including Rickie Niceta, the White House social secretary; Daniel Fisher, the director of the Visitors Office; and Lindsay Reynolds, Mrs. Trump\u2019s chief of staff, said they were bracing for criticism. But Mrs. Trump, who declined to be interviewed, has instructed her staff not to agonize over details and to stay focused, even amid swirling headlines about the Russia investigation and Stormy Daniels, the pornographic film actress who was paid hush money during the 2016 presidential campaign to keep quiet about a sexual encounter she has said she had with President Trump, which he denies.\n\nStephanie Grisham, Mrs. Trump\u2019s communications director, was characteristically defensive on behalf of the first lady, saying the small team had learned to weather negative feedback as part of the job. \u201cWe\u2019re probably not going to get the credit we deserve,\u201d she said in an interview. \u201cBut I know this team is great and she knows this team is great. We have not failed, and she has not failed.\u201d\n\nThe guest list has been so tightly controlled and debated that there was some private concern among aides that Mr. Trump would throw out an invitation to a Mar-a-Lago buddy or two. Some tried to keep close watch over his kibitzing with guests during Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan\u2019s visit to Palm Beach, Fla., last week, according to two people familiar with the planning.\n\nIn the end, the list was so small that after the must-invite American government officials and the large French delegation, there was room for the president to personally invite only four people, according to a White House official. Keeping with tradition, not all cabinet members are expected to attend, although Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and his wife, Louise Linton, made the cut.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere will be subtle hints at bipartisanship in the d\u00e9cor: Along with 1,200 Obama-inspired cherry blossom branches to decorate the Cross Hall, Mrs. Trump will use china from the Clinton White House.\n\nThe full guest list is expected to be released on Tuesday, right before the start of the dinner. The list traditionally includes a handful of lawmakers, along with the president\u2019s chief of staff and national security adviser, and at least two Supreme Court justices, according to Lea Berman, who was the White House social secretary during the George W. Bush administration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhere it goes from there,\u201d Ms. Berman said, \u201cit\u2019s a way of reading the tea leaves of who\u2019s in with the Trumps. It will be interesting to see how many family members make the cut.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAides within the East and West Wings say planning such a detailed event has been well within Mrs. Trump\u2019s comfort zone, and that she has grown comfortable with her role over time.\n\n\u201cShe is very organized,\u201d Ms. Niceta said, \u201cand she is very exact in how she wants something. There is no wavering.\u201d\n\nMrs. Trump chose white sweet peas and white lilacs for the tables in the State Dining Room, and it was the first lady\u2019s idea, Ms. Niceta said, to host Mr. Macron and his wife, Brigitte, for a private dinner on Monday evening at Mount Vernon. The estate was home to America\u2019s first president, George Washington, who hosted the Marquis de Lafayette there years after the two fought as allies in the Revolutionary War.\n\nThe White House has searched for ways to increasingly warm up a relationship between two leaders that is at its heart a pragmatic one: East Wing aides arranged a helicopter tour for Mr. Macron on Monday so that he could get a bird\u2019s-eye view of a city designed by the French-born Pierre Charles L\u2019Enfant on the way to Mount Vernon.\n\nFew of Mr. Trump and Mr. Macron\u2019s interactions will be observed by the public during the visit, but there will be one that will indicate if discussions have gone well, according to Ms. Berman.\n\n\u201cThe toast will reflect how the day has gone,\u201d Ms. Berman said. \u201cYou can usually tell from the toasts if they\u2019re really getting along or not.\u201d\n\nAs for Mrs. Trump\u2019s ability to strengthen diplomatic ties with the Macrons, Ms. Reynolds, Mrs. Trump\u2019s chief of staff and a former aide in the Bush White House, said she has learned over the past year that the first lady does not require as much direction as she initially expected.\n\nWhen Mrs. Trump took the Japanese prime minister\u2019s wife, Akie Abe, on a tour of the Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach last week, for instance, Ms. Reynolds killed time in the gift shop.\n\n\u201cI realized very quickly I was getting in her way\u201d with early attempts to direct the first lady on protocol during diplomatic visits, Ms. Reynolds said. \u201cShe\u2019s perfectly fine.\u201d", "title": "Trumps Throw Out Tradition for Their First State Dinner", "authors": ["Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "His message isn\u2019t consistent with where things stand in global currency markets. And it\u2019s vague. It\u2019s not at all clear what signal he\u2019s sending about a preferred policy.\n\nLet\u2019s unpack it.\n\nRussia and the Ruble\n\nThe comment about Russia is curious. While Russia is of course an important geopolitical player, its sclerotic economy and isolated financial system mean that it\u2019s not an important player in global commerce.\n\nFor example, the United States\u2019 trade with Russia is a rounding error \u2014 $17 billion worth of imports in 2017 (Chinese imports were 31 times that high). And the ruble is not on the radar of currency traders, the way that, say, the British pound or Swiss franc is.\n\nIt\u2019s true that the ruble has plummeted against the dollar this month, falling about 8 percent. But that isn\u2019t because the Russian government is playing some devaluation game. The ruble fell because stringent new sanctions on influential Russians are crimping demand for the currency.", "title": "Trump\u2019s Annoyed About Russian and Chinese Currencies. Should He Be?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The problem is that, once again, Mr. Trump has an impulse \u2014 in this case, he even has the right one \u2014 but no strategy, an emotion but little insight into reality on the ground. His call to withdraw troops immediately is at odds with warnings from American commanders who believe that it could lead to a resurgence by ISIS, like the rebound of militants in Iraq after Mr. Obama brought troops home from there. This is a familiar pattern for Mr. Trump: He skips past the hard work of commander in chief, seeking a quick political gain while foisting responsibility for difficult military decisions onto the generals. Fortunately, in this case, the generals have persuaded him to sidestep a quick withdrawal in favor of a more studied approach.\n\nThere are roughly 2,000 American troops fighting ISIS in Syria today. In January, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson declared they could expect to remain there indefinitely. Mr. Tillerson also said that the military mission would be \u201cconditions-based,\u201d meaning without either an end date or benchmarks for success. General Votel had a similar message on Tuesday, describing the military\u2019s future role as stabilizing and consolidating gains while \u201caddressing long-term issues of reconstruction,\u201d including training local forces to keep ISIS from regaining a foothold.\n\nDespite his isolationist tendencies, the president seemed to support that approach. Since taking office, he has tripled troop levels in Syria, just as he has also sent more troops to Afghanistan. In fact, Mr. Trump even faulted Mr. Obama for setting a timetable for withdrawing troops from Afghanistan, saying it gave the Taliban the upper hand. Now he has effectively done the same thing by announcing that \u201cit\u2019s time\u201d for the troops to leave Syria.\n\nMr. Trump is irritated that Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations have not contributed enough resources to the Syria campaign. Fine; as president, he should be able to do something about that, particularly given the close relationship he claims to have with the Saudi royal family. What\u2019s his plan?\n\nThe president just doesn\u2019t seem to get that any American withdrawal requires careful thought to ensure we don\u2019t surrender the gains we\u2019ve made, endanger troops on the ground or alienate our allies. What will happen, for instance, to Syrian Kurds who have been crucial American partners in fighting ISIS and now are under attack by Turkey, which considers the Kurds to be terrorists? Or to Israel, which is increasingly concerned about the foothold that Iran, an Assad ally that Mr. Trump has decried as a major regional threat, has gained in Syria?\n\nBesides Iran, another notable American adversary is likely to benefit from the president\u2019s apparent desire to retreat from the Middle East: Russia. Already, Mr. Trump is letting Russia take the lead in Syria, ceding to Vladimir Putin the crucial diplomatic work of forging a political agreement between Mr. Assad and the Syrian rebels. Mr. Putin, an Assad ally, met Iranian and Turkish leaders in Istanbul on Wednesday to plan Syria\u2019s future. How does that serve American interests?", "title": "Opinion | Trump\u2019s Approach to Syria Is No Way to Run a War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWelcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night\u2019s highlights that lets you sleep \u2014 and lets us get paid to watch comedy.
