For nonwork purposes, I love that I have a camera and video recorder with me wherever I am \u2014 crucial for a parent of young children.\n\nI do my banking, listen to podcasts, read, and jot down funny things my 4-year-old, Isaac, says. And I wrote out these answers on my phone (in the Notes app) while getting my hair cut.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSmartphones now also make for easy house stalking. I love going to a dinner party and then checking out the person\u2019s home on Zillow. My husband and I often play a game to guess how much we think the house sold for. (Life in the suburbs is underrated.)\n\nIn our own home, our kids love using our Amazon Echo. Isaac asks it all sorts of important life questions (like \u201cAlexa, do you like bubbles?\u201d). He also orders up his favorite songs, then he and his little brother dance around the kitchen.\n\nI wish there were a feature on my phone that could make it quickly obvious to others what I am doing on it. I grew up watching my parents read the newspaper over breakfast. I wish that when I was reading the news, my kids could tell. Instead, they just see my head in my phone. That is the major reason I still get the Sunday paper.", "title": "Twitter, Facebook, Slack: Using Every Tool to Hear What Readers Think", "authors": ["Hanna Ingber", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "On the website where the veteran composer and performer Eve Beglarian provides a trove of streamable music and downloadable scores, she often includes a simple note: \u201cYou are warmly invited to support this low-key way of publishing.\u201d\n\nThis informal, D.I.Y. attitude stretches back to the 1970s and \u201980s, when downtown music was actually performed in downtown New York ZIP codes. (Today those neighborhoods have more bank branches and fewer artists\u2019 lofts.) But, happily, some composers who emerged from that vibrant period and locale can now be heard all over town \u2014 even uptown.\n\nOn a recent Friday evening, the Morgan Library & Museum hosted an invigorating 80-minute set of selections from Ms. Beglarian\u2019s ongoing \u201cA Book of Days\u201d project, performed by her and a dedicated group of interpreters. That call lasted 35 seconds. Thirteen minutes later at 3:40 p.m., the complaint said, Mr. Lyons called Mr. Azimi and the two men spoke for 32 seconds. At 4:05 p.m., Mr. Azimi was captured on a surveillance camera at a pharmacy purchasing syringes a few blocks from Public School X811, where he taught disabled students.\n\nSeven minutes later, Mr. Azimi received another call from Mr. Lyons that lasted 17 seconds. Two hours later Mr. Azimi was dead.\n\nThe police began investigating Mr. Lyons, who was on probation. He had been released in September from federal prison, where he served three years for a firearms conviction.\n\nDuring the investigation, an undercover officer bought heroin laced with fentanyl, a potent and synthetic additive, from Mr. Lyons and Mr. Whitaker on four occasions in February, according to the complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe charges gave Mr. Azimi\u2019s wife, Rachel, some closure, but she said Sunday that \u201cnothing will bring him back.\u201d\n\nIf she could speak to the men, she said she would tell them \u201chow many people they hurt by this.\u201d\n\nMr. Azimi, a beloved teacher, had hid his addiction from friends, family and colleagues in the weeks leading up to his death. He struggled with drinking and drug use as a teenager in Bedford, N.Y., and his parents sent him to an alternative school, where he got sober.\n\nHe married and had children. He became a teacher, started a horticulture program at the school and played guitar for his students before dismissal. His students adored him.\n\nAt his home in Carmel, N.Y., photos of Mr. Azimi and his family hang on the walls along with his academic degrees. His clothes and coats remain in a closet where he left them. His workbag is nearby. His guitar is perched alongside the fireplace. A shelf with his books was left untouched. And in the bathroom, his toothbrush and a shaving kit remain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSometimes they are comforting, his wife said, other times they are painful reminders that he is never coming home.\n\nMs. Azimi was six months pregnant with their third child when her husband died. In March, she gave birth to \u201ca healthy and happy\u201d baby she named Roxanne whose skin tone, nose, brown hair and eyes favor her father.\n\n\u201cOne of the hardest things is I have a beautiful baby that he never saw, never held and he doesn\u2019t know her name,\u201d Ms. Azimi said through tears. \u201cI don\u2019t hate the men responsible for this. I have to grieve my husband and raise my kids. I don\u2019t have room in my heart for hatred.\u201d", "title": "Two Men Charged in Bronx Teacher\u2019s Overdose Death", "authors": ["Jan Ransom"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Two collections of previously undiscovered short stories found among the papers of the prolific author Noel Streatfeild will be published by Virago Press.\n\nStreatfeild, who died at 90 in 1986, wrote several much-loved children\u2019s classics, many of which drew on her own experiences of professional acting before she began to write. Her first novel, \u201cBallet Shoes\u201d (1936), was a huge success and, like many of her other children\u2019s books (\u201cThe Circus Is Coming,\u201d \u201cTennis Shoes,\u201d \u201cWhite Boots,\u201d \u201cThe Bell Family\u201d), is still popular with young readers today. (A made-for-television film of \u201cBallet Shoes,\u201d starring Emma Watson, was created in 2007.)\n\nThe stories were found after Donna Coonan, the editorial director of the publishing house Virago Modern Classics, was invited by William Streatfeild, the author\u2019s nephew, to look through her papers before they were sent to the Seven Stories museum, a center for children\u2019s literature in Newcastle, England, where they are to be housed.\n\nMs. Coonan wrote on Twitter: \u201cI am over the moon! Wonderful though \u2018Ballet Shoes\u2019 is, there\u2019s so much more to Noel.\u201d", "title": "Two New Collections by the Author of \u2018Ballet Shoes\u2019 Will Be Published", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "He estimates that he has spent about a million rand, or $84,000, so far, believing that it will help level the gender playing field while raising Africa\u2019s profile in the global art market, and its share of the $67 billion it generates.\n\nMr. Lutaaya knows what it means to fight through adversity. Abandoned by his parents, later a street child in Kampala, Uganda, he managed to get a scholarship to a university. In 2011 he won a residency at the Bag Factory in Johannesburg, which offered a studio and materials. He said he made the eight-day journey overland with a packet of cookies and a bottle of water. When the three-month Bag Factory residency ended, Mr. Lutaaya said he found part-time janitorial work, but soon also found himself, again, hustling to sleep indoors, making a loaf of bread last a week. He collected discarded newspapers and cut them into pieces for collages that he initially peddled for a few dollars.\n\nA few years and breaks later, Mr. Lutaaya has grown into an outsize presence. The scraps and flecks of newsprint work like Impressionist brush strokes: up close it\u2019s hard to see the image, but a few steps back you see poignant portraiture. Last December, at a sold-out solo show in Cape Town, one work went for 500,000 South African rand, about $40,000 \u2014 a soaring figure for any contemporary Africa-based artist not named William Kentridge.\n\nMr. Lutaaya\u2019s premise is that success in the art world depends as much on business savvy as it does on creativity and technical skill. Women of color need more opportunities to learn how the business and society of art works \u2014 from galleries to agents, collectors and selection committees. It robs them of possibility, but it is a loss for the whole continent, he said. And as time goes on, they often get discouraged and abandon their efforts.\n\n\u201cThey need to develop from within the system in a way to give them enough exposure to know what\u2019s going on, to engage with the broader community, locally and globally,\u201d Mr. Lutaaya said. \u201cOnce they do that, they became also great mentors for other young people they meet.\u201d", "title": "Two Projects Helping Female Artists in Africa Find Their Voices", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTwo valuable artworks by Egon Schiele, with a long disputed provenance, must be returned to the heirs of an Austrian Jewish entertainer who owned them before he died in the Dachau concentration camp in 1941, a New York State Supreme Court judge has ruled.\n\nThe ruling Thursday, by Judge Charles J. Ramos, is one of the first successful applications of the Holocaust Expropriated Recovery, or HEAR, Act, passed by Congress in 2016, and designed to ease statute of limitations restrictions for plaintiffs seeking to recover artwork stolen during World War II.\n\nThe two disputed Schiele drawings \u2014 \u201cWoman in a Black Pinafore\u201d (1911) and \u201cWoman Hiding her Face\u201d (1912) \u2013 were part of a 449-piece collection owned by Fritz Grunbaum, a well-known cabaret performer in Vienna who was also a vocal critic of the Nazis. For years, Mr. Grunbaum\u2019s heirs have argued in courts and elsewhere that the Nazis stole the collection, which included 81 Schieles, and that the collection should be returned to its rightful owners.\n\nIn a previous case, filed in 2005, a court ruled against the heirs as they attempted to recover a Schiele drawing from the Grunbaum collection \u201cSeated Woman With Bent Left Leg (Torso)\u201d from a Boston businessman who had bought the work in 1963. The court said too much time had passed prior to the Grunbaum\u2019s claim, causing evidence to be lost.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut this time, Raymond Dowd, the lawyer for the heirs, cited the HEAR Act in his pleadings and Judge Ramos cited it as among the legal justifications for his decision. \u201cThe HEAR Act compels us to help return Nazi-looted art to its heirs,\u201d the judge wrote in his 16-page ruling, in which he noted \u201cthe gut-wrenching process by which Mr. Grunbaum\u2019s property was looted.\u201d", "title": "Two Schiele Drawings Ordered Returned to Heirs of Nazi Victim", "authors": ["William D. Cohan"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "In George Balanchine\u2019s \u201cConcerto Barocco,\u201d nobody dies, nobody falls to the ground, nobody falls in love. The only set is the sky-blue backdrop. The women\u2019s costumes, minimal, are white tunics.\n\nYet much does happen. A group of women becomes a vision of pulsating classicism and of gleaming American energy.\n\nIn the 1940s, Balanchine was on a mission to \u201csave ballet,\u201d as he put it to the critic Edwin Denby. \u201cBarocco\u201d (1941) \u2014 the purest and most plotless of the works he made that decade \u2014 is a ballet about ballet, and its marriage to music. Made to Bach\u2019s double violin concerto, it returns to the repertory of New York City Ballet on Tuesday, the first night of the company\u2019s spring season.\n\n\u201cBarocco\u201d is one of Balanchine\u2019s most high-concentrate creations: When you pause to analyze any few seconds of it, it\u2019s uncanny how much there is to say.", "title": "Two Seconds That Explain Balanchine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIn the mid-1960s, I attended a science and engineering summer program for high school students that was sponsored by the National Science Foundation and held at Manhattan College in the Bronx.\n\nI stayed at an uncle\u2019s house in what was then called the Rugby section of Brooklyn. Every morning, my uncle would drive me to the subway station in Flatbush. He wanted to make sure I would get to school on time.\n\nAt the time, subway turnstiles still took tokens. Upon entering the station, I would slide a $1 bill though the slot at the token clerk\u2019s booth. The same clerk was there every day.\n\n\u201cGood morning,\u201d I would say. \u201cTwo please.\u201d\n\nI felt clever for buying the token for my return trip in the morning, so that I didn\u2019t have to wait in line again after school. (It never occurred to me to buy 10 tokens for the week.)\n\nOne morning, the clerk, in a thick Brooklyn accent, said, \u201cYou\u2019re not from around here, are you?\u201d\n\nI was surprised.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d I said. \u201cI\u2019m from Arizona. How did you know?\u201d\n\n\u201c\u2018Cause nobody ever says \u2018please\u2019 to me.\u201d", "title": "Two Tokens, Please", "authors": ["Wendell P. Goring", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe minimized the width of the tower on the river, on the lower levels,\u201d said Mr. Ingels, describing the west tower, which has a narrower base than top when seen from 11th Avenue. \u201cBut then as it rises, it expands, and at the top, it occupies the full western facade.\u201d\n\nThe eastern tower twists in the opposite way, he added, maximizing lower-floor views east and west, to the High Line and Hudson River, but then prioritizing views north and south over the city at the top.\n\nInside the west tower apartments, \u201cThere\u2019s a real emphasis on natural materials, to reflect natural elements embedded throughout the building,\u201d said Kimberly Sheppard, a partner at Gabellini Sheppard. The materials include wide-plank oak floors, gray larch wood Bulthaup kitchen cabinets with White Princess quartzite counters, and master bathrooms with eucalyptus wood vanities and walls clad in Taj Mahal quartzite with a leather-textured finish.\n\nIn the east tower, Gilles & Boissier will extend the atmosphere of the Six Senses hotel it is designing into the residential apartments. Doroth\u00e9e Boissier said her firm sought to mix polished and textured finishes to play up the natural character of materials, much like Gabellini Sheppard. However, the end result has more contrast.\n\nThe Molteni kitchens have smooth lacquer doors installed near others with a pronounced, brushed wood grain, and a mix of white Calacatta Gold and black Grigio Carnico marble. Master bathrooms have herringbone floors of light Arabescato Vagli Oro marble set off by a border of dark Saint Laurent marble.\n\n\u201cIf you have a diamond among diamonds, you don\u2019t see it as beautiful,\u201d said Ms. Boissier, explaining her firm\u2019s decision to use a high-contrast material palette. \u201cBut if you have a diamond surrounded by simple rocks, you really see the diamond. We think it\u2019s the same in design.\u201d\n\nThe amenity package includes a 4,000-square-foot fitness center with a 75-foot-long pool, a lounge and gallery in the glass bridge, a wine tasting room, a social lounge with billiards tables, a teen room and a children\u2019s playroom, in addition to priority access to Six Senses.\n\nSales are scheduled to begin on May 7, with the launch of a sales gallery with an immersive installation by the designer Es Devlin at 25 Little West 12th Street. One-bedrooms will start at $2.8 million, two-bedrooms at $3.9 million, three-bedrooms at $6.5 million, four-bedrooms at $9 million and half-floor penthouses at $25 million. The target completion date, said Mr. Feldman, is the last quarter of 2019.", "title": "Two Twisting Towers Come to the Far West Side", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Ah, Chapter Two. It described, in considerable detail, the first time one of the eight had sex.\n\nVassar is different from what it was in McCarthy\u2019s day \u2014 among other things, Vassar has admitted men since 1969. But Mr. Youd decided that \u201cThe Group\u201d was just the thing to type on the Vassar campus, and not just for its references to campus landmarks. Or its potential as a history lesson for undergraduates of the laptop-and-cellphone age who have never touched a carriage-return lever or heard the bell ring close to the end of a line.\n\n\u201cEvery novel has its flaws,\u201d he said. \u201cThis one, the difficulty is who\u2019s who. That many characters is a lot to stage-manage.\u201d McCarthy, he said, \u201cdoes try, and usually succeeds.\u201d\n\nUnlike a writer turning out double-spaced page after double-spaced page, Mr. Youd was typing a single single-spaced sheet of paper. That one page will contain the entire novel. By the time he reaches Page 487 and the last two words of \u201cThe Group\u201d \u2014 \u201cNew York\u201d \u2014 the page will be an inky, illegible mess.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m coming at this from the perspective of the visual artist who\u2019s interested in how text and literature manifest themselves in a visual way,\u201d he said.\n\nHe is a two-finger typist \u2014 \u201cme and Raymond Chandler,\u201d he said with a chuckle \u2014 but said he did not know how many words per minute he could bang out. \u201cI\u2019m more like a pages-per-hour guy,\u201d he said. \u201cI generally have to get 25 pages done in a day.\u201d Five pages an hour is a good pace, he said.", "title": "Typing a Novel About Vassar, Word for Word, as Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "One of the dangers of looking backward, however, is the tendency toward romanticization, and that is a particular risk when one considers this era. Yes, it was a party, but the party could be more of a masked ball, menacing and sinister. Yes, you could afford to live here, but that was because the city was broke, and dangerous, and crime-ridden, and profoundly unjust. And for every joyful night, for every drunken frenzy, there was also the plague, first significantly reported in The New York Times on July 3, 1981, but left unnamed for a year after its appearance. By the end of 1983, it had gobbled 857 lives in New York alone. The people AIDS claimed were, initially, largely gay men, and to look back on the inhumanity and indifference with which this community was treated is to reveal a particularly shameful part of this country\u2019s recent history.\n\nImage A self-portrait by Peter Hujar, 1983. Credit Peter Hujar, \u201cContact Sheet Frame: Self-Portrait,\u201d 1983. Peter Hujar Collection, Morgan Library & Museum, N.Y.C., purchased on the Charina Endowment Fund, 2013. 2013.108:8.4547. \u00a9 the Peter Hujar Archive LLC. Courtesy of Pace MacGill Gallery, N.Y.C., and the Fraenkel Gallery, San Francisco\n\nAnd yet the echo of those years has never felt louder than it does today. In 1981, there was a president who had embraced the religious far right (and who refused to even utter the word \u201cAIDS\u201d until 1985). There was a widening chasm between the very rich and the very poor. To be an artist was to be in opposition to the state, and art is always at its most thrilling when it is in disagreement with something, when the people who are making it feel that they are creating work not merely as an intellectual exercise, but in defense of the right to expression itself. This sense of urgency is also what made those years so enduringly vivid, and it is what makes them so relevant now, with so many peoples \u2014 women, Muslims, the transgender community, to name a few \u2014 who are fighting to be recognized as full citizens.\n\nThe New York City of 2018 is and isn\u2019t the one of nearly four decades ago. But as much as we may bemoan its transformations \u2014 the galleries replaced by boutiques, the lofts occupied by billionaires \u2014 the promise of New York continues to draw hopefuls, year after year. Cities change. They must. We may mourn what they were, or what they become. But in our city, we can find solace in the fact that many of the people who inspired us to come here in the first place are, in fact, still here, still making art. They are survivors: of a plague, of a government, of a decade. We also honor the ones no longer with us, the people whose deaths deprived of us of not just their company, but also of the hundreds, the thousands, of potential masterpieces they might have produced. We share the city with all of them. Our New York was, and still is, theirs as well.\n\nImage Peter Hujar, \"Contact Sheet Frame: Stephen Koch 5/11/83,\" 1983. Credit Peter Hujar Collection, Morgan Library & Museum, New York, purchased on the Charina Endowment Fund, 2013. 2013.108:8.4613. \u00a9 the Peter Hujar Archive LLC. Courtesy of Pace MacGill Gallery, N.Y.C., and the Fraenkel Gallery, San Francisco\n\nStephen Koch, director of the Peter Hujar Archive, on the artist\u2019s previously unpublished cover portrait of David Wojnarowicz:\n\nIn 1981, Peter Hujar did a series of photographs of David Wojnarowicz, who was then emerging as a young artist. It was a great shoot. It produced at least five pictures that are museum quality and, I think, masterpieces \u2014 most of which are in fact now in museums.\n\nThe contact sheet is what Hanya got interested in. It\u2019s been my policy never to reproduce \u2014 except for documentary purposes, and then only rarely \u2014 a photograph that Peter himself never printed. (This portrait Peter took of me, in 1983, was never printed, either). But it is true that the contact sheets are historically fascinating. So I agreed to let that happen. Let them be published, so long as everyone is clear that they are, in effect, rejects by Peter \u2014 but interesting rejects. In terms of the \u201980s, Peter\u2019s contact sheets are exceptionally fascinating and revealing. They say a lot about the relation between Peter and David, and for that reason, I am happy to have them known.", "title": "T\u2019s Culture Issue: Time on Fire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Treasures taken by British troops 150 years ago could be returned to Ethiopia on a long-term loan from the Victoria and Albert Museum, the institution\u2019s director said.\n\nA crown, a chalice, a wedding dress and a selection of jewelry are among the items in the museum\u2019s collection that are included in a new exhibition, \u201cMaqdala 1868,\u201d set to open Thursday.\n\nAhead of the exhibition, which has been organized in consultation with the Ethiopian Embassy in London to observe the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Maqdala, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, Tristram Hunt, told the Art Newspaper that he had made \u201ca clear statement to the ambassador, saying that if Ethiopia is interested in pursuing the long-term loan of the Maqdala items we would stand ready to assist.\u201d\n\nMr. Hunt was not available for comment. A spokeswoman for the museum said in an email, \u201cThere have already been a number discussions about further collaboration, including long-term loans of the collection.\u201d", "title": "U.K. Museum Offers Ethiopia Long-Term Loan of Looted Treasures", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Nicole Grobert is German, but she has spent almost all of her career in Britain, developing tiny nanomaterials and figuring out how to use them in everything from artificial bones to super-efficient batteries. Young scientists have an unusual degree of autonomy here, she has found, and European Union funds enabled her to build her own research group at the University of Oxford.\n\nThese days, though, Dr. Grobert says her future at Oxford looks cloudier than it used to. Since Britain voted to quit the union, she has been getting calls from universities on the Continent, and farther abroad, gauging her interest in a new job. For now, she is staying put, but if grants grow scarce or immigration rules create new hassles, she is ready to move.\n\n\u201cI came with a suitcase,\u201d Dr. Grobert said. \u201cI can grab that suitcase and go.\u201d\n\nFor decades, the European Union has provided a collaborative, cross-border framework in which British universities have grown and thrived. European grants fund research like Dr. Grobert\u2019s and nurture the international back-and-forth crucial to scholarly work in disciplines from archaeology to economics.\n\nFree movement within the bloc has meant faculty from other European nations can live and work in Britain visa-free, and students from elsewhere in the union pay the same tuition as Britons.", "title": "U.K. Universities Face Uncertainty as Brexit Looms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 After 11 male statues \u2014 mostly of white, middle-aged men of aristocratic pedigree \u2014 and nearly 200 years, the first female figure was unveiled on Tuesday in London\u2019s historic Parliament Square, the locus of the British establishment.\n\nHundreds of people, including Prime Minister Theresa May, attended the unveiling of the statue, which depicts Millicent Fawcett, a now relatively unsung hero of the feminist movement who led campaigning for women\u2019s right to vote. The bronze statue, which shows a middle-aged Ms. Fawcett holding a banner reading \u201cCourage Calls to Courage Everywhere,\u201d was installed in part to celebrate the centenary of women\u2019s suffrage in Britain this year.\n\n\u201cWhen you think of the great people in Parliament Square, and when you realize that not one of them is a woman, it sort of begs the question,\u201d said the mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, whose office agreed to the installation last year after an online petition for such a statue received tens of thousands of signatures. \u201cAre we saying there haven\u2019t been incredible women in the past? That our country hasn\u2019t been built on the back of great women?\u201d\n\nThe petition was started by Caroline Criado-Perez, a freelance writer who previously successfully campaigned for an image of Jane Austen to appear on the British 10-pound note, an endeavor that quickly made her a target of online abuse. Gillian Wearing, a Turner Prize-winning artist, created the Fawcett statue, becoming the first woman responsible for a statue in Parliament Square.", "title": "U.K.\u2019s Parliament Square Gets a Female Statue. It Only Took 200 Years.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Russia\u2019s ambassador, Vasily A. The inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons will try to determine whether chemical weapons had been used in the Douma attack.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. They think that they\u2019re indispensable. And hence, they think that they are above the law, above international law.\u201d", "title": "U.N. Security Council Rejects Russian Resolution Condemning Syrian Strikes", "authors": ["Sewell Chan"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "The German government said in a statement that Ms. Merkel, Mr. Macron and Ms. May agreed that if the tariffs go into force, \u201cThe European Union should be ready to decisively defend its interests within the framework of multilateral trade rules.\u201d\n\nThe uncertainty is sowing chaos in international supply networks. Car companies and other manufacturers do not know whether ships carrying steel may suddenly be barred from American ports.\n\nSome countries are confident they will avoid the tariffs. Australia is treating an exemption as if it\u2019s a done deal. Brazil, which primarily exports slab steel to American manufacturers, is hoping to escape by agreeing on limited quotas for more sophisticated products. Argentina is counting on the good relationship between its president, Mauricio Macri, and Mr. Trump.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIn the conversations that we have on the issue, the positive relationships between our governments \u2014 and our presidents \u2014 certainly comes up,\u201d Miguel Braun, Argentina\u2019s trade secretary, said in an interview.\n\nBut it\u2019s unclear whether the confidence is justified. The White House has not confirmed that Australia, Brazil or Argentina will receive exemptions.\n\nIn terms of the potential disruption to the global economy, the dispute with Europe may be the most critical. The United States and the European Union account for about one-third of world trade.\n\nOnly a few years ago the United States and Europe were discussing the possibility of eliminating almost all trans-Atlantic trade barriers. Now they are stymied by fundamentally different worldviews. As the Europeans see it, Mr. Trump is demanding concessions that would make them accomplices in dismantling a postwar trade framework they hold sacred.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Europeans want to play by the rules of the World Trade Organization; the Americans are making demands that would force the Europeans to break them.\n\n\u201cIf we stick to the rules,\u201d said Thiess Petersen, an analyst at the Bertelsmann Foundation in Germany, \u201cthere is no chance for concessions.\u201d\n\nGerman cars, a particular target of presidential ire, are one of the major sticking points.\n\nCommerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, who has been handling talks with the European Union, has been pushing the 28-nation bloc to reduce its tariffs on imported American cars as one way of cutting its trade surplus with the United States. In a recent interview with CNBC, Larry Kudlow, the chief economic adviser, said that the United States wanted more concessions before it granted a permanent exclusion.\n\nBut if the European Union accepted the demand for lower car tariffs, international treaties would require it to apply similar terms to automobiles from all other members of the World Trade Organization.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe biggest beneficiary might be China. A member of the W.T.O., China is keen to become an auto exporter and would be thrilled to get easier access to Europe without giving up anything in return.\n\nThe Europeans are offended that they are being asked to negotiate in the first place. Cecilia Malmstrom, the European commissioner for trade, said last week that the union would discuss terms of trade with the United States only after it had received a permanent and unconditional exemption to the steel and aluminum tariffs.\n\n\u201cWhen that is confirmed by the president,\u201d Ms. Malmstrom told reporters in Strasbourg, France, \u201cwe are willing as always to discuss anything. But we are not negotiating anything under threat.\u201d\n\nIn an extension of the disconnect between the two NATO allies, the president has expressed annoyance that he can\u2019t just bypass the European Union apparatus altogether and work out deals with favored leaders like Mr. Macron. That approach would be illegal under the E.U. treaty and undermine one of the bloc\u2019s fundamental principles \u2014 that all the members act in unison on trade matters.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI would rather deal just with France,\u201d Mr. Trump said at the White House on April 24, ahead of a visit by Mr. Macron. \u201cThe Union is very tough for us. They have trade barriers that are unacceptable.\u201d\n\nDavid O\u2019Sullivan, the European Union ambassador to the United States, said that if tariffs go into effect, \u201cwe are back to the need to pursue this with the World Trade Organization, including the possibility of imposing rebalancing counter-tariffs on equivalent U.S. exports.\u201d\n\nThe E.U. has already drawn up a list of products targeted for retaliation. They are meant to inflict maximum pain on the Republican heartland, including recreational power boats made in Tennessee, digital flight recorders made in Arizona and playing cards made in Kentucky.\n\nBut the strategy may not be effective. Business leaders who have visited Washington recently said that the president had been unmoved by protests from members of his own party.\n\nPhoto\n\nTogether, the countries seeking to extend temporary exemptions account for about half of American steel imports. The United States has already granted South Korea a permanent exemption as part of a revised trade deal.\n\nOther countries have already been denied exemptions and started paying tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum. They include China and Russia as well as Japan, a close ally.\n\nPrime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan refused to be coerced into one-on-one negotiations, instead trying to coax the United States back into the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a multicountry trade deal Mr. Trump left last year.\n\n\u201cOur country\u2019s position is that T.P.P is best for both of the countries, and based on that position we will be approaching the talks,\u201d Mr. Abe said in mid-April.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump was not persuaded. After briefly considering rejoining the trade agreement, he reversed course, writing on Twitter that the deal had \u201ctoo many contingencies.\u201d\n\nFor Canada and Mexico, among the largest exporters of steel and aluminum to the United States, the Trump administration has tied their exemptions to Nafta talks. Negotiators from the three countries are scheduled to meet again on May 7 as they push to work through the major remaining disagreements and announce a revised pact.\n\nThe direct impact of the tariffs on world trade, assuming they take effect, will be minimal, economists say. Though steel plays a big role in the public imagination, it accounts for a sliver of global commerce.\n\nEconomists are more worried that a trade war will escalate. Many of the effects will be difficult to predict.\n\n\u201cWhen two elephants fight,\u201d said Miguel Ponce, head of Argentina\u2019s Center for the Study of Foreign Trade in the 21st Century, \u201cit is the grass that suffers the most.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Allies Brace for Trade War as Tariff Negotiations Stall", "authors": ["Jack Ewing", "Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe rest of 2018 seems well assured given the substantial support that is going to come from government fiscal policy,\u201d Mr. Tannenbaum said, referring to the $1.5 trillion cost of the tax cuts.\n\nHe noted, however, that \u201clonger term, the immediate benefits of tax reform will fade, and what we\u2019ll be left with is the bill.\u201d\n\nEconomists on Wall Street and in Washington have repeatedly warned that the economy\u2019s upward streak is unlikely to extend beyond the next year or two. The nation\u2019s debt has topped $21 trillion and is growing, a level many view as unsustainable. And if the Federal Reserve follows through on its plan to raise interest rates, the cost of paying off that debt will grow larger.\n\nIn the longer run, the Fed expects real annual growth in the United States to fall to 1.8 percent. The Congressional Budget Office\u2019s 10-year outlook comes to the same disappointing conclusion.\n\nThe Winter\u2019s Tale\n\nExpectations about the first-quarter figure had fluctuated as pieces of the puzzle emerged. Imports fell and exports rose more than expected, narrowing the merchandise trade deficit for the first time in six months. Orders of durable goods remained sluggish, but revived somewhat as commercial aircraft orders surged in March. And although consumers continued to express a lot of confidence, they pulled back on their spending.\n\nHoliday shopping in the final quarter of 2017 had revved up consumer spending \u2014 which accounts for more than two-thirds of the nation\u2019s economic activity \u2014 to 4 percent. Businesses responded by replenishing depleted inventories. But the shopping surge receded when the new year started; consumer spending grew only 1.1 percent in the first quarter.\n\nAlthough the tax overhaul promised to increase take-home pay, its effects may have been blunted for several reasons, including the time it took for the Internal Revenue Service to produce updated withholding tables and for payroll managers to adjust their systems. A poll of registered voters done in April and released this week by Politico/Morning Consult found that only about a fifth of those surveyed were noticing more money in their paychecks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI think the fact that we didn\u2019t see a big spurt in spending after the tax cut suggests it\u2019s either too early in the game or consumers are going to continue to be a bit cautious,\u201d said Kathy Bostjancic, chief United States financial economist at Oxford Economics. Nonetheless, she added, \u201cI think there is a legitimate question as to how much of the tax cuts get saved to pull down debt, and how much actually gets spent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for business spending, many of the tax incentives were aimed not at immediate investment decisions, but at those in the medium term. \u201cIt does take time for that to filter through,\u201d Ms. Bostjancic said. Some businesses may have also sped up their timetables for purchases at the end of 2017 in order to take advantage of bigger deductions before the tax changes went into effect.\n\nFor several years, first-quarter growth rates have been weaker than the longer-term trends indicated, only to rebound in later months. This year, the result could reflect a falloff in spending after an unusual surge that followed the havoc wrought by late-summer hurricanes. Severe winter weather could have also slowed consumption. But some analysts wonder if data adjustments are part of the problem.\n\nGovernment economists try to account for seasonal changes, but the corrective measures may be only partially successful. \u201cThere\u2019s a little weakness in Q1 and then the other quarters are artificially inflated because of that,\u201d Ms. Bostjancic said.\n\nPhoto\n\nLooking Ahead\n\nIn any case, the gross domestic product estimate released Friday by the Commerce Department is not the final word on the first quarter. The estimate will be revised twice in the next couple of months. In the past, the final number has been higher or lower by as much as a percentage point.\n\nThis G.D.P. report, though, is the latest that the Federal Reserve will have when its policymakers meet next week. At last month\u2019s meeting, Fed officials raised interest rates and affirmed that they expected two more increases this year. Their concern is that a tight labor market will push up inflation as employers increase wages to compete for workers.\n\nThe number of workers applying for jobless benefits last week fell to its lowest level in nearly 50 years. Salary and benefit costs to employers also increased, according to new figures released Friday.\n\nFor most Americans, who have seen little income growth in recent decades, though, fears of steeper inflation seem overblown. That is why some economists warn against raising rates too much and too fast, arguing that the increases will choke off the recovery.\n\n\n\nAt the conclusion of the March meeting, Jerome H. Powell, the new Fed chairman, said, \u201cWe\u2019re trying to take that middle ground.\u201d\n\nMichael Pearce, a senior economist at Capital Economics, said he did not expect the Fed\u2019s outlook to change much, regardless of Friday\u2019s report.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Fed already acknowledged some of the incoming data and that they think it could strengthen this year,\u201d he said. Last month, the central bank announced that it had raised its median estimate for annual growth this year to 2.7 percent, from 2.5 percent.", "title": "U.S. Economy Grew by 2.3% in First Quarter, Easing Slightly", "authors": ["Patricia Cohen"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 The police in Pakistan have charged a United States Embassy security officer with seeking to obstruct an investigation into a car accident involving an embassy vehicle, police officials said on Monday, adding to diplomatic tensions days after an American military attach\u00e9 was barred from leaving the country over a separate collision.\n\nThe arrest was made after an American diplomat\u2019s Toyota hit and injured two people on a motorcycle in Islamabad on Sunday evening, the police said. The injured people were hospitalized, and the diplomat, identified as Second Secretary Chad Rex Ausburn, was briefly detained before being released after the Foreign Ministry confirmed his diplomatic credentials.\n\nBut the police said that Taimur Iqbal Pirzada, a security adviser for the American Embassy, sought to obstruct an investigation of the accident and to stop officers from taking the diplomat and his vehicle to a police station. Mr. Pirzada was charged with obstruction and with using assault or criminal force to deter a public servant from carrying out duties. He was released on bail on Monday after appearing in court.\n\nThe Islamabad police also registered a case of reckless driving against the motorcycle driver, Nazakat Aslam, on Monday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA spokesman for the American Embassy in Islamabad was not available for comment.\n\nA State Department spokesman, Nolen Johnson, said the issue of the involvement of the diplomat in the accident had been resolved. \u201cWe are aware of a motor vehicle accident yesterday involving a U.S. Embassy diplomat,\u201d Mr. Johnson said in an email. \u201cThe issue of his involvement has now been resolved. The American public saw little of the engagement: a few photos of familiar-looking soldiers in familiar-looking armored vehicles. The White House and the Pentagon stressed that the war in Syria against the Islamic State was being waged by Kurdish and Arab allies \u2014 small groups that American commandos were just \u201cadvising and assisting.\u201d The American war, it seemed then, was primarily fought from the sky, taking the form of thousands of airstrikes.\n\n[The Times is reintroducing the At War blog, a forum for the firsthand experiences of global conflict.]\n\nAs the months passed, the number of American troops on the ground increased.\n\nToday roughly 2,000 American troops live in Syria. The Islamic State\u2019s de facto capital, Raqqa, is littered with rubble and explosives, and some of the Islamic State\u2019s holdouts occupy a small slice of the Euphrates River Valley. President Trump has said he wants the Pentagon\u2019s forces to leave.\n\n\u201cI want to get out \u2014 I want to bring our troops back home,\u201d Trump said on Tuesday during a news conference with leaders of Baltic nations. \u201cIt\u2019s time. We were very successful against ISIS.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrump\u2019s statement ran almost directly opposite Pentagon plans, which were communicated at roughly the same time Tuesday by Gen. Joseph L. Votel, the top officer at the military\u2019s United States Central Command. On Wednesday, Trump adopted the Pentagon\u2019s view. The White House released a statement saying that the American military was going nowhere until the Islamic State was \u201ceradicated\u201d in Syria.\n\nGot a confidential news tip for At War? The New York Times would like to hear from readers who want to share messages and materials with the At War team.\n\nAmid all the mixed messaging, images of newly built American bases in the Syrian city Manbij had already started appearing online. Heather Nauert, the department\u2019s spokeswoman, said in January that the Trump administration had not changed its policy regarding the term \u201coccupied territories.\u201d But in her remarks at the time, she carefully avoided using the word \u201coccupied,\u201d and on Friday, she and other officials declined to answer repeated questions about the word\u2019s almost complete banishment from the report.\n\nAs in previous versions, the report identifies problems in 194 nations while excluding the United States, an omission that has long prompted foreign countries to cry hypocrisy.\n\nAsked whether this year\u2019s frequent descriptions of news media suppression might be considered particularly problematic in light of President Trump\u2019s musings to reconsider libel laws and penchant for dismissing critical coverage as \u201cfake news,\u201d officials drew a strong line between insulting journalists and killing or jailing them.\n\n\u201cI think the report is very clear about the kind of things that we consider to be inappropriate restrictions on freedom of the media,\u201d said Michael G. Kozak, an ambassador and the senior official in the State Department\u2019s bureau of democracy, human rights and labor. He added that journalists in Cuba \u201calso get called names, but if it were limited to that, they\u2019d be pretty happy as compared to the situation they\u2019re in now.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Human Rights Report Labels Russia and China Threats to Global Stability", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "An AT&T spokesman said the company was \u201caware of the investigation,\u201d had provided information to the government and was working \u201cto move this issue forward.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nG.S.M.A. confirmed that it had developed an eSIM standard that would allow a carrier to lock a device to its network but put the standard on hold pending the Justice Department\u2019s investigation. Under the pending standard, the G.S.M.A. said, a wireless carrier would need permission from a consumer to lock a device.\n\n\u201cThe G.S.M.A. is cooperating fully with the Department of Justice in this matter,\u201d the organization said in a statement.\n\nAt the heart of the investigation is whether the nation\u2019s biggest wireless carriers, working with the G.S.M.A., secretly tried to influence mobile technology to unfairly maintain their dominance, in a way that hurt competition and consumers and hindered innovation in the wider mobile industry.\n\nAT&T and Verizon together control about 70 percent of all wireless subscriptions in the United States. A technology that made it easy to switch carriers could lead to more turnover and fewer subscribers for them.\n\nThe investigation highlights a push by the Justice Department\u2019s antitrust chief, Makan Delrahim, to crack down on the opaque world of intellectual property, or I.P., standards. He has said the Justice Department will scrutinize potential coordination in standards-setting organizations that can hurt competition.\n\n\u201cIn the context of antitrust and I.P., we will be inclined to investigate and enforce when we see evidence of collusive conduct undertaken for the purpose of fixing prices, or excluding particular competitors or products,\u201d Mr. Delrahim said in a speech this month at a conference in Washington. He previously warned of the potential for \u201ccartel-like behavior\u201d by competitors that got together with standards-setting organizations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, the Justice Department is suing AT&T to block its $85.4 billion merger with Time Warner. Mr. Delrahim has said the deal will hurt competition and lead to higher prices for cable customers. AT&T and Time Warner have strongly disputed the claims in a federal trial that is expected to end this month.\n\nPhoto\n\nCurrently, most mobile phones use SIM cards, which contain unique identifying information about a user and are inserted into the devices so the phones can function. People typically have to buy a new SIM card when changing carriers.\n\nThe eSIM technology, which was introduced in early 2016, is embedded in mobile phones and other devices so that people do not need SIM cards anymore.\n\nThe eSIM technology is supported by gadget makers including Apple, Google and Microsoft, as well as several wireless carriers globally and in the United States. The Apple Watch 3, Google Pixel 2 smartphone and Microsoft Surface all have eSIM abilities, for example. For companies like Apple, eSIM technology would free up storage space in devices to use for other technologies like bigger processors and batteries. It would also make it easier for people to use their devices while traveling for business.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe push by the major carriers to restrict the flexibility of eSIM runs counter to a movement in which consumers were gaining more flexibility to move from carrier to carrier. In late 2013, under pressure by the Federal Communications Commission, the wireless industry agreed to let people take devices off any particular network without penalty once the devices were fully paid for.\n\nAfter the formal complaints against AT&T and Verizon were filed, several device makers and other wireless companies voiced similar concerns to the agency about the carriers\u2019 actions around eSIM, four people familiar with the investigation said. The investigation may also include other major American carriers, another person said.\n\n\u201cThe actions would limit choice for consumers and harm competition,\u201d said Ferras Vinh, a policy expert at the Center for Democracy and Technology.\n\nIn a private meeting of a task force called G.S.M.A. North America this year, AT&T and Verizon pushed for the ability to lock phones to their networks, bypassing the purpose of eSIM technology, said Harold Feld, a senior vice president of Public Knowledge, a nonprofit consumer group, who was briefed on the meeting. Verizon has said it needed to be able to lock down phones to prevent theft and fraud.\n\n\u201cThere is a constant problem with industry standards-setting organizations that on the one hand allow the industry to come together for the purpose of efficiency but can be very anticompetitive and operate in secrecy,\u201d Mr. Feld said.", "title": "U.S. Investigating AT&T and Verizon Over Wireless Collusion Claim", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "March was the 90th consecutive month of job growth, by far the longest streak on record. Employers have added an average of just over 200,000 jobs per month so far in 2018, a pace that has held relatively steady for the past two years. The unemployment rate hasn\u2019t budged since October, but remains at its lowest level since 2000.\n\n\u201cThe fundamentals still remain solid,\u201d said Dan North, chief economist for Euler Hermes North America.\n\nThe slowdown in March wasn\u2019t a surprise. February\u2019s job growth was probably inflated by a surge in hiring in construction and the retail sector that reflected unseasonably warm weather in much of the country. Both sectors slumped in March as winter storms blew through the eastern United States.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve had such unsustainably strong results in January and February that it was largely expected that we were due for some payback,\u201d said Ellen Zentner, chief United States economist for Morgan Stanley. \u201cThe weak number in headline payrolls does not change the fact that trend job growth is strong.\u201d\n\nWaiting on Wages\n\nThe one dull spot in February\u2019s report was wage growth, which slowed from January. That figure was revised up slightly on Friday, and earnings rebounded further in March, rising 2.7 percent from a year earlier. Economists caution against reading too much into the month-to-month data on wages, which is volatile and prone to distortions.\n\nThe bigger picture is that wage growth remains weaker than most economists would expect when unemployment is so low. Economists have proposed a long list of possible explanations, from globalization to weak productivity growth. Most still expect employers to have to raise pay eventually to attract and retain workers. But so far, employers are resisting.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a standoff, almost, on wages,\u201d said Jason Guggisberg, a vice president at the staffing firm Adecco. \u201cWho\u2019s going to go first?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Manufacturing Picture\n\nPhoto\n\nThe manufacturing sector has posted solid job gains over the past year, and that growth continued in March, when American factories added 22,000 jobs. But mounting trade tensions with China could threaten the sector\u2019s rebound in the months ahead.\n\nPresident Trump announced late Thursday that he would consider imposing tariffs on an additional $100 billion worth of Chinese products, escalating the rapid-fire exchange of trade actions by the two countries. It isn\u2019t yet clear what impact the tariffs could have on the economy. But the threat alone could disrupt some companies\u2019 plans, economists said.\n\n\u201cWhether trade tensions and threats come to fruition or not, even if there\u2019s not follow-through, the lingering uncertainty and the market volatility that it creates will start to permeate business decisions and household decisions,\u201d Ms. Zentner said. Already, she said, there are signs that upper-income households are becoming less confident, a sentiment that could affect consumer spending.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWall Street and Washington\n\nInvestors and policymakers alike are watching the job market closely for signs that the economy could be starting to overheat. Markets tumbled after a report of unexpectedly strong wage growth in January led to fears of inflation, and the interest-rate hikes it could bring.\n\nThe market reaction to Friday\u2019s report was more muted. The uptick in wages was sufficient to suggest that the job market remains healthy, but probably not big enough to force the Federal Reserve to reconsider its policy of gradual rate increases, said Michelle Meyer, head of United States economics for Bank of America.\n\nIndeed, in a speech in Chicago on Friday, the Fed chairman, Jerome H. Powell, suggested his view of the economy had changed little in recent weeks.\n\n\u201cThe labor market remains strong, and my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee expect it to remain strong,\u201d Mr. Powell told the Economic Club of Chicago, according to prepared remarks released by the central bank. He added that he would be \u201clooking for an additional pickup in wage growth as the labor market strengthens further.\u201d\n\nMr. Powell\u2019s prepared remarks made no mention of the looming threat of a trade war with China. But Ms. Meyer said the added uncertainty surrounding trade could tend to make policymakers more cautious.\n\n\u201cThe risks have increased given some of the headlines around trade,\u201d Ms. Meyer said.\n\nSeeking Workers\n\nPerhaps the biggest surprise in the blockbuster report for February was the surge of workers into the labor force. That flood of new workers partly reversed in March, when the labor force shrank by 158,000 people. Beyond such monthly gyrations, however, the labor force has been growing gradually, an impressive feat given the ongoing retirement of the baby-boom generation.\n\nWith available workers increasingly scarce, companies are going to greater lengths to find potential employees. Some are hiring people with criminal records or loosening hiring requirements. Others are trying to entice people previously on the economy\u2019s sidelines, like at-home parents and recent retirees.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had more conversations about retirees in the last month than I have in the last year,\u201d said Becky Frankiewicz, president of ManpowerGroup, a staffing firm. \u201cThat\u2019s an ideal population because they\u2019re still highly skilled and they\u2019re experienced.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Job Growth Eased in March; Unemployment Steady at 4.1%", "authors": ["Ben Casselman"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 An American military attach\u00e9 has been barred from leaving Pakistan after his sport utility vehicle struck a motorcycle and killed one of its riders this month, in another flare-up of diplomatic tensions between the two countries.\n\nPakistani officials have demanded that the United States waive diplomatic immunity for the attach\u00e9, Col. Joseph E. Hall, so that he can face criminal trial, but American officials have refused, according to the Pakistani Foreign Ministry. Pakistani officials said that Colonel Hall faces a civil suit from the family of the rider, Ateeq Baig, and that on Tuesday he was barred from leaving the country.\n\nVideo of Colonel Hall\u2019s truck running a red light on April 7 as it struck the motorcycle, killing Mr. Baig and seriously injuring the other rider, has gone viral in Pakistan. Kills Man", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The Obama administration established the DACA program on the premise that children brought to the United States as children should be treated as low priorities for deportation.\n\n[ALSO READ: What is DACA? Who Are the Dreamers? Here are Some Answers]\n\nAbout 700,000 of the young undocumented immigrants \u2014 who are known as Dreamers \u2014 have signed up but must renew their DACA status every two years. The program also gives them the opportunity to work legally in the United States. Immigrants must be 15 years old to apply.\n\nVideo\n\nThe Trump administration officially rescinded DACA in March, but the previous court orders allowed the Dreamers to file their renewal applications as challenges to the Trump administration\u2019s move made it through the legal system.\n\nThe Supreme Court in late February declined an unusual White House request that it immediately decide whether the Trump administration can shut down the program.\n\nIn a statement released Tuesday night, the Justice Department said that it would \u201ccontinue to vigorously defend\u201d the legality of its decision to end the DACA program and that it looked \u201cforward to vindicating its position in further litigation.\u201d\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security \u201cacted within its lawful authority in deciding to wind down DACA in an orderly manner,\u201d the Justice Department statement said. \u201cPromoting and enforcing the rule of law is vital to protecting a nation, its borders, and its citizens.\u201d\n\nImmigration advocates hailed Judge Bates\u2019s ruling, saying it highlighted the failure of the administration to justify the program\u2019s termination.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cEither President Trump finds another way to end the program, tossing hundreds of thousands of young people into deportation proceedings,\u201d said Ali Noorani, executive director of the National Immigration Forum, an advocacy group in Washington, \u201cor he works with Republicans and Democrats to find a legislative solution.\u201d\n\nIn trying to close the program, the Trump administration argued that Mr. Obama had abused his authority and circumvented Congress to create DACA. President Trump urged Congress to find a legislative remedy to replace it and expressed support for giving the Dreamers a path to citizenship.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. That lawsuit was filed by the University of California, which is led by Janet Napolitano, who was the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security when the program began.\n\nThe next month, Judge Nicholas Garaufis of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn decided in favor of attorneys general from 15 states and several advocacy groups that sued to block the DACA rollback.\n\nUnder Judge Bates\u2019s ruling, unless the administration can justify its decision within 90 days, the cancellation of the program will be rescinded.\n\nThe latest lawsuit was brought by the N.A.A.C.P. as well as Princeton University and Microsoft.\n\n\u201cPrinceton higher education and our country benefit from the talent and aspirations that Dreamers bring to our communities,\u201d Christopher L. Eisgruber, the university president, said in a statement. \u201cWe continue to urge Congress to enact a permanent solution.\u201d\n\nStephen Yale-Loehr, a professor of immigration law at Cornell Law School, said that Judge Bates\u2019s ruling, if upheld on appeal, would \u201cbenefit tens of thousands of Dreamers.\u201d\n\nHasan Shafiqullah, director of the immigration law unit of the Legal Aid Society of New York, said the ruling ushered in hope, especially for younger siblings of DACA recipients who, as of last September were ineligible to apply because they were too young.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn three months\u2019 time, they might be able to submit a new application, Mr. Shafiqullah said, \u201cand at last be able to come out of the shadows, register for DACA, and \u2014 like their older siblings \u2014 more fully integrate into the fabric of our society.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Must Keep DACA and Accept New Applications, Federal Judge Rules", "authors": ["Miriam Jordan"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "A warning to Rafael Nadal and other notorious tennis procrastinators: The dawdling days of time-wasting between points and games are coming to an end, at least at Flushing Meadows.\n\nThe United States Open will use a 25-second serve clock at this year\u2019s event, which will be the first time such a system will be deployed in the main draw at a major tennis tournament.\n\nPlayers will now have 25 seconds from the end of a point to serve for the next one. If they don\u2019t, they will face consequences, which have yet to be finalized. The first violation could incur a warning, followed by the loss of a point and then the loss of a game.\n\nThe U.S. Open will also enforce a seven-minute warm-up period before each match to ensure they start on time. Players will have one minute from the time they walk on court to meet at the net for the coin flip. Then they will have five minutes to warm up and another minute before the first serve. Violators could be fined $20,000.", "title": "U.S. Open Will Use a Serve Clock in the Main Draw", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "The murder of Mr. Camarena remains one of the most significant losses in the history of the D.E.A. It galvanized the Reagan-era war on drugs, leading to the nationwide institution of the \u201cRed Ribbon Week,\u201d an annual drug awareness effort.\n\nMr. Camarena is still honored regularly at D.E.A. offices across the country, where the horror of the 1985 episode lingers. \u201cThe investigation of Kiki Camarena\u2019s death is still an open wound,\u201d said John C. Lawn, who led the agency from 1985 to 1990.\n\n\u201cWhat is meaningful to D.E.A.,\u201d Mr. Lawn added, \u201cis that Caro is on the loose and has been, and we don\u2019t believe that the Mexican government is doing all they can to find him.\u201d\n\nMr. Caro Quintero initially evaded the authorities in 1985 with the help of a Mexican federal police officer, who was later charged over his role in the escape. The drug kingpin was released in 2013 after his conviction was overturned by a Mexican federal judge, who ruled that Mr. Caro Quintero should have been tried in state court \u2014 not federal court \u2014 decades before. He quickly disappeared.\n\nIn a letter days after Mr. Caro Quintero\u2019s release, nine previous D.E.A. administrators said it had driven \u201ca spike in the heart of Mexican-American bilateral drug enforcement efforts.\u201d The D.E.A. at the time called it \u201cdeeply troubling.\u201d\n\nThe release happened even as Justice Department authorities said they had made consistently clear to the Mexican government that they were interested in extraditing Mr. Caro Quintero. His lawyers have asked the judge, Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court, to \u201ctemper justice with mercy.\u201d They argued that federal guidelines call for only four to five years in prison and that Mr. Atilla should serve \u201csignificantly below\u201d that.\n\nBut prosecutors told the judge that at a time when the United States and other nations \u201cwere engaged in the momentous undertaking of depriving the government of Iran of funding for its malign and deadly activities\u201d \u2014 including its pursuit of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, and its support of terrorism \u2014 \u201cAtilla was a key player in massively undermining those efforts.\u201d\n\nIn seeking the stiffer penalty, the government said that Mr. Atilla\u2019s sentence should be more than 15\u00bd years and comparable to 20-year sentences imposed in \u201canalogous cases.\u201d\n\n\u201cAtilla\u2019s offenses simultaneously opened a multibillion-dollar channel of illicit funding for the government of Iran and relieved crucial financial pressure on Iran during negotiations to limit its nuclear program,\u201d the office of Geoffrey S. Berman, the United States attorney in Manhattan, wrote.\n\nMr. Caglayan, Mr. Aslan and five other Turkish and Iranian defendants charged in the case have not been arrested, Mr. Berman\u2019s office noted, adding, \u201cThere appears little prospect that any will be extradited in light of their nationalities.\u201d", "title": "U.S. Seeks 20-Year Prison Term for Turkish Banker in Sanctions Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Antonio Ortiz-Mena, a former Mexican diplomat in the United States, said he believed a deal would be possible in the coming weeks if negotiators were prepared to compromise. However, he said, \u201cI think the biggest threat to Nafta is the United States overplaying its hand and not being flexible enough.\u201d\n\nThe Nafta provision regarding automobiles has been among the most contentious, given Mr. Trump\u2019s focus on the car industry and its importance to all three nations\u2019 economies.\n\nAmerican negotiators have dropped an earlier demand that half of the value of an automobile be made solely in the United States to qualify for Nafta\u2019s zero tariffs. Instead, they are asking for an unspecified percentage of each vehicle to be made by workers earning at least an average wage rate for the North American industry, to be recalculated each year. According to preliminary calculations, that wage could be approximately $16 to $17 an hour.\n\nHowever, other parts of the proposal are unchanged, or add layers of rules. In keeping with its earlier proposal, the United States is asking for 85 percent of the value of a car to be made in North America to qualify for Nafta\u2019s benefits, up from 62.5 percent under the current Nafta deal. But it has set up a complex tiered system for other auto parts, for example requiring 85 percent of engines and advanced batteries to be made in North America, as well as 70 percent of monitors, wiring sets and autonomous vehicles parts, and 50 percent of brake pads and spark plugs.\n\nIt also requires 70 percent of certain auto parts made of steel and aluminum to be made in North America \u2014 a further boon to the American steel and aluminum industry, which the Trump administration has sought to protect.\n\nThese auto rules may be subject to a periodic review, for example every five years. Car companies would have three years to work on redesigning their supply chains before the rules went into effect.\n\nMexico has countered with an offer to raise the overall requirement for North American content in Nafta cars to 70 percent, up from 62.5 percent currently, people close to the talks said. It has also agreed to accept a proposal by Canada to add in the value of research and development when calculating how much of a car is produced in North America. But Mexico continues to reject the other provisions in the American proposal on automobiles, and insists that the industry be given seven years to transition to the new rules, rather than three.", "title": "U.S. Seeks Quick Nafta Deal, but Allies Balk as It Gives Little Ground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Transferring the man would render moot several important and unresolved legal questions raised by his case. Chutkan of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, had legitimate authority to order the government to give him at least 72 hours\u2019 notice before any transfer.\n\nThe man was born in the United States to visiting Saudi parents, making him an American citizen, but raised in Saudi Arabia, where he became a dual citizen.\n\nHe was captured by a Syrian militia in September and turned over to American forces as a suspected low-level Islamic State member, raising a dilemma about what to do with him. While security officials wanted him to remain locked up somewhere, Justice Department officials struggled to assemble sufficient courtroom evidence to prosecute him.\n\nIn the court filing on Tuesday, the Justice Department redacted details about the proposed transfer. But it said that after \u201cextensive discussion\u201d with his lawyer about the option, the man had decided not to consent to the transfer. But many of the adult listings were simply rerouted to sections of the site dedicated to dating.\n\nRevenue at Backpage increased to $135 million in 2014 from $5.3 million in 2008, according to a Senate report last year.
