Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Cato Institute report comes a week before the Supreme Court hears arguments in a challenge to the travel ban, the first version of which Mr. Trump announced a week into his presidency. The latest version of the ban, run by the State Department and Department of Homeland Security, had restricted travelers from eight countries \u2014 six of them predominantly Muslim \u2014 from entering the United States, though Chad was removed from the list last week.\n\nA group that is challenging the ban \u2014 including several individuals, a Muslim organization and the State of Hawaii \u2014 argues that the order amounts to a broad exclusion of visitors based largely on religion and national origin.\n\n\n\nThe Justice Department defended the executive order as barring a large number of people \u201cabout whom the United States lacks sufficient information to assess the risks they pose.\u201d\n\nMr. Bier said the government created a number of new agencies and improved methods to identify suspicious travelers after the 2001 attacks. That included creating terrorist watch lists, purchasing technologies to collect digital fingerprints and facial scans, hiring thousands of new border customs and immigration officers and revamping the visa approval process.\n\nThe Obama administration also tightened the American visa waiver program, making it harder for travelers to enter the United States from Europe if they had dual citizenship from Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria, or had visited one of those countries in the past five years. The administration later added Libya, Somalia and Yemen to the restricted list.\n\nThe Cato report concluded that the gamut of security measures, which reaches across the globe, already reduces the risk of terrorists slipping into the United States through the immigration system to attack.\n\n\u201cWhile people of all types \u2014 foreign-born or U.S.-born \u2014 will always pose certain risks to the country, the country has maxed out its capacity to improve immigration vetting,\u201d Mr. Bier wrote.", "title": "U.S. Vetting System Already Robust Before Travel Ban, Report Finds", "authors": ["Ron Nixon"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "For the United States, victory in such a war would be difficult to verify, much less achieve.\n\nChina could say it plans to ease back on government support. But that could be difficult to quantify because of the country\u2019s opaque political system and the state\u2019s control of information.\n\nChina could back off from rules that favor local competitors and require American companies to share technology if they want access to the Chinese market. For example, foreign automakers face pressure to transfer electric-car technology to their local partners, and foreign technology companies are increasingly required to submit to security reviews. Foreign businesses have long complained that many of the rules they must follow are unwritten.\n\nChina\u2019s government-financed campaign is already paying off in some ways. Drive into downtown Shanghai from Pudong International Airport and you pass a seemingly endless series of huge hangars and vast, glass-walled design centers, all part of the country\u2019s effort to create a commercial aircraft manufacturing giant to rival Boeing or Airbus. Travel to factory districts in Shanghai and on the outskirts of many other Chinese cities and you see enormous, newly built factories ready to churn out electric cars, the batteries they use and other components.\n\nProving that the Chinese government unfairly supports the effort could be difficult, however.\n\nThe United States could press its argument with the World Trade Organization, which oversees global trading rules and prohibits big loans from government-controlled banks at artificially low interest rates. But the W.T.O. requires many contracts and government documents to prove cases, evidence that can be hard to get in a tightly controlled country like China.\n\nEven when the W.T.O. rules against China, persuading the country to comply can be challenging. One such ruling, involving China\u2019s restrictions on foreign electronic payment systems, was issued nearly six years ago. China is still mulling how it will comply \u2014 despite numerous complaints from the Obama administration and more recent nudges from the Trump administration.\n\nSo the United States has turned to tariffs. That means it is using a 1980s tool to address an industrial policy issue that is already shaping the 21st century.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s top trade official, Robert Lighthizer, was a deputy United States trade representative under President Ronald Reagan. The tariffs that Mr. Lighthizer threatened against Japan in those days are among the same ones he is wielding now. But the two periods differ in two big ways.\n\nOne is that Japan depended on the United States in the \u201980s for military protection from the Soviet Union. China, by contrast, is an increasingly assertive global rival, sending naval vessels to the Baltic Sea and building a naval base in East Africa.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe second major difference between then and now is that the European Union deeply resented the tariffs of the 1980s, and Mr. Trump\u2019s use of them could make it difficult to persuade European officials to present a united front. In response to American tariffs, Beijing could simply shift business from American companies like Boeing and Ford to European rivals like Airbus and Daimler.\n\nChinese officials dispute the American accusations about their unfair trade practices. They say Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs violate W.T.O. rules, and they dispute claims that China forces American companies to hand over technology. As for Made in China 2025, Chinese officials say the plan is only guidance, not a government directive \u2014 and that foreign companies are free to participate, too.\n\nIn China\u2019s current industrial policy, the Trump administration sees an extension of how the country has already come to dominate one major industry of the future: solar power.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump himself is no fan of solar panels. He has spoken enthusiastically about coal, not renewable energy, throughout his campaign and his presidency. But the solar power industry is one of the biggest success stories so far in China\u2019s efforts involving advanced industries.\n\nThe United States played a central role in developing solar panels and manufacturing them until a decade ago. Around then, the Chinese government decided to finance a lavish expansion of the sector. State-controlled banks lent tens of billions of dollars at low interest rates despite the high-profile bankruptcies of solar manufacturers.\n\nChinese firms now produce three-quarters of the world\u2019s solar panels. Most American and European companies have closed factories, and many have become insolvent. China\u2019s success in producing solar panels has given Beijing a blueprint for seizing the lead in a long list of other high-tech industries.\n\nMany foreign companies are caught between China\u2019s industrial ambitions and Washington\u2019s efforts to stop them, including major aerospace companies and carmakers. The conflict may spread: Made in China 2025 could create major competitors to General Electric and Intel, and to companies outside the United States like Siemens and Samsung.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTariffs could hurt such companies if the United States and China follow through on their plans. They also risk losing their competitiveness if Beijing succeeds in subsidizing the creation of large Chinese rivals in their industries.\n\nBoeing, for example, could be hit by American tariffs on civilian aircraft parts it buys from Avic, a state-controlled Chinese military and aviation company \u2014 required purchases if the company, which is based in Chicago, wants to sell planes in China. China, in turn, is pushing a consortium that includes Avic to become a Boeing rival. Boeing, like other multinational companies, has refrained from endorsing or criticizing the tariffs.\n\n\u201cAlthough our members are unhappy with retaliatory tariffs being used,\u201d said Kenneth Jarrett, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai, \u201cthere is a belief that greater pressure has to be brought to bear on China.\u201d", "title": "U.S. and China Play Chicken on Trade, and Neither Swerves", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "News reports in South Korea and the United States have mentioned Geneva and the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator, as possible venues.\n\nMr. Moon has tried to be a mediator between Mr. Kim and Mr. Trump. His envoys met with the North Korean leader in Pyongyang in March, and went to Washington soon afterward to tell Mr. Trump that Mr. Kim wanted to talk.\n\nAccording to South Korean officials and analysts, Mr. Moon hopes for a \u201ccomprehensive deal\u201d in which Mr. Kim would commit to dismantling his nuclear arsenal and Mr. Trump would reciprocate by offering security guarantees for the North, including normalized ties with Washington.\n\nBut implementing such a deal would probably be extremely complicated and protracted. Past talks between North Korea and the United States have had similar aims, but they all collapsed in the early stages, over disputes about freezing the North\u2019s nuclear activities and how such a freeze would be verified.\n\nNorth Korea, as it has in the past, insists on a \u201cphased\u201d and \u201csynchronized\u201d implementation of any denuclearization deal. According to former South Korean officials who have dealt with the North, it fears that any deal it signs with Washington could come to an end after a change in American administrations. So rather than surrender its nuclear facilities up front, it wants incremental steps, matched with corresponding incentives from the United States.\n\nFor their part, American officials have said that North Korea has never been sincere in dealing with them, using negotiations to buy time while persisting in clandestine nuclear weapons development. Some hard-liners in Washington, like Mr. Trump\u2019s new national security adviser, John R. Bolton, have demanded a quick dismantling of the North\u2019s nuclear weapons program, suspecting that the North only wants to ease the tough international sanctions against it in exchange for a temporary, and deceptive, freezing of its nuclear program.\n\nSouth Korea hopes that North Korea and the United States will agree on a road map toward denuclearization and quickly implement key steps before Mr. Trump\u2019s term ends in January 2021, according to scholars advising Mr. Moon\u2019s government. Mr. Trump characterized it as the beginning of a sustained effort to force Mr. Assad to stop using banned weapons, but only ordered a limited, one-night operation that hit three targets.\n\n\u201cThese are not the actions of a man,\u201d Mr. Trump said of last weekend\u2019s suspected chemical attack in a televised address from the White House Diplomatic Room. \u201cThey are Syria Over Suspected Chemical Weapons Attack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Ciaran Martin, chief executive of Britain\u2019s National Cyber Security Center, said Russia had targeted \u201cmillions\u201d of devices in both countries, often seeking to hack into individual homes or small businesses or to control their routers.\n\n\u201cOnce you own the router, you own all the traffic, to include the chance to harvest credentials and passwords,\u201d said Howard Marshall, deputy assistant director of the cyber division at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. \u201cIt is a tremendous weapon in the hands of an adversary.\u201d\n\nIn particular, both governments said, Russians were seeking to exploit the increasing popularity of internet-connected devices around homes and businesses \u2014 the so-called internet of things \u2014 \u201cthe kind of thing you and I have in our homes,\u201d Mr. Joyce said.\n\nThe officials said the Kremlin was often utilizing what were known as man-in-the-middle attacks, in which hackers secretly inserted themselves into the exchange of data between a computer or server in order to eavesdrop, collect confidential information, misdirect payments or further compromise security.\n\n\u201cRussian state-sponsored actors are using compromised routers to conduct spoofing \u2018man-in-the-middle\u2019 attacks to support espionage, extract intellectual property, maintain persistent access to victim networks and potentially lay a foundation for future offensive operations,\u201d the British government said in a prepared statement. \u201cMultiple sources including private and public-sector cybersecurity research organizations and allies have reported this activity to the U.S. and U.K. governments.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut the officials said that the extent of Russia\u2019s successful penetration of Western computer networks was not fully clear, nor was the Kremlin\u2019s ultimate intent. Russia might be tapping into millions of home or small business computers and other devices to gain the ability to use them later in a coordinated attack on government computers or critical infrastructure, the officials said.\n\nThe goal \u201cis not always to steal information,\u201d Mr. Joyce said. \u201cSometimes it is to facilitate other operations\u201d or \u201cfor further aggressive acts.\u201d\n\nThe warnings issued Monday, including the release of technical guidance to businesses and individuals, had been in the works for a long period and do not reflect any response to recent events, the officials said. But the finger pointing toward Moscow also comes at a moment of escalating tensions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussian diplomats have castigated the United States, Britain and France for their airstrikes last week on what they said were chemical weapons facilities in Syria, where the Kremlin is backing the government of President Bashar al-Assad. Russia and the Western governments have also recalled diplomats in a back and forth over British accusations that the Kremlin used a nerve agent to try to assassinate a former Russian spy living near London.\n\nIn Washington, both Democrats and Republicans have criticized President Trump for what they say is his reluctance to hold Russia accountable for its hacking of the Democrats during the 2016 presidential election; American intelligence agencies have also blamed the Kremlin for those attacks.\n\nAgainst that backdrop, Washington and London have been moving together for months to publicize allegations of other malicious cyberactivities by the Kremlin. In February, they blamed Russia for a cyberattack the previous June that was known as NotPetya. Initially aimed at Ukraine, the attack spread through computer networks around the world, doing what the White House said was billions of dollars in damages in the United States, Europe and Asia.\n\nBoth the United States and Britain have accused the Kremlin of trying to penetrate the electrical grid in both countries, although without yet doing any damage.\n\nAfter describing the Russian threats, officials of both governments on Monday repeatedly urged individuals and businesses to better protect their own networks. \u201cWe need to place as much emphasis on security as we do on ease and functionality,\u201d Mr. Joyce urged manufacturers.", "title": "U.S.-U.K. Warning on Cyberattacks Includes Private Homes", "authors": ["David D. Nous nous entretenons d\u2019abord au fastueux H\u00f4tel Le St-James de Montr\u00e9al, puis nous migrons vers la belle demeure \u00e9douardienne de l\u2019artiste, qui, note-t-il, rappelle les chinoiseries \u00e9carlates du somptueux appartement de Diana Vreeland \u00e0 New York.\n\n\u00ab Toutes ces ann\u00e9es, j\u2019ai carbur\u00e9 \u00e0 la nostalgie : celle d\u2019une enfance que je n\u2019aurai jamais eue. \u00bb\n\nMenu et d\u00e9licat, une veste \u00e0 capuchon sur le dos et un tatouage du Dumbledore d\u2019Harry Potter au bras gauche, Dolan assaisonne nos \u00e9changes de mots tels prolix et epistolary, en anglais, passant rarement au fran\u00e7ais pour souligner un point. T\u00f4t dans la vie, il comprend qu\u2019il doit ma\u00eetriser la langue de Shakespeare s\u2019il veut conqu\u00e9rir Hollywood, ce qui l\u2019am\u00e8ne \u00e0 utiliser une partie de ses cachets d\u2019enfant vedette pour suivre des cours d\u2019anglais chez Berlitz.\n\nEn personne, Xavier Dolan est \u00e0 la fois exub\u00e9rant et intellectuel, entre l\u2019humour et l\u2019autod\u00e9rision.\n\nIl a parfois \u00e9t\u00e9 clou\u00e9 au pilori pour son audace et son arrogance, et a souvent \u00e9t\u00e9 qualifi\u00e9 d\u2019\u00ab enfant terrible \u00bb, une \u00e9tiquette qui l\u2019horripile. Il s\u2019agit peut-\u00eatre du prix \u00e0 payer, pour un r\u00e9alisateur tour \u00e0 tour compar\u00e9 \u00e0 Alfred Hitchcock, Woody Allen et Arthur Rimbaud.\n\nIl pond son premier sc\u00e9nario apr\u00e8s avoir d\u00e9croch\u00e9 du coll\u00e8ge, \u00e0 17 ans : c\u2019est J\u2019ai tu\u00e9 ma m\u00e8re, une \u0153uvre semi-autobiographique vaguement freudienne, \u00e0 propos d\u2019un adolescent homosexuel refoul\u00e9 qui se r\u00e9volte contre sa m\u00e8re. L\u2019un apr\u00e8s l\u2019autre, les producteurs l\u00e8vent le nez sur son projet. Il d\u00e9cide alors d\u2019investir toutes ses \u00e9conomies d\u2019enfant acteur afin de r\u00e9aliser lui-m\u00eame le film, de renomm\u00e9e internationale. Quand il d\u00e9clare plus tard qu\u2019Orson Welles, signant Citizen Kane \u00e0 25 ans, a \u00ab commenc\u00e9 sur le tard \u00bb, il suscite un toll\u00e9 et finit par expliquer sur Twitter qu\u2019il blaguait.", "title": "Un prodige du cin\u00e9ma dont l\u2019enfance perdue nourrit l\u2019art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "In short, adjustments, yes, wholesale revisions, no. There are several reasons for this caution. One has to do with preserving the industry\u2019s reputation and satisfying what amounts to its historical obligation. The Obama administration rules were plenty tough, calling for a doubling in fuel economy for new cars and light trucks, to more than 50 miles per gallon by 2025, equivalent to a real-world average of 36 m.p.g. But the automakers signed on, not least because multibillion-dollar bailouts by the Bush and Obama administrations kept them afloat, for which they still owe the American taxpayer a very big thank-you. Backsliding now on public health and the environment would not do the automakers a lot of good.\n\nA second reason is California. Because of its uniquely severe smog problems, and because its clean air rules predate federal rules, California has been allowed under the Clean Air Act to set its own, and traditionally tougher, air pollution standards, as long as it is granted a waiver by the federal government to do so. This in effect has confronted the automobile industry with the need to manufacture two versions of its cars \u2014 one for California and the dozen states that have adopted California\u2019s standards, and another for the rest of the country.\n\nPart of the genius of the Obama program was that it harmonized California\u2019s rules and the federal rules. But if the Trump administration tries to undermine this deal, California has said that it will once again go its own way, fracturing the American car and light truck market. Automakers don\u2019t need that headache and expense.\n\nThere\u2019s always a chance that a determined Mr. Pruitt, who deeply resents California\u2019s aggressiveness on this and other clean air issues, could try to revoke California\u2019s waiver and force the state to toe the federal line \u2014 something he signaled in a statement on Monday. That would inspire a legal donnybrook that Mr. Pruitt has no guarantee of winning and would make his efforts look even more feckless and destructive. California is \u201cprepared to take any and all legal action\u201d to protect its air emissions standards, Xavier Becerra, the state\u2019s attorney general, said last week.\n\nFinally, there is scant evidence that the automakers want to slow the steady march toward cleaner cars. Mary Barra, General Motors\u2019 chief executive, has expressed support for the current nationwide standards, which can only improve Detroit\u2019s competitiveness in an increasingly climate-conscious global market. Though sales of electric vehicles represent barely 1 percent of global car sales, China has a new zero-emission-vehicle mandate, which requires that 12 percent of new cars have no tailpipe emissions. France and Britain have pledged to end the sale of diesel and gas cars by 2040.", "title": "Opinion | Unclean at Any Speed: Pruitt\u2019s Attack on Obama Auto Pollution Rule", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Scott Lloyd\u2019s unadorned job title betrays little hint of the power he has over the pregnant teenagers in his custody.\n\nAs director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement, he oversees the assistance program for the tens of thousands of refugees who still seek shelter in the United States, even with the Trump administration\u2019s crackdown. But as the government official who is also responsible for the care of young, undocumented immigrants who enter the United States without their parents, he spends much of his time trying to stop those who want an abortion.\n\nHe has instructed his staff to give him a spreadsheet each week that tells him about any unaccompanied minors who have asked for one and how far along they are in their pregnancy. In at least one case he directed staff to read to one girl a description of what happens during an abortion. And when there\u2019s a need for counseling, Mr. Lloyd\u2019s office calls on someone from its list of preferred \u201clife affirming\u201d pregnancy resource centers.\n\nLast fall Mr. Lloyd\u2019s refusal to let a 17-year-old in Texas leave the shelter where she was living to get an abortion drew an admonishment from a federal judge who said she was \u201castounded\u201d the government had been so insistent on keeping someone from obtaining a constitutionally protected procedure. Last week another judge barred him from trying to prevent any girl in his care from getting an abortion, but government lawyers have asked for a stay and plan to appeal.", "title": "Under Trump, an Office Meant to Help Refugees Enters the Abortion Wars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "The hiring-then-firing of Kevin Williamson followed a familiar script. A mainstream media organization hires a conservative in the name of intellectual diversity, then is shocked, shocked to discover that he\u2019s dishonest and/or holds truly reprehensible views \u2013 something that the organization could have discovered with a few minutes on Google. But when the bad hire is let go, the right treats him as a martyr, proof of liberal refusal to let alternative viewpoints be heard. Why does this keep happening?\n\nAs others have pointed out, the real problem here is that media organizations are looking for unicorns: serious, honest, conservative intellectuals with real influence. Forty or fifty years ago, such people did exist. But now they don\u2019t.\n\nTo understand why, let me talk about what I know: the field of economics. This happens to be a field with a relatively strong conservative presence compared to other social sciences, and as far as I can tell even contains considerably more self-identified conservatives/Republicans than hard science. Even so, trying to find influential conservative economic intellectuals is basically a hopeless task, for two reasons.\n\nFirst, while there are many conservative economists with appointments at top universities, publications in top journals, and so on, they have no influence on conservative policymaking. What the right wants are charlatans and cranks, in (conservative) Greg Mankiw\u2019s famous phrase. If they use actual economists, they use them the way a drunkard uses a lamppost: for support, not illumination.", "title": "Opinion | Unicorns of the Intellectual Right", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "If there was one broad takeaway from the data leak involving Cambridge Analytica, the voter profiling firm that obtained private information from up to 87 million Facebook accounts, it\u2019s that you should hesitate before sharing your data with an unknown brand.\n\nThis lesson applies to just about everything that touches your personal technology, including the apps that you download to your phone or computer and the free online services that you use. And, yes, it also includes those seemingly harmless personality tests run by some unfamiliar organization on Facebook \u2014 the kind that helped Cambridge Analytica get the data on users.\n\nTo make matters worse, the information that can be stolen from you is becoming increasingly personal. Smartphones, for one, are embedded with microphones, motion sensors and cameras that can spy on your every move if corrupted by a bad actor. Home gadgets like internet-connected thermostats, power outlets and audio speakers are capable of collecting information about what you are doing at home, including listening to your conversations, and knowing when you are away from home.\n\nIt\u2019s time to stop using technology and the internet as though you were shopping at a supermarket. In a grocery store, you can reasonably assume that the food labels are accurate and the products safe to eat, because the food industry is heavily regulated. The handling of personal digital information, in contrast, is loosely regulated. There have been scores of obscure companies baiting you with products that purport to improve your life \u2014 but actually capitalize on your data.", "title": "Unknown Tech Brands Aren\u2019t Like Groceries. Don\u2019t Just Grab Them.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "In an interview last December, when the Ghent works were still on display, Mr. Toporovski said that he had acquired most of the works in Russia in the early 1990s.\n\n\u201cIn Russia these artists practically never sold before the Revolution,\u201d he said. \u201cThere were no galleries. This art was a little bit out of the market. That\u2019s why the provenances are quite special.\u201d\n\nMr. Zarug, in his interview, also spoke of how challenging it was to find art from the period with extensive exhibition or ownership histories.\n\nInitially a dealer who focused on Judaica, antique books and manuscripts, Mr. Zarug said he began hunting for things to buy in the Soviet Union after the fall of the Berlin Wall. \u201cThe U.S.S.R. in 1990 was like the Wild West,\u201d he said. Mr. Zarug said his diversification into Russian avant-garde art happened by chance. One of the dealers he had been working with regularly in Moscow offered him a painting attributed to Lissitzky for $3,000, he said, and back home in Israel, he displayed the painting for gallery owners in an exhibition in his office. The first person to arrive \u201cdidn\u2019t even look at the Judaica, he just looked at the painting,\u201d Mr. Zarug said. \u201cI saw his interest and understood it was something of value, so I thought I would ask a very high price. I asked for $30,000. He said O.K.\u201d\n\nMr. Zarug said he immediately returned to Moscow, bought another three paintings, and sold them to a dealer in Israel for a vast profit.\n\nAs he began searching for art in earnest across the Soviet Union, Mr. Zarug said he discovered huge stores of neglected paintings. On one occasion, he said, he found 100 pictures in very bad condition covered with a dust sheet in an attic in Moscow and bought them for $1,000 each. On another, he said, he was taken to a deserted building in Azerbaijan where he was offered 206 paintings \u2014 including works he said are by Malevich and Kandinsky. In Tajikistan, the staff members of a museum sold him artworks directly from the basement, he said.", "title": "Unknown or Unreal? The Shadow on Some Russian Avant-Garde Art", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Billy Joel\u2019s \u201cUptown Girl,\u201d released in 1983, was, on the surface, about the working-class Long Island rocker wooing the rich model Christie Brinkley. But the song was more deeply about a famed Manhattan boundary, one insurmountable at the time: \u201cUptown\u201d was shorthand for the well-lit East Side corridor where nouvelle society, powered by the Wall Street boom, resided in splendor. \u201cDowntown\u201d was the shadowy province beneath 14th Street \u2014 a countercultural warren of tenement walk-ups and industrial loft spaces.\n\nSuch a duality seems quaint now that artists are being priced out of Ridgewood, Queens, and billionaires range freely in aeries from Central Park South to Little West 12th Street, but in the early \u201980s, where you lived was an inarguable announcement of your politics, your values and your status. To say you lived uptown, even if you rented in a white brick 1960s building on upper Second Avenue, was to suggest where you longed to be: in a duplex at 740 Park Avenue like the one designed by Mark Hampton for the corporate raider Saul Steinberg and his third wife, Gayfryd, the couple who defined the era\u2019s excess. The burnt-umber brocade walls of their 34-room apartment, with its George II gilt-wood chairs and antique ormolu tables, were hung with Old Masters; on the marble mantel sat a harp that neither inhabitant knew how to play.\n\nTo declare yourself \u201cdowntown\u201d meant that as you lay on your futon next to the bathtub in a sublet studio on St. Marks Place, you imagined yourself an artist in a cavernous former factory in the no man\u2019s land that people had recently christened TriBeCa, living inside a loft with whitewashed walls, built-in platforms covered with gray industrial carpet, curved glass-brick partitions and steel tables by the designer Joe D\u2019Urso. Not everything was monochrome in the land of lofts, of course: For a jolt of color and madness, there were paintings by Neo-Expressionists, including David Salle, Eric Fischl and Julian Schnabel. The design world was also enraptured by Memphis, the Milan-based collective started by Ettore Sottsass in 1981. Few New Yorkers actually accessorized their homes with those Tinkertoy shapes in Crayola-color lacquer, but Memphis had an outsize influence; omnipresent in home design magazines, it was a playful reminder not to take Minimalism too seriously.\n\nAnd while the uptown aesthetic of these years may now seem anachronistic \u2014 cluttered with Louis XV canopy beds and gold-leaf mirrors \u2014 it was, in fact, its own revolution. Decorators like Hampton \u2014 and like Angelo Donghia, who outfitted apartments for Diana Ross and Ralph Lauren before dying of an AIDS-related illness in 1985 \u2014 transformed grand Fifth Avenue domiciles once bedecked with uncomfortable, inherited cane-backed settees into cushy sanctuaries adorned with the pattern-mad chintz of English country manors. Hampton developed formal window treatments \u2014 elaborately layered swags and jabots \u2014 for the homes of Est\u00e9e Lauder and others, while Donghia brought in enormous palms and poufs upholstered in men\u2019s flannel suiting fabrics. This style, an over-the-top celebration of WASP culture that was, ironically, on its way out, was in perfect harmony with mainstream fashion\u2019s embrace of ruffly Laura Ashley dresses and the popped collars of preppydom.", "title": "Uptown or Downtown? In the Early \u201980s, It Made All the Difference", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFor G.O.P., Threat of Impeachment May Spur Voters\u201d (front page, April 9):\n\nIt is particularly disappointing that in the campaign for the November elections, the G.O.P.\u2019s strategy will be the scare tactic of possible impeachment of the president should the Democrats win the House. Have they nothing else to present to the electorate? Like plans and ideas for the real problems and issues facing the country?\n\nThat the G.O.P. and its supporters will be using words such as \u201ccoup\u201d reveals their fear of having genuine and substantive discussions regarding policies and programs.\n\nRICHARD ANDRESEN, LOLETA, CALIF.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMany Republicans, both right-wing and moderate, are totally disgusted with President Trump and would much prefer the true ideologue, Mike Pence, as their president. I suspect they are kneeling in prayer for impeachment and conviction. They may be so upset that they could hold their noses to vote Democratic and for possible impeachment.\n\nConversely, there are many Democratic voters, especially on the left, who fear a purely ideological right-wing Pence presidency to the point of joining Republicans in opposing impeachment. This would militate against Republican fears of losing their president, and makes the possibility of Democrats taking Congress more probable. Go figure.", "title": "Opinion | Using Impeachment Fears to Energize the G.O.P.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nValerie Veatch and Benjamin Michael John Rampton were married March 31 at the Fourth Universalist Society in New York. The Rev. Carolyn Strauss, a Universal Life Church minister, performed the ceremony.\n\nThe bride, 32, is a documentary filmmaker based in New York. She directed and edited \u201cMe @ The Zoo,\u201d a documentary on HBO in 2012 and again in 2013, and also directed and produced \u201cLove Child,\u201d another documentary on HBO in 2014 and 2015. She graduated with distinction from the New School.\n\nShe is a daughter of Christina Marie Kimball and Kevin Veatch, both of Seattle. The bride\u2019s father is a creative director and music producer there. Her mother is a business coach and a fleet captain at the Seattle Yacht Club.\n\nThe groom, 35, is a vice president specializing in prime brokerage at JPMorgan Chase in New York. He graduated from Edinburgh University, from which he received a master\u2019s in classics.\n\nHe is a son of Janet Rampton and Christopher Rampton, both of London. The groom\u2019s father is the director of LTT Capital Partners, an investment management firm in London.\n\nThe couple met in June 2016 while dancing at Mr. Fong\u2019s, a bar in New York.", "title": "Valerie Veatch, Benjamin Rampton", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Was there anything that Joey DeFrancesco brought to the table that you felt was different from past musical partners?\n\nThey\u2019re all different, but it\u2019s not an intellectual exercise for me. My thing is not talking about music. It\u2019s about doing it. Other people talk about it, and they make a living talking about it. I make a living kind of singing it and playing it. If it feels right, and it\u2019s the right kind of vibe, then you should just go with it. On this, everything we tried worked, and we did it in two days. It took actually longer to mix it than to record it. In the old days, when I started, that\u2019s how they made records.\n\nI\u2019m assuming everything was pretty much played live in the studio on this album.\n\nYeah, absolutely. The thing about jazz is the spontaneity. That\u2019s the thing I love. In my song \u201cGoldfish Bowl,\u201d it says, \u201cJazz, funk and blues, folk music with a beat, and a whole lot of soul.\u201d That\u2019s kind of the mixture of what I do. But the emphasis is always on spontaneity and improvising. When I play live, I never sing a song the same way twice. So to understand it, you need to have come to a lot of gigs. You can\u2019t really tell by the recordings.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI\u2019ve always thought of your voice as almost like a tenor sax, in terms of its texture and power. But listening to you next to Joey, I hear a lot of overlap between the wide, windy organ sound and your voice. Did it feel different to be working with someone who has that much body in the way he plays his instrument?\n\nWell, it\u2019s whatever feels right and feels good. All the instruments influence me vocally, whether it be saxophone or guitar or organ or piano. The different thing about this is that these guys are such brilliant soloists. And Joey\u2019s kind of like a genius in his own right. So it puts a different spin on it. It\u2019s a challenge, and a challenge is always good. We all need challenges, right?\n\nYou often get grouped with certain other people from the British invasion: the Beatles, Eric Clapton, the Rolling Stones. But it\u2019s an association you\u2019ve resisted.\n\nThose were the people that were popular because they were promoted, and they made it on \u201cThe Ed Sullivan Show.\u201d There were tons of other people apart from that. There was hundreds of people that were in bands playing skiffle. There was literally hundreds at that time. I was never part of any invasion. I had to make it totally on my own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat do you think of the music industry right now, in terms of what it\u2019s promoting?\n\nI don\u2019t really think anything about the music industry, because I\u2019ve never been into pop music. Mose Allison said that he made it in spite of the music business. I made it in spite, and I\u2019m still making it in spite of the music business. I have absolutely nothing to do with the music business as you know it.\n\nAre you interested in contemporary jazz?\n\nNo, not really. I still go back to the original stuff. When I listen to it, I get more from it \u2014 the stuff I didn\u2019t hear the first time around.\n\nDo you have an example?\n\nWell, Louis Armstrong, for instance. And lots of vocalists, like Ray Charles, Bobby Bland, Sam Cooke.\n\nIn terms of Armstrong, what do you return to?\n\nI just go back to the All Stars, from the \u201950s, with Jack Teagarden.\n\nInteresting, most people would say the Hot Fives or the Hot Sevens. Why are the All Stars your favorite?\n\nI don\u2019t know. Why do you like a certain painting? I don\u2019t know.", "title": "Van Morrison Would Rather Play Jazz Than Talk About It", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt makes me proud to see the people from this village welcome with such enthusiasm an excavation project, especially because archaeology shouldn\u2019t just be about finding old things but also transmitting knowledge to those who live here today,\u201d said David Alv\u00e1rez Jim\u00e9nez, a historian who is involved in the Caraca project.\n\nUntil the 1950s, Driebes maintained a population of almost 1,200, not bad for a village located in a vast area known as \u201cthe Lapland of Spain\u201d because of its sparse population.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut just as Caraca was abandoned by the Romans, presumably because their mining activities ended, so too Driebes started emptying because of its dwindling agriculture.\n\nVillagers steadily moved to the new dormitory towns and factories built around Madrid, Spain\u2019s capital, just 50 miles away.\n\nMr. Rinc\u00f3n, the mayor, was born in Driebes in 1962, but left when he was an infant, because his father found work in an oil refinery in Arganda del Rey, a town of over 50,000 inhabitants some 30 miles from Driebes.\n\nMr. Rinc\u00f3n himself went on to work in the same refinery, but then returned to his village when the refinery closed 24 years ago. He set himself up as an independent meat distributor and was elected mayor in 2010.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI always felt that I\u2019d been snatched away as a baby from the family village that I really love,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been lucky to come back and also work here, but there\u2019s no question that we will need to create more jobs to save this village and keep young people.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHis own daughter, Montserrat, 32, lives in Driebes with her parents but is now unemployed.\n\nDriebes is not alone in facing a bleak future, even as Spain\u2019s economy continues its strong recovery from its 2012 banking crisis.\n\nIn February, the Spanish government said it would elaborate a new plan to fight loss of population in the countryside, particularly in this huge and arid stretch of land that averages less than eight inhabitants per square kilometer, making it one the least densely populated areas of Europe.\n\nOver all, Spain\u2019s national statistics show that more than half the country\u2019s municipalities are at risk of ceasing to exist, because they have already fallen below the threshold of 1,000 inhabitants.\n\nPhoto\n\nAround Driebes, some villages have survived only on the whims of good fortune or special investment projects.\n\nIn 2016, residents of nearby Brea de Tajo shared \u20ac120 million after buying a joint winning ticket for Spain\u2019s huge Christmas lottery.\n\nIn Estremera, the village\u2019s economy was lifted a decade ago by the opening of a penitentiary, whose inmates now include Catalan politicians awaiting trial for trying to secede from Spain.\n\nLike most other villages, Driebes has kept itself alive through a mix of regional, national and European subsidies.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf we talk purely about economics, neither our school, nor our medical center nor anything else in this village is now viable without subsidies,\u201d said Mr. Rinc\u00f3n, the mayor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe only thriving business involves retired people, he said, since about 40 pensioners regularly visit a community center that used to welcome about 10 people a decade ago.\n\nFernando Bachiller Higuera, one of seven farmers remaining in Driebes, said that he would struggle to break even without the subsidies he received from the European Union\u2019s common agricultural policy to grow cereals on land that \u201cisn\u2019t actually that suitable for cereals,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cI only became a farmer because my father died and something had to be done with the land, and we could get European subsidies,\u201d Mr. Bachiller Higuera, 47, said.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIf my two sons decide they prefer studying than the fields, I myself will stop in 20 years and this farming story will come to an end,\u201d he said.\n\nOn weekends and during the summer vacations, the population of Driebes swells as former residents return to enjoy traditional village feasts and take a break from city life. Even so, a dozen houses stand in ruins, half awaiting demolition.\n\n\u201cWhat this village doesn\u2019t have in physical beauty, it compensates for with its great personality and the friendliness of its people,\u201d said Mar\u00eda Teresa Vadillo S\u00e1nchez, who works in a town 30 miles away but returns most weekends with her daughters to a family home where her mother now lives alone.\n\nIt\u2019s too early to understand the Roman history that once breathed life into Caraca. But using a drone and ground radar technology, archaeologists have mapped the town that they will unearth, pending more funding.\n\nLast summer, 15 people got paid to help with the first excavation, but the archaeologists caution against raising expectations about their project and how it could bring economic sustainability to Driebes.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s great to get local people involved, but excavations are slow and expensive,\u201d said Emilio Gamo, one of Caraca\u2019s archaeologists. \u201cSo the people should also know that the dynamics of archaeology aren\u2019t necessarily those of a tourism project.\u201d", "title": "Vanishing Spanish Village Sees a Future in Its Roman Past", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 Today\u2019s quote, from Mary Beard\u2019s \u201cLaughter in Ancient Rome: On Joking, Tickling and Cracking Up,\u201d is a timely reminder of how some very basic and important expressions aren\u2019t based on origin, class, religion, ethnicity or anything but the commonality of being human.\n\nI found the difficulty today mainly in some tricky clues and a number of short monosyllabic words that broke the mold. Usually when you deduce an acrostic, finding a three-letter word that begins with T is \u201cthe\u201d and a two-letter word that begins with H is \u201che.\u201d So I went astray a couple of times, but worked it out. I started with RENEGADE, HORSEHIDE, and NOAHS ARK. I learned something new about the LORIKEET and what the olecranon process is (actually a part of the ULNA.) I was reminded, by ARGENT, of how resistant my memory is to the lingo of heraldry. We all have our blocks.\n\nWhen someone in the future writes the book called \u201cLaughter in the Ancient 21st Century,\u201d they will hopefully remember this bumbling and chaotic era as at least somewhat funny. Memes, emojis and acronyms will surely have their own analysis (Mary Beard\u2019s book, endearingly, has a chapter called \u201cBetween Human and Animal \u2014 Monkeys and Asses.\u201d) And although the differences in our acronyms are amusing \u2014 did anyone else here ever interpret LOL as affection rather than amusement? \u2014 I do think real humor will always be universal.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThough it may be rendered in print with global consistency, laughter in practice is wildly variable. Don\u2019t we all know a person who \u201claughs funny\u201d? Some people gasp almost silently, other people practically shout. Here is a passage from Vladimir Nabokov\u2019s novel \u201cPnin,\u201d describing the titular professor convulsed with mirth in front of his class: \u201cPresently the fun would become too much for him; pear-shaped tears would trickle down his tanned cheeks. Not only his shocking teeth but also an astonishing amount of pink upper-gum tissue would suddenly pop out, as if a jack-in-the-box had been sprung, and his hand would fly to his mouth, while his big shoulders shook and rolled. And although the speech he smothered behind his dancing hand was now doubly unintelligible to the class, his complete surrender to his own merriment would prove irresistible. By the time he was helpless with it he would have his students in stitches, with abrupt barks of clockwork hilarity coming from Charles and a dazzling flow of unsuspected lovely laughter transfiguring Josephine, who was not pretty, while Eileen, who was, dissolved in a jelly of unbecoming giggles.\u201d\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nVARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 The passage in this puzzle is a grand example of one of my favorite genres, rhapsodic nature writing. It\u2019s from a 2018 book by Simon Barnes, \u201cThe Meaning of Birds,\u201d that takes a big-picture look at the historical importance of birds as symbols, sustenance and inspiration for all manners of human endeavors from Poe\u2019s doleful poetry to Darwin\u2019s theory of natural selection.\n\nThe passage is about iridescence, and I couldn\u2019t resist including the above ScienceTake video of scientists studying peahens and what exactly they see in peacocks (there is a somewhat beleaguered-looking peahen wearing a knapsack and a head camera here, but she comes out of it about as all right as most of us on a tech-enabled date). The passage concerns a bird that\u2019s a lot less flamboyant, and who I often think looks like it fell in an oily puddle. They\u2019re talented though, and I\u2019ll try to remember this more lyrical description from now on.\n\nI learned a few things in the clues today, including the fact that \u201cgenu varum\u201d means BOWLEGGED, and \u201cthe German word for girl\u201d is actually NEUTER. I started with NO REGRETS, IN CROWD, AL CAPONE and BOTSWANA. I\u2019m sorry this puzzle didn\u2019t run on either Easter or Orthodox Easter so I could make a groaner pun about \u201cEaster eggs,\u201d secrets that designers conceal in animation, computer games and the like, because there\u2019s a great one here that soared above me like an albatross for a long time but is after-the-fact evident in the clues I cited above.\n\nThe Cox Rathvon machine produced its usual cornucopia of cleverness and subtle misdirection, so it was a good enough fight for a lovely little bit of writing to \u2014 dare I dream \u2014 herald birdsong, warmth and Spring.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nHow many did you see in the answers? 1-5: backyard birder. 6-10: avian expert. 11-15: life list champion.\n\nI was proud to get ten, and I don\u2019t even believe there are more. Prove me wrong. What did you think?", "title": "Variety: Acrostic", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 I would never, ever have filled in this blank grid correctly without the use of graph paper on the side. David Steinberg has created a tightly clued theme puzzle, with four long entries related to a very specific painting, by an artist whom I particularly adore (and have drawn from to illustrate this column in the past).\n\nPhoto\n\nThis puzzle is a little work of art in itself, a completely asymmetrical, negative image that was quite hard to see for me until I compared it to the theme work visually (shown here to avoid spoiling the game for you). If you feel stymied please consider creating a few blocks of clues that you do know on a piece of scratch paper \u2014 they all link together in the end.\n\nTo add to the mystification (and gratification, once you\u2019re through), Mr. Steinberg is whimsical and sophisticated in his theme clues. The name of the painting, for example, might not be what you think of as the name of the painting, as it goes by three more-or-less correct titles. The clue at 10D \u2014 PHENOMENON \u2014 is straight out of a college class or a museum guide, and I still don\u2019t quite understand it. When I go to Google I get a lot of explique dans la francais, oh la la, ma pauvre t\u00eate.\n\nAs far as the fill, I liked FORMIC, CRIME WAVE and TIES; I\u2019ll allow THE MRS and BRO CODE simply as counterweights to all the highbrow fanciness here.\n\nWhat did you think?", "title": "Variety: Diagramless Crossword", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "VARIETY PUZZLE \u2014 We are well into diamond jubilee territory when it comes to Times puzzles by Mel Taub; he has been contributing all types of crosswords since 1954, and his specialty is Puns & Anagrams, which come at you from every possible angle to make for a unique solving experience.\n\nIf you have never tried one of these, you are in for a treat. We have written about how to approach these creatures before (Will Shortz, the puzzles editor, offers background and explanation here). My advice is to begin looking for anagrams and use those as the gimmes to help crack the rest of the grid. Think of the anagrams as answers on a multiple-choice text: The right one is in front of you, you just have to narrow things down.\n\nWell, that\u2019s great, you say, but how does one know which answers are anagrams? This is where the fun starts, because you don\u2019t. You don\u2019t even know for sure there are any, although it would be pretty meanspirited of Mr. Taub to dispense with them entirely and keep the brand the same, wouldn\u2019t it? Suffice to say, it is probably a good bet that half of your clues will have an anagram as either all or part of its entry, so even if you miss a few on the first go-around, you are still going to make a dent in your puzzle.\n\nLet\u2019s do just that, with a good clear example at 13A, \u201cMilo\u2019s one dollar.\u201d If you have ever been into the cryptics, you are missing a letter count, which I think would be considered too much of a giveaway for this variety \u2014 but it\u2019s not as if that information is very secret, is it, as we can see this entry is eight letters long. Take Milo\u2019s (5) + one (3) and mix up those letters to find something that could mean a dollar in crosswordese, say, SIMOLEON, a slang term that you have hopefully heard of (in order to get the punch line to these jokes it helps to know the language). Anyhow, in its purest form, an anagram clue: one word to define, two words to scramble, nothing left over at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRight next door is another one of these, with a little wrinkle, \u201cThink of a date, i.e.\u201d, or IDEATE, in which that little solitary \u201ca\u201d serves to make the clue read prettily.", "title": "Variety: Puns and Anagrams", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "The arrest was the latest blow to the Roman Catholic Church as it struggles to overcome repeated cases of sexual abuse among its clergy. The case was also the worst involving a diplomat since that of former Archbishop Jozef Wesolowski, who in 2013 faced charges of paying boys for sexual acts and downloading and buying pedophile material while he was the Vatican\u2019s ambassador in the Dominican Republic.\n\nThe pontiff has declared zero tolerance for the abuse that has plagued the Church for decades, but critics say he has not done enough, particularly in holding bishops responsible for mishandling or covering up misconduct.\n\nThe State Department first notified the Holy See in August of a possible violation of laws relating to child pornography images by a member of the Holy See\u2019s diplomatic corps accredited to Washington, the Vatican said in September.\n\nA State Department spokesman said then that the United States had requested that the man\u2019s diplomatic immunity be waived to open the way for a possible prosecution there, but the Vatican had refused. The Vatican did not identify the cleric, but Italian news media reports and an American official familiar with the investigation said it was Monsignor Capella.\n\nHe could not be reached for comment; the Vatican said he was being held in a cell in the Vatican\u2019s police barracks.", "title": "Vatican Arrests Monsignor on Suspicion of Possessing Child Pornography", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Vel Phillips, a barrier-breaking African-American lawmaker from Milwaukee who became an influential voice in the national movement for fair housing during the 1960s, died on April 17 in Mequon, Wis. She was 95.\n\nHer son Michael confirmed the death.\n\nMs. Phillips \u2014 the first African-American to serve on the city\u2019s Common Council and the first woman elected to it \u2014 began introducing open-housing bills in 1962, two years after championing civil rights at the Democratic National Convention that nominated Senator John F. Kennedy for president.\n\nThe city legislation\u2019s aim was to end practices by landlords and real estate agents that had made it nearly impossible for blacks to find housing beyond Milwaukee\u2019s so-called inner core, a run-down section where nearly all the city\u2019s black population lived.\n\nBut she faced repeated opposition from the other members of the council, all of them white and male. Several times her bills were defeated, 18-1.", "title": "Vel Phillips, Housing Rights Champion in the \u203260s, Is Dead at 95", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Kenneth Frampton, the architectural historian who wrote the pivotal book \u201cModern Architecture: A Critical History,\u201d will be the recipient of the Golden Lion for Lifetime Achievement at this year\u2019s edition of the Venice Architecture Biennale.\n\n\u201cThere is no student of the faculties of architecture who is unfamiliar with his \u2018Modern Architecture: A Critical History,\u2019\u201d Paolo Baratta, the president of the biennale, which runs from May 26 through Nov. 11, said in a statement. He added that the award will go to \u201ca \u2018maestro,\u2019 and in this sense it is also intended to be a recognition of the importance of the critical approach to the teaching of architecture.\u201d\n\nYvonne Farrell and Shelley McNamara of the Dublin-based firm Grafton Architects, who organized this year\u2019s biennale, recommended Mr. Frampton for the honor, which in the past has gone to star architects like Rem Koolhaas, Frank Gehry and Renzo Piano.\n\n\u201cHis humanistic philosophy in relation to architecture is embedded in his writing,\u201d Ms. Farrell and Ms. McNamara said in a statement, \u201cand he has consistently argued for this humanistic component throughout all the various \u2018movements\u2019 and trends often misguided in architecture in the 20th and 21st century.\u201d", "title": "Venice Architecture Biennale to Honor Kenneth Frampton", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "As he walked into church in Palm Beach on Sunday morning, Mr. Trump did not respond to a question from reporters about whether his tweets meant that he would no longer support any deal for the young immigrants protected by the DACA program. But he said that \u201cMexico has got to help us at the border, and a lot of people are coming in because they want to take advantage of DACA.\u201d\n\nThe Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, known as DACA, gave protected status to hundreds of thousands of young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children. The program requires immigrants to have resided in the United States since 2007, meaning any crossing the border now would not be eligible.\n\nMr. Trump announced last year that he was ending the program, but courts have blocked his decision. He has said he is open to negotiating with Democrats on it, but has repeatedly backed away from potential deals that he argues do not include immigration changes that are tough enough.\n\nOutside the church on Sunday, the president said the Democrats \u201cblew it\u201d after having \u201chad a great chance.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut we\u2019ll have to take a look,\u201d he added.\n\nSeveral Democrats challenged the idea that they were at fault for a breakdown in negotiations.\n\n\u201c\u2018NO MORE DACA DEAL\u2019?!!\u201d Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota wrote on Twitter. \u201cYou were never doing a DACA deal. Your actions gave you away: cancelling DACA with no plan, making racist comments about Black/Brown immigrants, ejecting several by bipartisan deals. You didn\u2019t fool anybody.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Dwight Evans, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said on Twitter that DACA recipients were \u201cstudents, military service members, teachers, scientists, doctors, and lawyers \u2014 they are integral members of our community.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Evans said the president\u2019s comments were \u201csimply unacceptable.\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s remarks also drew a rebuke from a high-profile member of his own party. The United States, Mexico and Canada are locked in difficult negotiations over a revamping of the trade pact.\n\nThe president\u2019s tweets seemed at odds with some unifying steps taken last week by members of his administration: The homeland security secretary, Kirstjen Nielsen, met with President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto of Mexico to discuss ways to work together on security and trade issues, according to a description of the conversation released by the Department of Homeland Security.\n\nBut Mr. Trump may have been hearing a harder-line administration voice over the weekend. He was accompanied to his Palm Beach resort, Mar-a-Lago, by Stephen Miller, a senior policy adviser who has shaped much of the administration\u2019s tough stance on immigration.\n\nThe president, in his tweets, criticized what he called \u201cCatch & Release,\u201d a practice in which detained undocumented immigrants are sometimes released as they wait for a hearing before an immigration judge. In some cases, they are released because the government has nowhere to house them.\n\nCritics say the practice \u2014 which, contrary to the president\u2019s tweet, is not enshrined in law \u2014 gives the immigrants an opening to skip their hearing and settle undetected in the country. The Trump administration has declared an end to the practice, though it may take a while before significant changes are carried out.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s tweets on Sunday echoed remarks on \u201cFox and Friends\u201d by Brandon Judd, the president of the National Border Patrol Council, whom the president has praised in the past.\n\n\u201cOur legislators actually have to stand up, and the Republicans control the House and the Senate, they do not need the Democrat support to pass any laws they want,\u201d Mr. Judd said on the program. \u201cThey can go the nuclear option, just like what they did on the confirmation. They need to pass laws to end the catch-and-release program that\u2019ll allow us to hold them for a long time.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Judd also said that the \u201ccatch and release\u201d policy was helping to lure the caravan of Central Americans to the United States.\n\nA representative for a group called Pueblo Sin Fronteras, which organized the caravan, said that it would take four to six weeks before it reached the United States-Mexico border, and that the number of participants would be significantly smaller by then.\n\nMost people are likely to drop out of the caravan in Mexico, rather than journey all the way to the border, the representative said, because they know they would be turned back by American border officials.\n\n\u201cMany of them know they won\u2019t qualify for asylum. They are afraid of being detained,\u201d said Roberto Corona, the group\u2019s communications director, adding that most of them just wanted to reach Mexico, where they plan to speak with members of that country\u2019s Congress.\n\nMigrants who cannot prove that they face persecution or that their lives are endangered in their home country are unlikely to be allowed to remain in the United States. The Trump administration has also sought to increase detentions to deter would-be migrants.", "title": "Venting on Immigration, Trump Vows \u2018No More DACA Deal\u2019 and Threatens Nafta", "authors": ["Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The group included the two largest venture capital firms in the virtual currency industry, Andreessen Horowitz and Union Square Ventures. It also included lawyers from Cooley, Perkins Coie, and McDermott Will & Emery, the people involved in the effort said.\n\nThe group met with the S.E.C. in Washington on March 28 to present their idea for a safe harbor that would allow some tokens to be categorized as \u201cutility tokens\u201d rather than securities. An S.E.C. spokesman declined to comment on the meeting.\n\nThousands of virtual currencies have been created through so-called initial coin offerings in which entrepreneurs sold digital tokens to raise money for their projects. The tokens are generally intended to serve as internal payment methods in software that the entrepreneurs are building.\n\nOver the past year, entrepreneurs have raised more than $6 billion through initial coin offerings. These coins mostly trade on unregulated virtual currency exchanges. Many entrepreneurs have said that because their tokens have a utility, as a payment method, they should not be considered investment contracts or securities.\n\nBut Jay Clayton, the chairman of the S.E.C., has said in recent months that he believes almost every token issued through an initial coin offering should be registered as a security \u2014 almost none are today.\n\nThe S.E.C. has sent subpoenas to dozens of people and companies in the virtual currency industry asking for information about how various digital tokens were issued and marketed to investors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen investments are securities, they generally need to have paperwork filed with regulators and can only be traded on regulated exchanges, like those where stocks and commodities are bought and sold. No regulated securities exchanges offer virtual currency trading.\n\nMost investors assume that Bitcoin is safe from being categorized as a security because it was not originally issued through an initial coin offering or central organization. New Bitcoins are distributed on a daily basis to computers helping to maintain the network. Some large virtual currencies, like Litecoin and Monero, have similar designs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Ethereum, the virtual currency network that houses the Ether virtual currency, did raise money by selling Ether tokens to investors through what was then called a pre-sale and is now often called an initial coin offering. The Ethereum Foundation took in Bitcoin that were worth around $18 million at the time. Ether are now distributed in a manner similar to that of Bitcoin.\n\nThe group pulled together by Andreessen Horowitz said in its proposal that Ether \u201chas become so decentralized it should not be deemed a security.\u201d\n\nThe proposal suggests that digital tokens should generally be exempt from securities laws if they achieve \u201cfull decentralization\u201d or \u201cfull functionality.\u201d It adds that full decentralization could occur under several conditions, including \u201cwhen the token creator no longer has control of the network based on its ability to make unilateral changes to the functionality of the tokens.\u201d\n\nThe proposal says a token is fully functional when it can be used for its intended purpose on a computer network and is not just useful as a speculative investment, which is the case with many tokens today.\n\nThe group notes that these definitions are only suggestions, but the \u201cproposed safe harbor has been vetted by, and has the support of, many of the key players in the industry.\u201d\n\nPeople briefed on the meeting said that regulators did not immediately embrace the safe harbor proposal.\n\nMany entrepreneurs and law firms have been creating new ways for virtual currency projects to issue their tokens as securities and some exchanges have talked about getting registered as official securities exchanges.\n\nIt is still unclear what will happen to tokens that did not register as securities but are later categorized as securities.", "title": "Venture Capitalists Seek \u2018Safe Harbor\u2019 for Virtual various women\u2019s groups announced that they would lead protests on Thursday evening across Spain to condemn the ruling. The five men were sentenced to nine years in prison for \u201ccontinuous sexual abuse,\u201d rather than the almost 23 years in prison that the prosecution had sought for rape and other charges.\n\nThe woman\u2019s lawyer said she would appeal the ruling. Many called the police. As the confrontation with police officers occurred, people continued watching, some taking videos with their phones.\n\nThe police report suggested that Mr. Ohene was aggressive. \u201cOhene\u2019s goal was to seriously hurt himself or one of the officers on scene,\u201d the report said. \u201cOhene absolutely could not be reasoned with.\u201d\n\nThe report went on: \u201cUnable to pry Ohene\u2019s hands from underneath his body, I delivered approximately five strikes with a closed fists to the area of his stomach.\u201d Police shackled his ankles before putting him in an ambulance.\n\n\u201cA pool of blood remained on the pavement as the ambulance departed,\u201d according to the Black Law Students Association.\n\nIn its statement, the student group called on Harvard to form a crisis team to deal with emergencies without involving the police and demanded an investigation into the officers\u2019 conduct. It also said the officers had tried to obstruct witnesses\u2019 attempts to record the encounter, but it did not specify how.\n\nMr. McGovern, the mayor, said policing in this progressive city was \u201cfar ahead of many communities in the country.\u201d But Cambridge police have been criticized for their treatment of black residents in the past, most notably in 2009, when the police arrested Henry Louis Gates Jr., a black professor at Harvard, who was seen struggling to open his jammed front door.\n\nThe episode touched off an extensive national debate over police treatment of blacks, which intensified when President Barack Obama said the police had \u201cacted stupidly.\u201d A report commissioned by the city later called the incident \u201cavoidable,\u201d though it said both the officer and Mr. Gates escalated the encounter.", "title": "Video Shows Police Tackling and Punching Black Harvard Student", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Sri Gnana Skandhan, a Hindu priest, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 28, is a resident physician in New Brunswick, N.J., in the Department of Pediatrics at Rutgers Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, from which she received a medical degree. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. In July, she is to begin a fellowship in pediatric hematology and oncology at Yale.\n\nShe is the daughter of Mini Puthenpura and Sarat C. Puthenpura of Berkeley Heights, N.J. He graduated from Harvard, from which he also received a master's degree in chemistry, a medical degree and an M.B.A.\n\nHe is the son of Dr. Sita Laksmi Yanamadala and Dr. Srinivas Yanamadala of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.
