His father, an otorhinolaryngologist, is also in private practice, in Torrance, Calif.\n\nThe couple met through a mutual friend in January 2015.", "title": "Vidya Puthenpura, Vijay Yanamadala", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "These photographs are like an architect\u2019s elevation drawings, only much more solid. They also convey how the cathedrals once sat, and in some cases still do, above their towns and cities like large, protective beasts. Some of the buildings come to feel like the architectural equivalents of Barney. You may want to hug them.\n\nPrecedents for Mr. Brunetti\u2019s work include the Conceptual German photographers Bernd and Hilla Becher, who spent nearly five postwar decades documenting industrial structures, from shaky coal-mine winding towers to immense grain elevators. August Sander\u2019s prewar portraits of people from different German professions have a similar typographical ambition. But Mr. Brunetti\u2019s images have their own intense emotional resonance \u2014 the buildings are formidable expressions of collective faith made all the more so by their stalwart refusal to bend to perspective.\n\nThis show is a chance to get your European church styles down. There\u2019s one example of Romanesque, the Trani Cathedral, in Apulia, Italy, its plain stonework standing in stark, even disapproving contrast to almost everything else here, including the much more ornate cathedral in Siena, Italy, which is Romanesque Gothic.\n\nThen it\u2019s mostly Gothic and High Gothic, when the churches reached unprecedented heights in the naves and spires, thanks to the distribution of weight made possible by the Gothic arch (and flying buttresses, like those on the beautiful Flamboyant Gothic Church of the Holy Trinity, in Vend\u00f4me, France). You see how the sumptuousness of the style made the cathedrals more welcoming and urban. Their many sculptures turned them into bibles of stone while the ribbing and traceries added amazing decorative energy.", "title": "Viewing Europe\u2019s Houses of Worship in Wild Detail", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cHe Called Out Sick, Then Apologized for Dying\u201d (news article, April 16), about a civil rights lawyer who set himself afire in a Brooklyn park:\n\nAs a psychiatrist I know that dark emotions may lie behind the face we show to others, and that any suicide is the result of complex forces, a mix of anger and despair. All that may be needed to light the fuse is the \u201cright\u201d catalyst. David Buckel\u2019s suicide is likely no exception. What is unusual is the catalyst: Mr. Buckel said he wanted to die to call attention to climate change.\n\nClimate change has been linked to suicide and suicidal ideation, which increase during and after extreme weather events and on days of poor air quality from burning fossil fuels. Suicides among farmers in drought-stricken areas have skyrocketed. As the impacts of global warming ratchet up, so will the emotional toll.\n\nSuicide is a highly contagious act. This suicide was described as a political protest, and that makes it dangerously seductive for someone seeking a \u201cnoble\u201d rationale.\n\nThe antidote to rage and despair, with climate change the catalyst, is not individual self-destructive protest, but collective engagement in political action.", "title": "Opinion | Viewing a Suicide as an Environmental Protest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Tragedy of James Comey\u201d (column, April 9):\n\nDavid Leonhardt gets James Comey, the former F.B.I. director, in ways many Americans don\u2019t. I never thought for a minute that Mr. Comey sought to change the outcome of the presidential election, the balance of power in the Senate and the philosophical leaning of the Supreme Court.\n\nI also have no doubt the aw-shucks Jimmy Stewart impersonator did all three \u2014 not out of partisanship or venality, but out of an unspeakably arrogant na\u00efvet\u00e9 and self-absorption.\n\nHillary Clinton\u2019s poll numbers plummeted after Mr. Comey\u2019s October surprise, which left her campaign virtually defenseless as F.B.I. agents reviewed her email messages.\n\nMr. Comey\u2019s Shakespearean-scale blunder put a sword in Mrs. Clinton\u2019s back and led to the election of a dangerous, corrupt buffoon. Regardless of his intentions, his hubris has done our nation more lasting harm than words can capture.", "title": "Opinion | Views of James Comey: Tragic Figure or Hero?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "On Sunday, Viktor Orban\u2019s Fidesz party will likely cruise to another victory in Hungary\u2019s general election, giving Mr. Orban, the reigning champion of \u201cilliberal democracy\u201d \u2014 a term he proudly embraces \u2014 a fourth term to pursue his assault on democratic institutions, immigrants, the European Union and anything smacking of social change. The campaign has been surprisingly tough, but then Fidesz designed the voting system and controls much of the media.\n\nA victory will no doubt hearten the ranks of the nativist populists who, despite their avowed aversion to international organizations, take pride in being in the vanguard of an international reactionary movement. It is telling that after his ouster from the White House, Stephen Bannon went on a tour of European soul mates, during which he hailed Mr. Orban as his hero and \u201cthe most significant guy on the scene right now.\u201d\n\nA report by The Times\u2019s Patrick Kingsley on how Mr. Orban reached that august status offers a chilling look at the breadth of the populist assault not only on the \u201chardware\u201d of democracy \u2014 constitution, judiciary, the electoral system \u2014 but also the software: the culture, civil society, education system and religious organizations. Fidesz (founded in 1988 as the Hungarian Alliance of Young Democrats) has actively pushed a narrative of Hungarian victimhood and ethnocentrism in schools, theaters and universities while vilifying any opposing viewpoint, and especially pro-democracy organizations funded by George Soros, the Hungarian-American billionaire who has become something of a whipping boy for the far right throughout Central Europe.\n\nMr. Orban\u2019s defenders say people support him not for his populism but for his handling of the economy. Government debt and the budget deficit are down, the country\u2019s credit rating is up, growth has almost quadrupled since 2010. What these figures do not show, though, is that many of these improvements have come through membership in the European Union, which Mr. Orban assails at every opportunity. At the same time, according to the World Bank\u2019s Worldwide Governance Indicators, corruption has risen significantly under Mr. Orban.", "title": "Opinion | Viktor Orban\u2019s Perversion of Democracy in Hungary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-03-31 00:00:00", "text": "Now they will face third-seeded Michigan in the final on Monday night.\n\n\u201cEvery season has a defining moment,\u201d the Villanova assistant coach Ashley Howard said last week. \u201cI think that Creighton game could have been that for us.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Saturday, Villanova jumped out to a 22-4 lead in the opening seven minutes. The Wildcats entered the game seven 3-pointers short of breaking an N.C.A.A. Division I record for the most in a single season. They set it with 10 minutes left in the first half.\n\n\u201cThat was just one of those games,\u201d Wright said. \u201cMan, we made every shot to start the game.\u201d\n\nVillanova did not attempt a free throw until 8 minutes 48 seconds remained in the game.\n\nEric Paschall went 10 of 11 from the field for 24 points, while Omari Spellman added 15 points and 13 rebounds, and Brunson scored 18.\n\n\u201cThey got anything they wanted early,\u201d Kansas Coach Bill Self said.\n\nObscured a bit in the downpour of 3s was the fact that Villanova also forced 12 turnovers, took charges, blocked five shots and shook Kansas out of its game. Making shots bred confidence, which seeped into the defense, vitalizing both units on a feedback loop.\n\n\u201cIt gave us so much confidence,\u201d guard Donte DiVincenzo said. \u201cWe know we are knocking down shots, and when that happens, that energy just builds.\u201d\n\nBut DiVincenzo added, \u201cWe pride ourselves on our ability to win when we\u2019re not making shots.\u201d\n\nThe Wildcats held the Jayhawks to 33 percent 3-point shooting and a season-low eight assists.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt gets to 22-4 and it\u2019s like, oh my gosh,\u201d Self said. \u201cWe\u2019re seven minutes in, and we\u2019re going to have to play just about perfect to get back.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis was a battle between two No. 1 seeds \u2014 a surprisingly conventional showdown after a bracket full of upsets, including a No. 16 seed, University of Maryland-Baltimore County, beating a No. 1 seed, Virginia, for the first time in the men\u2019s tournament.\n\nBut the Jayhawks (31-8) and the Wildcats survived the gantlet to reach the Final Four on the strength of their senior leadership and guard play.\n\nVillanova, which beat North Carolina in the 2016 title game, rose to No. 1 in the nation in early December this season, but Wright sensed some complacency settling in. His Wildcats were undersized, and vulnerable to an off shooting night. And as Wright kept harping on defense, the players took weeks to accept that changes needed to be made.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Final in Three Seasons", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "One of the matters involving Mr. Bollor\u00e9 now under scrutiny is connected to Alpha Cond\u00e9, a Guinean politician who is believed to have befriended Mr. Bollor\u00e9 while he lived in political exile in Paris in the mid-2000s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter Mr. Cond\u00e9 returned to Guinea to seek the presidency in 2010, an international Havas unit helped guide his campaign, and then allegedly underbilled him for its services. After Mr. Cond\u00e9 won, the Guinea government transferred an agreement to run the container-port terminal at Conakry, Guinea\u2019s capital, to the Bollor\u00e9 Group from a French rival.\n\nThe deal, first reported by the French newspaper Le Monde, added a strategic jewel to the Bollor\u00e9 Group\u2019s network of assets in West Africa, where it has a virtual stranglehold on much of the transporting of billions of euros worth of cargo. A map of the group\u2019s holdings shows a web of Bollor\u00e9-run roads, railways, waterways, airports and ports that covers two-thirds of the continent and employs more than 25,000 people.\n\nA similar pattern emerged in Togo, another former French colony. There, the same Havas unit was said to support, with below-market-rate services, the re-election of President Faure Gnassingb\u00e9 in 2010.\n\nPhoto\n\nA few months before Mr. Gnassingb\u00e9, who has close ties to Mr. Bollor\u00e9, won a second term, his government awarded a contract for the container port at Lom\u00e9, the country\u2019s capital, to the Bollor\u00e9 Group.\n\nIn its statement on Tuesday, the Bollor\u00e9 Group said it had originally gotten a contract to operate the port in 2001, long before Havas was doing business in Guinea. In 2013, Havas stopped doing political consulting for French and African figures after some of its clients, including the former International Monetary Fund director Dominique Strauss-Kahn, became ensnared in scandals.\n\nThe Bollor\u00e9 Group has routinely sued French and African media outlets for defamation over reports on its business dealings on the continent. Journalists at Canal+, a French television channel owned by Vivendi, have accused Mr. Bollor\u00e9 of using his influence to try to suppress an investigative report about a popular revolt against Mr. Gnassingb\u00e9 in Togo. Two producers were fired after the report aired in December.\n\nThe suits have challenged the media outlets France Inter, France 2, Rue89 and Mediapart, among others. Those reports included investigative pieces alleging that workers at the company\u2019s Socapalm and Safacam units, which operate palm oil plantations in Cameroon, were being exploited.\n\nSince 2009, the Bollor\u00e9 Group has brought more than 20 defamation suits involving over 40 reporters and nongovernmental organization activists in France, according to Sherpa, a French anticorruption organization that pursues humanitarian abuses by corporations. \u201cBecause of their systemic nature, we regard these legal actions as \u2018gag suits,\u2019\u201d Sherpa said in a statement.\n\nThe Bollor\u00e9 Group has said the suits were meant to combat what it described as biased reporting.\n\nThe formal investigation of corruption charges against Mr. Bollor\u00e9 and the others means French judges believe there is evidence that points to serious wrongdoing. But the magistrates can later drop the charges if they do not believe the evidence is sufficient to proceed to trial.", "title": "Vincent Bollor\u00e9, French Billionaire, Faces a Rare Corruption Inquiry", "authors": ["Liz Alderman"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "PHILADELPHIA \u2014 Dwyane Wade snuffed out one 76ers rally by popping a 16-foot fadeaway with the shot clock ticking down. []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI feel strongly the timing is right to move forward with the Medicaid expansion,\u201d Mr. Hanger said in an interview on Thursday.\n\nBroadening Medicaid would give Mr. Northam, a Democrat who won by a landslide last year, a major policy victory, one that eluded and frustrated his predecessor, Terry McAuliffe.\n\nMr. McAuliffe, a potential Democratic candidate for president in 2020, spent years trying to wear down Republican lawmakers on the issue, with little success.\n\nMr. Wagner on Friday said he backed an expansion plan as long as it required able-bodied adults to work and taxed hospitals to pay the state\u2019s share of the $2 billion yearly costs.\n\nBoth provisions are in the House-passed version of the expansion, which received Mr. Northam\u2019s support despite liberals\u2019 opposition to the work requirements.\n\n\u201cThere were things we didn\u2019t want to see in the deal but were important to Republicans,\u201d Brian Coy, a spokesman for the governor, said. \u201cHe believes Virginians elected him to work with everyone.\u201d\n\nThe House and Senate must reach a compromise to pass a budget by June 30.\n\nAlthough the two Republican senators\u2019 embrace of expansion seem to promise a speedy resolution, there are enough differences in the proposals that a deal could founder.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMedicaid is the public health insurance program for low-income people jointly paid by states and the federal government. Since expanding benefits became a state option under a 2012 Supreme Court decision that upheld the Affordable Care Act, 33 states have embraced expansion. Eighteen, mostly led by Republicans in the South and Midwest, have turned it down.\n\nCurrently, Virginia has one of the most restrictive Medicaid programs. Childless adults are not eligible and working parents cannot exceed an income of 30 percent of the federal poverty level, or $5,727.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nExpanding Medicaid would cover families and single adults earning up to 138 percent of the poverty level, or $28,180 for a family of three.\n\nThe dam in the House began to break in February when an influential conservative Republican, Delegate Terry Kilgore, long an expansion opponent, announced his support in an opinion column in The Roanoke Times, saying: \u201cIt is time to act.\u201d\n\nMr. Kilgore\u2019s district in southwest Virginia is one of the poorest in the state, where each July thousands of people visit a free pop-up clinic at a county fairground.\n\nDelegate Chris Peace, another Republican who favored expansion in the House, said he had changed his position in part because in his family law practice, he had come to see the dire effects that a lack of health care had on low-income families.\n\nHe called the House bill that includes work requirements \u201cthe epitome of the Republican conservative mantra of a hand up, not a handout.\u201d\n\nAhead of the special session, activists from the conservative group Americans for Prosperity have demonstrated outside Mr. Peace\u2019s office in Mechanicsville, trying to pressure him to change his mind.\n\nHe dismissed them as remnants of the Tea Party movement straining to remain relevant. \u201cHalf are 60-plus gray-haired white men who hate Obama,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Peace said there was little question that November\u2019s ballot wave changed the minds of Republicans in the House, who he said wanted to get Medicaid expansion off the table as a political issue before the midterm elections this year and the next round of legislative elections in 2019.\n\nSenate Republicans opposed to expansion risk being swept from office next year, Mr. Peace said: \u201cThey haven\u2019t seen the wave that has come everywhere.\u201d\n\nJust as conservative activists have targeted Mr. Peace, liberal door-knockers are pressuring State Senator Siobhan Dunnavant, a Republican expansion opponent, whose suburban Richmond district was carried by Hillary Clinton in 2016.\n\nDr. Dunnavant, an obstetrician-gynecologist, said that she cared about improving public health and stabilizing the costs, but that expanding Medicaid would accomplish neither.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t fix health care by throwing money at it,\u201d she said. \u201cYou fix health care by using evidence-based programs and having them accountable.\u201d", "title": "Virginia Is Close to Expanding Medicaid After Years of Republican Opposition", "authors": ["Trip Gabriel"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Vittorio Taviani was born on Sept. 29, 1929, in the Tuscan town of San Miniato. His father, Ermanno, was a lawyer, and his mother, the former Jolanda Brogi, was a teacher.\n\nThe main early exposure to culture for him and Paolo, who is two years younger, came not from movies, but from trips to Florence to see Verdi operas. One day in Pisa just after World War II, though, everything changed for them.\n\n\u201cBy chance we happened to pass a local movie theater,\u201d Mr. Taviani recalled in a 1986 interview with The New York Times. \u201cAnd the people coming out were muttering, \u2018Don\u2019t go in, it\u2019s an atrocity!\u2019 So naturally we were curious. And there on the screen was everything that had happened to all of us just a few months before.\n\n\u201cSeeing it unreel before us was glorious and tragic,\u201d he continued, \u201cand we realized at once that film was the one means we had to understand our own reality. The movie was Rossellini\u2019s \u2018Paisan,\u2019 and from that day on we knew that the cinema was the road for us.\u201d\n\nNeorealism was in vogue, thanks to the films of Roberto Rossellini, Luchino Visconti and others. That genre had faded by the time the Tavianis began working in the movie business in the mid-1950s, first behind the scenes, then directing documentaries. But when they began making features together in 1962 with \u201cUn uomo da bruciare\u201d (\u201cA Man for Burning,\u201d directed with Valentino Orsini), a drama about a union organizer, they were envisioning a variation on the filmmaking that had first caught their attention.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe wanted to take the legacy of neo-realism and add to it the grandeur of the spettacolo \u2014 the panoramas of John Ford, the melodrama of Giotto\u2019s frescoes,\u201d Mr. Taviani said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough the brothers worked with top stars like Isabella Rossellini and Marcello Mastroianni, their films often used unknown actors. They drew on history and literature \u2014 their source material included Tolstoy, for \u201cSan Michele aveva un gallo\u201d (\u201cSt. Michael Had a Rooster\u201d) in 1972; and Luigi Pirandello, for \u201cKaos,\u201d in 1984. They would mix panoramic shots with close-ups in which, as one review put it, \u201cyou can play connect the dots with the actors\u2019 pores.\u201d\n\nTheir formula for co-directing their more than 20 films was simple: They would alternate scenes, and when it was one brother\u2019s turn to direct, the other would not actively interfere but would keep vigil at the video monitor.\n\n\u201cWe have a very acute nonverbal, telepathic communication,\u201d Vittorio Taviani told The Times in a 2013 interview. \u201cIf the one at the monitor starts to scratch his head, the other understands. So we have a silent meeting, we correct it, and then we go off again.\u201d\n\nIdeas would often be exchanged and scripts discussed while they walked their dogs together in a Rome park.\n\n\u201cIn the sun or the rain or the snow we keep walking,\u201d Mr. Taviani said in a 1986 interview with The Times, \u201cand talk about whatever comes into our heads \u2014 movies, dogs, beautiful things, horrible ones, the things that make us angry. At some point a story might emerge from an anecdote or a memory, or a page from a book, and eventually we realize it has to be written down.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Tornatore, for one, was envious.\n\n\u201cThey thought in exactly the same way, almost as if they were the same person,\u201d he said. \u201cLike all directors who understood their prodigious mental organization, I envied them. Who wouldn\u2019t want to have a brother with whom to share the difficulty of making films, without the work suffering even the most minimal stylistic incoherence?\u201d\n\nThe brothers had directed a half-dozen features and received some showings at international festivals when, in 1977, their big break came with \u201cPadre Padrone,\u201d a film about a shepherd whose brutal father deprives him of an education but who goes on to become a well-regarded linguist nonetheless.\n\nThe film won the Palme d\u2019Or, the top prize at Cannes, as well as the festival\u2019s International Critics Prize. Janet Maslin, reviewing it in The Times, called it \u201cvivid and very moving, coarse but seldom blunt, and filled with raw landscapes that underscore the naturalness and inevitability of the father\u2010son rituals it depicts.\u201d\n\nAmong the brothers\u2019 better-known later films are \u201cLa notte di San Lorenzo\u201d (\u201cThe Night of the Shooting Stars,\u201d 1982), a somewhat autobiographical tale about an Italian village at the end of World War II, and \u201cCesare deve morire\u201d (\u201cCaesar Must Die,\u201d 2012), a fictional film about a production of \u201cJulius Caesar\u201d staged in a prison, for which the brothers cast real inmates and ex-convicts. It won the top prize, the Golden Bear, at the Berlin International Film Festival and made its United States premiere at the 2012 New York Film Festival.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to his wife and his brother Paolo, Mr. Taviani is survived by his children, Francesca, Giovanna and Giuliano Taviani; another brother, Franco; and three grandchildren.\n\nAfter the release of \u201cCaesar Must Die,\u201d Vittorio Taviani, 83 at the time, was asked about future films.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re sure that another one will come along, just as we\u2019re sure about death,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m saying that in a beautiful realistic sense, considering our age.\u201d", "title": "Vittorio Taviani, 88, Dies; Made Acclaimed Films With Brother", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "In times of anxiety and distrust, it\u2019s much easier to argue for clear centralized authority than dispersed, amorphous authority.\n\nSecond, liberal democracy\u2019s ultimate loyalty is to an abstraction \u2014 to a constitution, a creed and a set of democratic norms. We in the democratic camp are always alarmed when we see a Putin or a Donald Trump or a Xi Jinping trashing norms to amass personal power.\n\nBut authoritarianism\u2019s ultimate loyalty is to a person. The man himself. As M. Steven Fish put it in The Journal of Democracy, \u201cPutin is not merely Russia\u2019s best-known, most powerful politician; he is its only politician.\u201d Neither Putin\u2019s followers, nor Trump\u2019s, nor Xi Jinping\u2019s are bothered by the trampling of norms, so long as there\u2019s a person in charge willing to take the mantle of command.\n\nIn times of anxiety and distrust, it\u2019s much easier to rally people around a person than an abstraction.\n\nThird, liberal democracy is built on a faith, a faith in the capacities of individual citizens. Faith, as you know, is confidence in things hoped for and evidence of things not seen. We democrats put faith in the idea that people know best how to run their own lives and that these individual choices can be woven into a common fabric.\n\nPutinism, like Trumpism, is based on a cynicism. It\u2019s based on the idea that one should have no illusions, be wise to the ways of the world. People are, as Machiavelli put it, ungrateful and deceitful, timid of danger and avid for profit. Rivalry is inevitable. Everything is partisan. Anybody or any institution that claims to be objective and above the fray is a liar.\n\nIn this world, everything is public relations, and the more shameless the charade the better because people will believe whatever is in their interest to believe.\n\nIn times of anxiety and distrust, it\u2019s much easier to sell cynicism than idealism.\n\nFinally, liberal democracy is built on the idea that people who are nothing like you are still worthy of respect and attention, that politics is about striking compromises with people you can barely stand to be in the same room with.", "title": "Opinion | Vladimir Putin, the Most Influential Man in the World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Thousands of students across the United States walked out of their classrooms and into the nation\u2019s schoolyards and streets on Friday in a renewed, coordinated protest against gun violence.\n\nThe demonstrations, from the statehouse in Texas to a Chicago park, coincided with the 19th anniversary of the mass shooting at Colorado\u2019s Columbine High School \u2014 a rampage that stirs students still, even though it happened before most of today\u2019s high school students were born.\n\nFriday\u2019s walkout was the third nationally organized student protest in the two months since 17 people were shot and killed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla. Students walked out of classes in March and held rallies across the country later in the month. They say that elected officials have not done enough to prevent school shootings despite a yearslong national debate and the grim roll call of campus killings since Columbine.\n\nShortly before the walkout on Friday began, at 10 a.m., another Florida high school was the site of a shooting when a 19-year-old man entered Forest High School in Ocala and shot a 17-year-old student before being apprehended by an officer stationed at the school. The victim was expected to survive.", "title": "Voices and Pictures From the Student Walkouts: \u2018We Deserve to Live Without Fear\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "He succeeded in preventing a collapse of sales and profits. But Mr. M\u00fcller, who has spent his entire career at Volkswagen or its subsidiaries, struggled to deliver on his promise to remake the company\u2019s insular culture. The carmaker has continued to suffer blows to its reputation, including revelations in January that it had financed tests on monkeys in a bungled attempt to show that diesel exhaust was not as dangerous as it once was.\n\nMr. Diess, 59, carries less baggage than Mr. M\u00fcller because he arrived at Volkswagen only a few months before the diesel deceit erupted. And Mr. Diess has led Volkswagen\u2019s push to mass produce electric cars, which are seen as essential to the company\u2019s ability to defend itself against challengers like Tesla, Uber and Google that are trying to upend the auto industry.\n\n\u201cThis is a chance for Volkswagen to make a change,\u201d said Christian Strenger, the former chief executive of Deutsche Bank\u2019s wealth management division, who is suing Volkswagen because he said it violated its duty to shareholders by failing to be forthcoming about the emissions scandal. But Mr. Strenger said that Mr. Diess would have to \u201chave the guts to clean things up.\u201d\n\nVolkswagen is still the target of a wide-ranging criminal investigation that has included searches of Mr. M\u00fcller\u2019s offices. However, there has been no new information that would have prompted Mr. M\u00fcller to leave now, said Klaus Ziehe, a spokesman for the prosecutors in Braunschweig who are conducting the inquiry.\n\nGerman prosecutors have not charged anyone in the Volkswagen case, but they expect to complete their investigation this year. Two former Volkswagen executives, James Liang and Oliver Schmidt, are serving prison sentences in the United States after pleading guilty to charges including conspiracy to violate the Clean Air Act.\n\nMr. M\u00fcller was a high-ranking executive involved in product development at the same time that the company was developing the illegal software and deploying it in vehicles. He also worked closely with some of the people under investigation over possible involvement in the emissions scandal. Mr. M\u00fcller has insisted he was ignorant of any wrongdoing, but he has nonetheless faced the accusation that he was part of a system that allowed it to take place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday, Volkswagen said it was considering \u201ca further development of the management structure of the group,\u201d which could \u201cinclude a change in the position of the chairman of the board of management,\u201d referring to Mr. M\u00fcller. The company said it had not yet made a decision on him, but merely calling his status into question effectively sealed his fate.\n\nMr. Diess has a shorter history at Volkswagen than most other members of the management board, but he would nonetheless satisfy the company\u2019s longtime preference for choosing chief executives from within its own ranks. He joined Volkswagen in July 2015 from BMW, where he had been a member of the management board in charge of product development. He has succeeded in improving the profitability of the division that makes Volkswagen brand cars like the Golf, Jetta and Passat. The division accounts for most of the cars that Volkswagen sells but is far less profitable than the company\u2019s Audi and Porsche luxury brands.\n\nMr. Diess, who managed factories in Britain for BMW, is much more comfortable speaking English than Mr. M\u00fcller and will have an easier time communicating with investors and media outside Germany. Mr. Diess has also not spent his career steeped in Volkswagen culture and may be in a better position to change it.\n\nBut he will most likely face resistance from entrenched interests within the company. He has already clashed with Volkswagen\u2019s powerful workers council, which has de facto veto power over major decisions.\n\nAnd Mr. Diess must answer to Hans Dieter P\u00f6tsch, the chairman of the supervisory board and former chief financial officer of Volkswagen. Mr. P\u00f6tsch is a confidant of the Porsche family, which via a holding company owns more than half of Volkswagen\u2019s shares. The family, descendants of the man who created the Volkswagen Beetle for Adolf Hitler, has been criticized by shareholders for failing to appoint more independent members of the supervisory board and resisting more sweeping change.\n\nThe challenges that Mr. Diess faces are considerable. Even now, the diesel scandal continues to corrode Volkswagen\u2019s reputation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn January, The New York Times reported that the company had helped to finance experiments in which monkeys were forced to breathe diesel fumes at a lab in Albuquerque. The exposure of the research caused a furor in Germany and beyond. Chancellor Angela Merkel condemned the experiments, the German Parliament debated possible consequences, and animal rights activists demonstrated outside Volkswagen\u2019s headquarters in Wolfsburg.\n\nVolkswagen\u2019s cheating has also had an effect on the wider industry. Diesel was once the most popular engine option in Europe because of its fuel economy. But diesel vehicle sales have been dropping since Volkswagen\u2019s deception was uncovered.\n\nThe scandal exposed the degree to which virtually all of the European carmakers took advantage of regulatory loopholes to sell diesels that polluted far more in everyday use than in official tests, causing poor air quality that led to thousands of premature deaths. As a result, cities across Europe have taken steps to restrict the use of diesel vehicles in urban centers. German carmakers have suffered the most from the backlash because of their dependence on the technology.\n\nVolkswagen\u2019s stock price closed the day 3.1 percent higher, at 169 euros, or about $208, on the news of Mr. M\u00fcller\u2019s upcoming departure.", "title": "Volkswagen Set to Oust Matthias M\u00fcller as C.E.O. After Diesel Scandal", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "And Volkswagen indicated it would prepare its truck and bus divisions for possible sale on the stock market, a major departure after decades of empire building by previous chief executives.\n\nUntil recently, bigness for its own sake was essential to Volkswagen\u2019s identity. The company\u2019s unique culture is pervasive not only within its vast factory complex but also in the city of 125,000 across a barge canal. Volkswagen is Wolfsburg\u2019s dominant employer, the main source of tax revenue, even the owner of the local professional soccer team.\n\nStatus at the company automatically brings status in the community. License plates issued for company cars include letter codes \u2014 understood by everyone in Wolfsburg \u2014 that signify whether the driver is a high-ranking Volkswagen manager or even a manager\u2019s spouse.\n\nVolkswagen\u2019s deeply embedded, conformist ethos was seen as a proximate cause of the scandal. It was why no one challenged the managers who devised illegal software to cover up excess engine emissions, and why no one reported the wrongdoing to any outside authorities for nearly a decade.\n\nPhoto\n\nChanging the culture is one of Mr. Diess\u2019s primary tasks. It is effectively a condition of the agreement Volkswagen made with United States authorities to settle civil and criminal actions stemming from the emissions wrongdoing. Volkswagen is required to establish a stronger whistle-blower system, and ensure that employees believe they can use it.\n\n\u201cCulture is certainly the most difficult task for Diess,\u201d said Ferdinand Dudenh\u00f6ffer, a professor at the University of Duisburg-Essen who follows the car industry.\n\nMr. M\u00fcller took over in late 2015 after the scandal became public, but lately seemed to lose momentum. He had expressed frustration with how long it was taking for Volkswagen to move past the scandal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Diess won favor with the Porsche and Pi\u00ebch families, who own a majority of Volkswagen\u2019s voting shares, by improving profits at the division that makes Volkswagen-brand cars despite a decline in the number of vehicles sold.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe has demonstrated to impressive effect the speed and rigor with which he can implement radical transformation,\u201d Hans Dieter P\u00f6tsch, the chairman of the Volkswagen supervisory board and a confidant of the Porsche family, said in a statement.\n\nBut Mr. Dudenh\u00f6ffer noted that Mr. Diess will still have to contend with the extraordinary power that Volkswagen workers and local politicians exert over strategy.\n\nThe State of Lower Saxony owns 20 percent of the company and has two representatives on the supervisory board. Worker representatives have another 10 seats on the 20-person board, meaning that unions and the state government together control the company.\n\n\u201cThere is no balance of power in the supervisory board,\u201d Mr. Dudenh\u00f6ffer said.\n\nIn a demonstration of worker power, the supervisory board on Thursday also named a high-ranking labor representative, Gunnar Kilian, as head of personnel. The board-level position includes responsibility for negotiations with unions.\n\nIn another major change, Francisco Javier Garc\u00eda Sanz, a Spaniard who has been the board member in charge of procurement since 2001, will retire. Mr. Garc\u00eda Sanz exemplified Volkswagen\u2019s preference for managers with a long record of loyalty.\n\nWorker control helps explain why people in Wolfsburg identify so strongly with Volkswagen. But it will also make it difficult for Mr. Diess to reduce the work force, a move considered essential if Volkswagen is to become as efficient as its biggest rival, Toyota.\n\nThe Wolfsburg system has defeated outsiders in the past. The last time Volkswagen had a chief executive who had not spent nearly all his career at the company was when Bernd Pischetsrieder, like Mr. Diess a former BMW manager, took over in 2002. Mr. Pischetsrieder was pushed out after about four years.", "title": "Volkswagen\u2019s New C.E.O. Is an Outsider. That\u2019s an Asset, and a Liability.", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "So our mind-set at that time is: How are we going to deal with this circumstance from an injury standpoint, a systematic standpoint and a smooth-running machine? That\u2019s in our brain at the beginning. We try to set our emotions apart from that immediately, but we\u2019re humans and we really care about the people we take care of. We have to fight the battle of depersonalization all the time, but when you\u2019re trying to save somebody\u2019s life, you can\u2019t be emotional.\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: It\u2019s a tragedy for the people involved, the community at large. For us, it\u2019s a Tuesday. We\u2019re going to do what we have to do whether it\u2019s two patients or 20.\n\nThe police say that the gunmen at the church and at the school used handguns, but that the suspect at Waffle House used an AR-15, a rifle. How do the weapons change the nature of the injuries you\u2019re treating?\n\nDr. Miller: Trajectory equals injury. It\u2019s much easier to know the trajectory of a single gunshot wound where you have an entrance and an exit and you can figure out the path. When somebody comes in with multiple gunshot wounds based on someone with an automatic rifle shooting them eight times, you\u2019ve got to figure out which bullet is going to kill them, and that can be a lot more challenging.\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: If a small bullet hits the right place, it\u2019s just as deadly as a big bullet that hits the right place.\n\nGiven the era we seem to be in, are you finding that bystanders are more prepared to offer first aid?\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: It started out slow, and now it\u2019s kind of building momentum.\n\nThe Boston Marathon bombing was kind of an eye-opener because of all of the extremity injuries that occurred. It married very well with what we\u2019ve seen in both the Iraq and Afghanistan wars: that tourniquets work, and they protect people from dying.\n\nPhoto\n\nIf pressure doesn\u2019t work, if wadding up some padding doesn\u2019t work, the next step is a tourniquet above the wound and tightening it down until the bleeding stops. That is something a 5-year-old can do. Whether you want to get into the ethics of teaching a 5-year-old to use a tourniquet, that\u2019s up to you. I can\u2019t see that any normal bystander without training would feel comfortable doing that, even if given the opportunity to. But in the modern world, the real concept is that we will each be at risk for this event occurring sometime in our life, and if we\u2019re not prepared to at least lend a hand, we\u2019re going to put people at risk.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Miller: People out of harm\u2019s way, if the harm has been done and is over, they want to help. They want to help other people.\n\nIt\u2019s just like doing C.P.R. on the street. Now it\u2019s changed from C.P.R. to stopping bleeding.\n\nHave you, or your response system, made any changes based on lessons learned from the shootings?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: Every single one of these events, we have a plan in place.\n\nWe sat down and talked about the process. You think about the logistics: It\u2019s not just the injury, it\u2019s not just getting the patient here, but it\u2019s the entire onslaught of everyone else around the institution that thinks that now is the moment that they can help.\n\nWe have a set amount of people that are supposed to be in every single trauma room, and now you\u2019ve doubled that \u2014 all with well-intentioned people. The flow gets changed by onlookers who are trying to do the best they can to help, and what they don\u2019t realize is we see 6,000 traumas a year.\n\nDr. Miller: You have to use your troops appropriately, and there are some of us who won\u2019t come in for the first surge. It\u2019s become, unfortunately, a science behind these mass shootings and disasters.\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: If you have a mass event and we look back on what we can do better, very little of that is going to be the clinical acumen of what we do. It\u2019s going to be the logistics.\n\nNot many trauma centers have recently dealt with as many mass shootings as Vanderbilt. How do you and your staff cope?\n\nDr. Miller: The balance between empathy and objectivity is very difficult sometimes because in the heat of the moment, you\u2019re trying to save somebody\u2019s life, but your empathy for the patient and the family after that can overwhelm you. If you\u2019re exposed to it too much without therapy, you\u2019re going to get burned out and you\u2019re done.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe therapy is, first and foremost, talking about it. We debrief after every tragedy. I mean, we get lots of 15-year-olds who get shot in the head and die, and we talk about that, not just in these circumstances.\n\nAnd then self-care. You must be able to take a break and intervene mindfulness and things that have meaning in your life. Whatever floats your boat. For me, it\u2019s triathlons. For Oscar, it\u2019s biking and swimming. We have to try and separate what we do here from what we do in the regular world. That is something that, in the past, we have not been very good at.\n\nWe also understand that we cannot save everyone\u2019s life. We have to understand that no matter what we do, people are going to die, and we have to accept the fact that we do the best that we can.\n\nDr. Guillamondegui: I don\u2019t think there\u2019s ever a way to get over all of it. I don\u2019t think that all of the wellness in the world takes away from the burden that you carry. I\u2019m not trying to make it into more than it is. I pray for grace and hope we make things better for the people around us. That\u2019s some solace.", "title": "Waffle House Attack Was These Doctors\u2019 3rd Mass Shooting in Just Months", "authors": ["Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities had cautioned that Mr. Reinking, who was accused of using an AR-15 in the assault early Sunday, should be considered \u201carmed and dangerous.\u201d On Monday morning the police said there were 160 law enforcement officers searching for Mr. Reinking, but there had been \u201cno credible sightings\u201d of him at that time.\n\nThe Tennessee Bureau of Investigation had added Mr. Reinking to its Top Ten Most Wanted list, and some of Nashville\u2019s public schools imposed \u201clockout\u201d rules on Monday in a bid to protect students and staff members from a suspect who was at large into the workweek.\n\nBy the time classes were dismissed on Monday, Mr. Reinking was in custody. But investigators said they were still working to piece together the attack that also left four others wounded.\n\nOfficials, from detectives to trauma surgeons at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, said there would have been greater bloodshed had a 29-year-old customer, James Shaw Jr., not wrested the rifle away from Mr. Reinking while he was reloading. Mr. Reinking then fled the restaurant, the police said, naked except for a green jacket.\n\nThe carnage stirred fears of a hate crime because Mr. Reinking is white and three of the people who were killed were black.\n\nBut in an interview on Monday, about an hour before Mr. Reinking\u2019s arrest, the mayor said he had no reason to believe that the shooting was provoked by racial animus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNobody has told me anything that would indicate that\u2019s the motivating factor,\u201d Mr. Briley said in his office.\n\nInstead, Mr. Briley said there was \u201cenough indication that there was some element of mental illness associated with it, as opposed to it being intentional or planned.\u201d\n\nMr. Reinking has had other encounters with law enforcement, including an arrest near the White House last July when he crossed a security barrier as he sought a meeting with President Trump. And just last week, police officers near Nashville pursued Mr. Reinking after he was accused of stealing a B.M.W. from a dealership in Brentwood, said Don Aaron, a spokesman for the Nashville police.\n\nAfter the car was reported stolen, officers spotted the vehicle, Mr. Aaron said, and began chasing it through rush-hour traffic. The police soon stopped the pursuit because of concerns for other motorists\u2019 safety and because the car had tracking technology.\n\nThe police found the car later that evening at the apartment complex where Mr. Reinking lived, Mr. Aaron said, but \u201cthey had no idea who the man was.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Reinking is believed to have moved to Nashville last fall, and police reports show family members expressed concern for his welfare after he exhibited delusional behavior for an extended time, including expressing a belief that the entertainer Taylor Swift was stalking him and hacking his phone and Netflix account.\n\nAfter his arrest near the White House Mr. Reinking, who lived in Morton, Ill., was forced to surrender three rifles and a handgun to officials in August, just months before he moved to Nashville.\n\nIn the wake of the rampage in Nashville on Sunday, officials could not fully explain how Mr. Reinking regained possession of his weapons. The Tazewell County Sheriff\u2019s Office in Illinois gave the weapons he owned \u2014 including the AR-15 he took to the Waffle House on Sunday \u2014 to his father, Jeffrey Reinking.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSheriff Robert M. Huston of Tazewell County said in a news conference on Sunday that while Travis Reinking \u201cvoluntarily surrendered\u201d the weapons on Aug. 24, his father had a firearm owner\u2019s identification card and a legal right to take the weapons.\n\n\u201cHe was allowed to do that after he assured deputies that he would keep them secure and away from Travis,\u201d Sheriff Huston said. \u201cWe have no information about how Travis came back into possession of those firearms.\u201d\n\nThe police in Nashville indicated that Mr. Reinking\u2019s father returned the weapons to his son. He could not be reached for comment on Monday.\n\nOn Monday, however, Special Agent Marcus Watson of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said Mr. Reinking\u2019s father could face a prosecution of his own for violating weapons laws.", "title": "Waffle House Shooting Suspect Is in Custody, Nashville Police Say", "authors": ["Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Jeffrey Reinking\u2019s act of returning the guns to his son is \u201cpotentially a violation of federal law,\u201d Marcus Watson, a special agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, said at a news conference.\n\nJeffrey Reinking could not be reached for comment on Monday. After Travis Reinking\u2019s arrest in Washington last year, the F.B.I. passed on information about him to local authorities in Illinois, where he was ordered to complete 32 hours of community service at a Baptist church near Morton. The F.B.I. closed its investigation of Mr. Reinking in October.\n\nAbout 160 law enforcement officials were involved in the search for Mr. Reinking, who officials said began his rampage at the restaurant southeast of downtown Nashville just before 3:30 a.m. on Sunday. The episode unnerved one of the largest cities in the South, focusing attention yet again on the ease with which so many people, including those with mental health issues, can access guns.\n\nMr. Reinking was seized on Monday afternoon in a wooded area less than a mile from the Waffle House. He was wearing a backpack containing a loaded handgun, but Nashville police said he surrendered without incident. The authorities said he was refusing to speak to detectives.\n\nThe police also said on Monday that Mr. Reinking had stolen a BMW last week after posing as a customer at a local dealership, and eluded officers in a chase.\n\nThe authorities identified those who were killed as Akilah Dasilva, 23; DeEbony Groves, 21; Joe R. Perez, 20; and Taurean C. Sanderlin, 29. The authorities said there would have been greater bloodshed had a 29-year-old customer, James Shaw Jr., not wrested the rifle away from Mr. Reinking while he was reloading. Mr. Reinking fled the restaurant after the attack, the police said, naked except for a green jacket.\n\nMr. Reinking is white, and the four victims were either African-American or Hispanic, but Mayor David Briley of Nashville said he had no reason to believe that these were racially motivated killings. Instead, Mr. Briley said, there was \u201cenough indication that there was some element of mental illness associated with it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Reinking lived in Illinois for most of his life and only recently moved to the Nashville area to work in construction.\n\nIn reports, the sheriff\u2019s department in Tazewell County, Ill., had described Mr. Reinking as a man who was hostile to the police, had threatened suicide and believed his family was harassing him.\n\nHis father, mother and grandmother were all worried enough about his behavior that they called for help. They told the police that Mr. Reinking had been having delusions since August 2014.\n\nIn May 2016, police officers responded to a CVS parking lot in Morton after Mr. Reinking\u2019s family reported that he had talked of committing suicide, and owned firearms. Mr. Reinking told officers that Ms. Swift had stalked him and hacked into his Netflix account.\n\nPhoto\n\nA few weeks earlier, he told officers, he had chased Ms. Swift in an attempt to get her to stop harassing him. \u201cTravis stated he was telling the truth and he had proof on his phone since it was hacked,\u201d the report said. \u201cHowever, Travis would not show us his phone.\u201d\n\nMr. Reinking was transported to a hospital to be evaluated. In June 2017, the police were called to a public pool in Tremont, Ill., where he had dived into a pool wearing a housecoat, then had shed the coat, wearing only underwear.\n\nAccording to the report, Mr. Reinking began yelling at lifeguards and then \u201cshowed his genitals, saying he was a man.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, he was not arrested.\n\n\u201cThis is an informational report showing the state of mind of Travis Reinking,\u201d the report noted. When the police contacted Mr. Reinking\u2019s father, he said that he had taken three rifles and a handgun away from his son \u201cwhen Travis was having problems,\u201d then gave them back to him.\n\nThe officers advised Jeffrey Reinking that \u201che might want to lock the guns back up until Travis gets mental help, which he stated he would.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn August 2017, Travis Reinking, driving a blue Mitsubishi, pulled up alongside a police car and said he wanted to file a report. About 20 to 30 people were hacking into his phone and computer, he told the police. He could hear people outside his home barking like dogs, but didn\u2019t know who they were. At a Walmart recently, he felt that a man in a black shirt was watching him, and no one else.\n\n\u201cTravis said he is tired of people messing with him,\u201d the report said. The officer advised Mr. Reinking to call the police if he heard people barking like dogs again. \u201cNo further action is being taken,\u201d the report said.\n\nLater that month, after the White House incident, the police approached Mr. Reinking and his father to deliver a copy of the paper revoking his license. He handed over the card and helped the police retrieve all of his weapons and ammunition, which were handed over to Jeffrey Reinking.\n\n\u201cJeffrey was advised that he needed to keep the weapons secure and away from Travis,\u201d the police report said. \u201cJeffrey stated he would comply.\u201d\n\nAccording to Illinois gun law, a person must be granted a Firearm Owners Identification card, or FOID, to possess a firearm. About 2.1 million people in Illinois have the cards.\n\nBut under the law, the process to keep firearms out of the hands of a person whose card has been revoked is weak, allowing many people to keep access to the weapons with little threat of enforcement or penalty.\n\nThe Illinois State Police revoked more than 11,000 cards in 2016, said a spokesman, Lt. Matthew Boerwinkle. People whose cards have been revoked are required to surrender the card and any weapons to a local law enforcement agency. But there is a provision that allows people whose license has been revoked to transfer their weapons to another person with a valid card, as Mr. Reinking\u2019s father had.\n\nThose local police departments are then required to document that the person has turned over the card and weapons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut local law enforcement agencies frequently fail to take action. In 2016, only about 4,000 of the 11,000 people whose cards were revoked submitted the mandatory reports explaining what they did with their guns, The Chicago Tribune reported in 2017.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re required to do it, but there\u2019s essentially no teeth in the law that holds the law enforcement agencies accountable to do it,\u201d Lieutenant Boerwinkle said on Monday.\n\nThere is nothing in the law requiring that the person holding the weapons must lock them up, or even live in a different house than the person whose FOID card was revoked, Lieutenant Boerwinkle said.\n\nTransferring firearms to another Illinois resident who does not have a valid card is a crime in Illinois. Jeffrey Reinking has indicated to the police that he gave his son\u2019s guns back to him, but it is not clear how and when he did so, said Mr. Aaron, the spokesman for the Nashville police.", "title": "Waffle House Shooting Suspect Once Had His Guns Taken Away.
