[The Guardian]", "title": "Waffle House, North Korea, Iran: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The show\u2019s influence was so great that it even managed to elevate Mr. Gandolfini, the bearish actor who played Tony Soprano, into a sex symbol after playing bit-player thugs in movies including \u201cTrue Romance.\u201d\n\nBut nothing in \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d was sexier than the setting itself. \u201cMy intention is to present New Jersey as a place of contrasts, like it really is,\u201d Mr. Chase was quoted as saying. \u201cI have a feeling that people think it\u2019s only a toxic dump. That\u2019s why I include shots of the waterfall and the more bucolic scenes. For such a small place, it has a lot of facets to it. And that\u2019s only northern New Jersey. I wish we could go down the shore, but on our budget we can\u2019t, sort of like when I was in high school.\u201d\n\nCalling in reinforcements: It made sense that New Jersey was suddenly embraced by the cool crowd, Mr. DeCaro argued, since seemingly every other celebrity turned out to be from there. A Vanity Fair story from a few years earlier, \u201cGarden State Babylon,\u201d listed more than 120 New Jersey-bred celebrities and influencers, including Charles Addams and Pia Zadora, broken down by turnpike exit. Meryl Streep, Martha Stewart, Bruce Willis, Jack Nicholson, Deborah Harry, Tom Cruise \u2014 was anyone super-famous not from New Jersey?\n\nAnd then there was that little-known comedian from Lawrenceville, Jon Stewart, before he transformed comedy television with \u201cThe Daily Show.\u201d No wonder that by 1999, New Jersey had \u201cgone from a private shame to a juggernaut,\u201d as the playwright Paul Rudnick, from Piscataway, was quoted as saying.\n\nFast forward: Two decades later, those old New Jersey jokes sound as dated as a Bob Hope routine (although Jersey bashing enjoyed a brief renaissance with \u201cJersey Shore\u201d). Sure, the Nets fled the Meadowlands for Brooklyn. But lately, the real flow seems to be going the other way, as stratospheric real estate prices in New York City have inspired members of the creative class to decamp to the Boss\u2019s backyard to live, raise families and, you know, \u201ccreate.\u201d\n\nThe migration is enough of a thing that Time Out New York ran an article a few years ago, \u201cThe Coolest Places in New Jersey for New Yorkers,\u201d that offered Garden State alternatives to New York neighborhoods: Montclair as Greenwich Village; Jersey City as Williamsburg; Westfield as the Upper East Side; and so forth. It was a useful guide for would-be colonizers, surely. But ask any Jerseyite: They really don\u2019t need New York publications to tell them they\u2019re cool, thank you very much.\n\nA Garden State of mind: \u201cI was born in Manhattan,\u201d Mr. DeCaro said last week, \u201cwhich technically makes me a New York native, but as Neve Campbell says in the movie \u201854,\u2019 let\u2019s face it, I\u2019m Jersey. It took me only 25 years of living in the city \u2014 and now five years of living in Los Angeles \u2014 to be able to say that. Today, from 3,000 miles away, I appreciate my home state like never before. In L.A., I proudly wear a Jersey Strong T-shirt and drink my morning coffee out of a Lincoln Tunnel mug, suburb-side forward. And, after all this time, I can finally, proudly admit something: My exit is 153-B.\u201d", "title": "Wait, New Jersey Was Once Not Cool?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Such was the reality of German and Austrian art, and German and Austrian society, in the initial years of Nazi rule: the awkward coexistence of fascists, democrats and Communists, who heard the rhetoric, who witnessed the hatred, but who still could not see how much horror lay ahead. One of the high points of \u201cBefore the Fall\u201d is a suite of woodcuts by Wilhelm Traeger, whose street scenes of Vienna in 1932 seem like an X-ray of a society on the edge. In these thickly inked, brashly contoured prints, made when Traeger was just 25, a hunchback shuffles past a brick wall plastered with a call to \u201cVote Red,\u201d while a skeletal veteran on crutches begs for change as women in furs strut past. Newspaper salesmen, taxi drivers, chain smokers in the coffee house: All are living on the brink.\n\nWas it even possible for painters who opposed the Nazis, but who did not follow Beckmann and other \u201cdegenerate\u201d artists into exile or dissidence, to make meaningful art in Germany in the late 1930s? \u201cBefore the Fall\u201d answers this question equivocally \u2014 but it comes closest with the art of a Jewish painter who, it goes without saying, could not treat that question academically. That artist, Felix Nussbaum, was in Rome in 1933, having been awarded Germany\u2019s most prestigious art scholarship to study there, when Hitler took power in Berlin. His scholarship was quickly withdrawn, and he lived and painted in exile \u2014 in Italy, Paris, Ostend, Brussels \u2014 before the Nazis arrested him and sent him to an internment camp in southern France in 1940.\n\nNussbaum escaped, and later that year, he painted \u201cSelf-Portrait in the Camp\u201d: a harsh, indelible artwork that puts all the other portraits in this show in their full, brutal context. Nussbaum appears in three-quarter profile, his left eye in shadow, his right eye sunken but locked upon us. He has grown a goatee, and his drab brown uniform has a frayed collar and a hasty patch on its right shoulder. Behind him, past scavenging and defecating prisoners, is a fence of barbed wire, and beyond it, a sky of ferrous gray. Nussbaum appears wearied. But his gaze is defiant, asserting an individuality that serves as proof of a continuing, unspeakable crime.", "title": "Walk Through This Exhibition With Dread. You Know Where It Leads.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "State securities regulators say that the legislation would gut their powers, even though relatively few executives were held to account following the financial crisis.\n\n\u201cThis bill would be terrible for investors all across America,\u201d Eric Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, said in an interview. \u201cFor every Fortune 500 C.E.O. who walks away with a bruised ego, there are dozens and dozens of lower-level scam artists who we put out of business through the state securities laws.\u201d\n\nJoseph P. Borg, the longtime director of the Alabama Securities Commission, said, \u201cAny way you look at it, this bill is going to put investors at not only a disadvantage, but deep in harm\u2019s way.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf I can\u2019t prosecute, then what\u2019s the deterrent?\u201d added Mr. Borg, who is also the head of the North American Securities Administrators Association. \u201cIf I can\u2019t bring civil action, then what\u2019s the deterrent? None.\u201d\n\nCritics of the bill also said it represented the kind of rollback of states\u2019 rights for which Republicans once criticized Democrats. President Trump is already challenging the states on sanctuary cities and California\u2019s power to set its own car regulations.\n\nThe securities bill was introduced by Representative Tom MacArthur, a New Jersey Republican and a former A.I.G. executive who once worked for Mr. Greenberg. C.V. Starr, Mr. Greenberg\u2019s current company, has backed Mr. MacArthur\u2019s campaign. A spokesman for the congressman said he was unavailable to comment.\n\nBlair Holmes, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Chamber, said the organization was reviewing the legislation. \u201cThis issue has always been important to many members,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIf it goes through, the bill\u2019s text says it would \u201cprovide for exclusive federal jurisdiction over civil securities fraud actions.\u201d It also says that \u201cdiffering state regulatory requirements\u201d create \u201cinefficiencies,\u201d raise costs and harm markets \u201cwithout providing material investor protection benefits.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Greenberg and his staff said the legislation would only affect civil enforcement related to stocks, bonds and other securities listed on national exchanges. State regulators disagree, saying it would also hamper their criminal jurisdiction related to such securities.\n\nThe bill language says that state officials can proceed with criminal enforcement provided they \u201ccomply in all respects with the legal requirements for securities fraud under federal law.\u201d State regulators fear that such language is specifically intended to curtail their ability to bring criminal cases.\n\nOne feature of the Martin Act is that it does not require the state to prove that someone actually intended to defraud people, a lower bar than what is required at the federal level.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s outrageous,\u201d Mr. Greenberg said of the intent issue. Asked if legislation broadly targeting all states was an appropriate remedy, he replied: \u201cSo is it better to have a law that violates every principle? Is that better? You can be tried for something without having to prove intent? Are we a third world country?\u201d\n\nThe case against him centered around two sets of transactions. One of them inflated A.I.G.\u2019s reserves at a time when analysts were criticizing the company for its flagging reserves. In a second series of deals, the insurer invested in an offshore entity in a way that allowed it to mask losses from one of its divisions.\n\nAfter Mr. Greenberg\u2019s ouster, A.I.G. restated its earnings by more than $3 billion. In 2006, the company reached a $1.64 billion settlement with federal, state and insurance regulators related to business practices stretching back two decades.\n\nMr. Greenberg has disputed much about the case.\n\n\u201cEliot Spitzer decided he wanted to take me down,\u201d he said. \u201cHe was successful. Destroyed a company that had a $180 billion market cap. Now it\u2019s what? A fraction of that. There\u2019s been seven C.E.O.s since I left the company. Destroyed a great asset.\u201d\n\nBut in a statement he made as part of his 2017 settlement, he said he \u201cinitiated, participated in and approved\u201d the transactions that \u201cinaccurately portrayed the accounting, and thus the financial condition and performance for A.I.G.\u2019s loss reserves and underwriting income.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA.I.G. also faced a reckoning and near failure in the financial crisis.\n\n\u201cThe notion that we would weaken one of the few statutes that was used effectively to confront structural failures on Wall Street defies logic, at a moment so soon after the economic cataclysm of 2008,\u201d Mr. Spitzer said in an interview.\n\nMr. Greenberg said he decided to settle last year because \u201cthere\u2019s a limit to how much any individual can endure fighting\u201d the state. He added: \u201cThere was no acknowledgment of any wrongdoing, No. 1. And that\u2019s important.\u201d\n\nMr. Schneiderman, the attorney general who settled the case, said Mr. Greenberg\u2019s case was \u201cvery straightforward,\u201d noting that A.I.G. had restated the transactions on its books.\n\nRegarding the legislation, he added, \u201cI don\u2019t know anyone who is saying we should have less regulation of securities fraud.\u201d", "title": "Wall Street Titan Takes Aim at Law That Tripped Him Up", "authors": ["Danny Hakim"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Still, Walmart missed out on China\u2019s e-commerce boom, and it does not want to make the same mistake with India \u2014 especially with its rival Amazon already a strong player there. Only about 2 percent of India\u2019s retail sales are online now, but tens of millions of Indians are getting onto the internet every year via cheap smartphones and rock-bottom mobile data prices.\n\nAmazon has committed at least $5.5 billion so far to building its India presence, fighting to gain market share among the country\u2019s young, increasingly tech-savvy shoppers. After starting an Indian site, Amazon.in, from scratch in 2013, Amazon blew past local players like Snapdeal and is now a close No. 2 to Flipkart in sales.\n\nWalmart\u2019s interest in India is the latest extension of the retailer\u2019s battle with Amazon. Rooted for decades in its network of stores, Walmart has been trying to bolster its online offerings. In just the past few years, it has acquired the hip, largely online clothing brands Bonobos and ModCloth, started a higher-end mattress and bedding line sold exclusively online and expanded home grocery delivery to 100 American cities.\n\nBased in Bangalore, Flipkart was founded in 2007 by Sachin Bansal and Binny Bansal. The two men, who are not related, worked briefly at Amazon\u2019s back-office operations in India before deciding to form their own company.\n\nLike Amazon, Flipkart initially started selling books online before expanding into a vast array of products. On its way to becoming India\u2019s top online retailer, it successfully navigated problems such as customers\u2019 preference for paying in cash and the country\u2019s spotty roads and delivery networks.\n\nWhile Walmart operates stores around the globe, India would be a relatively new frontier for the huge retailer. The company operates wholesale stores in India, but it has no public-facing retail or e-commerce presence.\n\nFlipkart would be one of Walmart\u2019s largest acquisitions since it acquired Asda, a large British grocery chain, in 1999. That deal would be valued at about $16 billion today, adjusted for inflation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnalysts point out that Walmart has made very few large acquisitions in its 56-year history and that some of those deals remain works in progress.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWalmart made a big splash in 2016 when it purchased the e-commerce site Jet.com for $3.3 billion. Jet, based in Hoboken, N.J., was supposed to be Walmart\u2019s answer to Amazon\u2019s appeal with higher-income, urban-dwelling millennials in the United States.\n\nBut there are signs that Walmart is still trying to fully integrate Jet into its larger e-commerce strategy. After reporting that its e-commerce sales growth had slowed in the fourth quarter, Walmart said it would focus on driving new customers through its main Walmart.com site, not through the Jet platform.\n\nAcquiring Flipkart would give Walmart an instant leg up on Amazon in India, but it is still likely to face stiff competition from its primary rival. Amazon\u2019s chief executive, Jeff Bezos, views India as his chance to make up for the company\u2019s failure to establish a major presence in China, just like Walmart. That likely means the online giant will double down on its investment there now that Walmart has come onto the scene.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think they should do it,\u201d Scott Mushkin, a retail analyst at Wolfe Research, said of Walmart\u2019s potential deal for Flipkart. \u201cAmazon is like an A.T.M. machine. I wouldn\u2019t want to be competing with Amazon in India.\u201d\n\nIn addition to pouring billions into its Indian e-commerce site, Amazon is also investing in original content from Bollywood movie studios and has developed local versions of crucial products, such as its Prime video streaming and Echo voice-activated speakers.\n\nAmazon\u2019s assault was so intense that a couple of years ago, some analysts were predicting that Flipkart would be crushed. Complicating matters, Flipkart was racked by management turmoil.\n\nBut Tiger Global, one of Flipkart\u2019s earliest and largest investors, pushed for the appointment of one of its own executives, Kalyan Krishnamurthy, as chief executive in January 2017. Mr. Krishnamurthy is credited with steadying the company and improving the customer experience.\n\nSoftBank, a Japanese investment firm that has been making large bets in India over the last few years, also agreed to provide $2.5 billion in fresh capital last summer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWalmart would bring an even larger potential source of funding to Flipkart as it tries to keep growing.\n\n\u201cFor the ecosystem, this is good,\u201d said Satish Meena, a senior analyst in New Delhi for Forrester, a technology research firm. \u201cThere is more money and more expertise coming into the system. And customers will get more products at a lower price.\u201d\n\nThe e-commerce market in India, which includes categories like travel, was about $38.5 billion last year, and it is expected to grow to $50 billion in 2018, according to a recent study by Deloitte and the Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India.\n\n\u201cThe whole game now is scale,\u201d said Bill Dreher, a retail analyst at Susquehanna International Group.", "title": "Walmart, With Billions to Spend, Seeks Flipkart E-Commerce Site in India", "authors": ["Vindu Goel", "Michael J. De La Merced", "Michael Corkery"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Fifty years ago on April 11, Congress enacted the Fair Housing Act, the last of the three great civil rights laws of the 1960s. Along with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act, it was an attempt by Congress to translate the movement led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and others into enduring statute. But it also has the more dubious distinction of being the most contested, most ignored and, at times, most misunderstood of those laws.\n\nFor most of the 20th century, an array of forces worked to divide American communities into black and white quarters. Some involved explicit discrimination, including racial redlining in federal mortgage insurance, and real estate covenants that restricted home buyers by race. But some were more subtle, like the steering by real estate agents of racial minorities into certain neighborhoods, biased lending and underwriting, and the concentration of low-income housing in low-income neighborhoods.\n\nBy the late 1960s, racial tensions came to a head, marked by civil disturbances that the bipartisan Kerner Commission attributed to the growth of \u201ctwo societies, one black, one white \u2014 separate and unequal.\u201d The fair housing bill, which had been filibustered for many years by segregationist senators, received a critical push from this report. Provisions that would have exempted single-family homes were defeated, and the law passed the Senate.\n\nThen, on April 4, 1968, Dr. King was assassinated. His death shook the nation, setting off another round of disturbances. Something had to be done \u2014 not just about America\u2019s ugly history of housing discrimination but also about the divided system that had led the nation to this awful moment. The assassination dislodged the stalled housing bill from the House Rules Committee, and one week later the Fair Housing Act was signed into law.", "title": "Opinion | Walter Mondale: The Civil Rights Law We Ignored", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "Help your local school district\n\nMany school districts have foundations set up to pay for things like classroom supplies and teachers\u2019 professional development, as well as other needs specific to each school.\n\nYou could start by calling your local school or parent-teacher organization and asking what the most urgent needs are. They may suggest that you donate to a foundation or perhaps buy specific supplies.\n\nOr, if you have something particular in mind, you can often designate where you would like your money to go: to musical instruments, for instance, or lab coats.\n\nCissy Bowman, a spokeswoman for the Mount Lebanon School District in suburban Pittsburgh, said some parents donated items like paper towels and Popsicle sticks. While schools are grateful for big-number donations that can help with larger needs, they are typically happy to accept any help they can get.\n\n\u201cThe real excitement in philanthropic giving is when you have many more smaller donations,\u201d she said.\n\nHelp individual students\n\nAshley Ford, a writer in Brooklyn, tweeted a suggestion in 2016:\n\nIn response, donors nationwide paid off thousands of dollars in lunch debts for thousands of students. Schools vary in their handling of such debts: Some schools will feed students regardless, others may offer less food, while still others could withhold meals entirely until the debts are paid.\n\nSchools probably won\u2019t tell potential donors about specific students\u2019 debts, but they may allow you to pay down the total amount of schoolwide debt. Start by calling the school and determining its specific policies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Ford said that \u201cit\u2019s about finding what the kids in your community need the most, starting at the most basic level and building from there.\u201d\n\n\u201cThink about sitting at that desk with your stomach growling,\u201d she said. \u201cHow do you focus on a math lesson? How do you really get into the book you\u2019re reading when you\u2019re hungry? You\u2019re doing these kids a disservice on every level if they\u2019re hungry.\u201d\n\nHelp schools across the country\n\nCharity Navigator, which assigns ratings to charities, lists hundreds of education-related organizations, many of which have no local connection. They cover early-childhood programs, scholarships, special education, classroom support and education policy support.", "title": "Want to Help Schools and Students? Here\u2019s How to Start", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The Mets went on to win, 4-2, taking the lead for good after the Phillies lifted their own top starter, Aaron Nola, who had worked five innings and thrown 87 pitches. The teams combined to use eight relievers, and the Mets\u2019 foursome \u2014 Robert Gsellman, Hansel Robles, AJ Ramos and Jeurys Familia \u2014 struck out eight in five scoreless innings.\n\nThis is baseball in 2018. The last two World Series have matched teams heavily influenced by analytics \u2014 the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians in 2016, the Houston Astros and the Los Angeles Dodgers last season. The Moneyball revolution that began in the early 2000s is no longer revolutionary. It is everywhere.\n\nLike Callaway, the former Cleveland pitching coach, the Phillies\u2019 Gabe Kapler is a first-time major league manager who came from one of those recent pennant-winners. But while Callaway is now 4-1 as a manager, Kapler, the former Dodgers farm director, has lost four of his first five games, some with baffling decisions.\n\nPhiladelphia fans \u2014 at least those who could find Wednesday\u2019s Facebook-only broadcast \u2014 cannot be happy. The Phillies will stage their home opener on Thursday, and even the presence of Doug Pederson, the coach of the Super Bowl-winning Eagles who will throw out the first pitch, may not save Kapler from an earful.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cLook, my focus is on getting our team ready to play our first home series,\u201d Kapler said. \u201cThis is not about me, this is about our players. Our players are very, very exciting. Our club is a good, deep, interesting club.\u201d\n\nSo far, though, Kapler\u2019s moves have been the most interesting thing about the Phillies, and not in a good way. He relies heavily on data, but several strategies have backfired, despite the research behind them.\n\nAfter lifting his starter on Wednesday \u2014 \u201cThe thought process was, as it always is: keep Nola safe, healthy and strong,\u201d he said \u2014 Kapler called for Drew Hutchison, a journeyman right-hander whose slider had impressed him all spring.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWith two out and two on in the sixth, Kapler expected Hutchison\u2019s slider to induce weak contact from the Mets\u2019 No. 9 hitter, Amed Rosario. He put right fielder Nick Williams in an extremely shallow position to keep a hit from falling in front of him \u2014 but instead, Rosario drove the slider well over Williams\u2019s head. It bounced to the wall for a two-run triple.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKapler is convinced that, in time, his moves will start to work. For now, though, he is left to insist that data-driven baseball will eventually pay off.\n\n\u201cWe have to be patient and trust that we\u2019re trying to look at a very large sample size to evaluate if our strategies are working effectively,\u201d Kapler said. \u201cI can\u2019t express enough confidence that our strategies will pay dividends, but I understand that in the short term, they haven\u2019t \u2014 and that can be disappointing. I get it.\u201d\n\nThe Phillies\u2019 pitchers will probably improve their current 5.56 earned run average, especially once their injured or rusty free-agent signees \u2014 Jake Arrieta, Tommy Hunter and Pat Neshek \u2014 join the roster. Likewise, the Mets\u2019 pitchers will probably not continue to strike out 61 batters every five games, and their bullpen will not be this sharp every day.\n\nThe larger question is what these trends mean for baseball. Statistics can be fascinating and revealing, challenging long-held assumptions and leading to more rational decisions. But when teams ask less of their players, we seem less likely to witness true greatness.\n\nConsider the fifth inning on Wednesday, when Nola faced Yoenis Cespedes with one out and the bases empty. It should not have been strange that he was allowed to do this. But now, with managers so nervous about letting pitchers face hitters three times in one game, it seemed almost quaint.\n\nCespedes had homered off Nola\u2019s curveball in the first inning, but this time, Nola struck him out with that very same pitch. Two batters later he was done for the day, and it seemed disturbingly normal.", "title": "Want to See the Starting Pitcher? Don\u2019t Arrive Late", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "CHENNAI, India \u2014 Over the last decade, India has been the world\u2019s largest importer of aircraft, ships and other military gear, most of it from Russia.\n\nIt is a dependence that the Indian government is eager to shed \u2014 and the United States wants to help.\n\nIn fits and starts, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been trying to build up a homegrown defense industry that can supply more of India\u2019s needs and even export weapons to other nations. The government in New Delhi is encouraging foreign defense companies seeking contracts from India to partner with local firms and share technology with them.\n\nThe Trump administration has supported India\u2019s efforts to get American technology, hoping to strengthen ties with a country it considers a key counterweight to China in the region, while diminishing Russia\u2019s influence. Major American defense contractors like Boeing and Lockheed Martin are also gung-ho, seeing the chance to win billions of dollars in business from a country that has historically chosen Russian and European suppliers.", "title": "Want to Sell Fighter Jets to India? Make Them There", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 China\u2019s vibrant technology scene is searching for people like Shen Yue. Qualifications: Must be attractive, know how to charm socially awkward programmers and give relaxing massages.\n\nMs. Shen is a \u201cprogrammer motivator,\u201d as they are known in China. Part psychologist, part cheerleader, the women are hired to chat up and calm stressed-out coders. The jobs are proliferating in a society that largely adheres to gender stereotypes and believes that male programmers are \u201czhai,\u201d or nerds who have no social lives.\n\n\u201cThey really need someone to talk to them from time to time and to organize activities for them to ease some of the pressure,\u201d said Ms. Shen, a 25-year-old who has a degree in civil engineering from a university in Beijing.\n\nChinese women have made great strides in the workplace. The country has the world\u2019s largest number of self-made female billionaires, while many start-ups have women in senior roles. But at a time when the United States and other countries are directly confronting the #MeToo movement, the inequalities and biases in China are rarely discussed openly and remain firmly entrenched.", "title": "Wanted at Chinese Start-Ups: Attractive Women to Ease Coders\u2019 Stress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The Assads created a pervasive apparatus where every ministry could be a ministry of fear, and multiple intelligence and security agencies \u2014 known generically as the mukhabarat \u2014 spied on and intimidated one another as well as the general population: \u201cAssad\u2019s Syria was a mukhabarat state whose intelligence agents didn\u2019t bother with the pretense of discretion,\u201d Abouzeid writes. \u201cThey didn\u2019t need to.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nThe blood that was shed so profusely in the early 1980s would color the conflict that erupted 30 years later. The ghosts of those massacred lived on, and some of the children and grandchildren of the slaughtered would bide their time, waiting to fight once again. But they were not the ones who started the uprising in 2011.\n\n\u201cRevolution is an intimate, multipart act,\u201d Abouzeid writes. \u201cFirst, you silence the policeman in your head, then you face the policemen in the streets.\u201d In early 2011, as she tells us, \u201cthe Middle East was electrified by an indigenous democratic fervor,\u201d and many Syrians were caught up in it.\n\nWhen Bashar al-Assad\u2019s response was mass arrests and the repeated slaughter of protesters, people felt they had to resist with weapons as well as chants and banners. Soon the Syrian landscape became a mosaic of groups that called themselves \u201cbattalions.\u201d\n\nPart of the Assad strategy was a calculated gamble. For years, the regime had operated on both sides of the terror chessboard, simultaneously fighting and facilitating the murderous designs of extremists. As Abouzeid mentions in passing and others have confirmed independently, the United States \u201crendition\u201d program turned over several suspects to the grotesque ministrations of Syria\u2019s interrogators. Yet at the height of the American occupation of neighboring Iraq, Assad encouraged Syrian jihadists to go martyr themselves by killing Americans.\n\nIn May 2011, as the peaceful uprising was gathering momentum, Assad declared an amnesty that released virtually all the Islamic extremists in his prisons. Now he had another use for them, which they understood perfectly well. If they took up arms, as one partisan of Al Qaeda told Abouzeid, \u201cthis would allow the regime to say to the world, \u2018Look at the terrorists.\u2019\u201d In the years that followed, Assad got his wish. He and his Russian and Iranian backers relentlessly portrayed their fight as their own \u201cwar on terror\u201d while setting out to slaughter any moderate forces that did not fit that description. This was a recipe for chaos, and such was the fractious, fractured nature of the conflict that over time even the hardened, disciplined fighters linked to Al Qaeda fought among themselves.\n\nAbouzeid navigated this increasingly treacherous terrain with legendary courage as she wrote for Foreign Affairs and other publications, building the stories of the people in this book around long, repeated interviews and, often, long days and nights under fire alongside them. The result is a tremendous sense of intimacy with the victims and the violence that surrounds them.\n\nIn Saraqeb, Abouzeid focuses on Ruha, a little girl of 9 when the war begins and a woman much older than her 14 years when the book ends. \u201cWe are children of now, not children of before,\u201d Ruha says in the closing pages.", "title": "War Without End", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "What is lawyer-client privilege?\n\nMost of the time, if someone possesses information that is relevant to getting at the truth about a suspected crime, the rules require that person to disclose such evidence, and prosecutors can use those facts in court. But courts have created exceptions to protect confidential communications between a client and a lawyer and a lawyer\u2019s work product on behalf of a client, like notes and files the lawyer gathered in anticipation of litigation.\n\nThe idea, said Samuel W. Buell, a former federal prosecutor who teaches white-collar criminal law at Duke University, is that it is generally in the broader public interest to encourage people to consult lawyers and talk candidly with them. That way, lawyers can steer their clients toward lawful conduct in the first place, and better-informed lawyers will make the legal system function more smoothly.\n\nAgainst that backdrop, Mr. Buell said, the search warrant for Mr. Cohen\u2019s office was \u201cnot going to happen unless they feel that they have to, and they think they have something that is really serious going on.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI would say that for any law-office search warrant,\u201d he continued, \u201cbut we just happen to be talking about a lawyer for the president of the United States.\u201d\n\nAre all files in a lawyer\u2019s office privileged?\n\nNo. Only materials that contain confidential communications between a lawyer and a client, or lawyer-client work product undertaken in anticipation of litigation, are potentially privileged. Since the public does not know the details of what law enforcement officials are looking for, that adds a layer of complexity to making sense of the raid.\n\n\u201cIt bears remembering that not everything in Michael Cohen\u2019s office, home or hotel is even covered by the privilege to begin with,\u201d said Miriam Baer, a former federal prosecutor who teaches white-collar criminal law at Brooklyn Law School. \u201cThere are a lot of papers, data or files that could be in Michael Cohen\u2019s office that don\u2019t fit the definition of privilege.\u201d\n\nAre all lawyer-client materials off limits?\n\nNo. In certain cases, lawyer-client materials do not receive special legal protections. One of them is called the \u201ccrime-fraud exception.\u201d Under this doctrine, the privilege does not protect lawyer-client materials in situations in which the lawyer was helping the client commit a continuing or planned crime or fraud, since that would not serve society\u2019s goal of ensuring lawyers can render sound legal advice. If the judge who signed off on the warrant invoked that doctrine, it would be \u201cextremely significant,\u201d said Katrice Bridges Copeland, a law professor at Pennsylvania State University and a former white-collar defense lawyer.\n\n\u201cTo have gotten this search warrant means they are finding that there was no separation between the attorney and the client, meaning they were working together in furtherance of a crime or some sort of fraud to cover up some previous crime,\u201d she said. \u201cThat is a big deal. It\u2019s not easy to make that showing to the court and get a search warrant on an attorney.\u201d\n\nWhat if the government gets more than it should?\n\nWhen the government seizes materials and sorts through them itself, it carries the risk that officials may see confidential files about unrelated cases or material that is covered by a valid claim of lawyer-client privilege. A defense lawyer could later use that to try to get a case dismissed. To mitigate that risk, the manual says the Justice Department is supposed to create a separate \u201ctaint team\u201d of officials who will go through the materials first. They are not supposed to tell their colleagues working on the main case what they saw in any files they end up setting aside. If the search is contested, a judge might review the materials the taint team decides are relevant before the main case team gets to see them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWho must sign off on a search warrant for a lawyer\u2019s files?\n\nThe manual requires high-level supervisory approval \u2014 such as from the head of the Justice Department\u2019s Criminal Division. In this case, the search warrant was personally approved by an even higher-ranking official, Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, according to three officials. Because Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from criminal investigations arising from the 2016 election, Mr. Rosenstein is the acting attorney general for such matters and also appointed and oversees Mr. Mueller.", "title": "Warrants and Privilege: Legal Questions About the Raids on Trump\u2019s Lawyer", "authors": ["Charlie Savage"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s not profitable to argue with Mr. Buffett about the markets. He is right, of course. The return prospects for bonds aren\u2019t particularly appealing today. That\u2019s because low bond yields reduce the odds that you will earn a return that keeps pace with inflation in coming years. And with the Federal Reserve pushing its target interest rate higher, bond prices are likely to suffer. (When rates rise, bond prices fall. A bond fund\u2019s total return is the sum of the interest paid plus changes in bond prices.)\n\nBut Mr. Buffett is a singular investor, one with deep pockets and an extremely long-term perspective, and he has an excellent track record of exploiting market sell-offs. Most people aren\u2019t like that.\n\n\u201cWhile Warren Buffett might be able to be greedy when others are fearful and fearful when others are greedy, most of us just follow the herd,\u201d said Allan Roth, founder of the Wealth Logic financial advisory firm. \u201cBonds provide liquidity and courage when stocks are falling.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBonds can be a boon for any investor who needs help in the courage department. \u201cYou own bonds to reduce volatility, not to earn a return,\u201d says Gregg Fisher, chief investment officer at the Gerstein Fisher financial advisory firm.\n\nMoreover, what concerns Mr. Buffett are the poor prospects for long-term bonds, especially given their current low yields. He routinely points out that a 30-year Treasury bond is the wrong place to be when rates are rising, as they have been lately.\n\n\u201cPensions and institutions that need to match their long-term liabilities with an asset use 30-year bonds. But most investors don\u2019t have that problem. Nobody owns them,\u201d said Kathy Jones, chief fixed income strategist at the Schwab Center for Financial Research.\n\nAccording to Morningstar Direct, $59 billion is invested in long-term bond funds and exchange-traded funds (defined as portfolios with average durations above six years). But that total is dwarfed by the more than $1.5 trillion invested in intermediate-term portfolios (3.5- to six-year average duration), which include core bond funds hewing to the Bloomberg Barclays U.S. Aggregate index. Another $431 billion is invested in short-term portfolios (one- to 3.5-year average duration).\n\nDuration is a measure of sensitivity to changing interest rates; the longer the duration, the more the price of a bond will fall when rates rise. For example, Dodge & Cox Income fund, with a duration of around four years, lost 0.9 percent in the first quarter. Vanguard Long-Term Bond Index fund, with a duration of more than 15 years, lost 3.75 percent.\n\nMs. Jones points out that from a low yield of 1.38 percent in July 2016, the 10-year Treasury note now yields nearly 3 percent. \u201cWe are in a bond bear market,\u201d she said. But that\u2019s nothing like a stock bear market.\n\nSince July 2016, the average intermediate bond fund has managed to post flat performance as higher yields have offset price declines. Shorter-term portfolios have eked out a small gain. On an inflation-adjusted basis, bond funds have negative returns over that stretch. A stock bear market, by contrast, doesn\u2019t begin until stocks have fallen at least 20 percent.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, core bond funds\u2019 struggles have been unsettling. And with a strong-enough economy spurring the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates, bond investors may need to reduce expectations.\n\nLast quarter may well have been the start of bad times for bonds. Peter Chiappinelli, a member of the asset allocation team at GMO, points out that bonds moving in the same downward direction as stocks \u201chas happened before and will happen again. That bonds are a dampener is not preordained by God,\u201d Mr. Chiappinelli said. \u201cAs we saw in the \u201970s and \u201980s, there are times when stocks and bonds can have a positive correlation,\u201d he said, meaning those assets can move in the same direction.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, the benchmark Bloomberg Barclays Aggregate is ratcheting up its risk. The duration of the index has increased from around 3.5 years in 2008 to six years today as the composition of the index shifted in response to the Federal Reserve\u2019s monetary policy. Treasury bonds, which tend to have longer durations, now represent more than one-third of the index compared with 22 percent in 2007. And corporations have spent the last decade issuing longer-term bonds to take advantage of low interest rates.\n\nMr. Chiappinelli said investing in a portfolio that is increasing its duration when interest rates \u201cwere at historic lows is the exact opposite of prudence.\u201d\n\nMoreover, Treasuries are quite sensitive to rate increases, and Ms. Jones found that the credit quality of the corporate bonds in the index had decreased since the financial crisis.\n\n\u201cWe tend to talk about owning the aggregate index as a core, and then adding some risk around it. Well, now might be a time to keep your core but add some less risky bonds,\u201d Ms. Jones said.\n\nFunds that own high-quality bonds with shorter durations, such as Fidelity Short-Term Bond, can help reduce your portfolio\u2019s sensitivity to rising rates. Or you might want to consider a wholesale shift to shorter duration funds.\n\n\u201cShorten up your entire bond portfolio to two or three years and you could probably afford to own fewer bonds and increase your stocks,\u201d Mr. Fisher said. His expectation is that the overall volatility of a portfolio 30 percent in short-term bonds and 70 percent in stocks is going to be on par with one that is 40 percent invested in a fund tracking the Bloomberg Barclays U.S. Aggregate index and 60 percent in stocks.\n\nMr. Roth recommends owning a laddered series of federally insured five-year certificates of deposit as a bond proxy. Online banks now offer five-year C.D.s yielding 2.5 percent or more.\n\nMs. Jones favors funds that hold floating-rate bonds \u2014 whose yields adjust when interest rates change \u2014 as a way of coping with the current environment. Ms. Jones suggests sticking with floating-rate funds that invest in high-quality bonds, such as the iShares Floating Rate Bond E.T.F. It has an average duration of less than one year and yields nearly 2 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo combat inflation, you might want to add a fund that invests in Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities, or TIPS, such as Vanguard Inflation Protected Securities.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what the return of bonds will be, and I am not suggesting it will be as good as the past 17 years, but I do expect the volatility of bonds relative to stocks to stay the same,\u201d Mr. Roth said.\n\nUnless you are as patient and prescient as Mr. Buffett, owning a slug of less-volatile bonds can help you stick to a long-term investing strategy when stocks fall.", "title": "Warren Buffett Isn\u2019t a Fan of Bonds. But They May Be Good for You.", "authors": ["Carla Fried"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Rudy Gay led the Spurs with 15 points off the bench. LaMarcus Aldridge was limited to 14 points on 5-for-12 shooting.\n\n\u201cThe first quarter we looked like deer in the headlights,\u201d Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich said.\n\nGame 2 in the best-of-seven series is Monday night here at Oracle Arena.\n\nThe Warriors looked unbeatable again. And that was without the do-everything Curry.\n\nGolden State said all week that it was a new season, then went out and showed it. The Warriors have plans for nothing short of a repeat title.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re a championship ball club,\u201d Green said. \u201cWe know what it takes this time a year to win.\u201d\n\nHe added: \u201cWe\u2019re primed for this. A lot of people tend to forget what we\u2019re capable of. We know.\u201d\n\nGolden State came with the kind of swarming defense it is so used to playing but hadn\u2019t exhibited much lately as rotations were mixed and matched because of injuries and illness.\n\nSan Antonio couldn\u2019t keep up from the opening tip.\n\n\u201cWe were just very overly excited, overzealous,\u201d San Antonio\u2019s Danny Green said. \u201cOverreacting to a lot of things because we are so excited that we\u2019re in the playoffs and playing, obviously, the best team in the world.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBeat up and missing its four All-Stars at times, Golden State endured a stretch last month in which it lost seven of 10.\n\nGolden State swept San Antonio in the Western Conference finals a year ago on the way to a second championship in three seasons and an astonishing, record-setting 16-1 postseason run.\n\nKerr always said his team would be ready when these playoffs came around.\n\nThe Warriors were determined to pick up their defense, and they did just that.\n\nGreen, Durant and the others quickly closed on shooters and got hands up to alter shots.\n\nThe M.V.P. of the 2015 finals, Andre Iguodala, moved into the starting lineup for the 2018 edition of that \u201cStrength in Numbers\u201d mantra \u2014 and all those bright yellow T-shirts through the arena were there to back it.\n\nIguodala, who started just seven games all season before Saturday, had missed four of the final five regular-season games with a sore left knee.\n\nKerr went with his best defensive unit.\n\n\u201cI thought it was important to re-establish our defense, one way or another, win or lose,\u201d Kerr said. \u201cThat\u2019s the reason this is a championship team. It\u2019s the defense that has been the key for this team for years.\u201d\n\n76ers 130, Heat 103\n\nBen Simmons had 17 points, 14 assists and 9 rebounds in his playoff debut, and Philadelphia romped again without Joel Embiid, beating visiting Miami for a 17th straight victory.\n\nPhoto\n\nEmbiid, the Sixers\u2019 All-Star center, was a spectator in Game 1 of the first-round Eastern Conference series because of a broken orbital bone around his left eye. He has said he is hoping he can return early in the series. The Sixers could end this one early with Embiid back in the lineup.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSimmons dished and dazzled in the lane, and the Heat had no answer for the Sixers reserves Marco Belinelli and Ersan Ilyasova. They used a 15-0 run in the third quarter to get the rout rolling in their first postseason game in five seasons under Coach Brett Brown.\n\nBrown won 47 games his first three seasons as the Sixers underwent the Process \u2014 and 52, plus Game 1, this season.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Lowry made both free throws, and on the ensuing possession, Wright gave Toronto the lead with a layup. After a missed shot by Morris, Miles hit a 3-pointer, capping a 7-0 run that gave the Raptors a 95-91 lead with 9 minutes 26 seconds left.\n\nKelly Oubre Jr. hit a 3, and Gortat made a dunk, putting Washington back in front, but Wright and Miles each hit 3-pointers as Toronto used an 8-0 run to take a 103-96 lead with 6:27 left and never trailed again.\n\nPelicans 97, Trail Blazers 95\n\nAnthony Davis had 35 points, 14 rebounds and four blocks, and the New Orleans Pelicans beat the Portland Trail Blazers, 97-95, in Game 1 of their playoff series.\n\nJrue Holiday added 21 points, outplaying both Damian Lillard and C.J. McCollum, and had a big blocked shot in the closing seconds as New Orleans held on after Portland erased almost all of a 19-point deficit.\n\nRajon Rondo finished with 17 assists, eight rebounds and six points as New Orleans won the backcourt battle on top of Davis dominating the interior.\n\nLillard finished with 18 points, seven rebounds and seven assists while McCollum had 19 points.\n\nThe sixth-seeded Pelicans were the only road team to win on the opening day of the N.B.A. playoffs. Nikola Mirotic had 16 points, 11 rebounds and also blocked four shots to help Davis earn the first playoff victory of his career.", "title": "Warriors Shake Off Their Late-Season Stumbles and Thrash the Spurs in Game 1", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "There are people with dementia who can be upset by being told sad news but, perhaps because they lack short-term memory, can\u2019t really assimilate it. It\u2019s simply unkind to tell such people the same painful truth over and over again, and it may be best not to tell them even once. But it sounds as if your aunt was in a good position to take in the fact that your mother had died. In these circumstances, it was disrespectful to deny her this information. People who have the capacity to absorb information are entitled to the truth about things that matter to them.\n\nYour cousin was wrong to lie to her mother, therefore, and wrong to ask you to play along, though she no doubt did this with the best of intentions. But you could certainly have handled the situation better. Once you realized that these lies were wrong, you should have told your cousin that you weren\u2019t going to participate in the deception any longer \u2014 and told her before you passed along the sad news. As it was, you weren\u2019t just delivering the news about your mother; you were telling your aunt that her daughter had been lying to her. You were right to show your aunt consideration and respect, but you could have tried to spare some too for your misguided but well-meaning cousin.\n\nI am the youngest of three children and the only daughter. My siblings are both in their late 60s, and both my parents have died within the last few years. When I was a child, my mother told me often that she had pined for a daughter, and I have always been aware that this desire was the reason she had a third child \u2014 me. My brother who was the second son always believed he was the least-loved child. Recently I was going through some old papers when I discovered a letter written to my mother by a close friend of hers when my mother was pregnant with this brother. In the letter, my mother\u2019s friend refers to the unborn child by my name, implying that my mother was so sure that this baby was a girl that my mother had already named her. To me, this validates the feeling my brother has always had that his parents valued his siblings more. My dilemma is whether to show my brother the letter. On the one hand I worry that he will be hurt and that it will reopen an old wound. On the other hand, it illuminates the truth of his experience. Should I show my brother the letter or keep silent? Name Withheld\n\n\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome people, as we\u2019ve seen, think that it\u2019s better to live without painful knowledge when there\u2019s nothing you can do about it. If your mother were still alive, your brother could have taken this up with her. Let me say I\u2019m not confident that such a conversation would have yielded much of value; for one thing, given how different children are, it\u2019s hard to evaluate claims that a parent didn\u2019t treat them equally. But at this point, there\u2019s not even a possibility of seeking resolution in this way.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOnce again, though, people are entitled to be in touch with the truth about things that matter to them. Your discovery, you feel, confirms your brother\u2019s sense about how he was valued. Maybe it will prove helpful to him. (He may have felt guilty about resenting your parents because he wasn\u2019t sure he had judged them fairly, and the letter may relieve some of that guilt.) Maybe it will, as you fear, prove hurtful. The fact is, it\u2019s hard to predict how he\u2019ll process it, and it\u2019s not up to you to do so. Don\u2019t try to manage his access to the truth. Let him see the letter.\n\nI work at a nonprofit where a majority of our staff works far more than 40 hours a week. We are allowed to work from home one day a week. One of my co-workers has told me that when she works from home, she is actually running errands and taking care of her kids and that she will sometimes work at night to make up for it. Since I and many of our co-workers already work many nights and weekends, this doesn\u2019t seem fair. She is often unavailable when she is supposed to be working.\n\nThis co-worker is currently on maternity leave, but we\u2019ve learned that she will be allowed to work from home indefinitely when her maternity leave ends. I fear that she is going to pull even less of her weight and that the rest of us will have to cover for her. To complicate matters, I suspect she gets this leniency because she is friends with one of our bosses. This is not the first time new rules have been created to accommodate her, but not others in a similar situation.\n\nOn the one hand, I don\u2019t want to get involved \u2014 if she wants to be dishonest, that\u2019s up to her. On the other hand, her lies have a direct impact on me; I have to work more because she\u2019s working less. Our clients are also affected, and because we are dealing with legal matters, her dishonesty may be a breach of her ethical responsibilities to them. Should I stay quiet? If not, how can I talk to management about this? Name Withheld\n\n\n\nIt would, I agree, be good for your organization and for your clients to remedy this situation. If your nonprofit has an H.R. department, you can start there, and there\u2019s always the board, which is charged with advising and supervising management. Consider contacting a board member if there\u2019s one you know and trust, or send the board the relevant information \u2014 perhaps anonymously, if you\u2019re worried about retaliation. The board should be concerned that members of the staff feel they cannot bring such issues to management. And the board should care about staff morale and efficiency and doing the best for your clients, all of which are at stake.\n\nTaking such measures may not be easy. But if you stay quiet, you\u2019re condoning an abuse of the system. Because it can be hard to estimate how long a legal task will take, clients and colleagues count on staff members to pull their weight. Your colleague isn\u2019t producing at the rate she would were she working the hours she has been paid for. What\u2019s more, her special treatment unfairly imposes burdens on others, and it creates a bad atmosphere, which can itself affect productivity. Leniency goes too far when it promotes dishonesty, unfairness and disaffection.", "title": "Was It O.K. to Let an Aging Relative Believe My Mother Was Still Alive?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Consider Capitals fans. Presented with an N.H.L. expansion franchise in 1974, they looked forward to building a successful team and perhaps someday winning a championship. It hasn\u2019t worked out that way.\n\nOh, the Washington Capitals have had some good teams over the years. There have been 11 division titles and 10 100-point seasons. In recent years, they have been even better: Three times in the last decade the team has had the best record in hockey, and Alex Ovechkin has won three Most Valuable Player Awards in that time.\n\nBut somehow it always goes sour in the playoffs. The Capitals have made just one Stanley Cup final in their 44 years of existence. (They were swept by the Red Wings in 1998.) Worse, they have made a conference final only one other time. (They were swept by the Bruins in 1990.)\n\nThat leaves a lot of early exits for a lot of good teams: 14 in the first round and 11 in the second.", "title": "Washington Capitals Know It\u2019s Hard; Vegas Golden Knights Make It Look Easy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "DealBook takes a closer look at the proposed changes to the leverage ratio, and finds:\n\nUnder the adjustment, the ratio would fall for all of the eight big banks that are subject to it. Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Goldman Sachs stand to enjoy some of the biggest declines. Compared with the current rules, the new leverage ratio would reduce capital required at the eight banks by around $86 billion. But other capital rules would, for the time being at least, prevent the banks from cutting their capital by that amount. Not all regulators support the proposed adjustment. The new leverage ratio swaps a fixed capital requirement for one that is in part based on a bank\u2019s size and reach in the global financial system. Critics of the current leverage ratio said it was causing banks to reduce certain important activities.\n\n- Peter Eavis\n\nEarnings were supposed to lift stocks...\n\nBut they are dragging them lower on Tuesday.\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 500 points, or 2.1 percent, while the S.&P. 500 and the Nasdaq Composite slid more than 1.5 percent. For the Dow, Tuesday\u2019s move lower push the blue-chip index back down more than 10 percent. If its losses hold through the close, it will mark the Dow\u2019s fifth consecutive down day, its longest such streak since 2017.\n\nDisappointing earnings from some of the stock market\u2019s biggest companies are weighing heavily on stocks.\n\n\u2022 Despite a 73 percent jump in Alphabet\u2019s net profit, shares fell more than 4 percent as Wall Street analysts raised concerns that a jump in capital spending could crimp profitability\n\n\u2022 3M\u2019s earnings met Wall Street expectation, but the stock is down 8.5 percent, its worst post-earnings selloff in more than a decade. The reason? The company lowered the high end of its guidance.\n\n\u2022 Caterpillar jumped 3 percent after its top and bottom lines easily beat expectations. But it shares gave up all their gains and then some during its conference call when executives said the first quarter would be the \u201chigh-water mark\u201d for earnings per share. The stock is now off 6.5 percent.\n\n\u2022 Shares of Apple are off 1.5 percent Tuesday and more than 7 percent since Thursday\u2019s close amid worries that demand for iPhones will be much weaker than expected this year.\n\n\u2022 Travelers is off 4 percent after its earnings missed expectations.\n\nIn all, Apple, 3M, Travelers and Caterpillar have accounted for 260 points of the Dow\u2019s decline.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nContext\n\nAs of Friday, with 17 percent of companies in the S.&P. 500 having reported, profits were on pace to rise more than 18 percent, the high quarterly rate in seven years. So far, 80 percent of companies in the indexes have reported have beaten expectation.\n\nPeter Eavis\u2019s take\n\nDespite all the bullish talk about earnings and the economy, stocks looked vulnerable going into the first-quarter earnings season. Analysts are expecting earnings for companies in the S.&P. 500 to grow 25 percent this year, an unusually large increase. At the 2018 forecast, the S.&P. 500 looks temperately valued at 17 times earnings. But looking back, stocks appear expensive, at 21 times the S.&P. 500\u2019s earnings for 2017. This large gap between future and historical valuations creates a chasm that stocks can fall into if profits disappoint. If companies, like 3M did on Tuesday, provide underwhelming earnings outlooks, investors will stop believing that stocks are cheap, based on 2018 earnings.\n\nTime to worry?\n\nThe yield on the 10-year Treasury note broke through 3 percent early Tuesday, the first time since 2014 that the benchmark borrowing rate has carried a \u201cthree handle.\u201d Big picture, there\u2019s not much news here. Rates are rising on the back of solid global growth and a Federal Reserve that continues to gradually raise rates this year.\n\nNo news, however, doesn\u2019t mean no worries. Nearly a decade after the worst of the Great Recession, no one knows exactly how reliant the American economy has become on rock-bottom interest rates. With average 30-year fixed mortgage rates now topping 4.4 percent, housing data has been persistently soft in recent months. And residential real estate is expected to be a drag on first quarter G.D.P. numbers when they\u2019re published on Friday, suggesting that if rising rates are no reason to panic, they shouldn\u2019t merely be shrugged off either.\n\nA number of prominent bond investors have long eyed the 3 percent level. Jeffrey Gundlach, chief executive of DoubleLine Capital and manager of one of the largest U.S. bond funds, warned that hitting 3 percent would trigger bear market for bonds.\n\nA similar move higher in February caused stocks to tumble. So far, though, equities have taken Tuesday\u2019s climb above 3 percent in stride. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S.&P. 500 are essentially flat in early trading.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere may not be a pay gap between female and male C.E.O.s\n\nThat stunning conclusion, from a new study, could shake up discussions in boardrooms and C-suites everywhere. (The study tracked compensation at 2,282 companies from 1996 to 2014.)\n\nMore from Andrew\u2019s column:\n\nOne of the most interesting theories about why women may have bridged the pay divide at the highest levels has been offered by previous studies and experts: that a premium has been applied because there is such a limited supply of women in the chief executive role. Some readers may find that an offensive idea on its face \u2014 that women in effect are being overpaid because of their scarcity \u2014 but it\u2019s one that has gained currency among some academics.\n\nImportant caveat: The new study isn\u2019t a sign that the overall gender pay gap in corporate America has improved, or that there\u2019s been a rush of women appointed as C.E.O.s. \u201cThere is still discrimination against women getting to the top,\u201d Sandra Mortal, one of the study\u2019s authors, told Andrew.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTakeda has made another bid for Shire\n\nIn a statement, Shire said that its board was considering the new offer, the terms of which it didn\u2019t disclose. Takeda\u2019s bid came ahead of a deadline Wednesday on whether to continue pursuing Shire.\n\nShares in Shire jumped in Tuesday trading, reaching 3,977.20 pence by late trading London time.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nChina\u2019s Didi is in talks to go public\n\nThe Wall Street Journal reports that China\u2019s Didi Chuxing Technology Co. is holding discussions about a multibillion-dollar initial public offering that could happen as soon as this year.\n\nDidi, China\u2019s largest ride-sharing platform, is hoping to fetch a valuation of more than $70 billion, the WSJ reports citing people familiar with the matter. In December, Didi raised $4 billion from a group of investors including Softbank that valued Didi at more than $50 billion.\n\nWhat does this mean for Uber?\n\n\u2022 Uber sold its business in China to Didi in 2016. As part of the deal, Uber and investors in its UberChina took a 20 percent stake in Didi and Didi invested $1 billion in Uber.\n\n\u2022 But the two are also increasingly competitors. Didi acquired full control Uber\u2019s main rival in Brazil in January, and this week it expanded its service to Mexico, a move that puts it in direct competition with Uber.\n\n\u2022 Uber is planning to go public, but Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber\u2019s chief executive, has said the offering is unlikely to take place this year.\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind Eddie Lampert\u2019s latest move at Sears\n\nWhat Mr. Lampert\u2019s ESL has proposed doing: buying the beleaguered retail chain\u2019s Kenmore brand, home-services and appliance-parts units and more of its real estate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nESL\u2019s argument: Buyers offering \u201cacceptable\u201d prices for the businesses haven\u2019t emerged, and Sears needs the cash for its self-help plan. Mr. Lampert, chairman and C.E.O. of Sears, would recuse himself from any board discussions over the bids, and a majority of Sears\u2019s non-ESL shareholders would have to approve any plan.\n\nCritics\u2019 argument: Mr. Lampert is trying to keep Sears\u2019s best assets for himself if the company files for bankruptcy protection, a fate most of the retail world think is a given. \u201cHe has been taking productive assets out of the company since Day 1,\u201d Mark Cohen, a former Sears executive, told the NYT.\n\nSears is burning through more than $1 billion of cash a year and its sales continue to decline.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Newell Brands finally settled with Starboard Value by changing out three of its directors. (Newell)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 CenterPoint Energy plans to buy another electric utility, Vectren, for about $6 billion. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Humana, TPG Capital and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe agreed to buy the hospice operator Curo Health Services for about $1.4 billion. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Henry Schein plans to sell off its animal health business to Vets First Choice through Michael\u2019s favorite tax-free deal maneuver, the Reverse Morris Trust. (CNBC)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow much would a wage rise hit Amazon\u2019s profits?\n\nWhat might happen to Amazon\u2019s bottom line if it paid its workers (median compensation: $28,466) more? If labor markets continue to tighten, the question soon won\u2019t be hypothetical.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince Amazon doesn\u2019t disclose its total compensation expense, Peter Eavis did some math. Multiplying that median pay number by the total number of employees gives a (hypothetical!) comp expense of $16.1 billion. Two more sums:\n\n\u2022 Bumping up median pay by 10 percent would have reduced 2017 pretax income by 42 percent, to $2.2 billion.\n\n\u2022 A 20 percent increase would have reduced pretax income by 85 percent.\n\nBy comparison, a 10 percent raise at Walmart would have cut annual pretax profit by 28 percent, and a 20 percent raise is a 56 percent hit.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 The Treasury Department suggested that it might ease sanctions on Rusal if Oleg Deripaska sold his stake. Robert Mueller took Paul Manafort\u2019s testimony about Mr. Deripaska during a raid on the former Trump campaign official\u2019s house last summer.\n\n\u2022 Some lawmakers say they will resist any move by the Trump administration to withdraw from Nafta if Congress doesn\u2019t approve a renegotiated version. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Worsening deficits may force Greenwich, Conn., to raise taxes on its friendly local hedge funds. (FT)\n\n\u2022 A quiet federal excise cut has led to a boom in self-investment by craft distilleries. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 How Conduent, which runs food stamp networks in 25 states, is blocking Propel, a start-up that lets users check what\u2019s left in their accounts. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Finland is ending its basic-income experiment. (Guardian)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Sean Hannity quietly became a real estate mini-mogul\n\nWhen the Fox News host said that he spoke with Michael Cohen because the lawyer knows \u201creal estate,\u201d it turns out that Mr. Hannity had a reason to ask. He has been linked to shell companies that spent at least $90 million on homes in seven states \u2014 and benefited from financial programs run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, according to The Guardian. (Mr. Hannity hasn\u2019t mentioned that when H.U.D. Secretary Ben Carson has been on his show.)\n\nMr. Hannity\u2019s response: The article was \u201cfake news,\u201d and he didn\u2019t pick the properties the shell companies invested in. (The Guardian reported that Mr. Hannity had signed documents related to the H.U.D. agreements.) Mr. Hannitty also said: \u201cI have never discussed with anybody at H.U.D. the original loans that were obtained in the Obama years, nor the subsequent refinance of such loans, as they are a private matter.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlphabet is preparing for life after advertising\n\nSure, Google is the most powerful force in digital advertising. But its parent company\u2019s latest financial results suggest that it\u2019s plowing headlong into potential new businesses. Capital expenditures tripled year-over-year, to $7.7 billion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlphabet is currently sitting on some $11 billion worth of start-up investments. (What may be its latest: a $2 billion investment alongside SoftBank in the Chinese truck-hailing company Manbang.)\n\nPrivacy corner: Google\u2019s C.E.O., Sundar Pichai, played down the potential impact of forthcoming European data privacy regulations. He may be right to, since incumbents like Google and Facebook already enjoy consumer trust and can better afford compliance with new rules.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner: Alphabet is following Amazon and asking investors to trust in the billions that it\u2019s spending on potential new businesses \u2014 and deserves the benefit of the doubt for now, Shia Ovide of Gadfly writes. Investors are getting squishy performance metrics, not concrete ones, Robert Cyran of Breakingviews writes.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Facebook has published its 25-page guide for community standards, which it uses to determine which content to remove. YouTube said that machines flagged most of the videos it removed.\n\n\u2022 The European Commission has opened an investigation into Apple\u2019s $400 million bid for Shazam, citing concerns about access to data from competitors like Spotify.
