Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Washington Moves to Soften a Big Bank Capital Rule: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Regulators appear ready to agree. The Federal Reserve, along with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, has proposed changing the capital requirement to make it \u201cmore closely tailored to each firm.\u201d That could wind up lowering the amount of capital that big banks must maintain.\n\nThe change was not supported by another bank regulator, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is currently headed by Martin J. Gruenberg, an Obama administration appointee. It also prompted a \u201cno\u201d vote from one of the Fed\u2019s three sitting governors, Lael Brainard, also an Obama administration appointee, who recently said it was too soon to lower capital requirements for the biggest banks.\n\n\u201cSome observers contend that current capital requirements are too onerous and are choking off credit,\u201d Ms. Brainard said last Thursday in a broad speech about bank regulation. \u201cBut the evidence suggests otherwise: U.S. bank lending has been healthy over recent years and profits are strong.\u201d\n\nUnder the Fed\u2019s proposed new method, Bank of America and Goldman Sachs\u2019s leverage ratio would most likely drop from 5 percent to 4.25 percent of their assets and certain off-balance sheet holdings, while Wells Fargo\u2019s might fall to 4 percent. Capital required for eight large banks under the proposed leverage ratios is around $86 billion less than the amount demanded at the 5 percent level, according to calculations by The New York Times.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Fed, in explaining the impact of the changes, said capital held by the banks would not fall by much. That\u2019s because a second set of capital requirements, based on assets\u2019 riskiness, would be set higher than the leverage ratio after the changes. The Fed estimated a theoretical reduction of $9 billion across the eight banks. That amount would be even smaller once the Fed\u2019s annual tests of banks\u2019 strength are taken into account.\n\nBut as regulators adjust capital rules in the coming months, the big banks are expected to enjoy significant relief. Several proposed changes could free up more than $50 billion of capital at large banks, according to recent research by Goldman Sachs, money that could in theory be distributed to shareholders.\n\nThe changes are part of a push, spearheaded by Randal K. Quarles, who oversees bank supervision at the Fed, to ease some of the regulations that came into effect after the financial crisis of 2008. The leverage ratio proposal builds on ideas that were under discussion at the Fed before Mr. Quarles\u2019s confirmation as a Fed governor last year but go beyond that approach. It is prompting concern from those who view the leverage ratio as an important tool to help protect the financial system by preventing banks from becoming overextended.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe leverage ratio was a much better predictor of financial health of banks going into the crisis,\u201d said Sheila C. Bair, who was head of the F.D.I.C. during the tumult of 2008, and who does not support the proposed changes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe change most likely won\u2019t lead to an immediate weakening of the financial system. But, over time, if the financial industry keeps pressing for looser regulations, and Washington obliges, there is concern that the absence of a strong leverage ratio could reduce confidence in the financial system, particularly in periods of stress.\n\nThe leverage ratio\u2019s importance is revealed in how large banks finance themselves. They get most of the money they need for lending and trading from two main sources \u2014 they borrow it in markets or they raise it from depositors. But an overreliance on those two sources can leave a bank vulnerable to runs, because many of the creditors and depositors can demand the bank return their money at short notice. That is why banks must get some of their funding from equity capital, which consists of retained profits and funds from shareholders, who cannot demand immediate repayment of their money.\n\nSome capital rules allow banks to hold less capital against an asset that is perceived by regulators to be less risky. The weakness of this approach was revealed in 2008 and during the European debt crisis when supposedly safe assets turned out to be dangerously risky. The leverage ratio, by contrast, requires banks to have a set amount of capital, regardless of the type of assets it holds.\n\nAcknowledging the importance of the leverage ratio, regulators increased it for the largest banks four years ago. At the higher ratio, the big banks had to have capital equivalent to 5 percent of their assets and certain off-balance sheet holdings. Under the new rule, it would decline significantly. The Fed and the Comptroller want to set the ratio at 3 percent, and then add half of a capital surcharge that is applied to eight large United States banks because their operations pose a heightened risk to the global financial system. (Daniel K. Tarullo, the Fed governor who previously oversaw bank supervision, floated this sort of change a year ago, but his suggestion would not have led to lower leverage ratios for three banks and it would have resulted in smaller reductions for the five others.)\n\nBank representatives say the leverage ratio has been a crude tool that has not made the financial system safer. \u201cThe best analogy is that it\u2019s like having the same speed limit for every road in the country,\u201d said Greg Baer, president of the Clearing House Association, which represents banks.\n\nSupporters of the leverage ratio, however, say that it should be at least as important as the malleable capital requirements, to provide reliable protection in a storm. \u201cIt\u2019s important to have strong, vigilant regulators but we shouldn\u2019t put all of our faith in them,\u201d Gregg Gelzinis of the left-leaning Center for American Progress said. \u201cWe should have this capital requirement that is simple, transparent and doesn\u2019t rely on expert determinations.\u201d", "title": "Washington Wants to Weaken Bank Rules. Not Every Regulator Agrees.", "authors": ["Peter Eavis"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "An article published in The New York Times Books section Tuesday profiles former Marine Lance Cpl. Maximilian Uriarte, creator of the \u201cTerminal Lance\u201d comic strip, upon the release this week of a hard-bound collection of his work.\n\n[Maximilian Uriarte attributes his success with \u201cTerminal Lance\u201d to accuracy and raw material from his loyal fans: disgruntled Marines.]\n\nPhoto\n\nI met Uriarte a few weeks ago, first for a meal that stretched on for hours. Each of us served in the Marine infantry, albeit in different eras, and as is often the case when two former grunts meet, there were countless stories and frustrations to exchange, and a rundown of people we both know.\n\nWe met again the next day so that I could watch him work. During this second interview, in his apartment in Burbank, Calif., that also serves as his studio, he shared a digital file that showed the creation of one of his three-panel strips.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe strip was published on Jan. 16, a few days after the false ballistic missile alert issued by the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency. That was an event ripe for spoofing by \u201cTerminal Lance,\u201d but the video was more interesting for what it showed of how he works \u2014 a process that becomes more understandable with the video\u2019s help.", "title": "Watch How a \u2018Terminal Lance\u2019 Comic Strip Comes to Life", "authors": ["C. J. Chivers", "At War"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Mark Weinberg, a young press aide detailed to Camp David on the weekends, would join a group of staffers in Aspen Lodge each time the president opened the door just before 8 p.m. Everyone would watch the films, and the staffers would also watch their hosts. More than 30 years later, with the former first lady\u2019s blessing, Weinberg began writing this amiable book about the experience. \u201cMovie Nights With the Reagans\u201d is fluffed with a loyalist\u2019s nostalgia, but it does offer entertaining glimpses of the first couple, and it may lure even Reagan nonenthusiasts to indulge in some nostalgia of their own.\n\nThe president was \u201cclearly excited\u201d to see \u201cTop Gun,\u201d though the sex scenes seemed to go on far too long for his and Nancy\u2019s taste. The \u201cover-the-top violence\u201d of \u201cRed Dawn\u201d may have similarly dampened their appreciation of its Commie-repelling Colorado kids. (Both Reagans expressed disapproval of the pot-smoking scene in \u201c9 to 5.\u201d) Among films with a political dimension, Weinberg insists that \u201cGhostbusters\u201d \u201chelped energize the 1984 campaign,\u201d featuring as its villain an over-regulating E.P.A. bureaucrat. The director, Ivan Reitman, had unusually conservative leanings for Hollywood, but Reagan himself seems to have had a nonideological good time watching the movie.", "title": "Watch One With the Gipper: An Aide Recalls Movie Nights With the Reagans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "I asked him why.\n\n\u201cHow do I get your attention?\u201d he answered. \u201cYou\u2019ve seen politics before. You\u2019ve seen the well-produced ads where I\u2019m holding my wife\u2019s hand and our kids are running down a hillside. You\u2019re sick of that. How do I honor what\u2019s going on now? Politics are changing dramatically. People are really looking for the most transparent, honest, direct way to connect with one another. And we\u2019re going to find it.\u201d\n\nBeto, 45, lives in El Paso, grew up there and has spent most of his life in Texas, apart from college at Columbia University, where he majored in English. He and Amy have three children, ages 7, 9 and 11. He started a small technology company before he served on the El Paso City Council and then in Congress.\n\nThat background has somehow given him enough material that whenever a voter asks him a question \u2014 about health care or school safety or the treatment of veterans \u2014 he\u2019s able to draw on some personal anecdote. After a town hall meeting on Thursday, two of the attendees whom I interviewed separately used the same adjective to praise him: \u201cRelatable.\u201d\n\nHe hits so many right notes that it\u2019s eerie. During campaign swings last summer, when school was out, the family camped out at night in state parks. His two youngest kids learned all the words to George Strait\u2019s \u201cAmarillo by Morning\u201d before an event in Amarillo, which they opened with an a cappella rendition.\n\nHe\u2019s quick to validate voters\u2019 ill will toward federal lawmakers, and he said, during that town hall, that only 9 percent of Americans approve of Congress. \u201cYou know that communism has an approval rating of 10 percent,\u201d he added. \u201cChlamydia is at 8 percent. So Congress is in the sweet spot. But watch out! The chlamydia lobby is working it hard and they are going to move up and surpass Congress soon.\u201d\n\nBut he\u2019s also careful to praise his colleagues in the House. \u201cThere\u2019s so much talent in the Democratic caucus,\u201d he told me, \u201cfrom Joaquin Castro to Cheri Bustos to Joe Kennedy to Hakeem Jeffries.\u201d In that one seemingly off-the-cuff sentence, he managed to include a fellow Texan, a storied dynasty, both genders and multiple regions and races.\n\nHe talks about fried catfish one second, James Joyce the next. (The older of his two sons is named Ulysses.) He\u2019s fluent in classic punk rock and contemporary country. He\u2019s fluent in Spanish, too.\n\nHe\u2019s clear about his beliefs that health care should be guaranteed, marijuana should be legal, Trump should be impeached and the border wall is ridiculous. That puts him to the left of many Texans. But he\u2019s just as voluble about his exhausting effort to visit every county in Texas, including the most staunchly conservative ones, and about the need for people of all political stripes to be respected.", "title": "Opinion | Watch Out, Ted Cruz. Beto is Coming.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "[This article has been updated to reflect changes to the launch schedule.]\n\nThere\u2019s a great world next door. Let\u2019s go.\n\nThe search for alien worlds, and perhaps alien life, will take another step outward on Wednesday when TESS, the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite, is launched into orbit around the Earth. TESS will spend at least two years scrutinizing the entire sky for exoplanets \u2014 planets around other stars \u2014 within about 300 light years from here.\n\nWhen is the launch? How can I watch it?\n\nThe launch was postponed on Monday and rescheduled for Wednesday at 6:51 p.m. Eastern. Live video is available on NASA\u2019s website at nasa.gov/live, or on YouTube.\n\nSpaceX, which will carry the spacecraft aloft, cited a need to work on its guidance and navigation systems, although NASA said on Monday that TESS is in \u201cexcellent health, and remains ready for launch.\u201d On Wednesday, the Falcon 9 rocket was returned to the launchpad in Florida, and SpaceX anticipated favorable weather for the launch:\n\nWhy is the TESS mission important?\n\nOver the last 30 years, astronomers on Earth and in space, using instruments like the Kepler spacecraft, have discovered 4,000 exoplanets, most of them far, far away. Our galaxy, astronomers now think, has more planets than stars. TESS will find the closest of these planets to Earth, pinpointing targets for the next generation of telescopes, like the James Webb Space Telescope, to study for clues to their habitability or even inhabitants.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTESS is sponsored by NASA, as one of its small Astrophysics Explorer missions. The spacecraft was designed by a collaboration led by George Ricker of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and built by Orbital ATK of Dulles, Va.", "title": "Watch as NASA and SpaceX Launch TESS, a Planet-Hunting Satellite", "authors": ["Dennis Overbye"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Andrea Constand and Bill Cosby have similar accounts of what transpired between them. It was agreed that they met through Temple University, where he was on the board of trustees and she was director of operations for the basketball team, and that the two became friends. It was agreed that a sexual interaction occurred between them on a night in early 2004 at his home in the suburbs of Philadelphia. But Ms. Constand said that she had been sexually assaulted that night \u2014 given pills and wine which left her incapacitated and incapable of consenting to sex \u2014 and Mr. Cosby and his lawyers said the interaction was consensual.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Cosby was found guilty of three counts of aggravated indecent assault against Ms. Constand. The jury returned the verdict on the second day of its deliberations; the first trial against Mr. Cosby for the same crimes, which took place last summer, ended with a deadlocked jury after six days.\n\nTo many, Mr. Cosby is a star in the pantheon of powerful sexual abusers, proof of the rampant inescapability of male sexual violence. In this narrative he is an African-American corollary to Harvey Weinstein, who has been accused of assault or harassment by more than 30 women . Mr. Weinstein and Mr. Cosby have been the chief villains of the social reckoning of the #MeToo and Time\u2019s Up movements. Now, one of them will be sentenced.\n\nAnother narrative, quietly visible at the trial in Norristown, Pa., is of Mr. Cosby as a victim of conspiracy.", "title": "Watching Cosby Fall", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAn Opioid Crisis Foretold\u201d (editorial, April 22):\n\nWe must act swiftly with a new plan to reverse the opioid epidemic: to trust science and educate the public. The science is clear: Treatment with approved medications (methadone, buprenorphine and extended-release naltrexone) must be a central component of treatment.\n\nInpatient detoxification not followed by medication typically leads to near-immediate return to opioid use, and longer inpatient stays carry a higher risk of death upon discharge unless patients receive continuing medication.\n\nStill, like all other chronic diseases, opioid addiction can\u2019t be cured, and patients with addiction often require other medical care and social support from families and peers to manage their disease.\n\nThe current approach is costing far too many lives, and far too much public and private money is being wasted on \u201ctreatment\u201d that denies the science and is therefore ineffective. We must demand easy access to what we know works, and embrace science over stigma.", "title": "Opinion | Ways to Address the Opioid Crisis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "What would a genuine legislative remedy look like? First, personalized data collection would be allowed only through opt-in mechanisms that were clear, concise and transparent. There would be no more endless pages of legalese that nobody reads or can easily understand. The same would be true of any individualized targeting of users by companies or political campaigns \u2014 it should be clear, transparent and truly consensual.\n\nSecond, people would have access, if requested, to all the data a company has collected on them \u2014 including all forms of computational inference (how the company uses your data to make guesses about your tastes and preferences, your personal and medical history, your political allegiances and so forth).\n\nThird, the use of any data collected would be limited to specifically enumerated purposes, for a designed period of time \u2014 and then would expire. The current model of harvesting all data, with virtually no limit on how it is used and for how long, must stop.\n\nFourth, the aggregate use of data should be regulated. Merely saying that individuals own their data isn\u2019t enough: Companies can and will persuade people to part with their data in ways that may seem to make sense at the individual level but that work at the aggregate level to create public harms. For example, collecting health information from individuals in return for a small compensation might seem beneficial to both parties \u2014 but a company that holds health information on a billion people can end up posing a threat to individuals in ways they could not have foreseen.\n\nFacebook may complain that these changes to data collection and use would destroy the company. But while these changes would certainly challenge the business model of many players in the digital economy, giant companies like Facebook would be in the best position to adapt and forge ahead.\n\nIf anything, we should all be thinking of ways to reintroduce competition into the digital economy. Imagine, for example, requiring that any personal data you consent to share be offered back to you in an \u201cinteroperable\u201d format, so that you could choose to work with companies you thought would provide you better service, rather than being locked in to working with one of only a few.\n\nRight now, Silicon Valley is stuck in a (very profitable) rut. To force it to change would not only make us safer but also foster innovation.\n\nThat would be a better, more satisfying outcome than any dramatic \u201cHave you no sense of decency, sir?\u201d moment that a congressional hearing might produce.", "title": "Opinion | We Already Know How to Protect Ourselves From Facebook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "We asked politicians from conservative parties around the world their thoughts on climate change. In the video above, they show how their views are very different from those of American conservatives.", "title": "Opinion | We Are Conservatives and We Believe Climate Change Is Real", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Tens of thousands of teachers are walking out of their schools in Arizona on Thursday. Arizona is the latest conservative state with protesters demanding an increase in teacher salaries and more resources for students. In this video op-ed, four conservative teachers lament the conditions in their classrooms and, in turn, wrestle with their political beliefs.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a die-hard Republican, and I\u2019m dying inside,\u201d says Allison Ryal-Bagley, an elementary school substitute teacher. \u201cRepublicans aren\u2019t taking care of our kids.\u201d\n\nOver the last decade, Arizona has had the greatest decrease in per-student spending in the country \u2014 a 36.6 percent drop since 2008 \u2014 making it 48th in the nation. Arizona also ranks 43rd in teacher pay, at nearly $11,000 less than the national average, according to the National Education Association.\n\nWilliam Kimsey, who teaches English, is fed up and is moving for a teaching job in Indonesia. Laura Fox, a music teacher, works the late shift at McDonald\u2019s to make ends meet. Jenny Bentley Ryan used to work as a Lyft driver to supplement her income teaching science. They are challenging Arizona\u2019s Republican governor, Doug Ducey, to increase taxes and give public education the funding it deserves. \u2014 The Editors", "title": "Opinion | We Are Republican Teachers Striking in Arizona. It\u2019s Time to Raise Taxes.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "How, after all, can governments save money on education? They can reduce the number of teachers, but that means larger class sizes, which will outrage parents. They can and have cut programs for students with special needs, but cruelty aside, that can only save a bit of money at the margin. The same is true of cost-saving measures like neglecting school maintenance and scrimping on school supplies to the point that many teachers end up supplementing inadequate school budgets out of their own pockets.\n\nSo what conservative state governments have mainly done is squeeze teachers themselves.\n\nNow, teaching kids was never a way to get rich. However, being a schoolteacher used to put you solidly in the middle class, with a decent income and benefits. In much of the country, however, that is no longer true.\n\nAt the national level, earnings of public-school teachers have fallen behind inflation since the mid-1990s, and have fallen even more behind the earnings of comparable workers. At this point, teachers earn 23 percent less than other college graduates. But this national average is a bit deceptive: Teacher pay is actually up in some big states like New York and California, but it\u2019s way down in a number of right-leaning states.\n\nMeanwhile, teachers\u2019 benefits are also getting worse. In particular, teachers are having to pay a rising share of their health insurance premiums, a severe burden when their real earnings are declining at the same time.\n\nSo we\u2019re left with a nation in which teachers, the people we count on to prepare our children for the future, are starting to feel like members of the working poor, unable to make ends meet unless they take second jobs. And they can\u2019t take it anymore.\n\nWhich brings us back to Bevin\u2019s unhinged outburst.\n\nOne way to think about what\u2019s currently happening in a number of states is that the anti-Obama backlash, combined with the growing tribalism of American politics, delivered a number of state governments into the hands of extreme right-wing ideologues. These ideologues really believed that they could usher in a low-tax, small-government, libertarian utopia.\n\nPredictably, they couldn\u2019t. For a while they were able to evade some of the consequences of their failure by pushing the costs off onto public sector employees, especially schoolteachers. But that strategy has reached its limits. Now what?\n\nWell, some Republicans have actually proved willing to learn from experience, reverse tax cuts and restore education funding. But all too many are responding the way Bevin did: Instead of admitting, even implicitly, that they were wrong, they\u2019re lashing out, in increasingly unhinged ways, at the victims of their policies.", "title": "Opinion | We Don\u2019t Need No Education", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "Friedkin used a hand-held camera to film an interview with Father Amorth, the chief Vatican exorcist, who worried that \u201cSatan rules the world\u201d and was in the Vatican. He died in 2016 at 91.\n\nThe director, who had never seen an exorcism, also talked the priest into letting him film the exorcism of an Italian architect named Christina with whom he had done the ancient ritual many times.\n\n\u201cIt was harrowing,\u201d Friedkin says. \u201cThese five strong guys are holding her down. They\u2019re sweating. Father Amorth told me that during one of the exorcisms, she accused him of his sins and they were real.\u201d\n\nFriedkin took this footage to neurosurgeons and psychiatrists, and one psychiatrist challenged it, saying Christina did not show \u201cthe classic symptoms\u201d of possession, such as her head turning 360 degrees and her body levitating.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Doctor, we made that up,\u2019\u201d Friedkin recalls dryly. \u201cBlatty invented what we think of as possession and exorcism today, and I had to find a way to film it. Father Amorth never encountered stuff like that, but he encountered other extraordinary occurrences and personality changes and voice changes. But there was no levitation or head spinning.\u201d\n\nThe filmmaker says that for his documentary he did nothing to amplify the guttural growl of Christina, which evokes the terrifying voice used by Mercedes McCambridge, which was dubbed in for Blair\u2019s in the possession scenes.\n\n\u201cWhen she breathed into the mic, you\u2019d hear five or six sounds come out at once, like John Coltrane playing the sax,\u201d he says. \u201cWhen I first called her, she said, \u2018I\u2019m in A.A. I had a serious drinking problem. I am a lapsed Catholic, but I still have strong ties to the church. So in order to do what you want, I\u2019m going to have to start drinking Jack Daniel\u2019s again and smoking cigarettes and eating raw eggs.\u2019 And she wanted to have her own two priests with her at all times.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | We Need an Exorcist!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The economic lifeline provided by subsidized oil from Venezuela is drying up, and Cuba does not have much of an export base. Investment laws from 2014 intended to open up the economy to foreign investment are falling short of their goals. Even the much-promoted (though exaggerated) successes of the revolution in health care and education have been eroded by shortages and lack of state investment.\n\nThe major economic challenge will be unifying Cuba\u2019s dual currency system, which uses a domestic peso and a separate international peso for trading with other countries. (The international peso trades artificially at a rate of one-to-one with the United States dollar, and the domestic peso trades at a rate generously assumed to be 24 local pesos to the international peso.) Unifying the currencies will cause upheaval in the economy, increasing the prices of imported goods and ending the double-booking system that many businesses use to keep themselves artificially solvent, leading to inflation and unemployment. Modernizing and advancing the Cuban economy requires addressing this wrenching change.\n\nThis is where the United States can come in. While it is not in America\u2019s interest to promote investment to prop up an anachronistic, repressive regime, it is also not in its interest to stand by while a neighbor\u2019s fragile economy crumbles under the weight of its failed policies. In the worst of cases, an economic implosion would produce social unrest and waves of migrants to American shores.\n\nMultilateral banks like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, at Washington\u2019s urging, could be given special allowances to offer economic assistance to the next Cuban government while providing international cover for American-led efforts. Any aid should come with a strong message from Washington and the banks that the Cuban government must refrain from repression in response to protests.\n\nDoing this would require restoring the American Embassy personnel to its pre-Trump levels so that officials can have broader contacts with the government and with the population \u2014 as was negotiated under the Obama administration.\n\nEven if incrementally, generational change is coming to Cuba. And whether or not Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel wants it, the country faces difficult economic decisions.\n\nRather than not engaging, the United States should play a cautious, principled role in helping Cuba, and by doing so, shape its future toward more economic and political openness.", "title": "Opinion | We Shouldn\u2019t Ignore Cuba", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThousands of teachers in multiple states have shut down school districts by walking out of their classrooms or calling in sick to protest cuts in pay, benefits and school funding.\n\nLawmakers in these states \u2014 West Virginia, Oklahoma, Kentucky and Arizona \u2014 have for years pursued cuts to public education and other services. Teachers, parents and students have noticed the impact on the classroom, whether it is a four-day school week in rural Oklahoma or canceled drama classes in Tulsa.\n\nAre you a public school teacher? How have budget cuts affected your school?", "title": "We Want to Hear From Public School Teachers", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Women at risk of giving birth prematurely have their weight checked at El Hospital de La Mujer in San Salvador, El Salvador. The country\u2019s total ban on abortion leads to an immediate suspicion of women whose pregnancies do not end with a healthy baby.\n\nCredit Fred Ramos for The New York Times", "title": "We Want to Hear From Women Around the World About Abortion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "With every new pregnancy came a new hope and a pledge to remain optimistic, only to see all of it come crashing down several weeks later.\n\nBecause we were able to get pregnant, our doctor said that it wasn\u2019t likely that my body was the cause. But they did not know what was.\n\nMy wife had an imbalanced thyroid, but that wasn\u2019t necessarily the problem. She also had an iron deficiency, but that wouldn\u2019t have been the sole culprit either. Both of these issues were treated with medication \u2014 and for good measure we added folate and CoQ10. My wife tried reiki. She attended a weeklong yoga retreat in Bali, returning with renewed energy and enthusiasm.\n\nStill the miscarriages came \u2014 and with each one an increasingly perilous emotional minefield.\n\nNow, miscarriages are common; they are usually nature\u2019s way of preventing an unhealthy baby from coming to term.\n\nAccording to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 10 percent of all pregnancies end in miscarriage \u2014 and that number jumps up to more than 30 percent for women over 40.\n\nYet they remain very private, painful, personal experiences that many people don\u2019t discuss.\n\nI was unprepared for the grief that followed the first miscarriage. That unmistakable, deep ache that lies beyond mere sadness. We had lost a family member. This was a place I had come to know very well when my mother died suddenly over a decade earlier. A place from which I thought I would never return.\n\nI don\u2019t recommend this approach for everyone, but in order to deal with that grief (and the depression that followed), I had to detach myself from the thoughts that triggered extreme negative emotions. I practiced living in the middle \u2014 no highs, no lows; no hope, no despair.", "title": "We Were Ready to Give Up on a Second Baby Until a \u2018Miracle\u2019 Arrived", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "By Jasmine Zamprogno\n\nOn my 11th birthday, a cyclone hit.\n\nMy parents shook me awake before dawn, wished me a happy birthday, and told me I needed to get out of my room in case the old gum tree in the backyard fell to the force of Category 4 winds. I received a digital camera as a gift, but I could not charge it until four days later, when the power was finally restored to our little Cairns suburb. My special birthday dinner was sausages cooked on a gas fire by candlelight.\n\nThere is the perception that Australian grit is defined by our nonchalance toward the many deadly animals we peacefully, indeed happily, coexist with.\n\nThe truth is that what makes us tough is how we weather the weather.\n\nIt takes guts to live in a country where our fire warning system starts at \u201cModerate\u201d and methodically progresses toward \u201cCatastrophic.\u201d Where, in Far North Queensland, cyclones are so common they are described by locals as \u201ca bit of a light breeze.\u201d Where, to quote Forrest Gump, some days, it just starts to rain \u2014 and rains, and rains, and rains until you forget what the sun looked like and what it was like not to be constantly damp.", "title": "Weathering the Weather", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Ayman Madhkoor, the head of the health office for the governorate of Hajjah, where the strike took place, said it hit the wedding after dark on Sunday, killing at least 21 and wounding more than 50 others. About 17 of the wounded were children, he said, and the groom had shrapnel scattered across his body.\n\n\u201cHe was speechless and appeared in a bad psychological state as some of his relatives had been killed,\u201d Mr. Rajihi said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. They say they have poured money into Yemen to help the humanitarian response.\n\nInternational peace talks aimed at ending the war have made little progress in years.\n\nAlso on Monday, the Houthis announced that the highest- ranking civilian leader of their movement, Saleh al-Samad, had been killed in an airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition on Thursday.\n\nMr. Samad had been the leader of the Houthis High Political Council, which effectively served as the government in Houthi-controlled areas of northwestern Yemen. He had been leaving a university in the Red Sea port city of Al Hudaydah when he and his entourage were targeted by three airstrikes, Abdel-Malik al-Houthi, the group\u2019s leader, said in a televised address.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSix of Mr. Samad\u2019s aides were also killed, Mr. Houthi said.\n\nIn statement released by the Houthi-run Saba News Agency, the group threatened revenge.\n\n\u201cThe oppressor must be aware that this crime will not pass without an earthshaking and painful response,\u201d it said.\n\nThe Houthis named Mahdi al-Mashat, a hard-line member of the group, to replace Mr. Samad.", "title": "Wedding Is Hit by Airstrike in Yemen, Killing More Than 20", "authors": ["Shuaib Almosawa"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Marriage can provide a bounty of emotional, practical and financial support. The statement said that further investigation showed that the car, a blue Hyundai, was stolen.\n\nSo when someone called to report a \u201csuspicious vehicle\u201d \u2014 the black Mustang \u2014 in a Walmart parking lot on April 5 and provided a license plate number, officers saw that it was registered to someone whose last name was Yarber and, once on the scene, recognized the driver, the statement said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Mr. Yarber was killed and one of his three passengers was shot and hospitalized. She has since been released.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt all happened very quickly, said Marlon Hawkins, 41, who was in the front seat of the car at the time of the shooting.\n\nHe said they had just pulled in when several police cars arrived, boxing them in. There was a lot of yelling and then a lot of gunfire.\n\nMr. Hawkins said he jumped out of the car and onto the ground. He suffered injuries and was taken to the hospital for a few hours. He got a phone call and learned that Mr. Yarber was dead.\n\n\u201cI was just devastated,\u201d Mr. Hawkins said. \u201cIt was just surreal. It was happening so fast, I couldn\u2019t believe it. I was sick.\u201d\n\nMr. Merritt has repeatedly called on the authorities to release the officers\u2019 names.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn its statement, the Barstow police said they were \u201cprecluded by state law from providing or sharing any information related to the personnel records of the involved officers.\u201d\n\nThe department said in its statement that the officers were wearing body cameras and that the footage was turned over to the San Bernardino County Sheriff\u2019s Department. It has not been released publicly.\n\n\u201cThis case is important because it really begins to explore the idea that law enforcement is above the law,\u201d Mr. Merritt said.\n\nCiting a California Supreme Court decision, Mr. Merritt argued that in the case of an officer-involved shooting, police departments that want to withhold names must show clear evidence that there would be a particular threat to officers involved if their names were made public.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve decided that they would go into a black box. It\u2019s almost as if they\u2019re hiding, waiting for everybody to go away,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re not going to go away.\u201d", "title": "Weeks After Police Killing of Diante Yarber, Officers\u2019 Names Remain Secret", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Unlike medications prescribed to treat a symptom or illness, statins are often given to healthy people to prevent a potentially devastating health problem, and the drug must be taken indefinitely to do the most good. Nearly half of Americans with cholesterol levels that put them at high risk of a heart attack or stroke are not taking medication to reduce that risk, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Under current guidelines, among people 60 and older, 87 percent of men and 54 percent of women not already taking a statin would be considered eligible for treatment.\n\nThere is no question that statins can protect the health of people who have already had a heart attack or stroke (or even angina) and thus face a significant risk of a recurrence that could prove fatal. But many people \u2014 especially those who are uncomfortable taking drugs for any reason \u2014 resist taking a daily statin if they have no history or symptoms of cardiovascular disease, only a risk of developing them, especially since it has not yet been proven that the drugs help such people live longer.\n\nFurthermore, people correctly regard \u201crisk\u201d as a possibility, not a probability, and vary in the degree of risk they are willing to tolerate. One chance in 100 may be acceptable to one person, while another may regard one chance in 1,000 as too risky.\n\nDoctors define cardiovascular risk as a percentage chance of a heart attack or stroke occurring within the next 10 years based on the presence of well-established risk factors: high cholesterol, high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, age, gender and race (and, in some cases, family history). You can determine your own risk using the calculator developed by the American College of Cardiology and American Heart Association at cvriskcalculator.com.\n\nIf your calculated risk is 7.5 percent or higher, your doctor is likely to suggest you consider taking a statin, although a relatively high cholesterol level may not result in such a recommendation if you have no other heart risk factors. The risk score is meant \u201cto start a conversation, not to write a prescription,\u201d according to Dr. Don Lloyd-Jones, professor of preventive medicine at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine and a spokesman for the heart association.\n\nLet\u2019s say your risk is 19 percent. That means among 100 people with similar risk factors, 19 are likely to have a heart attack or stroke within the next decade. Is that a risk you\u2019re willing to take? Or would you rather reduce your risk by a third by taking a statin? Only you can make that determination, and it should be based on a full understanding of the known benefits and risks of statins, not something you may have heard from a friend or read online.\n\nThe current labeling on statin prescriptions doesn\u2019t help matters. In 2012, the Food and Drug Administration ruled that the warnings should include several reversible side effects: confusion and memory loss, liver problems, increases in blood sugar and muscle weakness, as well as interactions with certain other medications.", "title": "Weighing the Pros and Cons of Statins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "A group called Salty Terror demonstrated voice-guided recipe instruction, which sounded as if Siri had entered a surgical theater. (\u201cThree mid-sized prep bowls.\u201d \u201cNext.\u201d \u201cStrainer.\u201d \u201cNext.\u201d \u201cKnife. \u201cRepeat.\u201d \u201cKnife.\u201d) Another, named G1 after the original Android phone, proposed a menu scanner for easier tracking of SmartPoints in restaurants.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis pleased Ms. Grossman, who is also on the board of directors of the casual-dining conglomerate that owns Outback Steakhouse. \u201cI remind them all the time that if Bloomin\u2019 Onion is 75 points, they need to work on some healthy options,\u201d she said, referring to the battered and deep-fried concoction cut like a flower and served with a mayonnaise-based dipping sauce.\n\nMost captivating was a team addressing the practice of privately pecking points and ingredients into smartphones. \u201cWhy does it have to be so awkward to do Weight Watchers with friends?\u201d a product designer wondered rhetorically. \u201cWhat if there were an easier, more social and more interactive way?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith their solution, you would never track alone, but rather share \u201cSwishpoints! From my phone to your phone in one quick \u2026 ssss \u2026 swish!\u201d\n\n\u201cAhhhh!\u201d murmured the crowd admiringly.\n\nA presenter described User A (a \u201cswisher\u201d) imparting a menu to User B (a \u201cswishee\u201d), with herself hypothetically subtracting the wine from the menu \u2014 as if Edward Albee\u2019s \u201cThree Tall Women\u201d had suddenly been outfitted with iPhones and concerns about their body mass indexes. (Wine, incidentally, is the second most common drink tracked by members, outranked only by coffee.)\n\nSoon after came a team called The Incredibles, proposing a sort of match.com for sharing recipes. \u201cSwiping right adds it to your \u2018soul foods,\u2019\u201d said the lead Incredible. \u201cMindy is always talking about personalization. I don\u2019t mean to call you out,\u201d he said to the top boss, \u201cbut it\u2019s true.\u201d\n\nMs. Grossman grabbed the microphone. \u201cPersonalization,\u201d she stage-whispered, to hearty chuckles.\n\nFrom Disco to Diller\n\nMs. Grossman\u2019s tenure of just under a year has not all been so lighthearted. In February, she encountered her first public relations crisis when Weight Watchers announced during a global employee event that it planned to offer free six-week memberships to teenagers. The well-oiled social media opprobrium machine heaved into gear, with the Balance Eating Disorder Treatment Center introducing an aggrieved hashtag, #wakeupweightwatchers, and the Academy for Eating Disorders posting an open letter to Ms. Grossman that cited studies linking restrictive diets during adolescence to potentially severe mental and physical consequences.\n\nThe following month, Oprah Winfrey \u2014 who in 2015 bought a 10 percent stake in Weight Watchers, along with becoming its spokeswoman \u2014 sold a quarter of that stake, prompting speculation about her long-term involvement. (Ms. Winfrey later said that she was donating some of those shares to a charity and that she remained committed to the company.)\n\nSitting in a fabric-lined boardroom with the company\u2019s senior vice president of corporate communications, Stacie Sherer, Ms. Grossman was as measured as a cup of popcorn (up to two SmartPoints) about the teenager kerfuffle.\n\n\u201cWhenever you do anything that\u2019s different from the norm, you\u2019ll have some people who think it\u2019s the most incredible thing in the world, that you\u2019re going to help generations get healthy,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd then you\u2019re going to have some people who want to weigh in thinking that we\u2019re putting the teenagers of the world on a diet which is exactly what we\u2019re not doing.\u201d She cited the company\u2019s consultation with pediatric experts. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing that we\u2019re going to do that\u2019s not rooted in science, and that doesn\u2019t make sense,\u201d she said, \u201c and so it\u2019s just a matter of clarification and communication.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe herself was an awkward-aged 14-year-old in the Long Island town of Valley Stream when she attended her first Weight Watchers meeting, taken there by her mother, Elaine Waldman, a homemaker who struggled with health problems as well as the scale. \u201cIt was mostly women just having a conversation about food and how they felt, and I remember listening to other people and supporting other people,\u201d Ms. Grossman said. She lost about 10 pounds on the program, felt better about herself and joined her high school\u2019s cheerleading squad.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMindy\u2019s father, Donald Waldman, worked nights for Candy Brand Tomatoes in St. Albans, Queens; he and her mother had tried unsuccessfully for a dozen years to have a baby on their own and hadn\u2019t been able to afford adoption until one night his boss gave him a check earmarked for that purpose. Told this story for as long as she could remember, their daughter developed a strong sense of filial obligation. She went to Manhattanville College a year early, transferring to George Washington University as a senior, and majored in English literature and philosophy with plans to become a lawyer.\n\nA sudden, if unfocused, epiphany came after a summer working as receptionist and occasional fit model for the company that made Nik Nik, the brightly patterned polyester shirts popular during the disco years. She broke an engagement to her high-school boyfriend and telephoned her parents.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m moving to New York,\u201d she announced, to horrified silence.\n\nHer graduation was in 1977, when the city was dangerous and dirty. She found an assistant job at another shirt company, Manhattan Industries, which paid $15,600 a year, and moved into a 330-square-foot studio apartment in an elevator building on First Avenue between 73rd and 74th Streets. The long bus ride to the west side cost 50 cents. \u201cI\u2019d be scrounging, looking for the quarter,\u201d said Ms. Grossman, who is currently renovating a $5.65 million condo at United Nations Plaza.\n\nShe moonlighted one winter as a server at Cachaca, a nightclub on 62nd Street above the better-known discoth\u00e8que Hippopotamus, to make extra cash for the holidays. \u201cYou know what? It was fabulous,\u201d she said.\n\nHer career in shirts progressed to the men\u2019s wear brand Enro. One day, the fashion designer Jeffrey Banks arrived there for a meeting and spotted Mindy Waldman handling a busy front desk. \u201cI watched this young woman \u2014 21, 22 years of age \u2014 dealing with irate salespeople and messengers, doing it so calmly and efficiently \u2014 I was just so captivated by her,\u201d he said in a phone interview. She would eventually become his vice president of sales, part of a rare convergence of talent that included the then-unknown designers John Varvatos and Isaac Mizrahi.\n\nLater, she worked for Willi Smith, a lover of bright color who collaborated with artists like Barbara Kruger and Keith Haring. \u201cLiterally the first designer to really articulate that fashions should come from the street up not the top down,\u201d Ms. Grossman said. \u201cTo bring democratization to fashion, before Target ever thought of it.\u201d\n\nMr. Smith died of AIDS-related causes in the spring of 1987. Later that year, a month before her 30th birthday, Mindy Waldman married Neil Grossman, a mathematical physicist turned lawyer turned financier. They have a grown daughter, Elysabeth, nicknamed Lizzy, and a 15-month-old granddaughter, Emma. \u201cIt\u2019s fabulous, it\u2019s so unbelievable, I\u2019m obsessed,\u201d Ms. Grossman said, adding brightly of Lizzy: \u201cAnd she\u2019s on the whole Freestyle and loves it, because a lot of today\u2019s young moms, they have to be healthy for their kids.\u201d (Under the Weight Watchers Freestyle system introduced in December, more than 200 foods including beans, peas, chicken breast and seemingly every fish in the sea can be consumed with wanton abandon.)\n\nShe went from Mr. Smith\u2019s company to then-fledgling Tommy Hilfiger, as vice president of sales and marketing, and then to the aesthetically similar Ralph Lauren as the president of its bridge line, Chaps. Later, she started Polo Jeans, which was directed at young people, and which has remained one of Mr. Lauren\u2019s most successful and enduring brand extensions.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Grossman\u2019s next stop was Nike, where she expanded the apparel business by over a billion dollars, with a particular focus on women\u2019s wear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut she was eager to be a chief executive, and after a recruiter from Barry Diller\u2019s InterActive Corp. contacted her about heading its retail division, she sold Mr. Diller on a plan to revive the then-ossified Home Shopping Network.\n\nVodka and Cereal\n\nInspired by the chatty format of her favorite cooking shows, Ms. Grossman brought higher-end labels and A-list celebrities including Jennifer Lopez and Serena Williams to the channel, along with much-heralded new Herman Miller Aeron chairs. In August 2008, spun off from IAC by Mr. Diller, Home Shopping Network went public. A month later came the fall of Lehman Brothers and subsequent international financial crisis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAll I could think about were the 6,000 people that worked for the company \u2014 their families, their future,\u201d she said. \u201cI was so stressed out.\u201d\n\nFor the next year, Ms. Grossman focused on bolstering company spirit. \u201cNumber one, there\u2019s never any bad news on H.S.N.,\u201d she reassured her employees. \u201cNumber two, even if somebody cannot afford to do business right now, I want them to think that we\u2019re a place they could go to be a part of the community, or interface with the brands they love, because it\u2019s the nature of the business, and it\u2019s not about selling.\u201d\n\nShe remained there over a decade, and the network\u2019s fortunes mostly rose. With waterfront property in St. Petersburg, Fla. and a house with vineyard in Millbrook, N.Y., Ms. Grossman considered retirement, but the opportunity to run Weight Watchers intrigued her. The financial returns are less important to her, she insisted, than freshening a brand that, with its cruises and oft-deserted storefronts, some considered as stale as an outdated package of SandwichThins (three SmartPoints).\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not the turnaround girl \u2014 I\u2019m the transformation-growth person,\u201d she said.\n\nOn Thursday, Ms. Winfrey, a little out of breath after a 45-minute run, praised Ms. Grossman, one of around five candidates brought to her by a search firm. \u201cShe\u2019s an executor and a doer, not just a sayer and a talker,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said during a phone interview.\n\n\u201cThe thing that did it for me was that she understood immediately that it was a lifestyle and not a diet, and that we were still operating as though it was a diet,\u201d she went on. \u201cShe said the same things that I had also felt and expressed, that it allows for your own accountability, but it\u2019s really so much more than that, so that was music to my spirit.\u201d (And how many FitPoints had that run earned Ms. Winfrey? \u201cI don\u2019t count them, because it\u2019s so ridiculous!\u201d Ms. Winfrey said. \u201cIf I were to count them, probably it would be four, and it would be so irritating.\u201d)\n\nWeight Watchers has long had to fend off other programs like Nutrisystem, Medifast and Jenny Craig. But the new millennium has also brought competition in the form of free tracking apps like MyFitnessPal and LoseIt! \u201cI keep doing the research and I realized that our greatest competition is people thinking they can get healthy themselves,\u201d Ms. Grossman said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThen there has been the rise of gleaming, \u201caspirational\u201d alternatives like Gwyneth Paltrow\u2019s Goop and boutique fitness classes. \u201cThere\u2019s a portion of wellness that seems for a small few,\u201d Ms. Grossman said diplomatically, \u201cand we think wellness should be part of everyone\u2019s life and accessible to all.\u201d (Weight Watchers\u2019s membership costs range from about $3 per week for an online-only plan to $12 a week with personalized coaching.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has countered the industry\u2019s largely middle-of-the-road rotation of celebrity endorsers like Marie Osmond (Nutrisystem) with the of-the-moment music producer DJ Khaled, who has embarked on a tour of various cities with a food truck. Fond of gardening, he has boasted of a 26-pound weight loss \u2014 though this week he came under fire for pouring vodka (only three SmartPoints, but still!) over his breakfast cereal.\n\nWhether because of such moves, or the wind beneath her wings of Ms. Winfrey, Weight Watchers during a February earnings call announced a 23 percent increase in subscribers from the previous year and set a goal of $2 billion in revenue, up from the present $1.3 billion, by 2020.\n\n\u201cMindy loves a challenge,\u201d Mr. Banks said. \u201cIn any job that\u2019s she ever had, she\u2019s had a mind like a computer.\u201d\n\nDebating \u2018SwishPoints\u2019\n\nIn the hackathon\u2019s deliberation chamber, Ms. Grossman did not seem as enthralled with SwishPoints as her fellow judges: \u201cI just question \u2014 really, how much utilization is that really going to get? I don\u2019t know if you\u2019re the mom, and you do it \u2014 the big thing you want to do is now be swishing?\u201d\n\nThe executives huddled in heated discussion for a few minutes, and then filed out so that Ms. Grossman could announce the results. Third prize went to a team that had figured out how to livestream Weight Watchers meetings to users who couldn\u2019t show up in person. Second was G1\u2019s menu scanner. First place was a tie between two of the teams.\n\n\u201cWe believe there\u2019s a big opportunity if The Incredibles and Swishpoints had a baby, seriously,\u201d Ms. Grossman said with a broad smile, and thanked out-of-towners for making the trip.\n\n\u201cAs much as we believe in technology,\u201d she said, \u201chaving people together is also pretty fabulous.\u201d\n\nAnd it was time for a beer at the happy hour \u2014 two to six SmartPoints, depending.", "title": "Weight Watchers Gets Its Own Makeover", "authors": ["Alexandra Jacobs"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Taking Action on Segregation\n\nA 2014 report found that New York City has one of the most segregated school systems in the country. Nearly 70 percent of students are black and Latino, and they overwhelmingly go to school in racially isolated classrooms, with few white and Asian children. Mr. de Blasio and Ms. Fari\u00f1a have repeatedly blamed the city\u2019s segregated neighborhoods and have suggested there is little they can do. Even after facing intense public pressure, they have taken only modest steps, such as setting aside seats in some schools for low-income students. When the mayor released what had been billed as a \u201cbigger vision\u201d for integrating schools, he resisted even using the word \u201csegregated.\u201d\n\nA high-profile example of the problem is the lack of black and Latino students at the eight specialized high schools where admission is decided by a single test. This spring, only 10 percent of offers at these schools went to black and Latino students. When Mr. de Blasio was running for mayor in 2013, he pledged to diversify these schools, but more recently he has suggested that his hands are tied and that any change must come from the state.\n\nWhat to Do About Renewal\n\nMr. de Blasio came into office pledging to lift up low-performing schools, rather than close them, as his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, had done. But his $582 million Renewal initiative, which flooded 94 schools with resources while subjecting them to sometimes contradictory directives, has produced disappointing results. This year, the city proposed closing eight of the schools \u2014 the largest number it had ever closed in one year \u2014 drawing protests from parents and elected officials.\n\nMr. Carranza will have to decide whether to continue the initiative, whose future looks cloudy; the official who led the effort was recently moved aside, and no successor has been named. Fifty schools are expected to remain in the program next year. Another challenge: The city\u2019s Education Department has said that, to replace some of the schools it is closing, it will open eight new schools in the fall, something that this administration has little experience doing.\n\nClosing the Achievement Gap\n\nThough the city has made real progress on increasing overall graduation rates, the academic divides between different groups of students are yawning. Citywide, the graduation rate last year was 87.5 percent for Asian students and 83.2 percent for white students. For black students, the rate was 70 percent and for Hispanic students, 68.3 percent. Just 32.5 percent of students still learning English graduated.", "title": "Welcome to New York, and Here\u2019s a To-Do List", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The misdeeds at Wells Fargo showed that the bank\u2019s sales culture had degraded. Bank employees, eager to meet sales goals, had been opening accounts for customers without their consent. Other misdeeds were revealed as well.\n\nThe scandals were particularly surprising because Wells Fargo, with its focus on traditional lending, was widely viewed as a worthy alternative to the Wall Street-focused institutions at the center of the financial crisis of 2008. Wells Fargo\u2019s steady revenue growth and its habit of invariably beating earnings forecasts lulled investors into a false sense of confidence and led them to pile into Wells Fargo\u2019s stock.\n\nGiven that the misconduct of the bank\u2019s sales force mostly took place in the lower ranks and did not lead to large immediate losses, it was hard for outsiders to detect the misdeeds. Regulators eventually acted when evidence of the misconduct trickled out. The $1 billion penalty brings some closure. But the lingering lesson of the Wells Fargo scandal is that abuses can go on for a long time at large, hard-to-police banking institutions.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\nThe NYT\u2019s James Stewart has been \u201ca harsh critic of Wells Fargo\u2019s previous management for fostering a culture of rule-breaking and customer abuse, and for marginalizing as disloyal and even firing anyone at the bank with the courage and integrity to try to stop the illegal practices.\u201d But with the new fine, he writes: \u201cEven I have to wonder: Has Wells Fargo been punished enough?\u201d\n\nA Russia-focused V.C. firm opens in the U.S. with $200 million\n\nNow would not seem like the ideal to start a venture capital firm that aims to help U.S. start-ups break into the Russian market, given the political tensions between the two countries.\n\nBut Fort Ross Ventures is making a go of it.\n\nThe firm said on Thursday that it has opened for business in the U.S. with a $200 million fund, its second, for investing in a variety of industries, from A.I. to fintech. And it has hired a veteran of Silicon Valley, Anurag Chandra, to help in that mission.\n\nVictor Orlovski, Fort Ross\u2019s founder and managing partner, said in an interview that the current state of U.S.-Russian political relations should not affect his firm\u2019s ability to operate. Declining to comment on politics broadly, he said that Russia \u2014 which remains one of the biggest markets for apps worldwide \u2014 will remain a compelling destination for start-ups.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe nature of start-ups is all about risk,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is a political tension, but not when you\u2019re talking to start-ups.\u201d\n\nCracking the Russian market can be difficult, Mr. Orlovski said, with that country\u2019s culture differing significantly from that in the U.S. or western Europe. Uber (which Mr. Orlovski said his firm is a small investor in) folded its Russian operations into a joint venture with that country\u2019s leading tech giant, Yandex, after finding it hard to compete there.\n\nFort Ross\u2019s team is betting its contacts in Russia and knowledge of the market will help attract U.S. start-ups. Mr. Orlovski was previously the chief digital officer at Sberbank, Russia\u2019s biggest bank, and maintains connections in that region, including through his former employer.\n\nFor one of Fort Ross\u2019s existing investments, the social trading start-up eToro, the investment firm introduced the portfolio company to a local player in Russia to help it crack that market.\n\nFort Ross began raising its latest fund in the fall, drawing investors from Russia and the Middle East. (Mr. Orlovski said that the investors are primarily family offices and wealthy individuals, though he does eventually want to branch out into traditional money sources like U.S. pension funds.) But the goal, he added, was to make the firm better-known in Silicon Valley, a task he argued would not be hampered by his background or focus.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t feel like we are a second- or third-tier venture firm just because I\u2019m personally from Russia or because we have connections to Russia,\u201d he said. \u201cOne year, or a couple of years ahead, we want to be a bigger player in the community of V.C.s here.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nIs the European Union bending to Trump on trade?\n\nThe European Union, with its $16 trillion economy and its reputation for toughness in trade negotiations, could be the immovable object that stymies President Trump\u2019s combative trade agenda.\n\nBut that outcome is looking less likely.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal on Wednesday reported that the European Union is prepared to offer some concessions to avoid the steel and aluminum tariffs that the United States has threatened to impose. The European Union\u2019s exemption to the tariffs expires on May 1, which means any negotiations would have to progress quickly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAccording to the Journal, the European Union is prepared to reduce tariffs on United States cars and industrial machinery, among other goods. The newspaper also reported that the bloc might offer to join the United States in pressuring China to relax its trade and investment rules. (In return, the European Union is reportedly asking for European companies to be given access to United States government procurement contracts.)\n\nThe Trump administration apparently proposed the punitive tariffs as a way to secure compromises from trading partners, and bring them into an alliance against China. If the European Union bends to this strategy, rather than rejecting it outright, it would be a notable gain for Mr. Trump.\n\nA compromise by the European Union would also suggest that the United States\u2019 large trade deficits are an advantage in its trade battles. Last year, the European Union exported $151 billion more to the United States than it imported from the U.S. If the United States raised barriers to the bloc\u2019s exports, it\u2019s economies, particularly that of Germany, with which the United States last year had a $64 billion deficit, could suffer.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nPhoto\n\nAllergan and Takeda each weigh a takeover of Shire\n\nTakeda Pharmaceutical disclosed on Thursday that it has bid for more than $60 billion for the Irish drug maker Shire, though the offer was rejected. But it may have competition in the form of Allergan, which said on Thursday it was considering an offer for Shire.\n\nLater on Thursday, Allergan decided to drop its pursuit.\n\nStill the disclosures, following weeks of speculation, again raises the prospect of consolidation within the pharmaceutical industry. Drug makers have long looked to big takeovers to broaden their product portfolios.\n\nFor Takeda, which is based in Osaka and whose products include treatments for acid reflux and for cancer, a big takeover would give it both more scale \u2014 the combined company would have some $30 billion in annual sales \u2014 and a bigger international footprint.\n\nBut Shire, which is headquartered in Dublin and is best known for producing Adderall, would be its biggest takeover by far. (Its next-biggest acquisition was the $13.7 billion purchase of Nycomed seven years ago.)\n\nTakeda\u2019s main competitor may be Allergan, the maker of Botox, is a veteran acquirer, having been built up through numerous mergers over the years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTakeda said in a statement that on April 12 it had informally offered \u00a346.50, or about $66, a share for Shire, made up of both cash and newly issued shares. That represented a roughly 30 percent premium to where the target company\u2019s shares had closed on the prior day.\n\nUnder the terms of that offer, Shire shareholders would own just over half of the combined company.\n\nShire said in its own press release that Takeda had bid three times, culminating in last week\u2019s offer. But the Irish company rejected each offer as too low.\n\nTakeda and Shire said that they are in discussions, which could lead to yet another revised bid.\n\nYet for both Takeda and Allergan, a deal for Shire could prove financially risky, since each company would need to borrow significant amounts of debt to finance a transaction.\n\nUnder British takeover rules, Takeda has until April 25 to decide whether to continue pursuing Shire. Allergan has until May 17 to do the same.\n\nAdvising Takeda are Evercore Partners, JPMorgan Chase and Nomura. Advising Shire are Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nGE\u2019s digital pivot\n\nNo old-line company embraced the digital wave with more gusto than General Electric. The industrial giant spent billions, hired thousands of software engineers, and even created image-morphing television ads to recast itself as \u201ca digital-industrial company,\u201d writes the NYT\u2019s Steve Lohr.\n\nToday, there are no such ambitions. The spending at GE Digital is being slashed, amid layoffs and sharply narrowed aims at G.E. under John Flannery, who became chief executive last August.\n\nFrom Mr. Lohr:\n\nThe rethinking of GE Digital, with its future still under review by Mr. Flannery, points to the difficulty of producing modern software for industrial businesses as they adopt digital technology. No one disputes the overarching vision of the so-called industrial internet of things \u2014 which includes low-cost sensors and a flood of data and clever software that should deliver insights to cut costs, conserve fuel and design better products, faster. But the company greatly underestimated the challenges of creating all the software needed to achieve that grand vision, said analysts and former G.E. managers.\n\nFearless Girl\u2019 is being moved and Wall Street bull go with her\n\nMayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that the statue known as \u201cFearless Girl\u201d will soon be moved from its spot at the southern tip of Broadway to a spot facing the New York Stock Exchange.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd if the city has its way, the bull will eventually go with her.\n\nJ. David Goodman of the NYT writes:\n\n\u201cThough visitors had posed with the bull for years, larger crowds had gathered since the \u2018Fearless Girl\u2019 statue, commissioned by State Street Global Advisors, a Boston-based financial firm, was placed in front of the bull at the narrow corner atop Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan last March. \u201cSo after deciding to allow the sculpture \u2014 placed temporarily at the spot \u2014 to remain for a year, city officials came to the conclusion that the number of pedestrians spilling into the streets created a safety hazard.\u201d\n\nHowever, the artist that created the bull, who was not pleased when \u201cFearless Girl\u201d was placed in front of it, is considering going to court to keep the bull in place.\n\nJeff Bewkes on fighting Silicon Valley\n\nDuring his court testimony in Washington yesterday, the Time Warner C.E.O. argued that his company\u2019s proposed $85.4 billion sale to AT&T was necessary, given the \u201ctectonic changes\u201d in the media world wrought by Netflix and Amazon.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore from Cecilia Kang of the NYT:\n\nAmong the biggest problems for Time Warner as a stand-alone television and movie producer is that it does not have access to viewer data to target advertising and other valuable customer information the same way that Amazon and Netflix do, Mr. Bewkes said. \u201cWe don\u2019t have emails, contact information, billing information \u2026 any of these things,\u201d he said.\n\nLawyers for the Justice Department, which has sued to block the deal, grilled him about an internal document from last year showing plans to create digital products even without AT&T.\n\nRandall Stephenson of AT&T could take the stand today.\n\nElsewhere in big media deals: Comcast\u2019s bid for 21st Century Fox assets was 16 percent higher than Disney\u2019s, but Rupert Murdoch turned it down because of antitrust worries.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe timeline for a potential U.S.-China trade war\n\nAs the U.S. and China continue to posture over trade \u2014 alarming U.S. farmers, many of whom are in key electoral districts in the Midwest \u2014 it\u2019s worth noting three upcoming dates, Peter Eavis writes.\n\nOn May 1, exemptions to the tariffs on imported steel and aluminum expire.\n\nOn May 22, the public comment period ends for another $50 billion worth of tariffs, and the Trump administration can announce a final list of targets.\n\nAnd Aug. 18 is potentially the deadline for the administration to act on an investigation into Chinese trade practices. But there\u2019s a provision for a 180-day delay after that.\n\nKey caveats: President Trump has the power to pursue trade policy almost at whim. And a W.T.O. proceeding against China could take years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nElsewhere in trade: How Qualcomm became collateral damage in the fight (China says its takeover of NXP Semiconductors has \u201chard to resolve\u201d issues), while Washington continues to fret about Chinese tech. Rusal is betting on China for relief from U.S. sanctions. What worries the Fed about trade. And why Wall Street and trading allies increasingly ignore presidential statements.\n\nPhoto\n\nBreaking: Amalgamated presses Sturm, Ruger on gun limits\n\nThe politically minded bank already adopted principles for limiting firearm sales laid out by the advocacy group Everytown for Gun Safety. Now it\u2019s using its position as a (small) shareholder in Sturm, Ruger to urge the gun maker to adopt six Everytown principles.\n\nAmong them: Supporting mandatory background checks for all sales; binding sellers to a code of conduct; and adopting smart-gun tech. If Ruger doesn\u2019t support those principles, Amalgamated would withhold votes for Sandra Froman, a Ruger director who\u2019s also on the N.R.A.\u2019s board.\n\nElsewhere in gun sales: Dicks\u2019s Sporting Goods plans to destroy its stock of assault-style rifles.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York wants to change state law to allow repeat criminal charges against offenders granted a presidential pardon. An adviser to President Trump warned that Michael Cohen could flip. And meet the judge in his case, Kimba Wood.\n\n\u2022 Karen McDougal and the publisher of the National Enquirer have settled. She can now publicly discuss her claim to have had an affair with Mr. Trump, who is spared the risk of legal proceedings. These are Amazon\u2019s stickiest and most valuable customers, who order often and can access its streaming service. The company had $9.72 billion in revenue from subscription services, including Prime fees.\n\nMr. Bezos also talks about the importance of \u201chigh standards\u201d for his digital behemoth. (And about yoga handstands.)\n\nElsewhere in Amazon: The company is moving its entertainment division to the Culver Studios, where \u201cRaging Bull\u201d and \u201cE.T.\u201d were made.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Facebook is reportedly designing chips, and working to move 1.5 billion users worldwide beyond the reach of European data privacy rules. Like the universal banks JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the shift carries plenty of risk. \u201cIt goes against their history as a firm; they\u2019ve no track record of expanding consumer, commercial or corporate banking,\u201d the analyst Brian Kleinhanzl of KBW told the FT.\n\nElsewhere in banking: Credit Suisse and UBS are reportedly in talks to combine some of their back-office operations. The activist investor Edward Bramson has built a 5 percent stake in Barclays and wants to wind down its trading division, unnamed sources told the London Evening Standard.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Bankers for Meredith have reportedly ruled out the National Enquirer owner A.M.I. as a bidder for Time, Fortune, Inc. and Sports Illustrated, rejecting a $300 million offer.
