I hate that guy. Everybody hates that guy. Even marathoners hate that guy.\n\nThat said, the Boston Marathon on Monday was, in a word, epic \u2014 as in epic misery. Though, now that it\u2019s over, it\u2019s a great story to drone on about at cocktail parties for the next while. Not long, I promise, maybe 20 or 30 years, tops.\n\nI\u2019m sure there have been more epic conditions for this race. They\u2019ve been doing it for 122 years, after all. It was nearly 90 degrees in 2012. But Monday was as high on the misery index as anyone I talked to could remember.\n\nFor days many of the race\u2019s roughly 30,000 participants had been staring at weather apps and radars, playing amateur meteorologist and praying that the forecast for temperatures in the 30s and 40s with driving rain and a 20-30-mile-per-hour headwind somehow wouldn\u2019t come true. We traded notes all Sunday on what we were going to wear. In the end, I never took off my windbreaker. Neither did the women\u2019s winner, Desiree Linden. That never happens.", "title": "What It Was Like to Run the Boston Marathon in a Freezing Deluge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "I squeezed into a seat in the front row of the press section, just over Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s right shoulder, and settled in for a marathon session. (You\u2019re not supposed to bring food or drink into these rooms, but I was warned it would be a long session with few breaks, so I smuggled some trail mix in my bag.) My seat was tiny and uncomfortable, with less legroom than your average discount airline. But the hearing itself was fascinating, and I quickly forgot about my discomfort as Mr. Zuckerberg began his testimony with a statement in which he said, \u201cWe didn\u2019t take a broad enough view of our responsibility, and that was a big mistake.\u201d\n\nI\u2019ve been covering Facebook for a long time \u2014 an embarrassingly long time. In 2006, when I was in college and Facebook was a two-year-old website that was only open to people with .edu email addresses, I wrote a paper for my freshman year English class about why Facebook was going to revolutionize social life at our school. That turned out to be true, but I wasn\u2019t as prescient about Facebook\u2019s future trajectory \u2014 I predicted that the social network would never be a huge success because there was no way it would ever let adults join. Oops.\n\nOne of the reasons I love writing about Facebook is that it\u2019s less like covering a company, and more like covering a foreign country. There are 2.2 billion people on Facebook, and those people do all kinds of fascinating and terrifying things with the tools Facebook gives them. Mr. Zuckerberg, the authoritarian leader of this \u201ccountry,\u201d is a compelling character in his own right, and watching him answer Congress\u2019s questions about Facebook\u2019s inner workings was deeply revealing. (If occasionally frustrating \u2014 such as when tech-challenged senators asked him basic questions about how computers work, which at times created the sensation of watching a very long Genius Bar appointment.)\n\nMy own Facebook feed is a total mess \u2014 I wrote a column last year about joining more than 100 Facebook groups, and permanently throwing off Facebook\u2019s idea of who I am as a result. I imagine that the algorithms saw me joining groups like \u201cFlat Earth Believers\u201d and \u201cQuilting For Beginners,\u201d along with lots of pro-Trump and anti-Trump groups, and just gave up on targeting me.\n\nBut as I sat in the halls of Congress, watching Mr. Zuckerberg testify in front of dozens of angry lawmakers, I logged on to Facebook, and right at the top of my feed was one of those \u201c10 years ago\u201d memory posts, with a throwback photo from my college years. I\u2019m on island time.\u201d When she travels to Jamaica, though, she doesn\u2019t do much. \u201cI eat a lot of ackee and saltfish, and chill. I don\u2019t do anything, just eat Jamaican food. My friend ordered eggs and was given the choice of French fries or home-fried potatoes. He chose French fries since we planned to share.\n\nWhen the food arrived, my friend\u2019s eggs were accompanied by home fries.\n\n\u201cI ordered French fries,\u201d he said to the waiter, pointing at the potatoes.\n\n\u201cThese are healthier,\u201d the waiter said, and then walked away.", "title": "What Kind of Potatoes?", "authors": ["Anne Silverstein", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Could there be a volcano under the Great Red Spot of Jupiter?\n\nA. A volcano is an unlikely explanation for the mysterious red storm observed on the surface of Jupiter since the early 19th century. The planet has been found to be mostly gas, lacking a defined crust to rupture in an Earth-style volcanic eruption that would release hot materials from the interior of the planet.\n\nThe spot remains a mystery, and it is not even certain that the storm reported by scientists in 1831 is the same one seen now. The exact nature of the chemical reactions that produce its red-orange color is also not known.\n\nThe latest observations by the Juno spacecraft, combined with historical records, show significant changes in the size, shape and motion of the Great Red Spot. It has shrunk in diameter in recent decades, NASA scientists reported in 2017 in Astronomical Journal, but has increased in height and depth, with its hot, swirling gases reaching at least 200 miles below the surface. The spot has recently started to drift westward at a faster rate than ever before.\n\nIt has also become brighter, and its color has become more intensely orange since 2014, possibly because it is exposed to more ultraviolet radiation at higher altitudes.", "title": "What Lies Beneath Jupiter\u2019s Great Red Spot?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "In 1991 the Hallmark greeting card company, based in Kansas City, Mo., decided it was time to get serious about diversity. America was changing, as was Hallmark\u2019s work force, and while the brand had dabbled in cards for black consumers since the 1960s, it didn\u2019t have a perennial line that addressed them directly.\n\nOver the years, businesses of all kinds have had to acknowledge blind spots for racial exclusion, including \u201cflesh-colored\u201d crayons mixed and melted in dusty peach shades to cosmetics lines that offer few to zero options for dark complexions. Hallmark realized that speaking authentically to black people would require a slight shift in its traditional tone and direction. And so, 81 years after its founding, the company created Mahogany, its first year-round imprint dedicated to cards for the African-American community.\n\nWhat makes a greeting card black? According to Dierdra Zollar, the editorial director for the Mahogany brand studio, sometimes it\u2019s explicit, like a Father\u2019s Day card bearing the silhouette of an African-American man, or a card touting \u201cblack love\u201d for romantic occasions. Others, however, are more subtle.\n\nMrs. Zollar said that a black customer browsing the greeting card aisle at a CVS may notice on a Mahogany card \u201cfamiliar expressions,\u201d terms or phrases that hint at a shared history. \u201cI see these cultural signifiers that let me know you\u2019ve been to my house, you\u2019ve been in my neighborhood, you\u2019ve participated in some of these church affairs, you have that insider knowledge that really speaks to being known,\u201d she said.\n\nI saw it for myself while browsing cards for mothers on Hallmark\u2019s website on a recent afternoon. The 543 options covered a lot of what someone might want to say to a mother \u2014 barring more extreme cases of familial dysfunction \u2014 from a \u201cThank You for Your Love on Rosh Hashana\u201d card to one whose cover featured a drawing of an androgynous figure farting out Einstein\u2019s mass-energy equivalence formula. The inside read: \u201cHappy Birthday from your smartass kid.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut many of the Mahogany cards did indeed stand out from the rest. They addressed their intended recipients as \u201cMama\u201d and \u201cAuntie,\u201d and their covers said things like, \u201cBaby, your love game is tight.\u201d I found that if the inside of a card mentioned \u201cstrength\u201d or \u201cdignity\u201d in the face of obstacles, it was often a Mahogany product. One Mother\u2019s Day offering read, \u201cThere is something deep within black women that allows them to stand strong, carry on, and make it over \u2014 with their dignity, class, and courage intact \u2014 no matter what challenges they have to face in life.\u201d", "title": "What Makes a Greeting Card Black?", "authors": ["Cord Jefferson"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "When Mark Zuckerberg appears Tuesday afternoon before members of two Senate committees, it will be the culmination of a Facebook public relations blitz in the face of a series of controversies that have tarnished the reputation of the world\u2019s largest social network.\n\nBeginning late last month, Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s 33-year-old founder and chief executive, suddenly granted interviews to The New York Times, Vox, Recode, Reuters and other news outlets before a conference call with dozens of reporters last week. Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook\u2019s chief operating officer, has been on her own, more limited apology tour, mainly on television. The company has also moved aggressively to announce changes to its rules, introduce a social media research initiative and promise additional disclosures to try to get ahead of congressional demands and possible regulation.\n\nIt will be the first appearance before Congress for Mr. Zuckerberg, who looks only slightly older than during his giddy first television appearance in 2004 to explain the unexpected growth of the college service he called \u201cThe Facebook.\u201d The company he built into a global behemoth, with more than two billion users, now faces the most intense scrutiny of its 14-year history. Here are the major issues he is likely to be asked to address:\n\nPrivacy\n\nThe New York Times, The Observer and The Guardian reported last month that Facebook data, including private information, of more than 50 million users had been given without their permission to a company, Cambridge Analytica, that had consulted for Donald J. Trump\u2019s 2016 presidential campaign and for other political candidates. Since then, Facebook has updated that number, saying that as many as 87 million people may have been affected by the misuse of data. The social network also acknowledged additional security weaknesses, including one that it said may have allowed \u201cmalicious actors\u201d to collect the public profile information on \u201cmost people.\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s main task may be to persuade members of Congress and millions of Facebook users that their information will be safe on the platform.\n\nF.T.C. Investigation\n\nThe committees are likely to ask about a consent decree Facebook signed with the Federal Trade Commission in 2011, which said it had \u201cdeceived consumers by telling them they could keep their information on Facebook private, and then repeatedly allowing it to be shared and made public.\u201d The F.T.C. is now investigating whether the company violated the decree, which could make it vulnerable to fines that, under the regulations, could reach an astronomical sum: up to $41,484 for each of the millions of users whose data went to Cambridge Analytica. Facebook denies that it has violated the 2011 decree.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRussian chicanery\n\nFacebook has taken heat for months for its slow response to Russia\u2019s hijacking of its platform to influence the 2016 presidential election. Russian military intelligence created profiles of fake Americans to promote emails stolen from Democrats by Russian hackers, and a so-called troll factory in St. Petersburg created pages to denigrate Hillary Clinton, promote Mr. Trump and post inflammatory messages on immigration, race, guns and other topics. It took Facebook until September 2017, 10 months after the election, to go public with its first findings on the Russian meddling, which it says appeared in the news feeds of 126 million customers \u2014 equal to nearly half the adult population of the United States.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFake news\n\nMr. Zuckerberg got off to a clumsy start when, two days after the election, he said it was \u201cpretty crazy\u201d to believe that the \u201csmall amount\u201d of false news spread on Facebook might have influenced the outcome. Since then, the company has taken a number of steps to increase the reliability of information on its platform, though the moves have garnered mixed reviews. The underlying problem, studies show, is that false, sensational stories spread faster through social media than factual stories do.\n\nPolitical bias and polarization\n\nRepublicans may question Mr. Zuckerberg about reports in 2016 from former Facebook employees that they had routinely suppressed articles from conservative publications. But a larger body of research suggests that Facebook, as well as other social media, tend to reinforce and intensify existing political views by creating an echo chamber of friends and like-minded users. Facebook has published its own research pushing back on that conclusion.", "title": "What Mark Zuckerberg Will Be Grilled On at the Congressional Hearings", "authors": ["Scott Shane"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "SESTO SAN GIOVANNI, Italy \u2014 For 70 years, Sesto San Giovanni, on the outskirts of Milan, was a bastion of the left as it drew thousands of migrants from Italy\u2019s poorer south to work in its factories.\n\nBut much has changed recently. The factories are shut down. The most recent migrants who have arrived are not from Italy\u2019s south, but other nations. And the center-right broke the left\u2019s long-unchallenged governing streak and won municipal elections last June.\n\nToday, if there is one place in Italy where the country\u2019s economic and migrant crises collide, it is in Sesto. And if there is one place to take the measure of the right\u2019s creeping anti-immigrant influence in politics and society, Sesto is that place, too.\n\nNationally, since Italy\u2019s inconclusive elections last month, political leaders have struggled to form a government, but there remains a good chance that the Five Star Movement, with a subtle Italians-first message, and the anti-immigrant, right-wing League could be a part of it.", "title": "What May Life in Italy Be Like Under the Right? These Immigrants Already Know", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Amazon does not disclose its total compensation expense, so it\u2019s not possible for outsiders to accurately compute what would happen to profits if it raised pay.\n\nBut the disclosure of median pay provides a little insight. Under S.E.C. rules, public companies must now disclose the median pay figure for all their employees. In annual filings, that number is then compared with the pay of the chief executive. In Amazon\u2019s case, the $1,681,840 that Jeff Bezos earned in 2017 was 59 times that of the median employee, a lower ratio than exists at other large public companies.\n\nOne way to get a rough proxy for a company\u2019s overall compensation expense is to multiply its median pay number by its total number of employees. For Amazon, that would produce a purely hypothetical compensation expense of $16.1 billion (566,000 employees times $28,466.)\n\nIncreasing Amazon\u2019s median pay number by 10 percent would bump the $28,466 up to $31,313, and the putative compensation expense would rise to $17.7 billion. Such an increase would have cut Amazon\u2019s $3.8 billion of pretax income in 2017 by 42 percent to $2.2 billion. A 20 percent raise would have slashed those earnings by 85 percent.\n\nHow does Amazon stack up against Walmart? The C.E.O. of Walmart, Doug McMillion, made $22.8 million in the company\u2019s latest fiscal year. That sum was 1,188 times as large as the median employee\u2019s pay of $19,177 (a number that excludes some foreign employees.)\n\nAt Walmart, increasing the hypothetical compensation expense would have less of an impact on earnings. A 10 percent increase would reduce Walmart\u2019s latest annual pretax profits by 28 percent, while a 20 percent pay increase would lower profits by 56 percent.\n\nThere are two ways to view such numbers. One is that retail is a cutthroat business and wages cannot rise by much if a company is going to be healthily profitable. The other is that large retailers have used their heft to lower as many of their costs as possible, including wages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nAlphabet slips after earnings.\n\nStrong advertising sales during the first quarter helped Google-parent Alphabet beat analysts expectations. The company\u2019s bottom line also received a lift from a change in accounting for its investments in startups.\n\n\u2022 Net profit jumped 73% to $9.4 billion in the first quarter, up from $5.4 billion a year ago.\n\n\u2022 Earnings per share came in at $13.33 per share, beating analyst estimates of $9.28 per share.\n\n\u2022 The company reported a $3 billion, or about $3.40 a share, gain on equity securities in the first quarter.\n\n\u2022 Sales rose to $31.1 billion, beating the consensus estimate of $30.3 billion.\n\n\u2022 Traffic costs hit $6.3 billion, up 35% from a year earlier.\n\nShares of Alphabet bounced around after hours. The stock rose as much as 2.2 percent but is now down slightly.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\nRobert Cryan of Breakingviews writes:\n\n\u201cThe tech group\u2019s $9.4 billion of earnings in the first quarter came with new noise after it adjusted the way it accounts for investments like ride-hailing app Uber, moved some smart-home appliances into Google and started stressing \u201cimpressions\u201d over clicks. Investors wanting concrete measurements are getting squishy ones instead.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nEdward Lampert offers to buy Kenmore\n\nShares of Sears Holding are up about 4 percent in recent trading on Mr. Lampert\u2019s latest attempt to save the troubled retailer.\n\nIn a letter to the Sears board, Mr. Lampert, whose ESL Investments hedge fund owns a controlling stake in the company, said ESL would also be willing to buy the retailer\u2019s home-services and its appliance-parts units.\n\nMr. Lampert offered to pay Sears $500 million for the home-services and appliance-parts units, but did not mention a price for the Kenmore brand or the real estate. He noted that the company had been trying to sell the assets for nearly two years, but had failed to find other buyers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lampert is Sears\u2019s chief executive. Any deal involving Sears and Mr. Lampert is complicated by his dual roles running both the retailer and the hedge fund, which is also a major Sears lender.\n\nMr. Lampert said in his letter that he would recuse himself from any board discussions about his proposal. Any deal would need to be approved by a majority of Sears shareholders not affiliated with ESL, the letter said.\n\nSears has already sold some assets, closed hundreds of stores and laid off workers across the country as offset falling sales. The company sold its Craftsman tool brand to Stanley Black & Decker for $775 million last year.\n\n\u2014 Michael Corkery\n\nPhoto\n\nNot so fast on that Shazam deal\n\nThe European Commission said Monday that it has opened an in-depth investigation into Apple\u2019s acquisition of Shazam, the maker of an app that identifies songs after listening to just a few seconds of them.\n\nMargrethe Vestager, the European Union\u2019s competition commissioner, said in a statement:\n\n\u201cThe way people listen to music has changed significantly in recent years, with more and more Europeans using music streaming services. Our investigation aims to ensure that music fans will continue to enjoy attractive music streaming offers and won\u2019t face less choice as a result of this proposed merger.\u201d\n\nThe European Commission is concerned that Shazam\u2019s strong position in music recognition would enable Apple to \u201cobtain access to commercially sensitive data about customers of its competitors.\u201d\n\n\u201cAccess to such data could allow Apple to directly target its competitors\u2019 customers and encourage them to switch to Apple Music. As a result, competing music streaming services could be put at a competitive disadvantage.\u201d\n\nThe European Commission has until Sept. 4 to finish its investigation.\n\nApple reached a deal to buy Shazam for roughly $400 million in December.\n\nPhoto\n\nBehind the bidding for India\u2019s e-commerce leader\n\nThe U.S. retail giant is reportedly close to buying a majority stake in Flipkart, the top e-commerce company in India, at a $20 billion valuation, according to Bloomberg. Existing investors like Tiger Global Management and SoftBank have agreed to sell substantial portions of their shares, giving Walmart a stake of 60 percent to 80 percent.\n\nWhy it\u2019s important: Both Walmart and Amazon have hungrily watched India, where the e-commerce market trails only the U.S. and China in terms of size but where foreign retailers have struggled. But don\u2019t expect Amazon, Flipkart\u2019s biggest rival, to give up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMove over, Spotify: Tencent Music reportedly plans to interview potential underwriters for a U.S. I.P.O., with a valuation exceeding $25 billion, according to WSJ. (It could also be the latest instance of a spinoff helping its Chinese parent\u2019s financial fortunes.)\n\nElsewhere in deals: Elliott Management wants Hyundai to reorganize its divisions and pay out more dividends. HNA cut its stake in Deutsche Bank amid its downsizing. How China is buying into Europe. Deutsche Telekom plans to fight Vodafone\u2019s plan to buy Liberty Media\u2019s German and Eastern Europe cable division. The parent company of Poker Stars agreed to buy Sky Betting & Gaming for $4.7 billion to get a foothold in Europe. Fresenius walked away from its $4.3 billion deal for Akorn, a maker of cancer drugs.\n\nNewell settles with Starboard\n\nJust over a month after cutting a deal with Carl Icahn (an agreement that Mr. Icahn\u2019s frenemy Bill Ackman said was \u201ca deal with the devil\u201d), the consumer brands conglomerate has reached an accord with Starboard Value as well.\n\nWhat\u2019s in the peace agreement: Newell will name three new directors. Two \u2014 Gerardo Lopez, the C.E.O. of Extended Stay America, and Robert Steele, a former senior executive at Procter & Gamble \u2014 are independent. The third, Bridget Ryan Berman, a former C.E.O. of `Armany and executive at Google and Victoria\u2019s Secret, was agreed upon by Starboard and Mr. Icahn.\n\nHow it came together: In a joint news release, Mr. Icahn said that Newell asked him to parley with Starboard. Key to reaching a truce was Mr. Icahn giving up two seats that he had taken on Newell\u2019s board.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat the parties said about the deal\n\n\u2022 Michael Polk, Newell\u2019s C.E.O.: \u201cThis agreement will enable the Company to now focus exclusively on the execution of our transformation plans and our efforts to strengthen our financial and operational performance.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Mr. Icahn: \u201cI am pleased that we were able to facilitate peace between the company and Starboard. Given that the company has so many more pressing priorities, this is clearly the best outcome for all shareholders.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Jeff Smith, Starboard\u2019s C.E.O.: \u201cWe are confident this newly reconstituted board will bring a refreshed sense of urgency, oversight, and accountability to Newell.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe market reaction: Shares in Newell were up over 3 percent in premarket trading on Monday.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nMike Bloomberg opens his wallet to fight climate change\n\nEven after the Trump administration withdrew from the Paris climate accord, Mr. Bloomberg insisted that the U.S. keep up its financial obligations to the U.N. body overseeing the pact \u2014 using $4.5 million of his own money. \u201cI\u2019m going to send them a check for the monies that America had promised to the organization as though they got it from the federal government,\u201d Mr. Bloomberg told CBS\u2019s \u201cFace the Nation.\u201d\n\nThe former N.Y.C. mayor has shown he has no problem speaking out on his personal causes, even if they\u2019re in opposition to President Trump\u2019s policies. And he\u2019s willing to put his own money to work as well.\n\nWhat Mr. Bloomberg isn\u2019t doing: Running for president \u2014 at the moment. \u201cI think I can as a private citizen help in some of those things and that\u2019s what I want to do with my life,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMeet the trading practice that Trump hates\n\n\u201cIf you talk China, I\u2019ve watched where the reporters have been writing 2 percent of our steel comes from China. Well, that\u2019s not right,\u201d President Trump said last month, before criticizing transshipping. The practice, which disguises the origins of metals and other imports, is a reason behind the U.S.\u2019s fight with China \u2014 and the E.U., South Korea and Canada have moved to crack down on illicit uses of the maneuver. (Certain instances can be legal.)\n\nMeanwhile, Steven Mnuchin is weighing a trip to Beijing, in the hopes that talks could avoid a full-blown trade war.\n\nElsewhere in trade: The E.U. and Mexico forged their own pact on Saturday, sending a message to Washington. And a trade war could hurt Google\u2019s Android.\n\nThe political flyaround\n\n\u2022 An NYT investigation into Scott Pruitt\u2019s career before the E.P.A. found close ties to lobbyists \u2014 and an instance of a house purchase involving a lobbyist, a shell company and a questionable sale price. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Mike Pence\u2019s older brother, Greg, is running for Congress \u2014 and his stewardship of a local gas station operator that went bankrupt is taking fire. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Republican tax cuts sliced $18 billion off the book value of 100 big U.S. public companies \u2014 but that math may change as a lower tax rate takes hold. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Will Kellyanne Conway finally take a role in the White House communications department? (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Has the office of the presidency become too big to manage? (The Atlantic)\n\nPhoto\n\nFacebook\u2019s hot seat moves to Europe\n\nMike Schroepfer, the company\u2019s chief technology officer, will appear on Thursday before the British government committee investigating fake news and social media following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. (No Mark Zuckerberg this time.)\n\nTestifying tomorrow before that committee will be Aleksandr Kogan, the academic who passed user data to Cambridge Analytica. Mr. Kogan apologized for his role, but said he was considering suing Facebook for suggesting that he had acted unethically. (The star witness last week \u2014 albeit in absentia \u2014 was the man who set up Cambridge Analytica\u2019s parent company decades ago.)\n\nElsewhere in Facebook: How the newsfeed played a central role in inciting violence in Sri Lanka. A deeper look at how much influence Campbell Brown, the former journalist who now leads news partnerships at the company, actually has.\n\nPhoto\n\nAmazon critics are wary of their newest ally\n\nFor years, the e-commerce giant has taken arrows from all corners, from labor unions to think tanks to competitors. Now President Trump has joined the fray, but not everyone is comfortable being on the same side.\n\nThe issue: Mr. Trump\u2019s attacks appear rooted in personal animus, clouding what others feel are legitimate criticisms. Matt Stoller of the Open Markets Institute told the NYT, \u201cWhat he\u2019s doing is a threat to democracy, but so is Amazon.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nElsewhere in Amazon news: The average Amazon employee is in a warehouse, not a data lab, and earns a median annual salary of $28,446. Many Americans believe the e-commerce titan has the most positive social impact of any big tech company, according to a new survey. (Another survey found that more than half of Americans want more regulations of tech companies.)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe problem with banks\u2019 answer to Venmo\n\nIt\u2019s the same issue that dogged Craigslist, PayPal and Venmo early on: fraud. Now Zelle, a payment service used by the likes of Bank of America and Chase, is grappling with what some analysts told the NYT is an alarming series of incidents. \u201cI know of one bank that was experiencing a 90 percent fraud rate on Zelle transactions, which is insane,\u201d said Genevieve Gimbert, a partner in PwC\u2019s financial crimes unit.\n\nThe problem: Customers often aren\u2019t notified when money is transferred; customers are subjected to phishing attacks that drain money from their accounts; buyers have no protections if sellers don\u2019t provide paid-for goods.\n\nWhy it matters: Banks want their share of digital payments, and 18 so far have signed up with Zelle.\n\nElsewhere in finance: UBS\u2019s strong first-quarter earnings were overshadowed by the bank\u2019s wealth-management unit missing estimates.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Gary Gensler has gone from Goldman Sachs trader to financial regulator under President Barack Obama to lecturer at M.I.T., where he plans to extol cryptocurrencies\u2019 virtues and warn of their regulatory problems. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Meet the kolion, a Russian cryptocurrency that is gaining favor in rural areas \u2014 and being watched warily by Moscow. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 NewsGuard, a service that uses trained journalists to rate thousands of news and information sites, is starting a hotline for reporting fake news sites. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Major American consumer brands said that Alibaba retaliated when they refused exclusive partnerships with the company. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "What Might Happen to Amazon\u2019s Profit if It Paid Its Workers More?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Did you know The New York Times publishes close to 30 film reviews each week?\n\nThat\u2019s hard for any film fan to keep up with \u2014 and doesn\u2019t even count the immense review archive within TimesMachine, going back nearly a century in film history.\n\nBut we\u2019re here to help by curating the most relevant and interesting reviews specifically for our Australian audience in a way that lines up with the local release dates.\n\nThis is our first wrap; email us if you like it, and we\u2019ll roll it out monthly.\n\n[Prefer not to go out? Check out our Australian Netflix guide instead.]\n\nStarring: Steve Buscemi, Simon Russell Beale, Jeffrey Tambor, Andrea Riseborough, Olga Kurylenko\n\nDirected by: Armando Iannucci", "title": "What Movies to See (or Skip) in Australian Cinemas This April", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Every year, the Pulitzer Prize for music is awarded \u201cfor distinguished musical composition by an American that has had its first performance or recording in the United States during the year.\u201d Take a look at the past winners here. What do you notice about these artists and compositions? What do you wonder?\n\nIn \u201cKendrick Lamar Wins Pulitzer in \u2018Big Moment for Hip-Hop\u2019,\u201d Joe Coscarelli writes:\n\nIn late January, the Compton, Calif., rapper Kendrick Lamar lost the Grammy Award for album of the year to Bruno Mars. \u201cDAMN.,\u201d Mr. Lamar\u2019s fourth LP, was his third straight to be nominated but ultimately fall short of the trophy, considered by most to be the top prize in popular music. But perhaps not anymore. On Monday, Mr. Lamar\u2019s \u201cDAMN.\u201d took home an even more elusive honor, one that may never have even seemed within reach: the Pulitzer Prize for music. Mr. Lamar is not only the first rapper to win the award since the Pulitzers expanded to music in 1943, but he is also the first winner who is not a classical or jazz musician. \u201cThe time was right,\u201d Dana Canedy, the administrator of the prizes, said in an interview after the winners were announced. \u201cWe are very proud of this selection. It means that the jury and the board judging system worked as it\u2019s supposed to \u2014 the best work was awarded a Pulitzer Prize.\u201d She added: \u201cIt shines a light on hip-hop in a completely different way. This is a big moment for hip-hop music and a big moment for the Pulitzers.\u201d Mr. Lamar was not immediately available to comment on his win. But Terrence Henderson, the record executive known as Punch from Mr. Lamar\u2019s label, Top Dawg Entertainment, acknowledged the achievement on Twitter, writing that from now on, no one should \u201cspeak with anything less than respect in your mouth for Kendrick Lamar.\u201d Ms. Canedy said the board\u2019s decision to award Mr. Lamar, 30, was unanimous. The board called the album \u201ca virtuosic song collection unified by its vernacular authenticity and rhythmic dynamism that offers affecting vignettes capturing the complexity of modern African-American life.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What is your reaction to Mr. Lamar\u2019s Pulitzer Prize for \u201cDAMN.\u201d? Do you think the award was well-earned? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with the jurors that rap music can be artistic, experimental and sophisticated? Why or why not? Can you give any examples to support your opinion?\n\n\u2014 Do you think this is a \u201cbig moment for hip-hop\u201d? Is it an important moment for the Pulitzers as well? Why do you think so?", "title": "What Musical Piece Would You Nominate for a Pulitzer Prize?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Image Ann Magnuson performing at Kenny Scharf\u2019s opening atop his \u201cUltima Suprema Deluxa\u201d Cadillac on November 14, 1983. Credit Allan Tannenbaum/Getty Images\n\n11:00 a.m.\n\nAnn Magnuson, actress and performance artist\n\nMy days changed depending on what show I was putting on, what sort of rehearsal schedule I had and how late I\u2019d been up the night before, though I had a rule for myself: Always be back before sunrise. My primary motive back then was to put on a show, and anything that slowed me down from that had to be curtailed. By 1981, I was no longer the manager at [the East Village performance space] Club 57, but I still helped out and performed there a lot. The Ladies Auxiliary of the Lower East Side \u2014 sort of a punk rock version of my mother\u2019s Junior League group, which I started with some other girls from the East Village \u2014 hosted several events at the club. We had a prom, a debutante ball, a ladies\u2019 wrestling night. In 1981, I suggested a bacchanal \u2014 a night of pagan merriment as spring was coming. So in April we held the Rites of Spring Fertility Bacchanal. We made an altar to a llama, and everyone dressed in kind of Greco-Roman outfits \u2014 I wore a toga with sequins. Wendy Wild made magic mushroom punch. We also created a percussive orchestra that was all pots and pans and a lot of racket, and that was the debut of the band Pulsallama. It was really like a combination of living theater and installation art, very communal. That\u2019s what happened at Club 57 a lot: We told people, \u201cThis is the theme. Come be a part of it.\u201d The doors would open and things would get going by 10, and by midnight it would be raging. In the mornings, usually around 11 a.m., I\u2019d go to one of the coffee shops around the corner on Avenue A. Odessa was one, and Leshko\u2019s was the other. People divided themselves into camps based on which one they favored \u2014 I liked Odessa better, but I\u2019d go to both. That\u2019s where you\u2019d run into people, share breakfast.\n\nJennifer Beals, actress\n\nWhen \u201cFlashdance\u201d came out in 1983, Paramount put me up in the Carlyle Hotel to do promotion. It was an incredible contrast from the last time I had lived in New York, when I was 17, during the summer of 1981, in a $500-a-month sublet loft that my boyfriend and I had found paging through our bible, the call to another life \u2014 The Village Voice \u2014 in his basement in Evanston. I remember I was drawn to the ad for the loft because it was in a place that sounded like \u201ctrifecta\u201d; my father had taken me to the track, so that seemed comforting and familiar. (What a loft was, I wasn\u2019t entirely sure.) Being at the Carlyle was amazing, but I was still an undergrad at Yale at the time, and the whole thing felt unreal, as though I was living two lives. One day, I was walking uptown to an appointment just before noon, and coming toward me was Robert Duvall. He recognized me and stopped to congratulate me on the film. It was crazy. He said he was going to lunch with some friends, and did I want to join? I couldn\u2019t, but I did turn around and walk with him for some blocks to the restaurant. It was a brilliantly sunny day, and standing outside was Dustin Hoffman. Bob introduced us, and Dustin congratulated me on the film and told me my acting was \u201cnaturalistic.\u201d It dawned on me that there are so many different styles of acting and you don\u2019t have to adhere to just one. I was 19. I didn\u2019t know anything. That completely opened my mind.\n\nImage The painter David Salle in his Manhattan studio, 1983. Credit Thomas Hoepker/Magnum Photos\n\n12:00 p.m.\n\nDavid Salle, artist\n\nThe election of Ronald Reagan in 1980 is sometimes used as a marker of the beginning of the end of the art world as it was then known, as if the two were somehow related, as if an election ushered in some new aesthetic permission, a new vulgarity, which is really a kind of negative magical thinking. I doubt if many artists experienced it that way. Everyone I knew hated Reagan and couldn\u2019t wait for him to get out of office. I remember being in someone\u2019s loft \u2014 it might have been [artist] Brian Hunt\u2019s \u2014 with a group of friends, watching the inauguration on a little black-and-white television. The silence, as they say, was deafening. No one could believe that this B-actor was about to occupy the White House.\n\nSamuel R. Delany, writer\n\nI got up at anywhere from 3 to 5 in the morning and worked as long as I could. I worked in my office at home, an eight-room walk-up on the Upper West Side. It was a very different kind of neighborhood from the one I grew up in in Harlem \u2014 just starting to be gentrified. The apartment was big, but the hall was in very bad repair, or at least looked it. \u201cMom says that your apartment looks like a crack den,\u201d my daughter told me once. A \u201ccrack den\u201d lined with books.\n\nAt 11 to 12, I\u2019d had a nine-hour day. I would walk around the neighborhood, go down to 42nd Street and do a lot of movie cruising. I\u2019d go for two, three, four hours and have a fairly good time. There was a theater called the Capri that I went to a lot. There were others: the Venus, and down in the 14th Street area, the Variety Photoplays, a Spanish one called The Jefferson, The Metropol [Metropolitan]. Some of them were open 24 hours a day, or they were closed maybe four hours a day for cleaning. They were relatively small, rundown theaters; they tended to have a fair amount of drug use going on. A lot of it was crack. Before that it had been pot. These places were used largely by working-class men, white, black and Latino, people who thought of themselves as straight and gay, many of whom were amenable to sexual things. They could be stimulated by the heterosexual pornography that was on the screen. This kind of activity is highly socially ordered: You don\u2019t barge in on other people, that\u2019s all part of it. I tended to feel particularly safe in the theaters. AIDS was a very strange situation; starting in \u201982 you knew very little about it, and then a few years later you suddenly realized it was the largest killer among your personal friends. It cut down a great number of the people who were out there doing it, but at the same time, the ones who were left were much more intense about it. You weren\u2019t afraid of getting it, you were wondering when are the symptoms going to show up.\n\n1:00 p.m.\n\nDebbie Allen, actress\n\nI held auditions for \u201cFame,\u201d the TV show, on a Sunday at the New York School of Ballet because that\u2019s where I trained, and Mr. Thomas [ballet dancer Richard Scott Thomas] was happy to give me a studio. I had been starring on Broadway in \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d and I had done the movie \u201cRagtime,\u201d which was also coming out, but dance has always been my heartbeat. So when they talked to me about playing the character Lydia Grant, the dance teacher, I said, \u201cYes, I would be so interested if I could also be responsible for the choreography.\u201d Because by this time, I had been developing as a choreographer, working with the Henry Street Playhouse and the New York Shakespeare Festival, and I really loved doing it. And they said, \u201cYeah, you can have that\u201d \u2014 they weren\u2019t even thinking about it. They paid me like a tenth of what they paid me to do the acting, and it became my whole life. We were shooting the pilot, and I was trying to find the best dancers I could. They were supposed to be 17 or 18. Some of them were lying about their age and I knew it, but I didn\u2019t care. I said, \u201cTo hell with it!\u201d Jasmine Guy auditioned; she wasn\u2019t of age yet. Bronwyn Thomas, she was like happy feet on her toes. She was the ultimate ballerina, and she became that on \u201cFame.\u201d I was excited that I would be able to introduce this new band of gypsies to the Hollywood scene.\n\nImage An unpublished male nude Polaroid from 1981 by photographer Tom Bianchi. Credit Tom Bianchi\n\n2:00 p.m.\n\nTom Bianchi, photographer\n\nColumbia Pictures had given me this SX-70 camera at a conference, and I started documenting life in the Fire Island Pines [an area of Long Island known as a haven for gay life], which just seemed very important to me. Growing up in the suburbs of Chicago, a boy like me didn\u2019t know there was a place for him in the world like that. Very quickly, I realized it had potential to be a book. Two editors at Simon & Schuster thought it was terrific, but they said, \u201cYou have to produce this yourself, and we can possibly get you a distribution deal. We can\u2019t put the money out for something this queer.\u201d Then [writer and editor] Bob Colacello saw the project and said, \u201cAndy Warhol has a three-book deal with Houghton Mifflin. He has one book but he doesn\u2019t have the next two. Maybe he could do your book under that contract.\u201d So I went to the Factory and stood at a tall table with Andy and Bob, and Andy went through the dummy. It was almost a surreal experience, because I had the feeling that this person is only vaguely here. As Andy turned the pages, he said things like \u201cOh, that\u2019s nice,\u201d \u201cOh, that could be larger,\u201d \u201cOh \u2026 \u201d At the end of it, he said, \u201cYes, I think we should do your book. I\u2019ve gotta go to something, Bob will call you.\u201d I took the elevator down to the street and I saw a phone booth and the first thought that came to my mind was, \u201cDo not call any of your friends and tell them Andy Warhol is doing your book because I don\u2019t think that\u2019s for real.\u201d And sure enough, he didn\u2019t.", "title": "What New York Was Like in the Early \u201980s \u2014 Hour by Hour", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThere will be a ton of attention this year devoted to the feelings of America\u2019s voters. But many more adult citizens in this country are likely to be nonvoters in this year\u2019s crucial midterm elections than voters. In the 2014 midterm, after all, only about one out of every three eligible voters actually showed up at the polls.\n\nYesterday, Suffolk University and USA Today released a fascinating poll of these likely nonvoters. \u201cEvery other poll conducted this election cycle will express the views of registered and likely voters,\u201d the organizations explained. \u201cThis is a poll of everyone else.\u201d\n\nNo one can know exactly who will not vote, of course. The poll surely includes some people who will end up voting and excludes some who won\u2019t. But based on demographic patterns and on what people say about their intentions, pollsters can get a good sense of someone\u2019s likelihood of voting. So the broad patterns in the Suffolk/USA Today poll are meaningful. And here\u2019s what the poll found:\n\n\u2022 Many nonvoters \u201csay they have given up on the political parties and a system that they say is beyond reform and repair.\u201d (Why? I think the stagnation of living standards is the main answer.) They also have a decidedly negative view of Donald Trump\u2019s performance.", "title": "Opinion | What Nonvoters Really Think", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Stinging, salty waves crashed over the deck as frantic figures climbed on board. It was midnight in November, and we were 30 miles off the coast of Libya, where our small ship was quickly filling with scores of terrified, freezing refugees whom we had rescued from the chilly waters. I stepped over an elderly paraplegic man sprawled on the deck so I could wrap blankets around a teenage Egyptian boy battling hypothermia. His eyes rolled back in his head as he tried to stay awake.\n\n\u201cDoctor, my name is Rafiq,\u201d he told me in broken English. \u201cI am alone. I am 15 years old. If I die, please tell my family.\u201d\n\nI peeled his clothes from his clammy body and wrapped my arms around him to try to keep him warm. I felt his heartbeat flutter and wondered if he would make it until morning. Beside him, the paraplegic man searched in vain for his small knapsack, which he had lost during the rescue. Nearby, a Sudanese mother cradled a wailing, emaciated 40-day-old baby covered in lumpy skin lesions.\n\nThese refugees, and others like them, risked everything to make this treacherous journey because the lives they left behind posed an even greater danger than the sea. The Syrian war has displaced millions who are desperately seeking an existence free from barrel bombs and chemical weapons. Others travel thousands of miles over land and water to escape poverty and authoritarian governments. Most of these migrants flow through Libya in the hope of making it to Italy by boat across the Mediterranean Sea \u2014 since 2015, nearly half a million have reached the Italian coast. From there, many continue their travels into Europe.", "title": "What Refugees Face on the World\u2019s Deadliest Migration Route", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI really think that you should have disclosed your relationship with Cohen when you talked about him on this show,\u201d Mr. Dershowitz said. \u201cYou could have said that you had asked him for advice or whatever.\u201d\n\nFox News issued a statement on Tuesday saying Mr. Hannity had the network\u2019s full support. Here\u2019s a look at the many times Mr. Hannity discussed Mr. Cohen on the program since the April 9 raid.\n\n\u2018Cohen was never part of the Trump administration\u2019\n\nHours after the news broke, Mr. Hannity opened his show by mentioning it. He immediately connected the action by federal prosecutors in New York to Robert S. Mueller III\u2019s investigation into possible links between the Trump campaign and Russian officials.\n\n\u201cMueller\u2019s witch-hunt investigation is now a runaway train that is clearly careening off the tracks,\u201d he said.\n\nThe raid on Mr. Cohen\u2019s office, court records show, was part of a monthslong investigation. It was overseen by the United States attorney for the Southern District. However Mr. Cohen\u2019s lawyer, Stephen Ryan, said on April 9 that the search was carried out on a referral by Mr. Mueller\u2019s office.\n\nWithout mentioning his own connection to Mr. Cohen, Mr. Hannity then told viewers that \u201cCohen was never part of the Trump administration or the Trump campaign.\u201d\n\nMr. Hannity went on to compare Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation and the raid on Mr. Cohen to an F.B.I. investigation in 2015 and 2016 that focused on Hillary Clinton\u2019s handling of her email.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou think Hillary Clinton\u2019s attorneys had their offices raided during this email investigation?\u201d he asked.\n\nHe raised the issue again later that evening, referring to it as \u201cthe double standard aspect\u201d in a conversation with the Fox News reporter Sara Carter.\n\nMichael D. Cohen longtime personal lawyer to negotiated payments to cover up an affair for acted as informal legal counsel to Donald J.
