Rosenstein, who supervises Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation.\n\nIn his third conversation with Mr. Dershowitz, he referenced Mr. Dershowitz\u2019s comments in the previous evenings that the raid violated Mr. Cohen\u2019s constitutional rights.\n\nHe then asked if Mr. Dershowitz thought it was \u201cthe attorney general\u2019s job to now step in and fire Rod Rosenstein?\u201d\n\nLater, he played a clip of former House Speaker Newt Gingrich comparing the F.B.I.\u2019s raid on Mr. Cohen to the German Gestapo and communist Russia.\n\n\u201cThese tactics are not American,\u201d Mr. Hannity said. \u201cThat\u2019s the point.\u201d\n\n\u2018A perfectly legitimate business move\u2019\n\nOn April 12, Mr. Hannity spent most of his show discussing James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director who released a memoir describing his relationship with Mr. Trump this week.\n\nBut he diverged briefly to discuss a report that a former Federal Election Commission chairman, Bradley Smith, did not think Mr. Cohen should be charged over his payment to Ms. Clifford.\n\n\u201cSmith is arguing that Cohen\u2019s payment is a perfectly legitimate business move,\u201d Mr. Hannity said, \u201cand that any attempt to connect it to an in-kind contribution is an extreme stretch. It doesn\u2019t fit.\u201d\n\nThen Mr. Hannity turned back to other news.\n\n\u2018It was such a minor relationship\u2019\n\nIt was not until he had a week of programs under his belt, after his name emerged in court, that Mr. Hannity described his relationship with Mr. Cohen.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe did so in response to the objections of Mr. Dershowitz, who had spent a week discussing the case with him, apparently unaware of the connection.\n\nEarlier in the broadcast, Mr. Hannity had acknowledged the attention the revelation by Mr. Cohen\u2019s legal team was getting, calling the media coverage \u201cabsolutely insane.\u201d He introduced a 46-second montage of cable news hosts and commentators saying his name repeatedly.\n\nAt the end of the show, in response to Mr. Dershowitz, Mr. Hannity repeated assertions he had made earlier in the day, saying: \u201cMichael Cohen never represented me in any legal matter. I never retained his services. I never received an invoice. I never paid Michael Cohen for legal fees. I did have occasional brief conversations with Michael Cohen \u2014 he\u2019s a great attorney \u2014 about legal questions I had or I was looking for input and perspective.\u201d\n\nThe host described the relationship as \u201cminimal\u201d in response to Mr. Dershowitz\u2019s initial objection.\n\n\u201cBut, you know, it\u2019s a complex situation when you are speaking to millions of people,\u201d Mr. Dershowitz later commented.\n\n\u201cProfessor,\u201d Mr. Hannity interrupted, \u201cit was such a minor relationship in terms of it had to do with real estate and nothing political.\u201d", "title": "What Sean Hannity Has Been Saying About Michael Cohen", "authors": ["Michael Gold"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "The explosion at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in 1986 has often been described as the worst nuclear disaster in history. But there are records of several larger and more destructive catastrophes. In \u201cThe Age of Radiance,\u201d a history of the nuclear era, Craig Nelson cites a 1957 plutonium-plant accident in the Ural Mountains that irradiated an area 14 times as large as the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone. There are other examples, too, but these accidents weren\u2019t publicized, because they took place in the U.S.S.R. during the secretive era before glasnost. So what makes Chernobyl history\u2019s worst? It\u2019s the fact that we all know about it.\n\nIn other words, our collective reckoning of what is or isn\u2019t a disaster entails publicity. Disasters are news because they are news.\n\nTrump isn\u2019t the only one who sees disaster everywhere. In every section of the newspaper, one has either just happened, is unfolding now or is about to occur. It\u2019s surprisingly common in the sports section, as in \u201cSixers avoid another near disaster with comeback\u201d \u2014 in sports, success and catastrophic failure can lie just a point or two apart. Most news disasters, though, are more literal, from the almost benign \u201cnatural disaster\u201d to the more threatening \u201cclimate disaster\u201d to the downright sinister \u201cdisaster capitalism.\u201d\n\nIn March, FEMA released a new five-year strategic plan, calling for less bureaucracy and more civilian disaster preparedness. It was soon followed by a news release from the Union for Concerned Scientists, reporting that the plan had been scrubbed of references to climate change. Citizens of the United States, according to the FEMA administrator Brock Long, needed to \u201cgo back to the old civil defense days of being ready.\u201d This advice would be echoed, two weeks later, in Rick Santorum\u2019s claim that instead of fighting for gun control, students should learn CPR: disaster preparedness as pre-emptive victim-blaming. (Santorum has since said that he \u201cmisspoke.\u201d)\n\nIf disasters must be sudden, as both of Merriam-Webster\u2019s definitions attest, must they also be surprising and unpredictable? Disasters, like accidents, are often described as \u201cwaiting to happen.\u201d The Challenger explosion has become a case study in avoidable disaster; it was known among NASA staff that one component had a high risk of failure under the unusually cold flight conditions that morning. They went ahead with the launch anyway.\n\nIt\u2019s possible all disasters are disasters waiting to happen. The word is so common that it\u2019s easy not to see its Latin roots hiding in plain sight: Dis as in negative, aster as in star. Ill starred. The etymology suggests that disasters are destined, inevitable, like a Greek tragedy. Fourteen years before the Titanic sank, the American writer Morgan Robertson published a novella called \u201cThe Wreck of the Titan: Or, Futility,\u201d in which the titular ship sinks after striking an iceberg. Twelve years before that, a British journalist named W.T. Stead wrote a short story meant to serve as a warning to the public of inadequate safety measures on ocean liners. He died on the Titanic.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s tempting, perhaps, to think of disasters as fated; it lets us off the hook. But the sense that a catastrophe could have been avoided through better planning only heightens our impression of the event as a disaster. Climate disasters, for instance, are now entirely expected, and we\u2019ve known for years that the worst outcomes could be avoided with immediate and drastic action. But we don\u2019t take that action. Our utter failure to respond in kind is part of the disaster.\n\nOn March 17, a BBC headline announced plans for a \u201cNorcroft Colliery memorial for \u2018unknown\u2019 mining disaster.\u201d David Hinchliffe, a former member of Parliament, was working to fund a memorial for the victims of an 1821 incident outside Barnsley, England, in which 10 workers, five men and five boys, were killed when a chain broke as they tried to ascend a mine shaft. He\u2019s the one who called it \u201can unknown disaster\u201d \u2014 \u201cwith unmarked graves, it has been forgotten.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow could a disaster be unknown? And while certainly tragic, wouldn\u2019t 10 deaths in a 19th-century mine more properly be termed an accident \u2014 one that\u2019s not particularly unexpected or urgent? But the youngest victim of the accident, John Hinchliffe, was the M.P.\u2019s great-great-grandparents\u2019 eldest son. The living Hinchliffe learned of the accident while researching his family history. That personal connection can collapse the distance from now to then: For Hinchliffe, the event could have the intensity, the immediacy, of disaster.\n\nThis is the difference between a disaster and an accident, between a school shooting and the everyday murders and suicides that add up to tens of thousands of gun deaths every year, few of them registering on the national consciousness. Disasters are public events that feel personal.\n\nIt\u2019s why people remember where they were on 9/11, and some even claim to remember watching the first plane strike on TV that morning \u2014 an impossible memory, since the only known footage of the event was captured accidentally and was not on the news that day. We don\u2019t have perfect recall for traumatic events: Studies have shown that our memories change and degrade over time, new information bleeding into them. But we see clips of disasters over and over \u2014 the tall, forked plume of the Challenger explosion, the second plane disappearing sleekly into the South Tower. Repetition gives these iconic, smoke-in-the-sky images the intimacy of memories. They confuse our personal history.\n\nThe spectacle of this media attention can be dangerous: School shootings and suicides often happen in clusters, one inspiring another. The constant horror of grim news can numb us to its significance. And while some events are turned into high-resolution dramas, others are, inevitably, ignored, too distant or abstract to make an impression.\n\nBy the end of that BBC story, readers learned that John Hinchliffe was just 8 years old when he fell about 17 stories to his death on the floor of a mine. Seeing the scale of it \u2014 the small boy and the very long fall \u2014 makes it feel more visceral, more known. This is both the power and the danger of \u201cdisaster\u201d: It lets you choose what becomes real and immediate, and what stays far away.", "title": "What Separates Ordinary Bad News From True \u2018Disaster\u2019?", "authors": ["Elisa Gabbert", "First Words"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "All told I communicated with maybe a dozen men during that time in my life, and had sex with fewer than half. Others I texted or talked with, which sometimes felt nearly as intimate.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore I met each man I would ask: \u201cWhy are you doing this?\u201d I wanted assurance that all he desired was sex.\n\nWhat surprised me was that these husbands weren\u2019t looking to have more sex. They were looking to have any sex.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI met one man whose wife had implicitly consented to her husband having a lover because she was no longer interested in sex, at all. They both, to some degree, got what they needed without having to give up what they wanted. But the other husbands I met would have preferred to be having sex with their wives. For whatever reason, that wasn\u2019t happening.\n\nI know what it feels like to go off sex, and I know what it\u2019s like to want more than my partner. It\u2019s also a tall order to have sex with the same person for more years than our ancestors ever hoped to live. Then, at menopause, a woman\u2019s hormones suddenly drop and her desire can wane.\n\nAt 49, I was just about there myself, and terrified of losing my desire for sex. Men don\u2019t have this drastic change. So we have an imbalance, an elephant-size problem, so burdensome and shameful we can scarcely muster the strength to talk about it.\n\nMaybe the reason some wives aren\u2019t having sex with their husbands is because, as women age, we long for a different kind of sex. I know I did, which is what led me down this path of illicit encounters. After all, nearly as many women are initiating affairs as men.\n\nIf you read the work of Esther Perel, the author of the recently published book \u201cState of Affairs,\u201d you\u2019ll learn that, for many wives, sex outside of marriage is their way of breaking free from being the responsible spouses and mothers they have to be at home. Married sex, for them, often feels obligatory. An affair is adventure.\n\nMeanwhile, the husbands I spent time with would have been fine with obligatory sex. For them, adventure wasn\u2019t the main reason for their adultery.\n\nThe first time I saw my favorite married man pick up his pint of beer, the sleeve of his well-tailored suit pulled back from his wrist to reveal a geometric kaleidoscope of tattoos. He was cleanshaven and well mannered with a little rebel yell underneath. The night I saw the full canvas of his tattoo masterpiece, we drank prosecco, listened to \u201980s music and, yes, had sex. We also talked.\n\nI asked him: \u201cWhat if you said to your wife, \u2018Look, I love you and the kids but I need sex in my life. Can I just have the occasional fling or a casual affair?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe sighed. \u201cI don\u2019t want to hurt her,\u201d he said. \u201cShe\u2019s been out of the work force for 10 years, raising our kids and trying to figure out what she wants to do with her life. If I asked her that kind of question, it would kill her.\u201d\n\n\u201cSo you don\u2019t want to hurt her, but you lie to her instead. Personally, I\u2019d rather know.\u201d\n\nWell, maybe I would rather know. My own marriage had not broken up over an affair so I couldn\u2019t easily put myself in her position.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not necessarily a lie if you don\u2019t confess the truth,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s kinder to stay silent.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m just saying I couldn\u2019t do that. I don\u2019t want to be afraid of talking honestly about my sex life with the man I\u2019m married to, and that includes being able to at least raise the subject of sex outside of marriage.\u201d\n\n\u201cGood luck with that!\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cWe go into marriage assuming we\u2019ll be monogamous,\u201d I said, \u201cbut then we get restless. We don\u2019t want to split up, but we need to feel more sexually alive. Why break up the family if we could just accept the occasional affair?\u201d\n\nHe laughed. \u201cHow about we stop talking about it before this affair stops being fun?\u201d\n\nI never convinced any husband that he could be honest about what he was doing. But they were mostly good-natured about it, like a patient father responding to a child who keeps asking, \u201cWhy, why, why?\u201d\n\nMaybe I was being too pragmatic about issues that are loaded with guilt, resentment and fear. After all, it\u2019s far easier to talk theoretically about marriage than to navigate it. But my attitude is that if my spouse were to need something I couldn\u2019t give him, I wouldn\u2019t keep him from getting it elsewhere, as long as he did so in a way that didn\u2019t endanger our family.\n\nI suppose I would hope his needs would involve fishing trips or beers with friends. But sex is basic. Physical intimacy with other human beings is essential to our health and well-being. So how do we deny such a need to the one we care about most? If our primary relationship nourishes and stabilizes us but lacks intimacy, we shouldn\u2019t have to destroy our marriage to get that intimacy somewhere else. Should we?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI didn\u2019t have a full-on affair with the tattooed husband. We slept together maybe four times over a few years. More often we talked on the phone. I never felt possessive, just curious and happy to be in his company.\n\nAfter our second night together, though, I could tell this was about more than sex for him; he was desperate for affection. He said he wanted to be close to his wife but couldn\u2019t because they were unable to get past their fundamental disconnect: lack of sex, which led to a lack of closeness, which made sex even less likely and then turned into resentment and blame.\n\nWe all go through phases of wanting it and not wanting it. I doubt most women avoid having sex with their husbands because they lack physical desire in general; we are simply more complex sexual animals. Which is why men can get an erection from a pill but there\u2019s no way to medically induce arousal and desire in women.\n\nI am not saying the answer is non-monogamy, which can be rife with risks and unintended entanglements. I believe the answer is honesty and dialogue, no matter how frightening. Lack of sex in marriage is common, and it shouldn\u2019t lead to shame and silence. By the same token, an affair doesn\u2019t have to lead to the end of a marriage. What if an affair \u2014 or, ideally, simply the urge to have one \u2014 can be the beginning of a necessary conversation about sex and intimacy?\n\nWhat these husbands couldn\u2019t do was have the difficult discussion with their wives that would force them to tackle the issues at the root of their cheating. They tried to convince me they were being kind by keeping their affairs secret. They seemed to have convinced themselves. But deception and lying are ultimately corrosive, not kind.\n\nIn the end, I had to wonder if what these men couldn\u2019t face was something else altogether: hearing why their wives no longer wanted to have sex with them. It\u2019s much easier, after all, to set up an account on Tinder.", "title": "What Sleeping With Married Men Taught Me About Infidelity", "authors": ["Karin Jones", "Modern Love"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 In January, when word got out that President Trump had disparaged African nations in vulgar terms during an Oval Office rant about immigration policy, his remarks were met with alarm and outrage by leaders and others on the continent.\n\nBut on Monday at the White House, both Mr. Trump and President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria, the first leader from sub-Saharan Africa to visit him at the White House, carefully avoided the topic, professing mutual respect for each other and their respective countries at a cordial news conference.\n\nLawmakers in the room with Mr. Trump in January said he had used the term \u201cshithole countries\u201d to describe African nations, an accusation he has previously denied. But he did not do so on Monday, instead appearing to try to justify its spirit by noting that many countries in Africa are riddled with problems.\n\n\u201cYou do have some countries that are in very bad shape and very tough places to live in,\u201d Mr. Trump said during a news conference with Mr. Buhari in the Rose Garden, asked by a reporter about his use of vulgarity to describe Africa. \u201cBut we didn\u2019t discuss it because the president knows me, and he knows where I\u2019m coming from, and I appreciate that.\u201d", "title": "What Vulgar Remarks? Trump and Buhari, Nigeria\u2019s Leader, Avoid Clash", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "From 1976 to 1986, one man struck fear in the hearts of Californians from Sacramento to San Francisco to Los Angeles, killing 12 people, raping at least 45 people and burglarizing more than 120 homes in meticulously planned crimes.\n\nHe was known by many names: the Golden State Killer, the East Area Rapist, the Diamond Knot Killer and the Original Night Stalker. But until last week, decades of detective work had not uncovered the name of Joseph James DeAngelo.\n\nA statewide hunt for the suspect finally ended on Tuesday, when the authorities said that they had arrested Mr. DeAngelo, 72, and that he was responsible for the series of murders and rapes. In the end, the decades-long hunt for the infamous figure ended not far from where the case started. Here\u2019s what we know so far about the suspect.\n\nHe was a former cop who served in the Navy\n\nThe Golden State Killer usually struck at night after carefully planning his attack, even down to the smallest details, ahead of time. He studied his victims\u2019 schedules, broke into their homes and unlocked windows or removed screens in preparation for his return. He turned off porch lights and hid shoelaces and ropes to use later to bind his victims.", "title": "What We Know About Joseph DeAngelo, the Golden State Killer Suspect", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "An Ode to the Simple Elegance of Amsale Aberra\n\nWhen it comes to a designer who has mastered the art of simple elegance, Amsale Aberra, who died earlier this month, has made this look iconic for more than 30 years. \u201cThe final collection designed by Amsale Aberra reflects the understated drama that she will forever be known for,\u201d said Sarah Swann, the Amsale Studio director. The collection was an ode to classic silhouettes inspired by cathedral elegance with grand and modern gowns accented with draped bows and crystal beading.", "title": "What We Saw at New York Bridal Fashion Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "While a series of actions by European judges and regulators are trying to curb some of the powerful targeting mechanisms that Facebook employs, federal officials in the United States have done little to constrain them \u2014 to the consternation of American privacy advocates who say Facebook continues to test the boundaries of what is permissible.\n\n\n\nFacebook requires outside sites that use its tracking technologies to clearly notify users, and it allows Facebook users to opt out of seeing ads based on their use of those apps and websites.\n\nThat has not stopped angry users from airing their grievances over Facebook\u2019s practices.\n\nIn 2016, for example, a Missouri man with metastatic cancer sued Facebook. The suit, which sought class-action status, accused the tech giant of violating the man\u2019s privacy by tracking his activities on cancer center websites outside the social network \u2014 and collecting details about his possible treatment options \u2014 without his permission.\n\nFacebook persuaded a federal judge to dismiss the case. The company argued that tracking users for ad-targeting purposes was a standard business practice, and one that its users agreed to when signing up for the service. The Missouri man and two other plaintiffs have appealed the judge\u2019s decision.", "title": "What You Don\u2019t Know About How Facebook Uses Your Data", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "No one knows for certain how they know to do this \u2014 or why. But this vertical migration \u2014 especially the one completed every day by some of the ocean\u2019s smallest creatures \u2014 may be making big waves.\n\nHalf a century ago Walter Munk, a renowned oceanographer and geophysicist at Scripps Institution of Oceanography, described what we accept today about this mixing: that the wind and tide help. In one paper, he also briefly mentioned that vertical migrations could play a role.\n\nDr. Dabiri would later discover in an email exchange with Dr. Munk that he had said this in jest: Animals can\u2019t kick up much more water than the amount directly around their bodies.\n\nAround the same time, it was deemed impossible that tiny animals, even collectively, could create enough power in their movements to stir up a layered ocean.\n\n\u201cThese animals are individually small, and the ocean is enormous,\u201d said Dr. Dabiri. \u201cIt sort of defies intuition that such small organisms could have a major impact in the oceans.\u201d", "title": "What a Scientist Learned From Studying the \u2018Synchronized Swimming of Sea Monkeys\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "John Malatare sat in his friend T.J. Haynes\u2019s truck, hurtling through the darkness. T.J. wore a wool cap with elk teeth affixed to the brim. A tribal cop who worked with Big Will, he grew up with John. Now each was a foster parent; it was T.J.\u2019s wife who committed suicide the previous February, before the state tournament. He was raising nine kids.\n\nJohn and T.J. had heard that buffalo were moving out of Yellowstone National Park, so they had loaded up T.J.\u2019s trailer with snowmobiles and rolled south at 2 a.m. In the 1870s, the Salish moved a few calves into the Flathead reservation, building up a herd that was later used to revive the flagging Yellowstone population. Now the Salish are one of six tribes with treaty rights allowing them to hunt Yellowstone\u2019s bison when they move out of the park.\n\nOn the ride down, the men rubbed their hands and whistled in anticipation. Sometimes the hunters just stood in line waiting for the bison to cross onto Forest Service land, and sometimes animal rights protesters tailed them. Even so, John would rather hunt buffalo than anything else. \u201cThe first time I shot one of these, it was a whole different feeling,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was just the respect.\u201d He and T.J. talked about their disdain for trophy hunters who sell the hides. \u201cPhillip, he sleeps on his,\u201d John said. \u201cGot to keep the fan on just \u2019cause he stays so warm!\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe considered his son\u2019s college prospects. He wanted Phil to get back to the Montana Tech coach. He knew Phil wanted to play for the Griz, but he didn\u2019t know what to do. Should he go knock down the coach\u2019s door and ask what it would take? He thought of a friend who had played college ball. The coach had given him a hard time. \u201cI said, \u2018They\u2019re testing you out,\u2019 \u201d John recalled. \u201c \u2018They\u2019re seeing how tough your willpower really is.\u2019 \u201d But his friend quit. John said, \u201cProven point right there.\u201d Native kids got one shot.\n\nA track star in high school, John always wished he had pursued athletics more seriously; Terry Pitts, Zanen\u2019s father, a retired coach and former tribal councilman, thought he could have been an Olympian. John met Becky, who was a descendant of European settlers and played basketball against his sisters, at age 22. Becky went on to work for a Missoula hospital, handling accounts, while John was hired by the Forest Service, digging breaks around wildfires. When he started out, \u201cWe heard a lot of, \u2018What are you Indians doing here?\u2019 \u201d he recalled. \u201cI had to work extra hard to prove that I could do the job.\u201d John became a supervisor, earning a good living, and when Phil was in sixth grade, four of his cousins, including Dar, came to live with the Malatares and their three children. After that the Malatares kept getting calls from the tribe, asking them to foster more kids. They came and came, sometimes for days at a time, sometimes more. Mounds of laundry piled up in the kitchen.\n\nWhen Phil was 6, he told his parents he was going to be a professional athlete. By the time he was a freshman, he said he wanted to be the best basketball player Montana had ever seen. John realized he hadn\u2019t considered his own life once his son\u2019s career ended. \u201cWhat are we going to do if he doesn\u2019t continue and play through college?\u201d he asked. \u201cI don\u2019t know. I don\u2019t know if I\u2019ve thought that far.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDawn revealed a blue, snowed-in landscape. T.J. and John parked at a pull-off, stepped out of the truck and fired up their snowmobiles. A wolf ran past. The men hopped on the sleds and tore off into the lodgepole. They wound up a long curving track to an overlook from which they could see wide plains and craggy peaks, but no buffalo. They descended into low timber and split up. T.J. wound his way a bit farther, then stopped. A herd of bison moved slowly through the trees, followed by hunters on foot and, behind them, a group of animal rights campaigners documenting the kills. Shots rang out, and the herd split up, some moving toward private property, some back toward the park boundary.\n\nAn hour or so later, John and T.J. met back at the truck. John hadn\u2019t caught the herd. \u201cEveryone without sleds killed \u2019em,\u201d John said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThem protesters must have pushed \u2019em all onto that private property,\u201d T.J. said.\n\nOver dinner that night at a sports bar, they joined a group of Salish hunters, who talked basketball and hunting and foster-parenting. At one point, one of the men tried to imagine life with endless buffalo. \u201cUsed to be a perfect world,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cSure ain\u2019t now,\u201d T.J. said.\n\nOn the way home the next day, John considered the state championship in Butte, six weeks away. With seven games remaining in the regular season, the Warriors were undefeated. John had already booked his hotel room. \u201cStars are going to have to start falling out of the skies,\u201d he said, \u201cfor us not to be there.\u201d\n\nBy early February, Phil was averaging 23 points, 10 rebounds, seven assists and six steals a game. He needed to decide about Montana Tech, but he didn\u2019t have a clear feeling. Then one day he was driving out to one of his horn-hunting spots, hoping to clear his head, when he received a text from a coach at the University of Montana. Phil called the coach right away, and the coach asked if he wanted a spot on the team. Phil pumped his fist and politely said that yes, he\u2019d like that very much. In a follow-up call with Phil\u2019s parents, the Griz offered Phil a \u201cpreferred\u201d walk-on spot, meaning he was guaranteed a place on the team but would have to pay his own way. Phil told the coach he was in. (Rachi Wortham, an assistant coach at the University of Montana, said, \u201cWe can confirm recruitment,\u201d but he declined to comment further.)\n\nAfter the call, John sat down in his leather recliner and exhaled. Becky was still partial to Tech \u2014 the school had great academics, and the free ride wouldn\u2019t hurt, given that the Malatares still had two more kids to put through high school and college. But Phil had made up his mind. He called Adam Hiatt to relay his decision, but he asked his parents not to share the news widely. He didn\u2019t want to disrupt the Warriors\u2019 playoff run.\n\nThe season came down to three weekends in late February and early March: the district championship, the divisional championship and state. By this point, Will had rediscovered his shot, and the Warriors played with devastating joy. In the last regular-season game, Phil and Will combined to score 72 points.\n\nPitts called a coach from a Montana college, gushing that Will had a 35-foot shooting range, defense that can\u2019t be taught, strong grades. The coach wanted to know about Will\u2019s family. Pitts said that Will\u2019s father was a cop and that if the coach gave him a chance, his mother would \u201chave him there tomorrow.\u201d Assuming his most authoritative sales voice, Pitts declared that Will would make it: \u201cI\u2019d stick my job on the line for him.\u201d The coach said he\u2019d think about it. Pitts hung up and shook his head.\n\nOn Tuesday, Feb. 20, just before divisionals, word spread of a suicide: a teenage basketball player from Two Eagle River, a competing team on the Flathead reservation. Pitts was worried. \u201cThe next week or two, another kid might do it,\u201d he said.\n\nThe divisional tournament was held in Hamilton, in the Bitterroot Valley, the ancestral homeland of the Salish. On the bus ride down before the first game, Pitts asked the players if they wanted to make a statement about the suicide. The boys thought it was a good idea and settled on a video as the way to do it. They decided that Phil would speak first and Will last, but when the camera rolled, Phil got nervous. One player didn\u2019t: Greg. His voice was calm and resolute. \u201cI was focused on helping these people,\u201d he later said. \u201cIt felt awesome.\u201d", "title": "What the Arlee Warriors Were Playing For", "authors": ["Abe Streep"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 \u201cABOU Ben Adhem\u201d is the Anglicized name of one of the most prominent early Sufi mystic saints, Ibrahim ibn Adham, who was the subject of a poem by the English poet Leigh Hunt. The entry, clued as \u201c\u2018___ Ben Adhem\u2019 (Leigh Hunt poem),\u201d was in the Tuesday, April 3, crossword puzzle and stumped many solvers.\n\nPublished in 1836 as part of a three-volume collection called \u201cThe Book of Gems: The Poets and Artists of Great Britain,\u201d the poem describes Ben Adhem waking from a sound sleep, only to see an angel inscribing the names of those who love God in a golden book.\n\nWhen he finds out that his name is not among those, he asks the angel to write his name down as one who loves his fellow man. Ben Adhem\u2019s name appears the next night at the top of the list, implying that those who love their fellow man also love God.\n\nWays It Might Be Clued", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: ABOU", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSPECIAL POST \u2014 BABAS, short for the singular \u201cbaba au rhum,\u201d are rich, rum-flavored cakes that are largely popular in France and Italy. The entry appeared in the Thursday crossword clued as \u201cRum cakes,\u201d and has been seen in only 32 other New York Times puzzles to date.\n\nThe baba originated in France, and was supposedly inspired by the Polish king Stanislaw I, whose daughter, Marie, married King Louis XV. It is said that Stanislaw was partial to the Alsatian Gugelhupf cake, though he discovered that the dry dough tasted better when dipped in liquor. The Parisian baker Nicolas Stohrer went on to popularize this combination, and one of his descendants eventually established rum as the alcohol of choice. Stohrer\u2019s patisserie is still around today.\n\nBabas have continued to be a staple of French baking, and the success of the cake has carried over to Italy and the United States. Babas are now often made with raisins in their dough, and they usually resemble Bundt cakes or doughnuts in shape. Variations may use sweet wine or liqueur in place of rum.\n\nWant to heat up dessert time? Try this flaming recipe from our friends at Cooking. Melissa Clark walks you through it.\n\nVideo\n\nWays It Might Be Clued", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: BABAS", "authors": ["Sam Ezersky"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSPECIAL POST \u2014 The Greek mythological character Niobe was the subject of a tough clue from the March 28 crossword puzzle by Peter Gordon: \u201c\u2018Like ___, all tears\u2019: Hamlet.\u201d\n\nNiobe is most closely associated with tears, which was acknowledged in William Shakespeare\u2019s play, \u201cHamlet,\u201d in Act I, Scene 2:\n\n\u201cA little month, or ere those shoes were old\n\nWith which she followed my poor father\u2019s body,\n\nLike Niobe, all tears. Why she, even she \u2014\n\nO God, a beast that wants discourse of reason\n\nWould have mourned longer! \u2014 married with my uncle \u2026\u201d\n\nIt was arrogance that was Niobe\u2019s undoing, and the cause of her tears.\n\nThe tragic story of Niobe\u2019s tears began at a ceremony held to honor the Titan Leto, mother of the divine twins Apollo and Artemis. In a fit of arrogance, Niobe bragged that she was superior to Leto because she bore either 12 or 14 children (the number varies in different versions of the myth), compared with Leto\u2019s two.\n\nWhen the twins heard this, they came to Earth and killed all of Niobe\u2019s children. In deep anguish, she ran to Mount Sipylus to beg the gods to put an end to her pain. Zeus felt sorry for her and turned her into a rock, so she would not feel anymore.\n\nHowever, even as a rock, Niobe\u2019s tears continued to flow, and the stream that pours from the real Weeping Rock in Manisa, Turkey, symbolizes a mother\u2019s eternal mourning.\n\nHow It Might be Clued\n\nNIOBE has appeared in The New York Times Crossword 139 times.\n\nEarly week: \u201cWeeper of myth,\u201d \u201cMythical weeper,\u201d \u201cWeeper of Greek myth\u201d\n\nMid-to-late week: \u201c\u2018Like ___, all tears\u2019: Hamlet,\u201d \u201cBoastful mother of Greek myth,\u201d \u201cDaughter of Tantalus,\u201d \u201cZeus turned her to stone,\u201d \u201cAnalogue of Lot\u2019s wife in Greek mythology,\u201d \u201cPetrified weeper of myth,\u201d \u201cWeeper of Thebes,\u201d \u201cWhom Turkey\u2019s Weeping Rock is said to represent\u201d", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: NIOBE", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 It\u2019s not often that a wild animal trips up New York Times crossword solvers to such an extent, but the ONAGER was the most-revealed answer in last Thursday\u2019s puzzle.\n\nThe Persian onager (Equus hemonius) is one of four subspecies of the Asiatic wild ass and is native to the desert of Iran. It has a pale, sand-colored coat and a short mane that stands straight up.\n\nFun fact: The medieval weapon known as the mangonel received its nickname \u201conager catapult\u201d because the sling fires in a way that is reminiscent of the intense kick of the wild ass.\n\nONAGER has appeared in The New York Times Crossword a total of 69 times. Before Will Shortz was named editor of the crossword in 1993, the entry was clued as both the wild ass and the catapult. More recently, the entry has exclusively been clued as the animal.", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: ONAGER", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 To pronounce the entry that stumped many solvers in last Wednesday\u2019s puzzle correctly, you need to know that Utne rhymes with \u201cchutney.\u201d It also helps to know that, when translated from Norwegian, it means \u201cfar out,\u201d an apt descriptor for a magazine whose masthead includes the phrase \u201cCure Ignorance.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nCreated by Eric Utne in 1984 as a way to \u201cbring people what I thought was the best that was out there,\u201d the Utne Reader started life as a 12-page newsletter that summarized articles in other publications.\n\nThese days, according to its website, Utne is \u201ca digest of the new ideas and fresh perspectives percolating in arts, culture, politics, and spirituality. A combination of original writing and reprints gleaned from books, journals, and the independent media at large, Utne is published quarterly in print and through monthly digital issues.\u201d\n\nIn a 2011 interview with MPR News, Mr. Utne replied that \u201cthe thing that surprised me the most is that The New York Times crossword puzzle has used the name 38 times in the last 16 years as an answer to their various clues. \u2018Independent publication.\u2019 That\u2019s enough for people to know it\u2019s the Utne Reader, which I\u2019m very proud about that.\u201d", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: UTNE", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cA lot of people take photos and post them on Twitter or Facebook,\u201d Ms. Li said. \u201cIt\u2019s evidence that \u2018I\u2019ve been there.\u2019 \u201d\n\nA post shared by Beyonc\u00e9 (@beyonce) on Oct 11, 2014 at 5:28am PDT\n\nIn October 2014, the American megastars Jay-Z and Beyonc\u00e9, and their daughter Blue Ivy, had the privilege of visiting the Louvre on their own. The resulting smartphone photo session drew huge attention on Instagram, prompting Buzzfeed to declare: \u201cNo Picture Matters More Than Beyonc\u00e9 And Jay-Z Posing In Front Of The Mona Lisa,\u201d and adding, \u201cIt might very well be the best picture of our generation. Or any generation.\u201d\n\nIt would be easy enough for a critic or curator to dismiss the \u201cMona Lisa experience\u201d as nothing more than selfie tourism. Yet Jay-Z and Beyonc\u00e9, like pretty much everyone who visits the Louvre, did actually look at the painting.\n\nThe way the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d is viewed is, in fact, soberingly representative of the way most art is viewed in today\u2019s saturated, digitally mediated, visual culture. How many more (or fewer) seconds do cellphone-wielding visitors spend looking at individual works at a commercial art fair or exhibition than at the Louvre? How is an artistic reputation made these days, other than through Instagram?\n\n\u201cShe is older than the rocks among which she sits; like the vampire, she has been dead many times, and learned the secrets of the grave,\u201d the British critic Walter Pater wrote in 1873, evoking the timelessness of the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d long before the advent of mass tourism, mobile phones, apps and fragmented attention spans.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Pater\u2019s much-quoted description of \u201cLa Giaconda\u201d (as the painting is also known) is redolent of a culture in which a privileged few would spend hours with masterpieces to try to divine their profoundest meanings.\n\nBut mechanical \u2014 and digital \u2014 reproduction has changed things. Another British critic, John Berger, wrote in his influential 1972 book, \u201cWays of Seeing,\u201d that in an age of digital reproduction, \u201cthe meaning of paintings is no longer attached to them; their meaning becomes transmittable.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Berger, who died last year, might have noted with interest that Beyonc\u00e9\u2019s 2014 Instagram post of her making a peace sign in front of the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d attracted almost 840,000 likes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSimilarly, a wealthy art collector does not need to spend hours in front of a Christopher Wool, Rudolf Stingel or Gerhard Richter abstract freshly purchased for a few million dollars. The collector knows exactly what it looks like, having already seen the image many times in digital reproduction.\n\nWhile the instantly recognizable quality of brand-name contemporary art reassures collectors \u2014 and by extension bolsters the pieces\u2019 value \u2014 other works can be diminished by their reproducibility. The \u201cMona Lisa\u201d is a prime example.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very underwhelming. It\u2019s small and dark,\u201d Katie Qian, 33, an engineer from Salt Lake City, said after seeing the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d for the second time in her life.\n\nChristie\u2019s, by contrast, offered viewers a quasi-religious experience at the pre-auction viewing of the much-restored panel painting \u201cSalvator Mundi,\u201d which had recently, not incontrovertibly, been re-attributed to Leonardo. The auction house, with the help of the advertising agency Droga5, promoted what it called \u201cThe Last da Vinci\u201d with a video of people moved to tears by the painting. It went on to sell for an all-time high of $450.3 million.\n\n\u201cThe bogus religiosity which now surrounds original works of art,\u201d Mr. Berger wrote in \u201cWays of Seeing,\u201d \u201cis ultimately dependent on their market value\u201d and \u201chas become the substitute for what paintings lost when the camera made them reproducible.\u201d\n\nBack at the Louvre, the millions of visitors who trudge through the Grand Gallery every year on their way to the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d tend to walk straight past \u201cThe Virgin of the Rocks,\u201d a fully documented Leonardo masterpiece from the early 1480s. Then again, perhaps not many tourists are aware that it is a painting that, in the unlikely event of it ever appearing on the market, would also sell for hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\n\u201cAt least millions of people want to see it,\u201d said Dulce Leite, 63, an Italian who seemed amazed by the throng in front of the \u201cMona Lisa.\u201d She had spent the previous 15 minutes contemplating a crowd-free \u201cVirgin of the Rocks\u201d (without taking any photos).\n\n\u201cNow they look at the picture and there\u2019s the possibility of taking a photo and posting it,\u201d she added. \u201cWe had to see it and memorize.\u201d\n\nImprisoned by its reputation as the most famous painting in the world, and by its security capsule, the \u201cMona Lisa\u201d has, to all meaningful intents and purposes, ceased to exist as an original work of art. It has become an idea \u2014 and a photo opportunity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat could be a more contemporary way of seeing?", "title": "What the Mona Lisa Tells Us About Art in the Instagram Era", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Over the past week, horrified Indians have protested vigorously on social media and in some cities. The disgust and the fury at the complicity of politicians, and the federal government\u2019s silence, grew into a thunderous chorus demanding that the prime minister speak up and fire the ministers backing the Hindu Ekta Manch.\n\nBelatedly reacting to popular outrage, Mr. Modi finally said: \u201cIncidents being discussed since past two days cannot be part of a civilized society. As a country, as a society, we all are ashamed of it.\u201d He promised justice. His vague statement delicately alluded to another case in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, where a lawmaker from Mr. Modi\u2019s party is accused of rape. Mr. Modi stayed away from his party\u2019s involvement in both cases.\n\nYet instead of uniting India in horror, the incident has deepened religious, political and ethical divides. It has also made clear that there is no automatic political cost to crime or falsehood if it furthers the hegemonic political narrative. The politicians involved were sacked only after a huge public outcry. Government ministers, officials, right-leaning media and right-wing supporters have been perfectly sanguine about using the dead child to polarize society with whataboutery, fake news and wild conspiracy theories.\n\nA spokeswoman for Mr. Modi\u2019s party, Meenakshi Lekhi, attacked opposition protests, suggesting that they were selective and opportunistic. \u201cYou see their plan,\u201d she said. \u201cFirst shout \u2018minority minority\u2019, then \u2018Dalit Dalit\u2019 and now \u2018women women\u2019 and then try to somehow fix blame of state issues on the center.\u201d An influential ex-editor tweeted that Muslim Rohingya refugees were to blame for the crime. A B.J.P. youth activist posted a comment, now deleted, on his Facebook page saying that the rape must have been fun. A pornography site reported a surge in searches for videos using the raped and murdered girl\u2019s name.\n\nThe sense of national crisis today is because Indians feel a rising urgency to either counter this ethical collapse or to capitalize on it in the run-up to the next election.\n\nMr. Modi came to power in 2014, and four years into his term, religious and cultural bigotry stands mainstreamed in Indian society.\n\nMany who voted for Mr. Modi\u2019s economic promises are disappointed by his failure to deliver, and impatient with his deliberate silences around sectarian and sexual violence and hate speech by his party colleagues and ministers. The systematic destruction of democratic institutions is hard to ignore.\n\nThe B.J.P. and its Hindu nationalist affiliates are bent on refashioning India into a country that is increasingly hostile to secular, democratic, pluralist and minority Indians. The rape and murder of the little nomad girl has thus taken on a larger meaning, reflecting the struggle for the fundamental character of India.", "title": "Opinion | What the Rape and Murder of a Child Reveals About Modi\u2019s India", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Unfortunately, the court\u2019s conservative majority has severely weakened the protections the law was intended to provide. The biggest blow came in a 2013 decision, Shelby County v. Holder. In that case, the five conservative justices, led by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., gutted the heart of the act, which identified several states with long histories of voting discrimination, most in the South, and required them to get federal permission before changing their voting laws. While that remedy may have been a necessary response to 1960s-era racism, the chief justice wrote, \u201cthings have changed dramatically.\u201d\n\nIn one sense, he was right: Racial discrimination in voting is no longer as blatant or systemic as it was in 1965. But the idea that the American fixation on race and power had magically evaporated in just a few decades was, at best, strikingly na\u00efve. It was also disproved within hours of the court\u2019s ruling, when Republican lawmakers in Texas and North Carolina, both states that had been covered by the Voting Rights Act, rammed through discriminatory new voting laws that they had been gunning to pass for years, including some that had been blocked under the act.\n\nIf this wasn\u2019t enough evidence that things have not, in fact, changed dramatically, the point was driven home by the election of Donald Trump in 2016, and the resurgence of overt racism and white nationalism that has followed, with no meaningful pushback from the president.\n\nIn the years before Mr. Trump\u2019s election and in the time since, Republican lawmakers around the country aggressively pushed through laws to make voting harder for certain groups, particularly minorities. Poll taxes and literacy tests have given way to voter-ID laws, cutbacks to early voting and same-day registration, polling place closings, voter-roll purges, racially discriminatory redistricting and felon disenfranchisement laws \u2014 most of which, though justified on race-neutral grounds, harm minority voters more.\n\nThey can also depress turnout, when voters who are not in fact blocked from voting become discouraged by a state apparatus that exudes hostility toward their attempts to exercise their fundamental right.\n\nAre these laws, passed almost invariably by Republican lawmakers, intentionally racist? Or are they merely taking partisan advantage of the fact that black people today vote overwhelmingly for Democrats? It shouldn\u2019t matter. Either way, black voters are targeted, their right to vote hampered.\n\nIn the past couple of years, lower federal courts \u2014 notably in Texas, Wisconsin and North Carolina, home to some of the worst voting laws in the country \u2014 have begun to recognize this. They have become more skeptical of lawmakers\u2019 rationales for passing voting restrictions and have zeroed in on the real impact of such laws on minorities and other vulnerable groups. In striking down a remarkably harsh North Carolina law in 2016, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit found that lawmakers had targeted black voters \u201cwith almost surgical precision.\u201d\n\nThis is an important step toward a robust judicial defense of voting rights. Now Congress must repair the damage the Supreme Court inflicted on the Voting Rights Act. The most important fix is to restore and strengthen the federal government\u2019s oversight of states and localities that continue to discriminate in voting. This would stop bad laws before they could take effect. It would also eliminate the years of delays that are part of most election-related litigation.", "title": "Opinion | What the Supreme Court Doesn\u2019t Get About Racism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "At the same time, the company expected significant overall revenue decline from 2016 to 2017. It closed the print edition of Teen Vogue; reduced the print frequency of GQ, Architectural Digest and Glamour; and cut employees across the company. After that crusade of downsizing \u2014 and the turnover of big-spending old-guard editors in chief like Vanity Fair\u2019s former editor Graydon Carter \u2014 there are now rumors of the impending departure of Anna Wintour, the company\u2019s artistic director and the editor of Vogue. \u201cWe emphatically deny these rumors,\u201d a spokesman told Page Six this week. She has unexpectedly become the avatar of a right-sized, moderately thrifty Cond\u00e9 Nast.\n\nAnd, rightly or not, Cond\u00e9 Nast is finally looking to digital. In recent years, it has launched additional online verticals; introduced a platform for gay, lesbian and transgender issues called \u201cthem\u201d; and embraced digitally focused leaders like Samantha Barry, the new editor in chief of Glamour, and Phillip Picardi, the chief content officer of Teen Vogue.\n\nPerhaps not surprisingly, a significant portion of the company\u2019s advertising solicitation is now devoted to video.\n\nThe idea that video will be a financial savior in the media business is contentious, and often mocked. It is expensive to create, and audiences aren\u2019t equivalent \u2014 yet \u2014 to print or even web in their ability to be monetized. (In human terms: One person watching a video is not financially equivalent to what one person paying for a magazine has been worth.)", "title": "What the \u2018Pivot to Video\u2019 Looks Like at Cond\u00e9 Nast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I think maybe you ought to make enchiladas tonight. I like enchiladas con carne (above), but you might prefer chicken enchiladas instead, or these meatless chili ones. Note that you don\u2019t have to go the roll-\u2019em-up route. Lately I\u2019ve taken to making the dish in a square cake pan, stacking the tortillas in the four corners with lots of overlap, as if I were making lasagna, with sauce and cheese between each layer. Serve with pineapple salsa and crema.\n\nNot for you? Not right now? Try this on for size: Quick-steamed asparagus on toasted, buttered bread, topped with a fried egg, some grated Parmesan, a few cranks of ground black pepper. You\u2019re welcome.\n\nOr you could roast a chicken. There are a gajillion recipes on NYT Cooking, but this morning I want to point you toward the New York chef Jonathan Waxman\u2019s version because it isn\u2019t really so much a recipe for roast chicken as a recipe for the chunky, delicious salsa verde that goes on top. And you could put that sauce on anything. You could make Waxman\u2019s salsa verde and serve it on an orthotic shoe insert and receive compliments. Imagine what it tastes like on top of a perfectly roasted bird. In any event, cook a chicken this week, please!\n\nAlso make: Chinese chili, a confection of Florence Fabricant\u2019s that really genius and utterly addictive. And maybe pasta with kale, shiitakes and sausage, before the weather turns too warm for such midweek heft.", "title": "What to Cook Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. It\u2019s an uncertain, difficult world we live in, sometimes hard to explain, and all the more so when you look around and it\u2019s as if everyone\u2019s mad at you, all the time, even when they say they\u2019re not. Here\u2019s some nickel advice: Take a good long walk after you read The Times in the morning, however you read it, and then cook dinner at the end of the day, even if it\u2019s just ramen from Sevs with a poached egg, scallions and a dusting of sesame seeds. Be active. Take care. That\u2019s the ticket to ride.\n\nDavid Tanis cooks like that, I think: very much in the moment, at peace. I love his new recipe for asparagus frittata (above), which he pairs with creamy burrata and an herb-laden pesto. It tastes to me of spring in the sort of place we all want to reside, where everything\u2019s delicious, everyone copacetic, where you\u2019re not going to run out of time. (Can\u2019t find burrata? Try the super-freshest mozzarella you can find, soft if not runny, and shred it into the center of the serving plate.) Try that on for size this evening, why don\u2019t you?\n\nI\u2019m perennially stoked for salmon burgers, especially now that the weather\u2019s warming and I can cook them outside on a grill. But they\u2019re pretty great griddled in a pan if you\u2019re bound to the kitchen, especially with a good swipe of Julia Moskin\u2019s lemon-garlic mayonnaise to help keep everything moist.\n\nAlso for beef and broccoli, which offers me time spent at the wok, refining my stir-fry technique, no different from practicing scales on the uke or drop shots on a drafty squash court \u2014 except more delicious.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur erstwhile colleague Marian Burros was in the office the other day, greeting old friends and doling out advice and wisdom, and it got me thinking about her terrific recipe for rosemary pork tenderloin, which she makes on a stovetop grill. I think it\u2019d be even better on an outdoor one, if you can swing that. But it\u2019d be pretty great, too, cooked under the broiler. Look lively, though, however you cook it. Pork tenderloin\u2019s easy to overcook.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Cooking Newsletter Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. It\u2019s full-on spring in New York at last, and there is some delicious writing about restaurants in the analog version of The Times that we delivered to our subscribers\u2019 front doors this morning. Pete Wells\u2019s accounting of the food, service and pleasures of Noma in Copenhagen leads the Food section, and Priya Krishna runs at his side, examining the success of a Hawaiian restaurant group in Utah, of all places. The combination \u2014 soft air, exciting news from away \u2014 has left a lot of us here in the shop itching to travel, same as when Mr. Mallard flies off to explore the rest of the river in \u201cMake Way for Ducklings.\u201d There\u2019s cool stuff out there.\n\nTravel often yields fruit for NYT Cooking. Kim Severson went to India last year with the chef Asha Gomez and came back with an amazing recipe for Kerala roadside chicken (above). Julia Moskin went to South Africa and returned with a super recipe for braai-spiced T-bone steaks. I learned how to make the best margarita ever on the porch of a beautiful home in the King William neighborhood of San Antonio, when I was in town to, among other things, learn how to make cabrito. Tejal Rao went to New Orleans and picked up a great recipe for grilled oysters with hot-sauce butter; it served as the ending of this marvelous love story she wrote. We really have the best jobs in the world.\n\nBut maybe you\u2019re not going to barbecue goat this evening, or chase down fresh curry leaves or Kashmiri chiles, or open oysters, or grill big steaks. Maybe you\u2019d just like a quick and elegant dinner of chicken in mustard sauce, with rice and roasted asparagus instead.\n\nPerhaps you don\u2019t want a recipe at all, but a kind of narrative prompt, a description of a meal, something to modify according to your larder and your inclinations. Like, for instance, you could roast sweet potatoes and serve them split open with sour cream and lashings of harissa, a little sprinkled mint. Those would be delicious on their own, but you could also serve them as a side dish for simply broiled lamb chops, the meat showered in salt and pepper, then blasted in the oven until crisp-skinned and rosy-hued within.", "title": "What to Cook Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. The oven stopped working the other day and in the morning I tore the stove apart to figure out why: a burned-out ignitor, $21.16 from the shop on the internet, delivery expected tomorrow. It should take about 20 minutes to install and put everything back together if Mr. Murphy doesn\u2019t poke his head into the proceedings and set me on fire. Meantime, there\u2019s been a toaster oven and rusting patio grill to explore.\n\nSo maybe you could join me for some grilled soy-basted chicken thighs with spicy cashews (above)? You can make the dish with peanuts if the cashews seem too expensive. And then serve the meat on top of a big salad of something sturdy and green and crisp. That\u2019s a really delicious meal.\n\nOr maybe don\u2019t cook over heat at all. Follow Gabrielle Hamilton\u2019s instructions for how to make steak tartare and you\u2019ll end up with a crazily delicious open-faced dinner on thick pumpernickel bread, and life will be good. But understand something: You have to follow the recipe exactly if you really want to thrill to its excellence. Gabrielle\u2019s recipes are not wide-ranging guidelines. They are Sondheim lyrics. You can\u2019t just go off book and improvise.\n\nOf course, you probably have a working stove. You could make this spring ramen bowl with snap peas and asparagus instead. Or Alison Roman\u2019s delightful version of chicken and dumplings.", "title": "What to Cook Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Cook anyway. Cook precisely because it is the start of the week and you\u2019re not up for it and even if it\u2019s just tuna salad sandwiches and a glass of milk the preparation will make it easier tomorrow to make a sheet-pan dinner or pot of soup.\n\nMore than that, cook because it will make someone feel better if you do, not least yourself. There are times when takeout or delivery is the best thing in the world to eat, times when a packaged and frozen prepared food is not just a lifesaver but a treat. This Monday night in April is not one of them. Monday nights are when you set the tone. Cooking on Monday night is how you win the week.\n\nThere are thousands and thousands of recipes to get you started on NYT Cooking. (Check out this marvelous lemon-ginger tart!) Please sign up for a subscription so you can access them, save them, share them, cook them, rate them and leave notes on them about what emendations you\u2019ve made, or substitutions you\u2019ve attempted, for good or for ill.\n\nThough if something goes really wrong, either with a recipe or with the technology, please reach out to us for aid: cookingcare@nytimes.com. We\u2019re happy to help. I answer as many as I can.)\n\nNow, I know it\u2019s some distance from immersion blenders and the best instant-read meat thermometer, but do take some time to read the BBC\u2019s investigation into a corrupt Baltimore police squad, \u201cWhen Cops Become Robbers.\u201d", "title": "What to Cook Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. This is your conscience writing. Today is the day to clean your oven, perhaps for the first time since before Thanksgiving, to scrub the stovetop, to empty the fridge and wipe it down. You might clean your cutting boards, too, get at the edges of your sheet pans with a scouring pad and some Bar Keepers Friend. You could sharpen your knives. It is really finally maybe at long last spring. Clean into it, so you can cook this week with a heart full of joy.\n\nOr, you know, don\u2019t. You\u2019ll get to it eventually, when the bugs come or your parents arrive, when someone interesting or attractive you met at the fly shop in Roscoe or the bakery in Santa Monica is due for dinner, and everything\u2019s sticky. Then you\u2019ll clean. You\u2019ll clean for someone sometime, if not for me.\n\nIn the meantime, read Ligaya Mishan on how kiwi changed New York\u2019s food scene back in the early 1980s, in T Magazine. She writes so well.\n\nNow, what\u2019s for dinner tonight? I\u2019m thinking a doubleheader of new recipes. I\u2019m sorry to say this will be my last newsletter. I\u2019ve renounced home cooking and intend to eat only what I can have delivered to my garret. I just can\u2019t anymore with the pots and the pans and the steam and the heat and the endless shopping and cooking and cleaning up afterward, the relentless good humor and every day more new recipes to test and to champion, to discover, to cheer.\n\nApril Fools! Most days, this is the best job in the universe, and every day I love it the way Claire Foy\u2019s Queen Elizabeth loves the crown \u2014 deeply even when it\u2019s difficult and the lifestyle strange.\n\nSo, shall we consider the week to come? For some, today will be spent in the presence of a ham. (Here\u2019s how to cook it.) Others will eat lamb. If you\u2019re not one of them and are lost for a Sunday supper idea, try this recipe for grilled tofu with chipotle barbecue sauce or this one for pan-roasted pork chops with apple fritters. Good eating either way.\n\nMonday night, if you\u2019re that guy, you could take a run through our collection of recipes for leftover ham. (Try David Tanis\u2019s recipe for leek and potato souffl\u00e9 with ham and Gruy\u00e8re!) But if you don\u2019t have leftover ham, Alison Roman\u2019s recipe for vegetarian tortilla soup (above) is a fine start-of-week feed.", "title": "What to Cook This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I wrote about beef and broccoli for The Times this week, that great Chinese-restaurant menu war horse. And, thanks to the chef Jonathan Wu, with an assist from the chef Dale Talde, I managed to put together a beef and broccoli recipe (above) that I think could become a regular part of your weeknight dinner rotation. It is ridiculously good.\n\nThe recipe calls for chuck beef, though you could make it with rib steak or brisket if you had any to hand. You could make it with venison. Up in Shishmaref, Alaska, you might make it with caribou or musk ox. Firm tofu is an excellent substitute for beef, as are chunks of boneless, skinless chicken thigh. You could even boil some small potatoes in water, rice wine and a little soy sauce, dry them off and smash them lightly before tossing them in the wok to crisp and then take up the sauce and have a delicious meal. Beef and broccoli is enormously adaptable. It is never not good.\n\nGive that a shot tonight or Saturday, so you start dialing in on the recipe. Practice works in cooking same as in golf and on the xylophone. Put your time in now, and you\u2019ll be able to work fast on a Wednesday night.\n\nPassover ends this weekend and, as our colleague Ron Lieber reports, that\u2019s cause for leavened excitement among those who have observed the holiday: pizzas and brownies and bagels after days of avoiding rising foods in a nod to ancestors who had no time to let bread dough rise while fleeing Egypt. Ron\u2019s story is about a delicious ritual for Moroccan Jews that follows Passover\u2019s end, Mimouna, a party in which the centerpiece is moufleta, a pan-cooked cake smeared with butter and honey. Whatever your faith, I think you should give moufleta a try.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Lastly, Samin Nosrat has a fine column up at The Times, about discovering the weeknight joy of using a little store-bought mayonnaise to bring a salad dressing together, and she shares it in this marvelous, easy new recipe for green goddess dressing that she learned from the cookbook author Jessica Battilana.\n\nSamin uses that dressing in an excellent new recipe for what she calls the greenest green salad. It is a very good feed, but I think probably you should not make it with romaine lettuce as Samin suggests, at least until the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention figure out what\u2019s happening with this E. coli outbreak tied to romaine. Don\u2019t freak. Make it with kale instead, or butter lettuce, and you\u2019ll be happy indeed. As Sergeant Esterhaus said, \u201cLet\u2019s be careful out there.\u201d\n\nThousands and thousands more recipes to cook this weekend are waiting for you on NYT Cooking. Just sign up for a subscription so you can access them all. It\u2019s good value: You can search all the recipes, save them to your recipe box, organize them into folders, send them along to family and friends, send yourself grocery lists and leave notes and ratings on the recipes to the benefit of yourself or the rest of us in this growing community of the delicious.\n\nWe are here for you if anything goes wrong along the way, either with a recipe, or with the technology that supports the site and apps.
