Our Tejal Rao spent a bunch of time recently with the pastry chef Natasha Pickowicz, of Caf\u00e9 Altro Paradiso and Flora Bar in New York, cooking leftovers for her \u201cEat\u201d column in The Times. Pickowicz is known for her glamorous fruit crostatas and pastries, but Tejal learned she also takes savory scraps and ends of this or that to make tarts to serve as a late breakfast, not to her customers but to the staff of the kitchens she runs.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really satisfying to find a purpose for all these things,\u201d she told Tejal, before explaining how she thinks about the bits and pieces she finds in the restaurants\u2019 walk-in refrigerators \u2014 how they\u2019ll cook on and in her pie dough and how she\u2019ll use the ingredients to build layers into every tart: mashed potatoes; grilled cauliflower; drapes of sliced ham.\n\nTejal thought about that, too, and now her Pickowicz-inspired recipe for a potato-and-radicchio tart (above) is absolutely on the docket for cooking this weekend, though I\u2019ll probably make a double batch of the pastry so that later in the week I can try Pickowicz\u2019s version with smudged mascarpone with braised leeks and lemon zest. I could probably eat one of both of those tarts every day for a month.\n\nAnyway, have a nice Saturday breakfast. Head to the market afterward, get some rhubarb, figure out what to do with it.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. Not long ago, we challenged our pal Alison Roman to come up with some definitive recipes for mac and cheese. We wanted a baseline understanding of the dish as a baked side dish for barbecues and cookouts, and as a midweek stovetop meal (above), the sort some ordinarily make out of a box. And, jeepers, did she deliver, with our latest laser-focus digital cookbook, \u201cHow to Make Mac and Cheese.\u201d\n\nWhat you think of mac and cheese, and which version of it you prefer, has largely to do with where you\u2019re from, Kathleen Purvis wrote last year in an essay about the dish\u2019s racial divide, what one meme called \u201cBecky\u2019s Mac & Cheese vs. Your Mama\u2019s Mac & Cheese.\u201d Alison\u2019s guide makes it possible to cook versions of the dish better than you ever have in the past, and her slick stovetop recipe in particular could lead a person to forever give up the Annie\u2019s and the Kraft.\n\nWe\u2019ll see, and I\u2019ll definitely make mac and cheese this weekend. Maybe Julia Moskin\u2019s recipe for crusty macaroni and cheese? That would go great with ribs, I think, if the weather report holds and I can fire up the grill tomorrow. Or if it doesn\u2019t: perhaps my own recipe for lobster mac and cheese? That is kind of a feast in itself.\n\nSpring is finally making itself known in New York. I\u2019d like to make some roasted asparagus with a crunchy Parmesan topping this weekend, or some charred asparagus with green garlic chimichurri. That last would be delicious alongside barbecued chicken, or to accompany grilled sausages with onions and peppers.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cAmericans Still Packing On the Pounds\u201d (news article, March 26):\n\nWe don\u2019t need more data; we need a government that values the health of its constituency. It doesn\u2019t take data to see the effects on American bodies of 50 years of hormones, pesticides, fungicides and genetically modified crops.\n\nHumans evolved along with the foods we consume; when we ingest altered substances, our biology cannot recognize the nutrients. We grow fat and sick. More data is an excuse to do nothing but keep feeding us corporately sponsored disease.\n\nRACHEL HOFFMAN, PORTLAND, ORE.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhat stops Americans from eating a healthier diet? Certainly not ignorance. Americans are bombarded with information about nutrition. But research shows that the more we sell the benefits of healthy eating, the more people prefer to eat unhealthy food. Why?\n\nTalking about food in terms of vitamins, minerals, fiber, antioxidants and the like \u2014 \u201cmedicalizing\u201d the meal \u2014 strips food of its enjoyment. It\u2019s time to start selling healthy food as tasty, so that the healthy choice becomes the pleasurable choice. Our national obsession with nutrition is getting in the way. The French would agree.", "title": "Opinion | What to Do About Americans\u2019 Weight Gain?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI am a young professional working for a nonprofit. I\u2019ve been in the same workplace for a couple of years, and there are many things I love about it. A few months ago, however, I got a new supervisor. I\u2019ve always been receptive to constructive criticism (and have received positive performance reviews). But this supervisor never gave me positive feedback, took credit for projects I\u2019d taken the lead on, and intensely micromanaged me \u2014 even leaning over my shoulder and criticizing how I format a spreadsheet. When I tried talking to him about my concerns, he suggested I quit. The stress being too much to bear, I elected to move to another job in the same organization. While the pay was lower, it would allow me to take some classes to beef up my r\u00e9sum\u00e9 \u2014 an ideal situation for me right now. Here\u2019s the problem. Initially, I agreed to help with minor tasks from my old department while it searched for my replacement. But it doesn\u2019t appear as though my old supervisor is actively searching. I am still under as much stress as I was working for him full time, but now I\u2019m getting less pay. How do I set boundaries and encourage management to hire a replacement without jeopardizing my new position, which accommodates my education schedule so well? ROSE\n\nWith hindsight, you have probably realized that it was a mistake to make such an open-ended offer. It would have been generous enough to suggest helping out with certain tasks for a specified period of time. That would have given your old supervisor \u2014 who doesn\u2019t seem to have done you any favors \u2014 a clearer incentive to replace you promptly.\n\nTo give him one now, proceed on two tracks. First, communicate what\u2019s going on to your current supervisor. Don\u2019t make it a huge complaint, just be matter-of-fact. You thoughtfully offered to help your old department through a transitional period for the good of the organization \u2014 but you can\u2019t keep doing two jobs forever, and you want to focus on doing the best you can in your new role. Your new manager needs to know that this is happening \u2014 and, frankly, should immediately step in to handle the matter without further discussion.\n\nBut second, you can simultaneously set some boundaries yourself. The next time your old boss asks you to do something, tell him that while you were happy to help during the department\u2019s transition, you must now give your new job your full attention.\n\nYou could make that effective immediately, or set some concrete deadline in the near future, but your best bet might be to suggest: \u201cI\u2019ll do this one last thing for you.\u201d", "title": "What to Do When Your Old Boss Won\u2019t Let Go", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Could you please review best practices if one\u2019s email is hacked? Is changing the password for that email sufficient? Is it necessary to change the email address (use a whole new email) for each site, like Amazon, that uses the hacked email as the user login?\n\nA. If you still have access to the compromised account, changing the password is one of many steps you should take to protect yourself. If you are having trouble regaining control of the account, visit your mail provider\u2019s site for instructions on recovering your account. Apple, Google, Microsoft and Yahoo all have guides on their sites, as should other email and internet service providers. Tell your friends that your account was hacked and to ignore any odd messages that appear to have come from you.\n\nYour account may have been hacked through malicious software, so scan your computer for malware and viruses with a security program. If you do not have security software installed, you can use Microsoft\u2019s built-in Windows Defender or Microsoft Security Essentials. Avast and AVG are among the many companies that make free basic antivirus software for Windows and Mac. Malwarebytes has free and trial versions of its malware-scanning program for Windows and Mac that can work alongside antivirus software. You should also update your computer and devices with the latest security updates.", "title": "What to Do if Your Email Is Hacked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "GOLD COAST, Australia \u2014 Australia has an affinity for nicknames, and Gold Coast \u2014 the country\u2019s sixth-largest city \u2014 has many of them. In fact, \u201cthe gold coast\u201d was once a nickname for the stretch of beach enclaves along Queensland\u2019s southernmost coastline. It wasn\u2019t until the 1950s that the name became official, and the area became a city. These days, people sometimes call it the Glitter Strip.\n\nWhat glitters? The beaches. The aquamarine water. The shiny high-rise condos and hotels that continue to proliferate at an incredible rate.\n\n[READ MORE: At the Commonwealth Games, Competing for Medals and Relevance]\n\nWhen the Commonwealth Games start on Wednesday, they will bring massive crowds, but the Gold Coast is built for visitors. Tourism is the region\u2019s biggest industry, and the city\u2019s infrastructure, from its easy-to-access international airport to its convenient light rail system, caters to that industry. There is no shortage of bland but familiar luxury. If you dig a little, though, there is a lot more to the city than its glittery facade.", "title": "What to Do in Australia\u2019s Gold Coast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "After they leave their buildings, participants will gather to observe 13 seconds of silence that are meant to honor the 13 victims in the Columbine shooting.\n\nFollowing that, further activities are up to the leaders of each school\u2019s individual protest. National organizers have called for daylong activism. In a planning guide on the National School Walkout\u2019s website, organizers encourage participants to hold marches, participate in voter-registration drives and set up speeches.\n\nWho is organizing it?\n\nThe idea for the National School Walkout came from Lane Murdock, a high school sophomore from Ridgefield, Conn., about 20 miles from Newtown, the site of the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012.\n\nIn the Change.org petition that Ms. Murdock started, she cited the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., in February as a catalyst for the event.\n\n\u201cIt is time for teenagers to speak their minds and put their frustration into action,\u201d she wrote.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Murdock has been working with a team of other students at her high school to coordinate the national protest. Individual walkouts at schools are being organized and staged by local students.\n\nWhat are their goals?\n\nThe walkout\u2019s website says the event has three goals: to \u201chold elected officials accountable,\u201d to advocate \u201csolutions to gun violence\u201d and to encourage students to be more engaged in politics.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore specifically, the event seeks to push Congress to pass legislation to halt gun violence. Among the specific requests are bills to strengthen the background check process for gun purchases; a ban on bump stock attachments, which allow semiautomatic guns to fire like automatic weapons; and raising the minimum age to purchase assault-style weapons to 21.\n\nOrganizers are also encouraging participants to pressure state and local governments to enact similar laws. They are also seeking to increase voter registration among younger Americans in the hopes of electing candidates who support gun control.\n\nDidn\u2019t we just have a walkout?\n\nOn March 14, one month after 17 people were killed in the Parkland shooting, students across the United States stepped out of their classrooms at 10 a.m. to call for stronger gun control laws.\n\nStudents left schools by the hundreds and thousands, sometimes in defiance of school administrators and school boards. In some cities, including New York, participants in the walkout then staged protests or marches.\n\nThe walkouts in March were the first major nationally coordinated action of a student-driven movement for gun control that was sparked by the Parkland shooting. Still, many students did not participate, especially in more conservative and rural parts of the country where gun control is not in wide favor.\n\nTen days later, on March 24, demonstrators gathered in Washington, D.C., for the March for Our Lives rally, as well as at more than 800 protests held around the world to call for action against gun violence.\n\nWhy is this one different?\n\nThe walkout held last month was much briefer, scheduled to last for 17 minutes, one minute to honor each of the Parkland victims. In practice, some students continued to protest for the rest of the day. This walkout on Friday is intended to last an entire school day.\n\nThe National School Walkout also comes as attention to the Parkland shooting has faded somewhat. Despite efforts by the student-driven movement, neither Congress nor the White House has taken significant action on gun control and gun safety measures. Congress did pass a spending bill in March that included measures to provide grants for school safety and to improve reporting to the background check system for gun purchases.\n\nGun regulation advocates have seen victory in Florida, three weeks after the Parkland shooting, Gov. Rick Scott signed a bill with some of the limits that students have been urging. But some have argued the legislation did not go far enough.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn their website, organizers for the National School Walkout wrote that they see their event as part of a larger push to advocate gun control and that the issues they are addressing need \u201cconstant attention if we hope to change anything.\u201d", "title": "What to Expect From the National School Walkout for Gun Safety", "authors": ["Michael Gold"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "With less than 200 days until the midterm elections, Democrats are generally thought to have a slight advantage in the fight for control of the House. That doesn\u2019t mean they are going to prevail. The polls could be wrong, as all should understand by now, and there\u2019s more than enough time for the national political environment to turn in favor of the Republicans. But these four indicators, for now, are consistent with a Democratic edge. Here\u2019s what they are and what they\u2019re telling us.\n\nGeneric Ballot: O.K. for Democrats, Worrying for Republicans\n\nOne of the best measures of the national political environment is the generic congressional ballot, a poll question asking voters whether they intend to support Democrats or Republicans in the next election.\n\nThe final generic ballot numbers typically perform well in approximating the House popular vote. Even this far ahead of an election, the generic ballot can do a decent job of predicting the final results. And Democrats can reasonably hope for their lead to grow, given the tendency of the measure to break toward the party out of power.\n\nThe Democrats\u2019 lead on the generic ballot is around seven points, one of their weakest leads of the last year. At their peak, in December, Democrats led by 13 points, after the passage of the Republican tax cut bill.", "title": "What to Keep in Mind When Thinking About the Midterms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Copenhagen is a combination of Old World Europe and 21st century modern sensibilities. Both extend deep, beyond the art and architecture to the life and feel of the city. We have tips to help you explore Copenhagen in our local guide. But before you go, pack these essentials to make the most of your trip.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing tips for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so we talked to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, about some of the things you might want specifically for a trip to Copenhagen. Here are her picks.\n\nDon\u2019t Forget Your:\n\nCycling gear. Copenhagen is very bike-friendly, and if you plan to tour Harbor Circle by bike, you may want to bring your own helmet in case your rental place doesn\u2019t offer them. Ms. Misra suggests the sleek Giro Savant, which will take up relatively little space in your luggage. She also suggests Smartwool\u2019s Merino 150 base layers (available in both men\u2019s and women\u2019s sizes) to wick away sweat and protect you from the sun.\n\nProtection from the rain. Curling up in a cozy sweater at one of the city\u2019s many coffee shops sounds snug \u2014 but if that sweater is sopping wet from your bike ride or walk over, that vision of hygge melts quickly. Ms. Misra suggests a packable rain jacket, such as Patagonia\u2019s Torrentshell Jacket, that will layer easily over your clothes. When you\u2019re off the bike, the small yet durable AmazonBasics Automatic Travel umbrella will keep both you and your belongings dry.\n\nSuper stylish carryall. The Fj\u00e4llr\u00e4ven K\u00e5nken Backpack is made of water-resistant fabric (helpful if you do get caught in the rain), it\u2019s sturdy enough to withstand plenty of wear and its simple but streamlined design will blend in neatly in the city streets. Plus, you\u2019ll get more life out of it on future trips.", "title": "What to Pack for a Trip to Copenhagen", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Lisbon has it all: world-class cuisine for the gastronomically inclined, ancient fortresses, art and architecture for the cultured traveler, and a vibrant local bar, music and night life scene for everyone in between. We have tips to help you explore everything Lisbon has to offer in our local guide. Before you go though, pack these essentials to make the most of your trip.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing essentials for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so we talked to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, about some of the things you might want specifically for a trip to Lisbon, and her thoughts on the best products to fill those needs. Here are her picks.\n\nDon\u2019t Forget Your:\n\nA good camera and a travel tripod. With gorgeous hilltop views and sweeping overlooks of both the city and the sea, you\u2019ll want a great camera to capture the scene. The Olympus OM-D EM-10 Mark II delivers crisp, clear images, but also is compact enough that you can comfortably transport it around the city. A travel tripod will help you set up those shots (or just give yourself time to jump in-frame after setting a timer!)\u2014but walking up Lisbon\u2019s hilly terrain will make you glad to shed any unnecessary weight. The MeFoto Roadtrip Travel Tripod packs down comfortably small for easy carrying. Ms. Misra reminded us to secure that camera, too \u2014 especially before a hilly walk. The BlackRapid Sport Breathe was the most comfortable camera strap Wirecutter tested, and also leaves your camera easily accessible for quick snapshots while you walk around town.\n\nA sheddable, lightweight outer layer. With nighttime drinks in Lisbon\u2019s gorgeous rooftop bars and cafes, and afternoon walks by the waterfront, you\u2019ll want a layer that you can slip on easily when the wind off the water kicks up, but that disappears inconspicuously when you head into a local bar for a glass of port and today\u2019s market specials. Outdoor Research\u2019s Tantrum Hooded Jacket packs down tiny, but is easy and comfortable to layer over an outfit when you want to.\n\nA bag for all your souvenirs, and then some. If you pick up some of the cork souvenirs that the city is known for (over a third of the world\u2019s cork forests are in Portugal) along the way, you\u2019ll need a place to hold it \u2014 and Baggu\u2019s Duck Bag is roomy and durable enough to give you a place to stash it (plus a few of your other essentials as you move around the city). This canvas bag has a long strap in addition to its handles, so you can sling it around your shoulder when wandering through museums and shops.\n\nAn ebook reader. If you have one, you probably already take it with you everywhere, but stick with us here. An Amazon Kindle Paperwhite in your tote will keep you entertained through an afternoon coffee break at one of Lisbon\u2019s world-class coffee bars (like F\u00e1brica Coffee Roasters, for example) or just while people watching in the square. Both of those are activities we heartily recommend. Another virtue, though, is that you can also flip through a travel guide as you move around the city, without looking like you\u2019re flipping through a travel guide \u2014 great for the tourist who wants to blend into the crowd. (Don\u2019t forget to protect your Kindle with a cover \u2014 Wirecutter likes this one from Omoton \u2014 before you tuck it into your bag, too.)", "title": "What to Pack for a Trip to Lisbon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Victoria, British Columbia, is awash in the Pacific Northwest\u2019s trademark natural beauty. It\u2019s also home to a blend of First Nations, Chinese, British and uniquely Canadian cultural elements, all of which we teach you to explore in our local guide. Before you go though, pack these essentials to make the most of your trip.\n\nWe\u2019ve shared packing essentials for any 36-hour trip in previous lists, so we asked Suzanne Carmick, our travel columnist who wrote our guide to Victoria, to name a few items she was glad to have on her last visit \u2014 or wished she had packed.\n\nThen we turned to Ria Misra, an editor at Wirecutter, for the best products to fill those needs \u2014 and her expert suggestions for other things to pack to make the most of your trip. Here are their picks.\n\nDon\u2019t Forget Your:", "title": "What to Pack for a Trip to Victoria, British Columbia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "No matter what you think of the work of the American Minimalist Dan Flavin, a pristine exhibition of early efforts titled \u201cin daylight or cool white,\u201d is worth seeing. His signature fluorescent-tube sculptures are rarely as impeccably selected or installed as they are here. The gallery\u2019s spaces seem made for them, meaning that the show illustrates both Minimal art\u2019s utter dependency on but also its glorification of the \u201cwhite cube,\u201d Brian O\u2019Doherty\u2019s well-known term for the unblemished exhibition space that became an increasingly essential framing device for so much art after 1960. Zwirner, which represents the estate of the artist, who was born in 1933 and died in 1996, fully complies with Flavin\u2019s demanding installation protocols: The outlets and cords for these plug-in pieces must be completely invisible.\n\nThe total unity of the space, the sculptures and the light they emit (there is no other lighting in the show) is, as intended, a bit awe-inspiring. The exhibition is also indirectly dispiriting, since probably no American museum can give Flavin\u2019s work the space and care, as here, to make it so convincing to the neophyte.\n\nThe 10 pieces on view date from 1963 to \u201972; as the show\u2019s title implies, all use one or both of the most generic shades General Electric produces: the warmish Daylight and the relatively clinical Cool White. The lack of color underscores how shocking these works once were.\n\nWithout disguising themselves as hardware store items, the tubes argue, in different arrangements, for their effect as art. They also indicate how carefully Flavin used their every aspect \u2014 the fluorescent tubes, their spreading glow and their white enamel base elements (which face outward or in, making the light more mysterious), as well available architecture, especially corners, which three of the works occupy. In \u201cuntitled (to Cy Twombly) 2\u201d of 1972, a tube of Cool White and one of Daylight, cross each other and a corner evoking Russian Constructivism. The show culminates in a gallery that contains three works from a series of \u201cmonuments\u201d dedicated to Vladimir Tatlin, one of the most prominent Constructivists. The display feels at once like a chapel and an Art Deco dance floor. Doing the best with the least so overtly and seductively, Flavin is the most magical and emblematic of the Minimalists. ROBERTA SMITH", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Sara Magenheimer is like a poet who plies her craft in film and video rather than in words, although she makes sculpture and art in other media, too. The results are impressive in \u201cNOON,\u201d her current show at the New Museum.\n\nThe title work is an installation that can be seen through the museum\u2019s front window. It includes video monitors and clothes on racks and breaks the word \u201cnoon\u201d into \u201cno\u201d and \u201con,\u201d or combines it with other words and images of ticking clocks in various locales, prompting you to think about the artificial constructs imposed on time. Inside the museum, a series of videos ruminates further on temporality and sequencing, language and different forms of perception.\n\nOne of the strongest works is \u201cBest Is Man\u2019s Breath Quality\u201d (2017), in which the video\u2019s subject is a box jellyfish. This creature is extremely poisonous, and its sting is so toxic that one survivor described the pain as worse than that of natural childbirth or injuries from a car accident. Both spineless (\u201cas if lacking a spine is weak\u201d) and translucent (\u201cnothing to hide!\u201d), the talking jellyfish persuasively challenges the human-defined hierarchy of species.\n\nOther videos hinge on monologues and dialogues spoken by eerily familiar automated voices that ruminate on punctuation and abstract, philosophical ideas of language. Ms. Magenheimer\u2019s art often feels like Gertrude Stein\u2019s work set to music (in one video, an evocatively pitched-down PJ Harvey song) and juiced up with images, like those of deer captured by surveillance cameras, primates looking into a mirror installed in a forest, or a lone piece of luggage on an airport conveyor belt, accompanied by a voice-over describing loneliness and heartbreak.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "An early example that uses stretchers is \u201cNorth Star\u201d (1968), whose crackling bands of color involve both hard-edge and stain painting and whose rectangular shape is transgressed by numerous notches, as well as by two cutout squares, so that it resembles a large mask. \u201cFor Happiness\u201d (1970) also combines multiple painting techniques; it has 13 ropes that jauntily tilt its surface back and forth in space, challenging understanding of the piece as a whole.\n\nIn contrast to this complexity, \u201cHoo Doo Mandala\u201d and \u201cMandala\u201d (both 1970) are relatively square and frontal, but also gently billowed and scalloped by their anchoring ropes. Their radiant, asymmetrical geometries are reminiscent of everything from semaphore and hot-air balloons to tantric painting and the early Modernist works of the married artists Sonia Delaunay and Robert Delaunay.\n\nIn several works from 1972, Mr. Overstreet switches to an explosive, staccato drip technique, whose intimations of starry skies are regularly contradicted by dividing lines or added segments of canvas, leaving us suspended between deep space and eccentric objects. I look forward to seeing these exuberant, groundbreaking creations becoming standard in museums and new art histories. ROBERTA SMITH\n\nJared Bark\n\nThrough May 12. Yancey Richardson, 525 West 22nd Street, Manhattan; 646-230-9610, yanceyrichardson.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe ready-made, an industrially manufactured object repurposed as art, was popular in the 20th century. But could there be such a thing as ready-made photography? Jared Bark could be said to have found it in his \u201cPhotobooth Pieces\u201d at Yancey Richardson. Mostly created between 1972 and 1975, these arrangements turn the strips of four photographs that were made in booth machines into artful grids.\n\nMr. Bark made his first work of this sort in Times Square in 1969. After that, he traveled around the country, asking people at Woolworth\u2019s drugstores to step inside the machines and pose. (He also acquired his own booth in 1972.) The resulting portrait grids, with their serial repetition of images, contain elements of Minimalism and Pop Art, as well as of the filmic realism of \u201970s auteur directors like Robert Altman.\n\nThe range of humanity on display here is also impressive \u2014 particularly when compared with that of similar projects, like Andy Warhol\u2019s photo booth works \u2014 as people of all ages and ethnicities appear in photos taken in, for instance, Phoenix or Provo, Utah.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn addition to inviting strangers to participate in his work, Mr. Bark often stepped inside the booth himself. Those results are more experimental, composed into abstract diamonds or squares, and with body parts photographed in rapid-fire succession, or a light bulb dangling alone in space.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA feeling of nostalgia and obsolescence pervades these pieces. Photo booths are nearly relics, now that almost everyone\u2019s phone has a camera. But Mr. Bark\u2019s works are like an ancestor of the selfie or the images on social media, with an endless view of photographed humanity scrolling by. MARTHA SCHWENDENER\n\nZoe Pettijohn Schade\n\nThrough May 6. Kai Matsumiya, 153\u00bd Stanton Street, Manhattan; 617-678-4440, kaimatsumiya.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt took Zoe Pettijohn Schade as long as a year and a half to make each of the intricate large gouaches in \u201cShifting Sets,\u201d a show lining the walls of Kai Matsumiya\u2019s tidy Stanton Street gallery. Weirdly timeless meditations on death, they simultaneously evoke cutting-edge Photoshop effects and rococo wallpaper, with tiled and overlapping imagery that includes skulls from the Parisian catacombs; toy army men in marbleized silhouette; and delicate, color-graded pigeon feathers modeled on one blackening example the artist found in her garden.\n\nWhat\u2019s most fascinating, though, isn\u2019t the pieces\u2019 nominal content so much as the seeming evanescence of the labor that went into them: If you lean in close, you can see every semi-opaque brush stroke in every pale gray feather, but from any greater distance, such small evidences of the artist\u2019s time and attention disappear in the overall dazzle.\n\nThe same kind of visual dynamic flickers across the whole of \u201cCrowd of Crowds: 100th Monkey\u201d (2017), which is covered in diagonal rows of grimacing, long-tailed primates. Because some of them are ghostly gray, and others mere silhouettes filled in with more feathers, skulls, or tombstones, it can take minutes of staring to notice just how simple the pattern is. WILL HEINRICH\n\n\u2018Clay Today\u2019\n\nThrough May 6. The Hole, 312 Bowery, Manhattan; 212-466-1100, theholenyc.com.\n\nPhoto\n\nContemporary art has been experiencing a ceramics renaissance for several years now, though its full breadth remains underexplored by galleries and museums. \u201cClay Today,\u201d a new exhibition at the Hole, provides a welcome, if not rigorous, introduction to the utterly creative and clever ways that artists are using this material.\n\nThe exhibition opens with a showstopper near the entrance: Francesca DiMattio\u2019s \u201cBoucherouite IV\u201d (2017), a blue-and-white human-size figure of sorts, whose body is a technical marvel of zigzagging rows of clay fringe. Bulging with appendages, \u201cBoucherouite\u201d incorporates items like a flowered porcelain handle and a Delftware vessel. Traditional ceramics have not been completely abandoned, but rather overtaken by experimentation. This feeling is echoed in Trevor Baird\u2019s vases adorned with panels of comics, and in Rebecca Morgan\u2019s gorgeously goofy face jugs. Allison Schulnik\u2019s \u201cRutile Pink Unicorn Vessel\u201d (2017) is a simple, oversize urn whose surface is teeming with miniature versions of the title creature.\n\nIn other places, clay looks a lot like something else, as in Diana Rojas\u2019s riff on a retail display of shoes. The most compelling of such works hang on the wall: Valerie Hegarty, Thomas Mailaender and Jesse Edwards have turned ceramics into imitations of paintings, photographs and TV sets, with the objects getting flatter as the illusionistic space deepens.\n\nIn the show\u2019s most exciting art, firm reference points slip away. Two pieces by Shinichi Sawada recall the ritual objects of a lost society. Heidi Lau\u2019s \u201cSeventh and Eighth Level of Hell\u201d (2018) evokes an alien, ominous world that incorporates elements of our own. And Roxanne Jackson\u2019s \u201cWild Mineral\u201d (2017) suggests the sawed-in-half skull of a dangerous, mythical creature. These works, grouped along one wall, demonstrate what can happen when clay becomes a vessel for pure imagination. JILLIAN STEINHAUER", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": ["Roberta Smith", "Martha Schwendener", "Will Heinrich", "Jillian Steinhauer"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nBinge This Classic\n\nDavid Caruso, left, and Dennis Franz, in \u201cNYPD Blue.\u201d Neil Slavin/ABC\n\n\u2018NYPD Blue\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Hulu\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nRecommending this show is bittersweet today because one of its creators, Steven Bochco, died on Sunday. Whether you\u2019re honoring his legacy or introducing yourself to the 15th Precinct, \u201cNYPD Blue\u201d \u2014 finally available to stream \u2014 is worth watching as both a historical specimen and a still-potent police drama.\n\nThe show debuted in 1993, and holy smokes is that first season a time capsule. \u201cER,\u201d which began only a season later, feels much more contemporary and could air more or less as-is today. Not so for \u201cBlue,\u201d which moves slowly in its first season, its hazy-lusty aesthetic blending with rough, tough characters, all housed in a brutal griminess. I think I\u2019m legally required to call the show \u201cgritty,\u201d and so I will.\n\nMy favorite \u201cNYPD Blue\u201d is Jimmy Smits-era \u201cNYPD Blue,\u201d which is Seasons 2 through 6. Season 6 is, to put it mildly, a huge bummer, but the show picks up again. By its 12th and final season, it is definitely out of juice, but there are glimmers of good arcs and moments till the bitter end, especially from Dennis Franz, whose long-suffering Andy Sipowicz became the beating heart of the series.\n\nMost cop shows are about crime or maybe cleverness. \u201cNYPD Blue\u201d is more about pain \u2014 its police officers are in near-constant distress, and its victims, witnesses and sometimes its perpetrators are in a state of suffering. That\u2019s part of what makes \u201cNYPD Blue\u201d so interesting and special, but it\u2019s also why the show became tiring toward the end.If you want to visit or revisit highlights from Bochco\u2019s stunning body of work, \u201cMurder One,\u201d \u201cDoogie Howser, M.D.,\u201d and \u201cHill Street Blues\u201d are also available on Hulu.\n\n0\n\nIf You Want a British Crime Show \u2026\n\nSarah Lancashire in \u201cNational Treasure: Kiri.\u201d Simon RidgwayChannel 4, via Hulu\n\n\u2018National Treasure: Kiri\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Starting Wednesday, on Hulu.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis show has no narrative connection to last year\u2019s superb mini-series \u201cNational Treasure,\u201d about a disgraced comedian, but the shows share a creative team. \u201cKiri\u201d is a four-part crime drama \u2014 another \u201cdead-kid show,\u201d bleak and well-acted and sad. The show centers on the murder of a young black girl in foster care; she\u2019s about to be adopted by a white family and is killed while visiting with her birth family. Sarah Lancashire of \u201cHappy Valley\u201d fame stars as the terrified social worker who finds herself being scapegoated in the media and by the grieving families.\n\nAlso This Week:\n\nFrom left, Ralph Abernathy, James Forman, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the Rev. Jesse Douglas and John Lewis lead a march from Selma to Montgomery in 1965, in \u201cI Am MLK Jr.\u201d Steve Schapiro\n\nThe N.C.A.A. men\u2019s basketball championship airs Monday at 7 p.m. on TBS, with Michigan taking on Villanova. Ah, it was fun while it lasted, Ramblers.\n\nABC\u2019s new supernatural drama \u201cThe Crossing\u201d debuts at 10 p.m. on Monday. If this show had debuted in the summer of 2003, it would have been my favorite thing ever \u2014 sad people wash up on a beach in the Pacific Northwest, claiming to be refugees from the future. It\u2019s a little like the \u201creturn from an alien abduction\u201d drama \u201cThe 4400,\u201d or \u201cLost\u201d and all its knockoffs.\n\nThis week is the 50th anniversary of the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Documentaries abound: \u201cKing in the Wilderness\u201d airs on HBO on Monday at 8 p.m.; PBS is rebroadcasting its \u201cRoads to Memphis\u201d from 2010 on Tuesday at 8 p.m. (check local listings); and \u201cI Am MLK Jr.\u201d airs Wednesday at 9 p.m. on Paramount Network.\n\n\u201cFixer Upper\u201d ends its influential run Tuesday beginning at 9 p.m. on HGTV.\n\nTracy Morgan and Tiffany Haddish star in the new comedy \u201cThe Last O.G.,\u201d starting Tuesday at 10:30 p.m. on TBS.\n\nWatch This Quirky \u201980s New-Wave Musical Comedy\n\nJo Kennedy in \u201cStarstruck.\u201d Palm Beach Pictures\n\n\u2018Starstruck\u2019\n\nWhere to watch: Stream it on\n\n. Stream it on Filmstruck or Kanopy Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe Australian director Gillian Armstrong is known for period dramas like \u201cMy Brilliant Career\u201d and the 1994 \u201cLittle Women\u201d adaptation starring Winona Ryder. But the strangest entry in her filmography is the punky Australian musical comedy \u201cStarstruck.\u201d Its plot is classic Hollywood: A 14-year-old aspiring music impresario in Sydney, Angus (Ross O\u2019Donovan), schemes to make his cousin, the quirky bar worker Jackie (Jo Kennedy), into a pop star. Love, disappointment and ill-advised publicity stunts ensue.\n\nWith its Day-Glo aesthetic and New Wave show tunes, the movie could have been made only in the early 1980s. Jackie sings in front of squiggly, neon rope lights, wearing poofy Madonna dresses. Her family\u2019s pub looks like a \u201950s-style diner as renovated by the B-52s. There\u2019s a synchronized swimming sequence that could have come straight out of a Busby Berkeley musical, except that the bathing beauties are men. And the songs, written in part by Tim Finn of the New Zealand art-rock band Split Enz, are devilishly catchy. \u201cStarstruck\u201d isn\u2019t for everyone, but cultists, \u201980s nostalgists and fans of offbeat teen comedies shouldn\u2019t miss it. \u2014 Judy Berman", "title": "What to Watch This Week", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "FRANKFURT, Germany \u2014 It\u2019s a testament to the lasting influence of Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C. Clarke\u2019s film \u201c2001: A Space Odyssey,\u201d which turns 50 this week, that the disc-shaped card commemorating the German Film Museum\u2019s new exhibition on the film is wordless, but instantly recognizable. Its face features the Cyclopean red eye of the HAL-9000 supercomputer; nothing more needs saying.\n\nImage A poster for the film. Credit MGM, via Photofest\n\nViewers will remember HAL as the overseer of the giant, ill-fated interplanetary spacecraft Discovery. When asked to hide from the crew the goal of its mission to Jupiter \u2014 a point made clearer in the novel version of \u201c2001\u201d than in the film \u2014 HAL gradually runs amok, eventually killing all the astronauts except for their wily commander, Dave Bowman. In an epic showdown between man and machine, Dave, played by Keir Dullea, methodically lobotomizes HAL even as the computer pleads for its life in a terminally decelerating soliloquy.\n\nCocooned by their technology, the film\u2019s human characters appear semi-automated \u2014 component parts of their gleaming white mother ship. As for HAL \u2014 a conflicted artificial intelligence created to provide flawless, objective information but forced to \u201clive a lie,\u201d as Mr. Clarke put it \u2014 the computer was quickly identified by the film\u2019s initial viewers as its most human character.", "title": "Opinion | What \u20182001\u2019 Got Right", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat is the most interesting topic you have learned about in school? Why did it appeal to you?\n\nIn \u201cPop-Ups Offer Classes on Today\u2019s Hot Topics,\u201d Abby Ellin writes:\n\nThe class was supposed to be temporary, a quick dive into the link between literature and anthropology. The professors had no idea if students would even come. It wasn\u2019t mandatory, they wouldn\u2019t get credit and it was taking place at night. Friday night.\n\nSo no one was more surprised than Kara Wittman and Joanne Nucho when 24 people showed up for their \u201cEssay as Resistance\u201d class, which had its debut at Pomona College in March 2017 and ran for three 90-minute sessions. \u201cWe were shocked that it was so popular,\u201d said Ms. Wittman, an assistant professor of English at Pomona, in Claremont, Calif., who taught the class with Ms. Nucho, an assistant professor of anthropology there. But that\u2019s exactly the appeal of the so-called pop-up class, an experiential, interdisciplinary, extracurricular workshop that appears briefly and usually vanishes. Pop-up classes have grown in popularity over the last few years, with a number of colleges and universities offering them. They\u2019re often related to current events. Bennington College\u2019s \u201cAm I Charlie?,\u201d held in 2015, was a response to the attacks on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in France. \u201cWhite Privilege\u201d was offered last year at St. Michael\u2019s College in Colchester, Vt., when Black Lives Matter gained traction on campus. \u201cIt was a time when our community on campus and nationally was divided around issues of race, and we wanted to give our students the opportunity to discuss some of these challenging topics,\u201d said Kimoi Seale, assistant dean of students, who taught the \u201cWhite Privilege\u201d class.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What do you think of the idea of \u201cpop-up\u201d classes? Would you choose to go to class during your free time if it was about something that interested you? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 Which classes mentioned in the article would you like to take? Why?\n\n\u2014 What pop-up classes do you wish your school offered and why?\n\n\u2014 If you could teach a pop-up class, what would it be about? How would you teach it?", "title": "What \u2018Pop-Up\u2019 Classes Do You Wish Your School Offered?", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 When Jan Koum, a founder of the messaging app WhatsApp, sold the service to Facebook in 2014, he explained how deeply he cared about the privacy of communication. Growing up in the Soviet Union during the 1980s \u2014 when surveillance was a fact of life \u2014 had made him realize the importance of being able to speak freely, he wrote.\n\n\u201cRespect for your privacy is coded into our DNA, and we built WhatsApp around the goal of knowing as little about you as possible,\u201d Mr. Koum wrote in a blog post after he had sold WhatsApp to Facebook for $19 billion. \u201cIf partnering with Facebook meant that we had to change our values, we wouldn\u2019t have done it.\u201d\n\nNow, instead of changing his values, Mr. Koum is leaving Facebook.\n\nOn Monday, Mr. Koum, 42, a member of Facebook\u2019s board of directors, said in a post on the social network that \u201cit is time for me to move on.\u201d He did not give a reason for his exit.\n\nBut according to a company executive, who asked not to be identified because the details of Mr. Koum\u2019s departure were confidential, Mr. Koum had grown increasingly concerned about Facebook\u2019s position on user data in recent years. Mr. Koum was perturbed by the amount of information that Facebook collected on people and had wanted stronger protections for that data, the person said. Mr. Koum had discussed leaving the company since late last year, the person added.", "title": "WhatsApp Co-Founder Leaving Facebook Amid User Data Disputes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nMore?\n\n\u2022 Read our introductory post, which includes information about using the \u201cNotice and Wonder\u201d teaching strategy.\n\n\u2022 Go to the A.S.A. K-12 website, which includes This is Statistics, resources, professional development, student competitions, curriculum, courses and careers.\n\n_________\n\nUpdated: April 12, 2018\n\nWho do you think is the most popular musical artist in the U. S.? Your response, I bet, will be tempered by what you and your friends think and not take into account the entire country. For a more national perspective, the weekly Billboard 100 lists current songs across all genres, ranked by radio audiences, sales data and streaming activity. But, that does not consider how popularity varies around the country. The four maps that we showed came from a group of fifty in the New York Times article \u201cWhat Music Do Americans Love the Most? 50 Detailed Fan Maps\u201d and were published on August 7, 2017. The maps set out \u201cthe contours of music fandom and culture in the United States.\u201d From these heatmaps (maps in which data values are represented by a range of colors), you can pinpoint the relative popularity of artists down to small U. S. regions.\n\nThe article determined \u201cmost loved\u201d music by comparing YouTube viewings by artist. How were the artists chosen, the data calculated, and the data shown? First, the top fifty artists were identified from the spring 2017 Billboard Top 100 list, which is not as current as we may have liked. We selected Rihanna (#2 on Billboard), Drake (#13), Taylor Swift (#18), and Luke Bryan (#42) to have some diversity of type of music and region of the country where they were most popular. Then, using YouTube\u2019s geocoded streaming data for the period January 2016 through April 2017, the number of times each of these artists was streamed was determined for each small region. This number was converted to a proportion by dividing the number of the artists\u2019 streamings by the total number of viewings for all fifty artists. Finally, the proportions were color-coded from light pink representing the smallest proportions to dark purple representing the greatest proportions. As the article states, \u201cIf one part of the map is lighter, it doesn\u2019t mean people there weren\u2019t watching the artist\u2019s videos; it just means fans were more likely to listen to a variety of other artists.\u201d\n\nLipi from Madison, Ga., summed up the graphs rather concisely. \u201cThese graphs show the level of popularity for Billboard singers in all fifty states. It shows that Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan are well-liked in almost all fifty states. However, Drake is popular in the Southwest, while Rihanna is more popular in the Southeast. I wonder what attracts these demographics to certain kinds of music. I notice that people are interested in many different kinds of music.\u201d\n\nHere are some questions you may want to think about critically.\n\n\u2022 Rihanna is #2 on Billboard, but she has very few purple regions. Thinking about how popularity is calculated and where she is popular, how could this be true? Similarly, Luke Bryan, who is only #42 on Billboard, seems relatively popular all over the country. How could this be true?\n\n\u2022 In the article, notice that some maps are mostly light pink. What may this imply about the map\u2019s artist? Also, no artist has a mostly purple map. Why do you think this is?\n\n\u2022 Rick of California says that some of his favorite rock \u2018n roll groups, like Led Zeppelin, Rolling Stones and AC/DC, are missing from the list, so rock n\u2019 roll, as we know it, has ended. Can we claim this from the graphs?", "title": "What\u2019s Going On in This Graph? | April 10, 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Updated: April 19, 2018\n\nStudents\n\n1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:\n\n\u2022 What is going on in this picture?\n\n\u2022 What do you see that makes you say that?\n\n\u2022 What more can you find?\n\n2. Next, join the conversation by clicking on the comment button and posting in the box that opens on the right. (Students 13 and older are invited to comment, although teachers of younger students are welcome to post what their students have to say.)\n\n3. After you have posted, try reading back to see what others have said, then respond to someone else by posting another comment. Use the \u201cReply\u201d button or the @ symbol to address that student directly.\n\nEach Monday, our collaborator, Visual Thinking Strategies, will facilitate a discussion from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time by paraphrasing comments and linking to responses to help students\u2019 understanding go deeper. You might use their responses as models for your own.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n4. Millions of moviegoers around the world became acquainted with Wakanda, the mythical African nation whose advanced society is hidden from the outside world behind a holographic camouflage. In the film, technology plays a big role, from the prevalence of vibranium to the use of kimoyo beads to remote piloting of planes.\n\nWe asked readers to share their views of what Wakanda would look like if they could actually visit the country. Here are some of the best responses we received, with visions of the fictional country by the artists Richie Pope and Ojima Abalaka.\n\n\u2014\n\nKacper Jarecki Using hologram technology, visitors can play and cuddle cheetahs. This is really popular with families. There is a cheetah gym facility where people get to experience running at 40 miles per hour!\n\nThere is also a giant rainbow waterfall, which is the biggest water park in the world. Of course, this water park is not completely real, but the thrill is just as real, if not more so.", "title": "What\u2019s It Like to Visit Wakanda? You Had Some (Great) Ideas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 I\u2019ve noticed a weird pattern, in fiction and life, about sexual encounters: Women decide they\u2019re not attracted to a guy they\u2019re nestling with. Limerence is not in the cards. But they go ahead and have sex anyhow.\n\nFirst, we have college student Margot in The New Yorker\u2019s much-discussed short fictional story \u201cCat Person\u201d who recoils as she watches Robert undress. \u201cBut the thought of what it would take to stop what she had set in motion was overwhelming; it would require an amount of tact and gentleness that she felt was impossible to summon.\u201d Margot doesn\u2019t want to seem spoiled or capricious, so she takes a sip of whiskey to \u201cbludgeon her resistance into submission.\u201d\n\nThen we have the 23-year-old Brooklyn-based photographer who hooked up with comedian Aziz Ansari at his TriBeCa apartment and talked about it anonymously to the website Babe. She was distressed by his arbitrary choice of white wine at dinner, his rush to sex, the way he jammed two fingers in a V-shape down her throat.\n\nBut at his request, she gave him oral sex twice; he briefly performed it on her once.\n\nOn \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d Stormy Daniels told Anderson Cooper that she was not at all attracted to Donald Trump but she had sex with him (without a condom). She said that she thought maybe \u201cI had it coming for making a bad decision for going to someone\u2019s room alone.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s Lust Got to Do With It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIts Ideals Tainted, Can Social Media Shine Again?,\u201d by Kevin Roose (The Shift column, Business Day, March 29):\n\nThe appropriate frustration and disappointment resulting from the recent Facebook and Cambridge Analytica disclosures are making it easy to forget the personal and economic benefits of social media.\n\nFor example, let\u2019s not forget that we choose to integrate these services into our daily lives because they allow us to deepen social connections and enable us to exercise our individual agency in a fashion that was impossible before their emergence. Or that these services have created millions of jobs, new business ecosystems and helped fuel the rise of the digital economy that brings broad societal benefit.\n\nBut it is important not to forget the learning of lessons and the hoped-for change. We are seeing some of these changes now. There is no playbook for addressing the principles at play here, and so it will not be all smooth sailing. But you can be certain that the effort will be earnest and that these services will be better as a result.\n\nDEAN GARFIELD, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is president and chief executive of the Information Technology Industry Council, a lobbying group for Google, Facebook, Twitter, Apple and Amazon, among others.", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s Right, and Wrong, With Social Media", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "When Fairchild arrived on the West Coast, he learned that the boat he and Lathrop were to board had already left, so they hopped on another train and began the two-week journey to catch another boat in New Orleans, stopping in Santa Barbara to meet Dr. Francesco Franceschi, \u201cwho cut for his visitor a slice of a curious squash \u2014 \u2018zucchini,\u2019 he called it.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nThis distant age of wonder \u2014 an era in which worldliness was hard-earned and Barbour Lathrop circled the globe many times \u2014 was full of innocence and promise. In a Washington, D.C., boardinghouse, Fairchild roomed with a former colleague from the Department of Agriculture named Wallace Swingle; together, they brainstormed about building a team that would travel to foreign countries and \u201cadminister the introduction of plants.\u201d As Stone explains, they \u201cfancied their title as \u2018agricultural explorer\u2019 \u2014 a term so whimsical, so obvious, that it came out of their mouths at the same time.\u201d\n\nSoon enough there was a sign on a door and a new government agency: the Office of Seed and Plant Introduction. The results were tremendous. Avocados, soybeans, nectarines and kale, Meyer lemons, hops, seedless grapes and watermelons were all either introduced or improved by Fairchild and his team.\n\nThis isn\u2019t another chapter in that old story about how we ate badly until fill-in-the-blank came along and revolutionized American dining. This is a story about a world in which there were no avocados until David Fairchild mailed some home, about a strange and meager period in our past in which no one had eaten a zucchini.\n\nStone doesn\u2019t editorialize about the consequences. \u201cIn 1908,\u201d he writes, \u201cfew people had seen a soybean,\u201d adding that within 100 years, \u201cthe evolved descendants of soybeans that Meyer shipped back would cover the Midwest of the United States like a rug. Soybeans would be applied to more diverse uses than any other crop in history.\u201d Although Stone wisely keeps himself out of the argument, it\u2019s a safe bet that most of his readers will hear the alarm.\n\nFairchild lived in optimistic times. Problems of land and crop management, he and his colleagues believed, were going to be solved in an entirely new way: \u201cAmerica\u2019s goal wasn\u2019t just to farm; it was to construct an industrial agricultural system bigger and more profitable than any group of people had ever built.\u201d The bloom, of course, is off that rose, but it doesn\u2019t make Fairchild\u2019s story, and the profound role he played in ushering us into modernity, any less fascinating.", "title": "What\u2019s a Zucchini? And Other Questions Americans Once Asked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Navarro\u2019s edible drawings fit into the tradition of food as performance or medium: the culinary manifestoes of the Futurists and Surrealists; the communal dining happenings of Gordon Matta-Clark, Rirkrit Tiravanija and Jennifer Rubell; Joseph Beuys\u2019s use of chocolate, lard and dried meat.\n\nBut Mr. Navarro is an outlier, Mr. Littman asserted.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve eaten Paul McCarthy sculptures or Dieter Roth sculptures, but they are made from chocolate or bubble gum,\u201d he said. \u201cBut in the 11 years I\u2019ve been here no artist has explored eating a drawing as a possibility.\u201d\n\nMs. G\u00fciraldes and Mr. Littman (who begins a new role as director of the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum in May) both suggested that Mr. Navarro\u2019s work might have more in common with William Pope.L\u2019s \u201cEating The Wall Street Journal\u201d (2000), in which the artist sat on a toilet suspended in the air and ate pieces of the newspaper to \u201cdigest the news\u201d or Felix Gonzalez-Torres\u2019s candy-mound portraits of his lover who was dying of AIDS, in which visitors are invited to take a piece as a representation of his diminishing weight.\n\nAnd while Mr. Navarro is not religious, it\u2019s hard not to think of the biblical passage in which Ezekiel eats a scroll so he can internalize and speak the word of God. Mr. Navarro also cites cannibalism as an influence, noting how some societies eat humans to gain their power and strengths. The thought did not elude me when I spotted a drawing at the diner of a bald entity with a giant eyeball connected to a coiling intestine \u2014 a frequent motif in his edible work. It looked like a totemic image from another galaxy.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Navarro gently tore apart the drawing and placed it on the surface of the soup, and the paper slowly transformed into a nearly translucent, gelatinous skin, leaving the black outline of the image still visible. \u201cIt\u2019s like a soup tattoo,\u201d he observed. It also added some welcome texture to the cream of broccoli, we both agreed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter taking a few bites, he sighed with relief. \u201cIt\u2019s liberating to think about the drawings leaving the archive,\u201d he said. \u201cThere is so much mummification in art. You have to think about how it\u2019s shown and how it\u2019s collected and stored and archived.\u201d\n\nA few days later, on a cold evening at the Drawing Center, Mr. Navarro prepared a spicy vegetable soup in a giant pot on a hot plate. He dissolved four sheets of a drawing of a multinosed creature into the pot, and visitors were offered a cup as they streamed through.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a different way of digesting it, much more visceral,\u201d said Jessica Kaire, who had also eaten a Gonzalez-Torres candy.\n\nWhen asked if ingesting the drawing made it more memorable, the art historian and critic Alex Kitnick replied, \u201cAsk me tomorrow.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s for Lunch? Soup, With a Side of Art", "authors": ["Meredith Mendelsohn"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Learn more about Meghan Markle, who will become the newest member of the British royal family. Or relax with buddy comedies that all have something in common.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nBILL & TED\u2019S EXCELLENT ADVENTURE (1989) 9 p.m. on Viceland. Way before he was Neo, John Wick or even Hamlet, Keanu Reeves was Ted, an affable high school slacker with a best friend named Bill (Alex Winter). In danger of flunking out of history class, they stumble on a time machine that lets them carouse with Napoleon, Joan of Arc and more; George Carlin plays their time travel guide. The movie was brutally panned in The New York Times upon release but has since become a cult classic and even received a shout out in \u201cReady Player One.\u201d Rolling Stone named it the \u201ceighth best stoner movie of all time,\u201d but if you\u2019re looking for a different strain of comedy there are plenty of options: CHEECH & CHONG\u2019S NICE DREAMS runs at 9:35 on FLIX; Comedy Central shows HAROLD & KUMAR GO TO WHITE CASTLE at 10; and IFC has PINEAPPLE EXPRESS at 8.\n\nJANE THE VIRGIN 9 p.m. on the CW.
