Jay-Z has been startlingly honest and introspective over the past year, whether on his wrenching album \u201c4:44\u201d or in a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times. He vents and ponders his past once again with David Letterman, who nowadays is far more prone to play therapist than crack wise. In this interview, Jay-Z recalls crying from happiness after his mother came out to him and his favorite moments with his daughter, Blue Ivy. He also discusses his favorite rappers, like Snoop Dogg and Eminem.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u20186 Balloons\u2019 and \u2018Troy: Fall of a City\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Leslie Odom Jr. won a Tony for portraying Aaron Burr in \u201cHamilton,\u201d where he flaunted a creamy falsetto, a jagged howl and a pristine rap flow. Since then he\u2019s been far less of an M.C. than a crooner, focusing on elegant interpretations of the American songbook. (\u201cHe has a sterling voice, and in his music he is much more comfortable with his upper register than in \u2018Hamilton,\u2019\u201d Jon Caramanica wrote in The New York Times.) There\u2019s hardly a better setting for his lush arrangements of standards than Lincoln Center\u2019s Appel Room, where this concert was filmed. You might not even mind not being in the room where it happened.\n\nDAVID BOWIE: FIVE YEARS (2013) 10 p.m. on BBC America. The title of this documentary refers not to the apocalyptic scenario of the David Bowie song but rather five crucial years across his career. Footage starts with 1971 \u2014 when he released that song and unleashed his Ziggy Stardust persona \u2014 and also examines 1975, with the emergence of the Thin White Duke, and 1983, when \u201cLet\u2019s Dance\u201d hit the top of the charts in both America and Britain. Like the current exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum, this documentary dips into Bowie\u2019s personal archive of costumes, set designs, lyrics and memorabilia to illuminate his life.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Bobby Kennedy for President\u2019 and \u2018Vice\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNetflix reboots a 1960s sci-fi series. And Wyatt Cenac hosts a docu-series exploring America\u2019s most pressing issues.\n\n\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nLOST IN SPACE on Netflix. The latest high-budget adventure from Netflix is a story from the past set in the future. It\u2019s based on the CBS sci-fi drama of the same name that ran during the 1960s space race. In the 2040s, members of the Robinson family join a group of colonizers and become lost en route to their destination. They end up on an unknown planet, battle the strange environment and make an uneasy alliance with a robot to survive. Molly Parker and Toby Stephens co-star. In his review for The New York Times, Mike Hale wrote that the show is \u201ca distillation of several generations\u2019 worth of family-adventure and science-fiction blockbusters.\u201d\n\nCHEF\u2019S TABLE on Netflix. There are food shows that focus on the host\u2019s personality, like \u201c____, That\u2019s Delicious,\u201d and others that home in on cultural aspects, like \u201cParts Unknown.\u201d But none build narrative quite like \u201cChef\u2019s Table,\u201d which takes a cinematic approach to exploring the outer and inner lives of the world\u2019s best chefs. The show lingers on excruciatingly beautiful close-ups of black truffle dim sum and chayote squash, then follows their creators into their messy homes and chaotic favorite markets. The fourth season streams Friday, with a twist: It\u2019s dedicated to pastry chefs, including Milk Bar\u2019s Christina Tosi.\n\nPhoto\n\nBOSCH on Amazon Prime. This police procedural, based on Michael Connelly\u2019s books, strides into its fourth season, with a fifth one confirmed. It follows the detective Harry Bosch (Titus Welliver) around the underbelly of Los Angeles. \u201cThe series works like a good page-turner,\u201d Neil Genzlinger wrote in a review in The Times.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE GRAHAM NORTON SHOW 10 p.m. on BBC America. Emily Blunt and John Krasinski come to the red couch to talk about both their real-life relationship and terrifying new movie, \u201cA Quiet Place.\u201d They\u2019re joined by Tom Holland (\u201cSpiderman: Homecoming\u201d) and Kylie Minogue.\n\nPhoto\n\nWYATT CENAC\u2019S PROBLEM AREAS 11:30 p.m. on HBO. After a somewhat contentious departure from \u201cThe Daily Show,\u201d Wyatt Cenac has thrown himself into an eccentric and diverse set of projects: hosting live comedy shows, starring in sci-fi series, lending his voice to \u201cArcher\u201d and \u201cBob\u2019s Burgers.\u201d His newest venture is a late-night docu-series that attempts to find creative solutions to social and cultural problems across America. One of those issues will be policing, as Mr. Cenac travels across the country to explore how police officers are hired and trained, and how they use their power.\n\nTHE LATE SHOW WITH STEPHEN COLBERT 11:35 on CBS. The always sardonic Aubrey Plaza shows up to chats with Mr. Colbert \u2014 as does Cookie Monster. John Cena comes to JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! on ABC to hawk his new movie, \u201cBlockers.\u201d And Jeff Daniels and Joe Manganiello are the guests on NBC\u2019s THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JIMMY FALLON.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Lost in Space\u2019 and \u2018Chef\u2019s Table\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "The poignant drama \u201cAmour\u201d traces a woman\u2019s decline and the toll it takes on her husband. And the documentary \u201cI Am Evidence\u201d explores the issue of unprocessed rape kits through the lives of four survivors.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nAMOUR (2012) on iTunes, Amazon, FilmStruck, Google Play, Sundance Now, Vudu and YouTube. At the outset of this Oscar-winning drama by Michael Haneke it\u2019s clear that there has been a loss. Then the story rewinds and we meet Georges (Jean-Louis Trintignant) and Anne (Emmanuelle Riva), a retired couple in Paris. The two lead a peaceful life centered on their unbreakable bond and shared love of music, but it\u2019s suddenly disrupted when Anne has a stroke. What follows is immensely touching, yet painful to watch. In her review for The New York Times, Manohla Dargis named \u201cAmour\u201d a Critic\u2019s Pick and wrote, \u201cThis is a film that will make you weep not only because life ends but also because it blooms.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Amour\u2019 and \u2018I Am Evidence\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "James Cameron gathers fellow sci-fi buffs to explore the genre\u2019s history in a new AMC series. And the eccentric Sherlock Holmes of \u201cElementary\u201d returns for Season 6.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nAMC VISIONARIES: JAMES CAMERON\u2019S STORY OF SCIENCE FICTION 10 p.m. on AMC. More than a century after the first known science-fiction movies were made, filmmakers continue to churn out supernatural stories, and viewers can\u2019t get enough. This six-part documentary series, led by the writer, producer and director James Cameron, traces the genre\u2019s shift from niche to mainstream and explores its themes through interviews with Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and other notable sci-fi fans. It opens with a look at alien-centered movies like \u201cArrival,\u201d \u201cAvatar\u201d and \u201cE. T.\u201d In an interview with The New York Times, Mr. Cameron shared his motivation to tell otherworldly tales: \u201cThe thing that encourages me is that we are actually approaching an existential crisis as human beings about artificial intelligence and the threat of artificial intelligence. The trick is to make these movies while they\u2019re still science fiction.\u201d\n\nVERY SUPERSTITIOUS WITH GEORGE LOPEZ 8 p.m. on A&E. While James Cameron explores the supernatural in entertainment, George Lopez searches for it in everyday lives. The actor draws from his upbringing in a superstitious Mexican household in this new passion project, crisscrossing the United States in search of unusual beliefs and rituals that some communities still hold dear.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018James Cameron\u2019s Story of Science Fiction\u2019 and \u2018Elementary\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cKing in the Wilderness\u201d looks at a lesser-known side of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s life. And \u201cThe Good Karma Hospital\u201d returns on Acorn TV.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nKING IN THE WILDERNESS (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. As the country honors the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. 50 years after his assassination, this new documentary sheds light on the final chapters of his life. Two of Dr. King\u2019s most notable accomplishments came with the passing of the Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights Act in 1964 and 1965. Yet the period that followed found him castigated by longtime friends and allies as he focused on economic justice and vehemently opposed the Vietnam War. In an interview with The New York Times, the director Peter Kunhardt said that while researching Dr. King\u2019s life, he realized that most accounts summarized his legacy with the \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech. He added: \u201cIt never went beyond that. So we were pleased to not deal with that aspect and look at the nightmare the dream turned into.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE CROSSING 10 p.m. on ABC. Some elements of this pilot parallel real-life stories of refugees fleeing their homelands in recent years. After dozens of people wash up on a shore in a small fishing town, a man describes the war they fled as a holocaust. A daughter says her father offered all he had for someone to get her across a checkpoint. Yet 10 minutes into the episode, one survivor reveals that the conflict hasn\u2019t happened yet, setting this sci-fi drama in motion. Steve Zahn plays Sheriff Jude Ellis, who\u2019s tasked with unspooling the mystery with a Department of Homeland Security agent, Emma Ren (Sandrine Holt).\n\nWHEN GOD SLEEPS (2018) 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). In 2012, the Iranian musician Shahin Najafi released a satirical rap song that sparked outrage among the country\u2019s hard-line clerics. Many called for his death, and an Islamist website placed a $100,000 bounty on his head. Directed by Till Schauder, \u201cWhen God Sleeps\u201d is an intimate portrayal of Mr. Najafi\u2019s life in exile (he now lives in Germany) that looks at oppression and resilience in Iran.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nDR. STRANGELOVE OR: HOW I LEARNED TO STOP WORRYING AND LOVE THE BOMB (1964) on iTunes, Amazon, Starz and Sundance Now. If the prospect of nuclear war chills your bones, you may want to skip this dark Cold War satire. An out-of-control American general (Sterling Hayden) orders a nuclear attack on the Soviet Union, causing chaos and panic within the administration. Peter Sellers stars in three roles; George C. Scott plays the hawkish Gen. Buck Turgidson.\n\nTHE GOOD KARMA HOSPITAL on Acorn TV. Amrita Acharia (\u201cGame of Thrones\u201d) returns as Dr. Ruby Walker in the second season of this British medical dramedy. A year after her move to India from Britain, Dr. Walker has settled into her new life and is gaining confidence at work. But she\u2019s still put to the test by Dr. Lydia Fonseca (Amanda Redman) at the local hospital.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018King in the Wilderness\u2019 and \u2018The Good Karma Hospital\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cSami Blood\u201d traces one woman\u2019s escape from her roots. And Netflix acquires its first Filipino series.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nSAMI BLOOD (2016) on Amazon and Sundance Now. When the teenager Elle (Lene Cecilia Sparrok) breaks away from her indigenous Sami family in 1930s Sweden, she ends up in a government-run boarding school where, despite her hard work, she\u2019s discriminated against as an inferior outsider. This debut feature by the director Amanda Kernell shifts between Elle\u2019s adolescence and adult life, when she adopts the name Christina, capturing the consequences of her choice to shun her heritage. \u201cWhile \u2018Sami Blood\u2019 can sometimes seem didactic,\u201d Ben Kenigsberg wrote in The New York Times, Ms. Kernell \u201crichly conveys a sense of the time and place, with elegant shots that glide through the Nordic wilderness.\u201d\n\nAMO on Netflix. The Filipino director Brillante Mendoza dramatizes President Rodrigo Duterte\u2019s war on drugs in this crime thriller. The series follows a high school student and small-time drug dealer (Vince Rillon) who becomes embroiled with threatening drug lords and corrupt government officials. There\u2019s no telling which agenda, if any, the show promotes. Human-rights organizations have largely condemned Mr. Duterte\u2019s indiscriminate killing, which has claimed about 4,000 to 12,000 lives. Yet Mr. Mendoza has supported the president\u2019s tactics.\n\nPhoto\n\nCHAVELA (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. The singer Chavela Vargas forged her own path in the 1950s and \u201960s with her emotional renditions of popular ranchera songs, androgynous appearance and tough spirit. Born in Costa Rica, Ms. Vargas moved to Mexico at a young age and became one of the first female entertainers to trade flamboyant costumes for pants. This portrait centers on candid footage of Ms. Vargas from 1991, and addresses her struggles with alcoholism in interviews with her friends and collaborators.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nWACO: THE LONGEST SIEGE (2018) 8 p.m. on Smithsonian. Survivors and journalists revisit the 51-day standoff at the Branch Davidian religious sect\u2019s compound in Waco, Tex., that ended in tragedy 25 years ago. On Feb. 28, 1993, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents raided a complex where more than 100 members of the sect lived, claiming the group was illegally stockpiling weapons. David Koresh, who led the clan, allowed more than 30 followers to leave. Despite multiple efforts to evacuate the rest, only nine escaped. Nearly 80 others perished inside when the building caught fire on April 19.\n\nTHE ART OF THE SHINE (2018) 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). \u201cIt pays the bills and I\u2019m free.\u201d That\u2019s how a former accountant and banker describes his second act as a shoeshiner in this new, delightful documentary. The filmmaker Stacey Tenenbaum picks the brains of shoeshiners around the world, some of whom claim the service serves a valuable purpose in the hustle and bustle of today\u2019s cities. Some take the trade to a whole new level: A shiner in Tokyo offers a flute of champagne during his hourlong sessions.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Sami Blood\u2019 and \u2018Amo\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJames Corden looks back at his favorite moments from \u201cThe Late Late Show.\u201d And \u201cPass Over\u201d reimagines \u201cWaiting for Godot\u201d in present-day Chicago.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE LATE LATE SHOW CARPOOL KARAOKE PRIMETIME SPECIAL 10 p.m. on CBS. The host James Corden rounds up another set of stars for his third prime-time special. He performs a musical number inspired by Bruno Mars with the musician and comedian Reggie Watts, while the actors Anna Faris, Allison Janney, Kunal Nayyar and Iain Armitage play along during a bizarre iteration of \u201cThe Sound of Music.\u201d Christina Aguilera gets in the passenger seat for some \u201cCarpool Karaoke.\u201d\n\nNEW ORLEANS: CITY OF STORIES 6 p.m. on National Geographic. New Orleans has a lot more to offer than mouthwatering Po\u2019 Boys and the tourist favorite Bourbon Street. This new travel series highlights the city\u2019s hidden gems as it celebrates its 300th anniversary. Artists, bartenders and historians share the movements and customs that give the Big Easy its charm.\n\nPhoto\n\nINTENT TO DESTROY: DEATH, DENIAL & DEPICTION 9 p.m. on Starz; also on iTunes and Amazon. As World War I unfolded, some 1.5 million Armenians in the Ottoman Empire were killed in what historians have long considered a genocide. Yet for a century, the Turkish government has denied the tragedy and muzzled efforts to revisit it by coercing media companies and other governments to do the same. This documentary details that systemic suppression through archival footage and historical insight. \u201cWhile there may be no completely dispassionate way to discuss its topic,\u201d Ken Jaworowski wrote in The New York Times, \u201cthe film\u2019s balance of emotion and composure helps make its stories even stronger.\u201d Much of \u201cIntent to Destroy\u201d captures the production of \u201cTHE PROMISE,\u201d a romantic epic set during the war. Stream it on Amazon, Google Play, Vudu or YouTube.\n\nMcMAFIA 11:10 p.m. on AMC. This coproduction of the BBC and AMC included a roster of international actors when it debuted in February. Created by Hossein Amini (\u201cThe Wings of the Dove\u201d) and James Watkins (\u201cThe Woman in Black\u201d) and inspired by a book of the same name, \u201cMcMafia\u201d stars James Norton as Alex Godman, a successful first-generation Russian in London who tries to keep his family\u2019s criminal past behind him. At the outset of this eight-part series, Alex is dragged into a web of organized crime involving mafiosos from Israel, India and Russia. In this season finale, Alex is detained in Moscow and must fight for his life.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nPASS OVER (2018) on Amazon. Two young, homeless black men, Moses (Jon Michael Hill) and Kitch (Julian Parker), live out a version of \u201cWaiting for Godot\u201d in Spike Lee\u2019s adaptation of the play \u201cPass Over\u201d by Antoinette Nwandu. As the young men pace a violent street corner, the two banter with each other, wondering when they will \u201cpass over\u201d to better lives. The lens only strays from the curb when it captures the reactions of the audience watching it at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018The Late Late Show\u2019 Special and \u2018Pass Over\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe stand-up comic Michelle Wolf takes on the risky role of hosting the White House Correspondents\u2019 dinner. And the documentary \u201c78/52\u201d arrives on Hulu.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nWHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENTS\u2019 DINNER 9:30 p.m. on CNN and C-Span. For the second year in a row, President Trump will skip the annual White House Correspondents\u2019 Association dinner, a ritual in which a host roasts the president in front of a tough crowd of politicians, celebrities and journalists before the president does the same to the press. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, will represent the administration at the head table instead. Even in Mr. Trump\u2019s absence, it\u2019s unlikely that he will be spared by this year\u2019s host, the comedian Michelle Wolf. In an interview with The New York Times, Ms. Wolf said she was relieved when she learned that Mr. Trump wouldn\u2019t be attending. \u201cI thought, oh, thank God, I don\u2019t have to hear him eat.\u201d\n\nTHE BEACH HOUSE (2018) 9 p.m. on Hallmark. With her life in shambles, Cara (Minka Kelly of \u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d) returns to the Lowcountry of South Carolina to visit her mother (Andie MacDowell) and help repair the family beach house in this adaptation of Mary Alice Monroe\u2019s novel. This feel-good homecoming story wouldn\u2019t be complete without a rekindling of old flames: Chad Michael Murray co-stars as Cara\u2019s former beau.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\n78/52: HITCHCOCK\u2019S SHOWER SCENE (2017) on iTunes, Amazon, Google Play, Hulu, and YouTube. Alfred Hitchcock used 78 shots, 52 edits and a casaba melon to piece together the seminal shower scene in his 1960 thriller, \u201cPsycho.\u201d Alexandre O. Philippe\u2019s documentary meticulously studies these and other elements of that horror masterpiece, capturing the film\u2019s enduring impact on cinema. Ben Kenigsberg made \u201c78/52\u201d a Critic\u2019s Pick in his review for The Times and wrote, \u201cEven moviegoers who know \u2018Psycho\u2019 backward and forward \u2014 who consider it a sacred text and who have read Stephen Rebello\u2019s excellent book \u2018Alfred Hitchcock and the Making of \u2018Psycho\u2019 \u2014 are bound to learn something new.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHROW MOMMA FROM THE TRAIN (1987) on iTunes, Amazon, Epix, and Vudu. For more of Hitchcock\u2019s influence, watch this comical take on his 1951 film, \u201cStrangers on a Train.\u201d Directed by Danny DeVito, who also co-stars, \u201cThrow Momma\u201d explicitly refers to its inspiration from the get-go. Owen (Mr. DeVito) has had enough of his half-crazy mother\u2019s belligerence. His writing teacher, Larry (Billy Crystal), suffers from writer\u2019s block and is embittered by his ex-wife\u2019s successful literary career. After Owen watches \u201cStrangers,\u201d he offers to kill Larry\u2019s ex-wife if Larry will return the favor by dispatching Owen\u2019s mother (Anne Ramsey). Writing in The Times, Janet Maslin praised Mr. DeVito\u2019s performance: \u201cHe\u2019s irresistible even when playing someone only a mother could love.\u201d\n\nKEEP THE FLAME, DON\u2019T PRAY TO THE ASHES (2016) on Cennarium and Medici.tv. In this documentary, Annette von Wangenheim journeys into the mind of the choreographer Martin Schl\u00e4pfer, who serves as artistic director and principal choreographer of Ballet am Rhein in Germany.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: White House Correspondents\u2019 Dinner and \u201878/52\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "A new documentary defines Elvis Presley as a musician first, superstar second. And the clever romantic drama \u201cRight Now, Wrong Then\u201d arrives on Mubi.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nELVIS PRESLEY: THE SEARCHER (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. Documenting Elvis Presley\u2019s life in a new light is no small feat. But the director Thom Zimny started working on this two-part portrait with one goal in mind: The King\u2019s music comes first. \u201cThe Searcher\u201d is a deeply personal look at Presley\u2019s creative process and musical influences, beginning with his childhood in Mississippi to his final recording sessions in 1976. Interviewees like Tom Petty, Bruce Springsteen and Priscilla Presley recount how the rock legend\u2019s music was often overshadowed by his image, emphasizing that he was most himself while creating and performing. Fans will surely appreciate the featured tracks; Presley\u2019s archivist generously offered 6,000 recordings to choose from.\n\nLITTLEST PET SHOP: A WORLD OF OUR OWN 12 p.m. on Discovery Family. This spinoff series shifts focus from the human protagonist in the original \u201cLittlest Pet Shop\u201d to six pet friends in two back-to-back premiere episodes. A magical portal transports pets to a utopia equipped with ski slopes, animal-friendly apartments and a beauty salon where cats offer back massages. The series opens as the Boston terrier Roxie, house sitting for a pop star, is confronted by a group of snobs who may be using her to throw a house party.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Elvis Presley: The Searcher\u2019 and \u2018Right Now, Wrong Then\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA \u201cBlack Panther\u201d star hosts \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d And depending on your tastes, watch a Chuck Norris marathon or a new series about poetry.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nSATURDAY NIGHT LIVE 11:30 p.m. on NBC. The Wakandan King and the Bronx Queen on \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d the same night? That sounds too good to be true. But Chadwick Boseman and Cardi B will be featured on this week\u2019s show. Mr. Boseman already has a grab bag of impressions ready to go from playing Jackie Robinson, James Brown and Thurgood Marshall. And while there was already one \u201cBlack Panther\u201d sketch on \u201cS.N.L.\u201d this season, you can bet he\u2019ll reprise his role in that record-breaking film. Cardi B will be the musical guest, on the heels of releasing her brash debut album, \u201cInvasion of Privacy.\u201d\n\n\n\nPOETRY IN AMERICA 7:30 p.m. on WLIW (check local listings) or online. Joe Biden, Shaquille O\u2019Neal, Bono and other luminaries show up in this series led by the Harvard professor Elisa New, which explores the ways in which poetry shows up in places you might not expect. The first episode dives into Emily Dickinson and looks at how poetry can move across mediums. The cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the dancer and choreographer Jill Johnson, and the actor and now gubernatorial candidate Cynthia Nixon appear to read and discuss poetry.\n\nPhoto\n\nRANSOM 8 p.m. on CBS. This show follows the efforts of a team of hostage negotiators trying to talk down criminals and resolve crises without violence. The second season starts on Saturday, with the stakes raised as the daughter of the team leader Eric (Luke Roberts) is kidnapped. The show has thrilling moments, but reviews were mixed: \u201cIts premise is built for adrenaline-rush moments, not for the long haul,\u201d Neil Genzlinger wrote in his New York Times review.\n\nCHUCK NORRIS MARATHON on HDNet Movies. Chuck Norris movies never got particularly good reviews, but if you\u2019re looking for nuance and character development, you\u2019re missing the point. Spend a full day watching roundhouse kicks with this six-film marathon, most of which have since gained cult followings. Watch the martial-arts star play a cop (HERO AND THE TERROR at 3:45 p.m.), a small-town Texas sheriff (SILENT RAGE at 5:25), and soldiers in the two-film franchises MISSING IN ACTION (9 and 10:45) and THE DELTA FORCE (12:25 and 2:35 a.m.).\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nFLEABAG on Amazon Prime. Phoebe Waller-Bridge will swerve into a new chapter of her career Sunday night when her \u201cKilling Eve,\u201d a drama starring Sandra Oh, begins on BBC America. Before it arrives, catch up with her previous triumph: the dark comedy \u201cFleabag.\u201d She plays the hypersexual titular character living in London, who struggles to hold it together after the death of her best friend and business partner. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t quite feel like anything else on television,\u201d Mike Hale wrote in his Times review; he also called it a \u201cbinger\u2019s dream.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Saturday Night Live\u2019 and \u2018Ransom\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Letdown\u201d puts a comedic spin on motherhood. And \u201cIndivisible\u201d follows three undocumented immigrants at the heart of a national debate.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nTHE LETDOWN on Netflix. Despite her determination to hold onto her former life after becoming a mother, Audrey (Alison Bell) quickly learns that parenthood is pretty much a full-time job. Her husband is too caught up with his career to help tend to their infant, so Audrey joins a new-parents support group and befriends other stressed-out moms. This Australian comedy blends emotional sob sessions with witty one-liners, leaving you pitying and laughing at the new parents.\n\nGREAT WIDE OPEN on Fandor and YouTube. Jared Leto is best known as an actor, the frontman for the rock band \u201c30 Seconds to Mars\u201d and a Snapchat enthusiast. But he\u2019s also a longtime rock climber. In this five-part documentary series, a passion project directed by Mr. Leto, he shares his love of the outdoors and explores five national parks alongside courageous adventurers. If you\u2019re looking for an excuse to spend more time in the wild, the breathtaking footage of green expanses and sun-kissed canyons should do the trick.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018The Letdown\u2019 and \u2018Indivisible\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCarrie Underwood and others perform at the Academy of Country Music Awards. And \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d ends its eighth season.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTHE 53RD ANNUAL ACADEMY OF COUNTRY MUSIC AWARDS 8 p.m. on CBS. Few genres romanticize rags-to-riches stories the way country music does. This show, hosted by Reba McEntire, will recognize promising newcomers and impressive veterans from the past year. Chris Stapleton, Garth Brooks, Miranda Lambert and Keith Urban are among those nominated for top awards. The broadcast will feature performances by Carrie Underwood, Lady Antebellum, Florida Georgia Line and Jason Aldean, among others.\n\n\n\nRIO (2011) 5 p.m. on FXM. This animated feature, set in the director Carlos Saldanha\u2019s native Rio de Janeiro, brings affection and fun to a story about a kidnapped bird adjusting to a new culture. Anne Hathaway and Jesse Eisenberg voice a pair of macaws. Jamie Foxx and will.i.am voice a canary and a cardinal. \u201cRio 2\u201d (2014) follows at 7.\n\nTHE WALKING DEAD 9 p.m. on AMC. A final episode wraps up the eighth season of AMC\u2019s zombie megahit. Right after, at 10, a new season of its spinoff, \u201cFear the Walking Dead,\u201d begins. Morgan (Lennie James), a character in the main series, appears in the first episode of the spinoff\u2019s fourth season.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nPHANTOM THREAD (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. Paul Thomas Anderson\u2019s latest film is about a man who thinks the world revolves around him. Daniel Day Lewis plays that man, a dressmaker in 1950s London named Reynolds Woodcock, in what he has said was his final screen performance. Vicky Krieps portrays Alma, a waitress who becomes his partner in both love and verbal sparring. \u201cIt\u2019s a chamber piece, romantic and baroque in equal measure, with arresting harmonies and ravishing changes of tone,\u201d A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. It also features an Oscar-nominated score by Jonny Greenwood.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: Country Music Awards and \u2018The Walking Dead\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJohn Legend steps into the sandals of Jesus. And Benedict Cumberbatch stars in a new movie about grief and loss.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nJESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR LIVE IN CONCERT 8 p.m. on NBC. Celebrate Easter by watching John Legend portray Jesus. The R&B superstar will take center stage to play the son of God in Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice\u2019s once-villified, now-canon rock musical. \u201cI had a hard time turning down the role of Jesus Christ,\u201d Mr. Legend told The Times. He\u2019ll be joined at the live Brooklyn armory performance by a starry cast that includes Sara Bareilles as Mary Magdalene and Alice Cooper as King Herod. And Brandon Victor Dixon, who recently played another conflicted antagonist as Aaron Burr in \u201cHamilton,\u201d will take the role of Judas.\n\nMLB BASEBALL There may have been a big snowstorm recently, but that\u2019s not stopping baseball from heralding the return of spring. Two games will be televised nationally on Sunday: At 1:10 p.m., the St. Louis Cardinals face the New York Mets on ESPN. And at 8:37 on ESPN, the San Francisco Giants hope to kick-start another year of Even Year Magic as they wrap up their series against the Los Angeles Dodgers, who came within one victory of winning the World Series last year. Rich Hill, who started two World Series games, gets the ball for Los Angeles.\n\nBEVERLY HILLS DOG SHOW 6 p.m. on USA. Despite protests at other events, expect to see lots of fur on the red carpet.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIN ICE COLD BLOOD 7 p.m. on Oxygen. As Fin Tutuola on \u201cLaw & Order: Special Victims Unit,\u201d Ice-T has spent a lot of time around crime scenes and corpses. He turns his attention to real victims in this new series, which spotlights crimes involving sex, money, and murder through interviews, archival footage and re-enactments. Is it any good? Well, this writer would prefer not to draw Ice-T\u2019s ire toward critics, as seen in a recent Twitter outburst: \u201cCriticizing things??! Is the EASIEST job in the world. It\u2019s [sic] takes NO talent what so ever,\u201d he wrote on Wednesday. So you\u2019ll have to watch to find out for yourself.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE CHILD IN TIME 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Benedict Cumberbatch has built a huge fanbase and drawn accolades for playing emotionless and highly poised characters, as in \u201cSherlock\u201d and \u201cThe Imitation Game.\u201d He plunges into a character with the opposite characteristics in this adaptation of Ian McEwan\u2019s 1987 novel. He plays Stephen Lewis, a writer whose daughter disappears; he and his wife (Kelly Macdonald) struggle to cope with the trauma, and he is soon besieged by memory jumps and hallucinations that leave him with a shaky grasp on reality.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nROSEANNE on Amazon Prime. \u201cFuller House\u201d didn\u2019t get nearly as many headlines. The reboot of Roseanne Barr\u2019s family sitcom stormed to the center of the country\u2019s culture war last week, as the first episode drew huge ratings and earned a congratulatory call from the president. Return to earlier, less contentious times by binging the original nine seasons. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "An officer and a killer play cat and mouse in \u201cKilling Eve.\u201d And the limited series \u201cHowards End\u201d arrives on Starz.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nKILLING EVE 8 p.m. on BBC America. This new eight-part thriller series stars Sandra Oh as Eve, a restless MI5 security officer who craves more action than her desk job demands. When a Russian politician is slain in Vienna, Eve must keep a witness under her watch as the killer remains on the lam. A few clues soon lead Eve to her suspect, Villanelle (Jodie Comer), a formidable assassin who traverses the globe assigned to take down one hopeless victim at a time, all while Eve studies her every move. This suspense drama, based on the novellas by Luke Jennings, has already been approved for a second season.\n\nAERIAL CITIES 8 p.m. on Smithsonian. The documentary series \u201cAerial America\u201d has presented bird\u2019s-eye views of the 50 states and their notable landmarks. This spinoff series borrows that approach, focusing on six metropolises with landscapes and skyscrapers best seen from above, beginning with Las Vegas. The premiere of a third spinoff series \u2014 \u201cAERIAL AFRICA\u201d \u2014 follows at 9.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Killing Eve\u2019 and \u2018Howards End\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAnthony Bourdain heads to Trump Country in a new season of \u201cParts Unknown.\u201d And watch one of opera\u2019s fastest-rising stars in performance at the Met.\n\nWhat\u2019s On TV\n\nANTHONY BOURDAIN: PARTS UNKNOWN 9 p.m. on CNN. In the 11th season of this food travel show, Mr. Bourdain will travel to exotic locales like Uruguay, Armenia and Bhutan. But his first stop is squarely in the mainland: he heads to Trump Country in West Virginia. There, he descends down a 5,000-foot mineshaft, chats with locals about their political views and samples the Appalachian cuisine, which includes \u201csnapping turtle patties, squirrel gravy, pawpaw ice cream, spaghetti pie and bear meat.\u201d\n\nAVENGERS MARATHON on FX. This week, the Times sent writer Jason Bailey to watch all 18 Marvel movies \u2014 for 31 hours straight. \u201cIt turns out the messiness of \u2018Age of Ultron\u2019 is done no favors by viewing it through bleary eyes between five-minute naps,\u201d he tweeted in hour 17. You can approximate his heroic feat on Sunday, starting with \u201cThor: The Dark World\u201d at 11 a.m., in which Thor (Chris Hemsworth) teams up with his brother Loki (Tom Hiddleston). Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.) tracks down a mysterious villain named the Mandarin in \u201cIron Man 3,\u201d at 1:30 p.m. Interstellar high jinks ensue over a 70s rock soundtrack in \u201cGuardians of the Galaxy\u201d at 4:30, and the mammoth \u201cThe Avengers\u201d wraps things up at 7.\n\nPhoto\n\nGREAT PERFORMANCES AT THE MET 12 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). The soprano Pretty Yende, one of opera\u2019s fastest-rising stars, will take on the challenging title role of Donizetti\u2019s \u201cLucia di Lammermoor\u201d at the Metropolitan Opera next month. Her performance as Adina in the Met\u2019s \u201cL\u2019Elisir d\u2019Amore\u201d from a couple months ago streams on Sunday. \u201cMs. Yende sang beautifully from the start, gaining warmth and depth as nonchalance and flirtatiousness developed into love,\u201d James R. Oestreich wrote in his New York Times review in January. Matthew Polenzani co-stars as Nemorino.\n\nWESTWORLD 9 p.m. on HBO. The robo-women Dolores (Evan Rachel Wood) and Maeve (Thandie Newton) are each on their own quests for truth and independence. They meet again in this episode, which is titled \u201cReunion.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nAGGRETSUKO on Netflix. \u201cMy new favorite cartoon character is a white-collar red panda with anger issues,\u201d Amanda Hess wrote in a Times critic\u2019s notebook last summer. She was referring to Aggretsuko, a panda created by Sanrio, the Japanese company that made Hello Kitty. But whereas Hello Kitty is docile and friendly, Aggretsuko flies into rages \u2014 complete with wailing heavy metal music \u2014 against the inanity and repetition of her workplace. \u201cAggretsuko\u2019s experience surely resonates with many young women who have come up against the sexist, or just plain dehumanizing, demands of corporate culture as they embark on careers,\u201d Ms. Hess wrote. The original bite-sized episodes, released in one-minute segments, have been upgraded to 15-minute portions on Netflix \u2014 still easily digestible for your daily dose of fury.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Parts Unknown\u2019 and an Avengers Marathon", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWestworld\u201d returns with more violence and mystery. And Savannah Guthrie talks with gymnasts who say they were abused by Lawrence G. Nassar, the former U.S.A. Gymnastics team doctor who is serving time in prison for multiple sex crimes.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nWESTWORLD 9 p.m. on HBO. These violent delights have returned. The future-historical epic is back for Season 2, with robo-women like Dolores (Evan Rachel Wood) and Maeve (Thandie Newton) in full rebellion. The show will also expand geographically, with a glimpse at an area of the park based on Edo-period Japan. \u201c\u2018Westworld\u2019 remains a glorious production to look at,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in his New York Times review, adding that the show is \u201c50 percent better when it takes itself 25 percent less seriously.\u201d (And catch up on the many plotlines with our refresher on Watching.)\n\nDATELINE: SILENT NO MORE 7 p.m. on NBC. The Karolyi Ranch in Texas used to be associated with glory, serving as the training ground for countless gold-medal-winning American gymnasts. But the ranch was one of the places that a team doctor, Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, had molested gymnasts. In this special, Savannah Guthrie travels to the ranch \u2014 which will no longer be used by U.S.A. Gymnastics \u2014 to talk with its owners, Bela and Martha Karolyi, who have been accused by at least one gymnast of enabling Mr. Nassar but have denied any wrongdoing. Ms. Guthrie will also talk with the gymnasts McKayla Maroney, who will speak out for the first time about Mr. Nassar, and Aly Raisman.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: \u2018Westworld\u2019 and \u2018Into the Badlands\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOlivia Pope drinks her last glass of red on the finale of \u201cScandal.\u201d And some extremely bad bakers compete on \u201cNailed It!\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nSCANDAL 10 p.m. on ABC. \u201cWe are going to handle the end the way we like to handle the important things in our \u2018Scandal\u2019 family: all together, white hats on, Gladiators running full speed over a cliff,\u201d Shonda Rhimes told The Hollywood Reporter last year. After seven seasons, the Washington soap opera will arrive at its last twist, as the Gladiators make a sacrifice to take down Cyrus and Jake. Afterward, Ms. Rhimes and the rest of the cast head to JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! at 11:35 p.m. to reflect on the show\u2019s legacy.\n\nMEET THE FOCKERS (2004) 8 p.m. on E! or streaming on Netflix. The drama surrounding Michael D. Cohen has produced parodies and punch lines, but perhaps none as unlikely as: \u201cI have nipples. Can you milk me, Mr. Cohen?\u201d That line, said by Robert De Niro (playing Robert Mueller) to Ben Stiller (Mr. Cohen) on \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d last week, was a homage to their lengthy history together as antagonists in the \u201cFockers\u201d film trilogy. The second movie in the series, \u201cMeet the Fockers,\u201d received mixed reviews but became a box-office smash and the highest-grossing film of Mr. De Niro\u2019s career; it depicts a disastrous meeting of in-laws, with Dustin Hoffman and Barbra Streisand in the cast.\n\nPhoto\n\nSHAUN THE SHEEP MOVIE (2015) 8 p.m. on Nickelodeon. If you\u2019re looking for a movie with minimal spoken dialogue you can go to a theater to see \u201cA Quiet Place,\u201d John Krasinski\u2019s agonizingly suspenseful thriller \u2014 or you can stay home and watch this charming stop-motion movie from Aardman Animations. It is filled with bleats, squeaks and grunts; it is about Shaun, a mischievous sheep who rebels against his farmer and sends him packing to the city, only to realize that his flock\u2019s life is better with someone who can reach their feed. Neil Genzlinger named it a Critic\u2019s Pick.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nNAILED IT! on Netflix. There are so many high-stakes food competition shows that one would inevitably come along to cut against the grain. Well, here it is: \u201cNailed It!\u201d is like \u201cThe Great British Bake Off\u201d \u2014 if the contestants didn\u2019t know how to bake. Amateur bakers take stabs at recreating lavish wedding cakes and other decorative sweets; the results often look less than appetizing. The host, Nicole Byer, gleefully walks the line between encouraging her optimistic contestants and then dunking on them when their woeful creations emerge from the oven.\n\nMONEY HEIST on Netflix. This Spanish-language series follows a heist at the Royal Mint of Spain, as a mastermind assembles a group of high-level thieves to carry out a multiday siege. \u201cIt\u2019s often as tense and exciting as early-era \u2018Lost,\u2019\u201d Margaret Lyons wrote on Watching.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: The \u2018Scandal\u2019 Finale and \u2018Nailed It!\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDwyane Wade and Gabrielle Union enter the Miami real estate business in \u201cAll-Star Flip.\u201d And \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d tackles DACA.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nALL-STAR FLIP 9:30 on HGTV. When you think of Miami you think of DJ Khaled, Cuban sandwiches, \u201cScarface,\u201d Gloria Estefan \u2014 and of course, Dwyane Wade and Gabrielle Union. The basketball player and actress practically embody the city\u2019s sunshine and glamour; they returned to Wade County after Mr. Wade was traded back to the Miami Heat in February. (Ms. Union responded ecstatically to the move on Twitter.) In this new special, the couple leave their mark on the city by entering the real estate business: They buy, overhaul and flip a house, with proceeds of the sale going to charity.\n\nTHE GREEN MILE (1999) 7 p.m. on AMC. This Stephen King adaptation was nominated for four Oscars, including best picture. It stars Tom Hanks, who was in the midst of a remarkable three-year stretch that also included \u201cSaving Private Ryan,\u201d \u201cCast Away\u201d and \u201cToy Story 2.\u201d He plays Paul Edgecomb, a death-row corrections officer during the Depression, as supernatural events begin to wreak havoc in the prison. Janet Maslin wrote in her review in The New York Times that Mr. Hanks \u201cis so unaffectedly good that it has become redundant to say so.\u201d\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nGREY\u2019S ANATOMY 8 p.m. on ABC. An agent from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement searches Seattle Grace Hospital for an intern who might be a Dreamer, an undocumented immigrant who arrived in the country as a child. Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) and Bailey (Chandra Wilson) work to protect the intern. On the penultimate episode of SCANDAL, at 10, Mellie (Bellamy Young) continues to defend against accusations that she tried to have Cyrus (Jeff Perry) killed. Olivia (Kerry Washington) is called to testify.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nTERRACE HOUSE on Netflix. On its face, this Japanese reality show couldn\u2019t seem more mundane. Six Japanese men and women enter a pristine house and live there together, carrying on their ordinary routines; there\u2019s no flipping of chairs or blindside betrayals. But the show is an engrossing study of modern Japanese culture and human character, as participants navigate tense relationships within the house and their fame on social media. \u201cEven the most anodyne interaction teeters on the edge of absurdity,\u201d Amanda Hess wrote in Watching. A new season set in Karuizawa, Japan, was recently added to Netflix; previous stints in Tokyo and Hawaii remain available for bingeing.\n\nPhoto\n\nFALLET on Netflix. From \u201cThe Killing\u201d to \u201cThe Bridge\u201d to \u201cMissing,\u201d the Nordic noir genre seems to be multiplying faster than the resolute pace of its shows. This new series could at first be mistaken for another addition to the canon, but really it seeks to knock the self-serious genre down a peg through parody. It has all the tropes \u2014 mismatched police partners, prying small-town reporters, gruesome murder \u2014 but everyone is bad at their job. Margaret Lyons called it a \u201cmasterly sendup\u201d in Watching.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018All-Star Flip\u2019 and \u2018Terrace House\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "The cast of the \u201cJersey Shore\u201d returns, older but maybe not wiser, to hit up the Miami club scene. And watch two gory Brian De Palma films that recently arrived on streaming services.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nMOM 9 p.m. on CBS. In days past, an actor might have had to choose between work in television and movies. Yet here\u2019s Allison Janney, in award-winning roles in films (she just won an Oscar for \u201cI, Tonya\u201d) while holding down a day job at one of television\u2019s most reliably funny sitcoms, \u201cMom.\u201d Her character, Bonnie, a recovering alcoholic and drug addict, struggles to be the stable one in her relationship after her fianc\u00e9, Adam, experiences a devastating loss.\n\nWRESTLEMANIA\u2019S GREATEST MOMENTS 8 p.m. on USA. It was almost happily ever after for the secret agents Alex (Priyanka Chopra) and Ryan (Jake McLaughlin) at the end of the previous season of \u201cQuantico,\u201d as they escaped to Italy after helping to take down a power-hungry president. But as the third season begins on Thursday with the action picking up three years later, Alex has forged a new life in Italy with someone else. Of course, the stasis won\u2019t last long, as Ryan recruits her to rescue Shelby (Johanna Braddy) from a notorious international arms dealer. And Marlee Matlin joins the cast.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nMARVEL\u2019S THE AVENGERS (2012) 7 p.m. on FX. Compared with \u201cAvengers: Infinity War,\u201d which arrives on Friday, the scope and cast of the original \u201cAvengers\u201d look paltry. But compared with any other movie, \u201cAvengers\u201d is an absolute behemoth, effectively combining characters from four different franchises into one. Captain America, Thor, the Hulk, Iron Man and other warriors team up to battle the Norse god Loki, who has acquired a dangerous weapon. In his New York Times review, A. O. Scott wrote that the movie\u2019s best scenes weren\u2019t the action sequences but the \u201cmoments in between, when the assembled heroes have the opportunity to brag, banter, flirt and bicker.\u201d And at 11:35, some of the actors in \u201cInfinity War\u201d \u2014 Don Cheadle, Benedict Cumberbatch, Elizabeth Olsen, Winston Duke \u2014 stop by to chat on JIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! on ABC.\n\nNFL DRAFT 8 p.m. on Fox and ESPN. The perpetually ill-fated Cleveland Browns have the first pick in this year\u2019s draft. They need a quarterback, but which one will they take \u2014 Sam Darnold, Josh Allen or someone else?\n\nGREY\u2019S ANATOMY 8 p.m. on ABC. The resilient Shondaland show was just picked up for a 15th season \u2014 the same number as \u201cER,\u201d the longest-running prime-time medical drama. In this episode, the hospital brings in crisis management when a prominent patron is accused of sexual harassment.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nFRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS on Hulu and Amazon Prime. \u201cRise,\u201d a high school musical drama from a \u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d executive producer, Jason Katims, has received mixed reviews in its first season. It\u2019s probably a safer bet to go straight to his former project, which burrows into the lives of a Texas town\u2019s residents with stunning empathy. After being dropped from Netflix last year, the show popped back up recently on Amazon Prime and Hulu. It\u2019s organized around a high school football team, but its focus isn\u2019t really on the sport so much as on the relationships between the people surrounding it. These include the stoic Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) and his wife, Tami (Connie Britton), who serves as the school\u2019s guidance counselor.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Quantico\u2019 and the N.F.L. Draft", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "The superhero series \u201cBlack Lightning\u201d wraps up its first season. And an expectant couple riff on their pre-parenthood anxieties in a new stand-up special.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nBLACK LIGHTNING 9 p.m. on CW. Last week\u2019s brawl between Tobias (Marvin Jones III) and Black Lightning (Cress Williams) left the middle-aged superhero vulnerable. That is until his daughter Jennifer (China Anne McClain) harnessed her superpowers to rescue him. In this season finale of the DC Comics-inspired show, the town Freeland is still shaken by the epic battle. But Tobias hasn\u2019t had enough just yet. Reflecting on the series\u2019 mainly African-American cast in The New York Times, James Poniewozik wrote, \u201c\u2018Luke Cage\u2019 and \u2018Marvel\u2019s Runaways\u2019 have diversified the comics-TV lineup.\u201d But, he adds, \u201cThis show\u2019s race-forward sensibility and its older protagonist, conflicted about getting back into the game, give \u2018Black Lightning\u2019 its spark.\u201d\n\nCIVILIZATIONS 8 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This new series examines the role of art since the first sign of human creativity emerged thousands of years ago. It highlights wondrous works throughout history and across cultures, exploring the idea that creative imagination is what makes us human. This premiere looks at creations looted from Palmyra, in present-day Syria, and decorative artifacts found in South African caves.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Black Lightning\u2019 and \u2018The Honeymoon Stand Up Special\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAntonio Banderas stars as Pablo Picasso in the second season of \u201cGenius.\u201d And \u201cThe Ice Cream Show\u201d has its premiere on Viceland.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nGENIUS: PICASSO 9 p.m. on National Geographic. Critics were impressed with this anthology series when it began last year. The first season dramatized the life of Albert Einstein in 10 parts; the second puts Pablo Picasso under the microscope. Antonio Banderas stars as Picasso, whom we meet as he is painting his most famous work, \u201cGuernica.\u201d Alex Rich portrays a rebellious, younger Picasso, who rejects the limits of academic discipline to find his own path. Mr. Banderas told The New York Times that playing Picasso had long been a dream role for which he studiously prepared: \u201cI\u2019ve been with him now for months every day and I can just actually say, \u2018O.K., come over here.\u2019\u201d\n\nTHE 100 9 p.m. on CW. In Season 1, 100 juvenile-delinquent teenagers were sent to Earth a century after a nuclear apocalypse to see whether it was inhabitable again. By the end of the fourth season, an impending nuclear apocalypse was threatening to ravage the planet yet again, separating the inhabitants who did the unthinkable to make it their home. Season 5 opens six years later. Clarke (Eliza Taylor) struggles to survive on the isolated Earth, but things are looking up for her friends in space.\n\nTHE ICE CREAM SHOW 10:30 p.m. on Viceland; also on Viceland.com. Who doesn\u2019t love ice cream? The ice cream maker Isaac Lappert proves that the business of the frosty dessert is alive and thriving, but running a successful company takes more than out-of-this-world flavors and mountains of toppings. Mr. Lappert tours the country in search of gooey goodness that sells, starting with the flagship store of his family\u2019s business, Lappert\u2019s Ice Cream. He then visits Jeni\u2019s Splendid Ice Creams in Los Angeles and explores the original Ben & Jerry\u2019s factory in Waterbury, Vt., with the help of a tour guide. (Yes, that job exists.)\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nFILM STARS DON\u2019T DIE IN LIVERPOOL (2017) on iTunes, Amazon, FandangoNow, Google Play, Vudu and YouTube. This drama captures the real-life romance between Peter Turner (Jamie Bell) and the Oscar-winning actress Gloria Grahame (Annette Bening). Despite an age difference of nearly 30 years, Mr. Turner won over Ms. Grahame\u2019s heart in the last years of her life, becoming a savior of sorts when she fell ill. Jeannette Catsoulis named the film a Critic\u2019s Pick in her review for The Times and argued that, as marvelous as Ms. Bening is, \u201cit\u2019s Mr. Bell who might be the film\u2019s greatest surprise.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKEVIN JAMES: NEVER DON\u2019T GIVE UP (2018) on Netflix. Kevin James\u2019s characters in \u201cKing of Queens\u201d and \u201cKevin Can Wait\u201d embody the trite role of the American sitcom dad: predictable, sarcastic and uninspiring. (That may change with the single-parent plotline of \u201cKevin Can Wait,\u201d but don\u2019t hold your breath.) Though family-friendly, this stand-up special lets Mr. James show his true colors. He draws from his parenting mishaps to deliver self-deprecating one-liners.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Genius: Picasso\u2019 and \u2018The Ice Cream Show\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe endearing ensemble comedy \u201cNew Girl\u201d returns for its final season. And a new documentary examines the many sides of the pro wrestler Andr\u00e9 the Giant.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nNEW GIRL 9:30 p.m. on Fox. When the creator of this sitcom, Elizabeth Meriwether, was told that Season 6 may be the show\u2019s last, she wrote a finale that could serve as a definitive ending or a precursor to one more run. And she wrapped that season up on a high note. (Major spoiler alert!) Winston (Lamorne Morris) and Aly (Nasim Pedrad) became engaged; Schmidt (Max Greenfield) and Cece (Hannah Simone) discovered they\u2019re expecting; and Jess (Zooey Deschanel) and Nick (Jake Johnson) finally admitted their feelings for each other. The seventh and final season picks up three years later, and the group has sure grown up: Jess and Nick have just completed a European book tour; Cece and a mustachioed Schmidt are raising their daughter; and the now-married Winston and Aly have a child on the way.\n\nSECRETS OF THE DEAD: HANNIBAL IN THE ALPS (2018) 8 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). For years, historians have scratched their heads over which route the Carthaginian general Hannibal took across the Alps to invade Rome during the Second Punic War. With newfound evidence, a team of experts proves that Hannibal led his army of 25,000 infantry, 6,000 cavalry and 37 elephants through the Col de la Traversette, the highest and most treacherous of the four possible paths.\n\nELTON JOHN: I\u2019M STILL STANDING \u2014 A GRAMMY SALUTE 9 p.m. on CBS. Lady Gaga, John Legend and other pop stars honor the musician behind hits like \u201cRocket Man\u201d and \u201cTiny Dancer\u201d in this Elton John tribute concert. Mr. John also gets behind a piano to perform a few classics. This special comes days after the release of two tribute albums, the pop record \u201cRevamp\u201d and its country counterpart \u201cRestoration,\u201d which celebrate Mr. John\u2019s decades-long career.\n\nPhoto\n\nANDRE THE GIANT (2018) 10 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. Andr\u00e9 Ren\u00e9 Roussimoff, the French wrestler who joined the World Wrestling Federation in the 1970s, died of heart failure at 46 in 1993. He was best known for his intimidating 500-pound, 7-foot-4-inch frame. But this new documentary directed by Jason Hehir goes beyond Mr. Roussimoff\u2019s eye-catching appearance, focusing instead on his upbringing in France, his unforgettable wrestling career and the emotional and physical distress brought on by the hormonal disorder that gave him his size.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nHOURS (2013) on iTunes and Amazon.
