The cast includes Jason Segel, Condola Rashad, Martin Sheen and Danny Glover.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Wednesday: \u2018The Originals\u2019 and \u2018The Wine Show\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. My cold is better, but I can\u2019t stop coughing. Isn\u2019t there a cold medicine that works?\n\nA. The search for an effective cough medicine can be frustrating.\n\nAmericans spend $8 billion a year on over-the-counter cough and cold products, yet there is little evidence that they suppress coughs. The American College of Chest Physicians underscored this point bluntly in 2017: \u201cFor adult and pediatric patients with cough due to the common cold, we suggest against the use of over-the-counter cough and cold medicines until they have been shown to make cough less severe or resolve sooner.\u201d\n\nWhen over-the-counter products fail, cough sufferers often look for \u201csomething stronger\u201d \u2014 namely codeine, widely regarded as the standard by which cough medicines are measured. Much of the interest in codeine dates from a 1950 experiment, unlikely to be undertaken today, in which 17 Swedish medical students agreed to inhale ammonia fumes. The cough that ensued was modestly ameliorated by pretreatment with escalating doses of codeine.\n\nBut a subsequent double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of 82 patients with upper respiratory infections found that the drug was \u201cno more effective than placebo,\u201d and some experts have labeled the cough-suppressing effect of codeine a \u201cmedical myth.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCodeine has a chemically similar cousin, dextromethorphan \u2014 the \u201cDM\u201d component of many cough medicines. But a systematic review concluded that dextromethorphan was about as good as honey at reducing cough frequency. Both codeine and dextromethorphan carry the potential for abuse and have serious side effects that have led to warnings from the Food and Drug Administration.\n\nSo what to do for a persistent cough after a cold? Stay hydrated, use a humidifier, and be patient. A cough from a cold will usually resolve within three weeks. You could also try honey, as it seems to be as effective as over-the-counter products. But don\u2019t cough up money for unproven and potentially unsafe medications.", "title": "What\u2019s the Best Medicine for a Cough?", "authors": ["Richard Klasco", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "These days almost everyone has the (justified) sense that America is coming apart at the seams. But this isn\u2019t a new story, or just about politics. Things have been falling apart on multiple fronts since the 1970s: Political polarization has marched side by side with economic polarization, as income inequality has soared.\n\nAnd both political and economic polarization have a strong geographic dimension. On the economic side, some parts of America, mainly big coastal cities, have been getting much richer, but other parts have been left behind. On the political side, the thriving regions by and large voted for Hillary Clinton, while the lagging regions voted for Donald Trump.\n\nI\u2019m not saying that everything is great in coastal cities: Many people remain economically stranded even within metropolitan areas that look successful in the aggregate. And soaring housing costs, thanks in large part to Nimbyism, are a real and growing problem. Still, regional economic divergence is real and correlates closely, though not perfectly, with political divergence.\n\nBut what\u2019s behind this divergence? What\u2019s the matter with Trumpland?\n\nRegional disparities aren\u2019t a new phenomenon in America. Indeed, before World War II the world\u2019s richest, most productive nation was also a nation with millions of dirt-poor farmers, many of whom didn\u2019t even have electricity or indoor plumbing. But until the 1970s those disparities were rapidly narrowing.", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s the Matter With Trumpland?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "None of these people actually had family members who needed assisted living. They were testers, professional actors working for the nonprofit Fair Housing Justice Center to investigate whether such facilities discriminate against wheelchair users.\n\nExcerpts from their recorded conversations are included in a federal lawsuit filed against those centers, claiming they discriminate against people in wheelchairs and are violating the Fair Housing Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act and other federal laws.\n\n\u201cPeople were being threatened with eviction, or actually evicted, for even part-time use of a wheelchair,\u201d said Fred Freiberg, director of the anti-discrimination group, which brought the suit after receiving complaints from residents and families.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s outrageous. They were told, \u2018If you\u2019re going to use a wheelchair, you can\u2019t live here anymore.\u2019\u201d\n\nRelated cases have popped up for years in senior housing nationwide, including continuing care retirement communities. In 2015, for instance, the Justice Department reached settlements with a continuing care facility in Norfolk, Va., and one in Lincolnshire, Ill., for discriminating against residents with disabilities.\n\nUnlike nursing homes, which are subject to federal regulations and regular inspections, assisted and independent living facilities operate under widely varying state laws.\n\nOklahoma and Alabama require residents to be \u201cambulatory,\u201d for instance, but Kentucky allows admission of the \u201cmobile nonambulatory,\u201d meaning people who use walkers or wheelchairs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMany states have similar policies, though with different language, like \u2018must be able to self-evacuate,\u2019 which is often interpreted to mean \u2018no wheelchairs,\u2019\u201d said Susan Silverstein, a senior lawyer for the AARP Foundation, which is representing the plaintiffs. \u201cFacilities often justify their policies by citing state laws that are ambiguous.\u201d\n\nAdministrators of the facilities named in the New York lawsuit, including Elm York Assisted Living and Madison York Assisted Living, (which share ownership with the other residence in Queens), often cited state laws as reasons to exclude wheelchair users, according to the complaint.\n\nAnd in this case, they appear to be correct. New York State regulations governing \u201cadult care facilities\u201d and Medicaid-funded assisted living programs, which all four facilities are licensed to offer, do prohibit residents who are \u201cchronically chairfast and unable to transfer\u201d or require assistance to transfer \u2014 even when, as in this case, the buildings have elevators.\n\nThose 40-year-old policies predate the federal laws barring discrimination based on disability, but the state has not revised them.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor that reason, the lawsuit also names the state health department and commissioner, plus Gov. Andrew Cuomo, as defendants.\n\nNeither the governor\u2019s office nor the four assisted living facilities would comment.\n\nThe state\u2019s health department said it considered \u201creasonable wheelchair accessibility\u201d in adult homes a priority and that it began working with existing homes last year on \u201cremediation plans that include appropriate upgrades.\u201d Newly constructed adult homes, it noted, must comply with federal, state and local accessibility requirements.\n\nThe suit asks that the four facilities adopt nondiscriminatory admission and retention policies, and that the state update its regulations to reflect federal law. It also seeks training and monitoring to ensure compliance.\n\nWhile administrators might still turn away applicants for individual reasons, they couldn\u2019t maintain blanket rules against wheelchairs. \u201cThere\u2019s going to be a much larger number of people in the next few years who will need assisted living, and those facilities need to be open to people,\u201d Mr. Freiberg said.\n\nAlthough the assisted living industry mainly attracts people who are paying for the care themselves, \u201cthe percentage covered by Medicaid is growing,\u201d said Eric Carlson, a lawyer at Justice in Aging, an advocacy group not involved in the lawsuit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA recent Government Accountability Office report pointed out that in 2014, Medicaid covered assisted-living services for more than 330,000 people in 48 states \u2014 part of the effort to support alternatives to expensive nursing homes.\n\nA favorable settlement or trial verdict in the New York lawsuit could bring changes in assisted living beyond Medicaid programs and beyond New York State. \u201cPrivate-pay assisted living is still subject to the Fair Housing Act,\u201d said Jota Borgmann, senior staff lawyer at Mobilization for Justice, a legal services organization and co-counsel in the case.\n\nSimilar court cases have already changed assisted living regulations and practices around the country, Mr. Carlson pointed out. \u201cIt\u2019s not like flipping a switch,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s step by step, but they have impact.\u201d\n\nWhile the relatives that testers described to administrators were fictitious, a retired lawyer in her 60s, known in court filings only as Jane Doe because she feared she might be blackballed from care facilities, is quite real. She\u2019s also a plaintiff in the lawsuit, along with her brother, who acts as her power of attorney.\n\nDisabled by severe osteoporosis, the plaintiff lived at VillageCare for five years, until last spring when a urinary tract infection and its complications sent her to a hospital, then to a nursing home for rehabilitation.\n\nAfter two months, according to the complaint, VillageCare told her she needed more assistance than it could provide, including help with \u201cambulation,\u201d and told her she could not return. It began eviction proceedings, which her brother contested.\n\nIn December, the facility agreed to an in-person interview and assessment. The session \u2014 including cognitive tests, sitting and standing, and taking her shoes on and off \u2014 lasted four hours.\n\n\u201cIt was grueling,\u201d said her brother, who traveled from his Florida home to accompany her. \u201cIt was a very difficult thing, but my sister did it. She walked with her walker just fine.\u201d\n\nBut VillageCare refused to readmit her, saying she needed assistance with activities of daily living, including \u201clocomotion.\u201d So she remains in a nursing home, where she is discouraged from walking at all, and worries that she may never go home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very disheartening,\u201d her brother said. \u201cI keep telling her, \u2018You\u2019re going to be out any day,\u2019 and I\u2019ve been wrong.\u201d", "title": "Wheelchairs Prohibited in the Last Place You\u2019d Expect", "authors": ["Paula Span", "The New Old Age"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "The Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation has helped pay for art and dance classes for thousands of children and opened galleries giving young artists of color, such as Kehinde Wiley, who would later paint the official portrait of Barack Obama, a place to showcase their work.\n\nBut for the first time ever, the foundation is having trouble raising money because its famous co-founder, the hip-hop mogul Russell Simmons, has been accused by several women of rape, allegations that he has denied. The charity\u2019s officials say they may have to end operations in New York, where most of their work is focused, if their fortunes do not improve.\n\n\u201cIt is a shame that there are those who can\u2019t separate accusations against the co-founder from both the good work that the organization does and from the children who need us,\u201d said Richard Slomovitz, the foundation\u2019s treasurer.\n\nThe Kevin Spacey Foundation mentored and trained young performers until several young actors accused Mr. Spacey of sexual misconduct. At the end of February, the charity announced it was shutting down after trustees deemed it \u201cno longer viable.\u201d", "title": "When #MeToo Infamy Taints Your Famous Benefactor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "The current problems for the Windrush-era migrants began in 2012 when the government, with Theresa May as home secretary, cracked down on illegal immigrants, making it necessary for them to document their right to government benefits, including health services. Many people born in Caribbean countries arrived as children on their parents\u2019 passports and had never applied for their own travel or immigration documents; many others took their status for granted.\n\nThe Home Office did not keep records that would have confirmed their status, and a Home Office whistle-blower revealed that thousands of landing cards from the 1950s and \u201960s, which would have confirmed the migrants\u2019 arrival dates, had been destroyed during a move. As The Guardian chronicled in a series of articles, the callousness of the bureaucracy led many to be threatened with deportation, denied health services, fired or left homeless.\n\nMrs. May, now Britain\u2019s prime minister, recently apologized to the many thousands of people affected, but she deserves little credit. As home secretary she set the stage for the scandal by pledging to create a \u201creally hostile environment\u201d for illegal immigrants, and it was only when public outrage soared, and leaders of former British colonies had gathered in London for a Commonwealth meeting, that she said, \u201cWe are genuinely sorry.\u201d\n\nThe British government has now set up a special team to urgently affirm the legal rights of these migrants and reimburse them for their losses. That is the least it should do.\n\nNothing can really compensate them for the hell many went through. Nor do the apology or belated fixes change the fact that this was due to the government\u2019s hostility to immigrants, and especially immigrants of color. The same official hostility can be found in many parts of Europe toward Middle Eastern refugees and in the Trump administration\u2019s policy toward immigrants from Central America.\n\nWhen Mrs. May speaks of creating a hostile environment for immigrants; or Hungary\u2019s prime minister, Viktor Orban, says that with mass immigration \u201cour worst nightmares can come true\u201d; or President Trump describes immigrants as criminals, they feed a hostility that spreads through bureaucracy, law enforcement and the public. And they inflict suffering even on those like the Windrush generation, people who have lived and worked for 50 years in a country they believe to be their own.", "title": "Opinion | When Dark-Skinned Citizens Lose Their Citizenship", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI have recently hired a new employee who is a crucial part of the daily work flow. She needs to communicate with a number of in-house and remote employees. I\u2019d like to be able to have casual work conversations with her during the work day, but she always wears earphones (listening to either music or podcasts). When I walk up to her and begin to talk, she stops, says \u201cWait, what?\u201d and pulls her earphones out. I feel like I need to have something particularly meaningful to say, because now I\u2019ve made her stop all work to hear me. To complicate matters, I sit in a small, private office so I have privacy during the day while she sits in a large room with employees all around her. My short-term solution has been to type back and forth on a messaging system \u2014 but it feels so inefficient and, really, kind of dumb when it\u2019d be quicker to resolve something in 25 (spoken) words or fewer. Recommendations? H.L.\n\nHeadphones and earbuds have of course become exponentially more popular at work as the so-called \u201copen plan\u201d office has spread. Even if collaboration or connection results from that obliteration of workers\u2019 privacy, sometimes we all need to block out everything (and everyone) and concentrate. Thus, as others have observed, for people like your new hire, headphones are the new walls.\n\nBut they can also complicate routine office life. And there are a couple of ways to think about that, depending on the details.\n\nAs a practical matter, interrupting a colleague wearing headphones involves only slightly more effort than interrupting someone who is working without them.\n\nForget the headphones for a moment: You already know that if you just burst into someone\u2019s space and start talking, she might miss the beginning of what you were saying because she was, for instance, completing a thought in an important email, or entering complicated data in a spreadsheet. That\u2019s why you might say, \u201cHey, Smithers?\u201d and wait to be acknowledged before proceeding.", "title": "When Headphones Get in the Way of Office Communication", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "When can I start eating bagged romaine again?\n\nLettuce has a short shelf life and a lot of retailers have taken bagged romaine off shelves. \u201cHopefully with it being in one particular growing region and that region moving to California, it won\u2019t be too much longer,\u201d said Laura Gieraltowski, who leads the C.D.C.\u2019s food-borne outbreak response team. That said, she urged consumers to wait for the all-clear from the C.D.C. before eating chopped romaine.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a fast-moving outbreak,\u201d she said. \u201cWe\u2019re getting reports of new illness daily from our state and local health departments.\u201d\n\nWhy is this outbreak so worrisome?\n\nEscherichia coli is in our intestines, the environment, foods and animals, but most of the time it doesn\u2019t make you sick. However, this particular strain \u2014 Shiga toxin-producing E. coli 0157:H7 \u2014 is particularly dangerous. Symptoms appear from one to 10 days after eating and can vary, but may include severe stomach cramps, bloody diarrhea and vomiting. While the people affected range in age from 10 to 85 years, the median age is 34 \u2014 meaning the bug is making otherwise healthy, strong people really sick. The hospitalization rate for E. coli illness is typically around 30 percent, but this strain has put 67 percent of the cases in the hospital. Five people have developed hemolytic uremic syndrome, a type of kidney failure. Given delays in reporting, those numbers are expected to grow.\n\nThe other concern is that unlike a recent multistate outbreak of salmonella in eggs, which resulted in a recall of a specific egg product, no specific grower, supplier or brand has been identified as the source of the romaine outbreak.\n\nWhere has the outbreak occurred?\n\nInfections linked to the outbreak have been found in 16 states, illustrating how widely bags of romaine are distributed around the country. You can find a list of states where cases have been reported on the C.D.C. website. Most of the reported cases have come from Pennsylvania (12), Idaho (10), New Jersey (7), Montana (6) and Arizona (3). New York, Connecticut, Ohio and Michigan have had two cases each, with one case each in Alaska, California, Illinois, Louisiana, Missouri, Virginia and Washington state.\n\nHow do I know if the greens I\u2019m eating contain romaine?\n\nMost people can\u2019t reliably distinguish romaine from other forms of lettuce, Ms. Halloran said. A head of romaine lettuce is more oblong than the round shape typical of iceberg. \u201cIt\u2019s the one with the pointy football shape,\u201d Ms. Halloran said. \u201cWhen it\u2019s chopped up you\u2019re not going to see that. It\u2019s a bit crunchier and chewier than bibb lettuce. The outer leaves are dark green and the inner leaves are yellow so color isn\u2019t going to tell you. If you\u2019ve had Caesar salad you\u2019ve almost certainly had romaine lettuce.\u201d\n\nWhy does the C.D.C. say it\u2019s O.K. to eat heads and hearts of romaine, but not bagged?\n\nThe documented cases have been linked to bagged romaine eaten at home or in restaurants, not full heads or hearts of lettuce. The lettuce at the source of the outbreak is grown in Arizona for bagged use. The C.D.C. suggests that the contamination is limited to some part of the bagged lettuce supply chain.", "title": "When Is It Safe to Eat Salad Again?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Next, churches can also enjoy the benefits of dark money. Unlike other groups, churches are required to disclose essentially nothing about who or what supplies them with their funds. And Focus on the Family, like a number of other groups on the religious right, may worry that its opposition to same-sex relationships will land it on the wrong side of anti-discrimination law. After all, the \u201cmoral behavior standards\u201d in their employee guidelines prohibit \u201chomosexual acts.\u201d\n\nThe Family Research Council, a close partner that for a time merged with Focus on the Family, is registered as a nonreligious nonprofit, rather than as a church. But one of the council\u2019s principal aims is to convert America\u2019s churches, or at least conservative ones, into partisan political cells. It seeks to place what it calls \u201cculture impact teams\u201d in churches to \u201cadvance Kingdom values in the public arena.\u201d\n\nThe way that Focus on the Family and the Family Research Council see it, the Bible offers specific information about how people ought to vote. Scripture, they say, opposes public assistance on principle (\u201cGod has charged believers to help the poor and widows and orphans,\u201d the council\u2019s culture impact team manual explains). Apparently, the Bible is also against gun control and supports privatization of schools through vouchers. It tells us that same-sex relationships are an abomination.\n\nIt does not want women to have access to comprehensive reproductive care. Environmentalism, according to the source the manual recommends to church groups, is a \u201clitany of the Green Dragon\u201d and \u201cone of the greatest threats to society and the church today.\u201d Other sources the manual recommends promote the notion that the earth is 6,000 years old.\n\nThere is no mystery about which political party the Bible supports, at least as these groups see it. In the run-up to the 2016 election, James Dobson, the founder of Focus on the Family and its former leader, praised Donald Trump and explained that the prospect of a Hillary Clinton presidency \u201cscares me to death.\u201d Their claim that they are nonpartisan is laughable.", "title": "Opinion | When Is a Church Not a Church?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "A liberal can believe that government can do more good or less, and one can debate how much to conserve. But progressivism is inherently hostile to moderation because progress is an unmitigated good. There cannot be too much of it. Like conservative fundamentalism, progressivism contributes to the polarization and paralysis of government because it makes compromise, which entails accepting less progress, not merely inadvisable but irrational. Even when progressives choose their targets strategically \u2014 Hillary Clinton, for example, called herself \u201ca progressive who likes to get things done\u201d \u2014 the implication is that progress is the fundamental goal and that its opponents are atavists.\n\nUnlike liberalism, progressivism is intrinsically opposed to conservation. It renders adhering to tradition unreasonable rather than seeing it, as the liberal can, as a source of wisdom. The British philosopher Roger Scruton calls this a \u201cculture of repudiation\u201d of home and history alike. The critic of progress is not merely wrong but a fool. Progressivism\u2019s critics have long experienced this as a passive-aggressive form of re-education.\n\nBecause progress is an unadulterated good, it supersedes the rights of its opponents. This is evident in progressive indifference to the rights of those who oppose progressive policies in areas like sexual liberation.\n\nThis is one reason progressives have alienated moderate voters who turned to Donald Trump in 2016. The ideology of progress tends to regard the traditions that have customarily bound communities and which mattered to Trump voters alarmed by the rapid transformation of society, as a fatuous rejection of progress. Trump supporters\u2019 denunciation of \u201cpolitical correctness\u201d is just as often a reaction to progressive condescension as it is to identity politics.\n\nWhere liberalism seeks to ameliorate economic ills, progressivism\u2019s goal is to eradicate them. Moynihan recognized this difference between Franklin Roosevelt\u2019s New Deal, which he always supported \u2014 as exemplified by his opposition to Clinton-era welfare reform \u2014 and Lyndon Johnson\u2019s Great Society, which he sympathetically criticized. The New Deal alleviated poverty by cutting checks, something government does competently even if liberals and conservatives argued over the size of the checks. The Great Society partook more of a progressive effort to remake society by eradicating poverty\u2019s causes. The result, Moynihan wrote, was the diversion of resources from welfare and jobs to \u201ccommunity action\u201d programs that financed political activism.", "title": "Opinion | When Liberals Become Progressives, Much Is Lost", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "He looked at me slyly and said, \u201cHow about the Olive Garden?\u201d\n\nI threw my arms around him.\n\nOn the drive, I burped in front of him for the first time. I remember it happening in slow motion, including the part where I cried out \u201cNo!\u201d right after. When I recovered, Joe told me that the first night he stayed at my apartment, I fell asleep on his chest and drooled all over him.\n\nJoe said \u201cI love you\u201d first. I said it back, then retreated into my own head. In all of my scheming before Joe, I had never conceived of a situation in which I would have the power to break someone\u2019s heart. I had assumed the man would have that power and my life would be a constant charm offensive to stop him from using it. I thought when someone said \u201cI love you\u201d to me, it would be the result of my hard work or even trickery.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s going on in that dome of yours?\u201d Joe asked as we stood on my building\u2019s fire escape. This is truly how he speaks.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to say it,\u201d I said.\n\n\u201cYou can say it.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m freaked out because I can imagine a day that I wind up hurting you,\u201d I said. \u201cNot that I have any plans, but the potential exists, and I can\u2019t imagine it the other way around.\u201d This is truly how I speak.\n\nJoe said: \u201cThere\u2019s an episode of \u2018Malcolm in the Middle\u2019 where Lois is upset because Hal loves her a little more than she loves him. He tells her it\u2019s O.K. because two people can\u2019t love each other that much. If they did, they\u2019d never leave the house.\u201d\n\nWe had one big fight that first year. I was dusting a ceiling fan in his apartment and he got angry that I was doing it in his prized Black Sabbath T-shirt. I stormed out of the apartment and walked to the subway.", "title": "When Love Seems Too Easy to Trust", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re familiar with grim stories about black-shirted federal agents barging into apartment complexes, convenience stores and school pickup sites to round up and deport immigrants. We\u2019ve heard far less about the forced labor \u2014 some call it slavery \u2014 inside detention facilities. But new legal challenges to these practices are succeeding and may stymie the government\u2019s deportation agenda by taking profits out of the detention business.\n\nYes, detention is a business. In 2010, private prisons and their lenders and investors lobbied Congress to pass a law ordering Immigration and Customs Enforcement to maintain contracts for no fewer than 34,000 beds per night. This means that when detention counts are low, people who would otherwise be released because they pose no danger or flight risk and are likely to win their cases in immigration court remain locked up, at a cost to the government of about $125 a day.\n\nThe people detained at these facilities do almost all of the work that keeps them running, outside of guard duty. That includes cooking, serving and cleaning up food, janitorial services, laundry, haircutting, painting, floor buffing and even vehicle maintenance. Most jobs pay $1 a day; some work they are required to do pays nothing.\n\nWorkers in immigration custody have suffered injuries and even died. In 2007, Cesar Gonzalez was killed in a facility in Los Angeles County when his jackhammer hit an electrical cable, sending 10,000 volts of direct current through his body. He was on a crew digging holes for posts to extend the camp\u2019s perimeter.", "title": "Opinion | When Migrants Are Treated Like Slaves", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "And now, in the aftermath of the attack in Toronto, men on incel communities are hailing the killer as a \u201cnew saint,\u201d with commenters changing their avatars to Mr. Minassian\u2019s picture in tribute.\n\nFeminists have been warning against these online hate groups and their propensity for real-life violence for over a decade. I know because I\u2019m one of the people who has been issuing increasingly dire warnings. After I started a feminist blog in 2004, I became a target of men\u2019s-rights groups who were angry with women about everything from custody battles to the false notion that most women lie about rape. In 2011, I had to flee my house with my young daughter on the advice of law enforcement, because one of these groups put me on a \u201cregistry\u201d of women to target.\n\nI was far from the only one. In 2014, a gaming award ceremony set to honor the feminist critic Anita Sarkeesian received a bomb threat; an anonymous harasser threatened to detonate a device unless her award was rescinded. Before Milo Yiannopoulos was a well-known alt-right figure, feminists knew him as one of the primary architects of Gamergate, a movement of young men who harassed and threatened women in the videogaming industry. Two fans of Mr. Yiannopoulos were charged with shooting a protester outside of one of his speeches.\n\nPart of the problem is that American culture still largely sees men\u2019s sexism as something innate rather than deviant. And in a world where sexism is deemed natural, the misogynist tendencies of mass shooters become afterthoughts rather than predictable and stark warnings.\n\nThe truth is that in addition to not protecting women, we are failing boys: failing to raise them to believe they can be men without inflicting pain on others, failing to teach them that they are not entitled to women\u2019s sexual attention and failing to allow them an outlet for understandable human fear and foibles that will not label them \u201cweak\u201d or unworthy.\n\nNot every attack is preventable, but the misogyny that drives them is. To stop all of this, we must trust women when they point out that receiving streams of death threats on Twitter is not normal and that online communities strategizing about how to rape women are much more than just idle chatter. There is no reason another massacre should happen.", "title": "Opinion | When Misogynists Become Terrorists", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "One of the earliest appearances of the muses was in a narrative poem called \u201cTheogony\u201d by the Greek poet Hesiod, who wrote around 700 B.C. that they were nine sisters born of Zeus and his lover Mnemosyne, or memory. Of them he wrote, \u201cthey plucked and gave me a rod, a shoot of sturdy laurel, a marvelous thing, and breathed into me a divine voice.\u201d Homer invoked the muse for his epic poem (\u201cSing to me of the man, Muse\u201d) as did Virgil. Over time, the muse became a less incantatory figure and more of a sexual one: The word is commonly used, for example, as a shorthand for the many wives and lovers Pablo Picasso captured in his work. With the rise of the model as celebrity in the latter half of the 20th century, the muse became more objectified. She could be the woman a fashion designer trusted to wear his clothes, both on and off the runway. Or she could be a figure of whom a world-famous photographer\u2019s lens never tired. These women and their looks \u2014 from Misia Sert\u2019s bohemian opulence at the turn of the last century to Twiggy\u2019s sprightly boyishness in the 1960s \u2014 can be as much an expression of their times as their era\u2019s music, literature or even politics.\n\nIn the early \u201980s, model-muses became as famous as the artists they inspired, paving the way for the supers of the subsequent decade such as Naomi Campbell, Cindy Crawford and Kate Moss. Today, the industry\u2019s commercial interests have transformed the role of the muse into something much more lucrative, but during the careers of models like Pat Cleveland and Alva Chinn, the relationship between model and designer was born more out of a sense of simpatico. Cleveland and Chinn were two of the first women of color to be photographed for mainstream fashion magazines and to walk the runways for major designers like Yves Saint Laurent and Karl Lagerfeld. Both, too, walked in the Battle of Versailles (a kind of fashion face-off between French and American designers in 1973) for the African-American designer Stephen Burrows, whose color-blocked, lettuce-edged dresses represented the free-spirited disco nights of the time. Cleveland said she\u2019d often be given clothes \u201cto go out dancing in the evening to see if they last through the night.\u201d", "title": "When Models Became as Famous as the Artists they Inspired", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 When the leaders of the world\u2019s two most populous nations meet on Friday in the Chinese city of Wuhan, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India will be pushing to get less from President Xi Jinping of China.\n\nLess trouble like the embarrassing territorial showdown that put the two countries on alert last year. Less worry of the kind India is feeling right now about rising Chinese influence on its doorstep, in Sri Lanka, Nepal and the Maldives.\n\nAnalysts say Mr. Modi is fixated on winning next year\u2019s election in India.
