The global interest, the overflow crowds and the gavel-to-gavel media coverage, the 84-year-old Utah Republican observed, was \u201cthe most intense public scrutiny I\u2019ve seen for a tech-related hearing since the Microsoft hearing.\u201d\n\nTwenty years ago, the tech titan in the Senate hot seat was another Harvard dropout, Bill Gates, co-founder and chief executive of Microsoft. At the time, Microsoft was the most feared corporate powerhouse in America, and the target of government investigations for uncompetitive practices. Mr. Gates was its fearless leader \u2014 and he made it clear that he wouldn\u2019t change his ways for Washington.\n\nBut that didn\u2019t end well for the company. A few months after Mr. Gates appeared on Capitol Hill, the federal government and 20 states sued Microsoft in a landmark antitrust case. The company lost at trial, and not long after started to lose its dominance.\n\n\n\nIf Mr. Zuckerberg\u2019s conciliatory performance in front of multiple congressional committees was any guide, he took the history lesson to heart. It also showed how many debates about the technology industry have evolved from traditional antitrust issues to more complex issues like privacy and the companies\u2019 role in democracy.", "title": "When Mr. Gates Went to Washington", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn every book there\u2019s a new perspective,\u201d Ms. Hahn said, \u201cso bookstores automatically fall on the side of openness and diversity.\u201d\n\nBut how best to serve customers is up for debate. In one of several panels dealing with the topic at the Leipzig Book Fair in mid-March, some independent sellers said they refused to order books from far-right publishers, while others argued that it is important for customers to be able to stay informed. (There are certain titles that Mr. Braunsdorf does not stock. He may order from some right-wing publishers upon request, but will give the customer a piece of his mind on the topic, first.)\n\nGermany has a healthy number of independent bookstores, thanks largely to a German law that requires all booksellers to sell books at set prices. But Zo\u00eb Beck, co-founder of a group called Publishers Against the Right, worries that market-oriented chain stores have weakened bookstores\u2019 role as a place of political debate. \u201cWhat J\u00f6rg Braunsdorf is doing is something I find exemplary,\u201d wrote Ms. Beck, in an email. \u201cThe need now is greater than ever.\u201c\n\nFor Mr. Braunsdorf, 58, social engagement has always been part of running a bookstore. Originally from Wetzlar, a small city in what was then West Germany, Mr. Braunsdorf started working in his 20s at a book collective there run by a group of his young left-wing friends. They did not do much business, but the shop was a meeting place for students and activists: There, they printed fliers decrying nuclear power plants or calling for affordable housing.\n\nToday, 37 years later, Mr. Braunsdorf is still working at a bookstore, but now it\u2019s his own shop, in Berlin, and other political issues have come to the forefront. \u201cNone of us expected that this confrontation with fascism would be so close at hand,\u201d he said, alluding to the AfD success in entering Parliament. \u201cI think in the next years we are going to need to not just protest \u2018against,\u2019 but really come up with a \u2018for.\u2019 What do we want, in our society?\u201d\n\nMr. Braunsdorf, who has hosted German-Arabic reading events at his shop for refugee children and moderated debates about gentrification, the economy and politics, said he \u201ccan\u2019t imagine running a bookstore just as a selling point.\u201d", "title": "When Neo-Nazis Marched Through Berlin\u2019s Old Jewish Quarter, a Bookshop Took Notice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Working in teams under cover of darkness, students would scour burial grounds looking for freshly turned earth, keeping an eye out for relatives sent to watch the grave.\n\nIf you had the means, there were other, less strenuous methods of obtaining cadavers. You could grease an undertaker\u2019s palm, for example, or hire actors to claim a body by posing as a dead person\u2019s relatives.\n\nThe volume of thefts during the winter of 1787-88 made body-snatching an open secret. On Feb. 3, 1788, a group of free black New Yorkers unsuccessfully petitioned the city\u2019s Common Council not to stop the practice, but to ensure it be \u201cconducted with the decency and propriety which the solemnity of such occasion requires.\u201d\n\nOpponents found an audience in The New York Daily Advertiser, which published an anonymous letter on Feb. 16 decrying the \u201cmerchandize of human bones.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlthough medical professionals today tend to be held in high esteem, the opposite was true in the 18th century. The field was filled with quacks, snake-oil salesmen and inexperienced apprentices who relied on whole-body \u201ccures\u201d like bloodletting.\n\nWhen a woman\u2019s body was stolen from the graveyard at Trinity Church, which offered a reward of $100 for information about the perpetrators, the plague had officially struck the well-to-do, setting the stage for a confrontation.\n\nIt\u2019s unclear how the riots started on April 13, 1788.\n\nOne explanation is this: A young student \u2014 medical studies began as early as age 15 \u2014 waved a dismembered arm in mock greeting at a group of boys playing outside, joking that it belonged to the mother of one of them.\n\nOne boy\u2019s mother had, in fact, just died. He ran off to tell his father, who dug up his wife\u2019s coffin; finding it empty, he recruited his mason colleagues to take their tools and march to the hospital.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the time the mob arrived, it had swelled to at least 2,000 angry residents, many of whom broke into the dissection rooms, displayed the dismembered corpses to shocked bystanders and burned the remains in the street.\n\nThe following day, while the mob conducted a house-to-house search for doctors and students, Gov. George Clinton called in the militia to maintain order. After some physical provocation, the militiamen opened fire.\n\nThere were six confirmed fatalities, with some estimates placing the final toll at 20 deaths. The carnage might have been worse had Mayor James Duane not hidden several doctors and students in jail, which the rioters were unable to breach.\n\nToday, medical school cadavers come from donors. Yet an underground market still exists: In 2008, a former dental surgeon pleaded guilty to running an enterprise that harvested organs from more than 1,000 corpses at funeral homes in Brooklyn.", "title": "When New York Medical Students Were Body Snatchers", "authors": ["Keith Williams"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "HONG KONG \u2014 In 2000, Kim Dae-jung, then South Korea\u2019s president, flew to Pyongyang to meet with Kim Jong-il, the leader of North Korea \u2014 the first time talks had ever been held between leaders of the two sides.\n\nThe distance between the two airports was just 100 miles. But the flight took more than an hour, because the plane swung out over the sea west of the Korean Peninsula, to avoid crossing the heavily militarized land border.\n\nOn Friday, Kim Jong-un, Mr. Kim\u2019s son and North Korea\u2019s current leader, is expected to walk across that border, where he will be greeted by President Moon Jae-in of South Korea before they sit down for talks on the southern side of the Demilitarized Zone.\n\nFriday\u2019s talks, the third summit meeting between the Koreas, could produce a statement about pursuing a peace agreement to end the Korean War of 1950-53, which was paused by an armistice but never formally brought to a close.", "title": "When North Met South: A Short History of Inter-Korean Summits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "While we appreciate this bipartisan effort, the measure may actually give presidents more power to decide when, where and against whom Americans can fight, by approving existing military operations that began without congressional approval, and by allowing presidents to expand that scope of action with only a minimal role by Congress. That\u2019s a concern no matter who occupies the White House but especially when the president is as impulsive as Mr. Trump.\n\nThe Senate Foreign Relations Committee needs to hold hearings to examine publicly how the measure can be modified to ensure there is a more effective congressional check on the president\u2019s ability to begin military operations so that the war on terrorists isn\u2019t used as cover to fight any enemy, anywhere.\n\nDuring the Vietnam War, Congress tried to reclaim some of its clout by passing the 1973 War Powers Act, which mandated that if a president sent troops into \u201chostilities,\u201d they could stay only 60 to 90 days unless Congress approved the deployment or extended the time period. In recent years, executive branch lawyers have concluded that presidents may act unilaterally if they decide that a strike would be in the national interest and that it would fall short of an all-out war involving ground troops. Congress, reluctant to be held accountable for putting troops in danger, and wary of challenging presidents, largely acquiesced.\n\nThat is until the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, when Congress passed an Authorization for the Use of Military Force to cover American-led operations against Al Qaeda and the Taliban in Afghanistan. In 2002 it passed a second authorization, to cover the war in Iraq. Although 17 years have passed since the attacks on the United States, President Barack Obama and Mr. Trump, defying credibility, kept using the same authorizations to justify operations against the Islamic State and other groups that didn\u2019t even exist in 2001 and to legitimize operations in many other countries, including Yemen, the Philippines, Kenya, Eritrea and Niger.\n\nUnder the Kaine-Corker proposal, these 2001 and 2002 authorizations would be replaced with one that approves the use of force not just against Al Qaeda and the Taliban but also against six groups not in the 2001 authorization: the Islamic State, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, the East African group Al Shabab, Al Qaeda in Syria, Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb and the Haqqani Network, which operates in Afghanistan and Pakistan. It would also increase the countries where force is authorized to include Syria, Yemen, Somalia and Libya.", "title": "Opinion | When Presidents Go to War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "STARTING IN 1979, when I was 21, I was an out reporter writing for underground queer newspapers, in which I covered key acts of political warfare in New York City. This was the beginning of President Reagan\u2019s terrifying and far-reaching unification with the Christian right. As a particularly despised group of people, queers were fighting police brutality on one front and racist admission policies in gay and lesbian bars on the other, homophobia at home and the closet at work. At the time, there was still no gay rights bill in the city, and sodomy was illegal in more than half of the states. Simultaneously, there were people who insisted on being out and who created rich subcultures that forged new ground in sex, night life, imagination \u2014 and rebellion.\n\nThree years later, in 1982, I witnessed a violent New York City Police raid on a gay bar, Blues, a place for black men in Times Square. The cops beat up patrons, breaking mirrors and shattering bottles. Then as now, police violence against black men largely went unpunished. And when the gay community came out in anger to demonstrate in favor of Blues\u2019s patrons, the action received no television coverage. The only documentation was by the Super 8 filmmaker Jim Hubbard. His grainy footage shows a multiracial, angry gathering of queer men and women holding small homemade signs; there were no mass-produced T-shirts emblazoned with slogans, no shiny pins, no professionally printed posters. This was what resistance looked like then: nothing to buy, and nothing to sell.\n\nSO HOW DID we get from that to the highly visible, art-directed expressions of the late 1980s and early \u201990s, which \u2014 as proven by the pink pussy hats and Black Lives Matter shirts of recent years \u2014 still resonate today? Look first to late-70s conceptual artists, including Jenny Holzer and Barbara Kruger, who drew attention to cultural contradictions with their stark, text-based works, originally pasted on buildings and construction sites in the newly gentrifying SoHo. Public fine art, in combination with the era\u2019s advertising, inspired a generation of graphic designers, including Avram Finkelstein, whose collective created the famous \u201cSilence=Death\u201d logo, later donated to ACT UP (Aids Coalition to Unleash Power) in 1987. Provocative protest iconography soon became the norm: Artists like Tom Kalin, Marlene McCarty, Loring McAlpin and Robert Vasquez formed Gran Fury, one of a number of art collectives in ACT UP. In 1991, AIDS activists\u2019 four-year campaign to expand the Centers for Disease Control\u2019s definition of AIDS, so that more infected women could get health benefits, was accompanied by a Gran Fury poster that read \u201cWomen Don\u2019t Get AIDS They Just Die From It.\u201d\n\nImage Also in \u201987, the collective General Idea made its first AIDS painting, updating artist Robert Indiana\u2019s 1965 LOVE motif. Credit Acrylic on canvas, courtesy of the Estate of General Idea and Esther Schipper, Berlin. Photo \u00a9 Andrea Rossetti\n\nIn many ways, this AIDS rebellion, and the aesthetic it created, drew from the 1960s Civil Rights template. Much as the Black Power movement had established its own look (black berets, leather jackets and a raised fist), so too did New York\u2019s AIDS activists develop a signature telegenic appearance, with their slogan T-shirts, jeans and Doc Martens. Artists such as Keith Haring, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and the collective General Idea made highly visible pieces about loss, inserting AIDS into public spaces, advertisements and even mass-produced apparel. By 1991, the filmmaker Jerry Tartaglia and others in an organization called Visual AIDS Artists\u2019 Caucus had conceived of the red AIDS ribbon as a sign of solidarity in a country that was stigmatizing and isolating infected people. That year, the 11-year-old actress Daisy Eagan wore one to accept her Tony Award for her work in \u201cThe Secret Garden,\u201d and the ribbon became an instant piece of iconography \u2014 of the AIDS movement, of course, but for all future movements as well, a symbol of the conflation of money and power that was a new kind of social currency altogether, one in which one should be, or appear to be, socially aware.", "title": "When Protest Movements Became Brands", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities in Indiana had warned Kennedy not to address the crowd. But he did.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe audience gasped and wailed in anguish at the news that King had been killed. Then, in an emotionally frank speech, Kennedy eulogized the civil rights leader, called for an end to violence and social injustice and addressed, for the first time in public, the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy five years earlier.\n\n\u201cFor those of you who are black and are tempted to be filled with hatred and distrust at the injustice of such an act, against all white people, I can only say that I feel in my own heart the same kind of feeling,\u201d Kennedy said. \u201cI had a member of my family killed, but he was killed by a white man.\u201d\n\n[Read and listen: Robert F. Kennedy\u2019s speech in Indianapolis.]\n\nKennedy\u2019s speech on the death of King has been credited with defusing tensions in Indianapolis, which was one of the American cities that did not see riots that night.\n\n\u201cLook at all those other cities,\u201d William Crawford, a member of the Black Radical Action Project who was there, told The Indianapolis Star in 2015. \u201cI believe it would have gone that way had not Bobby Kennedy given those remarks.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe sincerity of Bobby Kennedy\u2019s words just resonated especially when he talked about his brother,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe speech has also been hailed as one of the great political orations of the late 20th century, as much for what Kennedy said as for the tense environment in which he said it.\n\n\u201cIt was really that he went there, that\u2019s the most remarkable thing,\u201d said David Margolick, the author of \u201cThe Promise and the Dream: The Untold Story of Martin Luther King, Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy.\u201d\n\n[Read more: David Margolick on \u201cThe Power of Bobby Kennedy\u2019s Eulogy for Martin Luther King\u201d]\n\n\u201cThere was no other American politician remotely in sight who could have done that,\u201d Mr. Margolick said. \u201cHe was the only white man who had the credibility and the courage to go into the black community and talk about Martin Luther King and acknowledge what he represented and mourn for him.\u201d\n\nKennedy\u2019s progressive politics and history of personal tragedy were the source of that credibility. Richard Kahlenberg, a senior fellow at the Century Foundation, said Kennedy\u2019s rare reference to his brother \u201chelped give him standing to then deliver this powerful message of racial reconciliation.\u201d\n\nKennedy\u2019s speech that night was a plea for compassion and a rallying cry against the spiral of enmity and violence that had torn at the country for much of that decade, but its impact was limited.\n\nIndianapolis remained calm that night, but riots tore through dozens of other cities. Those in Washington, D.C., devastated large parts of downtown, which remained damaged for decades.\n\nKennedy\u2019s daughter, Kerry, and Representative John J. Lewis commemorated the speech on Wednesday morning in Indianapolis.\n\nThe drumbeat of unrest continued unabated for the rest of the year. Just 68 days after King\u2019s death, Kennedy himself was shot by an assassin in Los Angeles soon after winning the California Democratic primary. He died the next day, on June 6, 1968.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKing\u2019s assassination was a shocking blow to the country and, coupled with the murder of Kennedy just two months later, was seen by many as a violent end to an idealistic time.\n\n\u201cWhen the two of them were assassinated we lost leaders who were articulating a very different path for American liberalism and for America as a whole,\u201d Mr. Kahlenberg said. He said both leaders had argued that \u201cwe should look for common ground among black and white people who are struggling economically.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nKing was buried in Atlanta and his remains were moved to a tomb on the grounds of the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, a memorial and nonprofit education center founded in 1968 by his widow, Coretta.\n\n[Read more: How The Times covered Kennedy\u2019s speech on King\u2019s death.]\n\nKennedy was buried at Arlington National Cemetery near his brother. A memorial installed on the site in 1971 includes passages from his improvised speech in Indianapolis on the night that King was killed:", "title": "When Robert F. Kennedy Told an Indianapolis Crowd of King\u2019s Assassination", "authors": ["Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "A representative for Marvel Entertainment said that no one was available to discuss the question for this article, and DC Comics did not return a request for comment. But some film experts see an identity crisis. Outside of the government and the monuments, it\u2019s hard for Hollywood to imagine what Washington looks like. And worse (at least for D.C. enthusiasts): Whatever it looks like may not be exciting enough for these movies.\n\n\u201cAlthough it\u2019s a distinct region \u2014 not every city has trucks selling half-smokes \u2014 I think that Washington isn\u2019t part of what a lot of people\u2019s sense of their country is about,\u201d said Mr. Prelinger, who became familiar with the city\u2019s iconic sausage dish after living in the district for nearly two decades. He has since moved to California. \u201cD.C. is dull.\u201d\n\nMatt Fraction, a comic book writer recognized for his work on Marvel\u2019s Iron Man, Hawkeye and other characters, said he found it was a location better served in news clips behind television anchors instead of as an accelerant to a spectacular fight scene.\n\n\u201cWashington is an idea as much as anything else,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cWashington is about history and abstract notions.\u201d\n\nKelly Sue DeConnick, who has written independent comics and developed story lines for Captain Marvel, points to the mid-20th-century roots of the modern comic book, when the medium\u2019s writers and artists worked in New York. Though movies aren\u2019t always faithful to their source material, the city loomed large in the initial stories. It was where the biggest comic publishers were based and where most of their writers were living.\n\n\u201cThat was the center of both the Marvel and DC universe,\u201d Ms. DeConnick said. \u201cPeople were telling stories of their lives, of their families, and what was important to them.\u201d\n\n\u201cOnly Washington, D.C.,\u201d she added, \u201cthinks Washington, D.C., is the center of the universe.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIt\u2019s also not an ideal place for dynamic visuals, said Corey Creekmur, a film professor and comics scholar at the University of Iowa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNew York is famously vertical, and Washington isn\u2019t,\u201d he said, pointing to scenes of Superman flying over Metropolis, the fictional version of New York City, and the Avengers plummeting into Midtown. \u201cIt\u2019s not the space associated with superheroes in that regard.\u201d\n\nThere are also logistics to consider. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to build tall buildings in the swamp, things for Spider-Man to swing off of,\u201d Mr. Fraction said. Tom Holland, the current Spider-Man, had to bounce off a helicopter to swing into the Washington Monument for a dramatic rescue in last year\u2019s \u201cSpider-Man: Homecoming.\u201d (Perhaps that\u2019s why he returned to New York City for the film\u2019s final confrontation.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s the power of looking up on Fifth Avenue and seeing something streak over your head,\u201d he said, \u201cbeing enclosed on all sides by urban reality, and seeing what we\u2019re capable of streak by in the sky.\u201d\n\nWhile the district allows filming and is open to projects, its fees can mount quickly for large productions, and the city\u2019s federal spaces come with heavy caveats. On the National Mall alone, there\u2019s a delicate balance between stairs, permitted equipment and flags: You can film the Washington Monument outside the circle of flags around the base, but you cannot film the Lincoln Memorial above its white steps, and all of the Korean and Vietnam War memorials are open \u2014 except that only a hand-held camera is permitted.\n\n\u201cA lot of it has to do with the scope of special effects, pyrotechnics, big explosions \u2014 anything like that is going to be really sensitive to our federal core,\u201d said Herbert Niles, who heads the film division of the district\u2019s Office of Cable Television, Film, Music and Entertainment. He pointed to \u201cCaptain America: The Winter Soldier,\u201d for which more filming took place in Ohio than in Washington.\n\n\u201cOhio was able to give them a freeway and close it down for like three days,\u201d he said, adding that the district is working to make logistics easier for filming. \u201cThat\u2019s just not practical here.\u201d\n\nThe government, and by default Washington, has also increasingly played an antagonistic role in superhero movies, Mr. Creekmur said, as some writers contemplated how individuals with extraordinary abilities would be regulated in a country increasingly focused on maintaining borders and security. Like Batman clashing with the police in Gotham City, there\u2019s often an inherent conflict between the superheroes\u2019 vision of justice and the government\u2019s.\n\n\u201cDo we play along with the government, or do we work outside the government?\u201d he said of the plotlines that drove the splintering factions in \u201cCaptain America: Civil War\u201d (2016). \u201cAnd I think of that as a post-9/11 narrative.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWith the relentless cycle of political news and clashes between Hollywood and the current administration, Washington probably won\u2019t get the spotlight in superhero films anytime soon.\n\nBesides, fictional realms based in reality like Black Panther\u2019s Wakanda have become much more intriguing to moviegoers.\n\n\u201cHollywood is picking up on a widespread alienation from Washington and a widespread disengagement,\u201d Mr. Prelinger, the U.C. Santa Cruz professor, said. \u201cIn a canny way, it tries to present an opposing view.\u201d\n\nBesides, the city\u2019s reputation for political intrigue and elaborate bureaucratic dealings is best saved for acclaimed television shows like \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d on Netflix and \u201cScandal\u201d on ABC, Mr. Fraction said, where the dark hallways and complex dialogue are integral to the plot. Such political reality isn\u2019t suited for superhero stories.\n\n\u201cWhat people respond to is story and character, and politics are for politics,\u201d he said. \u201cIt feels like wearing football padding to a baseball game.\u201d", "title": "When Superheroes Battle Evil, Why Does Washington Always Lose?", "authors": ["Emily Cochrane"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Occasionally, there are moments of comedy. I found it difficult to keep a straight face as I spoke to the journalist sent by China Central Television, or CCTV, the state television network. Both of us were sitting there holding pieces of paper, and my script had all the questions and answers written out for us to recite. It was absurdly stage-managed, with state security agents directing how I was to behave and speak.\n\nThe theater hides a grim reality: I read the script in exchange for freedom for me and my girlfriend. We were both held in solitary confinement inside one of China\u2019s secret prisons, which operate under the euphemism \u201cresidential surveillance at a designated location.\u201d Because of a severe medical condition, I feared that I would not survive in custody. Many victims endure far worse, including prolonged physical and mental abuse and the harassment or detention of their children and siblings.\n\nThe use of these secret prisons has been expanded under the leadership of President Xi Jinping, and they are only one example of his efforts to hold power ever more tightly. Television and other media are crucial tools of the Chinese Communist Party in its soft power push around the world. CCTV\u2019s American unit, for example, claims to reach about 30 million households in the United States and won an Emmy Award in 2016.\n\nThese same Chinese media outlets, as well as some in Hong Kong, air forced confessions, which are illegal under Chinese law and are in violation of principles of human rights. After Iran\u2019s government allegedly collaborated with security services and prosecutors to broadcast forced TV confessions, the European Union in 2013 imposed a visa ban and asset freezes on the head of the state-run broadcasting authority, which was also blacklisted by the United States. When American intelligence agencies said RT America, a television station backed by the Kremlin, had participated in a campaign to manipulate the 2016 election, the Justice Department forced RT America to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act, which requires it to regularly disclose financial information.\n\nThe United States should enforce similar requirements on all Chinese media outlets in the United States. And the United States should invoke the Global Magnitsky Act to impose sanctions on the people in power at Chinese media companies, as well as those within the Chinese police and state security apparatus who are responsible for these televised humiliations. The Magnitsky Act offers great power to target individuals, by freezing their U.S. assets and banning them from traveling to the United States.", "title": "Opinion | When TV Takes Part in Human Rights Abuse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "For Sunday\u2019s tabloid, the team of designers and editors was careful to select images that readers would be as invested in as they were. \u201cEverybody who has looked at the pictures over my shoulder for the past month has been like, keep going, show me more,\u201d said Beth Flynn, a deputy photo editor. As more staff members got involved, they even began lobbying for the publication of particular photos. \u201cEveryone had their own favorites,\u201d said Fred Bierman, a design director at The Times. \u201cThe pictures all had little nicknames,\u201d including one whose subjects Mr. Bierman called his \u201cgrandparents,\u201d which unfortunately didn\u2019t make the final cut.\n\nThe team had been looking for a story fitting for the tabloid format for a long time. Broadsheet tends to work better for long stories because it marries pictures and texts nicely. For this story, however, the pictures would be the star. And indeed, it\u2019s hard not to study them closely in this design. Some take up entire pages in the tabloid, while some are paired with one other related photo on a given page. The designers played with spacing and alignment to add variety and pace.\n\nBut, as Andrew Sondern, a designer (who works frequently with the Reader Center and pages A2 and A3 of the newspaper), put it, \u201cIt\u2019s not about the size of these photographs, it\u2019s really kind of about how they relate to each other and thinking about the relationships of one next to the other.\u201d Photos show parkgoers in timeless activities, like walking happy dogs, climbing jungle gyms, cooling off in fountains and peacefully sunbathing (though often set against the backdrop of somewhat less enduring elements, like a man roasting a whole pig in the middle of a park).\n\nThe universality of summer in the park pervades, and the unity among photos is evident \u2014 despite the city\u2019s and the parks\u2019 struggles, New Yorkers found beauty and leisure. But, beyond that, the project doesn\u2019t require a resolute conclusion in the images\u2019 narrative. The tabloid\u2019s text doesn\u2019t overtake it \u2014 across the 44 pages, there is one central, 700-word story, and blurbs explaining the pictures throughout, but not much more.\n\n\u201cThe pictures are a part of a larger story of the history of the parks, but they\u2019re not a narrative in the way that the pictures are all associated with one particular story, which we\u2019ve done in the past,\u201d Ms. Flynn said. \u201cThis is like a narrative of five boroughs.\u201d", "title": "When The Times Goes Tabloid", "authors": ["Melina Delkic"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The revision puts the F.E.I. in the unusual position \u2014 and compromising optics \u2014 of having unwound in part a strict rule rooted in animal protection at a time of mounting awareness and consumer demand for greater concern for animal welfare in sport and elsewhere, from dairy cows to free-range chickens to racehorses.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think that it would be very shocking to the public that somehow, under some conditions, it\u2019s O.K. for my horse to be wounded in this way,\u201d said Kathy Guillermo, a senior vice president of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.\n\nThe F\u00e9d\u00e9ration pushed back at any suggestion that it was not protecting the horses. \u201cWe still have exactly the same rules about horse abuse,\u201d said Stephan Ellenbruch, the chairman of the F.E.I.\u2019s Jumping Committee and a judge this week at the Masters of New York at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y. The only difference, Ellenbruch said, is \u201cwe leave it a little bit more to the officials now to see if it was just an accident on the course, or if it was horse abuse.\u201d\n\nIndeed, Denis Lynch, an Irish rider, was eliminated after blood was found on the stallion he rode, All Star 5, at the show jumping final on April 13 at the F.E.I. World Cup in Paris.\n\nThe change has relieved top equestrians who say their horses are highly cosseted \u2014 many are worth millions and like professional athletes they are under the constant care of dietitians, massage therapists, acupuncturists and grooms \u2014 and any scrapes are incidental. At the same time, it has also angered animal activists and baffled people outside the sport\u2019s inner circles as to why anyone would fight to lessen a penalty when blood is drawn on a horse.\n\n\u201cI understand that there are people who will state that no horse should ever have a mark or injury that was inflicted by its rider,\u201d Bloomberg wrote in an open letter to the F.E.I. decrying Brash\u2019s disqualification last year. \u201cUnfortunately, the reality that every horseman and woman knows is that the occasional injury or mark on a horse\u2019s skin is inevitable. Just as any athlete may experience a rub or bruise during play, a small spur mark on a horse\u2019s side is a consequence of high-level competition; it is not abuse.\u201d\n\nBrash did not respond to requests for comment, and declined a reporter\u2019s request to speak at the Miami horse show.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVeterinarians like Alessandro Centinaio, an F.E.I. competition veterinarian for the Global Champions Tour, say that the mere presence of a drop of blood on its own is not a reliable indicator of abuse. \u201cIt\u2019s not black and white. Was a rider not correct, and too aggressive?\u201d Dr. Centinaio said. \u201cSometimes it just happens, because it happens \u2014 it\u2019s not so easy to determine.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHe said the new rule is more fair because it allows individual circumstances to be taken into account.\n\nSometimes an injury can seem happenstance: a horse may simply have bit its own tongue, as Adelinde Cornelissen, a Dutch dressage rider argued when she was eliminated from the F.E.I. World Equestrian Games in 2010 after her mount Jerich Parzival started bleeding from his mouth.\n\nBut other instances seem more clear cut, such as when Jur Vrieling, a rider from the Netherlands, was disqualified after he lashed his horse Zirocco Blue with a whip and drew blood at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVrieling was one of four riders cut from the Games over the rule, resulting in a call to re-examine the regulation.\n\n\u201cWe love these animals, there is no rider who doesn\u2019t care about his horse. Everything for us is the horse,\u201d said Sheikh Ali Bin Khalid Al Thani, a top Qatari show jumper, as he stood in the rider\u2019s lounge at the Miami Beach event. \u201cIf we get a scratch, believe me, nobody does it on purpose \u2014 mistakes happen.\u201d\n\nThe matter is far from settled.\n\nWhile professionals seem to be largely of one voice, debate resumes among show jumping fans, in the stands and online. One oft-referenced point: There can be a darker indication if the hide of a horse opens up easily during the short burst of intense competition; namely, was the animal\u2019s skin so fragile because of a history of injury?\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think rules should ever be weakened when it comes to the use of horses in sport. Whether the horse is injured in a so-called \u2018incidental\u2019 way, or whether it is from deliberate overuse of spurs, it\u2019s the same to the horse,\u201d said Guillermo. \u201cIf it\u2019s enforced at the discretion of a steward or somebody else, then there is leeway, and that\u2019s a problem.\u201d\n\nBloomberg praised the decision of the F.E.I. to modify the rule. \u201cThere are a lot of things in our sport that I understand fully that people who don\u2019t understand it might question,\u201d Bloomberg said in an interview. \u201cBut if a horse does not enjoy their job or want to jump, there is absolutely no force in the world you can use that\u2019s going to make a horse want to do that.\u201d", "title": "When There Is Blood on a Horse, Is It an Accident or Abuse?", "authors": ["Sarah Maslin Nir"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn March 2017, I was on a reporting trip, traveling through Montana\u2019s Flathead Indian Reservation. I saw a sign in Arlee, a small town in the foothills of the spectacular Mission Range, indicating that the boys\u2019 high school basketball team, the Warriors, had won a state championship. I proposed a profile of its star, Phillip Malatare, who was then a junior, to my editor at The Times Magazine, Charles Homans. The plan was to follow Phil, a Division I prospect, as he tried to reach a college program.\n\nBut I quickly realized that the notion of profiling one player was ridiculous. Phil was related to more than half of the Warriors, and the team\u2019s dominant style of play was predicated on cooperation and a lot of running. I also discovered there was more to the story than basketball. David Whitesell, the father of another one of the team\u2019s players, told me that during the previous year\u2019s championship run, the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes \u2014 a wealthy and powerful nation \u2014 had been combating a suicide cluster that directly affected the team.\n\nI told Mr. Whitesell, Phil\u2019s parents and the team\u2019s coach, Zanen Pitts, that the story was about a season with the basketball team, but that if they decided to grant access I would also cover the adversity the community had faced. They all decided to welcome me. They were proud of their athletic success and wanted their story told.\n\nOver the course of the coming year, I would join Mr. Pitts at rodeos and a cattle branding; accompany Phil Malatare\u2019s father buffalo hunting; and spend months living on the Flathead reservation. The team\u2019s games were expressions of joy for the boys and gathering places for the community. The Warriors beat two different opponents by the score of 95-19. Much of my reporting centered around the efforts of Phil and another senior to get noticed by college coaches.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThen, in February, one of the Warriors\u2019 opponents from another team on the reservation committed suicide. People in the community were concerned that another cluster might start.", "title": "When There\u2019s More to the Story Than Basketball", "authors": ["Abe Streep"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Next, the video shows, Constable Lam steps out and away from the cover of his car, indicating perhaps that he has assessed that the object in Mr. Minassian\u2019s hand was not a gun.\n\nConstable Lam then issues his first warning: \u201cGet down or you\u2019ll get shot.\u201d\n\nThroughout the encounter, the officer repeats the same simple command to get down. Yasmeen Krameddine, director of research and development at ProTraining, an Alberta organization that trains police forces in how to de-escalate confrontations involving people with mental health illness, said that it might have been better if he had varied his language.\n\n\u201cWe train officers to offer step-by-step instructions, and when they see a person is not responding to their commands, to use different words,\u201d she said.\n\nBut, she added, \u201cIn this situation, there was no time for that.\u201d\n\nConstable Lam then backs away from Mr. Minassian, who walks toward him, threatening object in hand. In response, the officer appears to replace his gun with a baton, visibly de-escalating the threat to Mr. Minassian.\n\nFormer Deputy Chief Federico said the officer was applying his training, to weigh the necessity of force deemed reasonable and choose the option best for the situation.\n\n\u201cSometimes officers put themselves in a position where they have no other choice but to use force,\u201d said Denise Rodriguez, a Washington-based researcher with CNA Analysis Solutions who has spent years delving into how police departments in the United States use force.\n\nThen, Constable Lam confidently and slowly approaches the suspect with his baton in hand. By the time the officer reaches him, Mr. Minassian has dropped the object in his hand, raised his hands in surrender, turned and laid down on his stomach with his hands behind his back.", "title": "When Toronto Suspect Said \u2018Kill Me,\u2019 an Officer Put Away His Gun", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "The current model for understanding SIDS suggests a confluence of risks. First, the infant may have some intrinsic anatomic or physiological risk factor. Second, there is a critical period of development when babies are vulnerable, before the age of 6 months. Third, there is an environmental component involving sleep position, bed sharing or overheated rooms. The final mechanism of death may be a failure to arouse out of deep sleep.\n\nMaybe, Dr. Goodstein said, when babies sleep in the same room as their parents, the background sounds or stirrings prevent very deep sleep and that helps keeps the babies safe. Room sharing also makes breast-feeding easier, which is protective against SIDS.\n\nDr. Ian M. Paul, a professor of pediatrics and public health sciences at Penn State Children\u2019s Hospital, has questioned whether it\u2019s reasonable to suggest that families undertake room sharing for as long as a year.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s clear that room sharing is protective against SIDS in the first four to six months,\u201d when the great majority of SIDS deaths occur, he said. \u201cAfter that there was no hard data to support that room sharing without bed sharing was any safer than the baby sleeping in their own room.\u201d\n\nDr. Paul was the first author on an article last summer in the journal Pediatrics that looked at the relationship between room sharing and sleep behaviors. The families that continued room sharing longer, he said, were at higher risk of moving the child into the parents\u2019 bed, which is unsafe. As for babies, \u201cthose that moved to their own room sometime after age 4 months had better sleep consolidation and longer overall sleep extended out to age 2\u00bd years.\u201d\n\nFamilies need to consider all these factors, he said, in figuring out what will work best for themselves and their babies. \u201cWe do know that poor sleep has effects on the child in the short and the long term and on the family.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI begin at 4 months in my clinical well visit, establishing good bedtime routines, not feeding or rocking a baby to sleep, put a drowsy but not asleep child to bed,\u201d Dr. Paul said. To discuss \u201ctransitioning out of the room at 4 months gives me a mental reminder in my anticipatory guidance to reinforce safe sleep in that new sleep environment, and I talk about the potential benefits of having a baby get better sleep consolidation in that second half of the first year.\u201d\n\nIn the first four to six months, Dr. Paul said, room sharing can help support breast-feeding. But by 6 months, he says it\u2019s fine for the baby to be in a separate room. The baby should no longer need to be breast-fed overnight, and in fact, mothers may be more likely to keep breast-feeding longer if they are not waking up several times a night.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor women who need to breast-feed in the night, and are concerned that they may fall asleep while nursing, Dr. Goodstein suggested, stay in bed but clear the bed of pillows, loose blankets, comforters \u2014 and try to stay awake so that you can put the baby back into a \u201csafe sleep environment,\u201d that is, the bassinet or crib that is not the parental bed. Babies should not be put down on surfaces like water beds, couches or cushioned armchairs, where there is a very large increase in the risk of SIDS.\n\n\u201cParents need to be aware of norms, that there are going to be awakenings,\u201d Dr. Goodstein said. \u201cAt some point when they\u2019re getting a little older, we should give them some time to self-soothe \u2014 we need to have these discussions about infant sleep safety, injury prevention, SIDS risk reduction, we need to acknowledge that parents have a hard job.\u201d\n\nIndeed, it is a hard job, and Dr. Paul said that many parents and many pediatricians were relieved by his position.\n\n\u201cI got so much fan mail when we published our paper,\u201d he said. \u201cPediatricians, many of them, didn\u2019t think it was a common sense recommendation for some families.\u201d\n\nBut everyone also understands the desire to see these deaths stop, and no one wants to take risks. \u201cThere are still 3,700 babies dying from unsafe sleep in this country, one dying every two or three hours of every day,\u201d Dr. Goodstein said. \u201cIt\u2019s a national tragedy. We really have to work at dropping these numbers down.\u201d\n\nJodi Mindell, a pediatric sleep expert at Children\u2019s Hospital of Philadelphia and chairwoman of the Pediatric Sleep Council, said that while the emphasis in the early months when risk is highest must be on the importance of keeping babies safe, we should also help families think about other aspects of sleep in the period between 3 and 6 months: \u201cEstablish good sleep foundations, with early bedtime, consistent bedtime routines.\u201d\n\nShe advised that doctors educate parents about safe sleep surfaces and the importance of no one smoking in the home.\n\n\u201cWe need to make it safe whether or not the baby is in the parents\u2019 room,\u201d Dr. Mindell said. \u201cOur job is to help families and support them in their decisions.\u201d", "title": "When Your Baby Is Your Roommate", "authors": ["Perri Klass", "The Checkup"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "On her return to her hometown, Ms. Moore found that philanthropy takes finesse. \u201cI didn\u2019t walk in and say, \u2018I\u2019m back, and I\u2019ve brought a bunch of money, so let\u2019s fix ourselves up,\u2019 \u201d she said. Instead, she paid for a study to see if anything could be done. It turned out there was a lot.\n\nMs. Moore is the sixth generation of her family to live on the same farm, where she has upgraded the farmhouse substantially and transformed the farmland into the Moore Farms Botanical Garden.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer credentials as a philanthropist are well established. She has given $70 million to the University of South Carolina, which named the business school after her, and made a $10 million gift to Clemson University, where her father was a star football and baseball player.\n\nBut Ms. Moore knew she was going to need the town\u2019s constituents, regardless of age or race, to buy into a vision they all could share. There were more than a few doubters, she said.\n\n\u201cI had a lot of credibility in the town because of my father and grandparents, not because of my resources,\u201d Ms. Moore said. \u201cYou couldn\u2019t do it without that. I\u2019ve known people who\u2019ve gone into towns with a large amount of money, and it failed. It\u2019s hugely complex.\u201d\n\nLike much in philanthropy today, many of these makeover projects require a mix of giving and investments with a social return so they can be sustainable. That combination helped Hamilton, Mo., population 1,809.\n\nIn 2008, two of Jenny Doan\u2019s seven children gave her a sewing machine designed for quilting. Twelve feet long and seven feet wide, the machine was too big for the family\u2019s home. So they bought a building to house it. Real estate was cheap because the town was struggling and many buildings had been neglected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the suggestion of one of her sons, Ms. Doan began to make YouTube videos on how to quilt. The videos took off. She kept sewing and making videos, and the family enterprise, the Missouri Star Quilt Company, kept buying and fixing up buildings.\n\nThe company now owns 26 buildings, including 14 quilt shops, three restaurants and a quilting retreat house for women, where up to 40 visitors can stay.\n\n\u201cWe bought as many buildings as we could,\u201d Ms. Doan said. But they all required extensive work before the Doans could use them.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe said the company had poured all of its profits back into the town for many years. It even put in the sidewalks along Main Street. Missouri Star Quilt now employs 450 people, mostly from the town.\n\n\u201cThis was one of the poorest counties in Missouri, and now people have a job,\u201d Ms. Doan said.\n\nRebuilding a civic space can be daunting and take years, if not longer, said Paul S. Grogan, president and chief executive of the Boston Foundation, one of the nation\u2019s oldest and largest community foundations. He said it was important to record small milestones.\n\n\u201cThe little victories add up to something significant,\u201d said Mr. Grogan, whose background is in community development. \u201cIt becomes substantial. In a neighborhood accustomed to failure, you generate some success.\u201d\n\nMs. Moore said she had started with the Bean Market, a historic building that was \u201cspit and taped\u201d together. It is now a central event space for Lake City. She moved on to the old feed and grocery store, which is now a Smithsonian-certified art gallery that hosted an exhibition of the Spanish artist Francisco de Goya in 2014.\n\nBut she has also funded less-glamorous tasks, like running high-speed fiber-optic lines into town.\n\nFor community leaders who lack resources, Mr. Grogan said, rehabilitating just one house or creating a community garden can have a catalytic effect. \u201cYou think, \u2018How could those things possibly make a difference?\u2019 \u201d he said. \u201cBut they do.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEventually, though, these towns need to attract outsiders to keep them viable. Ms. Doan\u2019s quilting stardom \u2014 her YouTube channel has nearly 500,000 subscribers \u2014 drew tourists to Hamilton. That, in turn, brought in other businesses.\n\n\u201cIn the beginning, not everyone was happy we were turning our farm community into a quilting community,\u201d Ms. Doan said. \u201cFor those people who weren\u2019t happy, we hired their children, and now they love us.\u201d\n\nIn Lake City, Ms. Moore knew she had to create an event to bring in visitors. Plenty of people go to nearby Charleston for its historical charm and opera festival and to Myrtle Beach for its golf and 60-mile stretch of coastline, but Lake City was not on anyone\u2019s must-see list.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a meeting with advisers, some of whom she had known since she was a girl, one talked about an art festival in Grand Rapids, Mich., that is supported by members of the DeVos family, whose wealth comes from Amway, the multilevel marketing company. Ms. Moore thought that doing something similar with art from Southeastern states might work in Lake City.\n\nThat festival, ArtFields, is now in its sixth year. When it opens next Friday, 400 works of art will be on display in buildings that Ms. Moore has renovated and in downtown shops.\n\nOne shop owner, Barbara Miles, met with controversy last year when she selected a provocative tapestry from the festival to hang in her store, the East Main Market. But Ms. Moore said she had decided the artwork should stay. \u201cIt was a real humdinger of an image,\u201d she said.\n\nSome philanthropists are drawn to the challenge of renewing neighborhoods in big cities.\n\nMarcus Samuelsson, the world-famous chef who owns Red Rooster in Harlem, started Harlem EatUp!, a weeklong food and cultural festival in the neighborhood, four years ago.\n\nHe said the festival, which draws attendees from the city and beyond, helped 80 businesses in the neighborhood. But Mr. Samuelsson said he was proud that 40 percent of the events were free, up from 20 percent when the festival started.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHarlem is a neighborhood with a deep cultural history, but Mr. Samuelsson saw this festival as a way to highlight its businesses. His goal has been to use a week of fun to bring economic benefits to Harlem and Spanish Harlem by connecting event sponsors with local chefs and restaurant owners.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a great place to live, to open a business, to create jobs,\u201d he said. \u201cBut it\u2019s also important that the restaurateurs meet sponsors like Ernst & Young or Citibank. That\u2019s massive because the next time they need a business loan, they might be coached by Ernst & Young and get the loan from Citibank.\u201d\n\nThat added benefit of opening up people\u2019s eyes to a community is something all of these endeavors have in common.", "title": "When Your Fixer-Upper Is Your Hometown", "authors": ["Paul Sullivan", "Wealth Matters"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "If you live in a co-op, eventually you may be asked to pay for a building improvement that does little to improve your apartment or your life. Maybe balconies need repair, but your apartment does not have one. Maybe the building needs a new elevator, but you live on the first floor, or use a different bank of elevators than the ones in disrepair.\n\nOr maybe you already have central air-conditioning in your apartment and do not want to pay for a project that would allow the rest of your neighbors to have it too, as happened in a small co-op in the far West Village of Manhattan, where a three-bedroom apartment is currently listed for $4.5 million.\n\nThe dispute, chronicled in an essay by Kathleen Hughes, led to Ms. Hughes, who was president of the board, stepping down before she could be voted out for supporting a proposal in which all the shareholders would shoulder some of the costs of installing central air-conditioning.\n\nSeveral shareholders and board members spoke to a reporter for this story to offer their views and to corroborate the sequence of events, but they requested that their names be withheld to protect the identity of the co-op.", "title": "When a Co-op Project Turns Into War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "When Rose Giuliano\u2019s grandmother died in 2014, the thought of selling the Brooklyn apartment building that had been in her family for 125 years was so unbearable that she and her husband moved back east from the San Francisco Bay Area to manage the property.\n\nHer great-great-grandfather, an Italian immigrant, had bought the six-unit building in Greenpoint, at 146 Newton Street, in 1889, moving into one apartment and filling the others with members of his extended family. Ms. Giuliano\u2019s grandmother was born in the building and when she married, her husband, who grew up nearby, joined her there.\n\n\u201cEven when they got older, and we were like, \u2018You can go to Florida,\u2019 I don\u2019t think she could envision herself in any other place but that house \u2014 that house, that neighborhood, that community,\u201d Ms. Giuliano said. \u201cIn the summer, they would sit on the stoop and play cards. The block was her family. She just seemed of that place, a certain place in time.\u201d\n\nMs. Giuliano and her husband lived in her grandparents\u2019 old apartment for a little over three years. But while the building itself was as she remembered it from childhood visits \u2014 the murals of Naples in the halls, the dumbwaiter they used to play with, the smell of fermented grapes that emanated from the corner of the basement where her grandfather made wine \u2014 nothing else was.", "title": "When a Family Homestead Can\u2019t Stay in the Family", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Bret: I\u2019m surprised to find myself writing this, but I think the strike was a waste of perfectly good cruise missiles. We did nearly the exact same thing last year, and it did nothing to stop Bashar al-Assad from slaughtering his own people and using chemical weapons on them. If we really believe, as I do, that the use of chemical weapons cannot be tolerated, then we can\u2019t allow the guy who used them to come away from the strike unscathed and \u2014 given that he\u2019s immediately renewed his offensive in the area \u2014 emboldened.\n\nThe strike really was classic Trump: A show of force mainly for the sake of show, without any strategy behind it. Iran has entrenched itself in Syria alongside Russia, while Israel is quietly preparing for war on its northern front. The administration looks likely to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal next month, but little thought seems to have been given to what comes after. In all, just another reminder that the Trump disaster is global.\n\nGail: We\u2019ve been looking for a good argument for so long I really wish I could pitch into this one. But my bottom line is that we\u2019d better avoid any serious conflicts as long as Trump is commander in chief. As to the Iran deal, the whole idea of pulling out of it is so traumatizing that I can\u2019t think of any response except crawling under the bed and assuming a fetal position.\n\nNow, let\u2019s be cowards and talk about domestic issues. Can we start with Paul Ryan? You wrote a wonderful column about what a weenie he\u2019s being by bailing out at this crucial moment. But I think we still disagree about his overall career. I see him as a guy who pretended to be all about balanced budgets but was really always just going for the tax cuts and screw the deficit. Same thing with Bush. Same thing with Reagan. Seems to be a pattern.\n\nBret: I think your complaint is a tad unfair. If Republicans like Ryan had filibuster-proof control of the Senate, they would likely pass entitlement reform and gleefully take an ax to domestic spending to keep the budget balanced. There aren\u2019t any honest deficit hawks anywhere in American politics \u2014 they just want to slash the other guy\u2019s priorities to fund their own. Aren\u2019t most Democrats that way, too? I mean, would you let a deficit stand in the way of Medicare-for-all?", "title": "Opinion | When a Politician and a Lawman Try to Play the Hero, the Lawman Usually Wins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nI have a friend who started an \u201cethical and fair trade\u201d clothing line that was just picked up by a big American retailer. The clothes are made in India by local workers and sold in the United States. The production seems fine, but what concerns me is that my friend (who is white) uses brown emoji hands when she markets the clothes on social media. The clothing itself \u2014 the cuts and prints \u2014 already seems appropriated. But her blatant use of dark-skinned emoji makes me uncomfortable. What should I say?\n\nANONYMOUS\n\nNot a syllable! You have too deeply discounted the value of your friend\u2019s fair-trade enterprise and over-magnified your relatively trifling concerns. Your friend may be offering life-changing wages to people in a poorer region. (With expansion, she could help even more of them.) Better still, ethical supply chains eliminate child labor and other exploitation in fabric making, pattern cutting, sewing, packing and distribution.\n\nGiven that all this work transpires in India \u2014 that the clothing is indeed made by Indians \u2014 her use of brown-skinned emoji hands seems reasonable enough. And if I total up your major complaints: fabrics and designs that seem \u201cappropriated\u201d (from the very region where they are made \u2014 huh?) and the dreaded brown-skinned emoji, you seem to be missing the forest for the trees.\n\nIt is exquisitely easy to stand on the sidelines and nitpick at the imperfections of worthy projects. (As a jealous person, I am often likely to pile on.) But rather than quibbling with your pal over symbolic concerns, why not congratulate her on the material good she\u2019s doing? If you can\u2019t, better to keep quiet.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne Tough Cookie\n\nAt a dinner party at my parents\u2019 house, the new wife of their neighbor bought four boxes of Girl Scout cookies from my daughter. She had two boxes of Thin Mints on hand and wrote an i.o.u. for the other two. The woman paid $20 for all four boxes. Four days later, I received a text from her: \u201cWhere are my cookies?\u201d I apologized and said we would bring them as soon as we could. (It\u2019s an hour\u2019s drive.) Three days later, she sent another text: \u201cI want my money back. Send me a check for $20.\u201d I explained that she had already taken two boxes, so I would send her $10. She then sent a photo of the clearly doctored i.o.u., showing that we owed her four boxes. Thoughts?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.
