View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe church has been to some degree disengaged,\u201d said the Rev. Dr. W. Franklyn Richardson of Grace Baptist Church in Mt. Vernon, N.Y. \u201cChurches that have social consciousness are pushed by this anniversary into a place of reflecting on how far we have come or not come, and have we abandoned what he gave his life for?\u201d\n\nFor pastors like Bishop Blake, that means embracing the parts of the movement he agrees with \u2014 ending police violence and empowering black entrepreneurs, for instance. But it also means holding the line on church teachings that young activists disagree with.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are also differences in approach. Pastors often want to work within the system to effect change, while many activists try to disturb and upend the system.\n\nBishop Blake is not someone to be found on protest lines or shouting down law enforcement; he tends to advocate through more formal channels. He departs from some activist ministers in his social conservatism, opposing same-sex marriage and abortion. Yet he tries to strike a welcoming posture in an era of activists who can feel like the church is judging them.\n\nHe hosted a rally at his church to protest the killing of Trayvon Martin. Last year, he wrote a letter to the mayor of St. Louis suggesting that if police practices were not reformed, his denomination could take its annual convention \u2014 and the millions of dollars that come with it \u2014 elsewhere. And at a gathering of black congressional leaders, his raspy voice grew louder as he declared that black people needed \u201cto take charge of our destiny.\u201d\n\n\u201cReligion at its best shows people how to live productively, safely and wisely and altruistically,\u201d said Bishop Blake, who has led the Church of God in Christ since 2007.\n\nSome ministers have an approach that is a more natural fit with the renewed religious left. Last year, the Rev. Dr. William Barber II, the pastor of Greenleaf Christian Church in Goldsboro, N.C., helped to start the Poor People\u2019s Campaign, patterned after the effort that Dr. King established to address urban poverty. Dr. King\u2019s campaign, which was to include setting up an encampment in Washington, was cut short by his death.\n\nDr. Barber is apt to politicize his sermons on Sundays and advocate civil disobedience to win change. He has linked L.G.B.T.Q. rights to the civil rights struggle.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe one thing that would be dishonorable for us is to bring all this attention to the assassination of Dr. King and not have a resurrection of the efforts and the unfinished business dealing with systemic racism, systemic poverty,\u201d Dr. Barber said.\n\nEven in Dr. King\u2019s day, black churches were not unified. Many did not follow Dr. King, and stayed on the sidelines. Some worried about attracting violent backlash. Some preferred a more gradualist approach. Similar tensions remain in the fight for his legacy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Rev. Traci Blackmon, an executive with the United Church of Christ, a Protestant denomination, and the leader of a church near Ferguson, Mo., sees the work that many churches perform, like feeding and housing the poor, as distinct from the advocacy that Black Lives Matter and other organizations are doing, she said.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m talking about the organized countermovement that has as its end goal the changing of systems and the dismantling of structures,\u201d said Ms. Blackmon, who was a front-line activist in the wake of the 2014 killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo. \u201cOften, the work that we do on church local levels does not have that as the end goal.\u201d\n\nBlack churches were born out of political and social resistance, with enslaved African-Americans organizing around a theology that God would deliver them from their oppression. With all that is going on around social justice, churches must calibrate what that means for them in the present, said the Rev. Dr. Yolanda Pierce, a professor and dean of the Howard University School of Divinity.\n\n\u201cChurches have to ask the fundamental question: \u2018Are we going to be at the forefront of struggles for justice, or are we always going to be catching up to where the arc of justice will literally take us,\u2019 \u201d she said.", "title": "Where Today\u2019s Black Church Leaders Stand on Activism", "authors": ["John Eligon"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "I wasn\u2019t going to take a chance. If Bangkok\u2019s ad hoc restaurants were threatened \u2014 not only by clean-sidewalk-loving governments but, just as seriously, by gentrification and changing tastes \u2014 I had to go before it was too late. In July, I flew to Bangkok for a week of eating nothing but street food.\n\nPretty much immediately, I learned that street food was a term with many definitions.\n\n\u201cFor me, street food is only a cart,\u201d said Duangporn Songvisava, known as Bo, who with her husband, Dylan Jones, runs the restaurants bo.lan, which received a Michelin star in December, and Err, which serves rustic drinking food with a focus on quality ingredients. When she was young, Ms. Songvisava, now 37, remembered, as many as 20 carts would line up outside her school to sell snacks on sticks to students. \u201cThey have, like, the moo ping \u2014 grilled pork on a stick, barbecue \u2014 the sausage, the fishball. It just fills you up before you have dinner.\u201d Some were pushcarts, others bicycle-based, but all were mobile and ephemeral.\n\nThat, she said, was the tail end of the golden age of Bangkok street food. \u201cIn the old days when someone want s to open a cart or a stall, they know how to cook,\u201d she said. \u201cThe idea was, you\u2019re a good cook \u2014 maybe you should make some food for other people, for a living.", "title": "Where to Find Bangkok\u2019s Best Street Food While You Can", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Raj Shah, a deputy White House press secretary, said Friday that after Mr. Tester\u2019s accusations, officials searched all of the government databases that contain records of accidents involving government vehicles, including at the General Services Administration. He called it a \u201ccomprehensive search\u201d for any crashes involving Dr. Jackson and a government vehicle.\n\nMr. Shah said that the search revealed three episodes, none of which resembled the crash described by Mr. Tester.\n\nIn one episode, Mr. Shah said that Dr. Jackson was rear-ended, resulting in a fender bender. In another, a bus sideswiped a side mirror on Dr. Jackson\u2019s car, according to Mr. Shah. The third case was an episode of road rage, Mr. Shah said, in which another person punched through a window on Dr. Jackson\u2019s car.\n\nNone sounded like the accusation contained in the document distributed by Mr. Tester: \u201cAt a Secret Service going-away party, Jackson got drunk and wrecked a government vehicle.\u201d That allegation was widely reported by news organizations at the time as lawmakers from both parties expressed concern and indefinitely delayed Dr. Jackson\u2019s confirmation hearing.\n\nA spokeswoman for Mr. Tester declined to comment on Friday night.\n\nIt was not clear whether the White House\u2019s records search might have missed an episode like the one on Mr. Tester\u2019s list of accusations, or if such an episode might have gone unreported. But White House officials said it would be inconceivable for serious damage to a government vehicle to escape notice and not be recorded.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Shah echoed earlier comments by Mr. Trump criticizing Mr. Tester \u2014 and the news media \u2014 for distributing anonymous accusations about the doctor.", "title": "White House Says Records Don\u2019t Match Accusation Against Jackson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Some concessions appear to be in the offing. The United States has now backed away from a proposal that would require half of the value of an automobile to be manufactured in the United States to qualify for Nafta\u2019s preferential tariffs. Instead, it is proposing a system that would require a certain proportion of auto parts to be made by workers earning certain wages.\n\nThat proposal is likely to be more palatable to Canada and could also encourage Mexico to ultimately pay higher wages. And it could help Mr. Trump court the votes of congressional Democrats, who complain that Mexico\u2019s low wages are the reason companies have relocated auto production from the United States.\n\nStill, the proposal is likely to face opposition from Mexican negotiators, given that their current wage scales are too low to qualify. And some auto executives also criticized the new proposal, saying it would be nearly as difficult for companies to comply with as earlier ideas, and could ultimately push manufacturing out of North America to cheaper areas.\n\nOther key areas of dispute also remain: Negotiators have so far concluded work on only six of the trade agreement\u2019s roughly 30 chapters, and little progress has been made on contentious issues like mechanisms for settling trade disputes or rules for government purchases.\n\nYet the renewed push to revise Nafta could usher in an agreement that until recently seemed at risk of collapse. Both supporters and critics of the Trump administration have pointed to the trade deal that the United States recently concluded with South Korea at the end of March as a possible precedent. Mr. Trump fiercely criticized that pact, but in the end his administration declared victory after renegotiating fairly modest changes.\n\nLabor unions, which have backed Mr. Trump\u2019s plan to dramatically remake trade policy, were disappointed with that deal, which did not include changes to labor standards, investment rules or content requirements for automotive manufacturing.\n\n\u201cYou see what you get if your priority is speed over quality,\u201d said Celeste Drake, trade and globalization policy specialist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. \u201cA quick deal that\u2019s not a good deal \u2014 is that what the administration wants to sell in these next few months? Or is it really looking to take the time it needs to get a good deal?\u201d", "title": "White House Tries to Pull Nafta Back From Brink as Deadlines Loom", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "People familiar with the negotiations say Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, and Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, have at times argued for more dialogue with the Chinese and quicker concessions that would help diminish the trade deficit \u2014 the gap between what China ships to the United States and what America ships in the other direction. Other top trade advisers, including longtime China critics like Robert Lighthizer and Peter Navarro, have taken a tougher stance, arguing that these changes would do little to address the mercantilist and protectionist trade policies China has adopted for decades.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s advisers said the president remains resolute and views the pugilistic approach as the only way to force China to end two decades of industrial policies that have hollowed out American manufacturing and resulted in a ballooning trade deficit.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Trump suggested in a tweet that he saw no reason to back down, since the United States was already on the losing end of trade with China.\n\n\u201cWe are not in a trade war with China, that war was lost many years ago by the foolish, or incompetent, people who represented the U.S.,\u201d he wrote. \u201cNow we have a Trade Deficit of $500 Billion a year, with Intellectual Property Theft of another $300 Billion. We cannot let this continue!\u201d\n\nHe added in another tweet, \u201cWhen you\u2019re already $500 Billion DOWN, you can\u2019t lose!\u201d\n\nIt remains unclear whether China will bend to the pressure and make significant changes to its economy \u2014 or whether the White House strategy will instead tip the two nations into a trade war that could harm both countries. Producers of American goods like soybeans, pork, automobiles and semiconductors depend on access to the Chinese market both for exports and production and say they are fearful about a conflict.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cCompanies are definitely caught in the middle of this,\u201d said Kenneth Jarrett, the president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Shanghai.\n\nEconomists predict that the direct effects of the tariffs will be relatively small for both China and the United States, since they apply to only a fraction of each country\u2019s economic output.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201dIt\u2019s hardly a life-threatening activity,\u201d Mr. Ross said in an interview on CNBC. He added that the volume of the tariffs was in line with the White House\u2019s calculation that the Chinese have cheated the United States out of $50 billion worth of intellectual property through coercion and cyberattacks.\n\nWhile tariffs would affect a small part of the overall United States economy, they impinge on a relatively large share of American exports to China. If China places tariffs on $50 billion of goods from the United States, as promised, that would be more than one-third of American exports to China. In contrast, American tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods would affect only one-tenth of China\u2019s vast exports to the United States.\n\nWithin that slice of the economy, the pain could be acute. American farmers and manufacturers, in particular, could suffer. On Wednesday, China said it would penalize American soybeans, cars, chemicals and other goods, hours after the United States announced tariffs on flat-screen televisions, medical devices and industrial machinery.\n\nThe economic effects could also quickly escalate beyond tariffs. The United States is preparing restrictions that could prevent China from investing in high-tech industries like semiconductors and electric vehicles, and it may consider other restrictions, including visas.\n\nChina, in return, could make life more difficult for the many American companies that do business in the country, or pare back its purchases of United States debt. China is the largest foreign holder of American debt, holding about $1.17 trillion in United States bonds, notes and bills in January, according to the Treasury Department.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cChina has many ways it can make life exceedingly uncomfortable for a large number of American businesses, both those that are hoping for access to China\u2019s fast-expanding market, and those that use China as an important part of their supply chains,\u201d said Eswar Prasad, a professor of international trade at Cornell University.\n\nThe Trump administration contends that if it does not challenge Beijing now, the Chinese government will heavily subsidize its companies to become dominant producers of cutting-edge industries from robotics to electric cars. That could imperil the United States\u2019 ability to create good-paying jobs for future generations, relegating the country to producing food, fossil fuels and financial services, while China extends its lead as the world\u2019s largest manufacturer.\n\nBut the administration\u2019s strategy for halting China\u2019s rise has been hard to discern, with some advisers insisting that China must remake its economy, while others say the priority is to reduce the trade deficit, prioritize market access for American companies or end China\u2019s infringement on American intellectual property. Some top officials have indicated the tariffs may never be implemented.\n\nOn Wednesday, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, refused to say whether the tariffs would ultimately go into effect, adding, \u201cI would anticipate that if there are no changes to the behavior of China and they don\u2019t stop the unfair trade practices, then we would move forward.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nCompanies have until May 22 to submit comments to the administration about the tariffs, with the penalties to be imposed at an undetermined date. Separate tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from China and other nations went into effect late last month.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the meantime, American officials including Mr. Mnuchin and Mr. Lighthizer have been in talks with the Chinese about ways to resolve their differences. Yet conversations have so far focused on concessions like China reducing tariffs on American cars, opening up its market for financial services and purchasing more semiconductors or natural gas \u2014 minor wins that are unlikely to satisfy Mr. Navarro and Mr. Lighthizer, who are pushing for significant and sweeping changes to China\u2019s market, according to people familiar with the negotiations.\n\nThe United States has also asked for a $100 billion reduction in the $375.2 billion trade deficit it runs with China. But the goods China has offered to buy to narrow that gap \u2014 including semiconductors \u2014 are not products the Trump administration wants to export. And some advisers say these kind of sales will not do anything to address the underlying problems with the Chinese economy.\n\nChina experts say an inconsistent message and approach could undermine America\u2019s ability to successfully negotiate.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all over the map,\u201d said Scott Kennedy, a China expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. \u201cThe Chinese are trying to take advantage of this lack of consensus and get the United States to take a quick deal that leaves China\u2019s industrial policy machine intact.\u201d\n\nBeijing is also eager to show other trading partners that it will not be bullied into changing its policies.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not very positive about large concessions or changes that are going to come from China,\u201d said Heiwai Tang, an assistant professor of international economics at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. China\u2019s current government is more assertive than recent ones, he said, and the country is heavily dependent on technology transfers from advanced economies as it tries to transform its own.\n\nFor the Chinese to successfully negotiate, analysts said, they have to be able to present the deal to their own people as a win. But the United States has refused to give concessions and has painted the confrontation as one in which China must ultimately lose.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTariffs are seen as a direct slap in the face, and it will be very difficult for the Chinese government to sit back and take those blows without retaliating,\u201d Mr. Prasad said.\n\nOn Wednesday, Cui Tiankai, the Chinese ambassador to the United States, said China preferred to resolve the conflict through talks but would keep its options open.\n\n\u201cNegotiation would still be our preference, but it takes two to tango,\u201d Mr. Cui said. \u201cWe will see what the U.S. will do.\u201d", "title": "White House Tries to Tamp Down Trade War Fears as China Retaliates", "authors": ["Ana Swanson", "Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "The Treasury Department, which issues tax regulations through the Internal Revenue Service and offers guidance that dictates how the tax code is applied, will have broad discretion in determining the effects of the law. It has long been exempt from the type of cost-benefit analysis that the Office of Management and Budget performs on most rules that government agencies issue.\n\nWith a host of unintended or unclear provisions stemming from the rapid passage of the law, the Treasury will need to decide how the legislation is implemented. It has already begun issuing guidance to clarify the law\u2019s intent and in March moved to block hedge funds and private equity firms from trying to circumvent a new rule aimed at limiting the use of the so-called carried interest tax break.\n\nSome congressional Republicans are rooting for Mr. Mulvaney\u2019s office to wield greater oversight of the tax law, in the hopes that it would push for the most lenient interpretations of regulations that enable the largest number of businesses to pay lower rates under the law. Other lawmakers and business groups are pulling for Mr. Mnuchin, believing that adding review by the Office of Management and Budget could slow down the creation of regulations that businesses say they need to make investment and tax planning decisions this year.\n\nMr. Mulvaney has taken the view that tax regulations issued by the Treasury are of significant economic importance and that decisions that determine the fate of hundreds of millions of dollars are being made without sufficient scrutiny by his office. The budget office analyzes regulations issued by agencies across the federal government, with its Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs determining whether agencies have sufficiently addressed problems during rule-making and either accepting regulations or sending them back to be reworked.\n\nThe Treasury Department does consult the budget office on some of its rule-making, but since a 1983 memorandum of understanding, the office has not had the authority to review the Treasury\u2019s tax guidance, on the theory that it is not economically significant enough to warrant it.\n\nAn executive order from Mr. Trump last year called for that arrangement to be re-examined. With the Treasury Department now playing a greater role in policymaking \u2014 for instance, overseeing enforcement of parts of the Affordable Care Act and trying to limit corporations from engaging in mergers to avoid taxes \u2014 Mr. Mulvaney and other White House officials think that the I.R.S. should be subject to greater accountability when making decisions that often go beyond technical clarifications.\n\nGreater accountability, however, could come with costs.\n\nIf Mr. Mulvaney wins the argument, \u201cit will slow the process down,\u201d said John A. Koskinen, a former I.R.S. commissioner whose term ended last year. \u201cIf you had all the regulations coming out of Treasury and I.R.S. subject to more review and delays, it would not be making taxpayers, accountants and lawyers happy. They are pushing to get that information as quickly as they can.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince the passage of the tax bill late last year, negotiations between Mr. Mnuchin and Mr. Mulvaney have grown increasingly vigorous, with both sides laying claim to being the law\u2019s final arbiter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA change would be seen as a win for Mr. Mulvaney, who has made deregulation a priority in the White House. It would also be a blow to Mr. Mnuchin, who has been the tax bill\u2019s most public defender on behalf of Mr. Trump, diminishing his department\u2019s authority under his watch.\n\nThe potential change in regulatory oversight could have major implications, both logistical and political.\n\nAdding a cost-benefit analysis by the budget office into the process would potentially add another layer of red tape \u2014 which Mr. Trump famously hates in other areas of regulation \u2014 to a process that is already proceeding too slowly for many business groups\u2019 liking. Treasury officials are concerned that the budget office lacks the resources and tax expertise to properly assess tax guidance and that the process will get bogged down, potentially delaying rules to clarify the law for months. One early hurdle would be hiring; the budget office does not currently employ its own team of tax lawyers.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a moderate level of concern that it could potentially slow down the guidance process,\u201d said Ken Spain, a partner at CGCN Group, a lobbying firm with a number of tax-related clients. \u201cAny time you blur the lines on what is already a tricky process to navigate, it\u2019s going to give the business community some degree of heartburn.\u201d\n\nOfficials from previous administrations also say that opening the tax regulation effort beyond Treasury would invite not just comments from the budget office, but from the White House political team and other advisory groups in the government.\n\n\u201cMidlevel political appointees get their fingers in there, find out when the meetings are and have their opinions,\u201d said Adam Looney, a senior fellow in economic studies at the Brookings Institution who served in President Barack Obama\u2019s Treasury Department.\n\nSuch an expansion, Mr. Looney said, also offers more avenues for lobbyists to press their case for why their clients should receive more preferable tax treatment. \u201cThe swamp is going to be enriched by this one,\u201d he said.\n\nBudget office officials say the desire for final oversight over the tax bill is in line with the administration\u2019s deregulatory push and that a more uniform approach to rule-making would benefit the federal government. They point to a 2016 Government Accountability Office report concluding that the agreement that has made Treasury an exception is outdated and that the department has been inconsistent in documenting its guidance process.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepublican leaders in Congress have walked a delicate line as the dispute plays out. Julia Slingsby, a spokeswoman for Representative Kevin Brady of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said last week that Mr. Brady \u201cappreciates the different, complementary roles that O.M.B. and Treasury play with respect to tax code regulations.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Ways and Means Committee has partnered with Treasury on developing the pro-growth tax reform legislation and we look forward to it continuing the partnership as Treasury and O.M.B. do their work on the regulations,\u201d she said.\n\nAdministration officials have suggested that a compromise could be reached within weeks.\n\n\u201cWe have been working productively with O.M.B. and are very pleased with the process,\u201d said Tony Sayegh, assistant secretary for public affairs at the Treasury. \u201cWe look forward to a resolution in the near future.\u201d\n\nMeghan Burris, a budget office spokeswoman said, \u201cWe do not discuss ongoing, pre-decisional processes and negotiations.\u201d", "title": "White House Turf Battle Threatens to Delay Tax Law Rollout", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration said Tuesday that it will place a 25 percent tariff on Chinese products like flat-screen televisions, medical devices, aircraft parts and batteries, outlining more than 1,300 imported goods that will soon face levies as part of a sweeping trade measure aimed at penalizing China for its trade practices.\n\nThe move, which stems from a White House investigation into China\u2019s use of pressure, intimidation and theft to obtain American technologies, is likely to inflame an already-simmering trade war between the countries. On Monday, China said it would slap tariffs on 128 American products in response to a separate White House plan to tax steel and aluminum from China and other countries.\n\nThe products targeted by the White House are part of its plan to go after China\u2019s dominance in cutting-edge technologies like semiconductors, electric vehicles and advanced medical products \u2014 industries that China is pursuing dominance in as part of an industrial plan known as \u201cMade in China 2025.\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration said that its analysts had identified products that benefit from these policies but refined the list to remove goods that were likely to cause disruptions to the United States economy or consumers.", "title": "White House Unveils Tariffs on 1,300 Chinese Products", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTRADE\n\nTrump to release list of next tariff targets.\n\nThe Trump administration is expected this week to announce the list of Chinese products that will be hit with tariffs over what the administration has called the country\u2019s theft of intellectual property. Mr. Trump has said the levies will affect at least $50 billion in imported goods and will most likely focus on cutting-edge tech products of the kind that United States fears losing out on to China. Americans are more likely to feel the impact of these tariffs than those applied to steel and aluminum in March, because they will probably hit consumer products found on store shelves, rather than raw materials used by manufacturers. Natalie Kitroeff\n\nECONOMY\n\nA new interest rate emerges on Tuesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve Bank of New York will begin publishing a new short-term market interest rate on Tuesday. The Secured Overnight Financing Rate, or S.O.F.R., was created to wean the world\u2019s financial markets off the London Interbank Offered Rate, or Libor, a benchmark rate that currently serves as the basis for hundreds of trillions of dollars of financial instruments \u2014 from interest rate swaps to credit card and mortgage debt \u2014 that incorporate floating interest rates. Since the 2008 financial crisis, policymakers and financial institutions alike have wanted to find a replacement for Libor, as the process for setting the rate has been vulnerable to manipulation. The New York Fed\u2019s new rate is based on the rates in the active market for a kind of short term-loan known as a repurchase agreement, or repo, which uses Treasury securities as collateral. Matt Phillips\n\nREGULATION\n\nCompanies in Britain must lay out gender pay gaps.\n\nBy Wednesday, thousands of companies with at least 250 employees in Britain must publish figures showing their gender pay gap for the fiscal year ending in 2017. The requirement to submit this data to the government has put pressure on companies to explain the differences, which are often a result of fewer women in management and more women in lower-paid levels or occupations. EasyJet, one of the companies that has already filed, reported a 52 percent pay gap and its chief executive cut his salary by 34,000 pounds to match his female predecessor\u2019s earnings. The filings have fueled debate over pay for women, which has been under greater scrutiny since the British Broadcasting Corporation attracted high-profile criticism for its pay practices. Amie Tsang\n\nECONOMY\n\nJob growth probably slowed in March.\n\nLast month\u2019s jobs report was a barn burner: Employers added 313,000 jobs in February, the most in one month since 2016, and the strong labor market drew hundreds of thousands of Americans into the work force. March\u2019s data, due from the Labor Department on Friday, is unlikely to match those highs. Still, all signs point to the job market \u2014 and the economy, in general \u2014 remaining strong. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg expected the report would show a gain of 189,000 jobs and a decline in the unemployment rate to 4 percent, which would represent the best mark since 2000. And in good news for workers, economists expect a modest pickup in wage growth, which was sluggish in February and has been weak for much of the nearly nine-year-long recovery. Ben Casselman\n\nFed\u2019s Chairman Powell to visit Chicago.\n\nJerome H. Powell will make his first speech outside Washington as the chairman of the Federal Reserve on Friday, choosing an itinerary that demonstrates his concern for business and entrepreneurship. Mr. Powell will tour a manufacturing incubator in Chicago on Friday afternoon, after giving a speech on the economic outlook at the Economic Club of Chicago. Jim Tankersley\n\nINTERNATIONAL\n\nThe Saudi Crown Prince wraps up a busy United States tour.\n\nCrown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia has met with President Trump, business leaders, journalists, technology executives and even rabbis on his whirlwind multiweek tour of the United States. He will finish up his trip on Saturday in Houston, the global energy capital, with visits to Saudi Aramco facilities, including a technology center and a refinery outside the city. Clifford Krauss", "title": "White House to List Chinese Products Facing Tariffs and the March Jobs Report", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nNow that President Trump feels more confident in his job and has unencumbered himself from advisers who actually knew what they were doing, we are beginning to see what a madhouse the White House has become.\n\nWhile issuing bellicose tariff threats, ordering the National Guard to guard the border with Mexico, throwing away speeches and bad-mouthing big businesses like Amazon may pass for leadership in the president\u2019s Twitter-delineated mind, Americans understand that this is not the way a president thinks or behaves if he wants to succeed.\n\nIt remains to be seen whether the Republican Party can muster the political wherewithal to stand up to the president and end the carnage unfolding before our eyes.\n\nMICHAEL SCOTT, SAN FRANCISCO", "title": "Opinion | White House, Madhouse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "CHICAGO \u2014 White Sox relief pitcher Danny Farquhar was in critical condition on Saturday, a day after suffering a brain hemorrhage while in the dugout during a game.\n\nFarquhar passed out in the sixth inning on Friday night after getting two outs against the Houston Astros. He was helped by team medical personnel and on-site emergency medical technicians, and regained consciousness before he was taken to a hospital by ambulance.\n\nThe White Sox announced that additional testing revealed the brain hemorrhage caused by a ruptured aneurysm. Farquhar was receiving treatment and being closely monitored in the neurosurgical intensive care unit at Rush University Medical Center here.\n\nManager Rick Renteria met with players before Saturday\u2019s game against Houston and updated them on Farquhar\u2019s condition. They are Diamond and Silk.\n\nDiamond and Silk are African-American sisters, Lynnette Hardaway and Rochelle Richardson, who became known during the 2016 presidential campaign for their unwavering support of Donald J. Trump.\n\nThey found a new audience this week when Republican lawmakers pressed Mr. Zuckerberg, the Facebook chief executive, on the sisters\u2019 accusation that the social media giant was discriminating against them for their beliefs. (The company says that is not true.)\n\nHere is a brief guide to Diamond and Silk and their troubles with Facebook.\n\nHow did they become internet-famous?\n\nMs. Hardaway, or Diamond, and Ms. Richardson, or Silk, became known in conservative circles for their social media videos, which heap praise on Mr. Trump and launch sometimes racially tinged attacks on his critics, like calling the Democratic Party \u201ca plantation\u201d and Hillary Clinton \u201ca slave master.\u201d", "title": "Who Are Diamond and Silk? A Look at 2 Pro-Trump Social Media Stars", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "To Plath devotees, the necklace is a tantalizing totem of the pyrotechnics generated by her relationship with Mr. Hughes. A Maltese cross flanked by two dragons, the baroque design is completely unlike Ms. Plath\u2019s other accessories, a mostly feminine assortment of rhinestones, hearts and flowers.\n\n\u201cThe pendant has a Hughesian sensibility. It\u2019s a little edgy for the time, and even has a whiff of the occult,\u201d said Heather Clark, whose biography \u201cSylvia Plath: The Light of the Mind,\u201d is forthcoming from Knopf next year. \u201cMaybe Hughes gave it to her. Or maybe she chose it with him in mind.\u201d\n\nMs. Plath wears the pendant in several well-known photographs taken after she was married, including two by Rollie McKenna at the National Portrait Gallery in London, in which she appears both knowing and impossibly young.\n\n\u2018Ted Likes This\u2019\n\nWhy would a daughter choose to part with such meaningful objects? Ms. Hughes, 58, a painter and poet herself, was a sleeping toddler when her mother committed suicide with a gas oven at age 30 in 1963, and in her 30s when her father died in 1998, of cancer. Her younger brother, Nicholas, a biologist, hanged himself in 2009.\n\nShe declined to comment on the sale further than her introduction to the auction catalog, in which she writes movingly that it all began with the Victorian mahogany armchair her father bought for Ms. Plath, originally covered in \u201ca coarse, shiny black fabric worn through at the front edge of the seat,\u201d which she remembers scratching the backs of her legs as a child. Once she was an adult, she had the chair reupholstered in pink, for her bedroom.", "title": "Who Bought Sylvia Plath\u2019s Stuff?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Live in a real house and you know that the list of unfinished projects and repairs seems endless. But watch Jonathan and Drew Scott on the \u201cProperty Brothers\u201d promise a dream home on a delusional budget, and that checklist can be dealt with in less than an hour.\n\nIn this fantasy world, we don\u2019t waste countless afternoons wandering the aisles of Home Depot in search of hardware. Jonathan will take care of it, selecting an oversize mirror to sit atop your Moroccan tiled fireplace. No weeks spent waiting for inspectors to arrive to close out electrical permits. Instead, you walk away from the chaos to an undisclosed location and return with a blowout and skinny jeans, ready to be wowed.\n\n\u201cIn America, the idea that our lives can be improved by consumption is an integral cultural belief,\u201d said Kate Wagner, who writes McMansion Hell, a blog that lambastes bad home design.\n\nThe typical HGTV narrative also tells us that our homes are inadequate beasts needing to be tamed. Yes, the stars of shows like \u201cHome Town\u201d can make shutters out of reclaimed wood and restore the original built-ins, but, for the most part, dated elements, like wood paneling or a \u201990s kitchen, are tumors to be excised on the journey to an Instagram-ready retreat. A house with an enclosed kitchen is one in need of a crew willing to demolish it, not a family hoping to live in it.\n\n\u201cThe home is no longer a place,\u201d Ms. Wagner said. \u201cIt\u2019s no longer a backdrop for the complex lives that we live. Now it\u2019s a flaw.\u201d\n\nTo fix such a flaw offscreen has real financial consequences. Americans spend a huge amount of money on home improvement, and that sum is growing. This year, Americans are expected to spend $340 billion on home upgrades, up 7.5 percent from 2017, according to the Joint Center for Housing Studies of Harvard University.\n\nThe biggest spenders last year were those who had lived in their homes for less than six years, according to HomeAdvisor. How are we paying for all these new farmhouse sinks and waterfall shower heads? With debt. Over the next five years, an estimated 10 million Americans will take out home equity lines of credit, according to TransUnion, more than double the 4.8 million credit lines opened over the previous five.\n\nBut if you live in a high cost area like New York, you cannot hope to remodel a kitchen for $25,000, a price often quoted on \u201cHome Town,\u201d which is set in the far more affordable state of Mississippi. Here, contractors don\u2019t wow you with fancy computer graphics where walls pull away like curtains and fresh cabinets magically descend from the ceiling. In real life, you\u2019re lucky if your contractor even calls you back with a quote.", "title": "Who Doesn\u2019t Love to Hate-Watch HGTV?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Ever since Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel was named first vice president in 2013, Cubans and Cuba watchers alike have scrambled to find out more about the enigmatic heir apparent, combing through his track record as party leader in the provinces of Villa Clara and Holgu\u00edn, and later as minister of higher education, for clues on how he will lead.\n\nIn each position, according to those who knew him at the time, Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel has been a quiet but effective leader, seemingly open to change. Many called him a good listener, while others described him as approachable, free of the rigidness and inaccessibility of typical party chiefs.\n\nThrough it all, he has also been a relentless defender of the revolution and the principles and politics it brought.\n\nStories of his Everyman qualities have spread widely in recent years: how he rode his bike to work instead of taking a government vehicle during gas shortages; how he defended the rights of a gay club in Santa Clara in the face of protests; how he patiently listened to academics grouse (sometimes about him) as minister of higher education.\n\nMore recently, he was a leading voice in the push for internet access in Cuba, arguing that the nation could not seal itself off from the outside world. Though his beliefs remain very much within the party line, those who know him say he does not adhere to the belief that Cuba can exempt itself from the modernization necessary to participate in the global economy.\n\nBut in Cuba, the continuum of political thinking is not black and white. Often, conventional definitions of progressives versus hard-liners do not apply. Leaders can be both, and Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel is an example of that. While he is seen as open to the ideas of others, as a younger man he led a campaign to stifle students who read and discussed literature that was not approved by the Communist Party, according to those who knew him at the time.\n\nLast year, a video was leaked of Mr. D\u00edaz-Canel addressing a group of party officials. In it, he lambastes the United States, claiming that Cuba had no responsibility to meet its demands under the reconciliation brokered by President Barack Obama.", "title": "Who Is Miguel D\u00edaz-Canel, Cuba\u2019s New President?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI was flabbergasted,\u201d she said, while describing being passed from department to department. \u201cI worked for the state for 13 years. I know bureaucracy. This is not my first rodeo. But at one point, I lost it, just sobbing, wondering what I was going to do.\u201d\n\nThese borrowers are not alone. As of 2016, according to FedLoan data that the Department of Education used in a presentation, FedLoan had processed 1,068,888 employer certification forms and rejected one-third of them. Of those rejected, 21 percent presented an unqualified employer, though it\u2019s not clear how many were close calls, as the National Association of Social Workers may have been.\n\nThe Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issued a scorching report last summer about an array of public service loan forgiveness messes. It noted that some borrowers reported months of delays in getting answers about certification form questions. One complainant reported that his form was rejected because of employer ineligibility while his co-worker\u2019s was approved a week later.\n\nAs for that litigation I mentioned before, one lawsuit over certification problems does shed some light on these matters. The American Bar Association and four individual borrowers, some of whom experienced the same FedLoan flip-flop as Mr. Francum, sued the Department of Education in late 2016. In a brief last year, the department, opining on the topic of whether people can rely on FedLoan not to change its mind, said that any response from FedLoan \u201cdoes not reflect a final agency action on the borrower\u2019s qualifications\u201d for forgiveness.\n\nIn other words, that certification form is by no means certain. Which is pretty rich, given that the Department of Education introduced the forms several years ago precisely because so many people were confused about whether their employment qualified. So good luck to you if you work for, say, a 501(c)(6) and want some financial certainty in your life. (I know of no employees of a 501(c)(3) organization whose employment was rejected, and the Department of Education website indicates that none of them should be. Please get in touch with me if it has happened to you.)\n\nAnd no, FedLoan will not precertify a job before you apply. Nor will it allow a forward-thinking employer to send in a job description for preapproval before trying to hire someone. Once upon a time, FedLoan\u2019s website encouraged employers to brag to prospective employees about current workers who had received certification, but that ended quickly once the American Bar Association\u2019s dumbfounded lawyers pointed it out in a legal filing.\n\nThat suit shows no sign of settling soon. So people like Ms. Gramlich wait and wonder. \u201cI\u2019ve been advocating for less fortunate populations my whole adult life, and here I am one of those people now,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I cannot get out of this mess.\u201d", "title": "Who Is a Public Servant? Borrowers Have a Lot Riding on the Answer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "ISTANBUL \u2014 Earlier this year, Turkey opened its closely guarded population register, a monumental archive of lineages going back to Ottoman times. A website that gives access to all public services in Turkey now includes a genealogy tab. Users can download ancestry documents, with records going as far back as 1882.\n\nSince the appearance of the new service, roots, migration, purity and hybridity have dominated the conversation in WhatsApp groups, offices and tea shops. In just two days, over 5 million Turks went looking for their heritage on the register. Interest was so intense that for a few hours the website collapsed. The government was forced to stop the service for several days.\n\nFor a century, the Turkish state imposed a rigid national identity on its citizens, one that excluded ethnicity and underscored \u201cpure\u201d Turkishness. The government\u2019s opening of its records has mesmerized people. As Turks absorb the news of their own ethnic diversity, the century-old idea of racial purity, manufactured and imposed by the state, has begun to crumble.\n\nSome Turks, especially those whose families have lived in the same towns for generations, have found reaffirmation in the proof of their own deep roots. Others are frustrated. One Turkish nationalist learned that his great-grandmother was of Kurdish origin. A writer friend was surprised to discover her great-grandfather\u2019s name was Isaac. One of my neighbors found out she had European roots and decided to apply for dual citizenship.", "title": "Opinion | Who Is a Turk? It\u2019s Complicated", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSPECIAL POST \u2014 In this month\u2019s \u201cWho Made My Puzzle?\u201d the spotlight shines on Sam Trabucco, who has made his mark after publishing only 10 crossword puzzles in The New York Times.\n\nMeet Sam Trabucco\n\nWhere do you currently reside?\n\nSan Francisco, California.\n\nWhere and when was your first puzzle published?\n\nI somehow got a poem published in a book of children\u2019s poetry in the second grade, and, looking back, I\u2019d call that poem quite puzzling. My first actual puzzle was published on October 14, 2015 at BuzzFeed. If you have not done any of the BuzzFeed puzzles, beware: they\u2019ve got a \u2026 different tone from more standard newspaper fare. I miss it!\n\nWhen was your first New York Times crossword published?\n\nMy first New York Times crossword came out just two weeks after the BuzzFeed one. I had to go to seven stores before I could find a physical copy of The New York Times. Leave it to a millennial not to be able to find a newspaper.\n\nHow did you get into puzzling? What is your first memory of solving?\n\nI\u2019ve always enjoyed puzzles of various sorts \u2014 I was the kid who would rather figure out the Towers of Hanoi than \u2026 uh \u2026 play tag? Is that what normal kids did? That\u2019s what I\u2019ve read. I also really enjoyed playing Scrabble growing up, as well as more general word games. During my junior year of high school I went to my first M.I.T. Mystery Hunt which is where \u201cpaper puzzling\u201d started morphing into a passion for me, and I soon started solving crosswords regularly.\n\nWhat made you decide to try your hand at making a crossword puzzle?\n\nThe summer before senior year of high school I got it into my head that making a crossword must be something I can do \u2014 it\u2019s basically the same as playing Scrabble! Little did I realize how difficult it really is. I decided I wanted to try making one for my high school\u2019s newspaper, and it\u2019s an abomination that we printed it. Among its funnier flaws was the presence of the entry IS IT TEN? clued as \u201cAre we eating brunch?\u201d That terrible, terrible puzzle (made in Excel!) might have been a one-off, fun project I did and forgot about a few weeks later, if not for the auspicious introduction of David Quarfoot to my high school\u2019s math department my senior year. He saw my pitiful attempt and one-upped me by writing an actually good crossword for the school paper, but he also encouraged me to start writing crosswords seriously. He showed me the software people use to help write good puzzles, as well as where to find a quality word list, not to mention a ton of other advice. My initial efforts improved, but I just didn\u2019t get super invested right away for whatever reason, and my interest petered out. I put crosswords on the back burner during college, never making another serious attempt until spring of my senior year \u2014 I\u2019m not sure what spurred this on exactly, but it was probably the free time I had while also embracing the \u201csenior spring\u201d attitude. But that attempt turned into two, which turned into 10, which has now turned into \u2026 many.\n\nWhy do you do this to yourself?\n\nTo rescue my hometown, Natick, Mass.\u2019s heinous reputation among crossword people. For real, I was very confused when I first got into crosswords and read about \u201cNaticks\u201d considering I did spend 18 years of my life there. I even used to watch the marathon from there, like the clue mentions! Seriously, I love making crosswords because I find grid construction to be a fun and satisfying problem to solve, and theme development/clever cluing to be nice creative outlets. I also really enjoy sharing my puzzles with friends and watching them solve/hearing their feedback. I\u2019m not sure what it is, but making something which provides people I care about a fun experience is really gratifying to me, and crosswords are the medium that\u2019s best allowed me to do that (unless you count karaoke, which my drunken self absolutely does).\n\nDo you use a computer software constructing program and, if so, which one? What do you like about it?\n\nI mostly use CrossFire for grid construction. To be honest, I primarily use it over Crossword Compiler because I have a Mac \u2014 I\u2019ve used and liked both. I really like CrossFire\u2019s user interface, and the grid-filling software in general is just such an improvement over by-hand construction that it\u2019s difficult to imagine myself being anywhere near as strong at grid design as I am without it. The software, in tandem with my word list (formed by taking Jeff Chen\u2019s word list, adding a bunch of stuff manually and via web scraping, and scoring some stuff with a simple algorithm based mostly on Google hits) allow me to make much better grids than I used to be able to in a fraction of the time.\n\nHow many hours a week, on average, do you spend on refining your tools, like your word list?\n\nThis is sort of difficult to count. Whenever I hear either a \u201cfun phrase\u201d or a new, crossword-friendly name or word (e.g. OMI, NIETO), I put it into my Notes app and add it to my list later. I also sometimes discover a new corpus of idioms or movies or something that I add programmatically to my word list. These tasks vary in time investment, but I\u2019d say it averages to about one hour of active management per month, plus whatever time I spend manually adjusting scores while constructing.\n\nWhat entry or entries would you NEVER put in a puzzle, and why? And with what entry would you deliberately fail the \u201cbreakfast test,\u201d and why?\n\nBesides the standard crossword crutches which I do my best to avoid (my personal absolute no-noes are random Roman numerals and massive obscurities which happen to have nice letters), there are some problematic words which, despite their prevalence in spoken or written English, I\u2019d never include. An example of such an entry is GYP, whose etymology I learned the hard way \u2014 by including it in a crossword (thinking it was benign) and hearing that it had ruined some solvers\u2019 experiences. [The word GYP is thought to be a slur against the Roma people. \u2014 D.A.] Any entry which has the power to do that \u2014 or which perpetuates the oppression of some oppressed group, or otherwise causes pain \u2014 is one I will not knowingly include in a crossword. In terms of the breakfast test \u2026 I think that some of my BuzzFeed puzzles will tell you how I feel about it! If I had my way, anything that doesn\u2019t fall under the umbrella from the previous paragraph would be fair game. I\u2019ve already debuted SEXILE in The New York Times, and entries that Will [Shortz, The Times\u2019s crossword editor] has asked me to edit out of my submitted grids include B.S. METER and KISS ASS. I\u2019m sure similar things will happen going forward, as I continue trying to push boundaries. Also, c\u2019mon, URINE has such nice letters!\n\nWhat are you working on these days?\n\nI contributed two puzzles to Queer Qrosswords, a puzzle pack organized by Nate Cardin by LGBTQ+ constructors to benefit LGBTQ+ charities. It \u201ccame out\u201d (ha) recently, so please consider a) supporting some awesome charities and b) solving some awesome puzzles!\n\nThank you for spending time with us, Mr. Trabucco.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Who Made My Puzzle?: Sam Trabucco", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "He discovered a way his approach could make sense: \u201cJudy was polished from a young age to appear a certain way, and the same thing with me,\u201d Mr. Whiteside said. \u201cEven through all that, you can\u2019t mask what\u2019s underneath.\u201d\n\nMr. Ferver has a solo and icon of his own: Michelle Pfeiffer as Selina Kyle/Catwoman in \u201cBatman Returns.\u201d \u201cShe\u2019s this geek who gets killed and then turns into this revenge person who can\u2019t accept intimacy,\u201d he said. \u201cI really get that. I deeply feel that I run on two tracks: Love and revenge, I wish I could tone my revenge back. But I can\u2019t. It\u2019s just my nature. I\u2019m a Scorpio rising.\u201d\n\n\u201cEverything Is Imaginable\u201d also includes a group number in which the cast seems to be transported to a nightclub \u2014 it\u2019s a reference to the men lost to AIDS \u2014 and duets, including one for Mr. Ferver and Mr. Bartelme, who are especially close. They have known each other since 1996, when they were students at Interlochen, an arts academy in Michigan; they reunited in New York in 2007.\n\nUp to that point, Mr. Ferver had tried to erase his past \u2014 but that was no longer possible with Mr. Bartelme in his life. \u201cWhen you\u2019re known you\u2019re vulnerable,\u201d Mr. Ferver said. \u201cSo to have him onstage with me has been about how to create dynamics for myself where I can be vulnerable as someone who has learned how to not be to protect myself.\u201d\n\nAnd a little over two weeks ago, Mr. Ferver was forced into accepting his vulnerability even more. He tore his calf muscle, an injury that he sees as being woven into the very fabric of \u201cEverything Is Imaginable,\u201d which is about the shattering affects of trauma.\n\nMr. Ferver can\u2019t jump; his injured leg cannot withstand full weight. His therapist advised him not to travel forward. The second half of the show has changed dramatically because of this \u2014 for the better, he said. (Mercifully, his Catwoman solo remains, altered accordingly.)", "title": "Who Made Them Feel Mighty Real?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Foodies Get Into Fashion\n\nThe idea of a restaurant collaborating with a fine jewelry brand sounds like a stretch, but for anyone familiar with the Lower East Side eatery Dimes, or its supercool founders, Sabrina de Sousa and Alissa Wagner, it seems natural. They have already won the hearts of many of the city\u2019s fashionable denizens thanks to an inventive healthy-but-not-in-a-health-store-way menu and sunny d\u00e9cor.\n\nNow the pair has teamed up with Loquet, a jewelry company founded in London by Laura Bailey and Sheherazade Goldsmith that has built a cultish following for its 21st-century take on lockets. Think simple gold pieces with crystal centers that allow you to see the charms inside.\n\nThe capsule, which will be carried at Broken English in SoHo starting April 17, mines the Dimes menu, with food-inspired charms including a fruit slice, an avocado and a sunny-side-up egg. Just don\u2019t take a bite.\n\nDimes for Loquet capsule collection of 14-karat gold charms with enamel, sapphires and tsavorite, $350 each at Broken English; brokenenglishjewelry.com.", "title": "Who Said Fashion People Don\u2019t Like Food ?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "When it comes to professional wrestling, there are the famous American federations with slick promotion, well-paid stars and merchandise-mad, free-spending fans.\n\nThis story is not about that.\n\nIn Mexico, generations have grown up admiring the masked luchadores who, for a $50 prize, will flip and body slam opponents in epic fights in modest arenas packed to the rafters with screaming fans. Theirs is a world where nothing comes easily, and the struggle to support their families is often a never-ending battle. There must be an easier way to survive beyond the world of lucha libre, but don\u2019t tell them that.\n\n\u201cWhat I saw was a love for the lucha,\u201d said Seila Montes, a Spanish photographer based in Mexico who spent more than two years photographing the masked men (and women) outside the ring. \u201cThey\u2019re not doing it for the money. The ones I photographed were not famous, and they only earned a little. But they transformed when they put on their mask and costume. That\u2019s when the actor and showman comes out.\u201d", "title": "Who Was That Masked Man? A Wrestling Priest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Just as during the 19th-century Great Game, the Kremlin has the advantage of not needing to worry about public criticism at home as it pushes an illiberal agenda abroad. On the contrary: While applying military force abroad tends to destabilize Western governments, it seems only to bolster the regime of Russia\u2019s president, Vladimir Putin.\n\nIf anything, the Russian population glories in the atrocities of its former leaders as well as those of the current one. According to a 2017 poll by the Levada Center, 38 percent of Russians regard the mass murderer Joseph Stalin as the \u201cmost outstanding person\u201d in world history, followed by Mr. Putin at 34 percent.\n\nHere\u2019s where the intellectual dimension of the Great Game comes in: Societal self-criticism, alien to a large part of Russian society, is a defining feature of many Western countries. Publicly expressed and debated tensions between the state and the people, and among various factions of the public, are what make a liberal society tick.\n\nBut the strength of this skepticism can prove to be a weakness if exploited by a force that seeks the destruction of the very concept of truth. As an intellectual force, Russia is to Europe what Mephisto is to Faust: \u201cI am the Spirit that denies!\u201d To paraphrase Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who wrote the most famous version of their story: For all the West has built, should rightly to destruction run.\n\nThis is why the Russian disinformation and its grotesque twisting of facts is so effective. Mr. Putin knows that Europeans deeply distrust their governments on questions of war and peace, especially after several of them relied on twisted intelligence to justify the Iraq war. The poison used on the former Russian agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter in England, and the chemical weapons dropped with impunity on the children of Syria kill people as well as trust in elected representatives in London, Paris and Berlin.\n\nThere is no doubt that the international community has violated its own standards at times, conducting legally questionable or outright illegal actions in Kosovo, Iraq and Syria. Russia and China are doing the opposite: using their power as permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to block justice and to undermine the West.\n\nWho will win in the long run? It is too soon to know whether the West is willing to stand up collectively to the challenge. The good news, though, is that Russia and China may yet lose at the new Great Game. It\u2019s expensive to play, and global power grabs untethered to a broader vision of global order tend to falter, as resources and lives expended abroad fail to bring peace and progress at home.\n\nThe German poet Theodor Fontane famously described the catastrophe that ended the British Army\u2019s attempt to secure hegemony against Russia in the Hindu Kush in 1842: \u201cWith 13,000 the trek began \u2014 one came home from Afghanistan.\u201d In one way or another, Russia and China may soon reap similar results.", "title": "Opinion | Who Will Win the New Great Game?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere\u2019s something to be said for the fact that you don\u2019t need to honor black folks by pleasing white people,\u201d said Quinton Lucas, a city councilman.\n\nMr. Lucas said he leaned toward giving the name to a street where white people tend to venture more often, because it could have a greater impact there. \u201cThere\u2019s something to be said for the fact that you need to make sure the entire community honors it, instead of saying, \u2018That\u2019s something the black folks are doing for the black folks in a black area.\u2019 \u201d\n\nComplicating this naming fight is a simple truth: Kansas City, like much of the country, struggles with segregation.\n\nTroost Avenue separates the east side of the city, where black residents are heavily concentrated, from the west. The coalition of black leaders, which includes Emanuel Cleaver II, a Democratic congressman and former mayor of Kansas City, has a street on the East Side in mind: Paseo Boulevard.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Paseo, as it is known, cuts a 10-mile north-south path through Kansas City that is a mix of promise and struggle. Parts of the boulevard have wide, grassy medians, Grecian columns, pergolas and classically styled mansions. But it also passes blighted homes, empty lots and depressed property values. It was named after Paseo de la Reforma, a grand thoroughfare in Mexico City.\n\nFor two years, advocates have lobbied the parks board, which oversees the city\u2019s boulevard system, to change the name. Jean-Paul Chaurand, the board president, responded last month with a letter stating that longstanding policy has been to name streets after local residents who made significant contributions to the city. He suggested creating a commission to discuss the renaming further.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat did not sit well with the advocates, who are pushing for the City Council to act, or for a referendum that would allow voters to decide the issue.\n\n\u201cIt is a travesty to the progress of racial justice and racial integration that it\u2019s being stopped,\u201d said Vernon P. Howard Jr., president of the city\u2019s chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and a leader of the coalition pushing to rename Paseo Boulevard.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s have white folks cross east of Troost,\u201d Mr. Howard said. \u201cLet\u2019s have them make this an integrated street, where they are required to stretch themselves and be a part of the African-American community.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne prominent black leader who is skeptical of the idea is the mayor, Sly James. He worries that, by naming a street in a mostly black part of town after Dr. King, \u201care you just moving a dividing line?\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m harkening back to all the cities that I\u2019ve been to, and have seen an M.L.K. Boulevard,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve never seen one in a shopping area. I\u2019ve never seen one that\u2019s been in anything other than a black neighborhood. Is Martin Luther King strictly a black hero? I would say not. I think he\u2019s a hero for everybody, and he ought to be honored that way.\u201d\n\nAt least 955 streets in the United States have been named after Dr. King, and they tend to be in lower-income areas with predominantly black populations, said Derek H. Alderman, a professor of geography at the University of Tennessee. But the idea that placing Dr. King\u2019s name on a street somehow causes a community to decline is inaccurate, Dr. Alderman said. It is more likely the other way around.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s because of the politics of the naming process,\u201d he said. \u201cThose were often the only streets that some African-American activists could get named for Dr. King.\u201d\n\nSince the first renaming of a street for Dr. King \u2014 in Chicago in 1968 \u2014 such moves have spurred debates in cities like Indianapolis a decade ago, and High Point, N.C., in 2015. Businesses and residents often complain about the hassles of address changes. Some people lament the supplanting of historical street names. Others say bluntly that the King name would hurt their communities.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Kansas City, residents vehemently opposed a proposal years ago to rename Prospect Avenue on the East Side after Dr. King, saying it would do nothing to benefit a deeply struggling part of town.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome residents have wondered whether it might be better to name an east-west street after Dr. King, because those streets connect black and white neighborhoods. Others have proposed streets in upscale areas that are mostly white, like the J.C. Nichols Parkway, which runs near the Country Club Plaza shopping district. Mr. Nichols, a developer who died in 1950, used racially restrictive covenants to prevent nonwhites from living in certain neighborhoods.\n\nMr. James, the mayor, appointed an advisory group this month to talk to residents and figure out the best way to honor Dr. King.\n\n\u201cWhy not put it right in the heart of the affluent part of the city,\u201d said Rita Hoop, a 50-year-old lawyer who is white, as she walked through the plaza, which Mr. Nichols designed. \u201cThat racial divide will not be addressed until every community addresses it, not just the black community.\u201d\n\nBut when Warren Turner, 53, was asked if a King street should be placed in a white neighborhood, he did not mince words: \u201cHell, no.\u201d\n\nMr. Turner, who has lived on the Paseo for a quarter-century, said it would be an honor to have it renamed because of what Dr. King meant to black people like him.\n\n\u201cI think, maybe it would bring some of the prestige back to the Paseo,\u201d he said.", "title": "Whose Neighborhood Should Get a Street Named for Dr. King?", "authors": ["John Eligon"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Today\u2019s highly industrialized economies \u2014 the United States and Europe \u2014 got a big head start on burning fossil fuels. But China and other developing nations have ramped up output in recent years.\n\nIn total, the United States pumped more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than any other nation between 1850 and 2014, the latest year for which the center\u2019s data is available. The European Union, including Britain, was the second-largest source of fossil-fuel emissions over that period; China came in third.\n\nBut China is today\u2019s biggest emitter, by a mile.\n\nThe rapidly industrializing country overtook the United States as the world\u2019s biggest source of carbon emissions in the mid-2000s, and has doubled its output since then.\n\nIn 2014, China released 10.3 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide from fossil fuels and industry; the United States released more than 5.2 billion metric tons that year.\n\n(Carbon emissions from both countries decreased slightly by 2016, according to the latest data from the related Global Carbon Project. But 2017 estimates suggest that Chinese emissions ticked back up last year.)\n\nChina\u2019s emissions per person are still much lower than the United States\u2019.\n\nChina may emit twice as much carbon dioxide as the United States today, but the country is home to four times as many people (about 1.4 billion compared to 328 million). Divvying up national emissions by population gives us a different view of \u201cresponsibility.\u201d\n\nSmall countries with fossil-fuel-intensive economies, like Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, tend to top the per capita emissions list. But among more populous nations, the United States, Canada and Australia rank highest.", "title": "Who\u2019s Most Responsible for Global Warming?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "As I was getting ready to leave the film board, I thought that this is an interest of mine and that I could dig a bit deeper into it and so I wrote to Douglas Rain.\n\n\n\nDid the film have a similar effect on Mr. Rain?\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was just a job for him. It doesn\u2019t really mean anything to him and he\u2019s never seen the film.\n\nHe was hired to do the narration for what was going to be an elaborate prologue to \u201c2001.\u201d They filmed interviews with all these amazing scientists and thinkers to set up the premise for the film and explain the context. But Kubrick stripped it away and didn\u2019t use the narration he\u2019d hired Rain to do.\n\nI think if Kubrick had kept all of the explanatory things it wouldn\u2019t it wouldn\u2019t be the classic that it is.\n\nSo how did Mr. Rain move from there to becoming HAL?\n\nIt was going to be Martin Balsam\u2019s voice. And even before that it was going to be a female voice. HAL was going to be an Athena.\n\nSo the voice was probably just a combination of circumstance and a gut choice by Kubrick. He literally said to Rain, \u2018I\u2019m not happy what I have in the can,\u2019 meaning the Martin Balsam recording that had been done a year before. \u2018Would you like to play the computer?\u2019 And then, in a day and a half, it was done.\n\nWhen I spoke to a linguist he said absolutely that HAL does not have a mid-Atlantic accent as Kubrick kind of thought. It\u2019s Standard Canadian English.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy is Mr. Rain indifferent toward the film?\n\nEven though it was done quickly and I don\u2019t think Rain had a very good time doing it, it was fantastic combination of Rain\u2019s performance, Kubrick\u2019s decision to use that voice and to edit it in a way that really brought that character to life.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Canada Letter Every week, receive a handpicked selection of news and opinion plus exclusive commentary from New York Times journalists.
