take aim at other countries,\u201d it said.\n\nThe party has also seized on the trade dispute as new evidence that the United States is intent on undermining China\u2019s rise as a global power, a central narrative used to justify the party\u2019s, and Mr. Xi\u2019s, rule.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn December, the state news media also highlighted the new National Security Strategy unveiled by the Trump administration, which declared that China \u201csought to displace the United States in the Indo-Pacific region, expand the reaches of its state-driven economic model, and reorder the region in its favor.\u201d\n\nThe document signaled a bipartisan shift in Washington\u2019s posture toward China after decades of economic cooperation and concessions. The party has argued that the United States is only now challenging China because it fears losing its privileged place in the world order.\n\n\u201cThe latest U.S. measures against China carry a sense of containment, which purportedly is commonplace among U.S. politicians,\u201d said an editorial in Global Times, a nationalist state-run tabloid. \u201cBut they have overlooked the fact that China has grown to be another economic center of the world.\u201d\n\nIt went on to note that China\u2019s market was now \u201cno smaller or less attractive\u201d than the American one \u2014 a bit of an exaggeration perhaps, but not as big as it would have been a decade ago. And that makes the country a more formidable opponent than Mr. Trump may have anticipated.\n\n\u201cTo take China down,\u201d the editorial said, \u201cwould mean an unimaginably cruel battle for the U.S.\u201d", "title": "Why China Is Confident It Can Beat Trump in a Trade War", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Thirty-four years after his death, Garry Winogrand\u2019s photographs continue to charm, befuddle and amaze viewers. A new book, \u201cThe Street Philosophy of Garry Winogrand,\u201d takes 100 photos and pairs each with an essay by Geoff Dyer. The experience was daunting, especially sifting through the stream of images shot in his prolific final years. But it was also quite the revelation. Jordan Teicher spoke with Mr. Dyer about the book, which was published by the University of Texas Press. Their conversation has been edited.\n\nQ: Why did you want to write this book?\n\nA: I was teaching down in Austin and had lunch with David Hamrick of the University of Texas Press, because I\u2019d written something for them before. Being a complete and utter lowlife I went along not just thinking, \u201cGreat, it\u2019s a free lunch,\u201d which is often motive enough for me, but I deliberately went along with a completely empty canvas bag in anticipation of all the free books I\u2019d take home.\n\nVery quickly, he came out with this line: \u201cI know what your next book is going to be.\u201d He then proceeded to remind me of something I\u2019d said in this printed email exchange with Janet Malcolm in Aperture, when having commented on the John Szarkowski book on [Eug\u00e8ne] Atget \u2014 which has a picture on each recto page, and an about 300-word caption on the facing verso page \u2014 I said something like, \u201cI hope I don\u2019t go to my grave without doing a book like that myself.\u201d So David said, \u201cWell, how about a book like that on Garry Winogrand?\u201d And it really this kind of lightning flash of a realization: \u201cOh my God, of course! This is what I\u2019ve been waiting for.\u201d The strange thing is I\u2019d not thought of Winogrand myself, but thankfully he had.", "title": "Why Did Garry Winogrand Photograph That?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "A lifetime ago, Anne Frank\u2019s family applied for visas to the United States to escape Hitler, but we rejected the Franks and other desperate Jewish refugees. We thought: This is Europe\u2019s problem, not ours, and we don\u2019t want to be overrun by \u201cthose people.\u201d\n\nToday President Trump is again slamming the door on desperate refugees. Indeed, the Trump administration is going a step further by wrenching children from the arms of asylum-seekers, apparently as a way of inflicting gratuitous cruelty to discourage new arrivals.\n\nJos\u00e9 Demar Fuentes, a 30-year-old college graduate, arrived in November with his 1-year-old son, Mateo, from El Salvador, where Fuentes was on a gang\u2019s execution list, according to his lawyer, Noreen Barcena. Father and son entered the United States legally, presenting themselves to an immigration officer, providing birth certificates and other documentation, and requesting asylum to save their lives.\n\nSeveral days later, immigration officers came and took Mateo.\n\n\u201cThey basically pried my client\u2019s son from his arms and told him that he had to give up his son,\u201d Barcena told me. \u201cThey were both crying.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Why Does Trump Treat Immigrant Kids Cruelly? Because He Can", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Those words often appeared alongside drawings by Keith Haring, who wasn\u2019t just the patron artist of ACT UP but the emblematic artist of the city during that period. His work \u2014 inspired by, and evocative of, graffiti \u2014 brought the street into the gallery, and vice versa, much as Jean-Michel Basquiat and his high school friend Al Diaz did around the turn of the decade, when their symbol \u201cSAMO\u201d suddenly sprouted on walls all across the city, the siren of a new sensibility.\n\nThe line between high and low culture, between fringe and mainstream, blurred. Hip-hop was one example. Madonna, who released her first album in 1983, was another. Both popularized and commercialized sounds and styles that Latino and black New Yorkers had already embraced. But they also reflected the abiding dissonance of those years: The very communities that were being creatively pillaged were being politically ignored and repressed, and their frustration would boil over as the decade progressed. Black New Yorkers marched in protest in 1986 after a young black man who was fleeing a mob of white youths was struck by a car and killed in the Howard Beach section of Queens. Those marchers were led by a fiery minister named Al Sharpton, whose relative anonymity at the start of the decade would be a distant memory by its end.\n\nJust as the era had its defining art and music, it had its signature restaurant, the Odeon. It opened in late 1980, pulling New Yorkers from more polished precincts to TriBeCa, which was then an urban frontier. In its sleek, unfussy dining room, glamour and grit sat cheek by jowl, and going to the bathroom to powder your nose could mean one of two things. That was immortalized in the novel \u201cBright Lights, Big City,\u201d which was published in 1984 and greeted less as fiction than as a distillation of the zeitgeist in all its greedy, seedy glory. It featured an illustration of the Odeon\u2019s Art Deco neon sign on its cover and established its author, Jay McInerney, as one of the nascent decade\u2019s bards. Like his protagonist, he relished being naughty but yearned to be rich; those desires were hardly irreconcilable in a city that simultaneously embraced the materialism of the Reagan era and rejected its moralism, where stretch limos deposited partygoers in unseemly neighborhoods and yuppies ran rampant while \u201cDie Yuppie Scum\u201d graffiti spread.\n\nThe Odeon was like Area, the rising Chelsea department store Barneys and so many other temples of the time: an improbable, irresistible nexus of tribes \u2014 bankers and sculptors, models and socialite housewives, power publicists and literary brats \u2014 that hadn\u2019t always played together before. \u201cThere had been a dividing line between uptown and downtown, and we wanted to make Barneys a hit so that everybody would come,\u201d Simon Doonan, who became the store\u2019s display director in the mid-80s, told me. \u201cWe broke down that division, which was more pronounced than it is now: The 1980s were when the cracks appeared.\u201d And Barneys was yet another gilded place to see and be seen, amid the wares of New York-based designers \u2014 Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Michael Kors \u2014 who weren\u2019t so much clothes makers as shamans, with a cache and currency that rivaled any Hollywood star\u2019s.\n\nTheir labels live on, with less shimmer. So does the Odeon, minus the bathroom rites. But the most important survivor of the early 1980s \u2014 something that was crystallized then \u2014 is the idea of New York as a cradle like none other in America, the country\u2019s messiest and most mesmerizing laboratory. \u201cNew York today is stronger economically, culturally more important and has a much different position in the world than it did then,\u201d said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban policy on the faculty of New York University since 1973. We have the early 1980s, in part, to thank for that.\n\nAnd I still feel the spirit, strivings and tensions of those years. We\u2019re a city once again at odds with the White House and its random and regressive edicts \u2014 with what it exalts and what it ignores. People are marching, though with pussy hats and Black Lives Matter signs as well as rainbow flags. We\u2019re at the forefront of the perversely belated quest for justice for women who have been sexually harassed and abused, and we\u2019re reckoning with how much our reality falls short of our ideals. New Yorkers, as always, come here to remake themselves \u2014 and to reinvent the city around them. It\u2019s an unfinished story, in which certain chapters are bolder and more complicated than others. One of them is now. One of them was then.", "title": "Why Early \u201980s New York Matters Today", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Even if it did pass \u2014 which seems unlikely in the current anti-regulation environment \u2014 the proposed certification requirement is unlikely to result in a wave of prosecutions. The criminal law is a blunt instrument for pursuing corporate misconduct, and executives are experts at keeping problems at arms-length, or at least maintaining the kind of plausible deniability that makes it difficult to prosecute them.\n\nProsecuting a bank is easier than proving an individual committed a crime. The intent of all employees is attributed to the organization, which is vicariously liable for what individuals do on its behalf. But prosecuting executives means showing they had knowledge of a violation. That can be difficult.\n\nMs. Warren\u2019s bill tries to remedy that by forcing management to make the necessary inquiries to determine that the organization is not violating the law.\n\nThe bill would add a new offense for an executive who \u201cwillfully\u201d files a false certification, including violations that are \u201cpart of a pattern of any illegal activity involving more than $100,000\u201d in a year. The maximum penalty would be up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe challenge for prosecuting such violations would be showing the requisite intent. The Supreme Court noted in Bryan v. United States that \u201cwillfully\u201d is \u201ca word of many meanings whose construction is often dependent on the context in which it appears.\u201d That means a court could interpret the provision as requiring proof a defendant purposely sought to mislead the government in filing a false certification. Such an interpretation would be a substantial hurdle to proving a violation.\n\nAnother possibility is having to show merely that executives knew they were engaged in wrongful activity. That is much easier to prove and something that prosecutors would no doubt prefer.\n\nCongress adopted a similar certification requirement in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act in 2002 in response to the accounting frauds at Enron and WorldCom. Under the law, the chief executives and chief financial officers of publicly traded companies must certify that any report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission \u201cfairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operation\u201d of the company, with a knowing or willful violation subject to criminal prosecution.\n\nThe first high-profile prosecution under the statute involved Richard M. Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth. But the case resulted in an acquittal, a black eye for the Justice Department.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Sarbanes-Oxley certification statute has been used in only a few cases since. In each instance, prosecutors had evidence that the executive had direct knowledge of the fraudulent activity.\n\nAbsent proof of an executive\u2019s involvement, or at least knowledge, of the fraud, a willful violation of the certification requirement in Ms. Warren\u2019s legislation would be difficult to prove. We can expect executives to put in new procedures to show that they tried to comply with the law, which can provide a basis for claiming there was not an intentional violation of the certification requirement.\n\nFor those reasons, I doubt the Too Big to Jail Act would result in increased criminal liability for executives. There is no simple cure to the challenge of holding senior managers responsible for what takes place within their organizations.", "title": "Why Elizabeth Warren\u2019s Effort to Hold Bank Executives Accountable May Fall Short", "authors": ["Peter J. Henning", "White Collar Watch"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "The wheels then were unlocked and for nine days, the mice could run at will, while also eating and moving around off the wheels as much as they chose.\n\nThe mice, which seem to enjoy running, hopped readily on the wheels and ran, off and on, for hours.\n\nThey showed a subsequent spike in their daily energy expenditure, according to the metabolic measures, which makes sense, since they had added exercise to their lives.\n\nBut they did not change their eating habits. Although they were burning more calories, they did not gorge on more chow.\n\nThey did, however, alter how they moved. Almost immediately after they started using the wheels, they stopped roaming around their cages as they had before the wheels were unlocked.\n\nIn particular, they stopped engaging in the kind of lengthy meanders that had been common before they began to run. Instead, they now usually jogged on their wheels for a few minutes, hopped off, rested or roamed in short spurts, and then climbed back on the wheels, ran, rested, briefly roamed, and repeated.\n\nThese changes in how they spent their time neatly managed to almost counteract the extra calorie costs from running, says Daniel Lark, a research fellow in molecular physiology at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, who led the new study.\n\nIn general, the running mice showed a slightly negative energy balance, meaning that they were burning a few more calories over the course of the day than they were taking in by chowing down.", "title": "Why Exercise Alone May Not Be the Key to Weight Loss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "COX\u2019S BAZAR, Bangladesh \u2014 I try not to overthink it, because there are probably 101 better things to do with my time, but I spend a lot of time scrolling through, liking, laughing at, getting angry about and sharing things I see on social media. Facebook tells me I have 3,549 friends when in real life I probably have around 30.\n\nIt might have something to do with my work. For the past eight years, I\u2019ve been supporting humanitarian aid work, far from where I grew up, in Alsager, England. My family and friends are all far away, so I see most of them only on Facebook. I can remember birthdays, and see friends fall in love and get married and have kids. I have never been one to pick up the phone, but give me 10 minutes on Messenger with a pal and I am instantly gratified.\n\nIt took my sister a million years to get a smartphone. She claimed that her reliable Motorola flip, circa 2001, was adequate. Imagine my delight when she entered my world in 2018 and got WhatsApp. We are many time zones apart, but a love-heart-and-kisses emoji goes a long way in a second.\n\nI am really no different from anyone else using Facebook. The dog in the file cabinet made my day. I post photos of my work and travels. The only difference is that I might post updates on Instagram and my Facebook page from unusual locations \u2014 like Quetta, Pakistan, during a polio campaign; at the United Nations to see the Pope; or on my daily commute to the largest refugee camp in the world.", "title": "Opinion | Why Facebook Still Matters to Me", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "And one more difference between the Godwin\u2019s-law internet and today\u2019s is that there is now a much greater supply of that sort of person \u2014 all sorts of persons \u2014 sharing the same enormous communications platforms. Everything is both more crowded and more interconnected. Toss a thought into the digital ether, and strangers can drive by from any direction, doling out hypothetical challenges, probing your convictions at their leisure, demanding you justify yourself. And sometimes this is less like an undergraduate seminar and more like a man in a bus-station crowd grabbing you by the collar and slurring, \u201cJust for the sake of argument. ... \u201d\n\nA little more than a decade ago, around the same time online sentiment began to turn against the devil\u2019s advocate, it also seized on a close cousin: the \u201cconcern troll.\u201d If the devil\u2019s advocate playacts disagreement with you for the sake of strengthening your argument, the concern troll is his mirror image, a person who pretends to agree with you in order to undermine you. The concern troll airs disingenuous worries, sows doubt, saps energy, has reservations, worries that things are going too far. At first, the term described purposeful double agents \u2014 people like the congressional staffer suspected, back in 2006, of posing as a Democrat to leave comments on liberal blogs suggesting everyone abandon the candidate vying for a Republican incumbent\u2019s seat. But the term has evolved in such a way that, at this point, a person can very easily qualify as a concern troll without even knowing it.\n\nA tidy summary on the \u201cGeek Feminism\u201d Wiki site explains why this is the case: Even earnest concern-airing can be pernicious, turning every discussion into a battle over basic premises. An activist group trying to combat climate change, for instance, cannot afford to let every conversation devolve into a debate about whether climate change exists. Other concern trolls may insist that they agree with a group in theory despite consistently opposing it in practice. (According to that Wiki, they might \u201cview themselves as potential allies who have just, oddly, never met a feminist opinion they liked.\u201d) But as the definition has expanded, even honest critics \u2014 people who earnestly disagree with their peers, even by a very little bit \u2014 can find themselves accused of discursive sabotage.\n\nThis confusion is not limited to liberal in-groups. A 2009 article in the conservative American Thinker suggested the following statement was a good example of diversionary trolling: \u201cThe court has ruled that Obama is a U.S. citizen. I think it\u2019s time for us to move on to more substantive issues.\u201d Before the 2016 election, the pro-Trump Reddit forum \u201cthe_donald\u201d banned what it considered concern trolling, giving moderators license to boot any Trump supporter who might have pointed out, say, that the subreddit had become an alarming pit of hate speech. There is almost no variety of self-selecting online community where this dynamic doesn\u2019t hold at least some sway \u2014 a guardedness, whether overt or subtle, against taking time to entertain challenges or skepticism toward group dogma.\n\nThere\u2019s one very simple trend that might explain this, and a lot besides. As more people began to spend more of each day arguing about serious issues with strangers online, it became necessary to sort out which opinions could be summarily dismissed. So the devil\u2019s advocate is pictured as a highhanded nerd popping up to play logic games in the face of pressing issues. Concern trolls are disingenuous drags on the conversation. There\u2019s hand-wringing, derailing, distraction, tone policing, silencing, gaslighting, \u201csea lioning\u201d \u2014 a label for every depressing rhetorical habit that could possibly present itself, each term a tool for narrowing down the number of ideas waiting in line for your consideration. Taken as a whole, this taxonomy feels both totally rational and slightly desperate \u2014 a way of insisting, against abundant evidence to the contrary, that a productive conversation remains possible.", "title": "Why Have We Soured on the \u2018Devil\u2019s Advocate\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Representatives of the General Union of Cultural Centers, the nongovernmental organization for which I serve as executive director, participated in planning meetings for the march, which included voices from all segments of Gaza\u2019s civil and political society. At the border, I haven\u2019t seen a single Hamas flag, or Fatah banner, or poster for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, for that matter \u2014 paraphernalia that have been widespread in virtually every other protest I have witnessed. Here, we have flown only one flag \u2014 the Palestinian flag.\n\nTrue, Hamas members are participating, as they are part of the Palestinian community. But that participation signals, perhaps, that they may be shifting away from an insistence on liberating Palestine through military means and are beginning to embrace popular, unarmed civil protest. But the Great Return March is not Hamas\u2019s action. It is all of ours.\n\nAnd our action has been so much more than tires burning or young men throwing stones at soldiers stationed hundreds of meters away. The resistance in the encampments has been creative and beautiful. I danced the dabke, the Palestinian national dance, with other young men. I tasted samples of the traditional culinary specialties being prepared, such as msakhan (roasted chicken with onions, sumac and pine nuts) and maftool (a couscous dish). I sang traditional songs with fellow protesters and sat with elders who were sharing anecdotes about pre-1948 life in their native villages. Some Fridays, kites flew, and on others flags were hoisted on 80-foot poles to be clearly visible on the other side of the border.\n\nAll this was taking place under the rifle sights of Israeli snipers stationed about 700 meters away. We were tense, we were fearful \u2014 indeed, I\u2019ve been in the proximity of people getting shot and tear-gassed \u2014 but we were joyful. The singing, the dancing, the storytelling, the flags, the kites and the food are more than symbols of cultural heritage.\n\nThey demonstrate \u2014 clearly, loudly, vibrantly and peacefully \u2014 that we exist, we will remain, we are humans deserving of dignity, and we have the right to return to our homes. I long to sleep under the olive trees of Bayt Daras, my native village. I want to show Ali, Karam and Adam the mosque that my grandfather prayed in. I want to live peacefully in my historic home with all my neighbors, be they Muslim, Christian, Jewish or atheist.\n\nThe people in Gaza have been living one tragedy after another: waves of mass displacement, life in squalid refugee camps, a captured economy, restricted access to fishing waters, a strangling siege and three wars in the past nine years. Israel assumed that once the generation who experienced the Nakba died, the youth would relinquish our dream of return. I believe this is partly why Israel keeps Gaza on the brink of humanitarian collapse \u2014 if our lives are reduced to a daily struggle for food, water, medicine and electricity, we won\u2019t be able to think about larger aspirations. The march is proving that my generation has no intention of abandoning our people\u2019s dreams.\n\nThe Great Return March has kindled my optimism, but I am also realistic. Alone, the march will not end the siege and the occupation, address the huge power imbalance that exists between Israel and the Palestinians or right the historical wrongs. The work continues until everyone in the region can share equal rights. But I could not be more inspired by or proud of my people \u2014 seeing us united under one flag, with nearly unanimous acceptance of peaceful methods to call for our rights and insist on our humanity.", "title": "Opinion | Why I March in Gaza", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "To tell the story, I\u2019d need to deal with my own financial mistakes. My wife, Jeanne, and I bought an apartment in New York City that we were later unable to sell when I got a job in Washington in the 1990s, and we were driven nearly to bankruptcy. Ultimately, we lost that apartment in foreclosure, which left me feeling like an utter failure.\n\nI hated dredging up the emotions from such a tumultuous time \u2014 who wouldn\u2019t? I felt the same angry tightness in my gut that hit me while I was trying to get a deadbeat tenant out of the New York apartment, the same weight on my chest I felt after giving up that apartment, then the biggest investment of my life. But I wanted to write a book that people might see a little of themselves in, and many of us have lived through financial stress and confusion. Telling it honestly might engage readers, and accomplish the main thing I was trying to do with the book: to reach readers who, like me, are a little afraid of thinking about money.\n\nI was also guided by that wonderful line from Jude Fawley, the tormented protagonist of Thomas Hardy\u2019s \u201cJude the Obscure,\u201d who said, \u201cI may do some good before I am dead \u2014 be a sort of success as a frightful example of what not to do; and so illustrate a moral story.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBesides, two decades after the lowest point in our financial mess, the story has a happy ending. We did climb out of the tightest times. Although paying college costs for our three children did put us under financial pressure again, we have stood on our own. Also, I really did a creditable job of putting my financial life in order \u2014 getting a will, vetting my 401(k), assessing my life insurance and more. I could tell a story that, when all is said and done, I feel good about.\n\nOne of the delights of the project was tracking down the lawyer who guided us through the worst times, who had explained to me that, despite the advice of friends and even of another lawyer I\u2019d hired to help us through the tenant problem, we didn\u2019t have to file for bankruptcy. The bankruptcy specialist, Gregory Johnson, was great to reconnect with after all those years in a series of emails and an emotional phone call in which I was able to thank him for saving our financial lives. He said that he had seen so many cases like ours, and that he understood the anxiety we\u2019d gone through. \u201cIt\u2019s like the horror movies,\u201d he said; the biggest fear comes from anticipation.\n\nIn writing this book, I was aided by the fact that I had written about my family before. My previous book, \u201cOddly Normal,\u201d described raising our youngest son, Joseph, who had a difficult childhood and struggled with his sexuality. We as parents struggled, too, to help him become more comfortable with himself. That book, which I wrote with Joseph\u2019s permission and help, was received well, and that led me to think that sharing our financial stories might also lead to good things.\n\nHere\u2019s hoping.", "title": "Why I Wrote a Book About My Finances (Foreclosure and All)", "authors": ["John Schwartz"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "I now have two sons, ages 16 and 18. I do not have custody of them \u2014 I lost it when I left the Hasidic world, and so I have no control over their education. Today, they cannot speak, read or write in English past a second-grade level. (As for my three daughters, their English skills are fine. Girls, not obligated with Torah study, generally receive a decent secular education.)\n\nLike me, my sons will be expected to marry young and raise large families. They too will receive no guidance on how to provide for them and will be forced into low-wage jobs and rely heavily on government support.\n\nThey are not alone. Across the state, there are dozens of Hasidic yeshivas, with tens of thousands of students \u2014 nearly 60,000 in New York City alone \u2014 whose education is being atrociously neglected. These schools receive hundreds of millions of dollars in government funding, through federal programs like Title I and Head Start and state programs like Academic Intervention Services and universal pre-K. For New York City\u2019s yeshivas, $120 million comes from the state-funded, city-run Child Care and Development Block Grant subsidy program: nearly a quarter of the allocation to the entire city.\n\nAccording to New York State law, nonpublic schools are required to offer a curriculum that is \u201csubstantially equivalent\u201d to that of public schools. But when it comes to Hasidic yeshivas, this law has gone unenforced for decades. The result is a community crippled by poverty and a systemic reliance on government funding for virtually all aspects of life.\n\nMen like Mr. Felder, beholden not so much to his Hasidic constituents as much as to their leaders who promise him votes, would like to pretend that this problem doesn\u2019t exist. The leadership of the Hasidic community argues that the issue is exaggerated, an attempt by outsiders to malign their community. They point to outliers, successful entrepreneurs \u2014 the Hasidic-owned electronics store B & H Photo Video in New York City is often touted \u2014 as examples of success.\n\nBut these are rare exceptions.\n\nAccording to a report by Yaffed, or Young Advocates for Fair Education, an organization that advocates for improved general studies in Hasidic yeshivas, an estimated 59 percent of Hasidic households are poor or near-poor. According to United States Census figures, the all-Hasidic village of Kiryas Joel, an hour north of New York City, is the poorest in the country, with median family income less than $18,000.\n\nOne heavily Hasidic district of Brooklyn, South Williamsburg, has, over the last decade, shown dramatic increases in using public income support such as cash assistance, Supplemental Security Income and Medicaid. New York\u2019s Hasidic community is also experiencing explosive growth \u2014 surveys show that the Jewish population of the five boroughs has increased for the first time in half a century, entirely because of the high birthrate among the ultra-Orthodox, which only increases the burden on taxpayers.\n\nKnowing all of this, it takes a special kind of audacity on Mr. Felder\u2019s part to successfully strong-arm the state\u2019s highest legislative body to legally deprive his own constituents\u2019 children of an education and a future. Some might call this chutzpah. In Borough Park, it would be more properly called a Chillul Hashem: a desecration of God\u2019s name.", "title": "Opinion | Why Is New York Condoning Illiteracy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "My past sounds melodramatic. By 17, I\u2019d left high school and moved out on my own. I\u2019ve survived divorced parents, a neglectful childhood, depression, an eating disorder, an abusive relationship, a traumatic car accident and a sexual assault. Seeing that list, it sounds absurd that all of that could happen to me. But here I am, paying for my therapy and yoga and journaling as often as I can. I\u2019m trying my best. Some of the women I work with are also going to school. When I think of their hard work, I swell with pride. I regard those who have survived eating disorders and toxic relationships as heroes. My friends and wonderful partner remind me almost daily that I\u2019m killing it, but I still think of myself as a loser. Some days I\u2019m furious with myself for not trying harder and being better. I beat up on myself for not going back to school sooner or getting a better job or writing more. I wish I could give myself the love I give others. And I wish I believed I can succeed because I\u2019m really not sure. What if my luck was used up and now I have none left?\n\nProud of Everyone but Myself\n\nSteve Almond: You did not survive the traumas of your childhood because you were lucky. You survived \u2014 and are thriving \u2014 because of your courage and resilience. Everyone around you can see that. But that doesn\u2019t help if you yourself can\u2019t esteem who you are and what you\u2019ve done. Most of the letters we receive at Dear Sugars come from people just like you, Proud, who tell themselves the same bad story: that no matter how hard they work to transcend their struggles, they aren\u2019t enough. And this bad story always begets a bad outcome. Rather than taking pride in all you\u2019ve accomplished \u2014 supporting yourself, acing your classes, establishing loving relationships, working to heal yourself \u2014 you see only your inadequacies. Even the hardships you\u2019ve endured get written off as \u201cmelodramatic.\u201d The question is: Why? I suspect the answer lies in a kind of twisted loyalty to the sorrow of your past. When you grow up amid instability, fear, and sadness, these feelings become your default setting, the known, and the safe. And it\u2019s hard to leave them behind and enter the kingdom of self-love. It makes you feel na\u00efve and unguarded, fully vulnerable to what the writer Sarah Manguso calls \u201cthe burden of hope.\u201d\n\nCheryl Strayed: I couldn\u2019t agree more with Steve\u2019s point that you don\u2019t magically arrive in the land of self-love and confidence by accident, Proud. There are reasons you\u2019re struggling to feel O.K. about yourself: the wounds of your past. Everything else \u2014 your solid track record as a student and employee, your wonderful partner and friends, your deeply enriching self-care roster of therapy, yoga and journaling \u2014 are all thanks to you. Not luck. Not coincidence. You. You know why? Because you\u2019re a survivor. You have done incredibly well against many odds. And you\u2019ve done that, in part, by refusing to allow those wounds of yours to rule your life. Well done, sister. I\u2019m proud of you. You made it this far, but there\u2019s further to go. You can\u2019t yet love yourself because there\u2019s more work to do and it has to do with healing the things that have hurt you. You\u2019re now strong enough to take a deeper look at that.", "title": "Why Is the Greatest Love of All Also the Hardest?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Why do you look so angry? This article hasn\u2019t even begun and already you disapprove. Why can\u2019t I ever win with you? I see it in your face.\n\nIf this sounds unfamiliar, good for you. You don\u2019t need this.\n\nFor the rest of us, it may be helpful to know that some people seem to have outsize difficulty with reading neutral faces as neutral, even if they are exceptionally accurate at interpreting other facial expressions. Over the past decade psychologists have been piecing together why this occurs.\n\nA study published in March in the Journal of Social and Personal Relationships suggests that some people who grew up with parents who fought a lot never learned to properly read those in-between faces, perhaps because they spent so much time watching out for signs of conflict.", "title": "Why It Seems as if Everyone Is Always Angry With You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "For a long time, the answer was high above Hong Kong\u2019s bustling city streets. Laundry hung out to dry on poles sticking out from the sides of buildings was so ubiquitous that it was jokingly called Hong Kong\u2019s \u201cnational flag.\u201d\n\nThat began to change in the 1980s, when washing machines and dryers became affordable as Hong Kong got wealthier, buoyed by the opening up of China\u2019s economy and the city\u2019s establishment as a major financial center.\n\nWalk around Hong Kong\u2019s public housing blocks and old tenement buildings today, and it quickly becomes clear that many residents still hang their clothes outside to dry. But rising incomes have allowed much of Hong Kong\u2019s population to move into sleek, glass apartment towers, without all the visible hanging laundry.\n\nNow, as housing prices grow ever more expensive per square foot, the challenge is no longer affording the washing and drying machines themselves, but finding the space to put them.\n\nOne result was a surge in demand for drop-off service at commercial laundries, which have long been common in Hong Kong. That led to such a backlog at some laundries that some customers faced days-long waits just to get their clothes back.\n\nPhoto\n\nEnter self-service laundromats.\n\nOn a recent evening after work, Michael Bolger, 27, sat reading a dog-eared book while waiting for his clothes at Coffee & Laundry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bolger, a native of Ireland who works at a bitcoin exchange, said that when he first moved to Hong Kong in 2016, his flat was too small to fit a dryer, and the humidity prevented his clothes from drying properly on a line. For a while he used a drop-off laundry, but his clothes would sometimes come back with tears and stains.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nice to just sit and read in a place that\u2019s not your apartment,\u201d he said of Coffee & Laundry. \u201cIt\u2019s kind of therapeutic, sitting here and watching the washing machines.\u201d\n\nNot far from Coffee & Laundry is a branch of LaundrYup, a local chain of self-service laundromats. The shop, steps away from a street full of antique stores, is tiny and strictly functional, with shiny white floor tiles, bright fluorescent lights and a single red bench. Instead of a cafe, there are lockers rented out to SF Express, a logistics company sometimes referred to as China\u2019s FedEx.\n\nPatten Mak, the chain\u2019s operations manager, said the combination of high demand and low maintenance and labor costs made it possible for even a tiny laundromat to earn the equivalent of thousands of dollars per month, enough to entice new chains to enter the market.\n\nAcross the harbor, in the working-class neighborhood of Tai Kok Tsui, a woman tapped away at a game of mah-jongg on her phone while waiting for her sheets to dry at a branch of Water Laundry, another local chain. Nearly every inch of the wall in the small laundromat was covered with machines.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cUs working class, we don\u2019t have the money to buy a washing machine, and there\u2019s no space to dry clothes at home,\u201d said the 40-year-old housewife, who gave her name as Ms. Lo. She said she lived in a cramped 90-square-foot subdivided flat with her husband.\n\n\u201cThis is an economic problem,\u201d she said. \u201cYou wouldn\u2019t use this kind of laundromat if you have money.\u201d\n\nThe spread of laundromats has begun to alter the social fabric of the city as laundry, which was once conducted in private, has been forced into the public realm, said Jianxiang Huang, a professor in the Department of Urban Planning and Design at the University of Hong Kong.\n\n\u201cThis is essentially changing the way people socialize, the way people live their lives, changing their mind-sets,\u201d Mr. Huang said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is exactly the goal of Mr. Lo, the co-founder of Coffee & Laundry, who said he wanted his shop to be as much a neighborhood hangout as a place to wash clothes. To this end, he has put tables on the sidewalk and scheduled events like an exhibition of a local comic book artist.\n\nOn a recent evening, there was a steady trickle of customers going in and out of Coffee & Laundry. Some milled around in slippers and pajama pants, counting down the last few minutes of the dryer cycle. Others said they had come for the coffee and ambience.\n\n\u201cNow in Hong Kong, people aren\u2019t always very neighborly,\u201d Mr. Lo said. Since opening Coffee & Laundry, however, \u201cI\u2019ve gotten to know my neighbors and the owners of dried seafood shops nearby,\u201d he said.", "title": "Why Laundromats Are the Hot New Place to Hang Out in Hong Kong", "authors": ["Mary Hui"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Women may also be better able to recalibrate their behavior and expectations based on circumstances (even if that doesn\u2019t mean making the more self-preservationist decision to quit altogether).\n\n\u201cAmong the athletes I\u2019ve coached, I think I\u2019ve had more women where when it\u2019s bad, they can blow up but they\u2019ll still finish the race, whereas men drop out,\u201d said the elite distance coach Steve Magness. \u201cWomen generally seem better able to adjust their goals in the moment, whereas men will see their race as more black or white, succeed or fail, and if it\u2019s fail, why keep going?\u201d\n\nAmericans in the elite races provided some evidence. The men\u2019s favorite Galen Rupp chased the lead pack until he dropped out around the 20-mile mark with hypothermia; in the women\u2019s race the favorites Molly Huddle and Shalane Flanagan dropped to paces much slower than their goal but still finished. In the early miles, the women worked together; Desiree Linden, another favorite, struggled and told Flanagan she thought she might quit, but hung in to support her teammates a few more miles for the American victory they sought. Then Linden bounced back and won.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a biological and social tendency for women to tend toward caregiving,\u201d said Adam Grant, the psychologist and host of the TED podcast WorkLife. \u201cSo what I would expect to happen is, when the going gets tough, the men either quit or they double down and say, \u2018I\u2019m just going to push through,\u2019 whereas women are more likely to reach out to runners next to them and offer support and seek support. Sharing pain and being part of a group can make it easier to withstand pain.\u201d\n\nOf course, the people who run Boston are a self-selecting group. Women are often discouraged from being athletic and competitive, so the female runners who made it to Boston had already overcome more social obstacles than men. They may simply be tougher, and this was a year when toughness worked.\n\nSo the simplest explanation is not based on gender at all. This Boston Marathon was ideal for people who thrive in adversity. Top spots for men and women went to amateur runners who juggle training in non-ideal circumstances around work and family. The men\u2019s winner, Yuki Kawauchi, is a high school administrator in Japan; Boston was already his fourth marathon, and fourth victory, of this year.\n\n\u201cFor me,\u201d Kawauchi explained after he won, \u201cthese were the best conditions possible.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Why Men Quit and Women Don\u2019t", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "What this means for the Trump coalition is that lots of Republicans who once resisted the Trumpian takeover have now accepted the various narratives that cast him as an indispensable man \u2014 because he\u2019s the only Republican who knows how to fight, because his removal would be a victory for the hated establishment and the even more hated media and the many-tentacled Deep State, because whatever else happens you can\u2019t let the liberals win. And evangelicals have their particular version of these Trump-the-indispensable conceits, from the analogies to King David (who slept around a lot, too, didn\u2019t he?) to the widespread belief that Trump\u2019s repeated against-the-odds victories mean that Providence somehow chose him for this role \u2014 and whom God has elevated, let no man impeach.\n\nBut for all their inevitable appeal, these are bad reasons to pre-emptively reject impeachment, in the Daniels case or any other that Mueller might reveal. And I don\u2019t just mean they\u2019re bad reasons because they\u2019re too partisan and tribal; I mean that the evidence from the last case like this, the Clinton impeachment in all its splendor, is that the partisan and tribal response does not necessarily serve your party or tribe that well.\n\nThere is no way of knowing exactly what would have happened, of course, had Clinton been pushed out by Senate Democrats and Al Gore installed in his place. But there are good reasons to suspect that as an incumbent steward of late-1990s prosperity untainted by his steadfast support for a lying boss, Gore would have had an easier time dispatching George W. Bush in 2000, and the entire trajectory of the early 2000s would have been more favorable to Democrats. And there are also good reasons to think that professional feminists, who contorted themselves absurdly in defense of Clinton\u2019s predatory conduct, would have been better off accelerating their reckoning with the pigs of liberalism rather than waiting for the age of Trump and the old age of Harvey Weinstein.\n\nThese lessons could apply to a Trump impeachment as much as to the Lewinsky affair. A Republican Party that ran in 2020 with a boring Midwestern guy (albeit, yes, one sure to be trailed by protesters in Handmaid outfits) as the steward of prosperity would not necessarily be worse off than a party lashed to its current leader; if Gerald Ford could almost win in Nixon\u2019s shadow, why not Pence in Trump\u2019s? And a religious conservatism that sacrificed a lot of cultural credibility in defending Trump might regain a little by abandoning him, vindicating itself against what seem now like reasonable charges of \u201ccharacter for thee but not for me\u201d hypocrisy.\n\nPlus, there\u2019s the providential aspect. Sure, making use of Donald Trump to keep Hillary Clinton from being president is a fascinating flourish by history\u2019s Author, but the idea that the Almighty might use a porn star to make Mike Pence president represents, if anything, an even more amazing miracle. So anyone interested in looking for the hand of God in history should probably welcome that miracle\u2019s arrival, rather than resisting in the name of MAGA.\n\nAm I jesting? Only to a point. That God has a sense of dramatic irony and narrative surprise seems like one of the most obvious lessons to be drawn from the Trump era. That God is using Trump not as an agent of his good work but as a kind of ongoing test of everyone else\u2019s moral character seems like a not-unreasonable inference to draw. That God would offer religious conservatives in danger of selling their souls a chance not just to step back from the brink but to literally replace Donald Trump with a fellow religious conservative \u2014 well, that seems like just the kind of opportunity that a beneficent deity would grant to erring members of his flock.\n\nAnd for those same religious conservatives to pass up the chance, preferring a scorched-earth battle in defense of priapism, would be a sad confirmation of the point that a beloved Christian author made many years ago: The doors of hell are locked on the inside.", "title": "Opinion | Why Not Mike Pence?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "On their second meeting, she said, he invited her to his suite at the Las Vegas Hilton, because he wanted her to practice improvising, even though she wasn\u2019t an actor. He gave her alcohol to relax, she said, and soon afterward she felt woozy and sick, like she might topple.\n\nMr. Cosby beckoned her over, she said, pulled her down between his legs, so that her back was against his groin, and began stroking her hair. Ms. Lublin remembers wondering why he was doing that, and that she couldn\u2019t understand a word he was saying. She has a few fractured memories of being guided by him down a hallway of the suite, and then nothing, until she woke up at home in her bed.\n\nMs. Lublin was mortified, but not, at the time, because of anything Mr. Cosby might have done. \u201cI looked at it as \u2018Oh my god, Lisa, you got sick from alcohol; you don\u2019t even remember how you got home,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nWhen Mr. Cosby reached out to her again, and even forged a friendship with her mother, she felt reassured: Maybe her blackout behavior hadn\u2019t been that bad. Ms. Lublin said she and Mr. Cosby met several times after that \u2014 though never alone \u2014 and that at his urging, she began running at a track as he looked on.\n\nWhen bystanders asked what Mr. Cosby was doing there, Ms. Lublin said he replied, \u201cI\u2019m out here with my daughter, Lisa.\u201d (Lisa is the name she goes by.) Eventually they fell out of touch.\n\nAfter Ms. Dickinson went public with her story late in 2014, Ms. Lublin began reconsidering what really happened at the hotel that night.", "title": "Why One Woman Testified Against Bill Cosby: \u2018I Had the Strength\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "For 50 years, Paul Theroux\u2019s addictive novels and brutally honest travel narratives have inspired readers to leave home, travel slow and with a purpose beyond sightseeing. His versatility and boundless curiosity shine in \u201cFigures in a Landscape,\u201d a new collection of essays (to be published on May 8), and in his latest autobiographical novel, \u201cMother Land\u201d (which will be published in paperback on May 1), where Mr. Theroux takes readers to his beloved Cape Cod and deep inside the Machiavellian world of a large, dysfunctional family run by a scheming matriarch. It\u2019s a deeply revealing and wickedly funny gem that may be the best book ever written about the interpersonal dynamics of a big family. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with him.\n\nWhy did you choose to set this novel on Cape Cod?\n\nThe Cape is the scene of my childhood happiness. As a traveler, you look for conflicted or misunderstood or little known places \u2014 good places to write about. But the place that makes you happy as a child is one you return to \u2014 the blue remembered hills, the happy highways of the Housman poem. If you have the opportunity, you go back there to recapture that sense of serenity you had in your childhood. My childhood was late 40s, early 50s \u2014 a period when Cape Cod was small and simple. The cottage we rented didn\u2019t have a refrigerator; there was an ice man who delivered blocks of ice for the chest.\n\nI remember the sunshine, the beaches, the smell of the salt marshes. I grew up in Medford [Massachusetts], but my parents moved to the Cape, and I always wanted to come back here. And so, as soon as I had some money, around 1975, when I was living in London, I bought a house on the Cape and I\u2019ve spent every summer here since then.", "title": "Why Paul Theroux Loves Cape Cod", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "In the aftermath of Dr. King\u2019s death, the civil rights movement was still a powerful force, leveling obstacles wherever it could, even out there on the prairie. Women were beginning to benefit from the addition of the word \u201csex\u201d to Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, and as the decade progressed, other groups began to assert their own claims to justice. Only five days before Kennedy\u2019s visit to Pine Ridge, Lyndon Johnson signed the Indian Civil Rights Act.\n\nKennedy\u2019s searing experience on a speaking tour of South Africa in 1966 may have had something to do with it, too. In Cape Town and elsewhere, he had enraged the apartheid regime with his forceful speeches against racial oppression. South Africa had created \u201chomelands,\u201d as the government called them; critics called them \u201cBantustans.\u201d African tribal populations were relocated there, to live in deep poverty. They were not very different from Native American reservations.\n\nAs a senator, Kennedy had focused increasingly on poverty, urban and rural, calling attention to inequality in a series of trips into some of the poorest parts of the country. In early February, he spent two days in eastern Kentucky\u2019s coal country, meeting with families trying to survive day to day. It was as if he were the senator from a much larger constituency than New York.\n\nFor all of these reasons, it was no surprise to see Kennedy devote extraordinary resources to a political constituency that had no ability to elect him. According to the historian Thurston Clarke, Kennedy scheduled approximately 70 events during the first month of his campaign \u2014 10 of them on Indian reservations or at Indian schools.\n\nHe began his journey on the morning of April 16. It required a complicated set of flights to reach a tiny town in Nebraska that served as the nearest airport. The long drive from there to the reservation in South Dakota was an education in itself. There was no infrastructure of the type Americans were used to. No buses, no banks, no supermarkets. Unemployment was 75 percent. Half of the homes lacked electricity or running water. Schools had no supplies. Life expectancy \u2014 48 years for men, 52 for women \u2014 was the second-lowest in the hemisphere, after that in Haiti.\n\nTwelve days earlier, Kennedy had accomplished what seemed impossible, when he connected with an angry and distrustful African-American audience in Indianapolis the night that Dr. King was killed. A few days later, after attending a Sunday church service in Washington, he took an impromptu walk through the riot-torn parts of the city, attracting an awe-struck crowd of hundreds. Now he was doing it again, forging a common bond with fellow citizens who looked nothing like him.\n\nKennedy\u2019s motorcade stopped here and there; at Calico Village he sat with a 10-year-old Lakota Sioux, Christopher Pretty Boy, who had lost his parents in a car crash a week earlier. McGovern had tagged along for the day, and together he and Kennedy convened a public hearing of their subcommittee, in a community hall. More than a thousand attended. McGovern later said that he had never seen \u201cso many Indian voters assembled in one place.\u201d He and Kennedy listened as people poured out their stories of hunger, joblessness and inadequate health care.\n\nAfter the hearing ended, Kennedy made an impetuous request: to see the small monument commemorating the massacre of Native Americans at Wounded Knee in 1890. As McGovern later recalled, it was just \u201ca very simple, concrete slab with a small obelisk, and a little church out on the plains. It\u2019s a very desolate area. It\u2019s a mass grave.\u201d But they went 30 miles out of their way to see it, even with a crowd of 5,000 waiting in the rain for a rally in Rapid City. Then, at the end of a long day, Kennedy flew to Eugene, Ore., for another day of campaigning.", "title": "Opinion | Why Robert Kennedy Went to Pine Ridge", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "Their comment spurred others to rally to Dr. Christensen\u2019s defense.\n\n(Dr. Anjan Chatterjee is a neurologist at the Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania who wrote \u201cThe Aesthetic Brain: How We Evolved to Desire Beauty and Enjoy Art.\u201d)\n\nThe arguments over Dr. Christensen\u2019s paper pointed to disputes within the emerging field of neuroaesthetics, or the study of the neural processes underlying our appreciation and the production of beautiful objects and artworks:\n\n\u25a0 On Team 1 you\u2019ll find the argument that the experience of pleasure from art is neurobiologically identical to the experience of pleasure from candy or sex. \u25a0 Team 2 believes that both making and appreciating art can offer unique neurobiological rewards. \u25a0 Team 3 asks, \u201cWho knows?!\u201d (\u201cWho cares?!\u201d seems to be a subset of this group.)\n\nGiven that pleasure is known to be a powerful motivator of human behavior, it\u2019s a dispute with implications far beyond art \u2014 at least according to Team 1 and Team 2.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s starting to get really hot,\u201d said Dr. Nadal of the debate. (In case you were wondering \u2014 he studies architectural lines because they are everywhere, affecting us in ways most of us have never considered, and they make \u201cfor good laboratory material because they are easy to control.\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nThere are some core elements that all sides seem to agree on:\n\n\u25a0 As with wine, how much people enjoy art seems to be affected by contextual cues like price or the reputation of the creator. \u25a0 Art is difficult but possible to define. (Definitions vary, however.) \u25a0 Across cultures, what people perceive as beautiful is less consistent with artwork than it is with architecture, landscapes and faces. (Faces are the most consistent.)\n\nWhat researchers do not agree on is whether enjoying a da Vinci engages a different neural process than enjoying a visit to Pornhub or McDonald\u2019s.\n\nDr. Nadal, speaking for Team 1, said in an interview that \u201chumans appear to use only one pleasure system to assess how pleasurable or unpleasurable a sensory experience is.\u201d He calls this discovery \u201cone of the most important insights to emerge from the last 15 years of neuroscience,\u201d and believes it shows that while enjoying Cheez-Its or a sculpture may feel different, in our brains they are processed the same way.\n\nOthers who study pleasure are not convinced.\n\n\u201cTalking in terms of shared neural systems is foolish,\u201d said Paul Bloom, a psychology professor at Yale University and author of the book \u201cHow Pleasure Works: The New Science of Why We Like What We Like.\u201d\n\nHe thinks that \u201cart scratches all kinds of itches.\u201d While watching \u201cThe Sopranos\u201d or parallel parking a car are all done by the brain, he says that doesn\u2019t mean they are the same.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Christensen, who studied dance before she became a neuroscientist, said she is not disputing that a single reward system processes all pleasures. But that does not eliminate the possibility that the arts also activate additional neural systems \u201crelated to memory processes, sense of self and reasoning that add something more to this pleasure.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis \u201chigh-level pleasure\u201d requires more scientific investigation. But given that we spend our lives chasing pleasures, she argues, why not try to better understand one of the few that \u201cdo not induce states of craving without fulfillment,\u201d or cause health problems and instead make \u201cyou think and experience things differently.\u201d\n\nAll of this may lead you to ask: If pleasures are so similar, why don\u2019t people ever orgasm from pleasure associated with food or art? Actually some do.\n\nAccording to Debra Herbenick, director of the Center for Sexual Health Promotion at the Indiana University Bloomington\u2019s School of Public Health, eating a ripe tomato or reading nonerotic prose has been reported to provoke an orgasm. So, too, has walking barefoot on wood floors and doing pull-ups.\n\nShe cannot yet say why, which lends support to the broader notion that \u201cthere is really so much we as scientists still don\u2019t understand about pleasure.\u201d", "title": "Why Scientists Are Battling Over Pleasure", "authors": ["Heather Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Even in an age of dizzying change, this one feels like a real loss. It\u2019s been a long time since I actually signed my name to a check, which I used to do with a sense of pomp and circumstance, always careful to make the \u201ct\u201d in \u201cSteven\u201d parallel to the one in \u201cPetrow,\u201d always placing an emphatic period after the \u201cw\u201d in my last name, my old-school form of encryption. Each signature was an original creation. Although I\u2019m pleased by how quickly I can pay my bills now, every time I open the bank app on my phone I feel my identity eroding, replaced by routing and account numbers.\n\nSome years ago I decided to organize a lifetime\u2019s worth of papers, which included handwritten notes, letters and postcards from my parents, my first girlfriend and first boyfriend, as well as some famous folks, including Senator Joe Biden, Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York and the tennis champ Billie Jean King. Each of them had its creator\u2019s unique signature.\n\nI particularly treasure the letters from my maternal grandmother. At the upper left of each envelope she would write out her name, Marjorie L. Straus, in classic cursive. Even before I could read I knew those curves and curlicues equaled my grandma. The dozens of cards and notes from her are all signed exactly the same way, \u201cLove, Grandma.\u201d The \u201cL\u201d and the \u201cG\u201d were original to her hand. I would have known her signature anywhere, and when I see it today I\u2019m reminded of so much more: Her hair. Her perfume. How we watched \u201cThe Mary Tyler Moore Show\u201d together on Saturdays. Her nightly Scotch and soda (which she always let me sip).\n\nGrandma died in 1973; she lives on eternally through her penmanship.\n\nI also still have the five-page letter my mother wrote me in 1981, shortly after I told her I was gay. She starts out in her usual formal hand, but as she goes on the pen quivers and she strays outside the lines. That told me so much more about her inner monologue \u2014 her fears for me \u2014 than her actual words.\n\nThe same message in an email would have provided no clues as to her state of mind. By the time she penned a jittery \u201cLove, Mom,\u201d I knew that her caring was very real even if she hadn\u2019t yet accepted my sexual orientation.", "title": "Opinion | Why Signatures Matter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "This is far from a perfect system, and a flood of tech sector lobbying has made it worse. Since 2009, Facebook has increased its spending on lobbying fiftyfold. And the $11.5 million it spent in 2017 still ranked it third behind Amazon and Alphabet. Lobbying works. Congress hasn\u2019t passed a single new major privacy law since a 2009 update to federal health privacy rules. Take a second to think of technologies popularized in the last nine years: drones, self-driving cars, Amazon Echo, Google Home, among others. If it blossomed after 2009, chances are, it is not regulated by any federal privacy law.\n\nWhat does that flood of lobbying look like? From 2011 to 2014, as a staffer for Senator Al Franken, then chairman of the Senate privacy subcommittee, I worked to pass a bill to force companies to ask for users\u2019 permission before collecting or sharing records of their movements. The bill would have outlawed so-called \u201cstalking apps\u201d that let abusers secretly track their victims\u2019 locations through their smartphones. Industry lobbyists outnumbered our supporters 54 to 2. Yet in 2012, thanks to a small coalition of privacy, women\u2019s rights, and anti-stalking groups, we managed to pass the bill out of the Judiciary Committee.\n\nThat\u2019s when the lobbying really started. When I called a meeting of industry stakeholders, I had to move it from our 12-person conference table to the full Judiciary Committee hearing room, which seats four or five times that. The bill stalled. It was never again brought up for a vote.\n\nPassing a strong industry-specific privacy law is tough. But at least it\u2019s possible. When the Obama administration tried to pass an omnibus privacy bill, the law\u2019s original framework was promising. It stressed that consumers needed control of their information, transparency about how it was used, and accountability when it was abused. In 2015, after Silicon Valley weighed in, the bill that the White House put forward was so toothless that almost every major consumer privacy group opposed it. Around the time our anti-stalking bill stalled, I remember a lobbyist telling me that we should really consider setting our bill aside until Congress could pass a comprehensive privacy law. Now I know why.\n\nIt could be that the Cambridge Analytica scandal will pave the way for previously impossible, European-style reforms. Facebook\u2019s actions tell a different story. Even as it yells mea culpa, Facebook is calculating that it can kneecap new privacy rules with impunity. Facebook is spending its lobbying money not only to gut the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act but also to stop a new California consumer privacy ballot initiative.\n\nThose calculations are right \u2014 if we make this a broad debate about \u201cpersonal data.\u201d Let\u2019s make this a debate about people and pass laws to address the threats they actually face. Let\u2019s talk about the people who are still stalked every year through their smartphones. Or how retailers secretly use face recognition to spot shoplifters, even though the technology misfires more often when trying to identify African-Americans and women. Let\u2019s make this a debate about how Facebook tracked people to determine if they had an \u201caffinity\u201d for African-Americans, Hispanics and Asians, and then let advertisers block those people from seeing real estate ads.", "title": "Opinion | Why Silicon Valley Lobbyists Love Big, Broad Privacy Bills", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "To be sure, defense contracts are hardly new in Silicon Valley, and Google\u2019s recent moves might be seen as heralding Silicon Valley\u2019s return to its natural home in defense contracting. But that would be to misunderstand both Silicon Valley history and today\u2019s technology.\n\nThe internet and much of digital computing did indeed emerge from decades of United States defense contracts, beginning as long ago as World War I. Yet the Pentagon itself sloughed off the internet \u2014 not knowing quite what to do with it, and rightly judging it to be insecure \u2014 to the National Science Foundation. When the internet became a commercial concern, the National Science Foundation off-loaded it to the Department of Commerce. Government might have given birth to the internet, but it sure didn\u2019t raise it.\n\nThe emergence of a civilian, entrepreneurial tech culture in the 1970s owed as much intellectually, if not (at first) financially, to the antiwar movement and the 1960s counterculture \u2014 hardly friends of the military-industrial complex. Out of this the dominant, highly creative ethos of geek antiauthoritarianism grew. It is hard to believe that closer ties with the military would perpetuate this culture of innovation.\n\nThe technology involved in projects like Azure Government Secret and Project Maven is also very different from the data-sharing projects of the 1960s. Those older technologies would not have been created in the absence of government funding. Today\u2019s projects, in contrast, are all basically A.I. plays. Very little of this is defense-specific, but all of it is useful for defense and espionage. Unlike, say, weapons development, A.I. research is inherently dual-use. United States tech giants would be pursuing it with or without government contracts. Silicon Valley does not need the Pentagon to initiate these endeavors.\n\nThe Pentagon is in a different position. It came around very reluctantly to the idea that it is dependent on private industry for the defense of the country and the projection of American power. But come around it has, in no small part thanks to China.", "title": "Opinion | Why Silicon Valley Shouldn\u2019t Work With the Pentagon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ritsuko Hotaka, a colorist at Hair Kuwayama in the East Village, said that nearly 20 percent of her clients are asking to go blond. Kelly Su, the founder of Sonder Hair Studio in NoLIta, reported that of all her Asian customers, about 50 percent are going lighter. (Both salons have a largely Asian client base.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt has so much to do with the number of Asian-American bloggers who are becoming increasingly visible,\u201d said Greta Lee, an actress who went platinum for the second half of last year. \u201cThere\u2019s an army of Asians who are rising in the fashion world.\u201d\n\nOnce a so-called editorial look adopted by a select few, like the popular Korean-American model Soo Joo Park, who found fame with her trademark ultralight locks, the aesthetic has paved the way for celebrities, street-style stars and more to follow suit. That includes the model and blogger Irene Kim, the designer Yoon Anh and the social-media influencers Vanessa Hong, Tina Leung and Margaret Zhang.\n\nNot all of them went blond with the sole desire of mirroring Western beauty ideals. Ms. Hong was going through a major moment in her life and wanted a drastic change. Ms. Leung, after seven years with a Skrillex side shave, felt as if she was missing an edge.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.
