Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will Bank Earnings Flash Any Warnings?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019ve seen a level of activism here that is off the charts,\u201d he told me after a town hall in Dallas where he spoke with voters about the school shooting in Parkland, Fla., and the need for gun-safety legislation. Sessions is a major recipient of donations from the National Rifle Association, and Allred, echoing the campaigns of Democrats across the country, is making an issue of that.\n\nThe mere existence of the runoffs that he, Jones and other Texas Democrats will compete in next month reflects Democrats\u2019 hopes in Texas in 2018, because it means that there were three or more Democratic candidates in districts that had two, one or none in election cycles past.\n\n\u201cDemocrats smell blood in the water,\u201d Harold Cook, a former executive director of the Texas Democratic Party, told me, \u201cand for the first time in maybe forever, there is a Democrat running in every single congressional district in Texas, including ones where it\u2019s a ludicrous thought that a Democrat could conceivably win.\u201d They\u2019re that angry about Trump and that convinced that his turbulent presidency and failure to nudge his approval rating much above 40 percent could mean an enormous blue wave.\n\nDemocrats are even eyeing a few districts that Trump won, like the 21st and 31st. The 21st attracted the party\u2019s attention largely because its Republican incumbent, Lamar Smith, isn\u2019t seeking re-election. He decided to retire after more than three decades in the House.\n\nAnd the 31st? Well, it\u2019s hard not to indulge in some optimism when your party\u2019s leading candidate is a female war hero whose story is possibly becoming a movie, \u201cShoot Like a Girl,\u201d starring Angelina Jolie. That candidate, M. J. Hegar, 42, did several tours of duty in Afghanistan as a search-and-rescue pilot and won a Purple Heart after she was wounded while saving fellow passengers when the Taliban shot down her helicopter.\n\nRichard Murray, a professor of political science at the University of Houston, told me to keep an eye as well on the 22nd District, a largely suburban swath of the Houston area that he described as a microcosm of demographic changes that are making the state ever more hospitable Democratic turf.\n\n\u201cThe suburban counties that led Republicans to dominance here 25 years ago are getting significantly less Republican fast,\u201d he said, adding that Fort Bend County, in the 22nd, is roughly 20 percent Asian-American now. The first-place finisher in the district\u2019s Democratic primary, Sri Preston Kulkarni, is Indian-American. Murray said that if Kulkarni wins his runoff, that could be a significant boost to Democrats\u2019 chances to nab this House seat.\n\nTrump took the 22nd by almost 8 points. But Mitt Romney won it four years earlier by more than 25. And bear in mind that Lamb notched his Pennsylvania victory last month in a district that had gone for Trump by a margin of 19 points.", "title": "Opinion | Will Democrats Win the House? Ask Texas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "No. 2: Every country in the union has at least one political party that built its fortunes on bashing Europe. But in Italy, lately, this attitude has been adopted by even the historically pro-European parties, which couldn\u2019t resist blaming Brussels for their own failures. Matteo Renzi, first as a prime minister (2014 to 2016) and then as the leader of the center-left Democratic Party (2017), could hardly open his mouth without saying something unpleasant about the union. Did he think he could outsmart his opponents that way? Well, he failed. \u201cBlame it on Brussels!\u201d didn\u2019t pay off for him or his government. It compares with what happened in Britain before the Brexit referendum. David Cameron, while leading the campaign to remain in the bloc, chose to acknowledge the union\u2019s shortcomings; he did it so well that he persuaded his fellow citizens to leave it.\n\nNo. 3: Italy, where feelings run high on these issues, senses an emotional disconnection between Europe and its citizens. For almost 60 years, Italian voters had seen the European Union as a dull but reliable babysitter who would ultimately take care of those rowdy Italian politicians. A former prime minister told me, \u201cIf not for Brussels, I could never resist pressure to expand public spending.\u201d All that is gone now. And a majority of Italians think the sitter is at least partly to blame.\n\nBut what about the union\u2019s very substantial achievements? It\u2019s created common standards in areas from home safety to cellphone roaming; it\u2019s allowed people to trade, work and live where they please; it protects agriculture and fishing; it\u2019s helped millions of students spend time abroad. And it\u2019s enabled 28 countries to speak with one voice and be respected \u2014 as Microsoft, Google and Facebook know well.\n\nAll forgotten? No. But most Italians, yearning for the supposed security of a lost age, find Brussels too distant. National, local and ethnic identities are more familiar, thus more reassuring.\n\nThat remoteness is important. The European Union looks soulless. Its greatest flaw may be that it cannot communicate its achievements. Take Europe Day. Only a small fraction of the 510 million citizens of the union even know about the day, let alone celebrate it, and almost no one has any idea why it\u2019s May 9. In fact, it was on May 9, 1950, that Robert Schuman, then France\u2019s foreign minister, officially proposed placing French and German coal and steel production under one authority; can you see why those 510 million don\u2019t deck the halls?\n\nSo here\u2019s an idea: Let\u2019s declare May 9 \u201cNo Europe Day\u201d and suspend all of the union\u2019s achievements for 24 hours. Border crossings will be reintroduced and trade barriers re-erected. People will exchange their currency for every trip, and soccer teams will field only players from their own countries.\n\nOh, and war will be once again a very real threat. Not far away. Right at home.\n\nOne day would be enough to remind its citizens what Europe is about. And in Italy, if they do form a government, Five Star and the League might understand the importance of our common European home.\n\nSure, it\u2019s not perfect. So let\u2019s not demolish it. Let\u2019s fix it.", "title": "Opinion | Will Italy Leave the E.U.? Not So Fast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 For as long as Kim Jong-un has been North Korea\u2019s leader, he has called for the simultaneous pursuit of nuclear weapons and economic growth with the aim of making the nation a \u201cgreat socialist nuclear power.\u201d\n\nOn Saturday, however, Mr. Kim abruptly announced he was retiring his signature policy, known as byungjin, or \u201cparallel advance.\u201d\n\nThe strategy has been at the center of his government\u2019s propaganda and is enshrined in the charter of the governing Workers\u2019 Party. But Mr. Kim said it was now time to adopt a \u201cnew strategic line\u201d and focus the nation\u2019s resources on rebuilding its economy.\n\nAs for nuclear weapons, he essentially declared that mission accomplished, saying North Korea no longer needed to test long-range missiles or atomic bombs and would close its only known nuclear test site. The byungjin policy, he said, already had achieved a \u201cgreat victory\u201d \u2014 an arsenal capable of deterring the nation\u2019s enemies.", "title": "Will Kim Jong-un Trade His Nuclear Arsenal to Rebuild Economy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Joni Ernst and Iowa\u2019s agriculture secretary, Mike Naig, both say the tariffs will hurt Iowans, and Mr. Naig says we need to expand markets, not shrink them. Senator Chuck Grassley said something similar, on Fox News: \u201cTariffs do not put America first \u2014 low barriers and expanded access do.\u201d\n\nChina has already responded with its own tariff on pork, which will have a dire impact on Iowa. Iowa is the nation\u2019s largest pork producer, producing three times as much pork as the next-highest state.\n\nA couple of banker friends who work with farmers every day told me last week that with commodity prices down and the tariffs imposed, approximately 10 percent of our farmers probably won\u2019t make it this year, and 10 percent more will likely fail next year. They also shared the news that in Iowa, larger agribusinesses are buying up smaller farms that are in financial trouble, and that people are starting to make comparisons to the farm crisis of the 1980s, when approximately 10,000 Iowa farmers lost their farms.\n\nEven Representative Steve King, the avid Trump supporter and Iowan every liberal loves to hate, is worried about a new farm crisis.\n\nDairy farmers are particularly hard hit, suffering through four years of declining prices. It\u2019s gotten so bad, dairy farming organizations are giving out suicide hotline numbers, as farmers are committing suicide in the hope that their insurance will save the family farm.\n\nI\u2019m focusing on the area I know, rural Iowa, but if the president stays on course with the tariffs, the impacts will hit many rural areas all over America, what I call Trumplandia.\n\n\u201cIt gives Democrats a generational opportunity to do the political work with farmers they haven\u2019t done since the 1980s farm crisis,\u201d said Matt Russell, a rural sociologist and farmer in Iowa. \u201cDemocrats do farm policy really well but are terrible at farm politics. Republicans do farm politics really well but have a history of doing terrible farm policy.\u201d\n\nHarvest will be coming in when members of Congress, in recess, return to Iowa to campaign. They will be getting earfuls from rural constituents about the economic impacts of Mr. Trump\u2019s tariffs.", "title": "Opinion | Will Trump Crash the Farm Economy?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "While there would be no immediate consequences for World Heritage sites, the withdrawal by the United States may affect Unesco in other ways. According to Dr. Stefan Simon, the director of Global Cultural Heritage Initiatives at Yale University, \u201cWith the U.S. once responsible for approximately 22 percent of Unesco\u2019s budget, of course the announced withdrawal is detrimental, and would painfully reduce Unesco\u2019s ability to fulfill its important missions, such as advancing and promoting literacy, gender equality, freedom of expression and scientific collaboration.\u201d\n\nIf the United States withdraws from Unesco, it would remain a state party, having signed and ratified the World Heritage Convention. \u201cThere is one consequence only,\u201d Mr. Papagiannis said about the United States withdrawal. \u201cThe U.S. cannot be elected to the World Heritage Committee,\u201d a managing committee made up of elected representatives from 21 countries. The committee is in charge of allocating financial assistance and determining what sites are included on, or removed from, the World Heritage List.\n\nDespite no longer being a paying member, the United States would be able to continue to submit sites for World Heritage List consideration. The World Heritage Committee will next meet in Bahrain from June 24 to July 4, 2018. \u201cThe leadership of the U.S. is crucial in this debate,\u201d said Dr. Simon. \u201cIts voice will be thoroughly missed at the table.\u201d\n\nThe United States played an integral role in the creation of the World Heritage program. Russell Train, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency who is often described as one of the primary architects of World Heritage, talked about the importance of the concept in a 2002 speech at the 30th Anniversary of the World Heritage Convention in Venice, Italy. \u201cThe World Heritage Convention itself represents a partnership among 175 nations,\u201d he said in his speech. \u201cI see the program as an opportunity to convey the idea of a common heritage among nations and peoples everywhere. I see it as a compelling idea that can help unite people rather than divide them.\u201d\n\nThere are several benefits for sites that are included on the World Heritage List. Unesco provides leadership on maintaining the health of the sites, including a focus on sustainable tourism. \u201cAn important component of what we do is providing guidance for managing tourism numbers in a sustainable way,\u201d Mr. Papagiannis said.", "title": "Will U.S. Withdrawal from Unesco Affect Heritage Sites?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Around the Mediterranean, the once bright promise of the Arab Spring has been betrayed by autocratic leaders, such as Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt (also just re-elected), who use security to justify the jailing of reporters and political opponents. Thanks to allies in Moscow and Tehran, the tyrant Bashar al-Assad retains his stranglehold over much of Syria. In Africa, the presidents who serve longest are often the most corrupt, multiplying the harm they inflict with each passing year. Meanwhile, the possibility that fascism will be accorded a fresh chance to strut around the world stage is enhanced by the volatile presidency of Donald Trump.\n\nIf freedom is to prevail over the many challenges to it, American leadership is urgently required. This was among the indelible lessons of the 20th century. But by what he has said, done and failed to do, Mr. Trump has steadily diminished America\u2019s positive clout in global councils.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n[To read more about the threat of authoritarianism around the world, read Roger Cohen on Eastern Europe.]\n\nInstead of mobilizing international coalitions to take on world problems, he touts the doctrine of \u201cevery nation for itself\u201d and has led America into isolated positions on trade, climate change and Middle East peace. Instead of engaging in creative diplomacy, he has insulted United States neighbors and allies, walked away from key international agreements, mocked multilateral organizations and stripped the State Department of its resources and role. Instead of standing up for the values of a free society, Mr. Trump, with his oft-vented scorn for democracy\u2019s building blocks, has strengthened the hands of dictators. No longer need they fear United States criticism regarding human rights or civil liberties. On the contrary, they can and do point to Mr. Trump\u2019s own words to justify their repressive actions.\n\nAt one time or another, Mr. Trump has attacked the judiciary, ridiculed the media, defended torture, condoned police brutality, urged supporters to rough up hecklers and \u2014 jokingly or not \u2014 equated mere policy disagreements with treason. He tried to undermine faith in America\u2019s electoral process through a bogus advisory commission on voter integrity. He routinely vilifies federal law enforcement institutions. He libels immigrants and the countries from which they come. His words are so often at odds with the truth that they can appear ignorant, yet are in fact calculated to exacerbate religious, social and racial divisions. Overseas, rather than stand up to bullies, Mr. Trump appears to like bullies, and they are delighted to have him represent the American brand. If one were to draft a script chronicling fascism\u2019s resurrection, the abdication of America\u2019s moral leadership would make a credible first scene.\n\nEqually alarming is the chance that Mr. Trump will set in motion events that neither he nor anyone else can control. His policy toward North Korea changes by the day and might quickly return to saber-rattling should Pyongyang prove stubborn before or during talks. His threat to withdraw from the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement could unravel a pact that has made the world safer and could undermine America\u2019s reputation for trustworthiness at a critical moment. His support of protectionist tariffs invites retaliation from major trading partners \u2014 creating unnecessary conflicts and putting at risk millions of export-dependent jobs. The recent purge of his national security team raises new questions about the quality of advice he will receive. John Bolton starts work in the White House on Monday.\n\nWhat is to be done? First, defend the truth. A free press, for example, is not the enemy of the American people; it is the protector of the American people. Second, we must reinforce the principle that no one, not even the president, is above the law. Third, we should each do our part to energize the democratic process by registering new voters, listening respectfully to those with whom we disagree, knocking on doors for favored candidates, and ignoring the cynical counsel: \u201cThere\u2019s nothing to be done.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m 80 years old, but I can still be inspired when I see young people coming together to demand the right to study without having to wear a flak jacket.\n\nWe should also reflect on the definition of greatness. Can a nation merit that label by aligning itself with dictators and autocrats, ignoring human rights, declaring open season on the environment, and disdaining the use of diplomacy at a time when virtually every serious problem requires international cooperation?\n\nTo me, greatness goes a little deeper than how much marble we put in our hotel lobbies and whether we have a Soviet-style military parade. America at its best is a place where people from a multitude of backgrounds work together to safeguard the rights and enrich the lives of all. That\u2019s the example we have always aspired to set and the model people around the world hunger to see. And no politician, not even one in the Oval Office, should be allowed to tarnish that dream.", "title": "Will We Stop Trump Before It\u2019s Too Late?", "authors": ["Madeleine Albright"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Speaking of the Constitution, and especially of the First Amendment\u2019s establishment clause, anyone with a passing awareness of American politics knows what\u2019s at the root of the travel ban: Mr. Trump\u2019s special animus against Muslims, which he\u2019s been nursing at least since December 2015. That\u2019s when he called for a \u201ctotal and complete shutdown\u201d of Muslims entering the country until we \u201ccan figure out what is going on.\u201d Since then he has given his lawyers a constant headache by tweeting regularly about the ban, saying just days before the latest version that it should be \u201cfar larger, tougher and more specific,\u201d but that this would be \u201cpolitically incorrect.\u201d In case anyone was still unclear about where he stands, last November the president retweeted inflammatory videos from a fringe ultranationalist group in Britain showing Muslims purportedly engaged in violence. (The videos were, as Mr. Trump likes to say, fake news.)\n\nFrom this angle, the travel ban looks a lot like Mr. Trump\u2019s other attempts to weaponize the federal government in the service of his own personal vendettas. Remember the election integrity commission? An entire operation created solely to justify the president\u2019s false claims that millions of people voted illegally in 2016. The commission folded in January without making any findings of fraud. In the case of the travel ban, Mr. Trump is surrounded by anti-immigrant hard-liners, including his attorney general, Jeff Sessions, who donated one of his favorite staffers, a zealot named Stephen Miller, to help draft the ban.\n\nIn truth, the latest proclamation functions as little more than legal backfill \u201cto legitimize a presidential command that was born of animus, persists in animus, and seeks to make animus the law of the land,\u201d as a supporting brief says.\n\nThat brief is one of many the court has received arguing against the ban; more than four times as many briefs oppose the ban as support it. They come from immigrants\u2019-rights groups and anti-discrimination advocates, naturally, but also from business and legal leaders, scholars of constitutional and international law, conservatives and liberals and libertarians, cities and states \u2014 and, notably, former national security and military officials, who warn that by encouraging the perception that the United States is anti-Muslim, it \u201cjeopardizes the stability of the support that the United States receives from its allies, erodes essential good will, makes it more difficult for the United States to win hearts and minds abroad.\u201d\n\nThis leads the justices to a thornier question: What to do with a president like Mr. Trump? Should they simply ignore everything he\u2019s said? Are they holding him to a different standard than previous presidents? That\u2019s hard to answer, because no past president behaved like Mr. Trump. In its brief to the justices, the administration argues that the court must not engage in \u201cjudicial psychoanalysis of a drafter\u2019s heart of hearts.\u201d But there\u2019s no need to get Mr. Trump on a couch. He\u2019s said over and over exactly what he thinks.\n\nThe Supreme Court has been faced with situations like this before. In World War II, it bowed to claims of unfettered executive authority and allowed American citizens to be locked up for years simply because of their Japanese heritage. It was a shameful moment for the court and for the United States. Today, in the face of an executive order again based on racial animus and unfounded fears, the justices have the chance to deliver a very different message about executive power, and the meaning of America.", "title": "Opinion | Will the Court Stand Up to Donald Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "It was two days after the young Yemeni man was released from surgery that the doctors first noticed the smell. The bullet that wounded the leg of the 22-year-old college student had shattered bone and torn a hole in the soft tissue. Now, the wound was emitting a distinct smell, described in the medical literature as \u201coffensive.\u201d It strongly suggested infection, perhaps life-threatening, and the wound was not getting better.\n\nRealizing that normal antibiotics were not working, the doctors at a trauma center run by Doctors Without Borders sent a blood culture for analysis to their new microbiology lab, the only one of its kind in the region. The tests found a bacterium, Acinetobacter baumannii, resistant to most standard antibiotics. Nobody knows how the student \u2014 who was identified using his initials, A. S., to preserve his privacy \u2014 acquired the drug-resistant infection, but it is so common in Yemen that it could have come from the bullet itself or the sand on the ground when he fell, said Dr. Nagwan Mansoor, the chief physician in Doctors Without Borders\u2019s antibiotic stewardship program.\n\nDoctors started the gunshot victim on a program of specialized antibiotics, medicines rarely used because of their potentially dangerous side effects. He required numerous surgeries, seven in all. What would normally have been a five-day stay became three weeks, during which the man was put into isolation to prevent him from infecting other patients. When his family came to visit, they could not touch him without wearing protective clothing.\n\nA. S. survived. \u201cWe captured the patient from the mouth of death,\u201d said Dr. Mansoor. But A. S. was lucky: Most hospitals in Yemen do not have the capacity or protocols in place to detect and treat drug-resistant infections; if he had been anywhere else, he would have lost his leg, or died.", "title": "Opinion | Will the Next Superbug Come From Yemen?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "When William S. Beinecke and his wife, Betty, moved to the Upper East Side of Manhattan in 1979, they were shocked by the dilapidated state of Central Park. Far from the emerald jewel that Mr. Beinecke recalled from childhood visits to his grandparents\u2019 New York apartment, the park had become strewn with litter, its buildings covered with graffiti, its gardens full of weeds and its benches broken and rusting.\n\n\u201cIt bothered us to see the park in such a state of disrepair and decay,\u201d Mr. Beinecke wrote in a memoir years later, \u201cbut we weren\u2019t sure what to do about it.\u201d\n\nThey didn\u2019t wait long to find out. In the spring of 1980, the Beineckes stopped by the city\u2019s Parks Department to ask how they could help. Unbeknown to them, the parks commissioner at the time, Gordon J. Davis, and a colleague were establishing a partnership to support the park. They had the support of Mayor Edward I. Koch but had struck out recruiting a chairman who could tap into the city\u2019s business community. Mr. Beinecke, newly retired from a successful corporate career, was the ideal candidate.\n\n\u201cHe literally just walked in the door,\u201d Mr. Davis recalled.\n\nMr. Beinecke (pronounced BUY-neh-key) agreed to serve as the first chairman of what became the Central Park Conservancy, and quickly recruited to the board many of the same corporate leaders who had previously turned Mr. Davis down. The conservancy is widely credited with helping to revitalize the park, and has served as a model for similar public-private partnerships across the country.", "title": "William Beinecke, Patron of Central Park and Yale, Dies at 103", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "William Prochnau, a journalist and author who wrote a critically acclaimed book, \u201cOnce Upon a Distant War,\u201d about a handful of skeptical reporters whose early warnings that the United States wasn\u2019t winning in Vietnam went unheeded, died on March 28 in his home in Washington. He was 80.\n\nThe cause was coronary artery disease, said his wife and frequent collaborator, Laura Parker, a staff writer for National Geographic magazine.\n\nMr. Prochnau (pronounced PROCK-now) was a reporter for The Washington Post and a contributing editor of Vanity Fair, where his article \u201cAdventures in the Ransom Trade\u201d was the basis for the movie \u201cProof of Life\u201d (2000), a kidnapping thriller starring Meg Ryan and Russell Crowe. (Ms. Parker said the film rights paid for the \u201cMeg Ryan Memorial Kitchen\u201d in the couple\u2019s Washington home.)\n\nHis novel \u201cTrinity\u2019s Child\u201d inspired the script of \u201cBy Dawn\u2019s Early Light\u201d (1990), an apocalyptic Cold War movie starring James Earl Jones.", "title": "William Prochnau, Journalist and Author, Is Dead at 80", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Flores turned on the pitch and rifled a line drive into the left-field seats. The home run, his second of the season (but the third game-winner of his career), ended the Mets\u2019 losing streak at one game and gave them a 12-2 record, best in the National League and second over all to the Boston Red Sox (13-2).\n\n\u201cThat was a great win,\u201d said Syndergaard, who had to settle for a no-decision despite allowing just two hits and striking out 11 in five and one-third innings. \u201cAnd this is a great team to be a part of. We pick up one another.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFlores\u2019s home run picked up the slack for a couple of his teammates, and even, to some extent, his manager, Mickey Callaway, who to this point in the season had been nearly flawless in his decision-making.\n\nBut Callaway\u2019s decision to use Jay Bruce to pinch-hit for catcher Tomas Nido with runners on second and third in the fifth inning was a head-scratcher \u2014 it was a foregone conclusion the Brewers would walk Bruce to load the bases for Syndergaard, and because of the injuries to Travis d\u2019Arnaud and Kevin Plawecki, Jose Lobaton was the only other catcher on the roster \u2014 as was his decision to allow Syndergaard to bat for himself.\n\nWhen Syndergaard, swinging at the first pitch, popped out harmlessly to the infield, it appeared Callaway\u2019s honeymoon period might be nearing its end. His decision to put in Robert Gsellman in place of Syndergaard, who had struck out eight consecutive Brewers at one point in the game, two batters into the next inning because he had thrown 101 pitches, did not help matters. Some shoddy play was also a factor, as the Brewers took a 2-1 lead when Amed Rosario\u2019s wild throw escaped Flores at first base later in the inning.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Really, anybody can be a hero here.\u201d", "title": "Wilmer Flores\u2019s Walk-Off Homer Ends Mets\u2019 Losing Skid at One Game", "authors": ["Wallace Matthews"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "G\u00fcnter Seeger said he selected the glasses for their ability to aerate wine and in some cases enhance its aroma.\n\nCredit Daniel Krieger for The New York Times", "title": "Wine Glasses With Style and Function", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "One day in 1957, when she was waiting at a bus stop, Nelson Mandela drove past. \u201cI was struck by her beauty,\u201d he wrote in his autobiography, \u201cLong Walk to Freedom.\u201d Some weeks later, he recalled, \u201cI was at the office when I popped in to see Oliver and there was this same young woman.\u201d\n\nMr. Mandela, approaching 40 and the father of three, declared on their first date that he would marry her. Soon he separated from his first wife, Evelyn Ntoko Mase, a nurse, to marry Ms. Madikizela-Mandela on June 14, 1958.\n\nMs. Madikizela-Mandela was thrust into the limelight in 1964 when her husband was sentenced to life in prison on charges of treason. She was officially \u201cbanned\u201d under draconian restrictions intended to make her a nonperson, unable to work, socialize, move freely or be quoted in the South African news media, even as she raised their two daughters, Zenani and Zindziswa.\n\nIn a crackdown in May 1969, five years after her husband was sent to prison, she was arrested and held for 17 months, 13 in solitary confinement. She was beaten and tortured. The experience, she wrote, was \u201cwhat changed me, what brutalized me so much that I knew what it is to hate.\u201d\n\nAfter blacks rioted in the segregated Johannesburg township of Soweto in 1976, Ms. Madikizela-Mandela was again imprisoned without trial, this time for five months. She was then banished to a bleak township outside the profoundly conservative white town of Brandfort, in the Orange Free State.\n\n\u201cI am a living symbol of whatever is happening in the country,\u201d she wrote in \u201cPart of My Soul Went With Him,\u201d a memoir published in 1984 and printed around the world. \u201cI am a living symbol of the white man\u2019s fear. I never realized how deeply embedded this fear is until I came to Brandfort.\u201d", "title": "Winnie Madikizela-Mandela Is Dead at 81; Fought Apartheid", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "CAPE TOWN, South Africa \u2014 Her legacy contested in death as in life, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela \u2014 an antiapartheid activist and the former wife of Nelson Mandela who was known as \u201cthe Mother of the Nation\u201d \u2014 was honored with an official funeral in Johannesburg on Saturday.\n\nMs. Madikizela-Mandela, who was 81 when she died this month, was to be laid to rest after the funeral, attended by more than 40,000 mourners at Orlando Stadium in the township of Soweto. The funeral was organized by the African National Congress, the governing party that for decades strove to keep her at arm\u2019s length.", "title": "Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, \u2018Mother of the Nation,\u2019 Mourned in South Africa", "authors": ["Kimon De Greef"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "But, in a measure of the North\u2019s drive for d\u00e9tente, South Korean reporters in Pyongyang received a remarkably graceful mea culpa after they were denied entry to a K-pop concert attended by Kim Jong-un, the North\u2019s leader.\n\n\u201cWe invited you and we are obliged to guarantee free coverage,\u201d a senior North Korean official was quoted as saying. \u201cI offer an apology and ask for your understanding for the wrong committed.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 The world\u2019s first ban on \u201cfake news.\u201d\n\nThe lower house of Malaysia\u2019s Parliament passed a bill that allows for up to six years in prison for publishing or circulating misleading information, and its Senate is expected to rapidly follow suit.\n\nCritics say the law is intended to stifle dissent before elections.\n\nIn the U.S., dozens of local TV anchors gave the same speech denouncing fake news recently. It turned out they were doing a \u201cforced read\u201d of a corporate script from the country\u2019s largest broadcaster, Sinclair.\n\n_____\n\n\u2022 British officials believe an assassin smeared a Soviet-developed nerve agent on a door handle at the home of a former Russian double agent, suggesting a high-level plot hatched by the Kremlin.\n\nSince the nerve agent, Novichok, is so potent and dangerous, the British authorities suspect that only a highly trained professional \u2014 on orders from the highest levels of the Russian government \u2014 could have carried out the attack.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cCharming, intelligent, complex, fiery and eloquent.\u201d\n\nOur esteemed former international correspondent wrote that in his obituary of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, a leader in South Africa\u2019s fight against apartheid, known to most of the world through her marriage to Nelson Mandela.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe died early Monday at the age of 81.\n\n\u201cIn time,\u201d he wrote, \u201cher reputation became scarred by accusations of extreme brutality toward suspected turncoats, misbehavior and indiscretion in her private life, and a radicalism that seemed at odds with Mr. Mandela\u2019s quest for racial inclusiveness.\u201d\n\nBusiness\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Shares of Tesla slid 5.1 percent, amid concerns about the electric-car maker\u2019s quarterly production numbers for its Model 3 sedan, which are expected in the next day or so. So the F.B.I.\u2019s forensic scientists were called in to crack the agency\u2019s oldest case.\n\n\u2022 Tim Franco, a photographer who splits his time between South Korea and China, explores the stories of North Korean defectors in a new portrait series. The title, \u201cUnperson,\u201d is a riff on a construct from George Orwell\u2019s novel \u201c1984.\u201d\n\n\u2022 And after nearing extinction 20 years ago, the Iberian lynx has made a comeback in southern Spain and Portugal, thanks to a vast E.U. recovery program (and about 50,000 rabbits).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nHong Kong, a special administrative region of China, has a vibrant mix of people, languages and cultures. Its flag takes a similar hybrid approach.\n\nThe flag was approved by the Chinese national legislature 28 years ago this week. It was first raised on July 1, 1997, the day Hong Kong was returned to Chinese rule after more than 150 years as a British colony and territory.\n\nThe flag was designed to reflect Hong Kong\u2019s new relationship with the People\u2019s Republic of China. It is the same shade of red as the Chinese national flag.\n\nIn the center is a white flower from the Bauhinia blakeana, or Hong Kong orchid tree. (The real flower is a purplish pink and is not actually an orchid.) Stars on each of the five petals echo the five stars on the Chinese flag.\n\nThe flag\u2019s two colors are said to represent the \u201cone country, two systems\u201d principle under which China agreed to rule Hong Kong for the first 50 years.\n\nIn recent years, Hong Kong protesters have waved the British colonial flag to express their displeasure with the way Beijing governs. Since the handover in 1997, lawmakers and activists in Hong Kong have also been prosecuted for desecrating the Chinese and Hong Kong flags.\n\nJennifer Jett contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Democrats outnumber Republicans two to one in the county, but Ms. Killian mounted an energetic campaign.\n\nThe importance of the race was underscored by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s involvement in the race: He stumped for Ms. Mayer in Mamaroneck on Sunday morning to help get out the vote, and was at her election watch party on Tuesday night.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAll of us are part of something bigger, a movement for change, a blue wave rising in special election after special election,\u201d Ms. Mayer said in a statement released after she declared victory. \u201cThis race was about finally bringing a Democratic majority to the State Senate so that New York can once again be a progressive leader.\u201d\n\nProgressive activists pledged to work even harder to unseat Republicans in the Senate this fall to give Democrats an unassailable edge.\n\n\u201cWe are committed to flipping the I.D.C. seats and, following that, flipping red seats to blue,\u201d Lisa DellAquila, a leader of True Blue NY, a liberal activist group, said in a phone interview on Tuesday, referring to the Independent Democratic Conference, a group of breakaway Democrats who have since reconciled with their party. \u201cI am confident that we can really make an impact in those areas and create a solid Democratic majority.\u201d\n\nWhile campaigning feverishly to ensure that Ms. Mayer, 64, would conquer Ms. Killian, 57, in Westchester, Democrats had been less worried about the special election for State Senate in the South Bronx. In that race, Luis R. Sep\u00falveda, a Democratic assemblyman, handily won the 32nd District, dispatching his Republican rival, Patrick Delices, and a Reform Party candidate, Pamela Stewart-Martinez.\n\nIn addition, nine vacant Assembly seats, from Long Island to South Buffalo, were decided in the special election. But he could not survive after losing in the second round of the playoffs last season to Ottawa and failing to reach the postseason this year.\n\nThe Rangers\u2019 defense and goaltending let them down against the Senators last season, and that theme continued into this year, as they left Lundqvist vulnerable too often. Lundqvist, 36, failed to reach the 30-win mark for the first time in a non-lockout year, finishing 26-26-7 with a career-worst 2.98 goals-against average.\n\nVigneault had said that the Rangers would only go as far as their goaltending would take them this season, a comment that was perceived as being critical of Lundqvist and his backup, Ondrej Pavelec.\n\nLundqvist, who has publicly vowed to remain with the Rangers during their revamp, will presumably play for his fourth coach next season. Before Vigneault and Tortorella, there was the cerebral Tom Renney, who took the Rangers to the playoffs three straight times.\n\nVigneault received a vague vote of confidence from Gorton on Feb. 8, the same day the Rangers released a letter to fans asking them to bear with the departure of popular players while the team rebuilds.\n\n\u201cA. The district was redrawn in 2012 by Senate Republicans to favor their party.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a county where Democrats outnumber Republicans by two-to-one, the presidency of Donald J. Trump has loomed large in the race. Ms. Mayer\u2019s campaign is running ads in which Ms. Killian is made to look like a Trump clone. In an interview, Ms. Killian declined to address Mr. Trump\u2019s record or rhetoric, saying she had been too focused on her race to follow the news out of Washington.\n\n\u201cThe perspective I want to bring to Albany is that of a mother, chemical engineer, finance person and community advocate involved in substance abuse and mental health issues,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s my on-the-ground experience that has shaped my views on the issues.\u201d\n\nA mother of five, Ms. Killian, 57, studied engineering in college and, after earning a master\u2019s in business, worked in finance. In 2012, she created a coalition to fight the opioid epidemic, which claimed the lives of several young people in Rye in recent years alone.\n\nAt a time of national reckoning for women who were victims of sexual abuse, Ms. Killian\u2019s campaign has sought to show that Ms. Mayer dropped the ball in addressing sexual misconduct complaints when, before running for the Assembly, she served as legal counsel to the Senate Democrats.\n\nAccording to a recent report in The Daily News, two women \u2014 one a former Senate staff member, the other still employed \u2014 said that in 2010, Ms. Mayer failed to help them when they alerted her to sexual harassment they had suffered at the hands of their bosses.\n\nIn recent debates, Ms. Mayer, 64, acknowledged that she met with one of the women, and learned about the other incident through the woman\u2019s boyfriend. She followed the protocol in place at the time, which was to refer allegations to the secretary of the Senate, a political appointee.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn both cases, I went to the secretary of the Senate and I made the case that they need to do more,\u201d she said in a debate held in the studios of WRNN-TV on Tuesday. \u201cThey failed to do so. \u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn an interview, Ms. Mayer said that the Assembly has a rule that requires mandatory reporting of any allegation of sexual misconduct to an outside law firm. \u201cI believe the policy in the Senate was very flawed then, and the Senate Republicans just adopted it again,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Killian has nonetheless seized on the report in an effort to cast doubt on Ms. Mayer\u2019s feminist credentials. \u201cShe\u2019s no champion of women,\u201d Ms. Killian said. \u201cShe had the opportunity to help them. She was the most senior woman in the Senate Democrats at the time.\u201d\n\nSome newly minted activists are not buying the portrayal. \u201cThere are two females in this race, but only one is pro-woman,\u201d said Jenny Geer, who leads a progressive group called Blue Blast in Larchmont and Mamaroneck and who has canvassed for Ms. Mayer. \u201cI think it\u2019s convenient for Julie Killian to piggyback on the #MeToo movement and exploit it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. They planned to make the leap to a three-bedroom elsewhere \u2014 Leonard Pointe doesn\u2019t have any \u2014 with the extra bedroom reserved for a live-in au pair.\n\n\u201cI was kind of excited at how many options there were, and at the prospect of finding something quickly,\u201d said Ms. Greenspan, 29, who works in marketing. \u201cI wanted to be settled well in advance.\u201d", "title": "With Baby on the Way, Laundry Comes First", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "H. Fred Walker stood before his Edinboro University community on a recent snowy day and issued a warning.\n\n\u201cWe have been very insular in that we have not looked beyond the boundaries of Edinboro,\u201d the college president told a group of staff and students who had gathered at a meeting in this town tucked away in Northwestern Pennsylvania to hear the details of the college\u2019s strategic plan. \u201cWhen we\u2019re judged against our peers, it\u2019s a punch in the eye for us.\u201d\n\nWhile it was difficult for many in the room to hear, it was a reality years in the making for Edinboro, a four-year public university with an enrollment of about 6,000 students that is part of the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education. In the last decade, enrollment has plummeted, faculty salaries have caused expenses to skyrocket and completion rates have dissipated.\n\nNo longer is the school\u2019s most promising pipeline the average teenager going to college for the first time, but more likely the adult who may need to go back for a second or third. After 160 years as an anchor of rural Pennsylvania, the university is becoming obsolete.", "title": "With Changing Students and Times, Colleges Are Going Back to School", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou fulfill your programmatic ideas and then you do everything you can to find the funding to make that happen,\u201d Mr. Hollein said in an interview at the Met.\n\nA \u2018Think Big\u2019 Coach\n\nThis ability to strike a balance between art and business was a skill Mr. Hollein learned from Mr. Krens at the Guggenheim.\n\nMr. Hollein met Mr. Krens through his father, the prominent postmodern architect Hans Hollein, whom the Guggenheim had tapped for a branch in Salzburg that ultimately never materialized.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou became part of the family,\u201d Mr. Krens said. \u201cWe had a close relationship.\u201d\n\nGrowing up in a creative household (his mother Helene was a fashion designer), Mr. Hollein became conversant in the art world and interacted with leading figures like Joseph Beuys and Claes Oldenburg. When Andy Warhol went to Vienna in the 1980s for a show of his late large-scale silk-screens, 12-year-old Max got the artist to sign every single page of Warhol\u2019s exhibition catalog.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cContemporary artists for other students were these out-of-this-world figures,\u201d Mr. Hollein said. \u201cFor me, it was a friends and family background.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Max had to do a report on an artist at school, other students chose subjects like van Gogh and Monet; Mr. Hollein said he chose Naum Gabo, the Russian avant-garde sculptor.\n\n\u201cMy parents would have loved me to be an artist,\u201d he added, \u201cbut I had no talent for that or inclination.\u201d\n\nMr. Hollein\u2019s sister, Lilli Hollein, the director of Vienna Design Week, said her brother\u2019s business instincts were apparent early on. \u201cHe once developed a game that had an economic background,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was played with farm animals and people, and you had to buy cattle and stuff and then sell it.\u201d\n\nAt the University of Vienna he studied under Konrad Oberhuber, an eminent scholar of drawings, and Hermann Fillitz, who directed Vienna\u2019s Kunsthistorisches Museum \u2014 but also, \u201cas a revolution against my parents,\u201d studied business.\n\nWhen Max was 21, he came to New York to work as an intern at the Guggenheim and Mr. Krens invited him to return for a job after completing his education. He ultimately became Mr. Krens\u2019s chief of staff and executive assistant, working closely on projects like the Guggenheim branch designed by Frank Gehry in Bilbao, Spain.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe reason that Max is so multifaceted and has had so many great opportunities in life has a lot to do with Tom Krens,\u201d said Lisa Dennison, chairman of Sotheby\u2019s Americas division, and a former director of the Guggenheim, who overlapped with Mr. Hollein. \u201cTom gave Max opportunities \u2014 he was building museums, he was thinking about technology and he told Max to think big.\u201d\n\nAfter five-and-a-half years at the Guggenheim, Mr. Hollein told Mr. Krens, \u201cI have to leave here because I risk becoming a copy of you.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat he took from Mr. Krens, Mr. Hollein said, was that he could push an ambitious agenda until the pieces fell into place and naysayers came around.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOne must not forget the success of Bilbao,\u201d Mr. Hollein said, by way of example. \u201cTwo years before it opened there were large amounts of people who thought it would be a huge failure.\u201d\n\nReturning to Europe, Mr. Hollein imported the strategies and techniques he\u2019d learned in New York. \u201cHe has this mixture of the European and the American know-how, and that\u2019s a very rare thing,\u201d said Ren\u00e9e Price, the director of the Neue Galerie and a fellow Vienna native.\n\nIn 2001, after impressing Frankfurt\u2019s mayor, Petra Roth, at a dinner in New York, Mr. Hollein was named director of that city\u2019s Schirn Kunsthalle, a non-collecting institution with such low attendance that local politicians were arguing for its closure.\n\nMr. Hollein quickly whipped it into shape, and was savvy about sponsorships, getting private corporations to help pay for exhibitions of Yves Klein and Pablo Picasso.\n\nAttendance surged, and hipsters in Berlin began to take note of the upheaval underway in sleepy, big-money Frankfurt. By 2010, the weekly newspaper Die Zeit had called the Schirn \u201cthe most exciting exhibition hall in Germany.\u201d\n\nAmbitions Beyond the Rhine\n\nMr. Hollein was soon invited by trustees to take the director\u2019s post at the St\u00e4del foundation, a more venerable institution, and home to one of Germany\u2019s best collections of medieval, Renaissance and Baroque painting. He agreed to take the post, as well as the directorship of the neighboring Liebieghaus sculpture museum under a surprising condition: that he keep the Schirn as well.\n\nThis struck some as a power grab, and in Germany, a country whose citizens stick their academic titles on every surface, Mr. Hollein\u2019s lack of a doctorate in art history caused additional concern.\n\nEventually, Mr. Hollein\u2019s efforts began to speak for themselves. At the St\u00e4del, he helped expand the collection to include 20th- and 21st-century art by brokering unusual long-term loans with two German banks \u2014 Deutsche Bank and DZ Bank AG \u2014 that allowed the museum to retain the works in perpetuity.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExhibitions of Cranach, Botticelli and Monet attracted hundreds of thousands of visitors. An ambitious digital program \u2014 including art history video lectures in German and English \u2014 brought international attention to what was once a museum of only regional influence.\n\nAnd at both museums, Mr. Hollein indulged his abiding passion for electronic music. At the Schirn, he backed exhibitions featuring experimental composers like Carsten Nicolai and Ryoji Ikeda; at the St\u00e4del, during a 2012 exhibition of Romantic and Symbolist painting, he invited the public to dance until 2 a.m. to D.J.s from the Berlin nightclub circuit.\n\nMr. Hollein\u2019s progress gained attention on the other side of the Rhine. In 2013, he emerged as the odds-on favorite to become director of France\u2019s leading modern art museum, the Pompidou Center in Paris.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMax, in Frankfurt, had been committed to very strong temporary exhibitions \u2014 blockbuster shows as well as more scholarly, researched, niche shows,\u201d said Alain Seban, who was the Pompidou\u2019s president from 2007 to 2015. He praised Mr. Hollein\u2019s \u201ccapability to make the whole curatorial team participate in an exhibition strategy for the museum. And perhaps, considering the current situation of the Met, it\u2019s something that he might have to do there as well.\u201d\n\nMr. Seban would continue to hold the top job \u2014 a situation that closely parallels Mr. Hollein\u2019s new arrangement at the Met, where he will report to Daniel H. Weiss, the Met\u2019s president and chief executive.\n\nYet leaks to the French press damaged his Pompidou candidacy, particularly reports that his requested salary was three times higher than expected. Mr. Hollein withdrew before the final selection. (The job went to Bernard Blist\u00e8ne, a Pompidou veteran.)\n\nIn his Met interview, Mr. Hollein said he felt that the French government couldn\u2019t give him the freedom he needed to make significant strides.\n\n\u201cI draw a lot of energy where I feel I can move the institution forward,\u201d he said, adding: \u201cIt clearly was not the money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome people in the art world were surprised to see Mr. Hollein take the job in San Francisco, in part because of its powerful board president, Diane B. Wilsey, who has a reputation for being loath to relinquish control of the Fine Arts Museums.\n\nMs. Wilsey, 74, ceded the chief executive title after the museums paid a $2 million settlement to a former high-ranking executive who said Ms. Wilsey had her ousted for revealing alleged museum misspending.\n\nBut both Mr. Hollein and Ms. Wilsey said they have had a very productive working relationship. \u201cHe pushes the staff, but they like it,\u201d Ms. Wilsey said in a telephone interview. \u201cThey\u2019re energized by his energy and intelligence and ambitions.\u201d\n\nIndeed, Mr. Hollein managed to make an impact during his short tenure at the museum, balancing the budget and initiating shows like \u201cContemporary Muslim Fashions,\u201d which is set to open in September. (Breitbart News Daily questioned whether it was \u201ca celebration of subjugation.\u201d)", "title": "With Choice of New Director, the Met Gets a Scholar and a Showman", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin", "Jason Farago"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "If anything, students at Polytechnic University in Managua, who had been protesting for days, seemed galvanized by Mr. Ortega\u2019s Sunday announcement.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not going to move,\u201d said Golden Rivas, 36, a nursing major who had been at the Polytechnic University throughout the sit-in.\n\nDara Nicole D\u00edaz, 18, a graphic design major, whipped out her cellphone to read a long list of the students\u2019 demands, which included the release of protesters detained in the past week and the resignation of the police chief.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t a struggle just from now,\u201d she said. \u201cThis has been a dictatorship for almost 12 years. The people can\u2019t take it anymore.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Ortega\u2019s announcement capped a weekend of intensifying pressure. The rallies had spread to cities around the nation and claimed up to two dozen lives, according to Cenidh, a leading human rights organization.\n\nBy the end of Saturday, a reporter for an official government channel had been killed while filming a Facebook Live video about the protests. A police officer in Managua, the capital, shot in the head, was fighting for her life as other families arranged to bury their dead.\n\nThe government posted images of city blocks burning, government buildings in shambles and widespread ransacking of supermarkets with no police officers in sight \u2014 looting that some accused the government of staging in order to justify a crackdown.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt lunchtime on Sunday, before Mr. Ortega\u2019s announcement, the streets of central Managua were largely deserted, with businesses looted or shuttered, as tension lingered.\n\nMr. Ortega and Vice President Rosario Murillo, his wife, had said the previous day that they were willing to consider changes to the social security overhaul, but the private sector lobby Cosep responded that it would not enter into talks until the government ended police repression, released detained protesters and allowed freedom of speech. One news station has been taken off the air.\n\n\n\nThe business group also said other sectors would have to join the talks.\n\n\u201cWe want to sit at a real table, not a false one,\u201d Fidel Narv\u00e1ez, 29, a lawyer organizing some of the protests in the capital, said before Mr. Ortega\u2019s announcement. \u201cWe want a national recall referendum.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe social security overhaul would have forced contributors to pay more into social security and retirees to receive 5 percent less.\n\nNow in his third consecutive term as president, Mr. Ortega has a strong grip on power, including every branch of government and the military. Many poor people who receive housing and other government benefits support him.\n\n\u201cThe objective of the people on the street, and the dead, was for the presidential couple to leave,\u201d said Fidel Moreira, the executive director of the Center for the Studies of Governability and Democracy, which supports the protests. \u201cLooking at logic and how power here is built, that is a little far-off.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOscar Pupiro Zuniga, 62, a local leader of the government\u2019s leftist Sandinista Front party, acknowledged that the government had erred in not negotiating the social security overhaul with business and union leaders first, but he said well-financed right-wing groups had taken advantage of the issue to sow chaos.\n\n\u201cWhy do I say those students are being manipulated?\u201d Mr. Pupiro said. \u201cDid you see the trucks filled with water, mortars and everything else the students might need? It\u2019s not a fair protest.\u201d\n\nOn Friday, bankers joined the protests, as the nation\u2019s largest business group called both for a dialogue and a nationwide protest on Monday. The Roman Catholic Church provided refuge to students as it became increasingly unclear whether the church, the business community or any other interlocutor could step in and resolve the growing crisis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSaturday\u2019s protests were galvanized by a rambling midday speech by Mr. Ortega, who cited what he called the cynical nature of the protests and said they were organized by right-wing forces.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re delinquents,\u201d he said of the protesters. \u201cThey are members of gangs. When they incorporate these gang members, they are criminalizing the protest. They are putting at risk the very groups who, with good intentions, came to the protest.\u201d\n\nHe said his administration had worked hard to foster a positive image that encouraged tourism and investment, only to see that ruined by news coverage that harked back to the nation\u2019s years at war.\n\nAfter leading a 1979 revolution to overthrow a right-wing dictatorship, Mr. Ortega was president of Nicaragua in the 1980s. But a war financed by the United States marked his entire term in office until he was voted out in 1990. After losing several further elections, he took office again in 2007 when legal changes allowed him to win with a plurality.\n\nOn Saturday, Fanor Avenda\u00f1o Alguera met with a group of other young professionals. They were strategizing their next move in the growing protests, when his phone started buzzing with messages from fellow doctors at a demonstration at the university, saying: \u201cHelp, they have us surrounded\u201d and \u201cThey\u2019re asphyxiating us.\u201d\n\nIn a flash, Dr. Avenda\u00f1o and the engineers, lawyers, economists and publicists at the meeting grabbed face masks and bottled water and dashed off to the university, where they were met by dozens of youths carrying slingshots, rocks and bags of paint. They surrounded the university building as volunteers and nearby residents offered them water and first aid, while police officers at another entrance pushed back against student protesters.\n\nThe sound of mortar fire echoed in the air.", "title": "With Death in Streets, Nicaragua Cancels Social Security Revamp", "authors": ["Frances Robles"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "But wait: Then came a survey by the European Central Bank showing that commercial banks in the eurozone are becoming more willing to lend. That information bolstered economists who believe that recent signs of slowing growth reflect temporary factors, like an especially pernicious flu season that kept many workers home and hurt business.\n\nAmid so much uncertainty, Mr. Draghi\u2019s view of growth is critical. He has a large staff of experts and access to data not available to private sector economists, not to mention a doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.\n\nAnd unlike the view of your average economist, Mr. Draghi\u2019s is partly self-fulfilling. If he displays confidence, banks will be more eager to lend, businesses may be more willing to invest in expansion and to hire more people and, lo, it will be so.\n\nFor financial markets, the key question in the weeks to come is whether recent economic data will alter the European Central Bank\u2019s schedule for ending the measures it used to keep the eurozone together during an existential debt crisis. Chiefly, the bank bought hundreds of billions of euros in government and corporate bonds as a way of pumping money into the economy.\n\nIn recent months, the Governing Council has been making subtle changes in the statements it issues after monetary policy meetings as a way of preparing investors for an end to the bond buying, known as quantitative easing. On Thursday, it left monetary policy unchanged, and made no major changes to its statement.\n\nSeptember is expected to be the last month of the purchases, though the bank will continue to reinvest money it gets back when bonds mature. The aim is to gently bring monetary policy back to normal. Sometime late next year, or maybe not even until 2020, the European Central Bank will then probably begin raising its benchmark interest rates, currently at a historic low of zero, for the first time since 2011.\n\nAny indication by the Governing Council that it is revising its timetable would be big news. But the council takes the long view and has shown in recent months that it won\u2019t be thrown off course by a few unsettling economic indicators.", "title": "With Eurozone Economy Wavering, E.C.B. Leaves Policy Unchanged", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "[Read statements by France and Britain, and a declassified French document on the airstrikes.]\n\nFor Mr. Macron, the move also had the salutary effect of shoring up his position as a broker between Russia and the United States and the European Union. Just hours before launching the strike, Mr. Macron was on the telephone with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to discuss Syria. And both Mr. Macron and his aides have said that he still plans to go ahead with a state visit to Moscow at the end of May.\n\nAt the same time, Mr. Macron is trying to reinforce France\u2019s position as an enforcer of international treaties, which includes the Chemical Weapons Convention that 192 countries have signed.\n\nMrs. May is in a more precarious position, with a tense standoff developing with Russia over the poisoning of a former Russian spy, Sergei V. Skripal, and his daughter, Yulia Skripal, with a weapons-grade nerve agent. Mrs. May has been under pressure to respond forcefully to Moscow for the attack, which exposed hundreds of citizens in southwest England to the deadly substance.\n\nOn Saturday, the British leader described the airstrikes in Syria as \u201cright and legal,\u201d drawing an explicit distinction between those and the poisoning of the Skripals \u2014 the first use of chemical weapons in Europe since World War II.\n\nMrs. May also benefited from the timing of the airstrikes, two days before lawmakers were to return from vacation. While not obligated to consult Parliament, she may have felt constrained to do so and could easily have lost a vote on a strike. Another imperative for Britain was to reciprocate the support that London has received from the United States in the dispute with Russia over the poisoning.", "title": "With Eye on Issues at Home, May and Macron Back Trump on Syria Strikes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Bush reportedly had an infection that flared dangerously, and he is quite frail, Dr. Berry and other experts noted. Any number of factors could have contributed to his hospitalization.\n\nThat is not to say that deep grief on rare occasions can\u2019t send the body into free fall. The best known of these reactions, and a model for understanding them, is what\u2019s aptly called broken-heart syndrome.\n\nJapanese doctors were the first to describe the reaction in detail, and their name for it was even more evocative: Takotsubo syndrome, after the Japanese term for \u201coctopus trap.\u201d On scans of the grief-stricken, the heart may look as if it being squeezed from below, its upper chambers swelling as if straining to break free.\n\nThe sudden loss of a spouse, child or parent \u201creleases an outpouring from the sympathetic nervous system, the fight-or-flight response, which is what seems to damage the heart in broken-heart syndrome,\u201d said Dr. Anne Curtis, chairwoman of medicine at the University at Buffalo.\n\n\u201cThe heart rate goes up sharply, blood pressure goes up,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is why people can also have a stroke in situations like this.\u201d\n\nThe octopus trap can ensnare any heart, healthy or not, young or old. The flash-flood of stress hormones causes a temporary weakening of the heart muscle itself. The rush may also precipitate a classic heart attack, in which a clot blocks blood flow, or an arrhythmia, in which the heart revs wildly. The latter two consequences are more rare than the first, and deadlier.\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Curtis estimated that about 1 percent of perceived heart attacks are due to broken-heart syndrome or similar surges of stressful emotion. \u201cWe tell people that many will return to normal or near-normal heart function,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the first major American study of the phenomenon, doctors at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine studied 18 women and one man who landed in coronary care with chest pains and no classic signs of cardiac arrest after traumatic events, including the death of a spouse. Most were middle-aged and older, but two were young adults. All 19 survived.\n\nSince that research appeared, thousands of cases have been reported. About 90 percent of them are middle-aged women or older, said Dr. Ilan Wittstein, who led the original study.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne possible reason is that levels of estrogen, which protect smaller vessels in the heart, drop with age. \u201cStill, 10 percent are men, so this is something that can happen to anyone,\u201d Dr. Wittstein said.\n\nIf what felled Mr. Bush was a worsening infection, as reported, then a tide of grief in theory could have worsened his condition. Studies have linked elevated levels of cortisol, a stress hormone, to increased risk of contracting flu, colds and other sicknesses.\n\n\u201cA lot of things happen when people are overcome with sadness \u2014 neuroendocrine changes, which include an increase in cortisol levels, can suppress immune response,\u201d Dr. Wittstein said.\n\nYet tracing a straight line between the death of a spouse and the subsequent physical decline of a survivor is no easy task. Cause and effect are difficult to prove.\n\nThat ailing spouses in their early 90s might die within a short time of each other is quite possible even if there were no such thing as broken-heart syndrome, simply because of their age and health, Bradley Efron, a statistician at Stanford University, said in an email.\n\nAnd signs of broken-heart syndrome rarely have been documented in large groups of people. In a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers reviewed 30,447 people aged 60 to 89 in Britain whose partners had died. The subjects were compared to 83,588 people of the same ages whose partners had not died.\n\nThose who were bereaved had a greater risk of a coronary event in the month after their partners died. But the increase in risk was tiny: Fifty in the bereaved group (0.16 percent) had a heart attack or stroke, compared to 67 (0.08 percent) in the comparison group.\n\nStill, the rare examples capture our attention, as Dr. Berry noted.\n\nThe actress Debbie Reynolds died one day after her beloved daughter Carrie Fisher. Quarterback Doug Flutie\u2019s parents died on the same day, both of heart attacks. Johnny and June Cash died within months of each other, after a long marriage.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSomehow we lose sight of the norm. As Brian Skyrms, a professor of philosophy of science and economics at the University of California, Irvine, noted: \u201cNursing homes are full of surviving spouses.\u201d", "title": "With George H.W. Bush Hospitalized, the World Wonders: Is It a Broken Heart?", "authors": ["Gina Kolata", "Benedict Carey"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The persistence of those political leaders brought tangible rewards. Almost 1,500 people died in Northern Ireland\u2019s \u201cTroubles\u201d during the 20 years before the agreement (also known as the Belfast Agreement), compared to fewer than 150 victims of conflict-related violence since, according to the BBC.\n\nBut the accord is under acute pressure. \u201cPeace has to be worked on continually so you should never think of it as guaranteed,\u201d said Mr. Blair, who added: \u201cAnd, yes, Brexit is a complication.\u201d\n\nPower-sharing arrangements at the legislature in Stormont in Belfast \u2014 one of the central pillars of the agreement \u2014 have broken down amid disputes over how to deal with the legacy of the \u201cTroubles\u201d and a disagreement over Irish language rights. That has left Northern Ireland without a functioning executive since January 2017.\n\n\u201cIn the end the people of Northern Ireland are going to have to stand up for this agreement at a certain point,\u201d said Mr. Blair, who urged them to make clear to leaders \u201cfrom whatever party they are in, that they want them to find a way through this impasse, and get the agreement moving forward again.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe moderate parties of course will be the ones who are advocating this,\u201d he added.\n\nMr. Blair also outlined his fears about the impact of British withdrawal from the European Union, or Brexit, a process he still believes can be halted.\n\nBrexit creates special problems for Northern Ireland which, as part of the United Kingdom, is to quit the European Union, while Ireland will remain a member of the bloc. Meanwhile, some supporters of Brexit in Britain have questioned the long-term future of the Good Friday Agreement.\n\nUnder the Northern Ireland peace process, visible signs of the Irish border disappeared, and the British government is struggling to explain how it can quit the European Union\u2019s economic structures without the reimposition of frontier checks.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Blair said that the removal of frontier points was an important part of the Good Friday Agreement because it represented \u201cpart of that nationalist aspiration\u201d to have \u201can open border between North and South.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not saying these issues can\u2019t be overcome, but plainly Brexit poses a challenge,\u201d he said, adding that it fundamentally affects a concept at the heart of the Good Friday Agreement.\n\nWhile ways might be found for the frontier problem to be minimized, \u201cyou are not going to make it disappear,\u2019\u2019 he said. \u201cI don\u2019t think there is a way apart from staying in the single market and customs union.\u201d Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain has promised to quit both those structures, which bind the European Union into a single trading bloc.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. But the spokesman, Jon Weinstein, said \u201cthe repairs to the Sandy-damaged Canarsie Tunnel are desperately needed to ensure the tunnel\u2019s structural integrity.\u2019\u2019\n\nSome transportation experts argue that even bolder action is necessary. To encourage car pooling they have called for banning vehicles with fewer than three people from the Williamsburg Bridge for longer than just rush hours as the city envisions and extending the ban to other bridges. And 14th Street, they say, should be restricted primarily to buses 24 hours a day to make it easier on subway riders.\n\n\u201cA lot of people don\u2019t commute 9-to-5 hours,\u201d said Kate Slevin, the vice president for state programs and advocacy at the Regional Plan Association, an urban research group. \u201cA lot of people are traveling down 14th Street all times of the day. During the morning and evening rush between Third Avenue and Ninth Avenue, it will be limited to buses with the exception of some vehicles, like delivery trucks.\n\nThe city has a goal of ensuring that buses can cross the bus corridor along 14th Street in 20 minutes, a speed rate of over 6.5 miles per hour and over 40 percent faster than buses there travel now.
