Freeman, a labor historian at the City University of New York. \u201cThere\u2019s been a slow chipping away of union clout.\u201d\n\nIncreasingly, developers who had customarily done all-union jobs have turned to \u201copen shops,\u201d in which union contractors compete against nonunion outfits for work.\n\nAt the Times Square rally, Bryant Nunez, a Marine veteran and a second-year apprentice with the ironworkers union, said, \u201cThe nonunion guys are taking our work. It\u2019s pretty much a bread-and-butter issue for me.\u201d\n\nRelated insists that its intention is not to break the unions, but to hold unions to their agreements. The company says that some have not made negotiated changes, like having work crews include more apprentices, paid at a lower wage, in order to bring costs down.\n\nLast year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sided with the construction unions, insisting that developers participating in a citywide affordable housing program must pay minimum wage rates that the unions argued would allow them to better compete for work. But it is not clear that the change has resulted in the unions\u2019 getting more work on residential projects.\n\nAlthough Related has been the most aggressive in its approach to the unions, the industry\u2019s powerful Real Estate Board of New York has also taken up the cause. The unions, said John Banks, president of the board, have \u201cchosen to try and apply pressure through the political process and aggressive public theatrics, rather than reform of their work rules and benefit structure. These futile efforts will result in such unions losing even more market share.\u201d", "title": "With Pickets and Lawsuits, Unions and Developers Go to War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "41A: When you are a child, a time out is a punishment, but when you reach adulthood, \u201cTime out?\u201d is a NAP and a privilege. If you want to be strict about the interpretation, \u201cTime out?\u201d means time spent unconscious.\n\n60A: \u201cDecked out?\u201d can mean dressed to the nines, but if you are playing cards, it means that you\u2019ve DEALT, or given out the deck of cards.\n\n1D: An ONAGER with a mane is an Asiatic horse. An onager with a sling is a type of catapult.\n\n8D: Fun fact: People around you look at you funny when you suddenly sing \u201cThe Jetsons\u201d theme song out loud in order to remember that their son\u2019s name was ELROY.\n\n21D: Don\u2019t let the fact that \u201cBolt\u201d and \u201clightning\u201d are used together fool you into thinking that this is about atmospheric discharges. We are not looking for a lightning bolt here; we\u2019re looking for USAIN Bolt, who is lightning in human form.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Eaton-Salners\u2019s theme is a bit hard to keep track of, but it\u2019s very cool, so I\u2019m going to give you one example here and then I\u2019m going to totally spill the beans behind this link.\n\nThe trick today is to use the number in the first square of an entry (the location) to get the complete answer to a different entry.\n\nSo, for 1A, the clue is \u201c5-Across, with respect to this answer\u2019s location.\u201d That means we take the \u201c1\u201d from 1-Across and combine it with its entry to gain perspective on why 5A is what it is. Translated into English, that means that 1 (location) + OVER = 1 over, which is a BOGEY, or the answer to 5A.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nClear as mud? Fear not: The rest of the theme is explained behind the link above.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nPuzzles with answers that must appear with specific clue numbers are challenging to construct because they require precise gridwork. One way to control which clue numbers correspond to which answers is to use \u201ccheater\u201d squares (black squares that don\u2019t change the puzzle\u2019s word count). For instance, the black square before 10-Across reduces all subsequent clue numbers by one. Without that square, the answer SEVEN would be at 25-Across instead of 24-Across. Other cheater squares may have different effects on numbering. For example, the black square before 28-Across doesn\u2019t affect the clue numbering at all, but its symmetric counterpart after 41-Across changes what would have been 44-Down into 49-Down and decreases the clue numbering for the intervening clues by one (after 49-Down the numbering is unchanged). Generally speaking, cheater squares in the upper-left corner of a region reduce all subsequent clue numbering by one, cheater squares in the upper right reduce the numbering of clues by one until the shortened down entry, whose clue number is increased by the number of intervening clue numbers, and cheater squares in the lower left and lower right leave clue numbering unchanged. The unedited version of this puzzle clued the gimmick in the opposite direction. 5-Across and 41-Across were clued as \u201cSee previous answer\u201d and 22-Across and 46-Across were clued as \u201cSee next answer.\u201d The words OVER, SEVEN, WINKS and FIFTY were clued without any reference to their clue numbers or the combined meaning. Perhaps that cluing approach is too difficult and many solvers wouldn\u2019t realize that reading the numbers in the grid in combination with the answers creates a new meaning (i.e., 1 OVER or 40 WINKS). I miss the elegance of the original approach, but if the change improves the solving experience, then I\u2019m all in favor.\n\n\u2018Women of Letters\u2019 Crossword Pack Now Available\n\nIf you would like to solve a brilliant set of crosswords, the \u201cWomen of Letters\u201d pack is now available for the cost of a donation to a woman-friendly charity.\n\nThis pack was edited by Patti Varol and Amy Reynaldo, based on a t-shirt that Erik Agard wore to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament a couple of years ago, and the puzzles were made by your favorite and upcoming favorite woman constructors.\n\nTo receive this pack, make a donation of $10 or more to any of the charities listed on the \u201cWomen of Letters\u201d page and email your receipt to WomenofLettersCrosswords@gmail.com.\n\nThe Tipping Point\n\nAlmost finished solving but just need a bit more help? We\u2019ve got you covered.\n\nWarning: There be spoilers ahead, but now you can take a peek at the answer key. While the answers are free to everyone, the crossword puzzles require a subscription.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "With Respect to an Answer\u2019s Location", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 As President Trump continued to fume on Tuesday about the Justice Department\u2019s raids on the office and hotel room of his longtime personal lawyer, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, made a provocative claim: The president, she said, believes he has the legal authority to fire Robert S. Mueller, the special counsel leading the Russia investigation.\n\nThe assertion by Ms. Sanders was surprising because the general understanding has been that Mr. Trump himself cannot directly fire Mr. Mueller, and that he would instead have to order the deputy attorney general, Rod J. Rosenstein, who is the acting attorney general for the purpose of the Russia inquiry, to do so. Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself from any involvement in the investigation.\n\nMr. Rosenstein has repeatedly said that he will refuse any order to fire Mr. Mueller unless he decides the special counsel committed misconduct. If the general understanding is correct, then, Mr. Trump would probably have to fire Mr. Rosenstein and hunt for a successor willing to carry out the order \u2014 echoing the \u201cSaturday Night Massacre\u201d during the Watergate scandal.\n\nIn 1973, President Richard M. Nixon decided to force the Justice Department to fire Archibald Cox, the first special counsel investigating Watergate. Both the attorney general and the deputy attorney general resigned rather than carry out those orders before the solicitor general, then the No. 3 official in the department, finally agreed to do so. The episode was a milestone in the eventual decision by the House to begin impeachment proceedings.", "title": "With Scant Precedent, White House Insists Trump Could Fire Mueller Himself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "It should be no surprise that in an administration whose propaganda efforts make Mr. Bush\u2019s seem quaint we find our democracy in thrall to a corrupt deal between Jared Kushner and Sinclair. The latter provided pedal-to-the-metal, positive coverage of Mr. Trump in the presidential election campaign. Now we find the Trump administration and its handpicked F.C.C. chairman, Ajit Pai, supporting Sinclair\u2019s efforts to bring its spooky anchor hostage videos to 72 percent of the households in the United States.\n\nThe potential deal also received direct support from President Trump, who tweeted Monday that \u201cSinclair is far superior to CNN and even more Fake NBC.\u201d\n\nAs Craig Aaron, the president and chief executive of Free Press \u2014 an advocate of diverse and independent media ownership that filed a formal challenge to the Sinclair-Tribune merger \u2014 stated Monday, \u201cThis Trump-Sinclair love affair looks like a quid pro quo \u2014 and it should be a national scandal.\u201d\n\nMany Americans don\u2019t even know that news is supposed to provide a \u201cpublic good.\u201d The Sinclair statement, at least in part, lays out what many people think of as the purpose of journalism: \u201cIt\u2019s our responsibility to pursue and report the truth. We understand truth is neither politically \u2018left nor right.\u2019 Our commitment to factual reporting is the foundation of our credibility, now more than ever.\u201d\n\nThat part sounds legitimate. But when you understand Sinclair management and the ways that it manipulates news, and take in the full ideological context, you see it for what it is: anti-journalism, or propaganda.\n\nLast month we saw the courageous act of a patriot, Ralph Peters, a retired Army lieutenant colonel who ended his role as an analyst for Fox News. He said that decades ago, \u201cI took an oath to \u2018support and defend the Constitution.\u2019 As Fox\u2019s assault on our constitutional order intensified, spearheaded by its after-dinner demagogues, I had no choice but to leave.\u201d\n\nI saw the same from the Washington bureau chief at Sinclair, Jon Leiberman, around the time I was there. This Bush voter walked out of a Sinclair meeting and straight to the media to expose the propaganda Sinclair promulgated.", "title": "Opinion | With Sinclair, We Have Trump TV. America Doesn\u2019t Need More.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Blog posts indicate that other drivers have experienced the same issue.\n\nThe Tesla owner\u2019s manual describes this situation as one that the system can\u2019t yet manage. Tesla said it expected future upgrades to solve the problem, but for now, drivers need to be as attentive to the rearview mirror as with any other car.\n\nTesla had no comment for this column.\n\nAt this juncture, Autopilot is a misnomer, as many others have observed. \u201cThis is not self-driving technology,\u201d said Bryan Reimer, a research scientist and expert on autonomous vehicle technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. \u201cIt\u2019s a collaborative system that leaves responsibility for safety in the drivers\u2019 hands and isn\u2019t intended to let them sit in the back seat or pursue other activities while driving.\u201d Even though some companies have said they plan driverless ride services in as little as two years, Mr. Reimer said full automation was likely to be many years or even decades in the future.\n\nSelf-driving automation systems are ranked from zero (no automation) to 5 (full automation). Tesla\u2019s Autopilot is Level 2. It requires drivers to keep at least one hand on the wheel. The car issues a prompt if it doesn\u2019t detect a hand on the wheel, and Autopilot shuts down if there\u2019s no response. In the Mountain View accident, Tesla has said, the driver \u201creceived several visual and one audible hands-on warning,\u201d but \u201cthe driver\u2019s hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision.\u201d\n\nGiven that this was my first extended drive using Autopilot, I was hypervigilant, maybe even more so than in a conventional car. I\u2019m told that wears off in time, as using Autopilot becomes second nature. The risk is that complacency contributes to driver inattention. Mr. Reimer and other experts are conducting research into the issue.\n\n\u201cAs technology supplants human performance,\u201d Mr. Reimer said, \u201cthe bigger question is how safe is safe enough. If lane-changing technology is 50 percent more effective than humans, is that good enough? That\u2019s the big question no one wants to answer.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, he said, he worries that \u201cintense media coverage of accidents like Mountain View will scare people off.\u201d He said it was too soon to draw any conclusions from that fatality, but noted that Tesla\u2019s excellent safety record over the many millions of miles its cars have now traveled suggested that using Autopilot \u201ccan\u2019t be substantially more risky than conventional controls.\u201d (There were more than 40,000 traffic fatalities in the United States last year.)\n\nAfter investigating a fatal 2016 crash involving a Tesla S and a tractor-trailer in Florida, the National Highway Transportation Safety Administration found no flaws in the Autopilot system. The National Transportation Safety Board concluded that Autopilot had performed as intended, but that the driver had become overly reliant on the technology.", "title": "With Tesla in a Danger Zone, Can Model 3 Carry It to Safety?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMIAMI \u2014 The Mets just continue to roll. With a solid start from Noah Syndergaard, opportunistic hitting and a sturdy bullpen, the Mets defeated the host Miami Marlins on Monday, 4-2, for their sixth straight victory, improving to 8-1 on the season.\n\nTwice before, the Mets have started 8-1: in 1985, when they did not reach the playoffs, and in 2006, when they reached the National League Championship Series. With one more victory, the 2018 Mets would have the best start in franchise history.\n\nThe Marlins, despite being maligned for another fire sale of top players this winter, put up a fight against Syndergaard, who battled his own command at times. He allowed two runs, only one earned, over six innings. He struck out five but walked two and hit a batter.\n\nThe Mets\u2019 offense struck first. Adrian Gonzalez drove in a run with a single off Marlins starter Jose Ure\u00f1a in the second inning. Kevin Plawecki tacked on a second run by hitting into a double play that allowed Asdrubal Cabrera to score.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJay Bruce pushed the Mets\u2019 lead to 3-0 when he singled to center field to score Amed Rosario in the third inning.", "title": "With Win Over Marlins, Mets Tie Franchise Record for Best Start", "authors": ["James Wagner"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "In early 2002, just a few months after he officially took over as the new owner and chief executive officer of Brooks Brothers, Claudio Del Vecchio confronted the reality that the classic American retailer had largely lost its way.\n\nMr. Del Vecchio knew that many of the clothing fabrics were no longer of high quality, that too many of its shirts were ill fitting and that there were often disconcerting irregularities, like a rack of navy blazers that weren\u2019t the exact same shade of navy.\n\nAnd longtime customers had noticed.\n\nAmong Mr. Del Vecchio\u2019s first acts as owner was to read a stack of angry letters from Brooks Brothers loyalists who griped about how the merchandise quality had fallen under the previous owner, the British retailer Marks & Spencer. They also balked at the limited selection of classic blazers and suits in the stores.\n\nThose letters confirmed much of what Mr. Del Vecchio, a wealthy Italian entrepreneur, had seen for himself and stiffened his resolve to return to the company\u2019s roots. \u201cI saw the business opportunity to increase sales,\u201d he said. \u201cI knew how to fix this.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA new executive team shifted into crisis mode. Led by an experienced chief merchant, Eraldo Poletto, with whom Mr. Del Vecchio had worked at Casual Corner (a women\u2019s wear retail chain that Mr. Del Vecchio sold in 2005), they began to corral the company\u2019s best suppliers to revamp all the store\u2019s merchandise. Hundreds of garment styles required new specifications, better fabrics and apparel factories. It took about six months for the first shipments of the improved garments to arrive in stores \u2014 swapping out the oversize khakis and shapeless polo shirts.", "title": "With a Glance Backward, Brooks Brothers Looks to the Future", "authors": ["Teri Agins"]} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cHe was all like, \u2018Uh, sure, O.K., I\u2019ll go play some volleyball,\u2019\u201d Chris said. \u201cWe\u2019re watching them play and they got to the playoffs and he\u2019s doing all these dinking serves and playing like he\u2019s been playing his whole life. That is a lot of what my Dad was like.\u201d\n\nDick Hammer would certainly think his grandson is a chip off the old block. And Darnold now has a chance to create his own legacy.\n\nDarnold, from Capistrano Beach, Calif., played just two seasons for U.S.C., but showed enough eye-popping ability as a playmaking passer to be rated by many as the No. 1 player at his position heading into the draft.\n\nDarnold is now tasked with helping lift a franchise that has been seeking a savior since the glory days of Joe Namath nearly 50 years ago. The Jets have been to just one Super Bowl \u2014 you know, the one Broadway Joe delivered after his guarantee in 1969. That\u2019s a lot of pressure for a kid who won\u2019t even turn 21 until June, but Darnold is becoming fully aware of what he\u2019s getting into.\n\n\u201cWinning a Super Bowl is everyone\u2019s goal entering a season, whether I\u2019m a backup or whether I\u2019m starting quarterback,\u201d he said. \u201cEveryone on the team wants to win a Super Bowl. That\u2019s the goal for everyone. Anything short of that is a failure, and we\u2019re aware of that. Everyone\u2019s aware of that. And whatever my role is, I\u2019m going to star in that role to work us toward that Super Bowl.\u201d\n\nDarnold already has a prominent place in Jets history, being the highest-drafted quarterback by the team since the 1970 A.F.L.-N.F.L. merger.\n\n\u201cGetting that phone call, it changed my life,\u201d Darnold said. \u201cI know it\u2019s going to change my life, and I\u2019m very confident here that we\u2019re going to win some games, and I think I\u2019m going to be here for a long time.\u201d", "title": "With the Jets, Sam Darnold Can Create His Own Legacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "More than 25 years into an ever-changing acting career, Ms. Posey, 49, continues to embody the irrepressible energy she has brought to films like \u201cDazed and Confused,\u201d \u201cWaiting For Guffman\u201d and \u201cParty Girl.\u201d\n\nShe unapologetically wears oversized, Elaine Stritch-style eyeglasses and carries Tic Tacs in a dispenser the shape and size of a giant Tic Tac. She shares her West Village apartment with Gracie, her 14-year-old bichon fris\u00e9-poodle-Maltese mix; her friends are fellow artists \u2014 actors, comedians, directors \u2014 and her tastes are eclectic. Her idea of a good movie, she said, would be something from \u201cthe Estonian film festival I saw 10 years ago.\u201d\n\nLike her best-known characters, Ms. Posey carries herself with a blithe spirit that conceals a cutting sense of humor. She spent a walk through her neighborhood on the lookout for starlings and blue jays, and when asked for the address of a restaurant she recommended, she answered: \u201cI\u2019m not going to tell you. I\u2019m a practicing psychic and I want to see if you can read my mind.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Posey, playing Dr. Smith is an opportunity to cavort among the stars on a big-budget series and to put her unique stamp on a beloved cult-TV character.\n\nBut it\u2019s also an acknowledgment of how challenging it has become, even for an actor of Ms. Posey\u2019s stature, to make a living solely from small prestigious films in today\u2019s industry.", "title": "With \u2018Lost in Space,\u2019 Parker Posey Finds an Unlikely Home in Serial TV", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Murky Perils of Quitting Antidepressants After Years of Use\u201d (front page, April 8):\n\nWe write as clinicians and researchers with experience treating antidepressant withdrawal. To practicing psychiatrists and the vast majority of patients, withdrawal is low on the list of priorities.\n\nBy amplifying the social media echo chamber, the article creates the unfortunate impression that most patients are forced to continue antidepressants out of fear of withdrawal rather than out of prevention of recurrence. This is simply not the case.\n\nFirst, although withdrawal has not been well studied, the clinical consensus is that it is real, rare and always treatable. Certainly more research into this phenomenon is warranted.\n\nSecond, mood and anxiety disorders are common, debilitating and often undertreated. That a greater proportion of afflicted Americans are now receiving treatment should be applauded rather than implicitly derided.", "title": "Opinion | Withdrawing From Antidepressants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Nader has received at least partial immunity for his cooperation, and it appears unlikely that Mr. Mueller is trying to build a case against him. Instead, it is common for prosecutors to interview as many people as possible to corroborate the testimony of a key witness like Mr. Nader.\n\nMr. Nader\u2019s dealings with Russia date at least to 2012, when he helped broker a controversial $4.2 billion deal for the government of Iraq to buy Russian weapons. At the time, he was an informal adviser to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq, and he accompanied Mr. Maliki to Moscow in September 2012 to sign the arms deal at a meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. Mr. Nader\u2019s role in the deal was earlier reported by Al-Monitor.\n\nThe deal was canceled shortly after because of concerns about corruption, and a spokesman for the prime minister said it would be renegotiated.\n\nEarlier that year, Mr. Nader also attended the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, an invitation-only conference organized by senior officials close to Mr. Putin that Russia presents as its answer to the World Economic Forum held annually in Davos, Switzerland. Mr. Nader is on a list of participants from 2012. Representatives of the St. Petersburg forum did not respond to inquiries about his attendance in subsequent years.\n\nSince then, according to people familiar with his travels, Mr. Nader has returned frequently to Russia on behalf of the Emirati government. He even had his picture taken with Mr. Putin, according to one person who has seen the photograph, although it is unclear when the picture was taken.\n\nCrown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed Al-Nahyan of Abu Dhabi, the de facto ruler of the U.A.E., is a close ally of the United States and a frequent visitor to the White House. He has also visited Moscow and met with Mr. Putin several times in recent years. One person briefed on the matter said Mr. Nader had accompanied the crown prince to Moscow on numerous occasions.\n\nLast year, days before Mr. Trump took office, Mr. Nader helped set up a meeting at a Seychelles resort between Mr. Dmitriev, Emirati officials and Erik Prince, the former head of Blackwater Worldwide and an adviser to Mr. Trump\u2019s transition team. The meeting, at the bar of a Four Seasons Hotel overlooking the Indian Ocean, was brokered in part to explore the possibility of a back channel for discussions between the Trump administration and the Kremlin, according to people familiar with the meeting.\n\nPhoto\n\nSuch contacts are at the heart of Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation, and his investigators have repeatedly used aggressive tactics to press witnesses. About four weeks ago, F.B.I. agents working with Mr. Mueller\u2019s team stopped a Russian oligarch at a New York-area airport, questioned him about his dealings with Mr. Trump and seized his electronics, according to a person familiar with the matter, which was first reported by CNN.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have asked multiple witnesses about the Seychelles meeting, part of a broader line of inquiry surrounding contacts between Emirati advisers and Trump administration officials. They have also pressed for details about a meeting Mr. Nader attended in New York in early 2017 with Mr. Kushner and Mr. Bannon with the hedge fund manager Richard Gerson, a friend of Mr. Kushner\u2019s and the founder of Falcon Edge Capital.\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s particular interest in that meeting is unclear, although Mr. Gerson has had business dealings with the court of the U.A.E.\u2019s Prince Mohammed. Mr. Gerson has developed relations with several senior Emirati officials over the years, including with Prince Mohammed himself, and he has often sought investments from Emirati state funds.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. Kushner has been friends for more than a decade with Mr. Gerson\u2019s brother Mark, a founder of the specialized research company Gerson Lehrman Group. Mark Gerson was also an early investor in Cadre, a real estate technology company founded by Mr. Kushner and his brother, Josh.\n\nJared Kushner\u2019s family foundation has also donated tens of thousands of dollars to an Israeli medical aid group led by Mark Gerson.\n\nA lawyer for Mr. Nader and a spokesman for Rick Gerson declined to comment. Mark Gerson did not reply to requests for comment.\n\nMr. Mueller\u2019s investigators have also questioned Joel Zamel, an Australian entrepreneur who has an office in Tel Aviv and knows Mr. Nader, according to people briefed on the matter. Mr. Zamel has had contacts with senior U.A.E. officials close to its ruler since at least 2014.\n\nIn February, federal agents working for Mr. Mueller stopped Mr. Zamel at Reagan National Airport outside Washington and briefly seized his electronic devices, the people said. Mr. Zamel later appeared before a grand jury and was questioned about Mr. Nader, though it was unclear whether Mr. Zamel had any information about Mr. Nader\u2019s ties to Russia.\n\nMr. Zamel is a witness in Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation and is not suspected of any wrongdoing, according to Marc Mukasey, a lawyer for Mr. Zamel and his crowdsourced consulting firm, Wikistrat. The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday that Mr. Zamel informally met with Mr. Mueller\u2019s team.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJoel and Wikistrat have not been accused of anything, have done nothing wrong and are not the focus of the special counsel,\u201d said Mr. Mukasey, a global chairman of Greenberg Traurig\u2019s white-collar defense and special investigations practice. \u201cProsecutors like to question as many people as they can \u2014 even if they have tangential involvement and limited knowledge.\u201d\n\nMr. Zamel briefly met last spring with Jared Kushner at the White House, another person said, though that meeting does not appear to be a focus of Mr. Mueller\u2019s inquiry.\n\nWikistrat, which pays security experts around the world for their insights, has landed several government contracts, according to databases and news reports. Its website says the firm can draw from a group of more than 2,200 analysts worldwide who share their thinking on an interactive platform.\n\nSome well-known experts serve on Wikistrat\u2019s advisory council, including Michael V. Hayden, a former head of the C.I.A. and the National Security Agency, and Dennis Ross, a former United States diplomat with deep expertise in the Middle East.", "title": "Witness in Mueller Inquiry Who Advises U.A.E. Reporters and photographers in a car behind her captured the moment, which quickly spread online and became a source of many jokes on late-night television.\n\nBut Ms. Briskman\u2019s employer, Akima L.L.C., did not find it funny.\n\nWhen she returned to work the following week, she said, company executives told her she needed to resign. Ms. Briskman, 50, had violated the company\u2019s social media policy on obscenity by sharing the image on Facebook and Twitter, they told her, according to the lawsuit filed on Wednesday in Fairfax County Circuit Court in Virginia.\n\nThe executives also feared blowback from the Trump administration, Ms. Briskman said the executives told her.", "title": "Woman Who Was Fired for Giving Trump the Middle Finger Sues Former Employer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "A woman\u2019s dismembered body was found in a park in eastern Brooklyn on Monday evening, the police said.\n\nAccording to a New York Police Department official, the woman\u2019s head and torso were found about 15 feet off a walkway in Canarsie Park, near East 86th Street and Seaview Avenue. The body was naked and facedown with no legs or arms attached, the official said. It was found under shrubbery, but it was not clear whether it had been deliberately placed there to conceal it.\n\nA passer-by saw the body, went home, called the police, and returned to the park around 6:10 p.m. to direct officers to where he had seen it, the official said. Investigators were looking into who the woman was and how long her body had been there.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Even a comedy like the ace Jaclyn Backhaus playlet \u201cThe National Foosball Championship\u201d (part of an omnibus of short works) revolved around a battle of the sexes.\n\nWhile everybody in Mark Schultz\u2019s \u201cEvocation to Visible Appearance\u201d is despondent, the two female characters feel powerless. Chatty Samantha (Suzy Weller) is dumped by her boyfriend (Lincoln Clauss) after informing him she\u2019s pregnant \u2014 which she may or may not be. Her sister, the sharp-tongued but depressive Natalie (Ronete Levenson), is in a mental institution.\n\nMr. Schultz (\u201cThe Gingerbread House\u201d) and the director Les Waters lay on the gloom a bit thick, but then the play is less about plot than about atmosphere, in this case dread fueled by dead-end jobs, illness and general misery.\n\nA sudden act of violence at a fast-food outlet does not feel earned, and comes across as gratuitous provocation, but the play is almost redeemed by a bizarre conclusion that left the audience as mystified as any I\u2019ve ever seen: In a kind of dark-arts s\u00e9ance, a deafeningly loud doom-metal song is performed live while Samantha attempts to conjure her possibly imaginary unborn child and her father (Bruce McKenzie) dances like a pained cartoon bear. The house lights abruptly come back. There is no curtain call.\n\nThis was quite the mic drop from Mr. Waters \u2014 who, incidentally, is departing as the artistic head of Actors Theater, which runs the festival.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe workplace violence in Susan Soon He Stanton\u2019s \u201cwe, the invisibles\u201d is more muted, but the threat is always there. Ms. Stanton\u2019s starting point was the Dominique Strauss-Kahn case, when he was accused of assaulting Nafissatou Diallo, a hotel housekeeper. At the time, in 2011, Ms. Stanton was herself working at a high-end Manhattan hotel, and the play is her attempt to give the \u201cinvisibles\u201d who form the hospitality industry\u2019s backbone their due.\n\nMs. Stanton likes to have fun with storytelling. (Last year\u2019s \u201cToday Is My Birthday\u201d was narrated through phone calls and voice messages.) Here the myriad quick-take scenes are well handled by the director D\u00e1maso Rodr\u00edguez and the excellent ensemble cast, which captures the hotel\u2019s staff as well as Susan (Rinabeth Apostol), the playwright\u2019s stand-in, usually seen interviewing former co-workers, and Ms. Diallo herself (Rebecca S\u2019Manga Frank).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile it has an appealing documentary quality, \u201cwe, the invisibles\u201d also feels directionless. Susan initially says she wants to leave \u201cD.S.K.\u201d out of her story, for instance, but he has a way of popping in. Re-enactments of Abel Ferrara\u2019s film \u201cWelcome to New York\u201d and the \u201cLaw & Order: SVU\u201d episode based on the incident are hilarious, but keep taking us back to the criminal case Susan claims not to be interested in.\n\nAnother workplace-focused drama is \u201cMarginal Loss\u201d by Deborah Stein (\u201cThe Wholehearted\u201d), which unfurls over the days immediately following the Sept. 11 attacks. The action is set in the New Jersey warehouse from which a Manhattan financial firm is temporarily operating, trying to get back to business.\n\nThe four-character play, directed by Meredith McDonough, is professional, but to what end? No matter how much they suffered or how many friends and colleagues they lost, the characters don\u2019t seem to live beyond the page. Ultimately \u201cMarginal Loss\u201d lacks a strong point of view on what these finance workers are trying so hard to accomplish: to make a ton of money again.\n\nPhoto\n\nLeah Nanako Winkler\u2019s \u201cGod Said This,\u201d the festival\u2019s highest-profile production \u2014 it recently received the Yale Drama Series Prize and will be presented in New York at Primary Stages next season \u2014 is a relatively traditional drama in which a Japanese-American family from Lexington, Ky., deals with the mother\u2019s cancer.\n\nMasako (Ako) is getting chemotherapy in a hospital, attended by her daughters: the good-girl, born-again Sophie (Emma Kikue) and the pot-smoking, rebellious Hiro (Satomi Blair), who has flown in from New York. Masako\u2019s husband, James (Jay Patterson), is not aging well, having turned into a bit of a hoarder. Fights, reconciliations, tears \u2014 events follow a conventional route.\n\nThe lived-in acting is a highlight of the show, directed by Morgan Gould. This may have to do with Ako, Ms. Blair and Mr. Patterson playing the same characters at Ensemble Studio Theater two years ago in Ms. Winkler\u2019s \u201cKentucky.\u201d It\u2019s unclear whether Ms. Winkler is planning a large-scale cycle, but her plays may work better in aggregate.", "title": "Women (and Men, Too) Pushed to the Edge at New Play Festival", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Ryozo Tatami, the mayor of Maizuru, a city of about 84,000 people in Kyoto prefecture, was giving a speech when he had a brain hemorrhage and collapsed.\n\nIn the video, it appears that several male sumo staff members gathered around Mr. Tatami before the female nurse arrived to start CPR. Three other women also rushed to help. When the referee told them to leave, the women backed off, causing confusion and scuffling around the patient.\n\nIt appeared from the video that a man took over CPR before male emergency workers from the Fire Department arrived. Mr. Tatami was taken to a hospital for surgery, where he remains in stable condition.\n\nMost of the reaction on Twitter criticized the referee for calling the women out of the ring. \u201cThis seems to present the crazy image of Japanese values that old-fashioned Westerners fantasize about,\u201d one Twitter user wrote.\n\nBut some commenters defended the tradition, even if they acknowledged that the referee should have made an exception for the emergency. One such Twitter user fretted that \u201ccrazy feminists will take advantage of this.\u201d\n\nHistorians trace sumo\u2019s roots to harvest rituals associated with the Shinto religion. Various theories exist as to why women are barred from the ring. One theory suggests that sumo matches were originally put on to entertain the goddesses of the harvest, and farmers believed that women in the ring would invoke the jealousy and rage of the goddesses, who would spoil the harvest.\n\nCeremonies resembling sumo matches were performed in the Japanese Imperial courts as far back as the eighth century, and during the Edo period, which ran from the 17th to mid-19th century, organizers began charging admission to sumo bouts.", "title": "Women Barred From Sumo Ring, Even to Save a Man\u2019s Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "According to the lawsuit, the female correction officer ran her hands over Ms. Reynoso\u2019s breasts and genitalia, asked her to squat and violently inserted two fingers into her anus. She said she was menstruating at the time of the visit. \u201cThey didn\u2019t care,\u201d Ms. Reynoso said. \u201cThey wanted to see if drugs would fall out from my clothes.\u201d\n\nMs. Reynoso is one of seven women interviewed by The New York Times who have filed lawsuits or notices of claim against the city alleging illegal searches conducted in violation of city policy. A review of these lawsuits and more than two dozen other court cases filed by visitors point to a similar pattern: The visitors said they signed a waiver for a routine pat-down, but instead, they said, they were taken to search rooms or bathrooms for full strip searches, some involving invasive cavity checks. The prevalence of strip searches of visitors in the city\u2019s jails, as detailed in lawsuits, was first reported last year in a joint investigation by The Intercept and WNYC.\n\nThe search Ms. Reynoso described is prohibited in city jails. In state and federal prisons, strip searches of visitors are permitted with consent, but not cavity checks. In city jails, however, neither strip searches nor cavity checks of visitors are allowed, Department of Correction officials said.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no reason for it, no justification for a cavity search, period,\u201d said Martin Horn, who ran the city\u2019s correction department from 2003 to 2009 and is now a professor at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. \u201cI can\u2019t be anymore emphatic than that.\u201d\n\nYet allegations of inappropriate searches of visitors are common enough to have prompted separate investigations by the Bronx district attorney\u2019s office and the New York City Department of Investigation during the last two years. Neither resulted in criminal charges.", "title": "Women Describe Invasive Strip Searches on Visits to City Jails", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, tales of workplace and classroom harassment have continued to pile up in the jazz world since early last year. The young trombonist Kalia Vandever posted an article on Medium in March attesting to her own experiences as an undergraduate at Juilliard and offering some ideas about what ought to be done. Ms. Vandever said that despite being promoted as a poster child for the school, she was one of only two women in Juilliard\u2019s robust jazz program, and often felt stranded. Teachers frequently subjected both her body and her playing to special scrutiny, sometimes making explicitly sexual comments, she said.\n\n\u201cLooking back on my accounts of sexual harassment and misogyny, it\u2019s difficult not to wish I had spoken up in the moment or confronted my peers or teachers directly after the misconduct, but I didn\u2019t have the guidance, knowledge, nor confidence to say something at the time,\u201d she wrote. \u201cIt shouldn\u2019t be my responsibility \u2014 especially within the classroom \u2014 to say something.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s this lack of support that the collective is aiming to confront \u2014 both by offering counsel and mentorship, and by codifying expectations for institutions.\n\nWe Have Voice\u2019s efforts are not the only of their kind taking place in the jazz world. The Women in Jazz Organization, an advocacy group pushing for gender equity, was founded last year. And at schools like the Berklee College of Music, students and teachers have organized on behalf of survivors of sexual assault and harassment.\n\nLooking broadly at the music industry, it is widely seen as lagging behind even Hollywood on gender equality, and it has no labor body comparable to the Screen Actors Guild \u2014 which released its own sexual harassment code of conduct in February \u2014 to battle for artists\u2019 interests.\n\nIn jazz, power is not as centralized in the hands of corporations, which in turn employ pop producers and control entire creative supply chains. Rather, in the improvised-music business, the most important single entity is the musicians themselves. Beyond that, it is festivals and educational establishments.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe Have Voice hopes many more such institutions will align with its code of conduct.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not really doing this for the branding, or trying to be part of the one time that this happens in the mainstream,\u201d said Rajna Swaminathan, a collective member. \u201cWe\u2019re really trying to do the groundwork and hold institutions accountable.\u201d", "title": "Women Fighting Sexism in Jazz Have a Voice. And Now, a Code of Conduct.", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cA Wave of Young Women Running Campaigns (and Changing Politics)\u201d (news article, April 5):\n\nIt was exciting to read about the surge of young women managing political campaigns. For too long, campaign leadership has been dominated by men, and the trend toward increased gender diversity in these roles is a welcome one.\n\nAt the same time, by featuring only white women campaign managers, the article missed an opportunity to highlight the important \u2014 and too often overlooked \u2014 leadership of women of color in politics. This includes women like Zakiya Thomas, who managed Justin Fairfax\u2019s successful and groundbreaking campaign for lieutenant governor of Virginia.\n\nIt includes Linh Nguyen, who is managing Laura Moser\u2019s bid for Congress in Texas.\n\nYoung women of color considering a career in politics need to be able to see women like them in top campaign positions. While there are far too few women of color leading campaigns, and there is not enough investment in changing this reality, it\u2019s critical that media coverage include the women of color who are already blazing the trail.\n\nLIZET OCAMPO, WASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is the political director of People for the American Way.", "title": "Opinion | Women Running Campaigns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Not long after she joined Richard Meier\u2019s architecture firm in 1989, Karin Bruckner was working at the office one Sunday, she said, when Mr. Meier came up beside her at a copy machine and started rubbing his body up and down against hers.\n\n\u201cI just stood there and froze,\u201d Ms. Bruckner said. \u201c\u2018This is not happening\u2019 \u2014 that\u2019s the first thing you think about \u2014 \u2018He\u2019s not doing this right now, I\u2019m sure he\u2019s not doing this.\u2019\u201d\n\nShe later confided to John Eisler, a senior associate, about what had occurred, and Mr. Eisler was sympathetic.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not something that was a secret,\u201d he said in a recent interview about Mr. Meier\u2019s conduct. But Mr. Eisler, who spent 20 years at the firm, said he did not confront Mr. Meier after hearing from Ms. Bruckner.\n\n\u201cI am sorry,\u201d he said, \u201cthat I did not.\u201d\n\nAfter a report last month by The New York Times detailing a pattern of sexual misconduct by Mr. Meier, more women have come forward to share their own upsetting encounters with him. But in recounting such experiences, these women said they had also been disturbed by a sense of helplessness that pervaded the firm. Mr. Meier\u2019s behavior was common knowledge, they said, but no one seemed to have the power to stop it.\n\nOver the last six months, a number of fields have been forced to reckon with revelations regarding powerful men who harassed or assaulted underlings, some for many years, without being stopped by their companies or organizations.\n\nAt Richard Meier & Partners Architects, there was no one more powerful than Mr. Meier, a world-famous architect whose firm depended on him for its prestige and success. It was years before #MeToo; protesting harassment was far more perilous.\n\nMs. Bruckner said she did not fault Mr. Eisler for his silence.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think he felt he had any power to do anything about it,\u201d said Ms. Bruckner, who worked at the firm until 1992, when she left to work for the architect Philip Johnson. She said people in the office were too afraid of what would happen to the firm, and their jobs, should Mr. Meier\u2019s name be sullied.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s behavior that goes on for decades and never changes,\u201d she said. \u201c\u2018We don\u2019t go up against the bad guy because it will have a domino effect; if he falls down, everybody else falls down.\u2019\u201d\n\nFollowing the initial Times report, which involved five women, Mr. Meier, 83, said that \u201cwhile our recollections may differ, I sincerely apologize to anyone who was offended by my behavior.\u201d He said he would take a six-month leave from his firm.\n\nFour more women have since come forward to share their experiences concerning Mr. Meier: Ms. Bruckner; Eileen Delgado, a former office manager; Lucy Nathanson, Mr. Meier\u2019s former personal assistant; and Liz Lee, who worked as the communications coordinator.\n\nThrough a spokesman, Mr. Meier and his partners declined to be interviewed about the new accusations but issued this statement: \u201cThe allegations involving Richard Meier, the most recent of which were nearly a decade old, do not reflect the ethos and culture of the firm, and it would be irresponsible to allow these personal allegations to tarnish the company.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear to what extent executives at the firm, including Mr. Meier\u2019s partners, were aware of the sexual advances women are now publicly describing. Most of the women said they were too afraid for their jobs to lodge formal complaints with the management.\n\nBut some women did, and the firm appears to have reached at least two settlements. Ms. Delgado said she received about $25,000 in 1992 after Mr. Meier threw himself on top of her.\n\nAs reported earlier, Alexis Zamlich received $150,000 in 2009 after Mr. Meier had exposed himself to her, and another employee \u2014 Laura Trimble Elbogen \u2014 reported that Mr. Meier had asked her to undress, accounts that have been confirmed by the firm\u2019s former chief operating officer.\n\nAll three episodes were said to have occurred in Mr. Meier\u2019s Upper East Side apartment.\n\nThe firm has declined to discuss any settlements, but it said that after the two 2009 incidents, it instituted its first sexual harassment training program and updated its sexual harassment policy, which was put in the company handbook in 1993. No women have come forward to report negative experiences at the firm from after 2009.\n\nMs. Delgado, who worked as the office manager for several months in 1991 and 1992, said that Mr. Meier had asked her to work at his apartment, where he gave her a glass of wine and sat beside her on the sofa. \u201cAll of a sudden, I was thrust back and hit my head on a table,\u201d Ms. Delgado said. \u201cThis man was on top of me, his tongue was down my throat, and he put my hand on his penis.\u201d\n\nThe next day at the office, Ms. Delgado told the bookkeeper, Francina Foskey, who she said responded, \u201cOh, God, you, too?,\u201d and then proceeded to spin through a Rolodex, pointing to the names of women who had complained to her about Meier\u2019s sexual overtures. \u201cShe said, \u2018Her, her, her, her,\u2019 and as she\u2019s turning them, we\u2019re counting,\u201d Ms. Delgado said. (Ms. Foskey died in 1997.)\n\nMs. Delgado said she got up the courage to hire a lawyer and settled with the firm under a nondisclosure agreement. Mr. Meier\u2019s two other partners at the time were Robert Gatje and Thomas Phifer.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Gatje, interviewed a short time before his death, said that he wound up suing the firm himself but would not say for what because he was bound by a nondisclosure agreement. Asked about the allegations of sexual harassment, Mr. Gatje said: \u201cThat was 25 years ago. Things were a lot different back then.\u201d\n\nMr. Phifer said that he never received a complaint of sexual harassment but that he had his own problems with Mr. Meier.\n\n\u201cWhat did happen is an enormous amount of verbal abuse, which I encountered myself, as did the rest of the office,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s the reason I left.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIndeed, the conduct employees objected to extended beyond sexual advances. Former workers said that Mr. Meier \u2014 a winner of the Pritzker Prize, architecture\u2019s top award, and the designer of notable buildings like the Getty Center in Los Angeles \u2014 ruled like a despot. They said he was loath to bring on partners, publicly berated even senior employees, and moved through the office as a brooding, bullying presence who inspired fear and deference.\n\nAdam Eli Clem, who worked as an assistant archivist from 1994 to 1996, said Mr. Meier\u2019s \u201ctoxic\u201d behavior prompted \u201ca kind of underground in the office that functioned to warn people about what they could expect.\u201d\n\nThis was particularly true for women, who knew to wait for one another at the end of the day to avoid leaving a female colleague alone with Mr. Meier. Despite such efforts, some women said they were nevertheless asked by Mr. Meier to work at his apartment.\n\nOne was Ms. Nathanson, Mr. Meier\u2019s personal assistant in 1995, who said he put his hands on her shoulders while showing her a book of vintage erotica.\n\n\u201cI felt trapped in my chair,\u201d she said. \u201cI felt my heart beating faster and faster and faster. I closed the book and pushed it away. I continued to work, but it was difficult to work.\u201d\n\nWhen she got her coat to leave, \u201che came up behind me, put his hands over my head on the wall and pressed his body into me with an erection,\u201d Ms. Nathanson said. \u201cThe elevator came, I got in and left. I collapsed in the lobby in a chair and started to cry.\u201d\n\nDespite what appeared to her to be a general knowledge at the firm about Mr. Meier\u2019s advances, Ms. Nathanson said, nothing changed.\n\n\u201cPeople would hold you in your arms and weep with you, but they wouldn\u2019t talk to the boss,\u201d she said. \u201cThey did not want to lose their jobs.\u201d\n\nJust three weeks later, Ms. Nathanson said, she lost her own job, in what Mr. Meier described to her as a \u201crestructuring.\u201d\n\nOne former partner, Gunter R. Standke, who worked there for 12 years until the early 1990s, said he had been aware that Mr. Meier was attracted to young women and that Mr. Meier would sometimes approach them at their desks in the evening and ask them to leave with him. But Mr. Standke said that none of the women had ever complained to him and that he was too busy to investigate what might be happening after hours.\n\n\u201cI had all the European projects,\u201d he said. \u201cI had no time to watch what Mr. Meier was doing.\u201d\n\nThe firm, in its statement, said its renown stemmed not only from \u201cbrilliant architectural design and execution\u201d but also \u201can environment that respects a diverse, motivated staff.\u201d It said that the average tenure of its employees \u2014 nearly 50 percent of whom are women \u2014 is 13 years, \u201ca testament to the positive workplace.\u201d\n\nWhile most of the women interviewed said they did not tell company officials what had happened to them, they did tell co-workers.\n\nLiz Lee, who worked as the communications coordinator from 2002 to 2004, said she was once called to Mr. Meier\u2019s apartment, ostensibly to inventory his art collection.\n\nWhen she walked in the door, Ms. Lee said, Mr. Meier was naked. \u201cI did not feel like I could just leave,\u201d she said. He later put his hand on her buttocks, she said, while showing her his collages.\n\nWhen Ms. Lee told colleagues, she said, they were not surprised. \u201cThey said, \u2018Richard is an abusive person,\u2019\u201d she said, \u201c\u2018but he\u2019s the boss.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Bruckner said that she, too, told other women at the firm about what had happened to her at the copy machine.\n\n\u201cIt turned out that everybody had a story,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cThey all said, \u2018Management doesn\u2019t want to hear about it, and the best thing is to just move on.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Women Say Richard Meier\u2019s Conduct Was Widely Known Yet Went Unchecked", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin"]} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "1. the faculty of contriving, inventive skill\n\n2. the act of devising something\n\n3. a device or control that is very useful for a particular job\n\n4. any improvised arrangement for temporary use\n\n5. an artificial or unnatural or obviously contrived arrangement of details or parts\n\n6. an elaborate or deceitful scheme intended to deceive or evade", "title": "Word + Quiz: contrivance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word vagabond has appeared in 25 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 19 in \u201cTo Get to the Blackhawks\u2019 Net, Jeff Glass Took the Long Way\u201d by Jeff Arnold:\n\nCHICAGO \u2014 For Jeff Glass, there have been so many stops during his existence as a hockey vagabond, so many different jerseys that he has worn, so many teams he has tended goal for from Binghamton to Belarus and plenty of other outposts in between, and so many moments when it would have been easy for him to quit.\n\nThere was the 38-game stretch in Siberia \u2014 where, to the best of Glass\u2019s recollection, snow fell for 45 straight days. He played for the Kontinental Hockey League\u2019s Sibir Novosibirsk then, and he found himself so far in the middle of nowhere that, as he put it, \u201call there was was hockey.\u201d\n\nNow, after 13 years of wandering, Glass realizes that each step played a meaningful role in his finding his way to his N.H.L. debut last month as a 32-year-old rookie with the Chicago Blackhawks.", "title": "Word + Quiz: vagabond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word accoutrement has appeared in three articles on nytimes.com in the past four years, including on Nov. 3, 2014 in \u201c\u2018Gotham\u2019 Recap: All Hail the Penguin\u201d by Jeremy Egner:\n\nAll of which is to say, the title of this week\u2019s episode, \u201cPenguin\u2019s Umbrella,\u201d was a welcome sign. It offered promise that was mostly fulfilled on Monday, as the series finally embraced its strengths and turned in what was, by a fairly wide margin, the best episode of its run.\n\nThe umbrella of the title refers, of course, to the Penguin\u2019s signature prop, which we see him carrying in the opening scene while flanked by two new flunkies, signaling his continuing evolution toward his supervillain destiny.\n\nBut the accoutrement also functions as a handy metaphor for both the Penguin\u2019s unparalleled ability to shield himself from trouble and the broad shadow the little man is casting across Gotham City. Everything in Monday\u2019s episode sprang from his actions, from Gordon running for his life (more on that in a minute) to the end of Nikolai the would-be Falcone usurper to the dispatching of Frankie Carbone, the Penguin\u2019s lone rival within the Maroni organization.", "title": "Word + Quiz: accoutrement", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word agonistic has appeared in one article on nytimes.com in the past year, on March 22 in the T magazine article \u201cDoes Having a Day Job Mean Making Better Art?\u201d by Katy Waldman:\n\nThe act of producing art can be anything but romantic. To escape the blank page, the only thing on earth as passive as yourself, you cast about for distractions, half-convinced that avoiding your project will shower some sort of mystical growth hormone on your ideas. Yet for some artists, such as William Carlos Williams, life and art were more than each other\u2019s palate cleansers. The poet doctor saw his dual vocations as mysteriously fused. \u201cThey are two parts of a whole,\u201d he contended in his 1967 autobiography. \u201cIt is not two jobs at all \u2026 one rests the man when the other fatigues him.\u201d As a physician, Williams developed an antenna for the \u201cinarticulate poems\u201d emanating from his patients, even as he resolved to \u201cuse the material I knew\u201d from practicing medicine in his writing.\n\nWhat, then, is the real relationship between art and trade? Agonistic? Complementary? The question, suggesting something like a creative sanctum shimmering a few meters above the room in which you punch a clock or schedule a meeting, supposes that aesthetic experience is categorically different from everyday experience, and that muse-fueled invention floats apart from earthier forms of productivity.", "title": "Word + Quiz: agonistic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "antediluvian \\ \u02ccan-ti-d\u0259-\u02c8l\u00fc-v\u0113-\u0259n , -(\u02cc)d\u012b- \\ adjective and noun\n\nadjective: of or relating to the period before the biblical flood adjective: so extremely old as seeming to belong to an earlier period noun: any of the early patriarchs who lived prior to the Noachian deluge noun: a very old person\n\n_________\n\nThe word antediluvian has appeared in 12 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 1 in the book review \u201cCreating a Lost World, From the Fossils Out\u201d by Rachel Poser:\n\nIn the summer of 1854, Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins created the world\u2019s first sculptures of dinosaurs for an exhibition at London\u2019s Crystal Palace Park. On opening day, 40,000 people came to see Hawkins\u2019s prehistoric menagerie \u2014 33 concrete beasts arranged on grassy islands in the lake. There they were, those \u201cterrible lizards\u201d so familiar to us today but almost entirely unknown to Hawkins\u2019s contemporaries. Children reportedly screamed and fainted at the sight. One newspaperman described the megalosaurus, the greatest of the \u201cantediluvian monsters,\u201d as a scaly dragon with the \u201chead of a gryphon\u201d and an \u201ceye as big as a cheese-cake.\u201d \u201cThese are the creatures,\u201d he wrote, \u201cthat prove fairy tales to be more veracious than ancient history.\u201d\n\nThink you know \u201cantediluvian\u201d? In the spring of 1969, Sacks began to treat them with a drug called L-dopa. The patients, miraculously, \u201cawoke\u201d from their locked-in states. Some walked the corridors; some began to speak, recounting stories of lives that had been deep-frozen in a neurological tundra. It was a coming-to-life moment that Sacks described in the book\u2019s prologue as \u201cthe most significant and extraordinary in my life.\u201d He was \u201ccaught up with the emotion, the excitement, and with something akin to enchantment, even awe.\u201d\n\nBut missing from the prologue is another story. The awakening was temporary. One by one, the responses foundered and died: Nearly all the patients became resistant and returned to their catatonic states. For me as a young clinical scientist, it was not the awakening but its opposite \u2014 the deadening \u2014 that remained as the lasting impression of the book.", "title": "Word + Quiz: catatonic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word chagrin has appeared in 85 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 6 in \u201cMetroCard Machines Won\u2019t Accept Credit Cards This Weekend (Briefly)\u201d by Sarah Maslin Nir:\n\nThe Metropolitan Transportation Authority delivered the news in a presidential manner \u2014 220 characters posted on Twitter last Wednesday night announcing that its MetroCard machines would not accept credit cards from about midnight on Friday through 5 a.m. on Monday while the computer system that runs the machines was upgraded.\n\n... In a rare instance of a government agency expressing chagrin, the advisory this time was sent widely to the news media, through email, with the heading: \u201cOvernight Weekend Timing Designed to Minimize Customer Inconvenience.\u201d\n\n\u201cAfter hearing clearly from our customers that they needed more information regarding this upgrade, we reassessed the entire process,\u201d said Veronique Hakim, the M.T.A.\u2019s managing director. \u201cWe are aggressively communicating with customers about this upgrade to ensure that we avoid confusion, and limiting the disruption to only the very early morning hours Saturday.\u201d", "title": "Word + Quiz: chagrin", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "consummate \\ \u02c8k\u00e4n(t)-s\u0259-m\u0259t , k\u0259n-\u02c8s\u0259-m\u0259t \\ adjective and verb\n\nadjective: having or revealing supreme mastery or skill adjective: perfect and complete in every respect; having all necessary qualities adjective: without qualification; used informally as (often pejorative) intensifiers verb: make perfect; bring to perfection verb: fulfill sexually\n\n_________\n\nThe word consummate has appeared in 112 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on April 10 in \u201cStanley Brezenoff, New York\u2019s 80-Year-Old Fixer, Steps In Again\u201d by William Neuman and J. David Goodman:\n\nHe was hired as commissioner of the Department of Employment by Mayor Ed Koch in 1978. He eventually became Mr. Koch\u2019s deputy mayor for operations and then his first deputy mayor, from 1985 through 1989. He was also the head of the city\u2019s Health and Hospitals Corporation and executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Along the way, he gained a reputation as the consummate, competent government operator, a skilled manager who could be relied on by mayors and governors to clean up a mess or right a foundering ship.\n\nThink you know \u201cconsummate\u201d? But with the ball in play against Butler, Ewing did not dramatically stamp his feet or pompously pump his fists like many of his more demonstrative peers.\n\n\u201cI do celebrate or get angry, but I try not to overly do it,\u201d he said the day after the Butler game. \u201cI don\u2019t want to embarrass anyone or embarrass myself.\u201d", "title": "Word + Quiz: demonstrative", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "_________\n\nThe word dilatory has appeared in two articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on April 6 in the Opinion essay \u201cPolluters on the High Seas\u201d by Hilda Heine and Christiana Figueres:\n\nInternational shipping is the backbone of our global trading system. But it can no longer be given a free pass on climate change. If this industrial sector were a country, it would be the sixth-largest emitter of greenhouse gases in the world \u2014 and if it doesn\u2019t act now to reduce those emissions, by 2050 they could surpass total anticipated European emissions.\n\nThe International Maritime Organization, which sets regulatory standards for international shipping, is set to meet in London next week to consider approaches to reducing these emissions. So far, progress by the I.M.O. has been agonizingly slow, and the group\u2019s timetable \u2014 to develop an \u201cinitial strategy\u201d next week and a plan by 2023 \u2014 is similarly dilatory.", "title": "Word + Quiz: dilatory", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "ecclesiastic \\ i-\u02cckl\u0113-z\u0113-\u02c8a-stik , e-\u02cckl\u0113- \\ adjective and noun\n\nadjective: of or associated with a church (especially a Christian church) noun: a member of the clergy or other person in religious orders\n\n_________\n\nThe word ecclesiastic has appeared in one article on nytimes.com in the past year, on Dec. 22, 2017 in \u201cIn Brooklyn, a Hare Krishna Reckoning\u201d by Kaya Laterman:\n\nThe Krishnas are not the only religious order facing hard real estate decisions in New York. Many organizations, including several Catholic churches, have become key players in high-power real estate transactions. Facing dwindling attendance, churches, temples and synagogues have sold their properties to start fresh elsewhere, combine parishes or even sell their properties\u2019 air rights to developers. ... The temple\u2019s president, David Britten (Ramabhadra Das), and his board twice asked the Hare Krishna Society\u2019s ecclesiastic directors, known as the Governing Body Commission, for permission to \u201cmove the deities,\u201d which implied a property sale \u2014 once in 1998 and again 2008. Mr. Britten and his board were given approval both times, said Seth Spellman (Sesa Das), a commission member and the head of a group tasked with halting the current sale. But a lack of interest from buyers, and then the financial crisis, held back possible deals.\n\nThink you know \u201cecclesiastic\u201d? In the American Heritage Dictionary, Fourth Edition, Unabridged (meaning \u201cbigger than Collegiate\u201d), this word that dates to the 14th century is defined as currently \u201can evildoer; a villain\u201d and the earlier meaning \u201can infidel; a heretic,\u201d rooted in the French mescroire, \u201cto disbelieve.\u201d But in Roget\u2019s II: The New Thesaurus, Third Edition, we get a definition of \u201cutterly reprehensible in nature or behavior\u201d and a fearsome farrago of synonyms as adjectives: \u201ccorrupt, degenerate, depraved, flagitious, perverse, rotten, unhealthy, villainous. Holson:\n\nScout Raskin owns three dogs, a cat, turtles and a pair of hermit crabs. But medically informed repose \u2014 experienced far and away from the world, quietly and alongside others as sick (or not) as oneself \u2014 can still be had. In Vals, Switzerland, not 70 miles from Davos (once studded with about 40 sanatoriums), thermal waters run through the valley\u2019s granite walls. A beautiful if deliberately sterile-feeling spa hotel sits just above the small village and beckons visitors from all over the world, who come to bathe in silence and eat overpriced pear bread while gazing at verdant pastures. Those seeking wellness today do not want outdoor concerts or lectures or chitchat. They want to be by themselves, ideally in a photogenic location with poor cellphone service.\n\n_________\n\nThink you know \u201crepose\u201d? A barrier like the four-minute mile, we\u2019re told, is impregnable \u2014 until someone like Roger Bannister shows, as he did in 1954, that it can be breached, and then everyone else follows. Kimetto\u2019s world record, having been bested by such a large (though unofficial) margin, has lost much of its mental force. So will it, as the bookies seem to anticipate, be swept aside with ease?\n\nTo me, the bout in Berlin seems like not just a clash of three heavyweights but a real-life test of the \u201cmental barriers\u201d theory of human endeavor. Faith in the primacy of mind over body is a trope as eagerly embraced in board rooms as in locker rooms and Nike commercials \u2014 and it\u2019s a message we\u2019ve lapped up, without much evidence, for centuries.", "title": "Word + Quiz: surmount", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "vex \\ \u02c8veks \\ verb\n\n1. cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations 2. disturb the peace of mind of; afflict with mental agitation or distress 3. be a mystery or bewildering to 4. subject to prolonged examination, discussion or deliberation 5. change the arrangement or position of\n\n_________\n\nThe word vex has appeared in 12 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 12 in the American Beauties column \u201cRiding Shotgun on Martha Gellhorn\u2019s Brave and Comic Adventures\u201d by Dwight Garner:\n\nIn 1978, when she was 70, Gellhorn set down the best disaster stories from her lifelong peregrinations in \u201cTravels With Myself and Another,\u201d a book that\u2019s as close as she came to writing a memoir. It\u2019s a brave and oddly merry volume. She lived the way certain tennis players compete: She rushed the net after every serve. ... She was tough and brash yet delicate in her way. She sunburned easily. She hated to be dirty. Her stomach was easily upset. These contradictions make her excellent company on the page. She writes about politics and culture and war while never losing sight of the daily indignities that vex all travelers.\n\nThink you know \u201cvex\u201d? She was still in law school at the time, and was serving on the legal team, while he was a manager for government sales and business development. Though they worked about 20 feet apart, they knew each other mostly as names on email distribution lists.\n\nBut in the fall of 2014, she was in Paris on vacation and bumped into some of her SpaceX colleagues. They invited her to join their events, and, at one, she and Mr. Brost struck up a conversation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
