In Washington. And he did get his watch back. (He\u2019s wearing it in the photograph.)", "title": "Work Colleagues, Friends, Then Something More", "authors": ["Nina Reyes"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "But tech is different. Unlike factories or airlines, tech companies live and die on their ability to attract and retain top talent. A shortage of skilled workers has led to lucrative bidding wars, tipping the balance of power in workers\u2019 favor. Because many of them are attracted to altruistic missions \u2014 and unhappy or morally conflicted workers can easily find other jobs \u2014 executives are compelled to listen to them.\n\n\u201cTech workers are the only point of leverage on these big companies,\u201d said Maciej Ceg\u0142owski, the founder of the social bookmarking service Pinboard.\n\nMr. Ceg\u0142owski, who has started an advocacy organization called Tech Solidarity, said that the typical instruments used to rein in corporate misbehavior \u2014 customer boycotts, shareholder activism and outside regulation \u2014 aren\u2019t likely to work on the largest Silicon Valley companies.\n\nInstead, change at these companies will need to come from the inside.\n\n\u201cEven a couple hundred employees working in concert could bring a site like Google to its knees,\u201d Mr. Ceg\u0142owski said.\n\nSome tech workers are already starting to flex their muscles. Employees from large tech companies led an effort to oppose the travel ban announced by President Trump last year. And employees of Facebook, Google, Intel, Cisco and Stripe attended a demonstration at the headquarters of Palantir to protest the company\u2019s development of surveillance technology for federal immigration enforcers. Just this month, more than 3,000 Google employees signed a letter objecting to the company\u2019s involvement in a Pentagon program that could use artificial intelligence to improve the accuracy of drone strikes.\n\nBut these are just warm-up skirmishes. For maximum impact, tech workers will need to scrutinize not just their employers\u2019 government ties, but their products, business models, and basic standards. And they\u2019ll need to do it in public.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRecall what happened at Uber. Women inside the company complained for years about the problematic behavior of Travis Kalanick and other company leaders. But it wasn\u2019t until Susan Fowler, a former Uber engineer, published her story of sexual harassment that things changed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout Ms. Fowler\u2019s brave disclosure \u2014 and her colleagues\u2019 willingness to back her up after she went public \u2014 it\u2019s entirely possible that Mr. Kalanick would still be Uber\u2019s chief executive and the company would still be run by boorish bros.\n\nTypically, when workers speak out or organize, it\u2019s because they want higher wages, better working conditions or stronger job security. Those aren\u2019t your problems. You probably work manageable hours in tastefully decorated buildings with free food, ergonomic desk furniture and plentiful amenities. Your compensation is generous. And you\u2019re in little danger of being fired or retaliated against, especially if you\u2019re part of a large group.\n\nThe possibilities for you are so much greater. What if Facebook employees publicly took their executives to task for neglecting the real-world violence their products are causing in places like Myanmar and Sri Lanka? What if Google or Twitter employees threatened to walk unless their executives took major action against radical extremists and hate speech? What if Apple employees insisted that the company stop parking billions of dollars in offshore tax shelters, or Amazon engineers threatened to quit unless the company paid its warehouse workers higher wages?\n\nAnd that\u2019s before we even get to the thorny ethical debates surrounding technologies like artificial intelligence, in which companies\u2019 goals \u2014 amass huge amounts of data to help train increasingly sophisticated machine learning models \u2014 may be at odds with what\u2019s good for society.\n\nThere are few signs that Washington is capable of policing the use of emerging technologies. And while companies like Google have formed their own A.I. ethics groups, those groups are ultimately powerless if executives decide to ignore their advice.\n\nThat leaves an opening for you.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not clear where the pressure\u2019s going to come from otherwise,\u201d said Leslie Berlin, a Stanford historian who has studied Silicon Valley\u2019s labor culture.\n\nSome tech workers are already making noise about unionizing, and service workers at several tech companies have already joined unions. But even if traditional labor unions don\u2019t take hold in Silicon Valley, there are still plenty of avenues for influence. The Tech Workers Coalition, a group of hundreds of concerned industry employees, has chapters in San Francisco, Seattle and San Jose, and a group called Tech Action began meeting in New York last year. The Center for Humane Technology, a group of ex-tech workers, has been pushing for ethical product development.\n\nThese groups are still small, and none has produced concrete results yet. But they are early signs that greater political consciousness is stirring in the industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a tech-dominated world, when the decisions made by a handful of Silicon Valley executives have the ability to reshape nations and transform billions of lives, there\u2019s no better time to stand up. Together, you can encourage your employers to behave in ethical and humane ways, and blow the whistle publicly when they fall short.\n\nOrganizing yourselves to push for change isn\u2019t just a viable option \u2014 it might be the only way out of this mess.\n\nGodspeed,\n\nKevin", "title": "Workers of Silicon Valley, It\u2019s Time to Organize", "authors": ["Kevin Roose", "The Shift"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "But as the party prepared to endorse Ms. Nixon, two powerful and prominent labor groups, with the governor\u2019s blessing, pulled their support from the W.F.P. \u2014 a blow to the finances of the party, which has a $1.7 million yearly budget and a statewide staff of about 15 people.\n\nThe party still has some labor groups in its corner. But the unions that withdrew last Friday \u2014 Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, and Communications Workers of America District 1 \u2014 count more than 150,000 members in New York. The state\u2019s biggest union, 1199 S.E.I.U., which represents health care workers, has also endorsed Mr. Cuomo, as have other major unions like the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union.\n\nAnd several other union leaders, including some that had supported Mr. Lipton\u2019s group in the past, were already speaking of the W.F.P. in the past tense, and speaking ill of its current leaders.\n\n\u201cThe W.F.P. was a good concept,\u201d said Mike McGuire, a construction union official and former treasurer of the W.F.P., adding that Mr. Lipton and others had turned it into \u201can irrelevant, impotent, money-hungry engine for their own personal agenda.\u201d\n\nMr. Lipton said that although the departure of the governor\u2019s labor allies had cost his party \u201cmillions in funding,\u201d both now and in the future, the W.F.P. still had ample power to promote Ms. Nixon\u2019s message through volunteering, canvassing, phone banking and social media. The party had already been using such methods in recent efforts to expel former members of the Independent Democratic Conference, a recently dissolved group of Democrats who cooperated with Republicans, from the State Senate.\n\n\u201cWe just had a dress rehearsal for this,\u201d said Mr. Lipton, noting 120,000 anti-I.D.C. phone calls and a half-million anti-I.D.C. text messages sent this winter. \u201cAnd we think this is going to be much bigger.\u201d\n\nThere are early indications that the alliance with the W.F.P., and a range of community groups whose funding were also threatened by Mr. Cuomo\u2019s labor allies, may offer Ms. Nixon a bevy of surrogates with which to attack the governor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Wednesday, for example, Ms. Nixon\u2019s campaign distributed a statement from Make the Road Action, a progressive community-action group that focuses on immigrant issues. The statement accused Mr. Cuomo of a \u201crecent pattern of falsehoods and exaggerations about his life story,\u201d citing the governor\u2019s suggestion that he was the son of \u201cpoor immigrants\u201d \u2014 his father, Mario M. Cuomo, was a lawyer and three-term governor \u2014 and the fact that he was \u201ca middle-class guy,\u201d something belied by his $173,000 salary, hefty investment portfolio and a lucrative book deal for his memoir. On Thursday, the Nixon campaign debuted an email attack on Mr. Cuomo\u2019s credibility, calling out his \u201clie of the day.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a reason Andrew Cuomo and Cynthia Nixon both fought so hard for the endorsement of the Working Families Party,\u201d Rebecca Katz, an adviser for Ms. Nixon\u2019s campaign, said. \u201cTheir ballot line sends a clear signal to voters about which candidate is the most committed progressive.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs Ms. Katz tells it, the W.F.P. endorsement could also help offset Mr. Cuomo\u2019s profound financial advantage \u2014 his campaign coffers contain some $30 million \u2014 particularly by appealing to small donors, who have been almost completely ignored by the governor\u2019s past fund-raising.\n\nThe two unions were not the only entities to pull out of the W.F.P.; the night before Ms. Nixon won the endorsement, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s campaign \u2014 sensing the party\u2019s inclination toward his opponent \u2014 announced that it would not seek the endorsement after all.\n\nAbbey Fashouer, a spokeswoman for the Cuomo campaign, underscored what she characterized as his \u201cunmatched progressive record,\u201d citing his work on securing a $15 minimum wage, marriage equality, gun-safety laws, a free college tuition program and paid family leave.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAfter nearly a decade of discord, we have a united Democratic Party and the governor is focused on maintaining that unity to win the State Senate, take back the House and fight Trump in Washington,\u201d she said.\n\nSupporters of Ms. Nixon say the W.F.P. is more aligned with the anti-President Trump sentiment that is expected to send waves of Democratic voters to the polls to punish Republicans \u2014 and maybe some moderate Democrats. \u201cWe\u2019re going to electoralize the resistance,\u201d Mr. Lipton said.\n\nThis argument is backed by a recent Marist College poll showing that Ms. Nixon does best among \u201chighly enthusiastic\u201d voters, the type that typically would find their way to polling stations for a September primary. Still, Mr. Cuomo has hefty leads in every public poll thus far.\n\nIn the 2014 Democratic primary, an underfunded candidate, Zephyr Teachout, mounted a surprisingly vigorous bid to unseat Mr. Cuomo, pulling in 34 percent of the vote.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lipton pointed out that the W.F.P. \u2014 which counts about 46,000 registered voters \u2014 has drawn at least that many people to the party\u2019s line in recent elections, including in 2016, when Senator Chuck Schumer won 241,672 votes on the party\u2019s line. All told, less than 600,000 Democrats voted in the 2014 primary, about 10 percent of all those registered.\n\nBut several political analysts warned that the unions\u2019 traditional muscle in turning out voters should not be underestimated.\n\nKenneth Sherrill, an emeritus professor of political science at the City University of New York Graduate Center, said the two unions that withdrew from the W.F.P., CWA and 32BJ, were \u201cpowerhouses\u201d that could make a difference in September.\n\n\u201cThe most powerful labor unions are able to deliver votes,\u201d Professor Sherrill said. \u201cAnd this clout is undoubtedly more powerful in the primaries than in the general election.\u201d\n\nH\u00e9ctor J. Figueroa, the president of Local 32BJ, said that his members were strongly behind Mr. Cuomo \u2014 citing accomplishments like a hike in the minimum wage and a paid family-leave program \u2014 and could bring as many as a quarter-million voters, including union members\u2019 families and friends, to bear on the race. \u201cWe intend to do what we do with every election,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have a very robust program.\u201d\n\nIt remains to be seen if Mr. Cuomo\u2019s more traditional campaign efforts \u2014 ratcheting up labor backing, doling out support for liberal causes and staging governmental events seemingly designed to promote the governor \u2014 can be offset by Ms. Nixon\u2019s social media popularity and of-the-people campaign style. A video of Ms. Nixon declaring her support for legalizing marijuana has been viewed 3.7 million times. A subsequent Twitter post about the issue garnered more than 180,000 likes.\n\nCharles Tien, a professor of political science at Hunter College, said the schism in the W.F.P. showed less an ideological difference between unions and progressive activists \u2014 \u201cideological soul mates\u201d \u2014 than differing opinions on how those ideals had or had not been fulfilled.\n\nThe answer, Professor Tien said, would determine which group could drive higher turnout.\n\n\u201cTheir candidate is the status quo candidate,\u201d he said of the unions\u2019 support for Mr. Cuomo. \u201cAre people feeling that the status quo isn\u2019t working? If yes, I think that\u2019s where you have the potential for a challenger to be successful.\u201d", "title": "Working Families\u2019 Nod to Nixon Ends a Battle, but the War Awaits", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "MONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 When we last saw Jason Mueller, he was busy spilling the beans on the real identity of a famous person, and today he takes us on a tour of a city that he says he\u2019s never even visited.\n\nStay with the group, please. This could get messy.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMr. Mueller hits some of the big spots in the world capital of PARIS, FRANCE. The theme is built on cross-referenced clues, which means that solvers will need to know the answer to 62A, because that\u2019s how the theme clues are worded (\u201c62-Across landmark\u201d for EIFFEL TOWER, for example).\n\nFortunately, the crossings around 62A are kind, so most should suss out the \u201cWorld capital\u201d revealer quickly.\n\nOne thing I really liked about this was the extra French flavor in the clues outside the theme, like \u201cD\u00f4me DES Invalides (historic church)\u201d and \u201cSt. Genevieve, for 62-Across,\u201d or PATRON saint of Paris in the Roman Catholic Church.", "title": "World Capital", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe difference was Ronaldo\u2019s composition,\u201d she said. \u201cIn the other series you had a narrative but you didn\u2019t have as strong a single frame.\u201d\n\nMr. Schemidt noted that the judges make the decisions, not he, adding that \u201cthe work of my colleague Juan is excellent and he certainly is also deserving to be in first place.\u201d When he took the photos he just saw it as \u201cone more journey in all the work I did in Venezuela,\u201d if anything.\n\n\u201cI work the same way anywhere in the world that I have to work but this is my country and I am shocked what Venezuela has become,\u201d he said. \u201cI have family and friends still in Venezuela struggling with the effects of the crisis.\u201d\n\nJos\u00e9 V\u00edctor Salazar Balza, the subject of Mr. Schemidt\u2019s winning image, recovered from 1st and 2nd degree burns.", "title": "World Press Photo of the Year: A Tale Told Twice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The study doesn\u2019t explain why greater graduation requirements might reduce risky behavior, but the authors offer two hypotheses. First, greater demands at school take more time: longer hours doing homework and studying. Students who spend more time on schoolwork have less time to do other things. (They could also be reducing sleep or exercise, however.)\n\nSecond, a number of other studies have shown that increased high school math graduation requirements have been linked to higher future earnings. This increases the potential loss to students who jeopardize those future earnings through risky behavior. (This second theory requires teenagers to be forward-looking, something parents of teenagers might find implausible.)\n\nRates of alcohol, drug, and tobacco use among teenagers are high enough to provoke concern among their parents. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, about one-third of high schoolers consumed alcohol in the last month, and 18 percent had five or more drinks when they did so. One in five had used marijuana in the past month, and more than 5 percent had used cocaine or hallucinogenic drugs. Just over 10 percent of high schoolers smoke cigarettes.\n\nNevertheless, by some measures, teenagers are engaging in less risky behavior than they used to. Their rates of alcohol and cigarette use have trended downward since the early 1990s, though use of other drugs is up.\n\nReducing risky behavior early in life is important because habits established in youth often persist into adulthood. Deterring those behaviors early has long-term benefits. A clever body of work takes advantage of school choice lotteries, in which families who win the lottery can place their children in their preferred \u2014 typically higher-quality \u2014 school. For example, one study of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg, N.C., school district found that lottery-winning middle school and high school enrollees entered higher-quality schools and committed less crime seven years later.\n\nThere are other ways the education system can help children be and stay healthy. There are many evidence-based programs that schools can use to directly address the factors that drive or deter substance use. One study found that higher teacher wages are associated with lower mortality. A study of Southern states found that decreasing student-teacher ratios, increasing teachers\u2019 wages, and lengthening the school year are all associated with better future health of students, including reduced smoking, obesity and mortality.\n\nThere is variation in results of studies like these. Not all find a connection between education and health or behavioral outcomes. It\u2019s also reasonable to be concerned that when connections are found, correlations are not causation.", "title": "Worried About Risky Teenage Behavior? Make School Tougher", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "In the first three years of the expanded program, revenue growth for Maryland\u2019s hospitals stayed below the state-set cap of 3.58 percent, saving Medicare $586 million. Spending was lower on hospital outpatient services, including visits to the emergency department that do not lead to hospital admissions. In addition, preventable health conditions and mortality fell.\n\nAccording to a new report from RTI, a nonprofit research organization, Maryland\u2019s program did not reap savings for the privately insured population (even though inpatient admissions fell for that group). However, the study corroborated the impressive Medicare savings, driven by a drop in hospital admissions. In reaching these findings, the study compared Maryland\u2019s hospitals with analogous ones in other states, which served as stand-ins for what would have happened to Maryland hospitals had global budgeting not been introduced.\n\nBut a recent study, published in JAMA Internal Medicine, was decidedly less encouraging.\n\nLed by Eric Roberts, a health economist with the University of Pittsburgh, the study examined how Maryland achieved its Medicare savings, using data from 2009-2015. Like RTI\u2019s report, it also compared Maryland hospitals\u2019 experience with that of comparable hospitals elsewhere.\n\nHowever, unlike the RTI report, Mr. Roberts\u2019s study did not find consistent evidence that changes in hospital use in Maryland could be attributed to global budgeting. His study also examined primary care use. Here, too, it did not find consistent evidence that Maryland differed from elsewhere. Because of the challenges of matching Maryland hospitals to others outside of the state for comparison, the authors took several statistical approaches in reaching their findings. With some approaches, the changes observed in Maryland were comparable to those in other states, raising uncertainty about their cause.\n\nA separate study by the same authors published in Health Affairs analyzed the earlier global budget program for Maryland\u2019s rural hospitals. They were able to use other Maryland hospitals as controls. Still, after three years, they did not find an impact of the program on hospital use or spending.\n\nChanges brought about by the Affordable Care Act, which also passed in 2010, coincide with Maryland\u2019s hospital payment reforms. The A.C.A. included many provisions aimed at reducing spending, and those changes could have led to hospital use and spending in other states on par with those seen in Maryland.\n\nA limitation of Maryland\u2019s approach is that payments to physicians are not included in its global budgets. \u201cMaryland didn\u2019t put the state\u2019s health system on a budget \u2014 it only put hospitals on a budget,\u201d said Ateev Mehrotra, the study\u2019s senior author and an associate professor of health care policy and medicine at Harvard Medical School. \u201cSlowing health care spending and fostering better coordination requires including physicians who make the day-to-day decisions about how care is delivered.\u201d", "title": "Would Americans Accept Putting Health Care on a Budget?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cI search for patterns/sense that isn\u2019t there,\u201d Jenn Wasner sings in the irresistible title song of Wye Oak\u2019s new album, \u201cThe Louder I Call, the Faster It Runs.\u201d The latest songs she has written with Andy Stack, the group\u2019s other member, are brimming with patterns: synthesizer lines that loop and pulse, circling guitar runs, brisk programmed drumbeats. The patterns interlock and stack up to grow dense and bustling, confident and luminous \u2014 the sound of a band simultaneously delving deeper into its music and opening it up.\n\nYet at the same time, the album title suggests how art defies intention. And all of the music\u2019s patterned, orderly activity \u2014 all that control \u2014 doesn\u2019t resolve the tangled inquiries that have filled Wye Oak\u2019s songs since its debut album, \u201cIf Children,\u201d in 2007.\n\nAs its musical vocabulary has steadily expanded, Wye Oak has long pondered how the personal turns metaphysical. Its songs grapple with questions of higher purpose, of personal and philosophical trust, of fate and self-determination, of belief and responsibility, and of connection and solitude. They can be cryptic, but the songs measure themselves against everyday experience.\n\nOn the new album, a bumpy flight home is the starting point of \u201cSay Hello.\u201d It places a stately melody above a nervously undulating mass of buzzing guitar tones and drumming that goes against the beat, while Ms. Wasner reflects on the inexorable passage of time, on the nature of truth and on endless human yearning. \u201cThere is no distance long enough/but still the lengths to which we go,\u201d she sings.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Wasner\u2019s voice and melodic sense, along with her perpetual self-examination, have always been the core of Wye Oak. Her tone is pensive and centered, smooth and resolute; it warms and sustains tunes that often leap at unexpected angles. She and Mr. Stack devise music that is as much counterpoint as accompaniment, an active participant in the songs\u2019 internal dialogues. On the new album, the music marks both an expansion and a restoration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWye Oak got started as a guitar-centered indie-rock band, usually deploying Ms. Wasner on guitar and lead vocals while Mr. Stack handled drums and keyboards. Then, with its 2014 album, \u201cShriek,\u201d Wye Oak willfully transformed its sound, nearly eliminating guitar to construct songs from keyboards and the rhythm section; Ms. Wasner moved primarily to bass, summoning both its architectural and propulsive functions. Suddenly, Wye Oak was showing connections to both electronic pop and progressive rock.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStill, Wye Oak hadn\u2019t abandoned guitar. \u201cTween,\u201d a 2016 collection of eight outtakes recorded from 2011-14, revealed paths the band had rejected for \u201cShriek,\u201d with songs that enfolded electronics in broad strokes of guitar. Now, with \u201cThe Louder I Call, the Faster It Runs,\u201d Wye Oak extends that approach to make it nimbler, more intricate and welcoming. There are joyful and sometimes rowdy sonic crosscurrents, even as the lyrics determinedly think things through.", "title": "Wye Oak Delves Inward and Opens Up on \u2018The Louder I Call, the Faster It Runs\u2019", "authors": ["Jon Pareles"]} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "BOAO, China \u2014 The International Monetary Fund chief praised his openness. A senior British banker lauded his authoritarian rule. The Philippine president said he loves the man.\n\nPresident Xi Jinping of China took center stage at his country\u2019s annual Boao Forum for Asia this week to the welcoming arms of many in the global elite. He portrayed himself as a champion of free trade and world order, speaking to a group that included Ban Ki-moon, the former secretary general of the United Nations, and Pascal Lamy, the former director general of the World Trade Organization, and his words helped move markets around the world.\n\nThe forum, held every year on the southern Chinese island of Hainan, has long been a platform for China to portray itself as an economic powerhouse and regional leader.\n\nBut this year\u2019s meetings took on an elevated role, as a platform for Beijing, a result of a growing trade dispute between China and the United States. It was an opportunity for Mr. Xi to present himself as a foil to President Trump, who has rejected globalization and focused on an \u201cAmerica First policy,\u201d targeting China, in particular, with a series of protectionist moves.", "title": "Xi Jinping Promotes Openness at a China Forum Rife With Restrictions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Xi traveled to Davos for the first time last year to call for global leadership on climate on the eve of the inauguration of Mr. Trump, who has publicly questioned the science behind climate change. Chinese officials were also front and center at the most recent Davos gathering, in January, where they cited China\u2019s progress and called for more international cooperation on several fronts.\n\nThat call for unity could also help calm some unease resulting from Mr. Xi\u2019s recent power grab. Last month, China formally ended term limits for its top leader, which could make Mr. Xi the country\u2019s chief for life. That move has caused jitters among some in the United States and other countries.\n\nAt Boao, Chinese officials have promoted Mr. Xi\u2019s leadership as providing an opening to carry out ambitious plans to overhaul the country\u2019s economy and make it more open.\n\nOn trade, government leaders and Chinese corporate chiefs have sought to strike a delicate balance: playing down worries about the effect on China of a protracted trade fight, while warning that the global economic system could be disrupted by a trade war and that the United States risks falling behind.\n\n\u201cIf a trade conflict becomes a trade war, the U.S. is more likely to be hurt worse by this than China,\u201d Dai Xianglong, a former governor of the People\u2019s Bank of China, said on Monday at the opening of the forum.\n\nOther countries could be hit as well, said Fan Gang, director of China\u2019s National Economic Research Institute. China is just a piece of a complicated regional supply chain across Asia, he said, citing the example of the Apple iPhone. Any retaliation from the United States would have a ripple effect from South Korea to Malaysia, Japan and Taiwan.\n\n\u201cThere is definitely a big uncertainty with this trade conflict. We started with trade friction and now conflict and possibly a war,\u201d Mr. Fan said. \u201cThis trade war has an impact on the whole supply chain, and this is the systematic risk for China right now,\u201d he added.", "title": "Xi Jinping Urges Dialogue, Not Confrontation, After Trump Seeks Tariffs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor me, St. Martin is going to need a good 10 years to reconstruct everything,\u201d said Raymond Laplace, the owner of one of the few beach hotels open after the storm in St. Barts. \u201cFor St. Barts to be like it was, I think we need about two years.\u201d\n\nThat is a reflection of population density: with about 80,000 residents on the entire island, St. Martin is about eight times more populous than St. Barts. It is also a reflection of economic means and of disparities in construction quality.\n\n\u201cThere haven\u2019t been strong building codes applied on St. Martin for many years, and there were certainly areas on the North Side where damage was extensive,\u201d Miller said.\n\nThe cleanup also has been slower than on St. Barts, where the local government and its many affluent private property owners had the wherewithal to respond with alacrity, even before insurance payouts.\n\nIn many sections of the island, you need to look carefully to spot storm damage but the closer you get to some of the main beaches, it sadly gets easier. Many of the larger seafront hotels were hit hard by the storm surge and the high winds and have yet to reopen, although villa rental agencies and some smaller hotels are operating.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople coming for Les Voiles are having to be clever to find housing,\u201d Tolede said. \u201cWe have the advantage that some nearby islands, like Antigua, were not that impacted by the hurricane, so people are going to be able to rent catamarans or boats to be able to house themselves. But above all, what we\u2019ve seen is a desire to come to Les Voiles to show solidarity after Irma.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[READ MORE: Jimmy Buffett\u2019s Support Helps St. Barts Move Forward]\n\nTolede and the race director Luc Poupon, the two longtime friends who created Les Voiles in 2010, expect about 55 yachts to take part instead of the customary 70. One of the newcomers is David Welch, an American optical engineer, who will be competing in his recently purchased HH66, a high-performance catamaran of all-carbon construction.\n\n\u201cMy ambitions are threefold,\u201d Welch said two weeks ago in a telephone interview from California. \u201cFirst, I want to enjoy myself. Second, I want to make sure the boat works the way we want it to work, and third is to do what we can to support the community. Those islands do a tremendous amount for the sailing world in general, so if there\u2019s a way to drive some business their way that\u2019s important.\u201d\n\nLloyd Thornburg, an American investor and veteran racer, was once called a \u201cthrillionaire\u201d by the Irish Independent because of his expensive taste for chasing offshore speed records. But Thornburg has owned a house on St. Barts for 10 years and is a regular participant in Les Voiles, which is lower-adrenaline fare than many of his salt-sprayed adventures.\n\n\u201cThe main appeal is it\u2019s a home regatta for me, but it\u2019s also one of the best because it\u2019s just so beautiful,\u201d he said over coffee at Le Bar de L\u2019Oubli in St. Barts last week. \u201cWhat makes it frustrating or interesting is that unlike traditional sort of buoy races or offshore races, they use a lot of these outlying rocks and islands as marks, and when you are coming around the island, there are a lot of wind shifts coming off of the rocks so local knowledge really helps.\u201d\n\nAt not quite 10 square miles, St. Barts is too small to host nearly any major sports event. But sailing presents an opportunity. It is after all how people first came to the island and how many still come to the island.\n\nPhoto\n\nBeyond Les Voiles, there is the Cata-Cup for multihulls in November; the Bucket Regatta for superyachts in March and the biennial Transat AG2R, which finishes in St. Barts and is the only two-handed trans-Atlantic race on identical boats.\n\n\u201cSailing is a big part of the life here,\u201d said Philip Trangmar, parish administrator for St. Bartholomew\u2019s Anglican Church. \u201cThe Bucket is a big party. Les Voiles is a much more egalitarian and bring-your-boat-and-fit-into-whatever-class sort of thing. The Transat, no matter what time that first boat arrives, whether it\u2019s the middle of the night, all the fishermen and all the boats gather to meet them. There\u2019s a real connection.\u201d\n\nThe Anglican Church, completed in 1855, is one of the few spots in central Gustavia where Irma\u2019s impact is still tangible. One side of the stone wall near the church\u2019s entrance was dislodged and knocked flat by the storm surge and still lies in fragments on the grass next to fund-raising signs.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. He gave up nine runs (five earned) on five hits and walked three.", "title": "Yankees Crush the Angels for Their 8th Straight Win", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "The new netting at Yankee Stadium tapers down from 20 feet high behind the plate to 9\u00bd feet high above both dugouts and then 5\u00bd feet above the railings in front of the high-priced seats down both lines.\n\nBecause of the 40-degree weather and steady misting rain, Tuesday\u2019s game was sparsely attended. About 100 widely scattered fans sat on each side of the field directly behind the nets. According to a Yankees news release, the netting down the lines is the same thickness \u2014 1.2 millimeters \u2014 as the netting behind home plate and is \u201cfield green\u201d in color, designed to blend in with the grass and minimize the visual impact.\n\n\u201cVery unobtrusive,\u201d said Dick Ruebenacker of Westbury, N.Y. \u201cWhich is surprising. I thought it would be a distraction.\u201d\n\nWhat some fans did find distracting was the series of black steel poles, 11 of them on each side of the field, that support the steel cable from which the net hangs.\n\nPhoto\n\nLonn Trost, the Yankees\u2019 chief operating officer, who was in charge of the netting plan, declined to be interviewed. A team spokesman did not say if the Yankees had received any complaints from fans about the new netting.\n\nLast July, after the Mets extended their netting at Citi Field during the All-Star break, Trost said the Yankees were concerned about negative reaction from their season ticket holders if they were forced to sit behind a net.\n\n\u201cThe issue is, how much screening is appropriate?\u201d Trost said at the time. \u201cWhat do the fans want? But considering Sabathia\u2019s age \u2014 he will turn 38 in July \u2014 the mileage on his pitching arm and the degenerative condition of his right knee, the Yankees are no doubt feeling uneasy about a pitcher who was one of the most reliable members of their 2017 starting rotation.\n\nSabathia\u2019s problems on Friday began in the first inning, when Machado, who had yet to hit a home run this season, crushed a hanging slider into the second deck in left field to give the Orioles a 1-0 lead.\n\nThe Yankees got the run back in the bottom of the inning on Giancarlo Stanton\u2019s broken-bat single that scored Brett Gardner from second, but Sabathia was victimized by Machado again in the third. This time, he drove a fastball clocked at 88 miles per hour over the left-center-field fence to make it 2-1.\n\nOnce again, the Yankees tied the game in the bottom of the inning, this time on an Aaron Judge single to center that scored Gardner, who led off the inning with a double. So effective for nearly five seasons in Oakland, he has been largely unrecognizable since he joined the Yankees at the trade deadline last season.\n\n\u201cWe got to circle the wagons around him and help him get through this because he\u2019s important to us,\u201d Manager Aaron Boone said. \u201cThis was tough tonight.\u201d\n\nTwice on Friday, the Yankees staked Gray to two-run leads, once on a home run by Giancarlo Stanton, who had not gone deep in more than two weeks. Gray promptly gave each lead back in the next inning.\n\nAnd after a tidy first inning in which he needed just 10 pitches, Gray quickly lapsed into a bad pattern \u2014 deep pitch counts, walks and ultimately another short outing. He allowed five runs on five hits, walking four and striking out none.\n\n\u201cI think anytime you walk that many guys, it\u2019s going to come back to bite you sooner or later,\u201d Gray said. \u201cI just kind of fell apart there in the middle innings.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoone acknowledged concern about the lack of velocity on Gray\u2019s fastball, which was clocked between 90 and 91 miles per hour, but said he believed that Gray was healthy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt just seemed like he couldn\u2019t reach back for much more,\u201d Boone said.\n\nGray, too, dismissed any suggestion that he was injured. He had spent a significant amount of time on the disabled list in 2016 with trapezius and forearm strains.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s 40 degrees outside,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t think anyone\u2019s throwing as hard as they will be in the middle of the summer.\u201d\n\nDespite the frigid weather, the ball was flying out of Yankee Stadium as if it were a steamy July night.\n\nWith a runner aboard in the second inning, Tyler Austin hit his third home run of the season to give the Yankees a 2-0 lead. He hit it off the Blue Jays\u2019 Marco Estrada, who also surrendered Austin\u2019s two other homers in the second game of the season.\n\nBut in the top of the third, Gray gave up a walk and then a two-run homer by Teoscar Hernandez.\n\nThe Yankees regained the lead with two runs on Stanton\u2019s homer, his fourth of the season \u2014 a line drive into the right-field seats. The shot ended a homer-less streak of 50 at-bats for Stanton. He never went more than 20 at-bats without a homer in 2017, when he led baseball with 59 home runs for the Miami Marlins and won the National League Most Valuable Player Award.\n\nBut Gray gave that lead back, too, on back-to-back doubles and then a two-run single by Lourdes Gurriel Jr., who was making his major league debut after being called up from Class AA earlier in the day. The Yankees tied the game on Miguel Andujar\u2019s solo home run in the bottom of the fourth, but German allowed two runs in the fifth \u2014 one on another single by Gurriel \u2014 and then a solo home run to Yangervis Solarte in the sixth.\n\nBut the real concern for the Yankees centers on Gray, who was expected to be their No. 3 starter behind Luis Severino and Masahiro Tanaka. It lasted 14 innings, over more than five hours, and by the time it was over, four Yankees had left the game either sick or injured. Better to forget about the whole thing for a few hours and go to bed.\n\nWhich Yankees Manager Aaron Boone eventually did, but at the ballpark. And before he could do that, he had to deal with all the problems created by Friday\u2019s loss, such as filling new holes in the roster, coming up with a plan for his depleted bullpen and trying not to get frazzled by the fact that the next game, on Saturday afternoon, was 12 hours away.\n\n\u201cWe had so much going on here, I never went home,\u201d said Boone, who has been a major league manager for all of nine games and is learning on the job very quickly.\n\nBoone did say that he was able to get a good night\u2019s sleep at Yankee Stadium. And that is not to mention the hard-throwing Tommy Kahnle, the lefty specialist Chasen Shreve and the steady Adam Warren.\n\nBut through the first seven games of the season, after a 5-2 loss to the Orioles on Thursday, the bullpen has been more of an Achilles\u2019 heel than a strength. The Yawkey Foundations, a major charity in Boston, said on Thursday that the campaign to remove the name \u201chas been based on a false narrative about his life and his historic 43-year ownership of the Red Sox.\u201d\n\nRenaming the street, the charity said, \u201cwill unfortunately give lasting credence to that narrative and unfairly tarnish his name, despite his unparalleled record of transforming the Red Sox and Fenway Park and supporting the city he loved through his philanthropy.\u201d\n\nIn a statement, the Red Sox said the vote was \u201can important step in our ongoing effort to make Fenway Park a place where everyone feels welcome.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe recognize we have a long way to go, but remain committed to building a spirit of diversity, inclusivity, and openness within our front office and our ballpark,\u201d the team said.\n\nNo matter what people thought about the name change, virtually no one on Yawkey Way on Thursday seemed to like the name Jersey Street or understand what it represented.\n\nAt the official Red Sox team store on the street, several people were buying up \u201cYawkey Way\u201d bumper stickers.", "title": "Yawkey Way, Where Red Sox Fans Converge, Will Be Renamed Over Racism Concerns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "The state embodies dynamics seen across the country. Shocked and despairing at Mr. Trump\u2019s election, women on the left concluded they had been complacent and are now diving into politics, many for the first time. Democrats are hoping to capitalize on a growing Hispanic electorate; Republicans are testing whether their close embrace of the president helps or hurts.\n\nAmong the state\u2019s marquee races is an all-out fight for the Senate seat being vacated by Jeff Flake, with candidates including Representative Martha McSally, the Air Force\u2019s first female fighter pilot; Kelli Ward, a former state senator and hard-right politician known for her conspiracy theories; and Joe Arpaio, the sheriff whose anti-immigrant stances cost him his job in 2016 on the Republican side. Representative Kyrsten Sinema is running against another woman and several men on the Democratic side. On the state level, January Contreras, a Democrat, is the first Latina to run for state attorney general.\n\nThere\u2019s also a #MeToo-inflected special election to replace Representative Trent Franks, who resigned under pressure in a sexual harassment scandal. On April 24, Debbie Lesko, a former state senator who beat 11 Republican male primary challengers as a full-throated Trump supporter, will face off against Hiral Tipirneni, a doctor and political newcomer who trained with Emerge America, one of several groups that recruit Democratic women to run for office.\n\nStill, Arizona remains a state that has not had a Democratic senator since 1995 and where Republicans have the trifecta of governor and both houses of the legislature. Entrenched conservative values will clash this year with a liberal fervor that often plays out at the local level, in grinding, unglamorous work.\n\nThis surge of activism is engaging women of all ages and backgrounds, but tensions are already flaring between women on the left and the center about whom to endorse. Advice and training are pouring in from a bevy of national organizations, including Planned Parenthood and Indivisible, another of the \u201cresistance\u201d groups that published a widely downloaded organizing guide.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nWomen make up a majority of Indivisible\u2019s ranks in Phoenix; they hold weekly protests, canvass for candidates and convene summit meetings, including a visit from the strategists who ran the ground game for the recent Democratic gains in the Virginia state legislature. Julie Golding, a financial analyst, maintains an \u201cAZ Resist\u201d calendar of activities across the state that logs between 30 and 60 events a day.\n\nDemocrats continue to hope that they can win votes by increasing turnout among Arizona\u2019s large and growing Hispanic population. Ana Maria Escobedo, an entrepreneur, joined Indivisible determined to rally more Hispanics to register; she is knocking on doors to enlist new voters, and proudly recounted how she and an avid Trump supporter spent all night talking at a wedding so she could rebut him point by point.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSustaining this momentum is far from assured. \u201cPeople are angry,\u201d said Kate Fisher, who corrals volunteers for Planned Parenthood. \u201cBut to translate that into activists who will be here in November \u2014 that\u2019s the challenge.\u201d On top of her day job as an engineer at Arizona State University, Ms. Fisher devotes nights and weekends to juggling schedules for voter registration, inviting volunteers to dinner and guiding them to political organizing tools like the Voter Action Network, a database that tracks voter records and assesses who\u2019s persuadable.\n\nOther women have geared up to run for local offices where Republicans have enjoyed considerable success, with the party controlling 32 state legislatures to Democrats\u2019 13. Jennifer Jermaine interrupted her maternity leave after the election to post a call on Facebook for a new group she christened Stronger Together Arizona to mobilize community action including voter registration. Within 10 days, she said she had 10,000 members and 1,000 women attended the first meeting on Nov. 20; they in turn spun off Save Our Schools Arizona, which capitalizes on growing anger about education cuts.\n\n\u201cThe moms of Arizona got pissed off and decided to do something,\u201d she said. Now she is collecting signatures to appear on the ballot to challenge a Republican state representative.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nThis influx of newly involved women meshes and sometimes clashes with years of political action by a growing cadre of Hispanics enraged by anti-immigrant policies. Carmen Cornejo, chairwoman of Chicanos Por La Causa and a longtime advocate for the Dreamers, said an early example and playbook for many of today\u2019s mobilization efforts in the Latino community was the recall of the State Senate president, Russell Pearce, in 2011 and the defeat of Mr. Arpaio in 2016.\n\nSeveral longtime Hispanic advocates welcome the swell of activism, but say that some of the newcomers failed to defer to their experience, heed their strategic advice, or embrace their political priorities.\n\n\u201cThey need to trust that women of color can be strategists,\u201d said Alejandra Gomez, co-executive director of Lucha, a local advocacy group. \u201cWe know we\u2019re in it for the long haul. We want these women to also be in it for the long haul, not just this fired-up moment.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Gomez\u2019s commitment was forged by personal experience. She is a citizen, but her father was not until recently, and the family left California in 1999 as anti-immigrant sentiment swelled, only to encounter it again in Arizona. She, like some other Hispanic activists and progressive groups, has balked at what she sees as a lessening of commitment on immigration issues by Democrats like Ms. Sinema who are trying to woo independents and moderate Republicans. Ms. Cornejo says she hopes young activists will eventually accept a candidate like Ms. Sinema to stave off harsher measures that Republicans endorse; Ms. Gomez once admired her but now says she would not back her. Ms. Sinema\u2019s office declined to comment.\n\nAs these tensions play out among Democrats, Republican women are also vying to claim an Arizona heritage that has embraced feisty women stretching back to the state\u2019s frontier and rancher roots.\n\nAs a former fighter pilot given to blunt pronouncements, Ms. McSally fits this mold and is most pundits\u2019 bet to oppose Ms. Sinema for Senate. According to a tally of statewide and congressional races kept by the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers, so far more Democratic women than Republican ones are running for state and congressional seats in Arizona, but Republican women remain formidable in the state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne early test of Republican strength may be the special election.\n\nMs. Tipirneni, in an echo of Democratic national strategy, is hoping to carve out support from independents and moderate Republicans through her embrace of health care and opposition to a school voucher plan Ms. Lesko backed.\n\nBut Ms. Lesko has several advantages: years in the state legislature; a district where far more Republicans voted in the primary than Democrats; and an electorate she says is majority pro-Trump, even as she has called on the president to address accusations of sexual improprieties. She also says her own history as an abused wife who mustered the courage to leave her first husband more than 25 years ago has resonated with other women.\n\nFor her part, Ms. Iyer is relishing her transition from suburban mother to legislative scourge. She posted her first newsletter on Facebook, reaching about 350 friends; now she posts it on a civic engagement site and estimates it reaches about 35,000 people. In the days after the presidential election, she discovered Arizona\u2019s Request to Speak program, which allows a verified voter to register an opinion on a bill and ask to appear before the legislature. At first, she said, she noticed a lawmaker rolling his eyes and others texting under the table as she spoke.\n\nBut after the successful Save Our Schools petition drive and her attendance at statewide protests calling for teachers\u2019 raises, she recounted a different attitude: \u201cThey know when we sit in their office that there are thousands more like us.\u201d", "title": "Year of the Woman? In Arizona, It\u2019s Women, Plural, and It\u2019s Both Parties", "authors": ["Susan Chira"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "More recently, though, Asian-Americans have deliberately sought to reclaim and then recast some of the most timeworn tropes.\n\nLast year, the Asian-American band the Slants won a yearslong battle that ended up before the United States Supreme Court, affirming their right to trademark the name, which draws on a demeaning stereotype about the shape of Asian eyes. And the television show \u201cFresh Off the Boat,\u201d and the memoir off which it is based, have sought to explore and dispel the misconceptions the title breeds.\n\nAs critics of Yellow Fever have pointed out, those cases involved art of a different kind. While food can be expressive, critics said the restaurant appears to be making little effort to challenge ideas about how Asian women are viewed sexually.\n\n\u201cI do think it\u2019s great to see an Asian-American woman start a successful business, and partnering with Whole Foods is probably a big benefit to her,\u201d said Karin Wang, a vice president with the Los Angeles branch of the civil rights organization Asian Americans Advancing Justice.\n\nBut she added: \u201cAs an Asian-American woman, I look at the term, and it\u2019s either a terrible disease you get in tropical countries or it\u2019s an offensive concept of white men pursuing Asian women based purely on their race. I don\u2019t know what\u2019s worth reclaiming about that.\u201d\n\nIn interviews, Kelly Kim, Yellow Fever\u2019s executive chef and co-founder, has said that she was drawn to the name because it was memorable and that she and her husband and co-founder, Michael, were trying to reappropriate it to mean something less pejorative.\n\nA media kit for the restaurant said, \u201cYellow Fever \u2026 yeah, we really said that.\u201d The kit said the name was attention-getting but that \u201cwe choose to embrace the term and reinterpret it positively for ourselves.\u201d", "title": "Yellow Fever Restaurant at California Whole Foods Sets Off a Debate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "Representative Mark Walker, a conservative Republican who is co-chairman of the Congressional Prayer Caucus, stirred up a squall when he suggested the next chaplain should be a family man, with a wife and \u201cadult children.\u201d Clearly, that\u2019s going to eliminate any new Jesuits. Those of you who are aware of the way the House of Representatives functions will not be stunned to hear that the motion was rather quickly snuffed out by a mostly party-line vote.\n\nRepresentative Connolly is now going around quoting Henry II, who, legend tells us, asked \u201cWill no one rid me of this meddlesome priest?\u201d just before some of his loyal soldiers ran off and murdered the politically difficult archbishop of Canterbury, Thomas Becket. Henry II is possibly the most often cited man in Washington these days \u2014 James Comey said that line was just what he thought of when Donald Trump asked him to do something about that irritating Michael Flynn investigation.\n\nIt cannot possibly be a good sign that an ancient invitation to homicide is coming up so frequently. But you have to admit this time the quote works pretty well, what with the actual priest and all.\n\nRyan, who\u2019s been vague about his motives, apparently did complain about the tax prayer. (Conroy says he told him, \u201cPadre, you just got to stay out of politics.\u201d) But that was last year. Through 20 games, he has a feeble .195 batting average and just four home runs. His 37 strikeouts lead baseball. And, despite leading the 14-6 Mets with 18 R.B.I., including three game-winning hits, he admitted he is \u201cfar too lost\u201d at the plate.\n\nHe gave a possible reason for the poor start this weekend: not playing enough golf, a hobby beloved by many baseball players. And, yes, he is serious.\n\n\u201cIn previous seasons, one of the things I did when I wasn\u2019t going well was to play golf,\u201d he said after a game on Friday in which he struck out four times but still drove in the go-ahead run in the 12th inning. \u201cThis year, I\u2019m not playing golf.\u201d\n\nCespedes made the decision to cut out his golfing habit, in an effort to perhaps prevent injuries. Cespedes, the Mets\u2019 slugging outfielder, blooped a single in the top of the 12th inning to drive in the winning run in the Mets\u2019 6-5 victory over the Washington Nationals on Sunday night.\n\nThe game featured a rough outing from Mets starter Matt Harvey, home runs by both teams, mistakes in the field and on the basepaths.
