Now Antioch is pushing the culture further.", "title": "\u2018A Culture Free of Sexual Violence\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 A desperately needed turnaround may be starting to take hold at Paramount Pictures, which found its first hit in two years over the weekend by making a wild bet on a nearly dialogue-free horror movie.\n\n\u201cA Quiet Place,\u201d which received rapturous reviews, sold an estimated $50 million in tickets at theaters in the United States and Canada, or twice as much as box office analysts had projected, resulting in No. 1 bragging rights. The PG-13 film, which cost $17 million to make, not including marketing, stars the married-in-real-life John Krasinski and Emily Blunt as a couple trying to evade creatures who respond to the slightest noise.\n\nThe horror genre, once a Hollywood backwater, has become an artistic hotbed \u2014 a corner of the mainstream movie business where filmmakers have been able to take risks with original concepts, largely because they cost so little compared to the \u201ctent pole\u201d fantasies studios now obsess over. And ticket buyers, especially teenagers and young adults \u2014 the hardest groups to pry away from their Netflix accounts \u2014 have been responding, making hits out of \u201cGet Out,\u201d \u201cIt,\u201d \u201cDon\u2019t Breathe,\u201d \u201cThe Witch\u201d and \u201cThe Visit.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about the story,\u201d said Kyle Davies, Paramount\u2019s president of domestic distribution, adding that horror movies are fun to watch in theaters. \u201cThat communal experience can\u2019t be replicated at home.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cA Quiet Place\u201d was directed by Mr. Krasinski and produced by a team that paradoxically included Michael Bay, best known for his deafening \u201cTransformers\u201d movies. Other producers included Andrew Form and Bradley Fuller, who (with Jason Blum and Mr. Bay) have powered \u201cThe Purge\u201d horror series, which will return in July with a fourth chapter, \u201cThe First Purge.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTo say that Paramount has recently been a quiet place would be exceedingly kind. The Viacom-owned studio has struggled with one misfire after another, including \u201cSherlock Gnomes,\u201d \u201cSuburbicon\u201d and \u201cBaywatch.\u201d It ranks last among Hollywood\u2019s major studios in domestic market share. At least six senior Paramount executives have been replaced in the last year.", "title": "\u2018A Quiet Place\u2019 Is a Huge No. 1 at the Box Office, Boosting Paramount", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cA Quiet Place\u201d continued to make noise at the box office, taking back the top spot from the blockbuster \u201cRampage\u201d and beating out the new Amy Schumer comedy \u201cI Feel Pretty.\u201d\n\nJohn Krasinski\u2019s nearly dialogue-free horror film made another $22 million over the weekend, and now sits at $132 million total domestically. The surprise hit from Paramount cost only $17 million to make and received excellent reviews. Its success shows the strength of original horror movies in today\u2019s film market.\n\n\u201cRampage\u201d cruised into second place with $21 million in its second week, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. The action movie from Warner Bros. reinforced the star power of its lead, Dwayne Johnson \u2014 playing a primatologist trying to corral a giant gorilla and other enormous animals \u2014 even though it didn\u2019t fare well among critics. The film has soared internationally, especially in China, and now stands at $283.3 million total globally.\n\nThe Amy Schumer vehicle \u201cI Feel Pretty\u201d made an underwhelming $16 million in its first week, slightly above expectations but below the opening figures of her previous two feature films. The STX film follows an insecure woman who suffers a head injury that imbues her with confidence; it was mired by backlash to an early trailer and mediocre reviews. (Women under 25, though, gave it a CinemaScore of A.) The film, which cost $32 million to make, puts Ms. Schumer on a downward trajectory following the 2015 smash hit \u201cTrainwreck,\u201d which opened to $30 million, and the lukewarm \u201cSnatched,\u201d which opened to $19.5 million last year.\n\nThe underdog \u201cSuper Troopers 2\u201d zipped along to $14.7 million, good for fourth place. The film revisits the high jinks of a profane group of Vermont state troopers played by the Broken Lizard comedy group; the sequel to the 2002 stoner classic was willed into existence by a devoted fan base that raised $4.6 million through an Indiegogo campaign. The film\u2019s opening, surely aided by a winking release date of April 20, nearly matches what the original made in total ($18.4 million).\n\nOn Saturday, the Broken Lizards wrote that the creation of a \u201cSuper Troopers 3\u201d would be contingent on the second film\u2019s box office success. \u201cOur opening weekend will determine whether we get to keep making movies,\u201d the group wrote on Indiegogo. \u201cYou\u2019re the ones who are going to decide what happens next.\u201d", "title": "\u2018A Quiet Place\u2019 Returns to No. 1 at the Box Office", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat this does for us as a country, the monarchy, this will push us through Brexit,\u201d said Darren French, who had come out of a hospital ward, wearing slippers and flapping cotton pajamas, to watch the spectacle. A black cab was slowly circling the block, with a wax figure of Queen Elizabeth II seated in the back.\n\n\u201cA lot of countries respect our monarchy,\u201d Mr. French added. \u201cIt makes us look solid. It makes us look staunch.\u201d\n\nRepresentatives of betting houses had been out on the sidewalk since morning with chalkboards, updating the odds on possible names for the baby. (Arthur led the male names, with two-to-one odds, and Alice led the girls\u2019 names, five-to-one.)\n\nThe baby\u2019s birth came a week before Catherine and William\u2019s seventh wedding anniversary and, perhaps more important in the eyes of the English news media and public, occurred on St. George\u2019s Day, named after England\u2019s patron saint.\n\nThe couple\u2019s first child, George, was born on July 22, 2013, and their second, Charlotte, on May 2, 2015.\n\nThe new child will be fifth in line for the throne, following Prince Charles, Prince William, Prince George and Princess Charlotte, and before Prince Harry. Changes to the Succession to the Crown Act in 2013 removed male bias, meaning that Princess Charlotte is the first girl to go before her younger brother in the royal line of succession.\n\nPhoto\n\nCatherine gave birth in a familiar setting: the Lindo Wing is where Princess Charlotte, Prince George and several other members of the royal family were born. Its website notes, \u201cDiscretion is key to our service, and we will ensure that you have the space, security and privacy you need to enjoy these precious early moments as a family.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite that promise, the street outside was mobbed with journalists, who were sorted by caste. The royal press corps, from major British outlets, had their own enclosure. They were dressed in trench coats and handsome suits, like intelligence agents. Farther down the road was the enclosure for unaccredited journalists, who were broadcasting live in a variety of Eastern European languages, and searching for nonjournalists to interview.\n\nThey seized on the town crier who had proclaimed the child\u2019s birth from the staircase, who turned out to be a man named Tony Appleton. He had taken the train in from Chelmsford for a second time on Monday morning, after a false alarm on Saturday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cKate, don\u2019t have any more, my nerves are shattered,\u201d he said afterward.\n\nMr. Appleton expressed irritation that he had frequently been identified as an \u201cunofficial\u201d town crier, noting that he was the official town crier of his hometown, Great Baddow.\n\n\n\n[Read more about the modern tradition of the royal baby watch at the Lindo Wing.]\n\nAmong the rubberneckers were a large number of visitors from other monarchies.\n\nBushra Siddiqui, 42, who was there on her lunch break, said she admired the British royals for their accessibility. In Saudi Arabia, where she was born, the royal families live in total separation from the general public.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t find out when their babies are born,\u201d she said. \u201cWe don\u2019t know how many kids they have. We don\u2019t know how many wives they have.\u201d\n\nBut Yasin Ozyaprak, 21, from the Netherlands, said he liked the British royal family for the opposite reason, complaining that the Dutch royals are now so accessible that they have lost their mystique.\n\n\u201cI like the distance,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen the Dutch princesses go to school, they just ride bikes. If you see the king, you just go up and speak to him.\u201d\n\nHe said many of his friends at home shared his enthusiasm.\n\n\u201cMy mom is just, like, Diana-obsessed,\u201d he said. \u201cI just FaceTimed her and she started crying.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe longest vigil had been kept by Terry Hutt, an 82-year-old carpenter and joiner dressed in a suit made with a Union Jack pattern. He had been sleeping outside the hospital on a bench for 15 days, having received contradictory reports about the Duchess of Cambridge\u2019s due date.\n\nHe had brought a piggy bank as a gift for the baby.\n\nMr. Hutt, who also held a vigil outside Buckingham Palace when Charles was born in 1948, said he did not expect any more babies from this royal couple.\n\n\u201cNow it\u2019s Harry\u2019s turn,\u201d he said.", "title": "\u2018A Royal Baby, a Prince!\u2019: Kate and William Welcome New Baby", "authors": ["Ellen Barry"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "But the idea that Mr. Spicer called inconceivable a year ago is back in play.\n\nOn Wednesday, White House officials said that President Trump planned to mobilize the National Guard to the southern border. The announcement came a day after Mr. Trump surprised some of his top advisers by saying that he wanted to send in the military to do what the immigration authorities, in his view, could not: secure the border from what he characterized as a growing threat of unauthorized immigrants, drugs and crime from Central America.\n\nKirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, said on Wednesday that her department and the Defense Department would work with governors to deploy the Guard to \u201cassist the Border Patrol.\u201d But beyond that, officials had few details about how many troops would go, when they would arrive or in what capacity they would serve.\n\nMs. Nielsen said she hoped the deployment would begin \u201cimmediately,\u201d but administration officials said the formal agreements with governors that would allow the troops to mobilize were still being negotiated.\n\nAt the Pentagon, several officials privately expressed concern about being seen as picking a fight with an ally at a time when the military has plenty of adversaries \u2014 the Islamic State, North Korea, Russia, Syria \u2014 to contend with. Massing American troops at another country\u2019s border, several current and former Defense Department officials said, would send a message of hostility and raise the chances of provoking an all-out conflict.\n\n\u201cWe are so lucky here in this country when you look at our borders,\u201d said Maj. Gen. Paul Eaton, a retired veteran of the Iraq war. \u201cWe\u2019ve got the Pacific on one side, the Atlantic on the other and allies to the north and the south. Mexico is not an adversary. Why would you present this offensive barrier to a friendly country?\u201d", "title": "\u2018All It Takes Is One Mistake\u2019: Worries Over Plan to Send National Guard to Border", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Earlier, Darius deduced that \u201cBenny made up Teddy to make up for the fact that he made himself look like a ghoul.\u201d The logic seemed sound, especially since there was no sign of another man in the house. When a masked figure in a wheelchair wearing a red smoking jacket like Teddy\u2019s wordlessly wheels himself over to Darius, it\u2019s reasonable to assume it is Teddy, and his games are getting increasingly warped. Using a chalkboard, the figure warns Darius that both their lives are in danger and tells him to find a gun in the attic.\n\nFed up at long last, Darius rolls his eyes and goes to leave with his piano, only to find his truck is now blocked in by a car. This is no longer just a creepy recluse toying with an unsuspecting guest.\n\nThe basement-dweller was right about the gun in the attic, only Teddy\u2019s now pointing it at Darius on the second floor. He turns away from obsessively watching home movies of his childhood trauma to explain his deranged plan. Teddy\u2019s going to frame Darius as a homicidal home invader, making him take the fall for Benny\u2019s death. This is full-on \u201cWhatever Happened to Baby Jane?\u201d madness and we still don\u2019t even have hard proof that there truly is a Benny. Until we do. And then, the whole macabre affair ends in abrupt tragedy.\n\nMoments before the fraternal murder-suicide, Darius tried to soothe his deeply damaged captor. \u201cNot all great things come from great pain. Sometimes, it\u2019s love,\u201d he said. But it was too little, too late. Ultimately, all he could do was bear witness to the dysfunctional brothers\u2019 bloody end.\n\nIn the final scene, a Stevie track plays \u2014 this time, fittingly forlorn \u2014 as Darius watches the police wheel out one body-bag, then another and lastly, the prized piano.\n\nIf it wasn\u2019t clear before this week, by now it should be crystal: \u201cAtlanta\u201d isn\u2019t here to give you the kind of sitcom you might want. Donald Glover is here to deliver the kind of genre-defying vignettes he wants.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 6: Whatever Happened to Teddy Perkins?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Season 2, Episode 7, \u2018Champagne Papi\u2019\n\nIt\u2019s safe to come out from under the covers; last week\u2019s boogeyman has been vanquished. (Though the ghost of Teddy Perkins will continue to haunt us all.)\n\nWe\u2019re back in more familiar territory \u2014 the Atlanta party scene. With a newly liberated Van as our vehicle, we get a behind-the-scenes look at those A-list bashes that appear glamorous, but only when snapped from the right angles.\n\nVan and her friends, Tami, Candy and Nadine, are prepping for the ultimate girls\u2019 night out, a New Year\u2019s Eve party hosted by the \u201cChampagne Papi\u201d himself, Drake. They\u2019re dressed in the requisite bodycon dresses, fixing their faces and filling in their followers on every detail.\n\nAfter Insta-stalking Earn \u2014 who has clearly moved on to other women (or at least his posts would have us believe as much) \u2014 Van is determined to get on with her life as well. First, she needs to up her social stock by revamping her \u201cweak\u201d Instagram feed, which is all pictures of her daughter, Lotte, and chicken. A photo of her and Drake would be the ultimate boost.", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Drake Has Left the Building", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The first shake-up comes in the form of a potential love interest \u2014 a confident, purple-haired around the way girl named Sierra who picks up Al for a day date. Despite being \u201callergic to girlfriends,\u201d as Darius put it, Al seems open to the possibilities with this one. In conversation, she gives as good as she gets and they\u2019re able to share a laugh together. She\u2019s even a good cheerleader when one of his songs starts playing on the car radio. You can see him starting to let his guard down, so much so that he\u2019s game for an itinerary that reeks of coupledom.\n\nFirst, they stop at a high-end boutique, where Sierra aims to give Al a fashion makeover. We know she\u2019s a former stripper, but her current gig hasn\u2019t yet been revealed. One thing is obvious: the woman is fame-savvy.\n\n\u201cNobody wants for somebody famous to look just like them,\u201d she says in an authoritative tone, advising him to scrap his usual sweaty polo shirts and cargo shorts.\n\nAs she commands the store\u2019s wary, dismissive employees to do her bidding, she makes it clear to Al that she\u2019s not bossy, she\u2019s a boss.\n\nShe urges him to \u201clevel up\u201d in terms of his management, too. Earn\u2019s free liquor connections are bush league; by her estimation, he should be procuring free shoes, clothes and more.\n\n\u201cYou need someone who\u2019s working for you,\u201d she tells Al. It\u2019s the third time (at least) that he\u2019s heard this counsel this season and, by the look on his face, he\u2019s finally ready to heed it.\n\nAfter this mini-intervention, he waits patiently while she poses for photos with a pair of excited fans, gallantly opens the nail salon door for her and joins in a his-and-hers pedicure. These glimpses of domestic bliss look good on Al, but they\u2019re short-lived.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs they\u2019re seated in the cushy salon chairs \u2014 Al giggling at the tickle of his first pumice scrub \u2014 Sierra\u2019s hustle comes to light. \u201cI\u2019m Instagram famous, boo!\u201d she says, happily scrolling through photos that the fans outside just posted on social media. She promotes her brand of diva wigs on social media and, unlike Al, she\u2019s unapologetic and proactive in her pursuit of fame. Of the two of them, she\u2019s the one who\u2019s actually all about that paper.\n\nShe pitches the idea of the two of them teaming up to form a power couple. \u201cWe can attach our brands. Boost each other,\u201d she explains.\n\nThis draws his ire, loath as he is to go in for any of the \u201cfake\u201d trappings of celebrity. He starts to see Sierra in a different light. The assertiveness he\u2019d admired earlier in the boutique now seemed more like rudeness. He\u2019s visibly embarrassed as she reprimands the nail technicians for not speaking English. The date is officially over once she snaps a candid shot of the two of them, planning to post it online. He realizes that her image-driven tactics don\u2019t jibe with his \u201cI\u2019m just trying to stay real\u201d credo.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re sitting over there whining, acting like you\u2019re better than me because I\u2019m trying to get paid,\u201d Sierra says angrily as Al rises to leave.\n\nHe pads off on his own, despite the fact that she\u2019s his ride. After a pitstop for a burger at Krystal, his fast-food chain of choice, Al heads home on foot. While walking, he encounters three teens who are discussing \u201cStar Wars\u201d (a not-at-all-subtle reference to Glover\u2019s next big project). They stop short when they notice a rapper in their midst and feign fandom.\n\nHere, Al gets his second rude awakening. While Sierra sought to benefit mutually from Al\u2019s fame, these three just want to take full advantage of it, Robbin\u2019 Season style.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis isn\u2019t the kind of warm, fuzzy fan interaction that greeted Sierra. After a brief, tense exchange of stares, one boy distracts him as another lands a suckerpunch and the third pulls out a gun. They take turns punching Al, then steal his watch and gold chain.\n\nHe takes off into the wooded area nearby, running from bullets. The gun-toting teen calls out to him, taunting him, as a badly-beaten Al grabs a stick for protection and lies low. After a while, he presses on, the air growing thick with the sounds of birds singing, crickets chirping and then flies buzzing \u2026 around a bloody deer carcass. Then comes an ominous humming, followed by chuckling. It\u2019s a chill-inducing \u201cDeliverance\u201d moment.\n\nThe thieving teens are no longer trailing Al; instead he comes face to face with a downtrodden old man. He\u2019s staggering amid the trees, incoherently offering Al money and Chapstick.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sorry. I\u2019m just high,\u201d he says, temporarily snapping back to his senses.\n\nIs this babbling old man real, or some sort of apparition? Al\u2019s already had a run-in with an ambitious Lady Macbeth-type; why not a full-on supernatural experience in the forest, to boot?\n\nAdding to this sense of David Lynchian suspense, the director, Hiro Murai, pans out slowly to reveal the vastness of the woods in which Al is now lost.\n\nNight falls and Al is still wandering aimlessly through the trees, his footsteps and heavy breathing keep time with the sounds of crickets, rustling leaves and creaking branches. Classic horror film elements like these keep the tension intact, as they\u2019ve done in nearly every episode this season.\n\nAfter another flash of the dead deer, the old man reappears. This time, he\u2019s got a new nickname for Al (\u201cBig Ol\u2019 Black Boy Deer Guts\u201d), as well as a heavy-handed warning.\n\n\u201cMake the decision,\u201d the man says, suddenly jutting a boxcutter toward Al\u2019s throat. \u201cKeep standing still, you\u2019re gone, boy. You\u2019re wastin\u2019 time. And the only people who got time are dead. And if you\u2019re dead, I\u2019m gonna take them shoes and your wallet \u2026 and that shirt.\u201d\n\nHe gives Al until the count of 30 to get out of his sight. It doesn\u2019t even take that long for Al to escape the trees and stumble into a gas station parking lot.\n\nPerhaps that wooded expanse only seemed sprawling because his battered psyche led him to believe it was so. By that logic, maybe the old man or the deer or both were just more manifestations of Al\u2019s (probably concussed) mind playing tricks on him.\n\nWhatever the true nature of this unsettling sylvan scene, it was enough to make Al see the light. All this time, he\u2019s been on the fence about whether or not he wants this fame of his. When a timid, preppy teen approaches him inside the gas station convenience store, he seems ready to step into his role. Despite being covered in blood, dirt and leaves, he gamely throws his arm around the young fan and poses for one photo after another.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a move signaling that Al is finally ready to be Paper Boi. Now, let\u2019s see if Earn\u2019s ready to earn.\n\nMore Fillers and Injections\n\n\u2022 Darius hosting his own YouTube cooking show is the content we all need in our lives. He returned to the kitchen this week, cooking up some \u201cfire pasta\u201d from a recipe he reportedly learned in a dream that starred Mayor McCheese and \u201cthe girl from \u2018Dharma & Greg\u2019.\u201d\n\n\u2022 \u201cI\u2019m gonna put my foot up in this,\u201d he said, seemingly referring to that idiomatic compliment reserved for cooks who\u2019ve made a top-notch dish. Only \u2014 Darius being Darius \u2014 he meant it literally.\n\n\u2022 The show\u2019s Easter eggs continue to keep us on our toes. Can anyone explain the grave looking video that was playing on the TV at the nail salon? It looked like a drug addiction PSA of some sort.\n\n\u2022 In last week\u2019s episode, one of Van\u2019s friends ranted about white women dating successful black men. This week\u2019s writer, Stefani Robinson, kept the pointed racial commentary coming by having Sierra sound off about white women and appropriation in the beauty industry. \u201cI gotta compete with white girls with lip fillers and butt injections selling lip gloss and spray tans,\u201d she said, rolling her eyes. \u201cEverybody wants to be a black girl, but the black girls ain\u2019t makin\u2019 no money from it!\u201d", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 8 Recap: Is Al Finally Ready to be Paper Boi?", "authors": ["Leigh-Ann Jackson"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou stay tryin\u2019 to be slick,\u201d Al says to Earn, doubtful about this corner-cutting contrivance.\n\nFreeloading Tracy tags along for the ride, taking on the role of one-man security detail. It\u2019s a development that Earn hadn\u2019t planned for and he\u2019s irked by any disruptions to a plan that he seems particularly proud of concocting.\n\n\u201cThis place kinda stinks,\u201d Darius says, when they arrive at Violet\u2019s run-of-the-mill college digs. Her apartment is already cramped with two other roommates, so Earn, Darius and Tracy have to carve out space where they can. Violet\u2019s plan for Al is different. She flips her hair, flashes double dimples, licks her lips and informs him that he\u2019ll be sharing her all-pink room.\n\nShe wastes no time enticing Al onto her bed. For a minute, it seems like one of Earn\u2019s plans could finally be panning out (if not financially, then at least physically). Then, mid-snuggle, she confesses details of a dream wherein Al was a crane and she, a white crocodile.\n\n\u201cAnd then I ate you,\u201d she whispers. \u201cThere was blood everywhere.\u201d\n\nWith a hard blink, a deep sigh and a placating \u201cMmm-hmm,\u201d Al lays there mentally subtracting points from Earn\u2019s score board. When he spots an unsettling footprint on her ceiling, a few more points get deducted.\n\nIn the next scene, we\u2019re on campus, where the concert has wrapped up and the crew is convening at a commons room after-party. Al and his entourage are dressed in silky sleepwear separates, as the event\u2019s theme was a Pajama Jam, referencing the early \u201990s film \u201cHouse Party 2.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Atlanta\u2019 Season 2, Episode 9: Al Is Ready for a Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Now Marvel says it wants to clear the table it has spent the last 10 years arranging and make way for something new.\n\n\u201cTelling a great story requires a great ending,\u201d Kevin Feige, the Marvel Studios president, said. \u201cWhen you dedicate yourself to that, it shifts the way you think.\u201d\n\nAudiences are about to find out what finality looks like for a motion-picture money-minting machine: Will the story actually come to a conclusion? Will characters die, and will actors leave the series?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhatever the answers, they have already been reached with the help of the Russo brothers, two of Marvel\u2019s most consistent and diligent \u2014 if not widely recognized \u2014 filmmakers.\n\nWhen they finish their \u201cAvengers\u201d movies, which they shot back to back over 18 months, the Russos will complete their own improbable arc, from indie-cinema oddballs to TV comedy moguls to directors of possibly the biggest franchise in movie history.\n\nThe brothers \u2014 Anthony, 48, the bespectacled brainstormer, and Joe, 46, the square-jawed pragmatist \u2014 have contrasting but complementary energies. As Mr. Downey described them, Anthony is \u201ca bit more reflective, a yin guy,\u201d while Joe is the intense yang of the partnership: \u201cBitcoin was invented to keep Joe Russo from killing himself during the last 20 percent of the shoot,\u201d Mr. Downey said.\n\nWhen they\u2019re together, Mr. Downey added, \u201cIt\u2019s like the two of them make a third thing that\u2019s better than any one person could be.\u201d\n\nThe Russos grew up in Cleveland, where their father, Basil M. Russo, served as Democratic majority leader of the City Council. When the city went into an economic tailspin in the 1970s and \u201980s, the brothers immersed themselves in movies and learned to appreciate their creative isolation.\n\nAs Anthony Russo explained it, \u201cThe virtue of growing up in the industrial Midwest is you have nothing to rub up against you and no one to tell you that you can\u2019t do what you want to do, because nobody\u2019s doing anything. You can just be a dreamer.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThey spent three years and $30,000 writing and directing an independent feature, \u201cPieces,\u201d about three brothers \u2014 also named the Russos \u2014 who dabble in crime. Despite some withering reviews \u2014 Variety called it an \u201cunabashed vanity project\u201d \u2014 \u201cPieces\u201d caught the attention of Steven Soderbergh at the 1997 Slamdance Film Festival.\n\nWith his help, the Russos made their first studio movie, a comic crime caper called \u201cWelcome to Collinwood,\u201d with George Clooney, William H. Macy and Sam Rockwell. But it flopped at its release in 2002.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the next several years, the Russos focused on directing television shows, including \u201cLucky,\u201d a short-lived FX series, and \u201cArrested Development,\u201d the rapid-fire satire that became a cult hit on Fox.\n\nDespite critical acclaim, \u201cArrested Development\u201d got notoriously low ratings. But the Russos said this lack of attention was a blessing in disguise, allowing them to experiment with narrative, tone and pacing, unencumbered by interfering network executives.\n\n\u201cThey so didn\u2019t get the show that they really didn\u2019t care what you did,\u201d Anthony Russo said, adding, \u201cIt was a huge creative upside.\u201d\n\nThe Russos used NBC\u2019s \u201cCommunity,\u201d another well-reviewed comedy with a meager viewership, to stage elaborate tributes to \u201cStar Wars\u201d and the spaghetti westerns of Sergio Leone. It was here that their work caught Marvel\u2019s attention.\n\nAt the time, the studio was generating hits with its earliest superhero offerings, made by established filmmakers \u2014 \u201cIron Man,\u201d directed by Jon Favreau; \u201cCaptain America: The First Avenger,\u201d directed by Joe Johnston. But Marvel wanted to expand its portfolio rapidly and bring in TV directors.\n\nMarvel also wanted to shift the tone of its \u201cCaptain America\u201d movies, starting with the 2014 sequel, \u201cThe Winter Soldier.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe first one was a fairly patriotic, gung-ho World War II movie,\u201d said Christopher Markus, who wrote the \u201cCaptain America\u201d films with Stephen McFeely. \u201cYou can\u2019t make a string of those before you get slightly nauseous.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Watching Get the most out of your screen time with movie and TV recommendations, news and commentary from New York Times experts. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe goal of \u201cThe Winter Soldier,\u201d Mr. Markus said, was to show Captain America \u201closing faith in all the institutions that had made him, giving you a way to see him as relevant in the modern era.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Russos envisioned \u201cThe Winter Soldier\u201d as a modern-day upgrade of espionage thrillers like \u201cThree Days of the Condor,\u201d and the studio responded strongly. When the movie sold $714 million in tickets worldwide, Mr. Feige said the Russos \u201credefined the franchise \u2014 not just the Cap franchise but all the Marvel movies going forward.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey found a way to keep the wonder, keep the spectacle, but ground it even more in realism,\u201d Mr. Feige said. \u201cWhich is a word I use lightly when it comes to our movies.\u201d\n\nThe Russos succeeded again with \u201cCaptain America: Civil War,\u201d an overstuffed 2016 sequel in which the Black Panther (Chadwick Boseman) and a new incarnation of Spider-Man (Tom Holland) were introduced, and the adventurers took sides in a conflict between Cap and Iron Man.\n\nEven before \u201cCivil War\u201d became a $1.15 billion global smash, Marvel had already started putting the pieces in place for what Mr. Feige called \u201cthe big finale of the initial story line we were developing.\u201d\n\nThe plan was ambitious: Mr. Markus and Mr. McFeely would write two \u201cAvengers\u201d movies, generated from a 60-page manifesto they started working on in 2015. All the major Marvel heroes had to be accommodated, and still more characters would be introduced. \u201cNot every scene can be 25 people in a room,\u201d Mr. McFeely said. \u201cYou\u2019re going to have to make kickball teams and then have a tournament.\u201d\n\nWith scripts in hand, the Russos would film these movies consecutively. In Mr. Feige\u2019s mind, there were no other directors who could handle the task of doing \u201cthree straight years of filmmaking.\u201d\n\nMr. Feige said, \u201cThere are two of them, which helps. But their individual stamina is unmatched.\u201d\n\nThe Russos moved from Los Angeles to Georgia for two years, where \u201cAvengers: Infinity War\u201d and its sequel were shot, principally at Pinewood Atlanta Studios. (They estimate that they took a break of about three weeks between filming the two movies.)\n\nThey said making the movies this way was an irresistible challenge \u2014 one that has been attempted by very few directors, including the Wachowskis (\u201cThe Matrix\u201d series) and Peter Jackson (the \u201cLord of the Rings\u201d and \u201cHobbit\u201d franchises) \u2014 and a test of their fortitude.\n\nPhoto\n\nDescribing the process, Anthony Russo said, \u201cYou\u2019re a really good marathon runner and you know how to train for it. All of a sudden, you\u2019re running a double marathon. You can\u2019t really understand it until you do it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Russos acknowledge that the films were made this way, in part, for economic reasons: it\u2019s cheaper for Marvel to hire actors \u2014 dozens of them, some of whom are very costly \u2014 for months at a time, rather than make individual deals for each movie.\n\nThough they must serve many corporate masters at Disney and Marvel, and Mr. Feige is known for having a strong hand in his films, the Russos say they were given the latitude to make the movies they want to make.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s no different than making any kind of narrative in a medium where capitalism thrives,\u201d Joe Russo said. \u201cYou have to have a Zen resilience about what it is that you want to do, and then do a really good job at it. And everybody stays out of your hair.\u201d\n\nMr. Downey, who first worked with the Russos on \u201cCivil War,\u201d said they were well served by their TV training, which has taught them to be quick and collaborative.\n\nAt any given moment on these films, Mr. Downey said, \u201cwe\u2019ve got 80 things that are going to blow up, collide \u2014 story points that are all about to happen at once.\u201d When one of the Russos had a new idea, he said, they would approach him with a gentle query: \u201cLet me pitch you this.\u201d\n\n\u201cNo one takes it personally, and then the idea emerges,\u201d Mr. Downey said. \u201cIt ends up an amalgam of everything that didn\u2019t hit the floor.\u201d\n\nThe Russos aren\u2019t revealing much about how, exactly, their \u201cAvengers\u201d movies will bring closure to this phase of the Marvel cinematic saga. (They wouldn\u2019t even disclose the title of the movie that follows \u201cInfinity War,\u201d protesting that even this much information would be a spoiler.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cUltimately,\u201d Joe Russo said, \u201cwhat you\u2019ll see by the end of the movies is, what does it cost to be a hero in a world where there are no easy answers? I think that\u2019s the world we live in.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDeath is a staple of comic books. Beloved characters are killed off all the time, sometimes replaced by successors who inherit their costumes and identities: Bucky becomes the new Captain America; Jane Foster the new Thor. There\u2019s no reason to believe that their motion-picture counterparts aren\u2019t similarly mortal and similarly interchangeable.\n\nMr. Evans has made no secret of his desire to move beyond the \u201cCaptain America\u201d movies. Meanwhile, Mr. Downey \u2014 who introduced himself in a phone interview as \u201cRobert Downey Jr., retired film actor\u201d \u2014 is already working on his next prospective tentpole movie, \u201cThe Voyage of Dr. Dolittle.\u201d\n\nHe talked about his time with Marvel in retrospective tones, and reflected on an encounter with Keanu Reeves, who at the time had just finished making the first \u201cMatrix\u201d movie.\n\n\u201cI was like, \u2018Hey, dude, how\u2019d it go?\u2019\u201d Mr. Downey recalled. \u201cHe said, \u2018I\u2019ve been on another planet.\u2019 Right now, I\u2019ve been on the planet Dolittle for a while. Being detached from it has given me a lot of warmth, affection and objectivity about this past decade.\u201d\n\nOf course, the Marvel engine will keep chugging away. \u201cThere will be more movies with some of these characters,\u201d Mr. Feige said, \u201cand with lots of new characters.\u201d\n\nDisney\u2019s pending acquisition of Fox would add even more familiar heroes to Marvel\u2019s toy chest, including the X-Men and Fantastic Four. But Mr. Feige said it was \u201cway too soon\u201d to make plans for these properties.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019d love to have all the characters back,\u201d Mr. Feige said. \u201cIt\u2019s a dream. But we\u2019re plenty busy with the next five films.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Russos, too, are preparing for their post-\u201cAvengers\u201d lives. They have established their own production company, Agbo Films, whose executives include Mr. Markus and Mr. McFeely and which has already secured $250 million in private Chinese funding.\n\nThe brothers are elliptical about whether there are more Marvel movies in their future. \u201cWe wanted to maximize our options as storytellers and artists,\u201d Anthony Russo said. \u201cWe\u2019ve structured our business life in a way to support that. It can be, or it can\u2019t be. We\u2019ve kept all options open.\u201d\n\nJoe Russo said there are still some \u201cvery personal projects we want to make,\u201d adding that he and Anthony want to nurture up-and-coming filmmakers just as Mr. Soderbergh did for them. \u201cWe owe a karmic debt to the universe because of what Steven did for us,\u201d he said.\n\nThe reality, though, is that the Russos are not even finished with \u201cAvengers.\u201d Once \u201cInfinity War\u201d is released, there is still a whole additional movie for them to construct from untold hours of raw footage, a task that they estimate will take them at least until the end of the year. \u201cThere are months of work left on it,\u201d Anthony Russo said. \u201cIt will be very cathartic for us to come out the other end. That\u2019s when our brains can open up to what\u2019s next.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Avengers,\u2019 the Most Lucrative Movie Franchise Ever, Is Wrapping Up. Why?", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSpider-Man: Homecoming\u201d was a soaring success. \u201cThor: Ragnarok\u201d opened even bigger. Then \u201cBlack Panther\u201d crushed both of them.\n\nBut none of those Marvel movies could compare to the franchise\u2019s shiniest jewel, \u201cAvengers: Infinity War,\u201d which rampaged through the weekend with $630 million worldwide \u2014 easily the biggest global opening of all time.\n\nExpectations were high for \u201cInfinity War,\u201d the first installment of a two-part finale, which will wrap up a whopping 20-film Disney franchise. The movie features a litany of brand-name stars \u2014 Robert Downey Jr., Scarlett Johansson, Chris Hemsworth, Gwyneth Paltrow, Don Cheadle, Chris Pratt and dozens more \u2014 as the heroes assemble to take down Thanos (Josh Brolin), the series\u2019 biggest baddie yet. Disney poured in around $300 million to make the movie and another $150 million or so to market it, sending the extensive cast around the world and to nearly every talk show.\n\n[ Read A.O. Scott\u2019s spoiler-filled article about the ending of \u201cAvengers: Infinity War.\u201d ]\n\nThe investments paid off. The $630 million global opening for \u201cInfinity War\u201d crushed the previous record-holder, \u201cThe Fate of the Furious,\u201d which arrived last year to a now seemingly pedestrian $542 million. Incredibly, \u201cInfinity War\u201d sprinted to first place without the enormous markets of China or Russia, where it will open in the next two weeks. Domestically, the film put up a cool $250 million and was celebrated in Hollywood as the biggest opening ever. When adjusted for inflation, though, \u201cInfinity War\u201d lags slightly behind \u201cStar Wars: The Force Awakens,\u201d which arrived in 2015 to about $261 million in today\u2019s dollars.", "title": "\u2018Avengers: Infinity War\u2019 Lands the Biggest Global Opening Ever", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019m not complaining, but rather pointing out how pointless, how silly it sounds when anyone bothers to venture a complaint. Who wants to be a hater? Still, it\u2019s worth noting that the ascendance of Marvel (and of other, not quite as universal entities like it) has narrowed the parameters of criticism. I\u2019m supposed to tell you, in this review, how much fun you\u2019ll have at \u201cInfinity War.\u201d (Yes, you will have some. Will you have enough? Almost.) But I\u2019ve probably already gone too far in trying to think about what it means. The Marvel movies and others of their kind often produce an illusion of profundity, a slick, murky overlay of allegorical suggestiveness. This provides grist for the kind of think pieces that spar with one another \u2014 \u201cInfinity War\u201d is liberal; no, it\u2019s conservative; but don\u2019t you see that it\u2019s a protest against Trump; actually, it\u2019s an attack on the tyranny of political correctness \u2014 until they catalyze the inevitable anti-intellectual backlash. It\u2019s just a movie! Don\u2019t spoil the fun!\n\nAnd of course it is with respect to \u201cspoilers\u201d that the policing of discourse is most ruthlessly and effectively practiced. Reviewers who attend advance screenings take a vow of silence about plot details that will be widely known within a week and all but forgotten a week after that. Government secrets are guarded with less care, and requests from public officials to go off the record are addressed with more skepticism. But if I mention which superhero dies, or which one has an unexpected relationship with someone else \u2014 well, I wouldn\u2019t dream of it. Not because I\u2019m afraid of Disney executives. It\u2019s the wrath of their obedient, weaponized minions I fear. In other words: you.\n\nThis is not a healthy situation. The reasonable concern that major plot elements not be divulged has spawned a phobic, hypersensitive taboo against public discussion of anything that happens onscreen. If, for example, I were to share that Thor (Chris Hemsworth) mistakes Rocket (Bradley Cooper), who is a raccoon, for a rabbit \u2014 whoops, you already hit \u201csend,\u201d didn\u2019t you? The joke is repeated a half-dozen times, so it kind of ruins itself. And until the end, the whole thing is weirdly free of any but the most superficial, mechanical surprises.\n\nThe action is especially tedious and predictable. I mean both the scenes of fighting and flying and the overall rhythm of the first two hours or so. People talk for a while, sprinkling jokes and morsels of personality into the heavy dough of exposition. Then they fight in the usual way, by throwing giant objects (and one another) and shooting waves of color from their hands. The noisy, bloated spectacles of combat were surely the most expensive parts of the movie, but the money seems less like an imaginative tool than a substitute for genuine imagination.", "title": "\u2018Avengers: Infinity War\u2019: It\u2019s Marvel\u2019s Universe. We Just Live in It.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "But metal\u2019s cultural centers are quickly becoming a thing of the past. Music clubs throughout the five boroughs are dying at an alarming rate, and those that served the metal community have been hit especially hard, with multiple pivotal clubs closing in quick succession.\n\nThe metalheads who frequent the concert circuit in Sunnyside or Corona aren\u2019t avoiding a trip to another borough; there\u2019s hardly anywhere left for them \u2014 or any other fans of underground metal \u2014 to go.\n\nWhen the Acheron, a metal haven in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, closed in 2016, it left a limited number of clubs that regularly host more extreme or lesser-known metal bands. Saint Vitus Bar, in Greenpoint, and Lucky 13, in Gowanus, have the most lively performance rosters, and both are in corners of Brooklyn not easily accessible by subway.\n\nBigger acts have more freedom of choice in terms of which clubs they're able to play, but to find the kind of raw, less-accessible metal that Mr. Proana, Ms. Buritica and their friends love, there are precious few options \u2014 which is why D.I.Y. shows held in bars and basements have become the lifeblood of their scene.", "title": "\u2018Behold Death, Darkness, Chaos and the Void\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "In Greenwich Village, when she was all of 20, Abbott fell in with a crowd that included the playwright Eugene O\u2019Neill (she had small parts in several productions of his plays), the poet Edna St. Vincent Millay, the writer Malcolm Cowley and the photographer Man Ray.\n\nShe did not have a trust fund, like some in her milieu. She worked as a waitress, a secretary and a reader for a clipping service. She wanted to study journalism but Columbia\u2019s program was too crowded for her taste, and then it closed during the First World War.\n\nAbbott was a chain-smoker, a big drinker at times, and she liked to dance. She and Man Ray were kicked off one dance floor for \u201cobscenity,\u201d Van Haaften writes, which is one definition of pretty good dancing. When Man Ray needed a divorce, and the only ground New York State would accept was adultery, Abbott agreed to be named as the other woman.\n\nImage Credit Sonny Figueroa/The New York Times\n\nAbbott began to slip an extra \u201ce\u201d into her birth name, which was Bernice. (She was upset when some publications, including The New York Times, omitted the extra letter.) She began to have relationships with women, and had several great early love affairs.\n\nAbbott moved to Paris in 1921, when she was 22. She might as well be \u201cpoor there as poor here,\u201d she thought. She became a portrait photographer after working as Man Ray\u2019s studio assistant. Her friends in Paris included Andr\u00e9 Gide, the bookstore owner Sylvia Beach and Hadley Richardson, Ernest Hemingway\u2019s first wife.\n\nHer fame was spread by Janet Flanner, who sometimes wrote about Abbott\u2019s work in her \u201cLetter From Paris\u201d in The New Yorker. Joyce immortalized his portrait session with Abbott in \u201cFinnegans Wake,\u201d noting how \u201cthe Tulloch-Turnbull girl with her coldblood kodak shotted the as yet unremuneranded national apostate, who was cowardly gun and camera shy.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Berenice Abbott\u2019 Captures a Large and Star-Studded Life", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 Seeking to build an identification system of unprecedented scope, India is scanning the fingerprints, eyes and faces of its 1.3 billion residents and connecting the data to everything from welfare benefits to mobile phones.\n\nCivil libertarians are horrified, viewing the program, called Aadhaar, as Orwell\u2019s Big Brother brought to life. To the government, it\u2019s more like \u201cbig brother,\u201d a term of endearment used by many Indians to address a stranger when asking for help.\n\nFor other countries, the technology could provide a model for how to track their residents. And for India\u2019s top court, the ID system presents unique legal issues that will define what the constitutional right to privacy means in the digital age.", "title": "\u2018Big Brother\u2019 in India Requires Fingerprint Scans for Food, Phones and Finances", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Season 3, Episode 2: \u2018The Wrong Maria Gonzalez\u2019\n\nLive like a king. It\u2019s a phrase that connotes wealth, luxury, excess, a life of unlimited possibility and security. How easy it is to let the sparkle of the crown jewels blind us to the dead enemies and discarded undesirables through which they were purchased. This week\u2019s episode of \u201cBillions\u201d reminds us, as bluntly as the show ever has, that the games played by Bobby Axelrod and his billionaire boys club in order to remain comfortable on their thrones can have as steep a cost to bystanders as to any player in the game.\n\nTake a close look at the title, \u201cThe Wrong Maria Gonzalez.\u201d The right Maria Gonzalez is a maid in the home of Victor, a former analyst at Axe\u2019s firm who led her to poisoning herself in order to tank the initial public offering of Ice Juice last season and thus get back in the good graces of his ex-employer. But to hear Maria tell it, she lived like a serf, bowing to the whims of her feudal lord and lady even before this act of industrial espionage landed her on an F.B.I. witness list. If she broke a glass, Victor\u2019s wife broke her taillight, putting her at risk of getting pulled over and, eventually, deported.\n\nWhich is exactly what Victor and Axe conspire to do to her once they get wind of her possible participation in the Ice Juice case. (Victor knew she was involved the moment she showed up slightly late for work; his oligarch-sense must have tingled.) To the horror of our hero Bryan Connerty and his F.B.I. ex-flame Terri McCue (Susan Misner), they arrive at the local immigration detention center only to discover that a different woman by the same name is being held captive there. Thanks to a record-keeping mishap, the \u201cright\u201d Maria Gonzalez is already on her way back to Guatemala \u2014 helped along, they correctly deduce, by Axe and his minions, in this case a comically sinister duo Axe has hired as his new skulduggery specialists.\n\nAnd if you thought that Attorney General Jock Jeffcoat would be sympathetic to the need to un-deport an \u201cillegal immigrant\u201d back to the United States so she can testify against an extremely wealthy white man, I\u2019ve got a building on Fifth Avenue to sell you.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: That Feeling in Your Stomach", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "On the billionaire side of the \u201cBillions\u201d ledger, the behavior is, unsurprisingly, even worse. Bobby begins the episode by officially signing divorce papers with his now ex-wife Lara; the meeting is cordial, as is their private discussion of their finances and legal situation afterward. The thrust of that conversation, however, is completely infuriating. They treat the prospect of the court case leaving them with \u201conly\u201d $300 to $320 million as if they\u2019d just been bankrupted.\n\nLater, Axe approaches the disgraced investor Michael Panay (Hari Dhillon) to operate as a catspaw, making the trades that Bobby is barred from handling on his own. \u201cForty,\u201d Panay says of the amount of money left to him after his downfall. \u201cGuess I can live on that.\u201d To be clear, he is talking about 40 million, not 40 thousand, dollars. In order to save himself from the ignominy of living off an amount of money most Americans won\u2019t see in the course of their lifetimes, he effectively sells his soul to the redheaded devil.\n\nIt is a move that should further enrich him, Axe, the police pension fund they\u2019re handling and Raul Gomez, the ex-cop who runs the fund. All it requires is becoming a highly paid wage slave to an even richer man. The heart bleeds, doesn\u2019t it?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRunning parallel to these threads of realpolitik and greed, Taylor and Wags\u2019s story line this episode raises the intriguing idea that even masters of the financial universe like themselves could be brought low by the rise of the machines. Contrary to longstanding policy at Axe Capital, Taylor wants to bring in quantitative analysts, or \u201cquants,\u201d who create complex computer algorithms that tell them what and when to trade instead of relying on the human insights and personal touches of Dollar Bill, Mafee, Kim, Rudy and the rest of the hotshots working the Axe Cap terminals. (Well, Dollar Bill is a hotshot, anyway; the others are nervous wrecks, as we see when Mafee\u2019s therapeutic session with Wendy Rhoades devolves, to his horror, into a slippery-slope monologue about whether or not he checks out her backside when she walks around the office.)\n\nA variety of entertaining candidates for the gig traipse in and out of the office. The final candidate is a real Goldilocks: He\u2019s older, wiser, calmer, kinder \u2014 a NASA data analyst with decades of experience who has become a quant because he sees the market as a way to learn what the whole world is thinking at any given moment. But as Taylor susses out, he is also working in cahoots with Wags to build a backdoor into his algorithm, allowing the firm\u2019s fully human traders to hastily recreate its analysis and reap the rewards themselves.\n\nTaylor winds up vowing to build Axe Cap a better quant of its own \u2014 perhaps the one time a boss actually acts on behalf of the underlings rather than against them. Like everything else on this end of the story, though, it\u2019s all in favor of filthy lucre in the end.\n\nTying together the episode\u2019s triangle of plotlines is a cynical sense of humor that\u2019s laugh-out-loud funny throughout, the way \u201cMad Men\u201d used to make you guffaw at its characters\u2019 avaricious awfulness. The episode opens with Ira\u2019s officially canceling his marriage proposal to his beautiful girlfriend on account of his financial woes; you can all but see his bank account draining with every sprinkle of $14-per-gram white truffles she has shaved onto her pasta. (She stops at 20 grams, which the waiter cheerfully says is the season\u2019s largest order. Hooray?)\n\nIra is also morbidly funny during an initial interview with Bryan over coffee, where he responds to the prospect of discussing Ice Juice\u2019s collapse by asking \u201cShall we relive my divorce, and the day the music died?\u201d As Ira, the actor Ben Shenkman makes for a terrifically sardonic patsy; this guy is not supposed to win, so when he does by accepting Axe\u2019s payout and the gift of a gigantic engagement ring, the applause of his fellow diners after his girlfriend accepts his proposal sounds like a mockery of the order of things.\n\nEven in their attempt to stop Jeffcoat from throwing the book at the abused prisoner, Rhoades and Sacher understand the need to properly angle the facts. \u201cLooks innocent, no?\u201d Chuck says as they pull up the photo that runs with the exonerating news story. \u201cHandsome, for sure,\u201d she says. \u201cEven better,\u201d he concludes. Bosses know how much perception matters. That\u2019s why, when you\u2019re used to billions like Axelrod and Panay are, no number of millions shy of that tenth digit will do.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou want it darker, we kill the flame,\u201d Leonard Cohen croons on the soundtrack as Axe cashes in and Ira slides his ill-gotten ring onto his fianc\u00e9e\u2019s eager finger. Funny and fast-paced though it is, \u201cBillions\u201d likes it quite dark indeed.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3, Episode 3 Recap: Boss Moves", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "Season 3, Episode 4: \u2018Hell of a Ride\u2019\n\nChuck Rhoades Jr. and Charles Rhoades Sr. are at war. They have been since the last season of \u201cBillions,\u201d when son betrayed father as part of a plot by Chuck to ruin his nemesis, Bobby Axelrod. But the most powerful weapon wielded in the conflict so far hasn\u2019t been a legal threat or a stock swindle. It\u2019s the kiss that Charles plants square on Chuck\u2019s mouth, hands locked on his son\u2019s head to prevent him from pulling away.\n\nThat kiss is the climax of \u201cHell of a Ride,\u201d this week\u2019s aptly titled episode from the writer Randall Green and the director John Dahl. In a series that has made a study of the physicality of the rich and powerful, the scene is a graduate-level course.\n\nOn one level, and like so many of these characters\u2019 other words and actions, it is very likely a reference to a work of macho pop culture: the kiss of betrayal that Michael Corleone plants on his disloyal brother Fredo in \u201cThe Godfather Part II.\u201d (Bobby quoted the first \u201cGodfather\u201d film earlier in the episode when he instructed his philanthropy guru, Sean Ayles (Jack Gilpin), to \u201cuse all your powers and all your skills\u201d in support of his latest stealthy venture.) But like the best such moments on \u201cBillions,\u201d the context transforms the reference into something new and unique, and in this case uniquely disturbing.\n\nThe father-son dynamic creates a power imbalance absent in the brother-to-brother version, adding an overtone of Oedipal anxiety and parental abuse. That ugliness is compounded in turn by the creepy sexualization of the two men\u2019s relationship in this episode, from Charles\u2019s bawdy stories of his collegiate sexual exploits to the revelation that Chuck lost his virginity at age fourteen to a prostitute hand-selected by his father based on firsthand knowledge of her skills. Charles\u2019s presence also looms large over Chuck and Wendy\u2019s heart-to-heart regarding her one-night stand with the space entrepreneur Craig Heidecker during their separation \u2014 an act of infidelity Charles had taken it upon himself to uncover and parade before his son.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3, Episode 4 Recap: Sealed With a Kiss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Season 3, Episode 5: \u2018Flaw in the Death Star\u2019\n\nThis week on \u201cBillions,\u201d romance is in the air. Who\u2019da thunk it, right? Sex, sexuality, the rewards and compromises of long-term relationships, even the eroticized thrill of spectacular professional success \u2014 these themes are never in short supply on this show. But the pangs of infatuation that make your eyes widen, your heart quicken, and (with any luck) your clothes melt away to the tune of Echo and the Bunnymen? That\u2019s \u2026 unexpected.\n\nEven more unexpected? The young lovers involved. The casting of comedian Mike Birbiglia added an uncharacteristically mellow presence to this high-strung, hard-charging show. If you predicted that this addition was a prelude to an affair between Birbiglia\u2019s Silicon Valley \u201cventure philanthropist\u201d character, Oscar Langstraat, and Bobby Axelrod\u2019s handpicked successor, the tightly wound gender-nonbinary genius Taylor Mason, congratulations: Your powers of prognostication outstrip even those of Axe himself. Yet from the moment these two very different visionaries make a nerd-love connection in defense of a supposed \u201cStar Wars\u201d plot hole, it makes sense, retrospectively, that they would hook up. It just feels right. (Granted, I\u2019m slightly biased in that I agree with their reasoning \u2014 \u201cWhat material could withstand the heat expended from that mammoth sphere?\u201d \u201cPlus, it was fortified with gun turrets!\u201d \u2014 but only slightly.)\n\nPredicated on a trip to San Francisco designed to further the connections between Oscar and Axe Capital, the story line is successful mainly because of how exciting it feels to see Taylor, well, excited by something. Asia Kate Dillon\u2019s portrayal of this blue-eyed brainiac is rooted in a Spock-like blend of ironclad logic and an outsider\u2019s insight into the prevailing culture. To see the flush of a crush on Taylor\u2019s face, melting that resolve and reserve, is a beautiful thing. The subsequent sex scene between the two characters is sweet, hot and groundbreaking in equal measure. You\u2019d be a fool to ignore any one of those three indissoluble elements.\n\nAn even odder, and far unhappier, couple dominates the action back in New York. It\u2019s a battle of pig versus prig at Axe Cap, as the gleefully macho and amoral Dollar Bill Stearn clashes with the company\u2019s compliance officer, Ari Spyros \u2014 Chuck Rhoades\u2019s one-time frenemy at the Securities and Exchange Commission, now working for the full-on enemy \u2014 over the kind of insider trading he used to be able to get away with as a matter of course. A \u201cthis firm ain\u2019t big enough for the both of us\u201d battle ensues that sends Wendy in search of a stiff drink \u2014 not least because she recognizes its similarities with the war between Chuck and Bobby.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3, Episode 5 Recap: The Family We Choose", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe\u2019re not in Hollywood, Chuck,\u201d Spyros sneers. \u201cNothing\u2019s going to happen. Say it loud enough, they may even make me president.\u201d Hey, even a broken clock, am I right?\n\nSo Spyros, in his own words, goes \u201cthe full le Carr\u00e9,\u201d arranging a melodramatic midnight meetup with Connerty in which he hands the eager attorney a smoking gun \u2026 with Wendy\u2019s fingerprints all over it.\n\nBack when Axe was sabotaging the Ice Juice initial public offering, in which Chuck and his friends and family were heavily invested, Wendy tried to warn him about what Axe was up to, not realizing that her husband was orchestrating the whole thing. In a play that was half pique and half shrewd financial management, she ordered an enormous short on the Ice Juice stock and made a killing.\n\nUnfortunately, she did so while within Chuck\u2019s offices, elevating mere insider trading into what looks for all the world like a criminal conspiracy with her husband. Now Bryan can use Wendy, much loved and respected by both Bobby and Chuck, as a leverage point against both men, either of whom would gladly go to prison to keep her out of it.\n\nThe fallout is a marvelous domino effect of reaction shots featuring talented actors. When Spyros reveals what he\u2019s done, Axe, Wags and the lawyer Orrin Bach, shoot Spyros looks that are withering enough to defoliate every plant in the office. In his comedic performance as Spyros, Stephen Kunken reacts with the kind of flabbergasted fear you would expect watching Lou Costello encounter Frankenstein\u2019s monster. When Bobby forces himself to break the news to Wendy, Maggie Siff\u2019s teary, slightly broken-voiced effort to stay calm and controlled should be familiar to all those who have experienced a moment of realization that, because of their own doing, life as they know it is about to end. (Or so I\u2019m told.)\n\nPaul Giamatti\u2019s gruff brand of dignity as Chuck gets a workout, whether he\u2019s glaring at Toby Leonard Moore\u2019s I\u2019m-not-angry-I\u2019m-disappointed Connerty or sobbing an apology to his no-longer-estranged father, Charles. This last bit gives the actor Jeffrey DeMunn what may be the reaction of the night: As his son embraces him, he finally manages to mutter, \u201cO.K., O.K.\u201d The first \u201cO.K.\u201d says, \u201cUh, this was unexpected\u201d; the second says, \u201cBut I can work with it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWe come, then, back to where we started, at the table with Axe, Wags and Dufresne. \u201cAt the climax, I felt the crack of its little rib cage, and the hot juices rushing out down my gullet,\u201d Wags reports after the deed is done. \u201cSublime.\u201d And then, Wags being Wags, he adds: \u201cGot any more? I\u2019m still a little peckish.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou know what they say about ortolan,\u201d Dufresne says. \u201cOne is bliss, two is gluttony.\u201d\n\nWags isn\u2019t deterred: \u201cHow about three?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the time the ortolans are devoured, Bobby has already informed his ex-wife Lara of his plan to surrender, and she has warned him that she\u2019ll move his kids to California if he goes through with it. (Malin Akerman\u2019s skill at conveying Lara\u2019s hard-earned combination of anger and admiration for her ex should not be underestimated.) Chuck has told Wendy he, too, will fall on his sword to protect her, and she\u2019s forbidden him from doing so. Instead she arranges a three-person summit at Bobby\u2019s apartment: just her, Axe, Chuck and, unbeknown to either of the other participants, the telltale slide that Chuck is carrying in his pocket.\n\nWhat follows is the show\u2019s subtlest and smartest reference to popular culture\u2019s macho milestones yet. After exchanging unpleasantries and seeming to calm down at Wendy\u2019s command (you can take the woman out of the dominatrix dungeon \u2026), Chuck and Axe sit staring at each other from across the table until Chuck asks if he can be excused to go to the bathroom, and Bobby acquiesces.\n\nIf you\u2019ve seen \u201cThe Godfather\u201d \u2014 and God knows Chuck and Bobby have the thing memorized \u2014 you\u2019ll recognize what\u2019s going on here. Sneakily proceeding through the apartment, Chuck arrives at the bathroom and starts rummaging around. He\u2019s not exactly Michael Corleone looking for the revolver Tessio planted behind the old-fashioned toilet tank so he can come out guns blazing. But if he goes through with his plan to plant the slide and have the feds raid the place the next morning, the results will be nearly as devastating to Bobby as Michael\u2019s trip to the restroom was to Sollozzo and McCluskey.\n\nThere\u2019s just one problem, unspoken but obvious: If Chuck does this while under a flag of truce negotiated by Wendy, he\u2019ll likely shatter her trust, and their marriage, forever. You can\u2019t take a trip to the Sicilian countryside and wait out that kind of crime.\n\nWhen Chuck returns to the table, we in the audience have a few seconds to contemplate Schr\u00f6dinger\u2019s slide: Did he or didn\u2019t he plant it, enabling the feds to proceed in their case against Bobby without needing Wendy as a bargaining chip? Then, boom! He lays his cards, and the slide, on the table.\n\nAxe is stunned. Wendy is first surprised, then visibly relieved. \u201cI think you used to have a moral compass,\u201d Bryan told him earlier in the episode, \u201cand it served you, got you where you are, made you great. Then it got warped, or broken.\u201d Granted, Chuck is currently colluding with his nemesis in order to spare the three of them from Connerty\u2019s wrath, but still, his sudden change of heart is unmistakably an effort to find his moral magnetic north once again.\n\nFrom writer Alice O\u2019Neill to director John Dahl to composer Eskmo (whose pulsating score has never sounded better) to the entire cast, \u201cBillions\u201d has served up a miniature masterpiece of ethical conundrums, shortcuts and sacrifices, exacting and enjoyable from start to finish. Got any more? I\u2019m still a little peckish.", "title": "\u2018Billions\u2019 Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: Eat or Be Eaten", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "When Justin Peck emerged as a professional choreographer in 2012, he seemed immediately a master of his trade. His dances for the new revival of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical \u201cCarousel,\u201d at the Imperial Theater on Broadway, are yet another feather in his cap. Though just 30 years old, he\u2019s already acquired such renown that, in Matthew Lopez\u2019s new play \u201cThe Inheritance\u201d (now at the Young Vic in London), \u201cthe latest Justin Peck\u201d is spoken of as a must-see New York artistic event.\n\nMr. Peck remains a dancer (soloist rank) at New York City Ballet, where he has been the resident choreographer since 2014. He makes at least two new ballets for the company (and others around the world) each year, often to new or modern music. His works, polished and contemporary, are energetic through each individual body and in striking ensembles; and they often ask gender questions, with both opposite-sex and same-sex pairings. His main dance language is ballet. But he has also set dancers moving with tap steps in sneakers; in \u201cCarousel,\u201d they\u2019re sometimes barefoot.\n\nIn almost every piece he tackles, he adds to his already impressive accomplishments. In \u201cCarousel,\u201d he and the director, Jack O\u2019Brien, handle dancers so that there\u2019s no clear division between them and other actors onstage. And yet he gives us real dance virtuosity and ensembles containing speed and elaborate geometry. Still, though exuberantly executed, the dances don\u2019t stay with me as most of this \u201cCarousel\u201d does.\n\nThe hardest part of \u201cCarousel\u201d for a choreographer to bring off is the Act II ballet, witnessed by the dead Billy Bigelow. He sees Louise, his teenage daughter, becoming an angry and bitter outsider, alienated from the social world of her upbringing. This psychodrama can easily seem the most dated part of \u201cCarousel.\u201d Film exists of the original choreography by Agnes de Mille. It looks creaky now, making its points all too obviously and clearly influenced by Martha Graham and Antony Tudor, the two masters of psychological choreography and social consciousness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut even de Mille\u2019s tendency to overemphasize catches the dream quality that earns this ballet a special place in the overall drama of \u201cCarousel.\u201d Kenneth MacMillan \u2014 the master of sex, violence and acrobatic lifts in late 20th-century choreography \u2014 went further when he made the dances for Nicholas Hytner\u2019s 1992 production (which reached Broadway in 1994). (MacMillan\u2019s \u201cCarousel\u201d pas de deux still makes a vivid impression when performed out of context, as it did when the Royal Ballet brought it to New York in 2015.)", "title": "\u2018Carousel\u2019 Dances Are a New Feather in the Enigmatic Justin Peck\u2019s Cap", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Edward Kennedy, one of the most famous members of America\u2019s most famous family, understood that he belonged as much to popular culture as to political culture. Now, nine years after his death, comes a movie about the event that, almost as much as the circumstances of his birth, established him in the tabloid pantheon: Chappaquiddick.\n\nThe film, by the same name, opened Friday and retells the story of an accident in July 1969, on the titular Massachusetts island near Martha\u2019s Vineyard, in which Mr. Kennedy drove off a bridge, killing his passenger, Mary Jo Kopechne, a campaign worker for his late brother Robert. It has been heavily promoted by conservative media outlets, and reviewers across the political spectrum have praised what they deem its damning but factual approach. Damning it is; factual it is not.\n\nLet\u2019s set aside the fact that, despite the film\u2019s advertisements claiming to tell the \u201cuntold true story\u201d of a \u201ccover-up,\u201d the story has been told plenty, and no one but the most lunatic conspiracy theorists see this as anything but a tragic accident in which nothing much was covered up. Let\u2019s also put aside the skein of conjecture and outright fabrication that the film unspools \u2014 in one scene Joe Kennedy, the family patriarch, murmurs \u201calibi\u201d to his son, like a Mafia don, when in fact he was so debilitated by a stroke that he could only babble incoherently. Setting all this aside, the movie nevertheless raises a serious issue.\n\nWhat is the relationship of fact to fiction, of the historical to the histrionic in art and entertainment? Ted Kennedy was a real man living out a real life. His political opponents could and did distort that life for their advantage. But just how many liberties can an artist or entertainer take when he or she deploys a biographical subject?", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Chappaquiddick\u2019 Distorts a Tragedy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Not quite. Based on Kevin Kwan\u2019s best-selling novel, the romantic comedy follows the couple to Singapore, where Rachel learns that her boyfriend is the son of a super-wealthy family of developers. Amid this opulent setting, she finds herself in a seemingly universal situation: She\u2019s unable to impress her judgmental would-be mother-in-law (Michelle Yeoh).\n\n\u201cCrazy Rich Asians\u201d has generated some controversy over the casting of the biracial Mr. Golding as the male romantic lead. Identity issues also resonate throughout the film, as Rachel\u2019s pal (Awkwafina, who will also soon be seen in \u201cOcean\u2019s 8\u201d) tells her that Nick\u2019s mother \u201cthinks you\u2019re like some unrefined banana \u2014 yellow on the outside, white on the inside.\u201d\n\nDirected by Jon M. Chu (\u201cNow You See Me 2\u201d), \u201cCrazy Rich Asians\u201d will reach theaters on Aug. 17.", "title": "\u2018Crazy Rich Asians\u2019 Trailer Stars Henry Golding and Constance Wu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "In a Facebook post that followed Wednesday\u2019s verdict, Mr. Krim said he and his wife were \u201cdeceived and betrayed by the defendant\u2019s family, who remain wholly unaccountable for their role in the murders of our children.\u201d\n\nMs. Severino and Celia Ortega did not respond to email messages and telephone calls on Thursday.\n\nAssemblyman Steve Otis, a Westchester Democrat, said he is in the process of drafting legislation that would make it a crime for child care applicants to falsify information on their resumes.\n\n\u201cThe horrific case of the Krim family and what they experienced highlighted something familiar to everybody: the task of hiring caregivers,\u201d Mr. Otis said in a recent interview. \u201cUnder the current law, there isn\u2019t a legal duty to protect children.\u201d\n\nAccording to testimony during the trial, Ms. Ortega\u2019s family did not tell the Krims that she had scant experience caring for children \u2014 she had abandoned her own son when he was 4 leaving him with her sister in the Dominican Republic. She also had a long history of depression, paranoia and delusion, they testified.\n\nIt is not uncommon for parents to make child care decisions based on feedback from their peers, and hire caretakers \u2014 nannies or babysitters \u2014 who are paid off the books, in cash, parents and experts in the industry said. In New York City, parents face soaring costs and challenges finding high-quality, affordable care for their children, and typically rely on recommendations from others.\n\nAgencies and licensed child care centers tend to be much more expensive, an issue that extends beyond New York. While there are local and federal programs that provide subsidies to low-income parents to assist with child care, the system in America lacks the robust infrastructure that exists in countries like Denmark and Switzerland, experts said, where such services are partially government funded.\n\n\u201cPlaces like Britain and Denmark combine paid family leave for parents with newborns, along with public preschool,\u201d said Bruce Fuller, a professor of education and public policy at the University of California, Berkeley. He noted that New York State is \u201cahead of the game, recently expanding paid leave. But we\u2019re a half-century behind Europe in these societies\u2019 commitment to young families.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRegulation of child care in the country also varies from state to state and by type of care, but in-home providers are among the least monitored, experts said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis is a totally unregulated kind of child care,\u201d said Julia Wrigley, a sociology professor at the City University of New York, and the author of \u201cOther People\u2019s Children,\u201d about cultural differences in education. \u201cIt\u2019s in the employer\u2019s home. The people are not really vetted until they are already in the home.\u201d\n\nThings had gone relatively smoothly for the first 18 months of Ms. Ortega\u2019s employment at the Krim household. She was only asked to work about 20 hours a week, usually in the afternoons, as Ms. Krim was a stay-at-home mother. She was rarely left with the children alone for very long. She earned at least $500 a week and helped pick up and drop off the children.\n\nIn April 2012 things began to change. Ms. Ortega had a bitter fight with her sister Miladys Garcia and was kicked out of the family apartment on Riverside Drive. She moved into an apartment in the Bronx belonging to other family members. In June, she brought her teenage son back from the Dominican Republic to live with her.\n\nIn that time, Ms. Ortega became more and more depressed, her family testified. She began to talk cryptically about feeling she was being followed by shadows, hearing voices and seeing a \u201cblack man,\u201d relatives testified.
