She told her sisters to pray for her and to take care of Jesus, as if she were going away.\n\nShe also had conflicts with Ms. Krim. She chafed at doing housework, even after asking for additional hours, and declined an offer from one of Ms. Krim\u2019s friends for a part-time job. After that refusal, Ms. Krim chastised Ms. Ortega in front of her children\u2019s school, an exchange prosecutors said infuriated the nanny.\n\nBy late October, Ms. Ortega moved back into the family apartment on Riverside Drive. Three days before the murders, Ms. Ortega sought help from a psychologist, but neither she nor her relatives ever informed the Krim family of her declining mental state.\n\nOn Oct. 25, 2012, after taking her middle child, Nessie, to swim class, Ms. Krim returned to her Upper West Side apartment after 5 p.m. and found her two other children dead in a bathtub and Ms. Ortega shoving a large knife into her own neck.\n\nThe case shocked parents throughout the city who rely on others to help care for their children. Christa D. Nader, the president of Kith & Kin, a household staffing agency, said after the murders she recognized \u201ca noticeable level of distrust\u201d among some parents.\n\nMs. Nader said she was a nanny at the time of the murders and recounted being in a park . There were other nannies with children they were caring for. She recalled the sorrow in their faces, the tears and the constant \u2014 \u201cI don\u2019t understand how someone could do that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe had this shared horror,\u201d she said. \u201cOur city relies on nannies, relies on these quality folks to be the hands, feet, mouths and voices of parents, and something like that was beyond imagination.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Deceived and Betrayed\u2019 by Nanny\u2019s Family, Krims Want References Law", "authors": ["Jan Ransom", "James C. Mckinley Jr."]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "This picture is misleading when applied to today\u2019s populists like Mr. Orban. In Hungary, it is not just the rule of law that has been under threat. Rights essential for democracy itself \u2014 especially rights to free speech, free assembly and free association \u2014 have been systematically attacked. As media pluralism disappears, citizens cannot get critical information to make up their minds about their government\u2019s record. Unless one wants to say that a democracy remains a democracy as long as the government does not stuff the ballot boxes on Election Day, it is crucial to insist that democracy itself is being damaged.\n\nUnless this point is understood, Mr. Orban will continue the perfidious game he likes to play with international critics in particular: He does not mind being called \u201cilliberal\u201d; he relishes it. For liberalism is supposedly just a matter of subjective value choices: Liberals, he and his defenders will say, simply do not like his conservative family policies, his defense of strong nation-states inside the European Union and, most of all, his complete rejection of immigration. Of course, one can legitimately disagree about these issues in a democracy. But by focusing all attention on them, Mr. Orban has remade what should be a debate about democratic institutions into yet another culture war. (This is a strategy Trumpists are also discovering.) Once the conflict has been declared a matter of subjective values, it becomes easy to accuse the liberals of being the real illiberals. Even though they are supposed to be the defenders of diversity, they cannot tolerate an ethnic nationalist like Mr. Orban, who seeks to deviate from a supposed Western mainstream of multiculturalism.\n\nA number of observers are even willing to concede that \u201cilliberal democracy\u201d might be a somewhat legitimate reaction to undemocratic liberalism. The European Union appears as an obvious instance of a liberal technocracy against which \u201cthe will of the people\u201d needs to be asserted. But the European Union prescribes neither a uniform legislative stance on controversial questions like same-sex marriage nor a single model of democracy. Its members just have to be democratic enough.\n\nWhen European Union leaders have criticized Hungary and, more recently, Poland, those countries\u2019 governments have countered that they are defending national sovereignty against liberal diktats from Brussels. The Union has played into their hands by suggesting that it is only concerned about the liberal rule of law. The European Union thus gives the impression that democracy will always be taken care of by the nation-state; and the technocratic liberal repair crew from Brussels only makes a call in a European capital, if there is a malfunction with the rule of law (hence the undermining of political rights and independent institutions appears like a technical glitch, not as the conscious authoritarian project it actually is.)\n\nThe notion of \u201cilliberal democracy\u201d has also made it easier for European elites to claim that the people themselves have unfortunately turned out to be illiberal and brought these authoritarian governments on themselves. Eastern Europeans, we are often told, are culturally different \u2014 code for thinking that they lag behind Western liberal enlightenment. But the citizens who brought Mr. Orban and the current Polish government to power actually did exactly what democratic theory would have counseled them to do: In two-party systems, they threw out the one major party that had a poor record and instead voted for politicians who, in both cases, presented themselves as moderate mainstream conservatives. The latter never revealed \u2014 or won an electoral mandate for \u2014 their real agenda, of perpetuating themselves in power by attacking the institutions that underpin democracy.\n\nIs all this just a matter of words? Thinkers like George Orwell and Hannah Arendt never tired of warning that the political catastrophes of the 20th century began with euphemisms and imprecise language. A democracy can have illiberal policies, but it cannot do without basic political liberties and protections. We are doing Mr. Orban a great favor by accepting him as any kind of democrat. The designation \u201cdemocracy\u201d still remains the most coveted political prize around the world. In what can only be called an unforced error, we are giving that prize to leaders who not only devalue it, but are also busy destroying the thing itself.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Democracy\u2019 Still Matters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Tumors have mutations that stud them with bizarre proteins. The white blood cells of the immune system try to attack but are repelled by a molecular shield created by the tumors. The new drugs allow white blood cells to pierce that shield and destroy the tumors.\n\nLast week brought a yet another example of the surprising power of this approach. Lung cancer patients who normally would receive only chemotherapy lived longer when immunotherapy was added, researchers reported in a clinical trial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the drugs are exorbitantly expensive. One that Dr. Sartor often uses costs $9,000 per dose if used once every three weeks, and $7,000 if used once every two weeks. Often, he and other doctors persuade a patient\u2019s insurer to pay. If that fails, sometimes the maker will provide the drug free of charge.\n\nImmunotherapy drugs can have severe side effects that can even lead to death. Once the immune system is activated, it may attack normal tissues as well as tumors. The result can be holes in the intestines, liver failure, nerve damage that can cause paralysis, serious rashes and eye problems, and problems with the pituitary, adrenal or thyroid glands. Side effects can arise during treatment or after the treatment is finished.\n\nFor most patients, though, there are no side effects or only minor ones. That makes giving an immunotherapy drug to a dying patient different from trying a harsh experimental chemotherapy or a treatment like intense radiation.\n\nThe problem is deciding ahead of time if an immunotherapy drug will help. Doctors check biomarkers, chemical signals like proteins that arise when the immune system is trying to attack. But they are not very reliable.\n\n\u201cA positive biomarker does not guarantee that a patient will benefit, and a negative biomarker does not mean a patient will not benefit,\u201d said Dr. Richard Schilsky, senior vice president and chief medical officer of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. \u201cYou don\u2019t have a solid biology to go on.\u201d\n\nIt was this problem, described at a medical conference a couple of years ago, that led Dr. Sartor to begin offering immunotherapy to dying patients.\n\n\u201cI was thinking, \u2018My God, these tests that are used to drive clinical decision making are not worth a damn,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThese are peoples\u2019 lives here. We are playing with the highest of stakes.\u201d\n\n\u201cFor certain people it is like, bingo, you give the drug to them and they have a long-lasting and positive benefit,\u201d he added. \u201cWhen our knowledge is not sufficient to inform our decisions, then we have an ethical conundrum.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Desperation Oncology\u2019: When Patients Are Dying, Some Cancer Doctors Turn to Immunotherapy", "authors": ["Gina Kolata"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Team owners, players and league executives held a confidential meeting in October, when they were under sharp criticism from President Trump over national anthem protests. [The full story on the private meeting is here.]\n\n\u201cThe problem we have is, we have a president who will use that as fodder to do his mission that I don\u2019t feel is in the best interests of America. Owners Made About Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "She stared down the iconic \u201cCharging Bull\u201d of Wall Street \u2014 and now she could make it move.\n\nThe statue known as \u201cFearless Girl\u201d will soon be moved from its spot at the southern tip of Broadway to a spot facing the New York Stock Exchange, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday. And if the city has its way, the bull will eventually go with her.\n\nThough visitors had posed with the bull for years, larger crowds had gathered since the \u201cFearless Girl\u201d statue, commissioned by State Street Global Advisors, a Boston-based financial firm, was placed in front of the bull at the narrow corner atop Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan last March.\n\nSo after deciding to allow the sculpture \u2014 placed temporarily at the spot \u2014 to remain for a year, city officials came to the conclusion that the number of pedestrians spilling into the streets created a safety hazard. Also, after the deadly attack with a truck last year in Lower Manhattan, officials said they worried that crowds around the two statues could present a tempting target for a terrorist behind the wheel.\n\nThe new location by the stock exchange is an area that is already heavily restricted to traffic, where huge numbers of pedestrians but few cars pass through.", "title": "\u2018Fearless Girl\u2019 to Move, and She May Take the Wall Street Bull With Her", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "A common refrain among conservatives is that black people should get over slavery. Even though conservatives refuse to.\n\nLast week, the Tennessee legislature withheld $250,000 from Memphis\u2019s bicentennial celebration budget, punishing the majority-black city for removing three Confederate monuments. Memphis had circumvented a state law prohibiting the removal of historical monuments by selling the parks that held statues of Nathan Bedford Forrest, the first head of the Ku Klux Klan; Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy; and Capt. J. Harvey Mathes, a Confederate soldier, to a nonprofit that took the monuments down last year.\n\nThe legislature\u2019s move to rebuke Memphis for honoring the wishes of its people continues an ugly tradition of mostly white Southern state legislatures yanking power away from cities with multiracial or majority-black leadership or voters when those cities act in ways meant to benefit their minority residents.\n\nIn 1917, the Georgia legislature established the county unit system, which operated until 1962 and allotted votes by county in primary elections instead of allowing the popular vote to decide those elections. So candidates could win the county unit vote without winning the popular vote.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Fightin\u2019 to Keep Slavery\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "It was the fall of 2004, and I was touring a film set at the studio that was adapting my war memoir, \u201cJarhead.\u201d The screenwriter walked me onto a soundstage that was supposed to look like my Marine Corps boot-camp barracks. It was small and inconsequential compared with the mighty buildings and squad bays on Marine Corps Recruit Depot, San Diego, where I survived grueling training and verbal abuse 16 years earlier. Still, the room gave off an ominous vibe. The drab colors were right. The bunks were tightly cornered. It closely resembled a boot-camp set from a movie I\u2019d watched many times before. A ghost filled the room: Marine Gunnery Sergeant Hartman.\n\nThe screenwriter, himself a Marine veteran of the Vietnam era, admitted to me that there was no way the filmmakers could ever top the \u201cFull Metal Jacket\u201d boot-camp sequences that were brought to life so intensely by R. Lee Ermey, a Marine Corps veteran who served two years as a drill instructor in the 1960s. The only thing they could try was homage to a famous scene and its defining character.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t just the film world on which Ermey\u2019s character left an impression. The Gunny\u2019s persona saturated military culture, especially that of the Marine Corps. The boys who wanted to serve believed that intimidation and humiliation were essential to the formation of their warrior selves. And drill instructors were happy to oblige.\n\nWhen the film was released in 1987, I watched it in a theater in Sacramento with a few other knuckleheads who were destined to join the Marine Corps. Because of Stanley Kubrick\u2019s previous work, many viewers expected a purely antiwar film. And they might have seen just that. But what we saw felt beautiful and profane and dangerous \u2014 normal American kids transformed into war-ready combatants through barbarism and violence and the best marksmanship training in the world. It was both terrifying and thrilling to watch. I wanted to experience the brutality and humiliation that \u201cFull Metal Jacket\u201d so fully embodied.", "title": "\u2018Full Metal Jacket\u2019 Seduced My Generation and Sent Us to War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nThe van massacre that traumatized Toronto on Monday was amplified by the spread of smartphone videos that showed the police arresting the driver, repeatedly screaming at him to lie on the ground as he dares them to shoot him in the head.\n\nThe videos quickly trended on Twitter and other social media.\n\n\u201cC\u2019mon, get down!\u201d an officer pointing a weapon yells at the driver, standing outside the damaged white van in the middle of the afternoon. \u201cGet down or you\u2019ll be shot!\u201d\n\nThe driver responds: \u201cI have a gun in my pocket!\u201d and \u201cShoot me in the head!\u201d\n\nThe Toronto Star created a montage of videos that showed the confrontation from different vantage points on the street and from a high-rise window, ending with the driver being subdued and arrested.\n\nThe police appeared to show extraordinary restraint about shooting the driver \u2014 a caution that may have reflected a new sensitivity about lethal use of force.\n\nVideo\n\nIn Canada there have been many videos of police officers killing or fatally wounding people in states of clear mental distress.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe most famous, perhaps, is the use of a Taser stun gun in 2007 on Robert Dzieka\u0144ski, a Polish immigrant to Canada who was agitated after waiting more than nine hours in the Vancouver airport and began to throw furniture. Although he was unarmed, the police struck him with Taser guns multiple times soon after arriving at the scene. He died shortly after.", "title": "\u2018Get Down or You\u2019ll Be Shot!\u2019: Videos of Van Driver\u2019s Arrest Captivate Social Media", "authors": ["Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "I walked into my college dorm in Iowa, looking for my African-American roommate from Yazoo City, Miss. Someone said, \u201cShe\u2019s in your room.\u201d When I opened the door, she was sitting by the window and turned to me. We said nothing and then broke down and cried in each other\u2019s arms. \u2014 Kathy Rayson, Pompano Beach, Fla.\n\nImage Ronald Spainhour was a teacher in Durham, N.C., and concerned what the death of Dr. King would mean for his students. Credit Courtesy of Ronald Spainhour\n\nDr. King\u2019s assassination was announced at the performance of a play I was attending at a black college in Durham, N.C. I was a young white instructor teaching for the first time. The news was shocking, and my first concern was for my students and what Dr. King\u2019s death meant for them. But there was little time to think of that as I was being escorted out of the auditorium by one of the black professors. I did not feel in danger but quickly found myself in a campus police car being driven away with a few other white people. \u2014 Ronald Spainhour, New York City\n\nBurning, Looting and the Fulfillment of Duties\n\nImage Linda Gartz was at her parents\u2019 house in Chicago when she heard the news on television. Credit Fred Gartz courtesy of Linda Gartz\n\nI was at my parents\u2019 house in Chicago. We heard the news that night on TV. My white parents still owned and cared for buildings in our home community on Chicago\u2019s West Side, which by 1968 was about 95 percent black. On April 5, a tenant called. \u201cDon\u2019t come down here,\u201d she said. \u201cThey\u2019re turning over white people\u2019s cars.\u201d My childhood neighborhood, the places where I\u2019d shopped, was in flames. My parents went there anyway on April 6 to take care of a furnace problem. No riots were going to keep them from their duty. \u2014 Linda Gartz, Evanston, Ill.\n\nActs of Valor, Acts of Cowardice\n\nImage Dawn McCarron just before her eighth-grade graduation dance, which was two months after the assassination of Dr. King and hours before the death of her \u201cother hero,\u201d Senator Robert F. Kennedy, who was shot on June 5, 1968. Credit Larry McCarron courtesy of Dawn McCarron\n\nI was 13, living in Carmichael, Calif., a predominantly white suburb of Sacramento. At school the day after the assassination, three of us walked to the flagpole and asked the custodian to lower the flag. Pointing to the office, he said he couldn\u2019t unless someone from there told him to. The vice principal came out to see what was going on and said he would meet with just one of us to calmly discuss it. We agreed that Melanie would be our spokeswoman. After her meeting, she told us he fed her a pile of administrative platitudes: \u201cIt\u2019s out of my hands. There are protocols to make a decision like this. Blah, blah, blah.\u201d We couldn\u2019t get them to lower the flag, but we tried. \u2014 Dawn McCarron, Carmichael, Calif.\n\nI had returned home from the Vietnam War and was stationed in Maine. I saw Senator Robert F. Kennedy tell the crowd that Dr. King had been killed in Memphis. A fellow Airman said, \u201cI think he was a communist.\u201d I remained quiet. \u201cI don\u2019t know,\u201d I said. To this day I regret not vouching for Dr. King. \u2014 Richard James, Williamsport, Pa.\n\nAshamed and Defeated\n\nIn the black community, the debate back then was Dr. King versus the black separatists, and the fact is that many of us decided to back Dr. King. That\u2019s why his being shot hurt so much. \u2014 Gregory Abdur Rahman, Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\nImage Randy Hurst was a college freshman, recently out of the Navy, when Dr. King was assassinated. Credit Courtesy of Randy Hurst\n\nI was just out of the Navy in 1968 and a freshman in college. As a white male who served with many African-American men when we were at war, I felt ashamed of my country, disgrace. \u2014 Randy Hurst , Orange County, N.Y.", "title": "\u2018Glee, Satisfaction and Weeping\u2019: How America Reacted When Martin Luther King Died", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "A Mind-Opening Experience\n\n\u201cHair,\u201d for me, affirmed that there was something beyond the working class town I grew up in \u2014 people with ideas, principles, flaws and flowers and people who would make the ultimate sacrifice for a friend. A peace-loving, antiwar counterculture, or its contemporary counterpart, was alive and well and waiting for me. ERICA V. PLOUFFE\n\nI saw it on Broadway in 1969. It was part of my high school graduation present \u2014 a trip to New York with my mom. It was the same weekend as Woodstock, but my mom so looked forward to this trip, I didn\u2019t even think of trying to leave. \u201cHair\u201d was the most counterculture happening you could get into back then, and my mom, the socialite wife of a Florida doctor, was one of the first to jump up and go onstage to dance with the cast. ARDEE WNC\n\nI saw \u201cHair\u201d in Minneapolis in 1972 when I was a senior in high school. When the cast came out from under a large parachute naked and proud I gasped a little bit and my friend sitting next to me said, \u201cThis is theater!\u201d SALLY TAYLOR PHILLIPS\n\nIt had a large impact on me seeing a tour of it in San Francisco as a teen in the early 90s. It was one of the first shows I saw with a truly diverse cast addressing race, sexual preference and politics as opposed to traditional musical narratives about white romance or cats. KEVIN T. MORALES\n\nPolitically Relevant Then and Now\n\nIn 2009, when I was 14, my dad took me to New York for Christmas to see \u201cHair.\u201d I didn\u2019t know that theater could be like that \u2014 ask questions and demand answers. As long as there is war, as long as there is violence, as long as there are people living on the outside of society, \u201cHair\u201d will be relevant and necessary. RACHEL ANNE WALSH\n\nI saw it in Los Angeles in \u201968 or \u201969. It was considered shocking, with nudity, songs about drugs and antiwar. We \u2014 the boomer generation \u2014 were young with our lives in front of us. The musical gave us hope for something better in our future, that perhaps we didn\u2019t need to fight wars like our parents did. That the world might find a different way. PENNI DAVIS\n\nI think the musical still resonates today because of the rise of the young people against the current administration. It opened my eyes about standing up for something and not being afraid to protest the issue. JSUN", "title": "\u2018Hair\u2019 50 Years Later: Readers Tell Us When They Let the Sunshine In", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 \u201cHamilton,\u201d the historical hip-hop musical about the United States\u2019 first Treasury secretary, dominated the Olivier Awards on Sunday night, scooping up seven trophies at the British equivalent of the Tony Awards.\n\nThe trophies for the show, which opened in London in December, included best new musical; best sound design; best lighting; and best theater choreographer.\n\nGiles Terera, who plays Alexander Hamilton\u2019s nemesis, Aaron Burr, won best actor in a musical; he was up against Jamael Westman, who plays the musical\u2019s title role. Michael Jibson was named best actor in a supporting role in a musical for his portrayal of King George III.\n\nLin-Manuel Miranda, the musical\u2019s creator and composer-lyricist, was also awarded on honor for outstanding achievement in music. He shared the award with Alex Lacamoire, the show\u2019s orchestrator. On the telephone that night, they spoke of Ms. Perez\u2019s upcoming trip to visit him in Nashville. He said he would see her on Wednesday, when he planned to pick her up at the airport.\n\n\u201cAnd now I will never see him again,\u201d she said. \u201cHe was my baby.\u201d\n\n[Read about the man who wrested the AR-15 away from the gunman.]\n\nDeEbony Groves, 21\n\nMs. Groves was a college senior who held two jobs, working shifts when she could step away from her classes and homework at Belmont University in Nashville. Despite her busy schedule, Ms. Groves always found time to visit her grandmother.\n\n\u201cEvery chance she could get,\u201d her grandmother, Carolyn Groves, said in an interview.\n\nThe visits were usually spur of the moment. Ms. Groves would call her grandmother before lunchtime, say she wanted to spend the day with her and then head to her home in Portland, northeast of Nashville. She always brought food, either a sub sandwich to split or McDonald\u2019s.\n\n\u201cShe was a sweetheart,\u201d her grandmother said.\n\nMs. Groves grew up in Gallatin, a Nashville suburb, and attended Gallatin High School. Sanderlin, 29\n\nMr. Sanderlin, of Goodlettsville, Tenn., was a Waffle House employee.\n\nThe Tennessean reported that the customer who wrested the gun away, James Shaw Jr., overheard Mr. Sanderlin say he was going to take a break before heading outside. Mr. Sanderlin was shot and killed outside the restaurant, the police said.\n\nWalter G. Ehmer, the chief executive of Waffle House, said Mr. Sanderlin had worked for the restaurant chain for about five years. The restaurant where the shooting took place had been open about five months.\n\nA man reached by phone who identified himself as Mr. Sanderlin\u2019s brother declined to comment.\n\nAkilah Dasilva, 23\n\nMr. Dasilva was a musician and videographer, creating and performing under the name Natrix Dream. He attended Middle Tennessee State University for two semesters, and was last enrolled in 2013, Jimmy Hart, a spokesman for the university, said. His proposed major was computer engineering technology, Mr. Hart said.\n\nAs a musician, Mr. Dasilva kept up an online archive of work as he produced it, sometimes in coordination with his brother, Abede. Mr. Dasilva was with his partner, Tia Waggoner, and his brother at the restaurant the night of the shooting, The Tennessean reported.\n\n\u201cMusic is my life and I will never stop until I achieve my dreams,\u201d he wrote on his Twitter page.\n\nMs. Waggoner wrote on Facebook that they had been together for five years. Hood ex machina wasn\u2019t intended to be entirely random. Perhaps it\u2019s a manifestation of all the anger on display earlier in the episode. Malcolm punches Ramon for throwing Hailey out of the treehouse. Duc finally unloads on Greg about the \u201cmoral crime\u201d of sleeping with an Asian prostitute when he knows Duc\u2019s mother was also an Asian prostitute. Greg calls out Duc for sleeping around in Vancouver when he professes to be celibate. (Did you find it likely that Greg would have heard gossip about his son picking up random Canadian women in bars? I did not.) When Navid tries to downgrade his relationship with Kristen back to a friendship, she blows up at him. On the air at a local morning show, Audrey dresses down Steve for using the Empathy Initiative to cover for his company\u2019s ties to child labor. Ashley is upset that her prospective employer sees her as a \u201cdiversity hire\u201d and exasperated when Malcolm tries to convince her to take the job anyway.\n\nIn the episode\u2019s most maudlin story line, the cause of Farid\u2019s repressed trauma finally comes into focus. Made to flog himself in a public square, as a child, for defacing a poster of the Ayatollah \u2014 and then beaten to a pulp by his mentally ill mother, a pious Muslim who believed Farid\u2019s irreverent act had gotten his father killed \u2014 he was rescued and taken to America by his uncle, Amir. Decades later, deep in the throes of his own mental illness, he tearfully flogs himself out of guilt over his father\u2019s death and his mother\u2019s decades-old unanswered telephone calls. He won\u2019t listen when his wife and son assure him that he\u2019s not responsible for what happened to his parents. Afraid for herself and their child, Layla takes Navid and leaves.\n\nFarid finds himself at Imam Chuck\u2019s door, the back of his white jacket stained with blood in the shape of angel wings. There\u2019s nothing subtle about the symbolism on \u201cHere and Now,\u201d and that\u2019s not necessarily a bad thing. But not even an actor as talented as Peter Macdissi, who plays Farid and is an executive producer of the show, can pull off material this overwrought.\n\nIf Farid\u2019s bloody search for meaning in Islam is a figurative ascent to heaven, then there\u2019s something hellish about Ramon\u2019s pursuit of the man on fire. Because he\u2019s at the top of a nearby hill when the eruption happens, he has to descend to the foot of Mt. Hood (in a mask so flimsy he\u2019s surely inhaling all types of harmful gases) for his climactic encounter with the flaming figure. When they lock eyes, dozens of wispy humanoid shadows begin to float upward on the ashy ground behind Ramon. Then, the burning man walks away and Ramon strides toward the volcano. It\u2019s a cryptic final shot, made even more ambiguous by the deceptively upbeat but actually quite dark Brian Eno track \u201cBaby\u2019s on Fire,\u201d which plays over the closing credits.\n\nStill, there\u2019s a cathartic mood to this conclusion that mirrors many characters\u2019 journeys from anger to relative peacefulness late in the episode. Duc turns to Carmen, whose intuitive powers begin to heal his nervous stomach, as they embark on a union that could become his first healthy sexual relationship. Kristen and Navid reconcile before he leaves town. Greg seems strangely comforted by his visit with Ike. The imam literally helps to heal Farid\u2019s wounds.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1 Finale: Baby\u2019s on Fire", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 8: \u2018Yes\u2019\n\nFinally, Duc Bayer-Boatwright gets his moment in the sun. Don\u2019t get too excited; it\u2019s not that he has a psychological breakthrough or stops being a jerk or even has a particularly substantial story line in this week\u2019s episode of \u201cHere and Now.\u201d For the second week in a row, he\u2019s gritting his teeth through a colitis flare-up \u2014 and Ramon\u2019s poop jokes aren\u2019t helping. Duc\u2019s big scene takes place during a hike with his love interest, Carmen. Doubled over in pain, he gets so frantic about finding a place to relieve himself that he falls down a hill and exits the date in an ambulance.\n\nDuc is, in other words, as hapless as ever in Episode 8. But that makes him the ideal avatar for this week\u2019s theme, as revealed in Greg\u2019s lecture. As an introduction to a lesson on \u201cThe Myth of Sisyphus,\u201d Albert Camus\u2019s essay on embracing the absurdity of a meaningless life over suicide, Professor Boatwright alarms his students by pressing a gun to his chin and demanding a reason not to pull the trigger. By persisting, he explains, \u201cWe become the absurdist hero, seeking meaning we know is not there, living life to its fullest in the face of a consistent and continuous struggle and inevitable failure.\u201d When the stunt ends in an involuntary six-month leave, the irony is that Greg\u2019s message to students was actually pretty life affirming, for once.\n\nSisyphus, a character from Greek mythology, was condemned to spend eternity pushing a boulder up a hill, only to watch it fall each time to the bottom. Grim as that fate may seem, Camus reframes Sisyphus as an absurdist hero, scrambling fruitlessly but nobly to make meaning for as long as he can keep the rock that is his life rolling. \u201cThe struggle itself toward the heights is enough to fill a man\u2019s heart,\u201d Camus writes in the essay\u2019s famous conclusion. \u201cOne must imagine Sisyphus happy.\u201d Considering that few afflictions scream absurdity like a benign yet incurable bout of diarrhea, I assume there\u2019s some symbolism in Duc\u2019s tumble down the hill.\n\nUsually, Ramon and Audrey are the show\u2019s great rock pushers, fighting tirelessly for empathy in a world that keeps knocking it down in favor of fear. But this week, both characters take some time off from their respective forms of martyrdom. Audrey, who is always there to comfort and nag her husband and children, skips a family dinner to consummate her flirtation with Steve. (She can thank Ashley for giving her the sexy heels that catch his eye.) Arriving at home next morning, she takes pleasure in informing a gloomy Greg of her conquest.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 8: The Absurdist Hero", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 9: \u2018Dream Logic\u2019\n\n\u201cGet ready for the future: It is murder,\u201d the prophet Leonard Cohen warned in one of his bleakest songs, \u201cThe Future.\u201d That lyric popped into my head midway through this week\u2019s episode of \u201cHere and Now\u201d and lingered there for quite a while afterward. Although it didn\u2019t actually feature any coldblooded killings, the episode, which is the penultimate chapter of Season 1, was the show\u2019s darkest and best hour to date. It was also the first episode in which many of the characters were forced to think seriously about their futures.\n\nThat reflection gave us a bit of welcome, if overdue, insight into the two Bayer-Boatwright kids whose ham-handed arcs have frustrated me for most of the season. In her first story line since the series premiere that isn\u2019t primarily about her race, Ashley fields a larger company\u2019s seven-figure offer to buy her clothing business. They want to close her shop so that she\u2019s free to help them build \u201ca tool so that every shopper can create their own perfect store.\u201d She tells her brothers that she\u2019s worried that if she becomes someone else\u2019s employee, she\u2019ll lose control of her own life. Duc suggests that she may actually be scared of getting what she wants.\n\nRamon, whom we\u2019ll return to later, is facing a similar choice: Should he take a job with a company that might one day develop his game, even if that means starting at the bottom and working on other people\u2019s projects first?\n\nOne person Ashley doesn\u2019t consult about the offer is her husband, Malcolm. Tensions between the two of them have been mounting since the premiere. His lack of ambition clashes with her Type A personality and longing for a more exciting life than the one she has with him and their daughter, Hailey. Ashley\u2019s recent, tentative embrace of her black identity also has her questioning her marriage to a white man. So, when he finds out that she hasn\u2019t told him about an opportunity that could have huge implications for their family, the conflict between the spouses finally (but inconclusively) explodes. This is all solid character development.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 9: Future Tense", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "President Ronald Reagan established a limited pool of imports that it apportioned among foreign producers. The first President George Bush renewed it. Mr. Clinton deployed diplomacy and antidumping measures to protect American steel makers. And in 2002 President George W. Bush put a new ring of \u201csafeguards\u201d around steel that lasted 20 months, until the World Trade Organization ruled them illegal.\n\nThey mostly shrugged off the repercussions for the many manufacturing companies that relied on steel. But in 2003, the United States International Trade Commission surveyed manufacturers about the effects. Not only did the tariffs imposed by the Bush administration put many American companies at a competitive disadvantage, but companies also reacted in ways that did the American economy no good.\n\nAlmost 500 steel consumers responded to at least some of the questions asked by the commission. About half of respondents reported paying higher prices. And roughly half reported problems procuring steel of the quality and quantity they needed. Over a third reported delayed deliveries; 132 reported steel shortages. About one in six said these problems had reduced sales, and one in three said they had cut into its profitability. A total of 82 companies \u2014 including 11 makers of auto parts, nine welded-pipe producers and five makers of fasteners \u2014 said they had lost sales to foreign competitors because of the higher cost of steel.\n\nSome steel consumers shifted from importing steel to importing assembled steel parts that were not subject to the new tariffs. York International \u2014 which makes air-conditioning systems, furnaces and the like \u2014 reported importing steel assemblies and complete products from overseas. The auto-part maker Metaldyne simply moved some of its operations to South Korea, where it could obtain cheaper steel.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Larsen is sympathetic to the plight of American steel companies. Though it is owned today by Everest Kanto Cylinder based in Mumbai, India, CP Industries emerged as an independent company in a 1989 spinoff from U.S. Steel. And still, whatever old loyalties persist, it makes little sense to force the company to obtain its steel domestically. For starters, no company in the United States produces pipes big enough to make its trademark six-ton containers.\n\nThe company estimated that it could get only a fifth of the steel pipe it needed domestically, from only one American firm. Domestic pipe is, moreover, delivered in random lengths and requires additional milling, cutting and testing, raising processing costs by about 16 percent. And Chinese pipes are much cheaper, the company added: Pipes from China delivered in Philadelphia cost $1,680 per metric ton, while U.S. Steel is charging $2,728 per metric ton at its works in Lorain, Ohio. A 25 percent tariff will not close the gap.\n\nPhoto\n\nCP Industries isn\u2019t simply going to let itself be pushed out of business. An option to consider is importing German steel \u2014 which so far has been exempted from the protectionist fusillade. But it will take time to shift suppliers. And German steel will be more expensive.\n\nOf course, there is lobbying. CP Industries has requested a waiver from the tariffs, and it is working to get Pennsylvania\u2019s congressional delegation on its side. Something else it could do is move part or all of the manufacturing process overseas to avoid the steel tariffs.\n\n\u201cWe have a whole list of ideas that we could execute,\u201d Mr. Larsen told me. \u201cBut nothing we do will be more efficient than what we are doing now. And it will mean less value added in the United States.\u201d\n\nMr. Larsen is not, by the way, an evangelist for free trade at all costs. Six years ago, when he was at Taylor-Wharton International, a manufacturer of smaller vessels for high-pressure gas, he teamed up with Norris Cylinder to bring an antidumping case against Chinese rivals and won. The government imposed an antidumping duty on Chinese imports to level the playing field.\n\nHe would love to try that approach against his new Chinese competitors. But Mr. Trump nipped the strategy in the bud: Dumping \u2014 selling below cost in order to drive rivals out of business and gain market share \u2014 is not necessary when you are suddenly granted a 10 percent cost advantage. That\u2019s roughly the kind of edge that the steel tariffs gave the makers of high-pressure gas vessels in China.\n\n\u201cAs it stands today,\u201d Mr. Larsen lamented, \u201cthey cannot be overcome.\u201d", "title": "\u2018How Long Can We Last?\u2019 Trump\u2019s Tariffs Hit Home in the U.S.", "authors": ["Eduardo Porter", "Economic Scene"]} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 With hashtags like #Iamgaynotapervert and images of hearts and rainbows, tens of thousands of Chinese residents took to social media over the weekend to protest efforts to censor gay-themed images, videos and cartoons.\n\nThe uproar was in response to a vow on Friday by Sina Weibo, one of China\u2019s most popular social media sites, to delete posts relating to gay culture, part of a three-month \u201ccleanup\u201d effort.\n\nSina Weibo, a site similar to Twitter, said in its announcement that it was trying to limit the spread of sexually suggestive and violent content and that it would target cartoons, pictures, texts, short videos and romantic fiction. The site said its aim was to promote a \u201cclear and harmonious\u201d environment and to comply with stricter cybersecurity laws put in place by President Xi Jinping.\n\nBut many users were incensed, saying the campaign was another sign of discrimination against lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in China, more than two decades after the country decriminalized homosexuality.", "title": "\u2018I Am Gay, Not a Pervert\u2019: Furor in China as Sina Weibo Bans Gay Content", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "NAIROBI, Kenya \u2014 Twenty-six journalists have been murdered in Somalia in the past decade. Nobody has ever been tried or convicted in these murders. Somalia has sat atop the Committee to Protect Journalists\u2019 Global Impunity Index \u2014 a list of the worst countries for the unsolved murders of journalists \u2014 for the past three years.\n\nThe Somali media is a battleground where government officials try to control the daily narrative, powerful businessmen are out to protect their business and clan interests, and Shabab militants attempt to intimidate the country\u2019s mostly young and badly paid journalists through death threats.\n\nOne afternoon in the winter of 2012, Hassan Ali Ismaan, a 27-year-old security and politics reporter for Dalsan Radio, a popular privately owned Somali radio station, joined his friends for a weekly soccer game in the Wadajir district of Mogadishu. Before he entered the field in an Arsenal jersey, he left his phone with a friend watching the game, asking him to alert him if he got a call from work.\n\nMr. Ismaan had played for about 15 minutes when his friend walked over with the phone. He took the call. \u201cI can see you,\u201d the caller said, with a menacing nonchalance. \u201cI know what you\u2019re wearing.\u201d Mr. Ismaan scanned the field, hoping to identify the caller among the couple of dozen spectators. \u201cHow will you leave here alive?\u201d the voice said.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018I Can See You. How Will You Leave Here Alive?\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "Two years ago, Boulder surveyed its students and found that 45 percent of high school students had used e-cigarettes, with 30 percent as current users. Officials say they expect the most recent survey, taken last year, to show about 45 percent of middle school students have used e-cigarettes.\n\nThe 2017 Monitoring the Future survey on adolescent drug use found that 11 percent of 12th graders, 8.5 percent of 10th graders and 3.5 percent of 8th graders had vaped nicotine in the previous 30 days. Of those high school seniors, 24 percent reported vaping daily, which the study defined as vaping on 20 or more occasions in the previous 30 days, said Richard A. Miech, a professor at the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan and a principal investigator of the study. Nineteen percent reported vaping on 40 or more occasions during that period.\n\nFifty-six percent reported vaping only on one to five occasions. Gregory Conley, the president of the American Vaping Association, which supports what he calls \u201cfair and sensible\u201d regulation of e-cigarettes, said that number indicated that most students who are vaping are not becoming addicted. \u201cYou can\u2019t use the definition of dependence and apply it to anyone using only one to five days in the prior month,\u201d he said.\n\nSchools say that unlike adults, most students who vape are starting out as nonsmokers.\n\n\u201cI have the same conversation with every student we catch vaping,\u201d said Scott Carpenter, the dean for discipline at Cumberland High School in Rhode Island. \u201cI say, \u2018If I handed you a cigarette would you smoke it?\u2019 And 100 percent of them look at you like you\u2019re absolutely crazy for even suggesting that they\u2019d do that.\u201d\n\nFederal law prohibits the sale of e-cigarettes to anyone under 18, and Juul and some other e-cigarette companies ask web purchasers to check a box saying that they are 21 or older. But the growing vaping industry has many items and campaigns that seem to appeal specifically to youth. There are vaping cloud contests, a line of hoodies and backpacks called VaprWear that make it easy to conceal the devices, and labels of vape \u201csauce\u201d that resemble the designs of well-known candy wrappers like those of Jolly Ranchers and Blow Pops.\n\nIn Millburn, N.J., one of the school districts that now require any student caught with a vaping device to be drug tested, teenagers said Juuls began showing up at parties last year, and by fall were at school and football games. Now, students post videos of themselves doing vapor tricks on social media.\n\nAt a local deli where seniors go for lunch, a dozen students interviewed said it was easy to buy a Juul online or at a gas station or convenience store, and to buy refill pods in the hallway at school. None would publicly admit to owning a device, but all said they had tried vaping.", "title": "\u2018I Can\u2019t Stop\u2019: Schools Struggle With Vaping Explosion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "She showed up for \u201cLucia\u201d at the Met this month with clear ideas about the opera and the inner strength of the character, a role closely associated with great divas like Maria Callas and Joan Sutherland. To rescue her family from ruin, Lucia is bullied by her brother into marrying a wealthy lord rather than her beloved Edgardo, who comes from a rival family. Every aspect of Lucia\u2019s being, Ms. Yende said, especially her consuming passion for Edgardo, is thwarted.\n\nWithin everyone who is unable to express their inner feelings is a \u201ckind of hidden strength\u201d that they hold onto like \u201ca survival instinct,\u201d Ms. Yende said. Lucia\u2019s desperation culminates in one of the most challenging mad scenes in opera. Forced to marry a man she considers her oppressor, the unhinged Lucia stabs him to death on their wedding night. Ms. Yende sees even this harrowing act as evidence that Lucia \u201cis clinging to a kind of willfulness\u201d that she shows to the world through murder.\n\nYou sense Lucia\u2019s tenaciousness coursing through Ms. Yende\u2019s performance of the mad scene on her latest Sony recording, \u201cDreams\u201d; even in the character\u2019s delirium there is a chilling directness, even defiance, to her singing. And it was fascinating to watch her in the Met\u2019s spartan basement rehearsal room during the first rehearsal for her five-performance run, a revival of Mary Zimmerman\u2019s slightly updated 2007 production.\n\nThis was a run-through of Lucia\u2019s first scene, accompanied only by piano. In fluent Italian \u2014 Ms. Yende lives in Milan \u2014 she discussed fine points of the music with the conductor, Roberto Abbado. But the main business was to go through the blocking with the singers \u2014 especially Ms. Yende, who had only seen the production years ago, when it played at La Scala.", "title": "\u2018I Could Barely Sing a High C\u2019: Pretty Yende Finally Conquers Lucia", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI Feel Pretty\u201d is based on a pretty little lie: Looks don\u2019t matter. It\u2019s what\u2019s on the inside that counts.\n\nIn the film, the down-on-herself Renee (played by Amy Schumer) conks her head in a SoulCycle accident and awakens believing that she has miraculously become supermodel-hot. She revels in it \u2014 charging into a bikini contest, snagging a promotion and basking in the affections of a beefy corporate scion \u2014 only to discover that her looks never changed a bit. The benefits she thought she accrued through beauty were won instead through her newfound self-confidence.\n\nThe movie suggests that the only thing holding back regular-looking women is their belief that looking regular holds them back at all. That attitude puts the onus on individual women to improve their self-esteem instead of criticizing societal beauty standards writ large. The reality is that expectations for female appearances have never been higher. It\u2019s just become taboo to admit that.\n\nThis new beauty-standard denialism is all around us. It courses through cosmetics ads, fitness instructor monologues, Instagram captions and, increasingly, pop feminist principles. In the forthcoming book \u201cPerfect Me,\u201d Heather Widdows, a philosophy professor at the University of Birmingham, England, convincingly argues that the pressures on women to appear thinner, younger and firmer are stronger than ever. Keeping up appearances is no longer simply a superficial pursuit; it\u2019s an ethical one, too. A woman who fails to conform to the ideal is regarded as a failure as a person.", "title": "\u2018I Feel Pretty\u2019 and the Rise of Beauty-Standard Denialism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "He sensed a moment when he could fight back.\n\n\u201cI acted in a blink of a second,\u201d Mr. Shaw said. \u201cWhen he reloaded his clip, that felt like 30 minutes. I looked at him, and he wasn\u2019t looking at me. He just had the barrel down. It was like, \u2018Do it now. Go now.\u2019 I just took off.\u201d\n\nHe scuffled with the man, whom the police later identified as Travis Reinking, a 29-year-old construction worker with a history of brushes with authorities. Mr. Shaw managed to seize the rifle and hurled it over a countertop. Mr. Reinking, he recalled, began cursing him.\n\n\u201cHe was mad at me,\u201d he said. \u201cI was just trying to live. I wasn\u2019t trying to get no money from him, I wasn\u2019t trying to do anything from his standpoint. I just wanted to live, and he was, like, astonished, that I wanted to live.\u201d\n\n[Read more about Mr. Reinking here.]\n\nMr. Shaw said it did not occur to him to chase Mr. Reinking, who would be arrested more than 24 hours later in a wooded area near his apartment complex. Only when Mr. Shaw tried to leave the restaurant did he realize that he was among the wounded. His truck was bloodied, his right arm dripping and painful.\n\nSince then, he has insisted he did not act for the common good. The shooting played out too quickly to contemplate acts of heroism, he said. \u201cI know I saved other people. I have a 4-year-old daughter: I didn\u2019t even think about her. In the midst of it, I was just trying to save myself.\u201d\n\nNashville is having none of it. Mayor David Briley accompanied him to the Vanderbilt hospital, and even lent him his office for an interview. Throughout the day, people approached in search of handshakes and hugs. There were words of gratitude and occasional tears.\n\nIn quiet moments, Mr. Shaw is left to consider what transpired at Waffle House: A man his own age tried to kill him. He fought back. By God\u2019s grace, it worked.\n\n\u201cI almost didn\u2019t make it to 30, if you really think about it,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd no matter how it would have went, it seemed like he didn\u2019t care that he wasn\u2019t going to make it to 30.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Just Wanted to Live,\u2019 Says Man Who Wrested Rifle From Waffle House Gunman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.\n\nBefore I could spend the night in my younger sister\u2019s dorm room at Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio \u2014 before I could read the spines of her textbooks or drink a disgusting but lovingly prepared vodka/sparkling wine/Red Bull \u2014 I had to report to security, where a jovial guard handed me a form to sign:\n\nAll sexual interactions at Antioch College must be consensual. Consent means verbally asking and verbally giving or denying consent for all levels of sexual behavior. Non-consensual sexual behavior, verbal and sexual harassment are not tolerated at Antioch College.\n\nIt was 2004, a decade before the phrase \u201caffirmative consent\u201d made it onto news shows or big university campuses. I was 21, a junior at another college. I think it was the first time I had heard people talk about consent as something you could ask for verbally. It was definitely the first time I\u2019d ever seen it written out like that.\n\nImage The Times video journalist Samantha Stark, right, visiting her sister Whitney at Antioch College in 2007.\n\nSome people might feel put off or over-policed by being handed such a form, but to me it felt so radical and \u2014 dare I say it \u2014 sexy that we were supposed to talk about sex at this school, that whoever wrote that form thought I was mature enough to do so. It stuck with me for years, the idea that there is a community where consent is such a big part of the culture that every person who goes there to visit gets reminded of it before they walk into the dorms.", "title": "\u2018I Kept Thinking of Antioch\u2019: Long Before #MeToo, a Times Video Journalist Remembered a Form She Signed in 2004", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "Entering the ring marks the end of one battle and the beginning of another, one that can feel simpler to Heather Hardy than life\u2019s day-to-day struggles. People often ask Ms. Hardy: Doesn\u2019t it hurt to fight?\n\n\u201cIt hurt to have my eight-pound daughter,\u201d Ms. Hardy said with a laugh. \u201cNobody asks about that.\u201d\n\nShe watched a client move around the ring at Gleason\u2019s Gym in Brooklyn just a few weeks before defeating Anna Julaton at Bellator 194, a company that promotes mixed martial arts competitions.\n\nFor as long as Ms. Hardy, who is known as the Heat, has been a fighter, she has also been a single mother, raising her daughter with help from her sister, Kaitlyn. Without her assistance, Ms. Hardy might never have started practicing martial arts.", "title": "\u2018I Love to Fight. I Live to Fight.\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Don Blankenship likes to believe he knows something about rough justice and who deserves it.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t need to investigate our president. He spent a year in prison on charges rising from the collapse of one of his coal mines, which killed 29 people. Mr. Blankenship nurses a deep sense of grievance, and he has no political experience to speak of.\n\nBut he does have a natural inclination for one of the most distinctive and defining contributions that Mr. Trump has made to American politics: its sound.\n\nIn Republican races across the country, candidates like Mr. Blankenship are parroting the president as they try to prove to voters that they are cut from the same cloth as he is. They recite the Trump lexicon, spouting his trademark phrases and slurs like \u201cDrain the swamp,\u201d \u201cBuild the wall,\u201d \u201crigged system,\u201d \u201cfake news\u201d and \u201cAmerica first.\u201d", "title": "\u2018I Was Trump Before Trump Was Trump\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "MOSCOW \u2014 Ten days of demonstrations that escalated throughout Armenia forced the resignation Monday of the man who has led the country for the past decade, creating the latest crisis in a post-Soviet state trying to overcome a legacy of weak democratic rule.\n\nThe unexpected resignation prompted scenes of jubilation in the capital, Yerevan, and other cities. Tens of thousands of people flocked to the central Republic Square in Yerevan, where all afternoon and into the night they danced, cheered and waved the Armenian flag, a striped tricolor of red, blue and orange.\n\nSerzh Sargsyan, president since 2008, reached his legal two-term limit earlier this month. A constitutional referendum in 2015 had transferred most presidential powers to the role of prime minister, however, and the Parliament, dominated by his right-wing Republican Party, swiftly voted him into the post with no other candidate given a chance.\n\n\u201cI was wrong,\u201d Mr. Sargsyan said in a brief resignation statement carried by the official news agency. \u201cThe street movement is against my tenure. The GTB\u2019s V12 engine screams with sophisticated mellifluous authority as revs climb, but Mr. Dal Monte is used to speaking over mechanical commotion.\n\n\u201cWhen I was in middle school I became fascinated with Enzo.\u201d He remembers as a teenager in the late 1970s taking an hourlong train ride from his hometown, Cremona, to Modena early one morning with his brother, just to catch a glimpse of Ferrari having his morning shave at a barbershop. Ferrari stared out at them staring in at him, and smiled.\n\n\u201cEven then he was the Grand Old Man, not just of motor racing, but also of the country. You could hear him call in on some of the early TV automotive racing shows and discuss to the point of shouting with the talk show host in order to defend his cars and his drivers \u2014 more the cars than the drivers, actually.\u201d", "title": "\u2018In Italy, There Was the Pope and Then There Was Enzo Ferrari\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Two months after releasing a sneak peek of \u201cIncredibles 2,\u201d Disney and Pixar have unleashed the animated sequel\u2019s first full trailer. Although the original film came out in 2004, the superhero family hasn\u2019t aged \u2014 Jack-Jack is still an infant \u2014 but it is showing signs of growing pains.\n\nWith \u201csupers\u201d having been outlawed, the matriarch Elastigirl (voiced by Holly Hunter) springs back into action, leaving Mr. Incredible (Craig T. Nelson) home to take care of the kids, including moody Violet (Sarah Vowell). \u201cIs she having adolescence?\u201d asks her brother Dash (Huck Milner). Meanwhile, Jack-Jack is starting to show his own powers, like spontaneous combustion. This could bring new meaning to the terrible twos.\n\nBrad Bird, the writer-director of the original as well as the sequel, returns as the fashion designer Edna Mode, and Samuel L. Jackson reprises his role as fellow super Frozone. Among the new voices are two cast members from \u201cBetter Call Saul,\u201d Bob Odenkirk and Jonathan Banks.\n\n\u201cIncredibles 2\u201d lands in theaters on June 15.", "title": "\u2018Incredibles 2\u2019 Trailer: When a Superhero Is Also a Working Mom", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cInk,\u201d a new British play about the rise of Rupert Murdoch, will have its American premiere on Broadway next spring.\n\nThe play, which was a hit in London last year, is about an early chapter in Mr. Murdoch\u2019s rise to moguldom \u2014 his takeover and tabloid transformation of The Sun, a British newspaper, starting in 1969.\n\n\u201cInk\u201d was written by James Graham, a Briton The Financial Times called \u201cone of the country\u2019s finest and funniest playwrights.\u201d His one previous Broadway outing, as the book writer for the Harvey Weinstein-helmed musical \u201cFinding Neverland,\u201d was a flop, but beyond Broadway he has won acclaim for his politically charged dramas, including \u201cPrivacy,\u201d which transferred from London to the Public Theater in New York.\n\nReviewing \u201cInk\u201d in London, Ben Brantley of The New York Times called the play \u201cboth an entertaining epitaph for a lost age and a chilling prophecy of days to come.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe play will be directed by Rupert Goold (\u201cKing Charles III\u201d) and presented by the nonprofit Manhattan Theater Club in collaboration with London\u2019s Almeida Theater, where the play first ran, and Sonia Friedman Productions. The production is being partly financed by the foundation established by Roy Cockrum, a onetime Episcopal monk who won a $153 million Powerball jackpot and has been using some of the proceeds to support theater projects.\n\nIn the London production, Mr. Murdoch was portrayed by Bertie Carvel (\u201cMatilda\u201d); the casting for New York has not been announced.", "title": "\u2018Ink,\u2019 a Tale of Rupert Murdoch\u2019s Rise, Is Coming to Broadway", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "They were even able to marry white women, despite Americans\u2019 panic at the time over \u201cracial mixing.\u201d In 1843, having retired from touring a few years before, Chang and Eng married Adelaide and Sarah Yates, two sisters from Wilkes County, a rural corner of North Carolina. The couples settled down just outside Mount Airy, N.C. \u2014 later the inspiration for the town of Mayberry in \u201cThe Andy Griffith Show\u201d \u2014 to make room for their sizable families.\n\nHuang devotes a short chapter titled \u201cFoursome\u201d to the question of sex. The couples had to deal with considerable physical and logistical challenges. (According to interviews with their widows, Chang and Eng would alternate weeks as the \u201ccomplete master\u201d who dictated how he wanted to go about business, with the other brother \u201cblanking out.\u201d) But the widespread social disapprobation that greeted their arrangement was beyond their control. The most vociferous indictments came from the abolitionist papers in the North, which declared \u201cso bestial a union as this\u201d yet another sign of how slavery had corrupted the Southern soul.\n\nAnd the twins did seem determined to be identified as Southern gentry. In addition to owning slaves, they supported the Whigs and became ardent supporters of the Confederacy, sending two of their sons to fight in the Civil War.\n\nHuang is right to point out the cruel irony in all of this, but when he characterizes his subjects as \u201ctwo brothers formerly sold into indentured servitude and treated no better than slaves,\u201d he inadvertently downplays the incomparable brutality of the slaveholding system in order to heighten the contradictions.\n\nAs Huang shows elsewhere, Chang and Eng were treated better than slaves; if anything, what really rankled them were instances when they compared themselves to white men and felt they weren\u2019t given the respect they were due \u2014 such as their first trans-Atlantic journey, when they were booked in steerage rather than first class. In the excellent 2014 study \u201cThe Lives of Chang and Eng,\u201d Joseph Andrew Orser argues that the twins deliberately \u201cmade claims to whiteness.\u201d\n\nBut their intentions were one thing and public perception another. They would always be known as the conjoined brothers from Siam, and after the Civil War rendered their slaveholding assets worthless, they went on tour again, this time with their children, to show the world that their union with two women \u201cwas able to produce normal offspring.\u201d\n\nHuang writes movingly about the twins\u2019 painful end in 1874, when Chang, a heavy drinker, died and the teetotaling Eng perished soon after. But it\u2019s in the epilogue that Huang unveils one of his most surprising turns.\n\nWhen Huang visited Mount Airy, or Mayberry U.S.A., he learned of a Chang and Eng exhibit kept in the basement of the Andy Griffith Museum. In other words, a shrine to an American myth of old-timey homogeneity was literally built on the more convoluted reality. Huang knew that the symbolism was almost too much to bear: \u201cAs Sheriff Andy says, \u2018If you wrote this into a play, nobody\u2019d believe it.\u2019\u201d", "title": "\u2018Inseparable\u2019 Finds Pride, Indignity and Irony in the Lives of Siamese Twins Chang and Eng", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIs this still a buddy movie?\u201d he said, \u201cor is Abe the ex?\u201d\n\nWhite House officials insist it is still the former, pointing out that Mr. Abe is the only leader to be a repeat guest at Mr. Trump\u2019s estate, Mar-a-Lago. The men have met six times and spoken by phone 20 times, though not since March 8, the evening that Mr. Trump stunned Mr. Abe, as well as his own aides, by accepting Mr. Kim\u2019s invitation to a meeting.\n\nMr. Trump, a senior administration official said, has a lot of respect for Mr. Abe\u2019s views on North Korea. In two days of meetings \u2014 alone and with their aides \u2014 the leaders are likely to discuss issues ranging from the demands Mr. Trump will make of Mr. Kim to the venue for the meeting.\n\nAmong the most politically salient issues for Mr. Abe is the status of Japanese citizens abducted by North Korea. He is expected to ask Mr. Trump to raise the matter with Mr. Kim in their meeting, and a person briefed on the White House\u2019s preparations said the president would probably assure Mr. Abe that he would do so.\n\nStill, for Mr. Abe, who has been a stalwart supporter of Mr. Trump\u2019s sanctions against North Korea, the summit meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim raises other problems. The first is that it leaves Japan isolated in what has been a round robin of diplomacy involving North Korea.\n\nSouth Korea, China and the United States have all been in contact with the North about potential meetings. Japan has not. If anything, anti-Tokyo propaganda in North Korea has intensified as Mr. Kim has reached out to leaders in Seoul, Beijing and Washington.\n\nJapan, moreover, has different security concerns than those of the United States. While Mr. Trump is likely to press Mr. Kim to halt development of intercontinental ballistic missiles, which could theoretically strike American territory, Japan is much more concerned about the North\u2019s medium-range missiles, which have already landed in waters around Japan.\n\nAmerican officials declined to say whether Mr. Trump would raise the issue of intermediate-range missiles, repeating only his general demand that North Korea relinquish its nuclear arsenal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe coordination between the Japanese and the White House is excellent,\u201d said Michael J. Green, a senior Asia adviser to President George W. Bush. \u201cBut the problem is that the president is so unpredictable.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s treatment of Japan on trade is a case in point. He initially said he planned to impose metals tariffs on all nations to buoy a struggling American industry. But one by one, American allies, including Canada, Mexico, Australia, the European Union, Brazil and South Korea, were given exemptions to the tariffs \u2014 all except for Japan.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
