Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s exactly what we want to ask the U.S.,\u201d said Takehiro Shimada, a spokesman for the Japanese Embassy in Washington. \u201cWhy?\u201d\n\nSome analysts said it was a calculated attempt to gain leverage over Japan in coming trade talks.\n\n\u201cLogically, they should have excluded Japan. They didn\u2019t,\u201d said William Reinsch, an Asia trade expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. \u201cThey\u2019re going to twist Abe\u2019s arm when he shows up.\u201d\n\nWhen Mr. Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, he proposed a bilateral trade deal with Japan in its place. But Japan\u2019s deputy prime minister, Taro Aso, ruled out that possibility in March, saying that such a negotiation would lead to unnecessary pain for Japan.\n\nInstead, Japan forged ahead with a deal among the accord\u2019s 11 remaining members, which they reached on March 8. Japan maintains that this agreement is still fragile, and that negotiating another pact with the United States could put its success at risk.\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s about-face on the Trans-Pacific Partnership could breathe new life into trade talks. Japan has said that it would be willing to enter a one-on-one deal only if it would serve as a bridge to the United States\u2019 getting back into the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\n\u201cIf you want to try to get the Japanese into talks,\u201d Mr. Reinsch said, \u201cI think the best way to do that is to tell them we\u2019re prepped for rejoining the T.P.P.\u201d\n\nThe Japanese responded to Mr. Trump\u2019s statement about the trade pact with a mix of puzzlement and cautious optimism. American officials said they expected both the tariffs and the Trans-Pacific pact to come up during the meeting, and noted that Mr. Trump has indicated a willingness to grant further exemptions if he can come to agreeable terms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe trouble could flare if Mr. Trump tries to strike a tougher deal with Japan than his predecessor did.\n\nJapan is wary of the bullying approach the Trump administration has taken to revising global trade pacts. In particular, it is unlikely to give additional concessions on agriculture, after opening up its heavily protected markets to the other members of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\n\u201cFor them, that is a nonstarter,\u201d said Wendy Cutler, the vice president of the Asia Society Policy Institute.\n\nMr. Abe, who is trying to weather a political scandal at home, has little room for maneuver with Mr. Trump. Until now, he has largely delegated trade-related matters to Mr. Aso, who has been carrying on an economic dialogue with Vice President Mike Pence. But White House officials are increasingly frustrated by what they regard as slow-walking on the part of the Japanese.\n\n\u201cAbe knows he\u2019s walking into a meeting where Trump may have a short fuse on trade,\u201d Mr. Russel said.", "title": "\u2018Is This Still a Buddy Movie?\u2019 Trump and Abe Will Soon Find Out", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "Ana Swanson"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Moments after that terrible Valentine\u2019s Day, the thought crept into the minds of the Aerie yearbook staff at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. They would have to memorialize this tragedy in their pages. Somehow.\n\nAt first, some students hesitated. \u201cI thought it\u2019d be too much,\u201d said Elizabeth Stout, 17, a senior who is the book\u2019s co-editor in chief, of the staff\u2019s offer to write about the students killed. \u201cI didn\u2019t know at the time if it\u2019d even be right to.\u201d\n\nFew students who have survived mass shootings in schools have faced the same dilemma. The children at Sandy Hook were too young. Those at Columbine were too far along in the school year.\n\nAt Stoneman Douglas High, where a former student is accused of killing 17 people in a deadly rampage, editors decided the shooting would not overtake their book. They insisted on preserving a record of the days that came before, the ones filled with the regular markers of high school life: Football games. Club activities. The Sadie Hawkins dance.", "title": "\u2018It Has to Be Perfect\u2019: Putting Out a Yearbook After the Parkland Shooting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Maile\u2019s arrival was the product of several months of behind-the-scenes negotiation in the hidebound Senate, whose rules until Wednesday barred children from coming onto the Senate floor. A few months after Ms. Duckworth announced she was pregnant, she asked Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, the senior Democrat on the Senate Rules Committee, to help her engineer a rule change, necessary because senators are required to vote in person.\n\nSo it was that on Wednesday, senators voted unanimously that, henceforth, both male and female senators will be permitted to bring infants up to age one into the chamber. In an institution where a fair number of members are in their 80s, this was a monumental change, hardly as simple as it might seem.\n\nFirst, Ms. Klobuchar said, there were the discussions over whether the Senate floor would turn into some kind of nursery.\n\n\u201cBut what if there are 10 babies on the floor of the Senate?\u201d Senator Orrin G. Hatch, 84, Republican of Utah, asked, according to The Associated Press. Replied Ms. Klobuchar: \u201cThat would be wonderful and a delight.\u201d\n\nThen came the concerns about whether there would be diaper changes. Or breast-feeding. (Ms. Duckworth, Ms. Klobuchar said, has no intention of doing either while on the Senate floor.)", "title": "\u2018It\u2019s About Time\u2019: A Baby Comes to the Senate Floor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "He was the person that stood up for everyone; he was everyone\u2019s voice. I don\u2019t think no one is outstanding like he was. Dr. King, he was a legend to me. That\u2019s all that\u2019s possible. When I think of his name, I think of a legend, a man that wanted our nation to be more, someone who wanted everyone to get along and be empowered by his speech and the things that he did.\n\nHe said, \u201cThe time is always right to do right,\u201d and some people went by it and some people didn\u2019t. I wish more people would follow behind his footsteps. People should get advice from the speeches that he made.\n\nI\u2019ve never been outside of Memphis. When Martin Luther King Day comes, I wonder what are they doing out there. Do they celebrate it, or do they go against him?\n\nI can walk out of my house now without having to look around and be like, \u201cAm I supposed to say this? Am I supposed to say that?\u201d like back when my grandma was around. I\u2019m comfortable in my own skin, and others are, too.\n\nPhoto\n\nTommy Applewhite, 13\n\nHe plans to become a pediatrician.\n\nI know he was an intelligent man who had a big dream.\n\nWe had a black history program, and I had to dress up and be Dr. Martin Luther King. I remember that day; I don\u2019t remember his speech, exactly, but I was someone from black history, and it made me feel like I can do the same thing he did.\n\nI always think about him and Rosa Parks and Booker T. Washington. I think I know Dr. King a little bit, but I want to get to know him better. I heard his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech and his \u201cMountaintop\u201d speech, but I feel like I need to get in more, see how he felt, what made him want to encourage more people. He didn\u2019t have to do it. What made him want to do it? What made him have that dream?\n\nWhat I really worry most about is trying to be safe around here because any time someone has a fight, they have to pull out a weapon and try to use the weapon against the other person. He knew that violence was not the answer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are still people fighting with each other, but there are people trying to bring them together instead of breaking them apart. If people just get along and stop the violence and stop going at each other and they just actually listen to Dr. King\u2019s speeches, they could get along better.\n\nWe\u2019re better. There are different races at this school. You\u2019ve got different races at more schools. If he was here, he\u2019d be proud to see that his dream was accomplished. He\u2019d be proud of his dream.\n\nPhoto\n\nCedricka Harris, 11\n\nShe loves math and wants to attend the University of Memphis.\n\nHe would still give his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech because he really wanted people to have equal rights and treat people the way they wanted to be treated.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPeople should listen to it more often because sometimes people might forget about it and still do things that Dr. King wouldn\u2019t want them doing. My favorite part is that he said one day, his four children would rise and not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of the character.\n\nI think about him a lot, almost every day. I\u2019ve got white friends and black friends that I play with a lot. I think he would be amazed right now at how far we have come since 1963 to 2018. I think he would be proud. People at this school treat people the way they want to be treated.\n\nPhoto\n\nGabino Valderrama, 12\n\nHis favorite subject is science.\n\nIf it wasn\u2019t for him, I probably wouldn\u2019t be here because my dad, he\u2019s African-American, and my mom is white.\n\nNow you see equal rights, but you used to not see that. Now you see people all sitting wherever they want on the bus. I think he would be proud. It started off as nothing, and it became a big project turning out to be successful.\n\nIf he hadn\u2019t died, I think his policy would have mattered, but things wouldn\u2019t be as better as they are today. I think it influenced the white people to what he was saying, and they started standing up for African-Americans. A white person killed him, so that probably just broke someone\u2019s heart. He was an honorable person.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s not as messed up as it was. I think there\u2019s some work to do: There are some whites and some African-Americans that still don\u2019t get along.\n\nIt could be done better, if you just meet up and talk it out and not having a dangerous fight about it. Get back together. If there was someone brave enough like how Dr. Martin Luther King was, they could get together. Don\u2019t look for the differences. Try to talk it out.\n\nPhoto\n\nNicko Brown, 13\n\nHe plays basketball and is a fan of the Golden State Warriors.\n\nWhen I hear his name, it\u2019s like an inspiration to me because he is a black man. He is a black individual, and he opened doors to the point where we can get along. We don\u2019t have to be separated from whites. We can get along with them. We can work with them. We can be in the same places.\n\nLook at this school, for instance. We have all kinds of races in here. We get along with each other: on the playgrounds, on the courts, on the football fields, everywhere, we get along with each other.\n\nIf he was still alive, there would probably be less problems. Some people still wouldn\u2019t like him; just like today, some people still don\u2019t like him, and they don\u2019t follow by his lifestyle and his greatness. Some people would love him.\n\nWhat worries me most is what\u2019s going to happen, like if I\u2019m going to be good at one moment and then be hurt or dead the next moment because people, they just don\u2019t listen. They don\u2019t follow by the rules. Dr. King could have fixed it. He probably would have done a march, done a testimony, went to Congress or went to court.\n\nI would tell Dr. King that his dream was a success. His dream, to me, was one of the best dreams you could ever have.\n\nPhoto\n\nGabriella Valderrama, 13\n\nOne of her favorite movies is \u201cTwilight.\u201d\n\nHe stood up for his people, and I think that when he stood up for his people, he stood up for me because I\u2019m different. I\u2019m thankful for it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhenever I\u2019m afraid to do something, I think about his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech, and I tell myself I can do it. When I tried out for cheerleading, I was scared at first. And then I thought of him \u2014 and then I finished the whole year of cheerleading.\n\nI would tell him I accomplished my dreams, and I would tell him I\u2019m so grateful. He was a leader. I\u2019m a leader. I think that you\u2019re a leader, you be yourself.\n\nI\u2019m glad that I\u2019m equal.", "title": "\u2018I\u2019m Glad That I\u2019m Equal\u2019: Six Students on Dr. King\u2019s Legacy", "authors": ["Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cJesus Christ Superstar\u201d will rise again \u2014 and tour North America. The announcement that a recent London production of the Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice musical will begin touring in fall 2019 came just days after NBC aired a well-received live performance of the show.\n\nThis production, directed by Timothy Sheader, opened in Regent\u2019s Park Open Air Theater in 2016, and won the 2017 Olivier Award for best revival. (It returned for another sold-out stint in 2017.) In his review in The New York Times, Matt Wolf wrote that the production \u201cdelivers a genuinely primal jolt, locating fear and foreboding in what can so easily devolve into overindulgent camp.\u201d\n\nThe creative team includes Drew McOnie (choreography), Tom Scutt (set and costume design), Lee Curran (lighting design), and Tom Deering (music supervision).\n\nSpecific dates and locations have yet to be announced, but producers said the show will make more than 50 stops.\n\nNBC\u2019s \u201cJesus Christ Superstar Live in Concert,\u201d starring John Legend and Sara Bareilles, drew 9.6 million total viewers in prime time on Easter Sunday.", "title": "\u2018Jesus Christ Superstar\u2019 Will Tour North America", "authors": ["Andrew R. Their adversaries \u2014 including Rafe Spall and Toby Jones \u2014 can also be seen in the new trailer.\n\nThe romantic chemistry between Owen and Claire remains on display. \u201cIf I don\u2019t make it back, remember you\u2019re the one who made me come here,\u201d he teases her, quickly adding, \u201cI\u2019ll be all right.\u201d\n\n\u201cJurassic World: Fallen Kingdom\u201d hits theaters on June 22.", "title": "\u2018Jurassic World\u2019 Trailer: A Rescue Mission Gets Underway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Created by Josh Heald (\u201cHot Tub Time Machine\u201d), Jonathan Hurwitz and Hayden Schlossberg (the \u201cHarold and Kumar\u201d films, \u201cBlockers\u201d), longtime friends and \u201cKarate Kid\u201d obsessives, the half-hour comedy flips the story to focus on Johnny. \u201cCobra Kai\u201d offers the young tough-turned-old deadbeat a chance at redemption while illuminating the reasons behind his behavior all those years ago. (They involve a stepfather played by Ed Asner.)\n\nWhen Johnny resurrects the old Cobra Kai dojo, it triggers Daniel, a successful car dealer who misses the stabilizing influence of his late mentor, Mr. Miyagi (Pat Morita). As the rivalry reignites and finds proxy in young prot\u00e9g\u00e9s, multigenerational resentments, confrontations and hook-kicks ensue.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a karate opera,\u201d Mr. Schlossberg said. \u201cThere\u2019s a fun sort of Hatfields and McCoys vibe.\u201d\n\nNow in their 50s, Mr. Macchio and Mr. Zabka each have had periods of wanting to keep \u201cThe Karate Kid\u201d at arm\u2019s length. (They\u2019ve heard enough \u201cwax on\u201d and \u201csweep the leg\u201d jokes for many lifetimes.) But they were lured back into their headbands by the update on the story and its themes, some of which, like bullying, are getting more attention now than they were in 1984.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Google-owned YouTube, which beat out more established outlets like Netflix and Hulu for the rights to \u201cCobra Kai,\u201d was enticed by the series\u2019s potential to expand the audience for YouTube Red, said Susanne Daniels, the global head of programming. The service has been making deals lately with established franchises (the \u201cStep Up\u201d movies) and filmmakers (Doug Liman) in an effort to move beyond its homegrown stable of viral stars toward more mainstream appeal.\n\nYouTube also knows from search metrics that \u201cThe Karate Kid\u201d remains popular among its users, and it plans to use its multitude of clips from and inspired by the movies to promote \u201cCobra Kai.\u201d Anyone who wants to relive, say, the original\u2019s cheesily triumphant \u201cYou\u2019re the Best\u201d montage, which has more than 15.5 million views, can expect to see in the adjacent \u201cup next\u201d queue the first two episodes of \u201cCobra Kai,\u201d which will be available free. (The show\u2019s trailer, hyped in similar fashion, has been viewed nearly 13 million times.)\n\nThat plus the fact that Ms. Daniels offered a full series deal in the pitch meeting was enough to get the \u201cCobra Kai\u201d creators to overlook the relatively paltry subscriber base. YouTube declined to release figures, but it\u2019s safe to say they lag far behind the totals for streaming behemoths like Netflix (125 million) and Amazon (which has more than 100 million people paying for Amazon Prime, which also includes access to its programming).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe upside, the creators say, is that unlike at a place like Netflix, which plans to release hundreds of shows this year, there is little chance \u201cCobra Kai\u201d will get lost in the marketing shuffle.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s nice to be a big fish in a small pond,\u201d Mr. Hurwitz said, \u201cwhen the small pond is Google.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere have been five \u201cKarate Kid\u201d films, including the initial three movies (Mr. Zabka appeared in the first two); a partial reboot with Hilary Swank replacing Mr. Macchio, in 1994; and a totally new one in 2010, starring Jackie Chan and Jaden Smith.\n\n\u201cCobra Kai\u201d draws almost exclusively from the first movie and actually begins with a flashback to the moment Daniel laid out Johnny in the \u201984 All Valley Karate Championship with the infamous crane kick, the legality of which is still debated online.\n\n\u201cThat kick to the head sent them on two different trajectories,\u201d Mr. Hurwitz said. \u201cDaniel on the upswing, and Johnny in the downward spiral that\u2019s been going for the last 30 years.\u201d\n\nJohnny is now a Coors-guzzling handyman who is \u201cstuck in 1989,\u201d Mr. Zabka said, cruising around Southern California in an old Firebird, jamming to vintage hair metal and scowling at billboards for LaRusso Auto Group, which gives away bonsai trees with every purchase. They are still on opposite sides of the tracks, but they\u2019ve switched sides: Daniel has a grand compound in affluent Encino, Johnny a dingy apartment in Reseda. (Aside from some exteriors, the series was shot in and around Atlanta.)\n\nWhen events conspire to bring the old foes back into both karate and one another\u2019s orbit, history repeats itself in melodramatic fashion. Johnny\u2019s student Miguel (Xolo Maridue\u00f1a), a bullied new kid in town, squares off with Daniel\u2019s prot\u00e9g\u00e9, Robby (Tanner Buchanan), who happens to be Johnny\u2019s estranged son. Each pines for Daniel\u2019s daughter, Samantha (Mary Mouser), shades of the Ali-Daniel-Johnny triangle of the first film.\n\n\u201cThe good news is now I\u2019m sitting on the sidelines \u2014 I\u2019m not getting my ass kicked,\u201d Mr. Macchio said. \u201cAt 56, no matter how much hair and makeup help me, everything hurts more in the morning.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven off camera, both he and Mr. Zabka, 52, are remarkably well-preserved. This is key to maintaining the possibility that the story\u2019s old guys might actually fight, too \u2014 the will-they-or-won\u2019t-they of this particular sitcom. (\u201cMy kicks are still high,\u201d Mr. Zabka warned, grinning. \u201cNo mercy.\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nBut neither was interested putting on a karate gi for a broad, nostalgic spoof. In separate interviews, the actors struck similar notes of protectiveness about the \u201cKarate Kid\u201d legacy, about how important it was for \u201cCobra Kai\u201d to spin the story forward and include some of the film\u2019s heart along with the clever callbacks, fan Easter eggs and \u201chumor that comes from the fact that these two guys have not moved past it,\u201d Mr. Macchio said.\n\nThe actors long ago made peace with the fact that as far as the rest of the world is concerned, they\u2019ll never entirely move past \u201cThe Karate Kid.\u201d\n\nMr. Macchio had other indelible roles in movies like \u201cThe Outsiders,\u201d \u201cCrossroads\u201d and \u201cMy Cousin Vinny,\u201d and he has starred on Broadway. But he knows that any time he attends a sporting event, the arena will put him on the Jumbotron and play \u201cYou\u2019re the Best\u201d at some point.\n\nMr. Zabka moved on to other roles and was nominated for an Oscar for \u201cMost (The Bridge),\u201d a 2003 short he co-wrote and co-produced, about a father forced to make a tragic sacrifice, but he still gets asked to send up Johnny in sitcoms and music videos. \u201cThere\u2019s something alive about it \u2014 these characters have become real to people in a way,\u201d he said.\n\nThe actors have a hard time articulating precisely why \u201cThe Karate Kid\u201d endures, chalking it up to some alchemy of the underdog story, the unforgettable characters (Mr. Miyagi, the aggro Cobra Kai sensei John Kreese) and a script that balanced the corniness and catchphrases with great pathos. (Even the villain got a moment of grace at the end, when Johnny handed Daniel the trophy.) The movie stuck with them, too \u2014 Mr. Zabka admitted that it was more than a decade before he was able to watch it with anything like objectivity.\n\n\u201cFor so long, I still felt that kick,\u201d he said.\n\nKept mostly apart during filming, Mr. Macchio and Mr. Zabka never really became friends until later, on the fan convention circuit. But while it\u2019s an odd thing, being randomly but inextricably linked to another person for your entire adult life, there\u2019s something transporting about it, too.\n\nMr. Macchio, for one, was stunned at how quickly the old fire came back once the actors finally faced off for the first time during filming for \u201cCobra Kai.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt just had all that tension \u2014 you look into his eyes, and he\u2019s looking at mine,\u201d he said. \u201cThe eyelids had a couple more wrinkles, but it felt like yesterday.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Cobra Kai\u2019: This Rivalry Is Not Quite Ready for a Body Bag", "authors": ["Jeremy Egner"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "But instead of facing that uncertainty and all that goes with it far earlier than expected, the Cavaliers and their fans can turn their attention to the top-seeded Toronto Raptors after clawing past a plucky Pacers team that actually outscored Cleveland by 40 points over the seven games.\n\n\u201cBring your passports!\u201d read the instructions scrawled in big letters on a greaseboard in the middle of the Cavaliers\u2019 victorious locker room. They will fly to Canada on Monday to face the Raptors in Tuesday night\u2019s Game 1.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m burnt right now,\u201d James said at his postgame news conference, explaining his reluctance to answer a question about matching up with the Raptors. He sounded eager to get away from the assembled news media members as quickly as possible.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m ready to go home. Can we \u2026 I\u2019m tired. I want to go home,\u201d he said.\n\nSeeing James abruptly head to the locker room with a minute remaining in the third quarter was a sufficiently scary moment for the Cavaliers and a home crowd of 20,562. He had played every second of the first half and had 26 points by intermission, but the stubborn Pacers sliced a 14-point deficit to 76-74 entering the final period.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt was reported on ABC\u2019s broadcast that James was suffering from leg cramps, which were a major issue for him during the ill-fated 2014 N.B.A. Finals against San Antonio, when he was a member of the Miami Heat. James refused afterward to acknowledge that he had indeed been suffering from cramps \u2014 or even to use the word \u2014 admitting only that he had refused the team\u2019s suggestion to intake intravenous fluids during his locker-room visit.\n\n\u201cJust a little minor injury,\u201d James said.\n\nYet there was no denying the boost that the Cavaliers, most of all James, received at the beginning of the fourth quarter with a 10-2 spurt that Cleveland assembled without him. James had returned to the bench and was preparing to check back in when the struggling Love hit a huge 3-pointer for an 82-74 lead with 9 minutes 42 seconds to play, enabling James to keep sitting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy the time James did come back, for the game\u2019s final 8:25, he had benefited from a lengthy rest and the team had an 86-79 cushion, thanks to a unit featuring Love, Hill, Jeff Green, Jordan Clarkson and Larry Nance Jr.\n\n\u201cIt was big,\u201d Cleveland Coach Tyronn Lue said. \u201cThey bought \u2019Bron minutes.\u201d\n\nConcerns about James, at 33, being able to sustain this type of across-the-board production for three more rounds are inevitable after the effort he expended in this series. Then again, perhaps just a little help and good health are all James needs given the way he\u2019s playing \u2014 at least when it comes to getting out of the Eastern Conference and securing his eighth successive trip to the N.B.A. Finals.\n\nEntering this Game 7, James was leading the league in Player Efficiency Rating in the postseason, at 34.8. James\u2019s teammates, through the first six games of the series, had combined to post a P.E.R. of 9.0, which would represent the lowest combined P.E.R. for one of James\u2019s supporting casts in his 42 career playoff series.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe rest of the Cavaliers not named James, furthermore, had shot a collective 12-for-49 from the floor Sunday before James made his temporary exit. But they emerged, for once, with multiple heroes.\n\nLove scored 8 crucial points in the first 5:25 of the fourth quarter. Hill, who had been out since Game 3 with back spasms and needed multiple painkilling injections just to be in uniform for Game 7, and wound up playing the final 19:12 without leaving the floor because Lue was desperate to get another ballhandler on the floor in the second half to ease the burden on James. And the out-of-favor Thompson, who had totaled just six rebounds in 24 minutes in the first six games of the series, grabbed seven rebounds in Sunday\u2019s first quarter and finished with 15 points and 10 rebounds.\n\nJames played a bit tentatively when he first returned, but he gradually got the legs back to make his share of clinching plays. Perhaps none was bigger than his layup with 30.2 seconds remaining for a 102-96 lead, cutting down the lane to capitalize on a gutsy Kyle Korver feed.\n\n\u201cBest receiver in the N.B.A.,\u201d Korver said of James.\n\nSaid the Indiana guard Victor Oladipo, who had 30 points, 12 rebounds and six assists in his effort to counter James: \u201cHe\u2019s the best in the world. That\u2019s what he does. Now I\u2019ve got to get to work so I can get on that level.\u201d\n\nThe Pacers arrived in Cleveland with their bags packed for Toronto, too, believing they could usher James and his Cavaliers into an unfathomably early summer after winning Game 6 in a 34-point rout. Indiana enjoyed a fairy-tale season after reluctantly trading the All-Star forward Paul George to Oklahoma City last June, but the Pacers will undoubtedly spend the summer lamenting their inability to capitalize on the 4 minutes and 35 seconds that James \u2014 who clearly intended to play a full 48 minutes \u2014 was forced into spectator status.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not very often where you\u2019re able to split the game ball in half, but G-Hill and Double T did that,\u201d James said, referring to Hill and Thompson.", "title": "\u2018King\u2019 James Briefly Sat, and His Subjects Carried the Load", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Polls show that Mr. da Silva still commands by far more support than any other Brazilian politician. His imprisonment, though, makes it most unlikely \u2014 though not impossible \u2014 that he will be able to run for president in October. His defense team hopes that the Supreme Court will rule that jailing him before he had exhausted his appeals was unconstitutional, but other investigations against him are underway.\n\nThat leaves the field, and the future, wide open. Without Mr. da Silva, the left has begun to fragment. His successor as president, Dilma Rousseff, was impeached for breaking budget rules; her successor, Michel Temer, the current president, has been charged with corruption and his popularity rating is near zero. Left to its own devices, the Congress is not likely to support any anti-corruption drive. About a third of the legislators face legal challenges but are effectively protected by a Constitution under which high officials and politicians can be tried only in the high courts, which move slowly and rarely convict. For all the successes of Operation Car Wash, nothing has been done to fix the judicial system. The danger of a lurch to populism and political radicalization is obvious.\n\nHowever painful and disheartening the fall of a charismatic and dynamic leader, and however exhausted Brazilians must be from the political havoc of recent years, this is not the time to give up. History shows that battling corruption takes years, but also that incremental successes do change norms. Judges like S\u00e9rgio Moro, who has courageously led the prosecution in Operation Car Wash, have demonstrated that Brazil does have the institutions and means to take on even the most powerful \u2014 and most popular \u2014 of malefactors.\n\nThere are still six months to go before the national elections. They should be spent in search of a leader who can ensure that the gains against corruption are not setbacks for democracy.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Lula\u2019 Is in Prison, and Brazil\u2019s Democracy Is in Peril", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "NEW DELHI \u2014 The schoolgirls ran into the auditorium, shouting, \u201cLet\u2019s go, let\u2019s go,\u201d in Hindi as they ushered one another into single-file lines. Some adjusted the big, red bows that held their braids together, part of their school uniform. Then they crouched into defensive postures, fists ready.\n\n\u201cOss!\u201d they yelled \u2014 a karate greeting combining the Japanese words for push and persevere.\n\nThey bowed slightly to their mentors before unleashing a series of punches, karate chops and kicks, interspersed with occasional giggles, whispers and sheepish smiles.\n\n\u201cDo not laugh!\u201d Police Constable Renu, who like many Indians goes by one name, called from the stage above them, her white T-shirt emblazoned with \u201cRespect Women\u201d on the back.\n\n\u201cDo you think they will laugh when they attack you?\u201d she asked. \u201cYou must strike back with anger.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Men Treat Us Like We Aren\u2019t Human.\u2019 Indian Girls Learn to Fight Back.", "authors": ["Maria Abi-Habib"]} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Such positions hark back to the 1930s, when Mexico nationalized its oil industry. Under the current government, a constitutional change enacted in 2014 let foreign companies invest in exploration, drilling, pipelines and even gas stations, and to team up on projects with the state oil company, Petr\u00f3leos Mexicanos, or Pemex. The move allowed companies like Exxon Mobil to invest billions of dollars to develop vast fields offshore.\n\nMr. L\u00f3pez Obrador\u2019s nationalistic policies are resonating in Mexico as the Trump administration vows to curtail Mexican immigration into the United States and threatens to withdraw from the North American Free Trade Agreement.\n\nThe election outlook has caused concern among American oil executives.\n\n\u201cMexico is very critical as an energy partner of the United States, so a retreat from current policies would be a tragedy for both countries,\u201d said Scott D. Sheffield, chairman of Pioneer Natural Resources, a major Texas oil and gas producer. \u201cIt\u2019s going to hurt Mexico long term and the United States long term.\u201d\n\nMr. Sheffield and other Texas oil executives are particularly worried that Mexico could slow its importing of American gas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn recent years, Mexico has replaced coal and diesel with cleaner American natural gas to produce about 30 percent of the nation\u2019s electricity. The shale-drilling revolution north of the Rio Grande has yielded an abundance of cheap natural gas for American and Mexican consumers, and Mexico announced a five-year plan in 2015 to increase imports.\n\nAbout 20 pipelines carry 4.5 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day to Mexico, and more are being built or planned.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe gas sales to Mexico are an important source of revenue for American oil and pipeline companies, and they relieve a bulge of gas that is bubbling up with oil from the Permian Basin of West Texas and New Mexico, the nation\u2019s most prolific shale field. California is switching from natural gas to renewable energy sources, while a shortage of pipelines and export terminals for liquefied natural gas means that if sales to Mexico dwindle, there will be excess gas with nowhere to go.\n\nThat gas will have to be flared, or oil drilling and production will need to decrease, a choice between increasing climate-warming carbon-dioxide emissions or decreasing profits.\n\nAmerican refineries also face problems. Before the boom in shale oil production, refineries along the Gulf of Mexico were designed to process heavy oil grades from Canada, Mexico and Venezuela. Imports from Canada continue to increase, but they are limited by scarce pipeline capacity. Production in Venezuela is plummeting, and an expected ratcheting up of sanctions by the Trump administration could further hamper imports.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat makes Mexico, which accounts for about 8 percent of American crude-oil imports, an even more critical source. American refineries can process lighter grades of oil but much less efficiently, or they can undertake expensive overhauls of their equipment. Either way, profits would slump.\n\nMexico, for its part, has been importing higher-quality transportation fuels from the United States, in an effort to clean up its cities\u2019 air. Last year, Mexico bought more than one million barrels of American petroleum products a day, providing $23 billion in revenue to American energy companies.\n\nMs. Nahle, Mr. L\u00f3pez Obrador\u2019s energy adviser, has said Mexico\u2019s own refineries can be retooled to handle a changeover from American gasoline and diesel.\n\nMexican oil officials, expecting at least a slowdown of their policies, are holding offshore auctions as fast as they can to lure investment before President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto, who is barred by law from seeking a second term, leaves office in December. More than 100 development contracts have already been awarded. The nation\u2019s oil production remains in decline, but officials hope they can reverse the trend as international companies begin to produce large amounts of oil in the Gulf of Mexico over the next two years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIndependent energy analysts have viewed Mexico\u2019s moves as a model for economic development, and some worry about a reversal. \u201cTo make a U-turn from the current reforms would be detrimental to the Mexican economy,\u201d said Fatih Birol, executive director of the International Energy Agency.\n\nSome oil executives and energy experts say they are not overly worried that the new contracts will be overturned. They note that Mr. L\u00f3pez Obrador will almost certainly not have the congressional support to entirely rescind the constitutional energy change. Campaign oratory could give way to the realities of governing, especially when the oil industry offers financing for more social services. The government has earned signing bonuses of $525 million from investors so far this year as a result of its efforts.\n\n\u201cMexico needs this change more than anybody else,\u201d said Ali Moshiri, who retired last year as Chevron\u2019s top executive in Latin America and is forming his own oil company to seek international opportunities. \u201cPemex has been a disaster, so they have to continue with the reform, though they could slow things down.\u201d\n\nIf necessary, international companies could focus less on Mexico and more on other Latin American countries, like Brazil, which also has huge offshore potential, or Colombia, which has significant potential for shale drilling. Both countries also have elections this year in which major candidates have expressed either opposition to giving foreign companies control over natural resources or environmental concerns about developing fossil fuels at all.\n\n\u201cThat creates a lot of uncertainties for energy policy,\u201d said Lisa Viscidi, an energy expert at the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington think tank. \u201cAround Latin America, there are serious contenders who want to make big changes in the oil sector and want to reverse previous reforms. L\u00f3pez Obrador particularly represents a lot of direct threats.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Mexico First\u2019 Campaign Could End Welcome for U.S. Oil Giants", "authors": ["Clifford Krauss"]} {"date": "2018-04-14 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 On the morning after, President Trump declared success. The surgical strike against chemical weapons facilities in Syria had been executed perfectly, he said on Saturday. \u201cMission Accomplished!\u201d he wrote on Twitter.\n\nThat\u2019s a phrase presidents and politicians have studiously avoided since President George W. Bush\u2019s ill-fated aircraft carrier visit prematurely declaring success in the Iraq war. But aside from the curious choice of words, it raised the essential question regarding Syria going beyond the one-time strike: What exactly is the mission?\n\nFor most of Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency, it has been to defeat the Islamic State and then get out. But what Mr. Trump outlined in his televised speech to the nation on Friday night was something more complicated. He promised a sustained campaign to stop Syria\u2019s government from again using chemical weapons on its own people, while also emphasizing the limits of America\u2019s ability or willingness to do more to stop the broader bloodletting that has devastated that country for seven years.\n\nMr. Trump finds himself in a position not all that different from that of his predecessor, President Barack Obama, and with no easier answers. The strike brought home Mr. Trump\u2019s competing impulses when it comes to Syria \u2014 on the one hand, his manful chest-thumping intended to demonstrate that he is the toughest one on the international block, and on the other, his deep conviction that American involvement in the Middle East since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, has been a waste of blood and treasure.", "title": "\u2018Mission Accomplished!\u2019 But What Is the Mission in Syria?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "But are they together together? Together enough? No, it seems. Which is to say: They are not married, and that is a crisis. \u201cNew Girl\u201d rivals \u201cFiddler on the Roof\u201d for its focus on engagements, marriages and parental approval. It\u2019s also disdainful of singledom in a way that\u2019s jarringly out of sync with the show\u2019s otherwise sunny demeanor: The pursuit of a long-term monogamous and almost always heterosexual romantic relationship is the be-all end-all for every character.\n\nSo Season 7 hinges on a specious will-they-won\u2019t-they for Nick and Jess to get engaged, just as Season 2 danced around a will-they-won\u2019t-they for Nick and Jess in general (yep, they would). The show likes a slow build, but the only thing that\u2019s ever stood in any couple\u2019s way has been an arbitrary shenanigan. There aren\u2019t even ones that got away on \u201cNew Girl,\u201d because everyone\u2019s one-who-got-away comes back for a second try. Jess\u2019s onetime one-who-got-away Sam returned, and then left Jess for his one-who-got-away. What do we want? Coupledom! When do we want it? On season finales!\n\nIn the penultimate episode of Season 5, Nick, the unhygienic but lovable novelist, declared that there are only seven kinds of stories: \u201cMan versus man, man versus dog, dog versus zombie, James Bond, stories of kings and lords, women over 50 finding themselves after divorce and car commercial.\u201d He soon after adds an eighth: \u201cFat boy talks to idiot.\u201d\n\nThese narrative categorizations are unimpeachable. And in this structure, \u201cNew Girl\u201d falls under \u201cwomen over 50 finding themselves after divorce,\u201d because the thrust of the show is a slow crawl toward self-actualization. The show\u2019s overemphasis on matrimony is really its attempted emphasis on stability. \u201cNew Girl\u201d is a show about hatching into adulthood, but it\u2019s never been sure how to let its characters actually hatch already. Professional advancement, enlightened attitudes about one\u2019s parents, clarity of purpose \u2014 nothing seems to stick or to lead to any meaningful gains in confidence or conviction.\n\nPerpetual self-doubt is the hormone that powers one\u2019s body through its 20s but at, say, 41 it starts to seem less darling and more tragic, on men and women alike. At the start of \u201cNew Girl,\u201d Jess is cripplingly insecure, and that only barely abates as the series goes on. She\u2019s in good company, at least, as it turns out every character on the show is insecure, and truly no one can communicate. Of the 144 episodes of the show that I have seen, the story arc for probably 120 can be summarized as \u201cI didn\u2019t know how to tell you\u2026.\u201d Imagine \u201cThe Office\u201d if every character was Season 2 Pam, forever.", "title": "\u2018New Girl\u2019 Returns, Up to Its Old Tricks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Hart (who also co-wrote the script) plays a barbecue-grill salesman who yearns for a career as a stockbroker but learns he must complete his G.E.D. first. In comes Ms. Haddish as the no-nonsense teacher, who declares he\u2019s \u201cclinically dumb.\u201d\n\n\u201cNight School\u201d reunites the actress with Malcolm D. Lee, director of her 2017 breakout hit \u201cGirls Trip.\u201d The film comes from the prolific producer Will Packer, whose credits include \u201cGirls Trip\u201d as well as Mr. Hart\u2019s \u201cRide Along\u201d movies.\n\nAmong the familiar faces spotted in the teaser are \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d alumni Taran Killam and Rob Riggle. We get glimpses of her accomplices \u2014 played by Cate Blanchett, Mindy Kaling, Sarah Paulson, Rihanna, Awkwafina and Helena Bonham Carter \u2014 and the victim (Anne Hathaway). Even the sight of late-night talk-show host James Corden as an insurance investigator isn\u2019t a surprise, since he also appeared in the previous trailer.\n\nSo what\u2019s new? A few numbers: $16.5 million (the amount of money each thief will receive from the heist) and five years, eight months and 12 days (Debbie\u2019s prison term). Oh, and the song accompanying the clip: Linda Ronstadt\u2019s \u201cYou\u2019re No Good,\u201d from 1974.\n\nWarner Bros. might need to offer up more to get moviegoers to fork over their money when \u201cOcean\u2019s 8\u201d lands in theaters on June 8.", "title": "\u2018Ocean\u2019s 8\u2019: New Trailer Offers a Few More Details", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "ATHENS \u2014 After a violent clash between Greeks and migrants seeking asylum in Europe, the Greek authorities and human rights groups say they fear rising tensions and more conflicts on the eastern Aegean Islands that house tens of thousands of refugees who have arrived via Turkey.\n\nThe confrontation, which lasted for hours on Sunday and Monday, took place on the island of Lesbos, where tolerance of the growing refugee population has worn thin, and where members of far-right, anti-immigrant groups have been exploiting the frustration. Tensions in the overcrowded migrant camps often erupt into brawls and riots, but major clashes with Greeks have been rare since the flood of refugees from Asia and Africa began three years ago.\n\nAbout 200 Afghans had been camped for several days in a central square of Mytilene, the main port city of Lesbos, to protest living conditions in the government-run camps and delays in processing their asylum applications. Lesbos is one of the areas most burdened by the refugee crisis; about 8,700 of the 60,000 migrants living in Greek camps are housed there.\n\nOn Sunday, local residents gathered in Mytilene to object to the presence of the Afghans, a demonstration that escalated into violence. Some of the protesters pelted the migrants in the square with flares, firecrackers and stones broken off sidewalks, and some chanted \u201cburn them alive,\u201d according to local news media.", "title": "\u2018One of the Hardest Nights\u2019: Violence Erupts Between Greeks and Migrants", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "When your mother handed you a copy of \u201cOur Bodies, Ourselves,\u201d it meant one of two things: You were about to have a pained conversation with a parent wielding a hand mirror, or you were meant to take the book, read it and never mention it again. Either way, you were prepared.\n\nFor generations of girls, \u201cOur Bodies, Ourselves\u201d was the starter pack to adulthood: It let you know whether your vulva was weird looking (it wasn\u2019t), what kind of birth control you might want to use and whether you were the only one who had a special relationship with your pillow. (You weren\u2019t, Page 162 assured.)\n\nBut after nearly 50 years, Our Bodies Ourselves, the Boston nonprofit home of the book, will stop publishing the pubescent tome amid a period of \u201ctransition.\u201d The book, last updated in 2011, will no longer have new editions. The nonprofit organization housing their programmatic work \u2014 they reported $279,460 in revenue for its 2016 fiscal year \u2014 will now be led by volunteers.\n\n\u201cThis is a really sad moment for our readers,\u201d said Julie Childers, the executive director of Our Bodies Ourselves. \u201cBut we still have a strong, scrappy board of directors and 300 experts in the field to continue being a voice in the public sphere.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Our Bodies, Ourselves\u2019? It\u2019s Shelved", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "It has also led to the feeling that many of the country\u2019s Pashtun population centers have been under functional occupation by the security forces. Using an alternative system of military counterterrorism courts along with an extensive network of covert jails, security and intelligence officers wield life-or-death power \u2014 often instantly \u2014 over the Pakistani region known as the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, a leftover from the British colonial system.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new Pashtun rights movement \u2014 which is known by the initials P.T.M., from words that translate as Pashtun Protection Movement \u2014 is the product of years of outrage over the security forces\u2019 power. It caught spark after the killing of a small group of Pashtun men, including an aspiring model named Naqeebullah Mehsud who was originally from the tribal areas, by police officers in Karachi in January. The officers have been accused of staging a fake shootout to cover up an extrajudicial killing spree.\n\nUnder the leadership of a young activist, Manzoor Pashteen, 26, the P.T.M. has evoked deep emotion from Pashtuns in Pakistan and Afghanistan, as well as overseas.\n\nMr. Pashteen and his allies say that Pashtuns, who make up about 15 percent of Pakistan\u2019s population of some 204 million, have endured countless human rights violations, from disappearances to forced evictions. At rallies, women clutch pictures of sons they say were hauled off by security officials, never to be seen again.\n\nMr. Pashteen says that from the start, the movement has faced hostility from the military and its agencies, and is increasingly the subject of propaganda and social media campaigns engineered by supporters of the security forces.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve spent these two months enduring accusation after accusation, that we\u2019re foreign agents and working on behalf of some other group,\u201d he said Monday in an interview. \u201cAll we can do is try to take the moral high ground. We know our first mistake will be our last.\u201d\n\nAnother leader of the movement, Mohsin Dawar, was equally stark about the risks of open protest against the military: \u201cSpeaking about the army like this in Pakistan is suicide.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the protest in Peshawar on April 8, Mr. Pashteen condemned the military and its agents as \u201coppressors\u201d and called for the end of curfews and army checkpoints in the tribal areas.\n\nPhoto\n\nThough the demonstration drew tens of thousands of Pashtun marchers from all over the country, its coverage on local television news media was next to absent, and only a smattering of Pakistani newspapers covered the event.\n\nThen, three columns about the movement that were published by The News International, one of Pakistan\u2019s biggest English-language news outlets, disappeared Sunday from its website not long after being posted.\n\nInterviews with newspaper editors and writers \u2014 many of whom spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear of the military\u2019s reaction \u2014 portrayed an atmosphere in which reporting on the Pashtun movement was widely being seen as a red line for the country\u2019s security establishment.\n\nThe journalists described the main factors in keeping the movement out of the news as a combination of direct warnings from military officials or their go-betweens and self-censorship in order to avoid being shut down.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn recent weeks, the country\u2019s biggest news channel, Geo TV, has been run off the air by cable operators who are broadly seen here as under threat from a military establishment that has increasingly been flexing its authority over civilian institutions.\n\n\u201cA lot of this is self-censorship, but you can\u2019t ask individual journalists to be crusaders for free expression,\u201d said Saroop Ijaz, a representative for the advocacy group Human Rights Watch in Pakistan. \u201cNow that the state has demonstrated its power against Geo, you have a chilling effect. They\u2019ve set a precedent for blatant censorship.\u201d\n\nKhan Zaman Kakar, an anthropologist and P.T.M. activist, was among those whose columns were abruptly removed from The News International. \u201cMy column went to print in the Sunday paper, then disappeared from the site around midday,\u201d he said. \u201cThen I received a call from my editor saying it wasn\u2019t a technical issue.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kakar said he could read between the lines and wasn\u2019t surprised that his column was censored: \u201cI knew when I submitted it that it touches an issue the state does not want.\u201d\n\nMany journalists described coming under immense pressure to keep the Pashtun movement out of the headlines.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s happening now is far more detailed and micromanaged as compared with the past,\u201d said Talat Hussein, a senior broadcast journalist and talk-show host. \u201cIt makes the current crackdown deadly and disturbing,\u201d he added, because there are no avenues for recourse.\n\nMr. Dawar, one of the movement\u2019s lead activists, said the censorship was sad, but not surprising. \u201cWe were actually surprised that the columns ran in the first place,\u201d he said. \u201cMost publications are reluctant to cover any issues against the military.\u201d\n\nHe said social media had allowed the movement to gain supporters, as well as sympathetic international audiences. \u201cElectronic media, print media \u2014 we don\u2019t need them. The entire world is seeing it, and seeing it live,\u201d Mr. Dawar said.\n\nThe movement\u2019s founders are counting on the idea that the world is watching as they continue to defy the military.\n\n\u201cWe have no option but to continue,\u201d Mr. Pashteen said. \u201cWe are on the last possible option.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Our First Mistake Will Be Our Last\u2019: Pakistani Rights Movement Defies Army", "authors": ["Meher Ahmad"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, it costs nothing to take the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg bridges either way across the East River.\n\n\u201cThere is no rhyme or reason to the tolls that people pay,\u201d Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said when he addressed the issue in January by calling for \u201clowering the outer-borough tolls, which are crazy high\u201d as part of any congestion pricing plan.\n\nFor commuters like Marcel Vantuyn, the tolls add up quickly, even with E-ZPass discounts. He pays $88.85 every week in combined tolls for the Verrazano and Goethals bridges just to shuttle back and forth between his home in Brooklyn and his job in Elizabeth, N.J. \u201cMonthly tolls basically add up to a car payment,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Vantuyn, 58, said that while a reliable public transit system is vital for the city, the funding for it should be raised from taxes on all city residents, and not just tolls on drivers. \u201cIt\u2019s not good policy to target a particular group,\u201d he said. \u201cI think everything for the common good should come from a common pool.\u201d\n\nTruckers pay even higher tolls. On the Verrazano, the full tolls range from $34 to $132 depending on the number of axles, and with an E-ZPass discount, $20.80 to $79.52.\n\nSteve Margarella, 64, who owns a road construction company on Staten Island, has to absorb between $2,000 and $10,000 in bridge tolls every month to send his fleet of trucks around the city. \u201cIt puts all Staten Island companies at a disadvantage,\u201d he said.\n\nIn some neighborhoods, the tolls also lead to spillover congestion from \u201cbridge-shopping.\u201d Canal Street in Lower Manhattan has become jammed with drivers from Brooklyn bound for New Jersey who go out of their way to avoid the Verrazano toll. Many cross over on the Manhattan Bridge, travel along Canal Street and then into the Holland Tunnel to New Jersey.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou have a situation because there\u2019s so much excess regional traffic coming through what is now a neighborhood,\u201d said Ellen Baer, president of Hudson Square Connection, a business improvement district, who has seen traffic to the Holland Tunnel block intersections, impede deliveries and worsen noise and pollution.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe wide disparity in bridge tolls is largely a function of who runs what bridge. Of the more than 2,000 bridges in the city, the major crossings are operated by three different entities: the city\u2019s Transportation Department, the state-controlled Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the interstate Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.\n\nThe city oversees 789 bridges and does not charge tolls on any of them. Some elected officials view the East River bridges as a free public resource and have opposed periodic attempts over the years to toll them.\n\nIn contrast, the Port Authority and M.T.A. charge tolls on their bridges, but independently set the amounts based on their financial needs. \u201cYou\u2019re buying more than the bridge when you pay that toll,\u201d said Robert E. Paaswell, a civil engineering professor at the City College of New York. \u201cIn theory, tolls are supposed to go away when a bridge is paid for, but that rarely happens. The costs are skewed because in addition to maintenance, they are used by different agencies for different purposes.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTolls from the four Port Authority-run bridges \u2014 the Bayonne, Goethals, Outerbridge Crossing and George Washington \u2014 and the Lincoln and Holland tunnels are used not only to support those crossings but also public transit services, including the Port Authority bus terminal and the PATH train system. Ron Marsico, a spokesman for the authority, said that it \u201cconsolidates the revenues from all its operations to meet the capital investment and operating needs of its facilities.\u201d The last toll increase was in 2011, and less than 15 percent of drivers \u2014 those without E-ZPass \u2014 currently pay the full $15 cash toll, he said.\n\nThe M.T.A. operates seven bridges, including the Verrazano, which was the longest suspension bridge in the world when it opened in 1964 with a toll of just 50 cents. Today, it is one of the city\u2019s busiest links with, on average, 196,000 vehicle crossings per day on weekdays, of which Staten Island residents account for about 75,000 crossings per day, according to M.T.A. data.\n\nM.T.A. officials said that the $17 toll is higher than its other bridges because it is priced to cover the return trip. A federal law pushed through by then U.S. Representative Guy V. Molinari, a Republican from Staten Island, converted two-way toll collections to one-way in 1986 to reduce commuting times and air pollution on the Staten Island end of the bridge. Similarly, in 1970, the Port Authority decided on one-way tolls on traffic going into New York City to reduce congestion and emissions.\n\nThe M.T.A.\u2019s other major bridge crossings \u2014 including the Bronx-Whitestone, Throgs Neck and Robert F. Kennedy (formerly the Triborough) \u2014 all charge a top toll of $8.50 each way, for a total of $17 round-trip.\n\nThe Verrazano toll has long riled local residents on both sides of the bridge, many of whom subscribe to an enduring urban myth \u2014 repeatedly debunked \u2014 that the bridge was supposed to be free once it was all paid for. Instead, the toll has steadily crept upward, most recently by $1 last year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not because the bridge is getting more expensive,\u201d said Samuel I. Schwartz, a transportation consultant who has proposed reducing such tolls as part of a congestion pricing plan. \u201cIt\u2019s because we need more and more money to pay for the subways and trains coming into Manhattan.\u201d\n\nFrom the Verrazano alone, the M.T.A. collected $417 million in tolls in 2017, up from $393 million the year before. M.T.A. officials said the money paid for the bridge\u2019s maintenance, services and debt, with any remaining surplus going to support public transit.\n\nAbout 85 percent of vehicles crossing the Verrazano qualify for the E-ZPass rate, according to M.T.A. data. Of those, about 45 percent received an additional Staten Island resident discount, paying $5.50, or $3.20 for car pools.\n\nBut many drivers and their supporters complain that efforts to offset the high tolls do not go far enough.\n\nState Senator Martin J. Golden, a Republican from Brooklyn who has led rallies at the foot of the bridge for lower tolls, said many Brooklyn residents also relied heavily on the Verrazano yet do not receive the resident discount. \u201cTalk about gouging people,\u201d Mr. Golden said. \u201cMy community is very upset. It\u2019s a tremendous burden on them and it shouldn\u2019t be.\u201d\n\nOn the other end of the bridge, Linda Baran, president of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, said she recently heard from an architect struggling to find workers willing to commute because of the tolls \u201cand he\u2019s not the only business that has mentioned it.\u201d\n\n\u201cPeople hesitate to visit Staten Island because the tolls are so high,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s really frustrating when you see the East River bridges are free. I believe that everybody needs to give a little.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Outrageous\u2019 $17 Toll to Cross the Verrazano Vexes Drivers", "authors": ["Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-04-21 00:00:00", "text": "A mail carrier in Brooklyn stashed about 17,000 pieces of undelivered mail for more than a decade because he was \u201coverwhelmed\u201d by the amount he had to deliver, the authorities said.\n\nThe carrier, Aleksey Germash, told investigators he \u201cmade sure to deliver the important mail,\u201d according to a complaint filed in federal court.\n\nMr. Germash, a Postal Service employee for more than 16 years, was charged with detaining and delaying mail on Thursday.\n\nThe service\u2019s Office of Inspector General received a tip this month about a Nissan Pathfinder parked in Brooklyn with mailbags stuffed inside. Several children survived.\n\n\u201cThe scene was full of panic, cries, chaos and disaster,\u201d said Rakesh Pathania, a local politician who was at the site of the crash.\n\nThe bus, the authorities said, was carrying elementary school students from a private school in the state of Himachal Pradesh in the Himalayas when it swerved and fell hundreds of feet into a deep ravine around 3:15 p.m.\n\nThe bus was carrying 40 people, and the children who died were between the ages of 4 and 12, said Prabodh Saxena, the principal secretary of the state government.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt is not clear why the bus crashed,\u201d Mr. Saxena said. \u201cWe have called for an inquiry.\u201d\n\nOne surviving boy, 10-year-old Ranveer Singh, told The Hindustan Times that he heard a loud bang and the bus started rolling down the side of the gorge. \u201cJust then the window near my seat broke and I and a girl sitting by my side fell out,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat girl, along with several other students, survived the crash. A convoy of cars and bicycles made up of passers-by rushed to bring injured students to a nearby hospital before ambulances arrived at the scene near the town of Nurpur.\n\nPhoto\n\nBetween 300 and 400 local residents \u201cworked like monkeys\u201d to rush down to the crash site and rescue trapped passengers, Mr. Pathania said. Most of the children died from head injuries or suffocation. (Partly at Rondo\u2019s suggestion, they chose Thursday.)\n\nReason being: Rondo has the pulse of this team like no other. Long regarded by various teams he\u2019s played for as a headstrong handful, and by some members of the news media as chilly (or worse), Rondo has been a popular teammate almost everywhere he\u2019s played, reminiscent of the media-averse former All-Star forward Rasheed Wallace.\n\nIn New Orleans, though, Rondo is flat-out beloved by his teammates.\n\n\u201cSometimes they don\u2019t agree, coaches and him, because he likes to do what he thinks is best for the team,\u201d said Nikola Mirotic, the sharpshooting New Orleans forward. \u201cBut I always say, with Pau Gasol, he\u2019s the best teammate I ever had.\u201d\n\nSaid Gentry: \u201cYou can\u2019t go in that locker room and talk to one guy that doesn\u2019t believe in him.\u201d\n\nDespite Rondo\u2019s reputation for being, at the very least, relentlessly contrarian and challenging to coach, Gentry compares him to Nash often. He said that Rondo\u2019s former coach in Boston, Doc Rivers, dismissed his own ups and downs with a younger Rondo and strongly assured Gentry that their partnership would be prosperous.\n\nEven after everything that happened with the Mavericks, Rondo\u2019s former coach in Dallas, Rick Carlisle, insists he\u2019s not surprised by the success Rondo has found in New Orleans given \u201cthe assortment of shooters and finishers they have on that roster.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf you put the right pieces around Rondo, he is a proven champion,\u201d Carlisle said. \u201cWe didn\u2019t have the right personnel around him for things to work well in Dallas. The truth is that we were probably a worse fit for him than he was for us. He helps make New Orleans a very scary second-round opponent.\u201d\n\nGentry, meanwhile, does acknowledge at least some creative tension, pointing to the practice floor from his office and saying, \u201cEvery day in there is not a picnic, now.", "title": "\u2018Playoff Rondo\u2019 Politely (Not Really) Requests a New Nickname", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 True movie stars can \u201copen\u201d a film of any quality simply by having their name above the title. Very few of those specimens remain in this fragmented entertainment age, but Dwayne Johnson proved himself as one over the weekend.\n\n\u201cRampage,\u201d a PG-13 cheesefest involving mutant animals and marketed squarely around Mr. Johnson\u2019s presence, generated $34.5 million in ticket sales in its North American debut, on the low end of prerelease analyst expectations but enough for No. 1. \u201cRampage,\u201d which received weak reviews, collected an additional $140 million overseas, according to comScore, which compiles box office data.\n\nImage The producer Jason Blum, left, and Tyler Posey, one of the stars of \u201cBlumhouse\u2019s Truth or Dare.\u201d Credit Earl Gibson Iii/Getty Images\n\nNew Line Cinema, a division of Warner Bros., spent at least $220 million to make and market \u201cRampage\u201d worldwide.\n\nSecond place for the weekend went to the hit horror movie \u201cA Quiet Place\u201d (Paramount), which collected a strong $32.6 million, for a two-week domestic total of about $100 million.", "title": "\u2018Rampage\u2019 Is No. 1, Proving Dwayne Johnson\u2019s Box Office Might", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 Steven Spielberg aced his test.\n\n\u201cReady Player One,\u201d a nostalgia-soaked science-fiction adventure that marked a high-wire attempt by Mr. Spielberg, 71, to return to his crowd-pleasing roots, arrived to $53.2 million in ticket sales over the four-day Easter weekend in North America. Overseas audiences chipped in an additional $128 million, with Chinese ticket buyers turning out in particular force.\n\nThose results, boosted by IMAX and other premium-priced, large-format screenings, easily make \u201cReady Player One\u201d the No. 1 movie in the world. Warner Bros. and Village Roadshow spent at least $155 million to make the movie, which carried more than $100 million in global marketing costs.\n\nGoing into the weekend, box office analysts had feared that \u201cReady Player One\u201d might arrive to as little as $38 million in ticket sales in the United States and Canada. Its stars, Tye Sheridan and Olivia Cooke, are not household names. Its story line \u2014 teenagers in a dystopian future search for treasure inside a virtual-reality world called the Oasis \u2014 was exceedingly difficult to explain in marketing materials, especially without resorting to spoilers.", "title": "\u2018Ready Player One\u2019 Overcomes Challenges to Dominate Box Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cRen & Stimpy,\u201d one of Nickelodeon\u2019s first original shows, ran for five seasons between 1991 and 1995, though Mr. Kricfalusi, who worked as its producer and director, left the show in 1992. (In 2014, he denied having been fired.)\n\nWith its edgy sense of humor, the show pushed the limits of what could be considered children\u2019s television. It went on to influence the creators of proudly politically incorrect cartoons including \u201cSouth Park\u201d and \u201cRick and Morty.\u201d\n\nMr. Kricfalusi did not answer phone calls seeking comment. A lawyer speaking on his behalf, Daniel R. Perlman, gave a statement in response to BuzzFeed.\n\n\u201cThe 1990s were a time of mental and emotional fragility for Mr. Kricfalusi, especially after losing \u2018Ren & Stimpy,\u2019 his most prized creation,\u201d the statement said. \u201cFor a brief time, 25 years ago, he had a 16-year-old girlfriend. Over the years John struggled with what were eventually diagnosed mental illnesses in 2008. To that point, for nearly three decades he had relied primarily on alcohol to self-medicate. Since that time he has worked feverishly on his mental health issues, and has been successful in stabilizing his life over the last decade. This achievement has allowed John the opportunity to grow and mature in ways he\u2019d never had a chance at before.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Perlman did not immediately respond to further questions about discrepancies between the timeline offered by his statement and the accounts of Ms. Byrd and Ms. Rice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society.
