View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA spokeswoman for Nickelodeon declined to comment when asked about the allegations against Mr. Kricfalusi.\n\nIn an interview on Monday, Ms. Byrd said she expected more women to come forward with claims about Mr. Kricfalusi. She and Ms. Rice were introduced to each other by Mr. Kricfalusi, who, Ms. Byrd said, later fostered a rivalry between them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe pitted us against each other and we hated each other,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s funny \u2014 I was only 19, but I thought, \u2018He\u2019s replacing me with a younger woman.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Rice agreed in a separate interview, saying, \u201cWe probably would have been best friends but he decided to make it a contest instead and played us against each other.\u201d\n\nBut six years after Ms. Byrd left the animator for good, she and Ms. Rice began to correspond. They became friends, and when Ms. Rice was approached by BuzzFeed, she and Ms. Byrd deliberated for several months before deciding to go on the record about Mr. Kricfalusi, she said.\n\n\u201cWe have to do this,\u201d Ms. Byrd recalled telling Ms. Rice. \u201cGet your courage up. We\u2019re just going to hold hands and jump off the cliff together.\u201d\n\nUntil Friday morning there were two pictures of Mr. Kricfalusi hanging in Nickelodeon\u2019s West Coast office in Burbank, Calif., including a portrait and a fabric banner that included an image of his face, according to a person at the network who was not authorized to speak. They were both taken down on Friday.\n\nMs. Byrd said Monday that the publication of the BuzzFeed article had offered her a remarkable sense of catharsis and that she had received support from many people online. Her therapist has encouraged her to start drawing again, and she has set up a Patreon so that her supporters can help her to pursue a craft she had thought she would never take up again.\n\n\u201cThat was going to be my career and I just ran away in 2002,\u201d she said. \u201cBut now this is happening.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Ren & Stimpy\u2019 Creator Accused of Sexual Misconduct With Teenagers in the 1990s", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich", "Liam Stack"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "They settled on the cult classic \u201cCarrie: The Musical,\u201d and as they worked the parallels between it and \u201cRiverdale\u201d became increasingly clear to them. \u201cIt felt as though the songwriters had written songs for the same set of characters,\u201d Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa said.\n\nAnd he would know. Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa co-wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film remake of \u201cCarrie.\u201d\n\nThe ties between \u201cCarrie: The Musical\u201d and \u201cRiverdale\u201d allowed the writers to advance the plot of the show. \u201cWe wanted it to function as a true musical, which is to say that the stories kept going through the songs,\u201d said Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa.\n\nThe seven songs featured in the episode are performed by the characters during rehearsals and as they go about their daily lives. The roles they are cast in also become intertwined with the story line. In a fit of pique, Betty says to Archie, \u201cFrom where I\u2019m standing, Veronica is just as much of a privileged, selfish, spiteful mean girl as the part she\u2019s playing,\u201d referring to Veronica\u2019s role as Chris Hargensen, Carrie\u2019s main antagonist.\n\nThe line between \u201cCarrie: The Musical\u201d and the world of \u201cRiverdale\u201d almost disappears altogether in shocking ways toward the end of the episode.\n\n\u201cRiverdale\u201d is just the latest show to bring a bit of Broadway to the small screen. Here are five other musical episodes of otherwise nonmusical television shows.\n\n\u2018Buffy the Vampire Slayer\u2019: \u2018Once More With Feeling\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Season 6 of \u201cBuffy the Vampire Slayer,\u201d Sunnydale\u2019s residents begin singing instead of speaking. It turns out that Sweet, a powerful demon whose presence causes humans around him to act like they are a part of a chorus line, has come to town. Buffy must defeat him as she struggles to reconnect with her job as a slayer after returning from the dead.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt took the series creator Joss Whedon six months to write the music for \u201cOnce More, With Feeling,\u201d and the cast underwent three months of vocal training to prepare. Hinton Battle, a three-time Tony Award winner, lent his Broadway credentials to the show by appearing as Sweet.\n\nSarah Michelle Gellar, the star of the series, was ambivalent about the experience. \u201cI\u2019m not a singer. I never have been and I didn\u2019t have a lot of time with the material. So my original intention was to have someone else do the singing,\u201d she told Entertainment Weekly.\n\nMs. Gellar came around and the episode earned an Emmy nomination in 2002 for outstanding musical direction.\n\n\u2018Scrubs\u2019: \u2018My Musical\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe hospital staff at Sacred Heart needed to diagnose a patient who begins to hear everyone\u2019s speech as song after losing consciousness in Season 6 of \u201cScrubs.\u201d At first, they think she\u2019s suffering from a psychological problem, only to find out she has a brain aneurysm.\n\nDebra Fordham wrote the episode, with music written by Jan Stevens, Paul Perry, Doug Besterman, and the writers of \u201cAvenue Q,\u201d Jeff Marx and Robert Lopez.\n\nThough the series had included musical elements before, like the \u201cWest Side Story\u201d parody in the episode \u201cMy Way or the Highway,\u201d Bill Lawrence, the series creator, didn\u2019t want to make a musical episode if it wasn\u2019t going to fit into the show.\n\n\u201cWe wouldn\u2019t have done [a musical], except that our medical adviser on the show stumbled onto this case where somebody had an aneurysm and was hearing everything in music,\u201d Mr. Lawrence told TV Guide. \u201cObviously, they weren\u2019t hearing an entire Broadway musical with singing and dancing, but for us in the world of \u2018Scrubs,\u2019 that works.\u201d\n\n\u2018Community\u2019: \u2018Regional Holiday Music\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen the Greendale glee club suffers a collective mental breakdown after it is forced to stop performing copyrighted music in Season 3 of \u201cCommunity,\u201d the study group is enticed into taking its place for the school\u2019s Christmas pageant. The performance is a complete disaster, and the glee club\u2019s leader confesses to engineering the bus accident that killed a previous iteration of the group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe main target of the acerbic satire in this episode is Fox\u2019s \u201cGlee,\u201d which the show also criticized in Season 1 for rarely using original music. \u201cRegional Holiday Music\u201d features all original music by Ludwig G\u00f6ransson, with lyrics by the show\u2019s writers.\n\nIn an interview, the series creator Dan Harmon said the writing team wasn\u2019t sure the episode would work until deep into the writing process.\n\n\u201cAt first it seemed like it was never going to work and then we kind of hit a final point the night before the table read where we finally kind of realized the whole John Carpenter\u2019s \u2018The Thing\u2019/\u2018Body Snatchers\u2019 sort of angle to this,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2018It\u2019s Always Sunny in Philadelphia\u2019: \u2018The Nightman Cometh\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nThe \u201cSunny\u201d gang is confused when the quasi-literate Charlie announces he has written a musical in Season 4. They assume there is some sort of selfish motivation behind it, but Charlie insists he did it for fun. Enlisting his friends, he puts the show on and convinces his longtime crush, the Waitress, to attend. He promises that if she does, he won\u2019t bother her again.\n\nThe musical, called \u201cThe Nightman Cometh,\u201d is a thinly veiled autobiographical story about Charlie\u2019s long-running infatuation with the Waitress and the sexual abuse he suffered at the hands of Uncle Jack.\n\n\u201cThe Nightman Cometh\u201d did not stay confined to the small screen. In 2009, the team brought it to the stage for a seven-stop tour after a successful, somewhat impromptu show at a club in Los Angeles.\n\n\u201cThe Troubadour posted that we were going to perform \u2018The Nightman Cometh\u2019 and it sold out in record time,\u201d Charlie Day told Spin. \u201cWe realized that we had to do something good.\u201d\n\n\u2018Grey\u2019s Anatomy\u2019: \u2018Song Beneath the Song\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Season 7 of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy,\u201d a pregnant Callie Torres \u2014 played by Tony Award-winner Sara Ramirez \u2014 is seriously injured in a car accident and begins to hallucinate that everyone around her is singing. A debate between her friends and colleagues ensues about how to treat her.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer deteriorating condition pushes the doctors to perform a high-risk procedure to save her life. Her baby is born prematurely but survives, and Callie eventually wakes up, and accepts a marriage proposal from her girlfriend, Arizona, that preceded the crash.\n\nThe series creator Shonda Rhimes said she wanted to create a musical episode of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d since filming the show\u2019s pilot, but it took several years to actually make it happen.\n\nFor the episode, Ms. Rhimes, the executive producer Betsy Beers and the director Tony Phelan chose songs that had played an important part in earlier episodes of the show. \u201cIt became about picking the most iconic ones, the ones that best suited our singers, and the ones that made the most sense,\u201d Ms. Rhimes told TV Guide.", "title": "\u2018Riverdale\u2019 Brings Broadway to the Small Screen With \u2018Carrie: The Musical\u2019", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "In all, Tuesday\u2019s figures were a 16 percent decline from the premiere. In the 18-to-49-year-old demographic vital to advertisers, \u201cRoseanne\u201d notched a 3.9 rating, a 25 percent decline.\n\nThe loss, however, was in line with what executives at ABC and rival networks expected. And at a moment when the number of live viewers is plummeting, the figure suggests that a sizable audience is willing to watch TV the old-fashioned way.\n\nIn conversations on Tuesday, network executives said that if the second week of \u201cRoseanne\u201d experienced a decline in ratings of around 15 percent, ABC should still count it as a success. Stomachs were likely to churn at ABC\u2019s Burbank, Calif., headquarters only if the show lost more than 25 percent of its initial audience.\n\nOther recent revivals have experienced significant ratings losses once the novelty of their returns faded. In September, NBC\u2019s \u201cWill & Grace\u201d lost 30 percent of its audience from its first week to its second. The show has continued to bleed viewers, but its ratings have stayed strong enough to make it a top 10 program. In 2016, Fox\u2019s \u201cThe X-Files\u201d lost 40 percent of its audience for its second episode. On Showtime, \u201cTwin Peaks\u201d experienced a decline of more than 50 percent between its first and second weeks.\n\nThe robust return of \u201cRoseanne\u201d has made the show and its namesake star political lightning rods. Fox News pundits joined Mr. Trump in hailing the success of the \u201cRoseanne\u201d premiere as a victory of their own. Some viewers on the left have expressed misgivings about supporting the show. And there were hot-take commentators who argued that \u201cRoseanne\u201d is surprisingly subversive, with more nuanced politics than either its ardent fans or its vocal detractors have acknowledged.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe third episode was about a generational parenting conflict that pitted Roseanne\u2019s stricter, more traditional style against the looser, hands-off approach of her daughter Darlene.\n\nA wild card factor is how much of a ratings drop will come in the show\u2019s third week. Will \u201cRoseanne\u201d suffer mild, 5-to-10-percent declines as it moves closer to its ninth and final episode? Or will the falloff be steeper?\n\nTo make matters more complicated, Ms. Barr has her Twitter feed back.\n\nTwo months before the show premiered, she was not much of a presence on Twitter. She said her family had taken her password away, and she mentioned that she did not \u201cwant it to overshadow the show.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in recent weeks, Ms. Barr has been posting frequently on Twitter, and it did not take long for her to stir up controversy. Over the weekend, she seemed to endorse a fringe conspiracy theory known as \u201cThe Storm,\u201d which suggests that Mr. Trump is breaking up child sex-trafficking rings involving Democratic politicians.\n\nThe message, which was later deleted, raised questions about whether Ms. Barr might eventually cause a revolt among viewers or advertisers, a cause for some concern among ABC executives, who have publicly backed their reborn star.\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t control Roseanne Barr,\u201d Ben Sherwood, the president of Disney and ABC\u2019s television group, said in an interview last week. \u201cMany who have tried have failed. She\u2019s the one and only.\u201d\n\nThe \u201cRoseanne\u201d reboot came out of a strategy hatched at ABC after Mr. Trump\u2019s victory in November 2016. The goal was to increase the network\u2019s appeal to Middle America. The premiere episode more than doubled ABC\u2019s internal ratings estimates, and it performed best in heartland cities that do not usually light up the Nielsen meters.\n\nIf the show continues to deliver strong numbers, it could help take ABC out of last place among the four major broadcast networks.", "title": "\u2018Roseanne\u2019 Mania Cools Slightly in Show\u2019s Second Week", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Many of the comments I received were supportive \u2014 retweets, likes and the always flattering fist emoji. However, I have to admit that the loudest voices to me were the ones that were vitriolic and shockingly mean. Among the hundreds of replies I got, some included words like \u201ccrybaby\u201d and \u201cbitch.\u201d One comment was simply three short words: \u201cSlant eye ____.\u201d For some reason, when that one appeared, I stared at it for a good 60 seconds (probably because my eyes are so slanted) trying to wrap my head around what had just happened.\n\nIn putting my thoughts to tweet, I was attempting to do a few things: question the creative motivation behind the joke, point out glaring industry double standards and shed some light on the systemic complacency that allows these things to happen.\n\nWhat I was definitely not attempting to do was presume knowledge of any sinister intentions of anyone at the show or at ABC. But the truth remains: They wrote a bad joke. It wasn\u2019t funny, it used broad racial generalizations for no ostensible reason, and it never should have made it to air.\n\nA show that shares its title with the name of its lead actress is already testing the \u201cfourth wall\u201d by design. By airing a joke by which that fictional character suddenly references other fictional characters from different TV shows on the same real network, the writers were basically begging the audience to blur this line even further. There\u2019s a reason you don\u2019t often see this happen \u2014 it takes the viewer out of the story. When was the last time you heard someone on \u201cNCIS: New Orleans\u201d go: \u201cQuick! The killer\u2019s getting away with the serum! Maybe \u2018Kevin Can Wait\u2019 \u2026 but we sure can\u2019t!\u201d In the case of \u201cRoseanne,\u201d this was especially jarring in light of Roseanne Barr\u2019s extensive right-wing political advocacy and the showrunner Bruce Helford\u2019s explicit request that viewers somehow separate that advocacy from the fictional world of the show.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat said, as a television writer myself, I can sympathize with the pressures and deadlines of network comedy. Not everything is going to be a winner. Not everything is vetted and picked apart. At the end of the day, it was a couple lines on a TV show. Let\u2019s all just move on. I kind of agree.\n\nKind of.\n\nBecause, to me, this isn\u2019t just about a couple lines on a TV show. This isn\u2019t just about Twitter or outrage or political correctness or even race, per se. To me, this is about attention. This is about the basic human need to have someone say: \u201cI see you. You matter.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI am watching \u201cRoseanne.\u201d I have it on my DVR and will probably finish the season. Like so many of us, I was a huge fan of the show\u2019s original iteration in the \u201990s and the opening harmonica alone sends endorphins cascading down my spinal cord. The set, the tone, the music and the actors (including the national treasures Laurie Metcalf and John Goodman) all conspire to instantly bring me back to a simpler, more comforting time.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMoreover, I sincerely believe the show is attempting to tell stories in an awkward, nuanced middle ground that makes it laudable. It is with this high standard that I am watching \u201cRoseanne,\u201d so when I sit down to take in an episode \u2014 I am paying attention. And what my attention reveals to me is a show about people who feel left behind.\n\nAfter a two-decade hiatus, \u201cRoseanne\u201d has suddenly returned in glorious HD for a reason. Its astronomical ratings \u2014 over 18 million viewers watched the series the night it had its premiere \u2014 proclaims not only the show\u2019s enduring resonance, but also a restitution of something lost (or at least something passed). In this era of capital-D Diversity, numbers like that indicate an unequivocal hunger (dare I say nostalgia) for stories about families like the Conners, who live blue-collar, paycheck-to-paycheck lives; fighting, laughing, and loving in the earnest heartland (read: white working class) of America. Not unlike the results of the 2016 presidential election, the #MakeAmericaWatchRoseanneAgain movement is a beacon in the night, illuminating a once-abandoned subsection of the country with a spotlight of validation. As if it were saying: \u201cI see you. You matter.\u201d\n\nWhich is why it\u2019s so galling that a show celebrating ostensibly marginalized Americans would consider shows about even more marginalized Americans a punch line, tossed off between two yawns and a meh, followed by a roomful of people laughing.\n\nAnd although, admittedly, I have no idea what it means to be white or working class, there are at least a half-dozen shows out there through which I can experience it vicariously. Meanwhile, white working-class people have one \u2014 and only one \u2014 current network show to help them understand the lives of Asian-Americans (hint: it rhymes with Shmesh Off the Shmoat).\n\nPhoto\n\nBecause here\u2019s where I agree that we are all the same: It\u2019s the invisibility that hurts. It\u2019s the passing over, the looking away, the casual flick of the hand. It\u2019s the denial of basic recognition. It\u2019s the reluctance to concede that your story deserves to be told. In some profound or perverse way, I see a subtle kinship between the watershed premiere of \u201cFresh Off the Boat\u201d in February 2015 and the recent revival of \u201cRoseanne\u201d in March 2018. In both instances, the shows were received with the same profound subtext: \u201cI see you. You matter.\u201d\n\nI don\u2019t think it\u2019s a zero sum game. I refuse to believe that just because one group gets attention, another group gets dismissed. I don\u2019t understand how telling one kind of story requires a blas\u00e9 disregard for another. In fact, I think different stories can serve different purposes. I can watch one TV show as an uplifting reflection of my own experience, while watching another as a deep dive into \u201cOthersville.\u201d\n\nBut that requires effort and patience and curiosity and attention. As comfy and cozy as it might be, we can\u2019t fall asleep in front of our television sets like Roseanne and Dan. We have to somehow resist the safety of our heavy eyelids and the security of our warm couches. If we want others to respect our stories, we have to respect theirs.\n\nAt the very least, we have to stay awake and continually challenge ourselves to say: \u201cMaybe we\u2019re not all caught up.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Roseanne\u2019: When a Punch Line Feels Like a Gut Punch", "authors": ["Kelvin Yu"]} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "Over on Team Madam Buttrface, Yuhua Hamasaki was bossy, but captain Mon\u00e9t humanely subdued her, privately bemoaning in a confessional, \u201cThere is no \u2018I\u2019 in team, girl.\u201d (True, but there is an \u201ce\u201d in \u201cbutter,\u201d so perhaps we should not cite alphabetical omissions in our adduction of others\u2019 poor decisions.) Yuhua passive-aggressively refused to make herself as legitimately ugly as her role demanded \u2014 while her teammates gamely obscured their beauty with fake noses and rubber warts, she painted herself like a Florida dinner-theater Grizabella \u2014 and when called out for it, she let loose an acrid spray of defense.\n\nThe gorgeous Asia O\u2019Hara, made down to resemble \u201cLucy, the missing link,\u201d proved to be the found link of the challenge. She stole the show with her gnarled mugging, which was benevolently whipped up by team leader Mon\u00e9t, though she later regretted this X Change of power (\u201cFocus on meeee!\u201d). Vanjie!\n\nDespite the presence of the conflama addict The Vixen and the oratory addict Eureka, the sweet-faced Blair softly guided Team End of Days through a very funny, freewheeling bit \u2014 Eureka purse-slapped Miz Cracker, for which the latter offered retroactive consent: \u201cDrag is a contact sport!\u201d She really is great.\n\nThe Vixen was cast in the role of a street doomsayer, wearing a sandwich board bearing the prophecy, \u201cThe End Is Near.\u201d (Here\u2019s hoping that this also prophesies the fate of her stint on this show.) She crabbed that Eureka\u2019s charismatic scene theft was somehow rigged, and yet, had she spent less time rolling her admittedly lovely eyes and just a few minutes making a distinctive choice and committing to it, she could have chewed that sandwich board and made a meal of her character.\n\nBack in the workroom, Blair popped the cork on a bottle of sparkling kiki and opened up about how much she missed her mother, and how close they are, despite her family\u2019s strong religious beliefs. The Vixen\u2019s attempt to derail the story by picking a fight with Aquaria about a borrowed wig (it should be mentioned that, for a millennial, Aquaria seems surprisingly resistant to the sharing economy) was blessedly concluded by a Deus ex arachnia (A spider was discovered crawling on a dress, sending into a squealing fever all of the queens save for the strapping Kameron, who calmly captured it and, hopefully, released it outdoors, far from where it could hear any more fighting.)\n\nThe heretofore under-heralded Dusty Ray Bottoms snatched the open kiki bottle and poured out the heartbreaking tale of her ostracism from her religious family. They were so hidebound that, after sucker punching her into coming out, they subjected her to an exorcism, claimed that she was \u201cpossessed by a gay demon\u201d and sent her to conversion therapy, where she was told that \u201cin a homosexual relationship, you\u2019ll never find success, you\u2019ll never find love.\u201d\n\nIn the kind of moment that is the apogee of this show, she wept and recounted that she then stopped the \u201ctherapist,\u201d packed her car and drove off to a \u201cbeautiful life,\u201d a hot fianc\u00e9e (a photo confirmed this as hard fact), and the revelation that she \u201cdidn\u2019t have to compromise or change for someone\u2019s small-minded view.\u201d She then blew what was left of our minds by saying, \u201cI still believe in God, because I cried out, and I was heard.\u201d Thank you, Dusty, for reminding us that sometimes, you have to get away from Jesus in order to truly come to Jesus.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMonique offered a moving coda, saying, \u201cHearing everyone\u2019s story is truly helping me see the truth of who they are. We come here with big makeup, big hair, and it\u2019s easy to live behind a character. So, it\u2019s so great to see vulnerability.\u201d I raise my glass of sparkling kiki to that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Vixen, smelling blood in the bubbles, savaged the moment by dusting the cobweb off the Aquaria fight, barking, \u201cThe problem with Aquaria is, she likes to poke the bear and run. This bear will chase you.\u201d Under this bear\u2019s pointless pursuit, Aquaria exited the workroom, and the others chided The Vixen for her constant combativeness.\n\n\u201cYou knew I was a pit bull!\u201d she retorted. This demon just cannot stop vomiting soup \u2014 Dusty, do you still have that exorcist\u2019s number?\n\nRu ushered in the runway challenge, titled simply, \u201cFeathers,\u201d which released a flock of toothless avian puns from the judges that largely did not fly.\n\nThe guest judge Nico Tortorella, who is living proof that a polyamorous pansexual relationship can also bring you success and love, presided, along with Courtney Love, who is living proof that the end of a love relationship can bring you success.\n\nStandouts included Aquaria as a wounded bird pierced by two arrows (presumably slung by the outrageously fortunate The Vixen), and Asia O\u2019Hara, in a daring Tweety Bird raiment, who, owing to her equally brave and unique performance in the maxi-challenge, was deservedly named this week\u2019s winner.\n\nThe bottom two: Yuhua, whose look called to mind an ill-advised remake of the \u201cBirds\u201d featuring Carrie Bradshaw \u2014 on second thought, that is a \u201cSex and the City 3\u201d concept that I would actually watch \u2014 and the spiritually hogtied Mayhem Miller.\n\nMayhem was flogged for her failure to take control of her scene, and for her lack of discipline in her exchanges with those in power. She was ordered to throw off her restraints, push herself to her edge and assume the dominant role in her own Ru-demptive arc.\n\n(My kindred sister Mayhem: I strongly recommend that you fully inhabit this role, as it really does help a late-blooming lady to discover, articulate and demand the reaction she wants from a partner.)\n\nMayhem finally found her inner mistress and dominated the lip sync, to Hole\u2019s \u201cCelebrity Skin.\u201d By the end she was ripping madly at her feathered collar, a caged bird wanting to break free. The molting, jolting Yuhua was cropped from the competition, and sent back down to the dungeon to pack her toys.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHope is the queen without feathers. Our dreamgirl Mayhem is changing. Look at her.\n\nSee you next week. Vanjie!", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019 Season 10, Episode 3: Fifty Shades of Mayhem", "authors": ["Amanda Duarte", "Rupaul S Drag Race"]} {"date": "2018-04-12 00:00:00", "text": "Season 10, Episode 4\n\nGreetings, mother-earthlings. I signal you from the planet Phenylephrine, the foggy orbit of which I have been launched into by the unseasonable cold in my corner of our rapidly-warming globe. Fortunately, our leaders do not deny the forces that are causing these herstoric temperature spikes, and have set about taking immediate action. I am, of course, referring to our RuPresident and his armoire of realness executives.\n\nLast week\u2019s guest judge Courtney Love no doubt pushed the hands of the doomsday clock forward when she caterwauled that \u201cArmageddon \u2026 may be coming!\u201d at which the doomed room laughed and laughed. Somehow I have always known that it would be Ms. Love who would open the seventh seal.\n\nWell, if we\u2019re all going to die, at least we will die having seen the kind of \u201cDrag Race\u201d episode we live through this for. After a slightly frosty exchange between Mayhem and Monique and an icy glare from Aquaria toward The Vixen at the top of the episode, the workroom climate quickly changed as the queens were launched into two delightful challenges that set them buzzing about like endangered bees.\n\nCommander Ru, sporting both a slight vocal strain and tinted glasses that barely concealed his somewhat puffy eyes, sent our comely crew on its first mission: a mini-challenge in which they posed for \u201cphotobombs,\u201d to be edited into images of such supernovas of our shrinking cultural galaxy as the Jonas Brothers, Kim and Kanye and Grumpy Cat.", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019 Season 10, Episode 4: RuPocalypse, Now?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-26 00:00:00", "text": "Ru then dragged our girls from the workroom to the boardroom with the week\u2019s maxi-challenge: a mock-up of RuPaul\u2019s Drag Con. (\u201cFor a queen, it\u2019s a chance to entertain and inspire \u2026 and make a few coins on the side.\u201d) They were ordered to assemble panels, perform demos and discuss the building blocks of drag \u2014 body, face and wigs \u2014 in front of every artist\u2019s worst nightmare: a live audience with an invitation to ask questions.\n\nPrevious teammates Cracker, The Vixen and Blair ru-peated themselves and became Team Wigs; Asia, Monique and Aquaria snapped each other up for Team Face; and the ascending Miss Congeniality candidate Eureka took pity on the ostracized, \u201ctainted\u201d Mon\u00e9t and the silent-but-deadly Kameron Michaels, and warmly embraced them to form a delightfully diverse Team Body.\n\nAsia smugly speculated that, in a public speaking challenge, a body composed of the chatty Eureka, the quiet storm Kameron and the struggling Mon\u00e9t might not work. \u201cAll of them have issues that they\u2019re battling, so we\u2019ll see how that goes,\u201d she said.\n\nListen up, young ones: Drag, as well as most forms of art, is about battling issues, and Team Body got right down to operational-level strategy. Eureka\u2019s past experience at Drag Con led her to wisely appoint herself as panel moderator, and when she accidentally neologized \u201cproportionizing,\u201d the team\u2019s recent experience of assessing what was under their posteriors led them to wisely assent that they were sitting on a pot of gold. Merch first!\n\nTeam Wigs took a controlled-chaos approach, opting not to elect a moderator, with Cracker unwisely cracking that Drag Con is \u201creally just an excuse for queens to hang out.\u201d Drag Con President, CEO and Rear Admiral Ru looked as if he had been stabbed in the forehead with a knife. He gently pulled it out and sagely intoned, \u201cOver the years, I have branded every damn thing I can, and that\u2019s what you should be doing, too.\u201d Ladies, read your contracts and check your flanks!\n\nMonique and Asia expressed concerns that their teammate, the walking selfie Aquaria, would be too lo-fi to rise to the challenge of extemporaneous speaking. The ever-vescent (neologism is contagious) Monique went on to lament her underfunded wardrobe, which necessitated her to \u201cjimmy-rig\u201d (I love her so much) a \u201cdress-gown\u201d (I love her so much) from a raw slab of iridescent paillettes brought from home. She aptly described herself as \u201cthe MacGyver of drag,\u201d saying, \u201cI came to this competition with glitter and Jesus, and bitch, I am making it work, okaaaay?\u201d Okaaaay!\n\nDressed in a merch bag from the Paisley Park gift shop, Ru introduced the queens to the live \u201cDrag Con\u201d audience that ringed the runway.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTeam Body lifted their competitors\u2019 embargo, fired \u201cProportionizing!\u201d into the crowd, and sold the heaven out of it. The three infotainingly demonstrated padding techniques on the incomprehensibly hot Opie-lescent Pit Crew member Brian, behind a shoji screen embellished with what I can only hope are scale, full-color representations of his cunning ham.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe exact type of man who usually has \u201cmore of a comment than a question\u201d at a panel discussion took the mic with, surprisingly, a question! \u201cIn today\u2019s political climate (an abrupt change of topic at which Eureka squalled, \u201cOh!\u201d, and I choked on a Popchip), why is drag so important?\u201d\n\nWithout skipping a beat, Eureka switched gears to the body politic and warmly answered, \u201cWe\u2019re all afraid. We do drag to celebrate ourselves, our femininity \u2026 people celebrate drag with us because it\u2019s a way for them to escape and to feel like they belong, in a political climate where none of us feel like we belong, truly.\u201d Ladies, gentlemen, and everyone in between and beyond: This is what a drag superstar looks and sounds like. I\u2019m starting to have vivid visuals of a crown on her head.\n\nTeam Face made a fun showing, with the moderator Monique (\u201cthe Heart of Season 10!\u201d) and even the typically Mayfair-muted Aquaria leaning in with some choice quotes and dishing out useful tips, like blow-drying false eyelashes into place and using glue to anchor a \u201cred glitter lip,\u201d which, for some reason, was pink.\n\nIt actually causes me physical pain to write about Team Wigs. Blair\u2019s contrived charisma hung in the air like a child star\u2019s burp. Cracker\u2019s playful pitches of shade splatted onto the unoccupied home plate like globs of cigarette-butt-flavored Jell-O. And The Vixen, who up until this moment in the episode seemed refreshingly chastened, responded to the other queens\u2019 jovial jests with not only a complete lack of humor, but, and I can\u2019t believe I\u2019m typing this, actual threats of physical violence. (Perhaps she should ask the Season 2 winner Tyra Sanchez how threatening violence at Drag Con works out.)\n\nThe judges all looked like they were sitting on dead fish, which, in a sense, they were. The crucial fourth building block of drag is the art of shade. If one cannot create in that medium, one has not earned the title of \u201cdrag queen,\u201d and should go back to school until they learn how to properly read.\n\nCouture chapeaus were celebrated in the runway challenge, titled \u201cHat\u2019s Incredible\u201d \u2014 a tip to a television show that ended two years before Blair was born. Mon\u00e9t redeemed herself with an impressive \u201cUber-Executive-to-church\u201d look that tithed her team into the top three, with Eureka named the overall winner for the second week in a row. Blair, in yet another \u201cold Broadway musicals\u201d inspired look, and The Vixen, in the sweepings from Philip Treacy\u2019s studio floor, were sent to the back of the parade.\n\nBlair tearfully confessed that her endless dessert menu of drag was in response to a college rape, and choked, \u201cI urge to find daintiness, because I feel dirty.\u201d Drag Oprah Ru empathetically responded that \u201cwe\u2019ve all had trauma \u2026, and the first response to that is to \u2026 put rainbows on everything. But we know that doesn\u2019t work, and you have to walk through that.\u201d\n\nBlair, you are dainty as heaven, and we are so grateful for your brave confession. But Ru is right: The integration of your trauma into your art is a process for which you are, I\u2019m so sorry to say, due. You have acres of potential, but in this, the springtime of your discontent, you are still a bit green. We love you, Blair. (Me, too.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBlair and The Vixen were consigned to battle to that rugged hymn of the Ru-public, \u201cI\u2019m Coming Out\u201d by Diana Ross. Both performances were amateurish in polar opposite ways \u2014 The Vixen tumbled, jumped and thrashed sans POV, whilst Blair earnestly auditioned for the role of Eponine in a state-college production of \u201cLes Miz.\u201d Sadly, despite a heart full of love, Blair took the bullet, and was sent off on her own. (I can\u2019t wait to see her at her Fantine in Season 6 of All Stars.)\n\nPanel Man\u2019s question was actually quite prescient \u2014 why is drag so important in the current political climate? We are at a fascinating moment where the rebel forces are becoming war profiteers. And, unlike the other wars our generations have endured, this one will have an actual winner. That winner must ask not what her charisma, uniqueness, nerve and talent can do for her, but what she can do for her charisma, uniqueness, nerve and talent. Do we want to elect a community organizer, or a businesswoman? An experienced veteran, or an unpredictable outsider? Who will wield their power most Ru-sponsibly?\n\nThis episode, as promised, helped separate the pros from the cons, the glitter from the Jesus, and, hopefully, the merch from the madness.\n\nSee you next week.", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019 Season 10, Episode 6: Merch Madness", "authors": ["Amanda Duarte", "Rupaul S Drag Race"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Fortunately, we went to this war with the army we want, and our semper fine girls lined up in fetching formation. Monique Heart detonated the runway in grenade earrings and camo chaps, and a newly focused Asia was the bomb as a purple-fatigued Mad-Maxine. But The Vixen, in an Ann-Taylor-for-Army-Surplus capsule-confection, was named the victor.\n\nOur Ru-tenant then announced that the battle was moving to lower ground \u2014 the daytime talk show, that hallowed American theater of war \u2014 in which the ladies\u2019 improvisation skills would be tested in front of a live audience.\n\nThe Vixen was ordered to split the troops into assignments \u2014 silly segments for the talk show, to be hosted by the delightfully off-brand \u201cBossy Rossy\u201d Mathews. She intentionally paired her two mortal enemies, Eureka and Aquaria, openly admitting that she \u201cdidn\u2019t try to [expletive] nobody over except those two. They\u2019re both two big babies, so I hope they suffer.\u201d\n\nEureka and Aquaria were \u201ctwo big babies,\u201d all right \u2014 they both latched on to their segment, \u201cLook At Me, I\u2019m A Sexy Baby!,\u201d and milked the bit dry. Convicted scene-burglar Eureka once again pocketed the challenge, realizing her weight was gold and emerging naked but for a diaper and bib, parroting my Tinder mantra \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m shaped like a fat baby already, so why not give them, like, legit fat sexy baby?\u201d\n\nFor a \u201clook queen,\u201d Aquaria was surprisingly funny, shaking her rattle-dazzled nipples and cooing in a baby voice (an accent that was, sadly, as liminal as Nicole Kidman\u2019s in \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d though it didn\u2019t affect the accolade-winning chances of either).\n\nUpon finding out that her husband had left her for a baby (funny, this is why I joined Tinder), Eureka\u2019s character decided to become one, and upon finding out that Aquaria was the baby he left her for, she threw a ground-pounding tantrum that brought the house down, the house down.\n\nThe rest of the squadron\u2019s improvised devices were not terribly explosive. Blair was zero-dark-twenty-one as a cactus\u2019s cuckold, hitting the panic button early on in her scene with the wig-snatching Monique by screaming their agreed-upon \u201csafe word\u201d, which was, of course, \u201cVanjie!\u201d (Has any first-eliminated queen ever made such a memorable impression? If she is not brought back, I will girlcott this show.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSurprisingly, Mon\u00e9t, a brilliant improviser in her live shows, misfired with a confusing setup that attempted to conflate angel food cake with the hip pads her character was \u201caddicted to\u201d eating, and her bit collapsed. Sweet Mayhem soured as a pickle-phobe, while her partner Miz Cracker tickled as \u201cDr. Dill,\u201d a pickle who was also a psychotherapist who was also Jewish, and then was not.\n\nThe Vixen and Asia\u2019s \u201cSingle Black Female\u201d bit really threw the dog out of the window \u2014 their attempt to mock Cracker and Aquaria\u2019s copycat feud did not progress beyond their similar yellow dresses and, after swinging and missing at all of Ross\u2019s jokey pitches, The Vixen simply walked. I mean, I only made it through level two at the Upright Citizens\u2019 Brigade, but even I know that the cardinal rule of improv is \u201cYes, and,\u201d not \u201cNo, bye!\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn elimination day, Mayhem attempted to broker peace between Eureka and The Vixen. After a painful \u201cUntucked\u201d clip in which Eureka was legit bitchy and The Vixen threw water boiled with fission, the latter froze to ice as Mayhem amiably advocated for an armistice.\n\nEureka ceded the battleground to The Vixen, gently offering her space and conceding that, although she was sure she\u2019d said \u201cy\u2019all\u201d and not \u201cyou\u201d (this was important in a context that I have neither space nor energy to describe), if \u201cyou\u201d was what she\u2019d actually said (it was), she was sorry.\n\nEureka shared that, after a lifetime of antagonism and abuse, drag helped her \u201cfind her voice,\u201d and admitted that, now that her mouth has been opened, she can get \u201ca little out of hand.\u201d\n\nThis elicited the glimpse of The Vixen\u2019s inner workings that we have been longing to catch, as she confessed in turn that for most of her drag career, she would silently \u201cshow up, get my money and leave,\u201d but that the \u201ccurrent climate\u201d radicalized and uncorked her.\n\n\u201cI go from 0-100, because it is still new for me,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd I don\u2019t know how to get to 50.\u201d\n\nEureka extended an olive branch, a bowl of picholines, a dish for the pits and a cheese plate, and offered to shake Vixen\u2019s hand, but was rebuffed. The generous Eureka warmly said, \u201cJust know that my friendship\u2019s here. Whatever direction that goes in.\u201d The Vixen smiled, but only to apply her blush. Then she growled, \u201cI\u2019m tired of this mushy [expletive].\u201d\n\nFor the many experiences that have led her to this moment, and the many systems that have undoubtedly failed her, I am truly sorry. But, Vixen, it\u2019s been 18 months. I\u2019m afraid of getting to 50 in this climate too, but we must, and this is how we do it. The same softness which once made you a target now compels people to trust you with their stories. Take their hands.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWaving a white flag of a gown, Ru announced the fashion challenge, \u201cDenim and Diamonds.\u201d The girls answered the call of booty, as cutout backsides ruled the runway. The Vixen got her range of motion down to 50 in a killer denim mermaid dress; Asia destroyed in a distressed Tina Turner homage; and Miz Cracker delighted in a Pippi-esque long stocking with a hilarious buckteeth reveal. When will she win a challenge? She is qualified and without obvious flaw. Did her husband cheat or something?\n\nKameron surprised in a \u201cyoung Dolly Parton\u201d look, and in a lovely moment, Ru gave her the floor to express her lifelong adoration for the guest judge Shania Twain, who has gotten to 50 quite nicely. (Well, she is Canadian. Single-payer and poutine do a body good.) Eureka, in a funny-sexy Elvis-style jumpsuit, won the maxi-challenge, as well as two tickets to Cirque du Soleil in Vegas, for which she now has the perfect outfit.\n\nAspiring \u201cchocolate Judd\u201d Mayhem looked more like \u201cstrawberry LaToya Jackson,\u201d and Mon\u00e9t\u2019s cutout jumpsuit created the wrong kind of gap in the crotch. The two were sent to their stations for a lip sync battle to Ms. Twain\u2019s \u201cMan, I Feel Like A Woman.\u201d\n\nMayhem made a strong standard-issue showing, but Mon\u00e9t, a lip sync beast, twisted it out Vanjie-style, butching it up in a cropped wig and pantomiming smoking a joint whilst riding a motorcycle. In a coup de main, she sealed her style and her safety by pulling out not one, but two cans of Aqua Net, and spraying away the competition. (Is it cruel to hope that she\u2019s in the final two every week? Her lip syncs have been the highlight of the last two episodes.) She shant\u00e9-stayed, and our dream-diplomat Mayhem was dispensed, to bring her message of peace to a world that urgently needs it.\n\nReaders, I implore you: We\u2019re all terrified of World War III, so let\u2019s not start it with our sisters. Although this life is competitive, reach out to your fellow struggling women and offer them your hand. We can only get to 50 together, and these days, we\u2019re all just improvising. Let\u2019s go, girls.\n\nSee you next week. Over and out.", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u2019: Season 10, Episode 5: Getting to 50", "authors": ["Amanda Duarte", "Rupaul S Drag Race"]} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe number of industries and ventures along Sepetiba Bay has been growing exponentially in recent years,\u201d said Dr. Alonso, the biologist. \u201cWhat that generates is a greater concentration of pollutants in the seafloor and in the food chain.\u201d\n\nScientists have attributed the rash of dolphin deaths to morbillivirus, an airborne virus from the family that causes measles in humans. They are now seeking to understand how the dolphins became so highly vulnerable to the virus, and are examining the role of pollution and environment degradation.\n\nThe effects of the virus \u2014 rash, fever, respiratory infection, disorientation \u2014 suggest an agonizing death. Dying dolphins were seen swimming sideways and alone. Some carcasses had ugly deformations, and blood dripping from their eyes. Outbreaks have been reported among dolphins in other parts of the world, but this is the first for the species in the South Atlantic.\n\n\u201cThe reality is that the mass death caused by morbillivirus is only the tip of the iceberg,\u201d said Leonardo Flach, the scientific coordinator at the Grey Dolphin Institute, a conservation group that is also involved in the sleuthing.\n\nThe Guiana dolphin, a species found from Central America to southern Brazil, is considered a sentinel because, as a top predator and mammal, it is prone to disease linked to polluted waters, Dr. Flach said. He has urged the creation of a marine conservation area to study and safeguard the bay.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSergio Hirochi, 49, a fisherman who was born in the area and owns three small boats, said he had seen the bay\u2019s environmental decline, beginning in the mid-1990s when the mining company Ing\u00e1 Mercantil operated in the area. The company closed in 1998 after it came under scrutiny for dumping pollutants, but a burst of new development followed.\n\n\u201cFrom here, I see how much mineral waste winds up in the ocean,\u201d said Mr. Hirochi, who sells fish at a warehouse near his waterfront home. \u201cThe Bay of Sepetiba is an estuary, a nursery of species. And when you destroy it, you destroy marine life.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Sentinel\u2019 Dolphins Die in Brazil Bay. Some Worry a Way of Life Has, Too.", "authors": ["Dado Galdieri", "Photographs"]} {"date": "2018-04-19 00:00:00", "text": "The would-be exorcists blamed the internet and atheism for what they see as a spike in evil, but the urgency evident in the course also seemed to have something to do with a growing conservative view that the church has gone astray under Pope Francis, and that end times had drawn nigh.\n\nThe pope recently had conservative heads spinning when he was quoted, incorrectly according to the Vatican, by an Italian reporter with credibility issues as not believing in hell. \u201cBeyond what is tolerable,\u201d the American cardinal Raymond Burke, a leader of the conservative resistance to Francis, said at the time.\n\nIn fact, the pope often speaks about the devil. In this month\u2019s apostolic exhortation, Rejoice and Be Glad, he wrote that while in biblical times, \u201cepilepsy, for example, could easily be confused with demonic possession,\u201d the faithful should not conclude \u201cthat all the cases related in the Gospel had to do with psychological disorders and hence that the devil does not exist or is not at work.\u201d\n\nFather C\u00e1rdenas had no doubts about the pope\u2019s belief in the devil. Neither did Cardinal Simoni, who has encountered evil firsthand, surviving decades in prisons and work camps for practicing his faith under the Albanian Communist regime of Enver Hoxha.\n\nPhoto\n\nDuring Monday\u2019s keynote address, the cardinal answered the questions of Father C\u00e1rdenas\u2019 fellow priests, like one from a French priest who asked him to share his exorcising secrets. \u201cPray without interruption,\u201d the cardinal said, reminding the audience that \u201cmore than anything, chastity\u201d was key.\n\nAsked if he preferred the ancient ritual or the new Vatican norms introduced in 1999, Cardinal Simoni said, \u201cJesus knows all the languages.\u201d\n\nAnother priest asked how to tell the difference between bipolar and possessed personalities. \u201cIt\u2019s important to differentiate between psychopathic illnesses, neurasthenia, pathologies,\u201d the cardinal said. \u201cSatan you can recognize.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis theme will be tackled on Tuesday afternoon,\u201d interjected Professor Giuseppe Ferrari, an organizer of the course, who runs a socio-religious research group.\n\nAt that, Father C\u00e1rdenas perused his blue program, illustrated with Raphael\u2019s Transfiguration. On Tuesday, he could listen to an exorcist lecture on \u201cThe Prayer of Liberation, a Theological and Pastoral Approach\u201d or \u201cThe Auxiliary Exorcist: Skills and Duties.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, there was \u201cMagical, Esoteric and Occult Links to Some Alternative and Energy-giving Therapies,\u201d followed by Friday\u2019s \u201cThe Exorcist: Life, Choices and Mistake.\u201d But he was especially interested in Wednesday\u2019s talk on \u201cWitchcraft in Africa.\u201d\n\nThe Vatican has had an uncomfortable relationship with some of its best-known African exorcists. Archbishop Emmanuel Milingo, of Zambia, gained notoriety as a healer and exorcist in the 1990s, when he lived in Italy and where he was known as the \u201cwitch doctor bishop.\u201d He later married a Korean woman at a group wedding presided over by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, and was excommunicated for ordaining four married men as priests.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMore recently the Vatican has formally recognized an International Association of Exorcists in 2014, which keeps its 250 or so members updated on the latest best practices in confronting the devil. The death in 2016 of Father Gabriele Amorth, Italy\u2019s most famous demon remover, prompted a new national outcry for recruits.\n\nAn exorcism documentary, \u201cLibera Nos,\u201d won a prize at the Venice Film Festival in 2016. The film follows a rotund Sicilian priest in a friar\u2019s frock and wool hat; in one scene, he yanks on the bangs of a woman who grunts at his command that she love her neighbors.\n\nIn a separate cellphone conversation in the film with a possessed woman, the priest implores, \u201cI exorcise you, Satan.\u201d He then signs off with, \u201cO.K., talk soon,\u201d and \u201csay hello to your husband for me.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n(\u201cIt\u2019s a good way to learn how not to do an exorcism,\u201d Professor Ferrari said.)\n\nIn the seminar on Monday, Cardinal Simoni reported dramatic successes. Asked by one priest how he knew if an exorcism had worked, he responded, \u201cAh, you can see it immediately,\u201d explaining that one possessed person went from jumping up and down and \u201ckeeping three or four men busy\u201d to rising with a \u201cjoyous smile.\u201d\n\n\u201cYour exorcisms are very effective, it seems,\u201d said Professor Ferrari, who then told the crowd, \u201cWe will meet back here after the coffee break.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe students headed for a long table with snacks and soda while reporters pressed Cardinal Simoni about conducting exorcisms by cellphone, which is technically banned by church law. (He had done them \u201c100, 1,000 times\u201d he said.)\n\nFather C\u00e1rdenas waited in the aisle, his cellphone out, hoping to get a picture of himself with the cardinal. But the elderly exorcist shuffled past, leaving the Colombian grumbling, though not demonically.\n\nTurning back to the topic at hand, Father C\u00e1rdenas warned that black magic can be transmitted through screens (\u201cAmerican films are also a problem\u201d), that demons enter the body \u201cthrough the back of the brain,\u201d and that early traumas, like sexual abuse, can make a person vulnerable to homosexuality and the demons who, in grave cases, cause suicidal or violent tendencies and need to be chased away.\n\nA few feet away, The Rev. Joseph Poggemeyer, from Toledo, Ohio, said exorcists needed to confront the evil spread on the internet. He said that every diocese should have an exorcist on hand, but that the reforms of the Second Vatican Council and its \u201cconfusion\u201d had eroded exorcism expertise and deprived seminarians of instruction in demonology.\n\n\u201cThat was simply lost,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of dioceses in the United States haven\u2019t had exorcists for a very long time.\u201d\n\nOrganizers called the priests back in for a lesson on a bishop\u2019s role in exorcism, after which they broke for lunch. While budding exorcists waited in line for pasta behind texting students, or discussed the manifestations of pure evil over yogurt, Mr. Ferrari said he hoped to invite the pope\u2019s preferred exorcist, a Lutheran, to next year\u2019s conference.\n\nReplenished, Father C\u00e1rdenas and the others returned to the basement hall for the afternoon session, \u201cExorcism as a Ministry of Mercy and Consolation Amid the Bewilderment of Contemporary Society.\u201d\n\nIt was led by Archbishop Luigi Negri, who made news in 2015, when he was overheard on a train wishing for the death of Pope Francis. The pontiff subsequently replaced him as the leader of the Ferrara archdiocese.\n\nOn Monday, Archbishop Negri warned the priests what dark forces they would be up against.\n\n\u201cThe actor of this evil \u2014 this diabolical and evil entity,\u201d he explained, \u201cis greater than any single man.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Shut Up, Satan\u2019: Rome Course Teaches Exorcism, Even by Cellphone", "authors": ["Jason Horowitz"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "A separate explosion near a voter registration center in the northern province of Baghlan killed five people and wounded four others, officials there said.\n\nIn the week since voter registration began, staff members have been abducted in the western province of Ghor, and at least one registration center came under rocket fire in Badghis Province in the country\u2019s northwest. In the eastern city of Jalalabad, gunmen on a motorcycle shot and killed two police officers guarding a voter registration center.\n\nOfficials said that even provincial capitals were struggling to open all voter registration centers. \u201cThere are 55 voter registration centers in Kunduz city and the villages that belong to the center, and 20 of them are closed because those villages are under Taliban control,\u201d said Gen. Abdul Hamid Hamidi, the police chief of Kunduz Province.\n\nThe country\u2019s parliamentary elections have been delayed by three years as the leaders of the coalition government, which came out of a messy presidential election that almost tore the country apart, debated measures to prevent the fraud that had marred previous elections.\n\nAfter public disagreements that added to the voter fatigue, the leaders announced an October date for the elections. They also decided to declare void the millions of voter identification cards already in circulation, which have been used in vote rigging in the past.\n\nInstead, they asked people to return to their local polling centers and register with their national ID cards. Officials and party leaders have expressed concern about the low response, especially after recent attacks targeting registration centers or their staff. In the first week of voter registration, just 190,000 people signed up \u2014 from what political parties estimated is a pool of about 14 million eligible voters.", "title": "\u2018So Many Bodies\u2019: Bomber Kills Dozens Signing Up to Vote in Kabul", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "Nonhuman figures on display include the Wookiee Chewbacca, who reveals that he\u2019s 190 years old (\u201cYou look great!\u201d says Han), and Lando\u2019s droid co-pilot L3-37, voiced by Phoebe Waller-Bridge of the British sitcom \u201cFleabag.\u201d Two other English actors, Thandie Newton and Paul Bettany, can be briefly glimpsed. \u201cSolo\u201d reunites Mr. Bettany with his \u201cA Beautiful Mind\u201d director Ron Howard, who took over the prequel late in its production after the original helmers Phil Lord and Christopher Miller left, citing creative differences.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve got a really good feeling about this,\u201d Han says at one point in the trailer. Disney hopes fans of the franchise will share that enthusiasm when \u201cSolo: A Star Wars Story\u201d lands in theaters on May 25.", "title": "\u2018Solo: A Star Wars Story\u2019 Gets a New Trailer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "The young Han Solo will make his debut at the Cannes Film Festival in May.\n\nLucasfilm announced on Friday that \u201cSolo: A Star Wars Story,\u201d which depicts Solo\u2019s life before the events of \u201cStar Wars: A New Hope,\u201d would have its premiere at the festival before opening in France on May 23 and in the United States two days later.\n\nThe film\u2019s director, Ron Howard, is expected to attend the festival, along with the cast members Alden Ehrenreich, Donald Glover and Emilia Clarke, among others. Mr. Ehrenreich plays Han Solo and Mr. Glover plays Lando Calrissian. Ms. Clarke will be featured as Qi\u2019ra, a childhood friend and accomplice of Solo.", "title": "\u2018Solo: A Star Wars Story\u2019 Is Going to Cannes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Russia has been researching the application of chemical agents to door handles as a way to assassinate its enemies, and has been training personnel \u201cfrom special units\u201d to carry out such attacks, said Mark Sedwill, Britain\u2019s national security adviser, on Friday in a letter to the secretary general of NATO.\n\nMr. Sedwill\u2019s letter, the most detailed account of British intelligence on the subject to be shared with the public to date, also reported that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was \u201cclosely involved in the chemical weapons program\u201d beginning in the mid-2000s.\n\nDuring that period, the letter claims, Russia was secretly developing the nerve agents known as Novichok that British officials say were used in the March 4 attack on Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Yulia, in the quiet cathedral city of Salisbury, England.\n\nRussian officials have strenuously denied producing Novichok or carrying out the attack, which has brought relations between Britain and Russia to a post-Cold War low.", "title": "\u2018Special Units\u2019 in Russia Were Trained in Ways of Skripal Attack, U.K. Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "The first time Ms. Danler, the show\u2019s creator, an executive producer and a service industry veteran, walked through the space, \u201cIt was like waking up in my own dream,\u201d she said. \u201cTotally surreal.\u201d\n\nAnd yet \u201cSweetbitter,\u201d which begins a six-episode first season on May 6, isn\u2019t really a show about a restaurant. The reason is simple: \u201cPeople try restaurant shows every year, on network, on cable,\u201d the showrunner Stuart Zicherman explained. \u201cThey never work.\u201d\n\n(Mr. Zicherman exaggerated that frequency, but the network version of \u201cKitchen Confidential\u201d was canceled after four episodes and last year\u2019s \u201cFeed the Beast\u201d was nixed after a single season, so he has a point.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAudiences aren\u2019t interested in whether a restaurant can wrangle the best seafood supplier or whether the steak arrives on the table perfectly black and blue. \u201cIt\u2019s like, blah blah blah,\u201d Mr. Zicherman said, speaking at a latte shop near his home. Even a visit from a food critic isn\u2019t enough to drive an episode.\n\n\u201cSweetbitter\u201d isn\u2019t about that, he said. \u201cIt\u2019s about someone who has never belonged to anything in her life wanting to belong.\u201d The day boat scallops, the chicken liver mousse \u2014 they are just the side dishes to a slow-burn coming-of-age story.\n\nSo come for the food. Stay for the existential journey.\n\nIt\u2019s a journey Ms. Danler, 34, has mapped herself. The book and the show aren\u2019t autobiography. Ms. Danler isn\u2019t Tess, a 22-year-old newcomer thirsty for experience and Beaujolais and bar-bathroom hookups. She was never that na\u00efve, never that reckless. When she moved to New York right in 2006, the same year as Tess \u2014 in those gritty, halcyon days just before smartphones \u2014 restaurants were a way to make money until she could sell a novel. But then they became her world. \u201cI fell absolutely head over heels in love,\u201d she said. \u201cI thought, \u2018I found my people. This is it.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Danler, briefly in town from Los Angeles where she now lives, was speaking at Via Carota, a West Village trattoria. Via Carota doesn\u2019t take reservations, but even on a seething Saturday night, with a line stretching out the door, a prime table had been conjured for her instantly. Blond and kittenish, she is so effortlessly charismatic that the couples on either side kept leaning over to suggest new delicacies for her to order.\n\nShe already knew the menu; she\u2019d worked at Buvette, a sister restaurant. So after a quick perusal, she asked for a few vegetable plates \u2014 leeks, carrots, the first ramps of the season \u2014 and a sunset-tinged Americano, garnished with a daredevil swoop of orange peel.\n\nFood matters to Ms. Danler, and even if \u201cSweetbitter\u201d is a restaurant-set show that\u2019s not about a restaurant, food matters there, too. The episodes don\u2019t try to compete with what Mr. Zicherman calls the \u201cfood porn\u201d of reality TV. But since taste is central to Tess\u2019s awakening, the camera lingers seductively on an oyster or a glass of wine and then shows how that bite or that sip affects Tess, played here by Ella Purnell, an expressive British ing\u00e9nue with the eyes-to-face ratio usually found in a giant squid and a seeming ability to soak up the whole world. Ms. Danler calls this quality a \u201creckless absorbency.\u201d\n\nFor the most part, the show doesn\u2019t fake the food (the grape-juiced and food-colored drinks are obviously another story), and in terms of hospitality it doesn\u2019t fake much else. \u201cThat\u2019s for the restaurant people,\u201d Ms. Danler said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t show my face anywhere if I\u2019d cheated.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe producers hired a front-of-house consultant, Justine Slattery, the woman who trained Ms. Danler at Union Square Caf\u00e9, to give a crash course to the main actors on proper server etiquette \u2014 posture, place settings, the dreaded three-plate carry. The background actors playing the kitchen staff spent two weeks at the Institute of Culinary Education learning food prep.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think on our first day of waitress training we broke something like 15 bottle openers,\u201d said Caitlin FitzGerald, who plays Simone, the longtime server and Downtown sophisticate idolized by Tess. But now everyone is handy with a wine key. Ms. Purnell struggled, just as Tess does, with the three-plate carry and was surprised to discover how physically demanding the work is. \u201cCarrying heavy plates, three of them, all day and kicking the door open, everything hurts,\u201d she said.\n\nTess earns her own aches and bruises, some from her culinary education, some from her sentimental one. But what\u2019s maybe most radical about \u201cSweetbitter\u201d is that not much happens, not in each half-hour, not in the whole first season.\n\nThese first six episodes unfold over the two weeks of Tess\u2019s probationary period at the restaurant. Her desire for the brooding bartender Jake (played here by Tom Sturridge), her tentative friendship with Simone, her coaching by the restaurant\u2019s manager Howard (Paul Sparks) \u2014 the relationships that undergird the book \u2014 are only thinly outlined. This season is more or less a \u201cthree-hour-prologue,\u201d Ms. Danler said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Danler admitted that \u201cmanufactured drama\u201d is hard for her, and in her initial scripts, Tess was almost entirely passive. A first-time television writer who learned the form by locking herself indoors with a stack of pilot scripts, Ms. Danler had to push herself to provide action. The first six episodes build to what she calls \u201cour explosive moment,\u201d and that moment is a brief and silent look between two characters.\n\nSlowing down the story is a way to capture some of the imagism that made the book so distinctive, to give the viewer time to appreciate the sights and sounds that mark the world of the restaurant as a seductive space. It also acknowledges that while sometimes people grow up all at once, more often, like Tess, we become ourselves subtly, incrementally, taste by taste.\n\n\u201cSweetbitter\u201d Ms. Danler said, is about a moment when \u201cyou\u2019re waiting for your life to start and it has already started.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Sweetbitter\u2019 Is a Coming-of-Age Story, With Wine Pairings", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "And then there was the general. We\u2019d met him before, as Colonel Lyle Rennhull, back in Season 1. (The final episode of that season, \u201cThe Colonel,\u201d was named after him.) Back then, he was meeting Philip to tell him that America\u2019s Star Wars missile-defense system was a pipe dream, a meeting that initiated a sequence of events that ended with Elizabeth\u2019s being shot. He resurfaced because Moscow wanted Elizabeth to shake him down for a piece of American tech, a lithium-based radiation sensor. If he didn\u2019t obtain one, his past treason would be exposed.\n\nRennhull (still played by Victor Slezak) has not been the most admirable character \u2014 in Season 2 he killed the informant Sanford Prince in order to protect himself \u2014 but this time he decided to stand on principle, declaring that all he ever wanted to do was avoid war and that he wouldn\u2019t sell out his country now. So, an idealist, like Elizabeth. When they met in a park in Virginia, he pulled a gun, and she fell to her knees and played the I\u2019m-a-mother card, pretending to beg for her life. This was a distraction, of course, before she lunged, tackled him, wrestled for the gun and then slowly, purposefully forced it under his chin and pulled the trigger.\n\nPaige ran from her post in the parking lot to her mom\u2019s aid, but this being \u201cThe Americans,\u201d there was no hugging or crying. The emotion was packed into the moment when their eyes locked, as Elizabeth yelled at Paige to get back to the car. Paige, the good soldier, hesitated only briefly before turning and running back without a word. Then the credits rolled, the fallout put off until next week.\n\nElsewhere in the episode, Philip had further setbacks in his new capitalist existence. His employee Stavos (Anthony Arkin) lost one of the travel agency\u2019s valuable clients, and when Philip told the story to Henry, the son gently reprimanded the father: Maybe Stavos was right and Philip should have kept the client himself. The American-born Henry probably has better business instincts than his wannabe-bourgeois dad.\n\nHenry\u2019s brief appearance, by phone from New Hampshire, was one of two heartwarming cameos. The other: a walk-on by the mail robot, gliding through the back of a scene at F.B.I. headquarters. In a related subplot, we were given both some comic relief and some spy-story tension via the Gennadi-and-Sofia story. Tired of her once glamorous husband, Sofia let it slip to Stan that she had found a sympathetic ear at the Tass office, a co-worker named Bogdan.\n\nThe episode was time-stamped by the baseball game on Glenn Haskard\u2019s radio: Oct. 4, the last day of the 1987 season. Glenn listened as Chili Davis of the San Francisco Giants tied the game, 4-4, with a home run off the Atlanta Braves\u2019 Chuck Cary. (The Giants went on to win, 5-4, on Bob Brenly\u2019s walk-off homer in the 10th inning. They won the National League West that year but lost to the St. Louis Cardinals in the league championship series.)\n\nFinally, the episode\u2019s title referred to Claudia\u2019s favorite composer. She played a Tchaikovsky recording for Paige \u2014 I\u2019m sure one of you can tell us which piece it was \u2014 and the melancholy strains continued on the soundtrack as Paige and Elizabeth had their uncomfortable conversation about sex. Let us know in the comments what you thought about \u201cTchaikovsky\u201d and the latest stages in Paige\u2019s education.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6, Episode 2 Recap: Our People", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-11 00:00:00", "text": "They were right to be wary: Elizabeth immediately began dressing down Paige for leaving her post and possibly endangering the mission. Paige was worried about her mother, of course, but Elizabeth was hearing no excuses and brooking no Philip-like softness: \u201cYou don\u2019t get to talk about what you thought or how you felt or anything else, not now.\u201d When Paige asked if she could spend the night at her parents\u2019 house, Philip said \u201cOf course\u201d but Elizabeth said no to the change in routine, and Paige, the good soldier, got up without protest and went home alone. It was more fuel for the Elizabeth haters out there \u2014 a group of which I am emphatically not part \u2014 but we all realize that her love of, and fear for, Paige are at the heart of her reactions, right?\n\nLater, without telling Paige the whole story, Elizabeth told her that Rennhull \u201cwas caught up in something and didn\u2019t see a way out,\u201d which of course was a pretty good description of Elizabeth\u2019s current situation. Elizabeth acknowledged that she mishandled the whole Rennhull situation, telling Philip that she moved too fast because of the pressure she\u2019s under from the \u201ctrouble back home.\u201d In a quiet, sad moment in the kitchen, they both kept secrets, though Elizabeth admitted that she was withholding her mission from Philip. Philip, guilty and grim, was just plain working her.\n\nThe mission took Elizabeth and the chastened (but increasingly self-assured) Paige to a stakeout of Haskard\u2019s team of American and Soviet arms negotiators. After some more baseball talk \u2014 Haskard is a fan of the Minnesota Twins, formerly the Washington Senators \u2014 there was finally some action involving the Soviet expert Elizabeth is staking out. When an American suggested a get-together at his house to watch a World Series game, two Soviets immediately begged off, but Elizabeth\u2019s target was suspiciously enthusiastic.\n\nThere was also the matter of the radiation sensor Rennhull was supposed to have obtained. (As Philip somewhat snippily pointed out, Rennhull no longer has access.) Shifting focus to a worker at a warehouse where the sensors are stored, she posed as an auditor to quiz him about security procedures. It looked like a benign operation until he mentioned that his girlfriend worked there, too \u2014 in security. Cue the chokehold strangulation, with Elizabeth subduing a considerably larger man for the second week in a row. (She killed the civilian to the melancholy strains of Leonard Cohen\u2019s \u201cDance Me to the End of Love\u201d on the soundtrack.)\n\nElsewhere, it was a good episode for Stan Beeman fans. We got to see him in the kitchen with Renee, who appeared to upend a lot of fan speculation by announcing that she wanted to serve her country and join the F.B.I. Stan gently pointed out that she was over the cut-off age for new agents, 37. (Presumably the KGB would know that.)", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6, Episode 3 Recap: Moscow Believes in Beef Stew", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "To be fair, he also donned a couple of greatest-hits disguises and did some spy work, but even those scenes felt a little inconsequential. He had a second meeting with Oleg (who assured him, correctly as we found out, that he hadn\u2019t been followed). After some preliminaries, Oleg got to the point \u2014 Elizabeth\u2019s extreme loyalty to the Soviet Union \u201ccan be used,\u201d and a downcast Philip grudgingly told him about Rennhull and the quest for the radiation sensor.\n\nSecond digression. Two questions for Elizabeth haters: Is she less admirable than the husband who stepped away from his duties, giving her the entire espionage workload, and is now informing on her? And if you watch a thriller in which a fictional American, most likely male, operative routinely murders Russians or Latin Americans or Arabs, do you react with the same kind of visceral moral repugnance?\n\nPhilip also paid a nostalgic visit to the Breland house, dressed up as hipster Jim and communing with his soul mate Kimmy, now a junior at Michigan. \u201cYou should have the job, the relationship, everything you want,\u201d she said, unaware that he has those things and they\u2019re not making him happy. The visit only contributed to his angst: When he had to report that Kimmy\u2019s holiday trip to Greece meant no more recordings of her father before the arms summit, Elizabeth was not happy.\n\nThe Jenningses\u2019 domestic war slowly heated up. First seen wearily eyeing each other from opposite sides of the kitchen, they later openly clashed in front of a highly uncomfortable Paige. Philip complained about the peril in which Paige is being placed, and Elizabeth reminded him that they had a deal \u2014 Paige is hers and Henry is his, with the private school and the hockey glory. But that\u2019s just another in Philip\u2019s own basket of worries, and in a painful scene he had to tell Henry that his senior year might not be at St. Edward\u2019s. (This was balanced by Stan\u2019s relatively carefree discussion of Matthew\u2019s post-college plans, and his financial insouciance. In the soulless capitalist snake pit, having a government job gives him security.)\n\nThe show gave us a moment of partial d\u00e9tente between Elizabeth and Philip, when she climbed into bed with him and his ever-present financial statements and asked, sympathetically, \u201cYou rich yet?\u201d She was sad at the idea of Henry not being able to finish at St. Edward\u2019s but not too sad. \u201cWell, he\u2019s your department,\u201d she told Philip. They looked into each other\u2019s eyes and kissed, but we know how this story ends \u2014 Elizabeth rolling over, Philip staring at the ceiling.\n\nI\u2019ve left for last what I suspect many will consider the episode\u2019s most unsettling development: the possible beginning of Paige\u2019s own career as a honey pot.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6, Episode 4 Recap: The Birth of a Honey Pot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Sex was also an issue, indirectly, for Oleg, who encountered his former lover Tatiana. She tracked him down at his urban transport seminar and quizzed him about his reasons for being in America. When he wouldn\u2019t answer, her bitterness over his betrayal \u2014 after the failure of her germ-warfare project, her career has stalled out \u2014 led to a not-so-veiled warning to watch his back. Later at the Rezidentura, she suggests pressuring his father for information and recommends that a cable be sent to Moscow saying that he\u2019s not loyal. Nice knowing you, Oleg.\n\nAnd then there was Paige. Tired of being lectured, she lied to her mom by omission, saying she met up with the cute congressional intern but leaving out the part about sleeping with him. Later she confronted the ugly side of the bar scene: A jerk she (rightfully) insulted grabbed her and she put him on the floor, punching his friend in the nose for good measure.
