(At the same time, her father was in bed with Kimmy and her mother\u2019s first attempt to kill Gennadi was being interrupted by an F.B.I. agent, who got a good look at her.)\n\nWhen Paige \u2014 in the middle of an impromptu sparring match with Elizabeth \u2014 told her parents about the barroom incident, the real fireworks started. Paige can match her mom in outbursts, at least, including \u201cCould you just stop yourself for one second, please?\u201d and \u201cYou don\u2019t tell me who I should and shouldn\u2019t sleep with.\u201d That last one made Philip snap to attention.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhy would I sleep with them if I don\u2019t like them?\u201d Paige asked. Her education remains incomplete.\n\nThat led to what I\u2019d call the episode\u2019s emotional high point: a quiet, violent scene in which Philip dropped in on Paige at her apartment. He started out as the understanding dad, but when Paige undercut him \u2014 saying she was \u201cinto\u201d the work in a way that he wasn\u2019t \u2014 he went very quiet and taught her a lesson.\n\n\u201cI want to see what you\u2019ve learned,\u201d he said, and proceeded to throw her around the room. He didn\u2019t need to point out that he could have killed her at any point. But Paige didn\u2019t back down \u2014 when her elbows and punches didn\u2019t work, she bit him, hard, in the arm. His murmured \u201cnot bad\u201d as he walked out could be taken ironically, but I think we were supposed to see that he was both worried for her (and a little contemptuous, in that way he has) and reluctantly impressed.\n\nDespite Paige\u2019s and Philip\u2019s workouts, though, Elizabeth got the week\u2019s big action scene, and it was a brutal one. Sneaking into Gennadi\u2019s apartment, she was surprised by Sofia\u2019s presence, and tried to sneak back out. But Gennadi came into the kitchen for a glass of water, and that was it \u2014 a knife in his throat, and then a knife in Sofia\u2019s ribs as she tried to run. Then the real tension: Elizabeth saw Ilya asleep in front of the television and had to leave quietly before she was forced to kill him, too. (As it was, his mother was done in by her sentimentality \u2014 she had told Stan, to his delight, that she was having second thoughts about divorcing Gennadi.)\n\nA couple scenes felt wedged in, just to remind us someone was there or make use of an actor who was already being paid. Stan suggested to Renee that she apply for a personnel job at the F.B.I. (no age limits), leaving open the continuing question of her function in the plot. And the bedridden Erica appeared briefly, furiously exhorting Elizabeth to draw. It\u2019s as if her concentration on Elizabeth\u2019s efforts is what\u2019s keeping her alive.\n\n\u201cYou have to put in the time,\u201d she exhorted. \u201cThat\u2019s what time is for. No one understands that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe episode\u2019s title came from Claudia, who spent an early scene educating Paige about the Great Patriotic War, taught in American schools as World War II. It was a lesson \u2014 for Paige and for us \u2014 in what drove cold warriors of Claudia\u2019s and Elizabeth\u2019s generations: their (quite supportable) belief that the Soviet Union, not the United States, was most responsible for Hitler\u2019s defeat; and their direct connection to the war\u2019s toll, which Claudia gave as 27 million Soviet deaths compared to 400,000 American. Those figures are in line with historians\u2019 estimates \u2014 in military deaths alone, the Soviet Union lost at least 21 times as many people as the United States. It\u2019s hard to argue with Stalingrad.", "title": "\u2018The Americans\u2019 Season 6, Episode 5 Recap: The End Game Is Here", "authors": ["Mike Hale", "The Americans"]} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Without referring directly to the letter to Mr. Pichai, Google said in a statement on Tuesday that \u201cany military use of machine learning naturally raises valid concerns.\u201d It added, \u201cWe\u2019re actively engaged across the company in a comprehensive discussion of this important topic.\u201d The company called such exchanges \u201chugely important and beneficial,\u201d though several Google employees familiar with the letter would speak of it only on the condition of anonymity, saying they were concerned about retaliation.\n\nThe statement said the company\u2019s part of Project Maven was \u201cspecifically scoped to be for non-offensive purposes,\u201d though officials declined to make available the relevant contract language. The Defense Department said that because Google is a subcontractor on Project Maven to the prime contractor, ECS Federal, it could not provide either the amount or the language of Google\u2019s contract. ECS Federal did not respond to inquiries.\n\nGoogle said the Pentagon was using \u201copen-source object recognition software available to any Google Cloud customer\u201d and based on unclassified data. \u201cThe technology is used to flag images for human review and is intended to save lives and save people from having to do highly tedious work,\u201d the company said.\n\nSome of Google\u2019s top executives have significant Pentagon connections. Eric Schmidt, former executive chairman of Google and still a member of the executive board of Alphabet, Google\u2019s parent company, serves on a Pentagon advisory body, the Defense Innovation Board, as does a Google vice president, Milo Medin.\n\nIn an interview in November, Mr. Schmidt acknowledged \u201ca general concern in the tech community of somehow the military-industrial complex using their stuff to kill people incorrectly, if you will.\u201d He said he served on the board in part \u201cto at least allow for communications to occur\u201d and suggested that the military would \u201cuse this technology to help keep the country safe.\u201d\n\nAn uneasiness about military contracts among a small fraction of Google\u2019s more than 70,000 employees may not pose a major obstacle to the company\u2019s growth. But in the rarefied area of artificial intelligence research, Google is engaged in intense competition with other tech companies for the most talented people, so recruiters could be hampered if some candidates are put off by Google\u2019s defense connections.\n\nAs Google defends its contracts from internal dissent, its competitors have not been shy about publicizing their own work on defense projects. Amazon touts its image recognition work with the Department of Defense, and Microsoft has promoted the fact that its cloud technology won a contract to handle classified information for every branch of the military and defense agencies.", "title": "\u2018The Business of War\u2019: Google Employees Protest Work for the Pentagon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "COMEY: Yeah.\n\nBARBARO: In your account of that February 14th meeting in the Oval Office, in which the president asks you \u2014 says he hopes that you can let the Flynn matter go, you said in your book that you had no choice but to stay in the Oval Office alone with the president \u2014 those are the words you used \u2014 when he asked these other people in the room to leave, one by one. And I wonder why you didn\u2019t have a choice? We talked a little earlier about power dynamics, but you are, at this point, the director of the F.B.I., you are a profoundly distinguished law man, you\u2019re an independent operator, and you are, by your own description, stubborn and prideful. So why do you have to stay? Why do you have no choice in the matter to be alone with the president in the Oval Office?\n\nCOMEY: I don\u2019t suppose there\u2019s literally no choice. I mean, I was not handcuffed to a chair. But given that I am the director of the F.B.I., and the president of the United States has, in essence, issued an order for the room to be cleared and me to stay, it never entered my mind to walk out. Just because of my respect for the office, the literal physical office in which I stood, and the office of the president of the United States, I, I can\u2019t imagine \u2014 many things people can second-guess, but walking out at that moment I don\u2019t think is one that could be fairly second-guessed.\n\nBARBARO: But I guess what I\u2019m getting at is why, at this point, as F.B.I. director, aren\u2019t you doing anything more meaningful about these encounters than memorializing them in a memo? If they\u2019re becoming troubling to you, as I think you\u2019re suggesting they very much are, why are you just writing these stories down and locking them away \u2014 even if there are two copies, one at the F.B.I., one at home \u2014 and hoping, as you said, that they never end up having to be seen?\n\nCOMEY: Well, I\u2019m doing more than that, I think, including, in the course of the dinner with the president on the 27th, trying to interject, to explain to him why it\u2019s important for there to be distance between the president and the Justice Department, and why I was there a week earlier, about a week earlier, February the 8th, talking to his chief of staff, and part of that conversation was about the appropriate channels for communicating with the F.B.I.\n\nBARBARO: But, as I recall, that meeting with Reince Priebus ends with him, in your mind, inappropriately guiding you over to the president once more, to have a conversation you didn\u2019t even really want to have, but you had it.\n\nCOMEY: Yup. And then the day after the Valentine\u2019s Day conversation, I spoke to the attorney general, my direct boss, and told him, it can\u2019t happen that you\u2019re kicked out of a room and the president meets with me. You have to be between me and the president.\n\nBARBARO: But you chose not to tell the attorney general about what the president had asked of you, which was to drop the Flynn investigation.", "title": "\u2018The Daily\u2019 Transcript: Interview With James Comey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-06 00:00:00", "text": "In a sign of how timely the franchise has become, she\u2019s interviewed by CNN\u2019s Van Jones, who asks, \u201cIs the Purge a political device?\u201d Her response: \u201cIt\u2019s a psychological one.\u201d Yet the trailer hints at a government conspiracy in which soldiers are sent into poor, African-American neighborhoods posing as nonmilitary citizens to wreak havoc. This leads to the formation of a resistance, which fights the Purge.\n\nAlthough Ethan Hawke and Frank Grillo \u2014 who starred in previous \u201cPurge\u201d films \u2014 are seen in the trailer, they\u2019re not expected to appear in the new film. The cast includes Y\u2019lan Noel (\u201cInsecure\u201d) and Lex Scott Davis (from the forthcoming \u201cSuperfly\u201d remake).\n\nWhether we\u2019re ready or not, \u201cThe First Purge\u201d hits theaters on July 4, aptly enough.", "title": "\u2018The First Purge\u2019 Trailer Hits Political Notes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "Taken together, scenes like these suggest that however angry you are right now, there\u2019s a good chance it isn\u2019t angry enough.\n\nStill, those flashbacks are tense and poignant suggestions of an uneasy present on this side of the TV screen. Emily bristles at being asked to hide her family life, but before she knows it, the bigots\u2019 prejudices have become law. Even June and Luke\u2019s conversation about trying for another child has sinister undertones: If Luke wanted another child, he could force the situation by simply withholding his signature from the birth control form (echoes of Burwell v. Hobby Lobby). It\u2019s already his decision, not June\u2019s, which hardly seems to bother Luke \u2014 their home is already a smaller version of Gilead. Those red cloaks didn\u2019t happen overnight. Everyone, in increments, had to agree to them.\n\nGiven how hard \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u201d can be to watch, it\u2019s amazing how beautiful it is. While it doesn\u2019t avoid some truly gruesome and upsetting images, the show is stunning even in its most horrifying moments. The rich visual aesthetic established by Reed Morano, who directed the first three episodes of Season 1, is still felt, as in the stark, terrifying, Francis Bacon-like surreality of the scene at Fenway Park, where Aunt Lydia takes the handmaids for their mock execution. In contrast, we later get a first look at the Colonies, where Gilead sends its female transgressors \u2014 called Unwomen by their oppressors \u2014 to do punishing environmental cleanup until the radiation kills them. The women there, almost too exhausted for despair, are like drab dots in an Andrew Wyeth landscape, bathed in a dusky light that further deadens everything it touches.\n\nBut this show\u2019s greatest strength is still its cast, and the best thing the series does is give them all room to breathe, even in the smaller moments. Yvonne Strahovski is consistently gripping as Serena, who stews in the very pot she filled to boil other women in, but never becomes two-dimensional. Alexis Bledel is a revelation as Emily, and being part of the makeshift community inside the Colonies has only made her brittleness more interesting.\n\nMarisa Tomei, a guest star in Episode 2, is likewise incredible as a Gilead mistress who\u2019s sent the Colonies for adultery, a true believer who suddenly finds herself surrounded by the women she helped oppress. (\u201cI had an M.F.A. before the law changed, in interior design,\u201d she tells Emily in a tone-deaf attempt to relate, one of the funniest beats this show has ever had.) She\u2019s so earnestly faithful, and yet so deeply poisonable, that it\u2019s both surprising and cathartic when Emily slips her a deadly dose.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are hints that the show wants to make more of Ann Dowd, as any show would. Her Aunt Lydia is a fascinating amalgam of contradictions \u2014 glimpses of sympathy and true belief amid blatant hypocrisy, sadism and condescension. (\u201cYou\u2019ll just have to be my very good girl,\u201d she coos at June while forcing her to eat under threat of solitary confinement.) But what makes Dowd\u2019s standoff with Elisabeth Moss in the premiere so electric is the sincerity of Lydia\u2019s anger.\n\nNo doubt some of that rage is just frustrated power \u2014 now that June is pregnant and can\u2019t be harmed too badly, Lydia has been robbed of an object lesson. But there\u2019s something genuine when she sneers to June: \u201cSuch a brave girl, aren\u2019t you? Standing in defiance but risking nothing.\u201d I both wonder and dread what more we have to learn about Aunt Lydia, in the same way that I can only imagine what June will do if she ever has Aunt Lydia even momentarily in her power.\n\nThe decisive moment of the Season 1 finale was the handmaids\u2019 refusal to stone Janine: an act of mercy and a passive exercise of power. Episode 1 focuses on the emotional and physical torture Lydia puts the handmaids through in order to discourage any more rebellion, although her sadism at the gallows and her smugness as she handcuffs Alma (Nina Kiri) to a burning stovetop underscore how little the handmaids have to lose by fighting back \u2014 if it\u2019s pain either way, you might as well fight. This montage of agony is a reminder that violent revolution will be the only way out of Gilead, and that we can expect a lot of blood if it comes. Crucial to this season, it seems, will be the question: What are the limits of mercy?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the novel, Offred was an observer of a world that stripped her of humanity and largely directed her narrative. Her complexity drew you inward, while the story carried her forward in its wake. Moss, a riveting screen presence, answered every call the character made of her in the first season. Her monologues grounded Offred\u2019s periods of hopeless stasis, her gaze pierced the camera, and her despair and determination were the center of the series.\n\nBut the core of her performance is her ability to make silence staggeringly important \u2014 observation as an action rather than as a passive state. Her quiet, incandescent anger powers the bulk of Episode 1 this season. And that rage is so powerful that, once June is removed from immediate danger in Episode 2 and left to her own devices, the uncertainty of her situation consumes her. While sitting helplessly in the Commander\u2019s house last season, she dreamed of doing something, and this new limbo begins to make her desperate.\n\nIt\u2019s no wonder she considers a suicide mission to rescue her daughter and drive for the Canadian border. At this point, anything, even certain death, seems better than more waiting.\n\nOther Gossip\n\n\u2022 I\u2019m excited that this season seems to be scaling back June\u2019s voice-over. The writers last season understandably wanted to incorporate the book\u2019s narrative voice, and the monologues still make good grace notes. But at this point, Elisabeth Moss has the emotional immediacy well in hand.\n\n\u2022 A vital undercurrent in the relationship between June and Nick is that we\u2019ve seen her suffer so much that his drop-ins this season to express concern and guilt feel somewhere between facile and insulting. We understand why she needs him, but by the end of \u201cUnwomen\u201d it\u2019s clear that she\u2019s beginning to resent it.\n\n\u2022 Serena sitting in June\u2019s window seat, helplessly waiting, is a rewarding shot.\n\n\u2022 Interesting to see sincere expressions of faith from June, even in Gilead, in her solo vigil for the Boston Globe staff.", "title": "\u2018The Handmaid\u2019s Tale\u2019 Season 2, Episodes 1 and 2: The Limits of Mercy", "authors": ["Genevieve Valentine", "The Handmaid'S Tale"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Dig just past the shiny surface of today\u2019s mainstream pop music, and you might find yourself asking questions like, \u201cWhy does it take seven people to write a song that sounds like it came from a computer?\u201d\n\nIn the case of the current smash hit \u201cThe Middle\u201d by Zedd, Grey and Maren Morris \u2014 which has topped Billboard\u2019s pop radio airplay and dance music charts while collecting hundreds of millions of digital streams on services like Spotify, YouTube and Apple Music \u2014 the process went far beyond even its three lead artists and seven credited songwriters.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat began as a demo by the Monsters and the Strangerz, a behind-the-scenes Los Angeles studio team, and Sarah Aarons, a young wallflower songwriter from Australia, took more than a year of fiddling between the germ of the idea and its Top 40 debut \u2014 a creative roller coaster that included three distinct waves of musical production, 14 prospective vocalists, a corporate tie-in and a video premiere during the Grammys.\n\nLennon-McCartney this was not.\n\nBut while \u201cThe Middle\u201d and other would-be major hits of its ilk may strike some purists (or snobs) as cynical \u2014 compositions by committee, designed for mass appeal and maximum pleasure \u2014 they are also meticulously constructed, deeply collaborative and often inventive, squeezing multiple moods and genres into a three-minute package that can somehow feel universal.\n\nIn the inaugural Diary of a Song, a new video series from the pop music team of The New York Times that pulls back the curtain on how music is made today, we tracked the writing and production of \u201cThe Middle\u201d through voice memos, demo versions, text messages, emails, interviews and more provided by those behind the track.\n\nThe material revealed an intricate dance between no fewer than eight collaborators \u2014 including, ultimately, an incongruous pair: the producer-D.J. Zedd and the pop-country singer Maren Morris \u2014 all of whom put egos and personal preferences aside in service of the sonic whole.", "title": "\u2018The Middle\u2019: Watch How a Pop Hit Is Made", "authors": ["Joe Coscarelli"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE SANDMAN\n\nBy Lars Kepler\n\nTranslated by Neil Smith\n\n449 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.95.\n\nThe setup for \u201cThe Sandman\u201d is a bit of a stop-me-if-you\u2019ve-heard-this-one-before joke, a familiar recipe: A serial killer, so intelligent and seductive he seems able to murder people from beyond his maximum-security cell, matches wits with a world-weary, brilliant cop. Add ice and snow; serve warm-blooded for a \u201cSilence of the Lambs\u201d-goes-Nordic noir thriller. Good genre writing, however, is all about creating a comfy amity whose expectations are overthrown, and \u201cThe Sandman\u201d \u2014 written by Lars Kepler, the pen name for the Swedish husband-and-wife team of Alexandra Coelho Ahndoril and Alexander Ahndoril \u2014 is a dandy exercise in surprise.\n\nThe novel commences with the return of Mikael Kohler-Frost, a young man missing and thought dead for the past 13 years. He staggers, malnourished and dazed, out of the Stockholm countryside, babbling that he\u2019s escaped from a sadist he calls the Sandman, and that his sister, Felicia, also missing for the same period, is alive but still being held captive. The man who interrogates him, a police detective named Joona Linna, is stumped: A sadistic criminal, Jurek Walter, is locked away in a heavily guarded psychiatric ward, convicted of the presumed deaths of Mikael and Felicia as well as other murders. So who is the Sandman? Linna enlists a colleague, Saga Bauer, to enter the hospital undercover. She is to pose as a patient and befriend Jurek, getting him to reveal what he knows about the Sandman so Joona can find and rescue Felicia before it\u2019s too late.\n\nPhoto\n\nAll this is told via 181 short chapters, many less than two pages long. The desired effect is to keep things moving; it\u2019s as though the authors were editing each other as they wrote. (\u201cWho needs that adjective? Delete!\u201d) \u201cThe Sandman\u201d is the fourth in the Joona Linna series \u2014 is their method a formula? I read the first, \u201cThe Hypnotist,\u201d and skimmed the second, \u201cThe Nightmare.\u201d Yup: same structure, same quick-chapter pacing. But \u201cThe Sandman\u201d has a fresher crackle than these predecessors, a more vigorous snap to its hard-boiled frost. (I intuit that some credit should go to the Ahndorils\u2019 new English translator, Neil Smith.) The phrasing is rudely blunt. (\u201cHe walked down to the beautiful beach where his boys used to swim, took out his service pistol, fed a bullet into the chamber and shot himself in the head.\u201d) The scenes cut back and forth between hero and villain with brutal efficiency. Basically, a Lars Kepler thriller stops only to fixate on Joona\u2019s eyes, which distractingly transfix any number of characters who take in this tall hunk of melancholia. At various times, his peepers are described as \u201can intense gray,\u201d \u201cas gray as a rainy sky,\u201d \u201cas dark as lead\u201d and just downright \u201cvery unusual.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe Sandman\u201d makes Saga Bauer \u2014 faced with an increasingly violent Jurek in the psychiatric ward \u2014 as crucial to the crime-solving as Joona. Indeed, with her fierce athleticism and stoic grace under pressure, Saga is more of an action figure than Joona, who must do the heavy narrative lifting, pondering the metaphysical implications of a universe in which someone as evil as Jurek \u2014 and the Sandman \u2014 can exist. It\u2019s easy to identify with Joona: He feels gloomy and guilty about his work and its value. And, on occasion, who among us does not? A character like this makes us feel more optimistic about the world precisely because he fights his own pessimistic approach to that same world. With this as its subtext, \u201cThe Sandman\u201d sends us off to dreamland with a nightmare that can make us happy.", "title": "\u2018The Silence of the Lambs\u2019 Goes Nordic Noir", "authors": ["Ken Tucker", "Lars Kepler"]} {"date": "2018-04-09 00:00:00", "text": "At the end of 2017, Hank Azaria, the voice behind Apu Nahasapeemapetilon, a convenience-store owner on \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d with a thick Indian accent, responded to a recent groundswell of criticism that the character was racist. It came to the forefront thanks to Hari Kondabolu, a comedian of South Asian descent, who made a documentary, \u201cThe Problem With Apu,\u201d which debuted last fall.\n\n\u201cI think the documentary made some really interesting points and gave us a lot of things to think about and we really are thinking about it,\u201d Mr. Azaria told TMZ. He said he found the situation \u201cupsetting.\u201d\n\nOn Sunday night, \u201cThe Simpsons,\u201d a cultural staple and television\u2019s longest-running sitcom, now in its 29th season, finally responded: with a dismissive nod that earned the show more criticism, especially from Mr. Kondabolu himself. The episode, titled \u201cNo Good Read Goes Unpunished,\u201d featured a scene with Marge Simpson sitting in bed with her daughter Lisa, reading a book called \u201cThe Princess in the Garden,\u201d and attempting to make it inoffensive for 2018.\n\n[ Want to know what\u2019s new on your streaming services? Lucky for you, we\u2019ve done all the hard work and picked the best new titles to watch on Netflix, Amazon Prime and Hulu this month. ]", "title": "\u2018The Simpsons\u2019 Responds to Criticism About Apu With a Dismissal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Season 8, Episode 16: \u2018Wrath\u2019\n\nEven if \u201cAll Out War\u201d sometimes felt more like the Hundred Years\u2019 War, eventually it had to end. In its eighth season finale, \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d brings Negan\u2019s yearslong arc to a conclusion following the show\u2019s lowest-rated season since its humble beginnings, and perhaps for that precise reason, the writers gave every viewer everything one could possibly want.\n\nThis week\u2019s episode attempts to have it both ways, and very nearly succeeds. The faction of fans braying for Negan\u2019s bloody demise and those loyalists holding fast to the show\u2019s founding principles of humanity and mercy both get their way in the multiphase battle that fills out this episode\u2019s back half. It may be the safest route the episode could have taken, but in one of this series\u2019 most rocky seasons, the safest also happens to be the wisest route.\n\nIn \u201cThe Dark Knight,\u201d Heath Ledger\u2019s nihilist Joker taunts his caped nemesis: \u201cYou won\u2019t kill me out of some misplaced sense of self-righteousness, and I won\u2019t kill you because you\u2019re just too much fun. I think you and I are destined to do this forever.\u201d Over the two episodes preceding \u201cWrath,\u201d Rick and Negan have arrived at the understanding that they\u2019re locked in a similarly elemental soul-deep clash. They each recognize too much of themselves in the other to completely abandon pity, and so when the two of them break off from the main battlefield for a mano-a-mano showdown by a solitary tree, there can be no definitive resolution.\n\nFor Rick to take Negan\u2019s life would be a betrayal to Carl\u2019s memory, his final request being for peace. Rick\u2019s turning his back on his own son\u2019s dream would have been the cruelest, most cynical turn in a show that has frequently drawn criticism for those very traits. Rick takes the high road without softening up, allowing Negan to live against Maggie\u2019s strongly stated wishes, then threatening to open up his stitches as he lies convalescing.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8 Finale: War Is Over, if You Want It", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "Season 8, Episode 14, \u2018Still Gotta Mean Something\u2019\n\nAlthough some critics refer to it as the \u201cDisney Death,\u201d that old trick of seemingly killing off characters only to revive them hastily will soon be more closely associated with \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d if things keep on at the current rate. Last week\u2019s installment did not include a title card emblazoned with the words \u201cNow, Henry is dead,\u201d but it did show young Henry getting trampled, characters looking for him and a somber aerial shot of a graveyard. All signs indicated that the boy had passed on to the next life, but this week\u2019s episode had other plans.\n\nHenry is not nearly as dead as we had been led to believe, found stuck in a zombie bog by Carol near this week\u2019s close. She retrieves him, they embrace, Morgan\u2019s disturbing hallucinations finally subside, and even Ezekiel finds his spirits lifted upon the boy\u2019s return. It is supposed to be a celebratory moment, a rush of relief that it\u2019s not too late to preserve this show\u2019s last embodiment of innocence. (Never mind that Henry was in murderous spirits when he was last seen. His life-or-death encounter seems to have scared the nihilism out of him.)\n\nIn practice, however, Henry\u2019s non-death feels like yet another yanked-away football that the viewers were na\u00efve enough to run after.\n\nAt this late juncture of the season, this particular criticism has aged into an old refrain, but if the show insists on repeating this gaffe, so be it: Using death as a ploy to put other characters through a hardship and then reversing that death to tidily resolve it is at best easy writing, and at worst manipulative. If the ultimate objective in this episode was to return hope to Morgan, Carol and Ezekiel, the more satisfying route would have been to force these characters to accept the difficult realization that the only way to honor the dead is to continue living. By erasing the shadow of Henry\u2019s death, the writers provide all three characters with an instant escape hatch from their own emotions.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8, Episode 14: Resurrection", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "That leaves Dwight, a double agent in two sets of cross hairs. It turns out that Laura was the mystery passenger Negan scooped up at the close of last week\u2019s episode, and she gladly tattled on Dwight. Negan could deal with him like he dealt with Simon \u2014 maybe bash in his skull, string him up as a zombified example and call it a day \u2014 but he instead wisely uses the new information to his advantage. Dwight has more use to him as a conduit through which he can knowingly feed the coalition faction false intelligence, such as the phony battle plan map that Negan tricks him into delivering. The moment he outlives his usefulness, Dwight\u2019s life is almost assuredly over. But if the season finale next week deals a mortal blow to Negan, he might just escape in one piece.\n\nMaddening as such an outcome would be, Gregory just might be poised to come out on top when the dust settles after this season\u2019s finale. An expert at playing both sides against the middle, Gregory had allied himself both with Simon and Dwight. But now that Negan has come home to roost, Gregory will have to do what he does best and weasel out of a treacherous situation through deception, flattery, manipulation and a few well-placed back-stabbings. Regardless of whether Negan will hold him responsible for Dwight\u2019s or Simon\u2019s sins, Gregory is already formulating a contingency plan for his own backside.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy the final scene\u2019s re-declaration of war, the episode has cleared a path for a free-for-all brawl next week, as the show wraps for the season. The unwritten rules of combat in \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d suggest that whoever holds the most hate in their hearts will emerge on top when it comes to blows, giving the steadfastly hateful Negan a seeming edge. But Rick is motivated by the lingering pain of his son\u2019s death, a lasting hurt that seeps even deeper into his bones as he reads Carl\u2019s letter.\n\nUrban legends murmur about mothers who heave cars off their infants; the power of a parent cannot be underestimated. \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d has diverged from the comic books\u2019 mythology enough times that adherence to the source material can\u2019t be taken for granted, but trust that Rick will be out for blood when he and Negan meet next. They\u2019ve set the terms of their rivalry, and in the fashion of the old Westerns, this town ain\u2019t big enough for the two of \u2019em. Someone must die. It\u2019s not what Carl would have wanted, but it\u2019s all that\u2019s left.\n\nA Few Thoughts While We Survey the Wreckage:\n\n\u2022 Eugene manages to give Rosita and Daryl the slip using the classic projectile vomit getaway \u2014 oldest trick in the book.\n\n\u2022 There\u2019s no way the writers could have known \u2014 the timeline doesn\u2019t square up \u2014 but all the same, there\u2019s no denying the similarities between Negan\u2019s fight with Simon and the brawl for supremacy between Killmonger and T\u2019Challa in \u201cBlack Panther.\u201d\n\n\u2022 How Aaron might factor into the greater fabric of the impending clash is anyone\u2019s guess. His encounter with the Oceansiders in the woods feels a bit remote from the main plot, and in this week\u2019s episode it plays more like a skipped beat in the steady escalation of the enmity between the Saviors and the coalition.\n\n\u2022 Gabriel is still upright and alive, working in forced servitude at Eugene\u2019s bullet factory, subsisting on garlic-flavored mashed slop and not doing well at all. A raid from coalition forces could mean his salvation, whether that\u2019s a rescue or mercy kill.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead\u2019 Season 8, Episode 15 Recap: Cleaning House", "authors": ["Charles Bramesco", "The Walking Dead"]} {"date": "2018-04-28 00:00:00", "text": "Since February, in collaboration with the United Nations, the Brazilian Army has been building temporary shelters with spacious white tents across the city. By the end of May, it hopes to have 11 shelters with a capacity for some 5,500 people.\n\nVenezuelans who have been vaccinated and registered at one of the shelters may apply to be resettled in larger cities in Brazil via a military flight. But that process is off to a slow start because of funding constraints.\n\nThe United Nations recently asked international donors to pitch in $46 million to address the crisis during the remainder of this year, but so far it has only secured 6 percent of that goal.\n\nOn a recent morning, Mercedes Acu\u00f1a, 50, said she felt blessed to have been among the first admitted into a shelter. She arrived in Brazil two months ago, rail thin, after an anguishing period during which she joined an ever-growing mob in the capital, Caracas, picking apart piles of garbage for bits and pieces of discarded food.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Acu\u00f1a said she had nothing but gratitude for the Brazilians who have helped her, but she has come to agree with those who say it\u2019s time to shut the border.\n\n\u201cI realize we\u2019re all in need,\u201d she said. \u201cBut their country is being invaded.\u201d\n\nAt the General Hospital of Roraima, the director, Samir Xuad, says the daily patient population has surged from 400 per day to 1,000 over the past couple of years.\n\nThat requires working his employees so hard that some of them end up getting sick, too, said Mr. Xuad, adding that he had lost more than 20 pounds from the stress. Medical supplies as basic as syringes and gloves have run out, he said, and during particularly busy periods, patient gurneys line up in hallways.\n\n\u201cWe try to make magic,\u201d he said. \u201cBut it\u2019s difficult.\u201d\n\nOutside of work, he said, residents of Boa Vista have become fearful of crime and wary of the mobs of aggressive window washers who approach drivers at stop lights.\n\n\u201cRoraima was a place where you could sleep with your door open at night,\u201d he said. \u201cThat is no longer the case.\u201d\n\nThrongs of Venezuelan prostitutes now work the streets of a residential area that has become an ever-expanding red light district.", "title": "\u2018Their Country Is Being Invaded\u2019: Exodus of Venezuelans Overwhelms Northern Brazil", "authors": ["Ernesto Londo\u00f1o"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 Through the dark days of the 1990s civil war and the Taliban\u2019s oppressive rule, the Afghan photographer Shah Marai never left his country. As the bloodshed continued after the 2001 American-led invasion, he repeatedly expressed a feeling shared by so many Afghans caught in the devastating cycle: \u201cThere is no more hope.\u201d\n\nYet through it all, Mr. Marai, 41, continued to bear witness, focusing his camera on the profound human suffering that has become so routine, so forgotten.\n\nOn Monday, he was among the couple of dozen journalists in Kabul who had rushed to the site of yet another bombing, when a second attacker detonated his explosives amid the reporters and first responders. Altogether 25 people were killed, nine of them journalists.\n\n[Read about the two-stage attack, which became journalists\u2019 deadliest day in Afghanistan since at least 2002.]\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Afghan war has dragged on for so long that it has redefined seasons and reshaped conventional battle norms. Spring, everywhere else associated with the blooming of flowers, is seen here as a time when deaths pile up. No one \u2014 aid workers, police officers, shopkeepers, doctors \u2014 is spared. While wars usually have a front line, here the whole country has turned into one giant front line, the guarded capital, Kabul, suffering the highest number of casualties year after year.", "title": "Photojournalist Killed in Kabul Left a Legacy of Images", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump said on Monday that he would not apologize for campaign statements calling for a \u201cMuslim ban,\u201d appearing to undercut an assertion at a Supreme Court argument last week from Solicitor General Noel J. Francisco. In defending Mr. Trump\u2019s efforts to restrict travel from several predominantly Muslim countries, Mr. Francisco said that the president had already disavowed the statements.\n\nMr. Francisco\u2019s own assertion contained a mistake, a Justice Department spokeswoman said on Monday. \u201cThe president has made crystal clear on Sept. 25 that he had no intention of imposing the Muslim ban,\u201d Mr. Francisco said during the argument. But he got the date wrong by eight months, and critics said the statement he referred to was less than crystal clear.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s comment and the Justice Department\u2019s clarification arose from an exchange at Wednesday\u2019s argument.\n\nChief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. asked whether Mr. Trump could immunize his order from constitutional challenge by disavowing his campaign statements.", "title": "\u2018There\u2019s No Reason to Apologize\u2019 for Muslim Ban Remarks, Trump Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cLet me say that the Democratic conference will not need you in November the way they need you now,\u201d the governor wrote in a letter to Mr. Felder and distributed to the news media. \u201cI believe there will be additional Democrats who win and are seated for the next Legislature. You have said that you act in the best interest of your constituents. For their benefit, now is the time that matters.\u201d\n\nFor all that rhetoric, however, it was not clear that Mr. Cuomo, or other Democrats, had enough leverage to convince Mr. Felder that he would pay a political price, and even if so, whether they would use it any time soon. Indeed, the governor\u2019s letter was met with a polite shrug from Mr. Felder \u2014 \u201cI look forward to productive conversations with the governor and respect his position,\u201d he said on Wednesday \u2014 and little, if any, immediate follow-up.\n\nThe leader of the Senate Democratic Conference, State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins, who was cc\u2019d in the governor\u2019s letter, had not spoken to Mr. Felder on Wednesday, nor had Mr. Cuomo.\n\nThe state Democratic Party, meanwhile, seemed to have no plans to revoke Mr. Felder\u2019s membership, a move that would end its mathematic majority. Mr. Felder does have a primary challenger, Blake Morris, but his campaign would seem to be a long shot in a district in which Mr. Felder runs on multiple party lines, and won unopposed in 2016.\n\nOne group, however, was undeniably happy about Mr. Felder\u2019s recent decision to continue to caucus with the Republicans. Before a brief legislative session on Wednesday in Albany, John J. Flanagan, the Long Island Republican who leads the Senate, addressed his Republican colleagues, with Mr. Felder in attendance, and thanked him for staying. The Republican conference then gave Mr. Felder a round of applause.", "title": "\u2018These Are Not Usual Days\u2019: Cuomo Urges Felder to Rejoin Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWe were happy,\u201d Mr. Ncongwane said, adding, in hindsight, \u201calthough we were happy for a crook.\u201d\n\nIn 2012, Mr. Zwane and agricultural department officials arrived in Vrede to promote the dairy farm project. Flanked by the council speaker, Roseline Zwane, known as Topsy \u2014 who happened to be his wife \u2014 and by his longtime ally, Mayor Tlokotsi John Motaung, Mr. Zwane told the crowd about a dairy farm that would empower black farmers and create 150 jobs.\n\nShortly afterward, his department signed the first of its two dairy farm agreements with a company called Estina.\n\nThis was a peculiar choice. Estina was to buy cows for local farmers and process milk at the farm. But the company was headed by a businessman from India who had a background in information technology \u2014 not in farming. Yet, importantly, he had long worked for the Guptas.\n\nDespite the project\u2019s sketchy details, Mr. Zwane signed off on it and asked the provincial treasury to start paying Estina, according to an investigation by the National Treasury. Initially, he was overruled by lawyers in Mr. Magashule\u2019s office, who deemed the contract invalid because procurement rules, like a competitive bid, had not been followed.\n\nBut that was only a hiccup. The province signed another contract with Estina the following month \u2014 this time with the lawyers\u2019 blessing. That agreement stated that Estina would invest just under $20 million in the project and the province would contribute about $30 million over three years. Local farmers, the so-called beneficiaries, would retain 51 percent of the shares.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere was \u201csomething fishy\u201d from the start, said Doctor Radebe, who was a councilor for the opposition Democratic Alliance in Vrede. Mr. Zwane and the agricultural officials presented no business plan or budget for the project, but they and the mayor insisted on pressing ahead, Mr. Radebe said.\n\nThe local municipality quickly decided to hand over 3,400 hectares, or about 8,400 acres, of land for the dairy farm.\n\nIn fact, the municipality was so determined to get the project underway that it compensated four white commercial farmers, who had been leasing the land for about $80,000 a year, in order to prematurely break their leases. Later that year, just before Mr. Zwane and his local choir left for India, on a trip sponsored by a Gupta company, the province leased the farm to Estina \u2014 rent-free, for 99 years.\n\nIn an interview, Mayor Motaung said, \u201cWe had no doubt that the plan will work.\u201d\n\nBut the mayor acknowledged that Mr. Zwane presented no detailed plan or document about the proposed dairy farm. Even basic details \u2014 like the criteria for selecting the beneficiaries \u2014 were missing, the mayor said, acknowledging that his role in the project was now under scrutiny.\n\nThe payments to Estina began months later. Court documents show that the province deposited just under $21 million in two Estina bank accounts over three years. Days after every payment, the company transferred the entire sum to other accounts. From there, prosecutors say, the money was withdrawn by individuals and other Gupta-linked companies that had little to do with the farm.\n\nIn fact, prosecutors say that only about 1 percent of the money invested by the province actually went into dairy farming. Beyond that, the National Treasury found no evidence that Estina ever invested its own money in the project, despite its obligation to do so.\n\nEmails leaked from a Gupta company server indicate that some of the money was sent to the United Arab Emirates and put into accounts registered to the Guptas. The money then made its way back to South Africa through a maze of bank transfers, according to spreadsheets, logs and an invoice in the email trove.\n\nThe emails, amounting to thousands of exchanges, were leaked last year to South African news organizations and an anti-corruption group. It is not known who leaked them, though they soon fanned national outrage at the Gupta family and at Mr. Zuma. The Guptas denied the authenticity of the emails, but some A.N.C. officials included in the correspondence confirmed that they were real.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn one of the emails, Gupta companies paid one another for expenses at a relative\u2019s lavish four-day wedding in 2013, including fireworks, dancers, chocolates and scarves.\n\nIn another exchange, KPMG, then an auditor of the Gupta companies, ignored a junior employee\u2019s protest and allowed the Gupta family to write off some of the expenses at the wedding as business costs.\n\n\u201cI have never been to an event like that,\u201d Moses Kgosana, a KPMG executive who attended the wedding, gushed to a Gupta brother in one of the emails, calling it \u201can event of the millennium.\u201d\n\nThe accounting firm has since acknowledged that its actions \u201cfell well short of the quality expected.\u201d\n\nMany of the problems surrounding the dairy farm could have been ignored had the province not tried to tap into a national fund for struggling farmers. The national government initially agreed to give about $4 million to the project on the condition that the province submit, among other things, a list of 100 poor farmers who would benefit from the farm.\n\nWhen the government found no evidence that local farmers were involved, it sent National Treasury auditors to investigate in 2013. Though Mr. Zwane, sometimes accompanied by his wife, had held meetings to look for beneficiaries, no official list had been drawn.", "title": "\u2018They Eat Money\u2019: How Mandela\u2019s Political Heirs Grow Rich Off Corruption", "authors": ["Norimitsu Onishi", "Selam Gebrekidan"]} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "The F.S.B., the K.G.B.\u2019s successor agency, went to court to obtain the order to block the app after Pavel V. Durov, Telegram\u2019s inventor, a Russian who lives in exile, declined to provide the security agency with the means to decrypt messages. The F.S.B. said it needed to be able to read the messages to thwart terrorist attacks.\n\nThe effort to close Telegram has knocked out countless other sites, including some top websites, like Yandex and Vkontakte, the Russian equivalents of Google and Facebook. Although the shutdowns were brief, those companies did not hide their pique.\n\n\u201cWe do not consider this situation to be acceptable,\u201d Yandex said in a statement. \u201cThe Russian market can develop only in conditions of open competition.\u201d\n\nThe effort has provoked anger and frustration far beyond the habitual supporters of the political opposition, especially in the business sector, where the collateral damage continues to hurt the bottom line. There has been a flood of complaints on Twitter and elsewhere that the government \u201cbroke the internet.\u201d\n\n\u201cA large number of people are aware of the situation and they are not O.K. with it,\u201d said Nikita Likhachev, editor in chief of TJournal, an online publication covering internet culture, technology and politics.\n\nWith no public accountability, nobody has any real sense of the scope of the shutdown, he said. \u201cThe whole point about the internet being broken in Russia is that we don\u2019t know what is happening and whether it can be fixed at all,\u201d Mr. Likhachev said.\n\nCountless people who play online games or use specialized services and tend to be apolitical, Mr. Likhachev said, have suddenly realized how much the government can affect their daily lives. \u201cThey have started asking questions about what is happening,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the rally, which was peaceful, one hand-painted sign reflected that mood: \u201cThings are so bad that even introverts are here.\u201d\n\nNo arrests were reported.\n\nThe rally, organized by Russia\u2019s small Libertarian Party, had an official permit \u2014 often a sign that the government knows that a broad segment of the population is angry. The roster of speakers included opposition stalwarts like Aleksei A. Navalny, the anticorruption activist. He led chants of \u201cDown with the Czar!\u201d and called on people to continue to fight censorship at the May 5 rally he has called nationwide to protest Mr. Putin\u2019s inauguration for a fourth term.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVarious speakers and demonstrators said they had never been to any public demonstration before.\n\nAlexander Gornik, 34, a software entrepreneur, said many of the tools that his employees use for work, like Slack, Pipedrive and Tralier, were now inaccessible. To make high-quality software that can compete globally, Russia needs to be connected to the world, he said.\n\n\u201cThis is not just about Telegram, it is an attempt to isolate the Russian segment of the internet,\u201d Mr. Gornik said.\n\nDespite all the attention paid to Russian hacking and other expertise on the internet, the programmers at the government regulatory agency have not been capable of handling the complicated process of shutting down an app with international reach.\n\nMr. Durov, who left Russia after his previous creation, Vkontakte, was wrestled away from him in 2014, generated countless additional I.P. addresses to thwart efforts to block Telegram. Some 13 million Russians are among its 200 million users worldwide, and many in Russia can still access the site. Mr. Durov encouraged the demonstrators from afar with a series of posts on Vkontakte.\n\n\u201cRussia is at a crossroads \u2014 full-scale censorship has not yet been introduced,\u201d he wrote in one post. \u201cIf action is not taken, Russia will lose Telegram and other popular services.\u201d\n\nUnder sunny skies in the early afternoon, he posted again, writing: \u201cThousands of young and progressive people are at this moment speaking out in Moscow in defense of the internet. This is unprecedented.\u201d\n\nIn recent months, the Putin administration, particularly the Foreign Ministry, has repeatedly accused the West of \u201cRussophobia\u201d for sanctions and the general sour mood toward Russia.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne rally organizer turned that accusation on its head, telling the demonstrators that it was various politicians and bureaucrats who were shutting down the internet who were really afraid of the Russian people. He began shouting the names of some of them followed by \u201cRussophobe,\u201d and the entire crowd chanted with him.\n\nThere was no immediate government reaction to the protest.\n\nMany of the demonstrators carried paper airplanes, the symbol of Telegram, which whipped around above the heads of the crowd.\n\nThe turnout of many thousands was particularly notable in that Monday was the start of a weeklong holiday, when Muscovites depart the city in droves for the country or abroad. A second rally is planned for Tuesday in St. Petersburg.\n\nPolina Oleinik, 17, and Polina Bulakh, 16, both students, said it was the first demonstration that they had ever attended.\n\n\u201cYoung people between the ages of 15 and 30 are very upset about this,\u201d Ms. Oleinik said. \u201cRussia must be a democratic country free of censorship. That is why we came.\u201d", "title": "\u2018They Want to Block Our Future\u2019: Thousands Protest Russia\u2019s Internet Censorship", "authors": ["Neil Macfarquhar"]} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "The Bernie Bros and Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter trolls had called me a donkey-faced whore and a Hillary shill, but nothing hurt worse than my own colleagues calling me a de facto instrument of Russian intelligence. The worst part was, they were right.\n\nA few weeks before Election Day, I was stuck in my cubicle poring over John Podesta\u2019s emails. I wanted to be on the road. \u201cI just feel like the election isn\u2019t happening in my cubicle,\u201d I said. \u201cBut it\u2019s over,\u201d an editor replied, reminding me that the Times\u2019s Upshot election model gave Mrs. Clinton a 93 percent chance of winning. The ominous \u201cthey\u201d who would keep the glass ceiling intact didn\u2019t look that powerful then.\n\nUntil the last day on the road, though, it never really felt like a winning campaign. Not that I thought Mr. Trump would win. I believed in the data. Yet I couldn\u2019t shake the nagging sensation that no matter how many people I\u2019d met in black churches and union halls and high school gyms around the country who told Hillary Clinton their problems, no matter how many women chanted, \u201cDeal me in!\u201d in unison, she wouldn\u2019t win.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI looked around at a get-out-the-vote rally in Akron, Ohio. It was just over a month until Election Day. Dozens of empty chairs sat in the press area. Extension cords dangled unused off folding tables. Cherry pickers set up to give photographers an aerial shot sat idle.\n\nPhoto\n\nI had to remind myself that there was a time, during the Harkin Steak Fry, the political event of the year for Democrats, in the fall of 2014, before Mrs. Clinton was even a candidate and while Mr. Trump was still a reality TV star, when she had been the media\u2019s obsession. Two hundred reporters had stampeded across the lawn for a glimpse of the most irresistible, dramatic story of what Salon called the \u201chorribly dull political year to come.\u201d\n\nThe first woman with a real shot at the presidency, then able to capture the world\u2019s attention with a single flip of sirloin, hardly registered by the time voting approached.\n\nI always figured that this was just how Hillary Clinton would win. It was the painful logic always at work for her: She was expected to project the iron of a commander in chief, the warmth of a best girlfriend and the charisma of a drinking buddy. And if she had somehow done all of that, there would still be some essential quality she lacked, in many people\u2019s minds, because we simply had no template for a female president. The long-suffering feminist heroine would make history not in a festooned lovefest but in a dreary, mechanical slog.\n\nBy late fall, the traveling press \u2014 called \u201cthe Girls on the Bus\u201d since on any given day, of our cohort of about 20 regular reporters, as many as 18 of us were women \u2014 were calling it Hillary\u2019s Death March to Victory.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe went through the motions. \u201cHello [insert swing-state city here]!\u201d\n\nShe did a whole riff on making lists. \u201cI have a plan for just about everything,\u201d she said. \u201cYou know, maybe this is a woman thing. We make lists, right? I love making lists. And then I love crossing things off!\u201d\n\nIf I had to identify a single unifying force behind Hillary Clinton\u2019s candidacy, it was her obvious desire to get the whole thing over with. \u201cThis election is 10 days away,\u201d she said at a rally in Des Moines. \u201cEleven, but we\u2019re more than halfway through today.\u201d\n\nWhen I started covering Mrs. Clinton in 2007 for The Wall Street Journal, she\u2019d been a hands-on senator constantly in touch with her upstate constituents. But by her second campaign, she seemed like Rip Van Winkle, awake again after her stint as secretary of state to find a vastly different country. She\u2019d missed the rise of the Tea Party. She\u2019d missed the Occupy Wall Street movement and the rage over health care and bank bailouts and the 1 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd in early 2015, when her advisers told her that people no longer wanted to be called middle class \u2014 a data point that seemed a fundamental shift in the American psyche and as clear a sign as any that there was something stirring in this election \u2014 Hillary Clinton saw only a linguistic challenge.", "title": "\u2018They Were Never Going to Let Me Be President\u2019", "authors": ["Amy Chozick"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "This is the new American human rights movement, fueled by activists who understand that enforcement of rights \u2014 including economic, social and cultural rights \u2014 is an inherently political fight. And they are stepping into the ring.\n\nELISA MASSIMINO\n\nWASHINGTON\n\nThe writer is president and chief executive of Human Rights First.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nWhile Samuel Moyn is correct in arguing that economic inequities should be included in the issues addressed by human rights advocates, it needs to be recognized that rectifying those disparities will not in themselves result in improving human rights standards.\n\nOne need only recall the abuses of the former Soviet Union or those currently occurring in China or Cuba to realize that improving economic equality does not lead to reducing political repression of free speech or the right to protest or any of the other activities associated with human rights.\n\nEnsuring economic equality should go hand in hand with improving human rights, but does not do so when the provision of material and economic well-being is used to justify repressing political rights. In fact, it can be argued that there is such a fundamental difference between the nature of economic forces and human rights issues that linking them in any direct or absolute manner is problematic.\n\nThat does not mean that we should not strive to improve economic inequalities. It just means that we should not consider them to be a method that will remedy human rights abuses without consideration for a broader spectrum of factors operating within the political fabric.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018This Is the New American Human Rights Movement\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-01 00:00:00", "text": "She\u2019s defending him against Lang, who displays no likable qualities and blames Paul\u2019s predicament on Paul himself. \u201cHe\u2019s been kicked out of every school he\u2019s ever been to,\u201d Lang complains. \u201cDrinks, takes drugs, lives in a squat with God knows who.\u201d (The answer is Paul\u2019s girlfriend, her twin sister and another drifter friend, Marcello.) Chace, noticing that Lang is critical of Paul\u2019s general existence, asks Gail if Lang might be behind Paul\u2019s disappearance. No, she responds: \u201cFor one thing, he\u2019s not clever enough.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s sufficient for Chace. They share a knowing look, and it\u2019s a nice little moment of candor and trust-building between them.\n\nBut ultimately, Gail and Chace will diverge on how, exactly, the kidnapping did go down. In the final moments of Episode 1, it seemed very possible that the kidnapping was a hoax. (Paul places a sack over his own head as the men behind him wait, almost patiently.) The central line of inquiry in Episode 2 is whether the ploy was Paul\u2019s or he was really taken against his will.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe investigation certainly seems to start under the assumption that the kidnapping was real, and rumor has it that the mob is involved. Through a tip from a bellboy \u2014 whom Chace has a humorous relationship with, and plies with immense bribes \u2014 Chace finds his way to a man we see in the very first scene, in Paul\u2019s squat, watching porn and trying to have Paul\u2019s girlfriend and her twin sister raped. He turns out to run a restaurant, where Paul\u2019s paintings hang all over the walls \u2014 payment for meals when Paul didn\u2019t have money, the man tells Chace.\n\n\u201cHe owed a lot of people money around here,\u201d says the man. \u201cI tell you one thing, Mr. Texas, if I saw him now, I\u2019d kidnap the little bastard.\u201d But when Chace offers him the briefcase stuffed with money in exchange for Paul\u2019s return, the man\u2019s cronies ultimately refuse it, telling Chace they\u2019re out of \u201cstock\u201d (Paul). Chace is back to Square 1. The situation appears to be a little more complicated than a mafia kidnapping.\n\nChace eventually arrives at the same conclusion we\u2019ve seen hinted at by the abduction scene in Episode 1: He discovers that Paul has been writing a movie involving a faked kidnapping, likely inspired by a scene in the 1972 movie \u201cTravels With My Aunt,\u201d which Paul had recently watched. He combines this clue with some further fishy details (the ransom note was plopped directly on Paul\u2019s bed, not delivered to the police; the timeline between the ransom note\u2019s appearance and Paul\u2019s last sighting don\u2019t line up; Paul\u2019s girlfriend and her sister show a surprising lack of concern) and becomes convinced that Paul has fixed the whole thing.\n\nGail begs to differ. Her idealist son would not be capable of something like this. In a moment of desperation, before Chace leaves, she asks him what to do. \u201cWell, the good lord preaches forgiveness,\u201d he begins. \u201cBut what that boy done to his mama? I\u2019d whoop his ass.\u201d This is peak Chace: Very Texan, Christian, straight to the point, and hard not to like. For the time being, Gail has to continue the investigation on her own.\n\nIn the end, Chace morphs back into the omniscient narrator to close things out, reminding us what\u2019s at the root of this whole mess: money. \u201cTurns out a rich life is just as messed up as a poor life, just a different kind of messed up,\u201d he tells the camera. And this particular mess, he adds, is just getting started. The last image we see is of Paul, whimpering, chained up at the bottom of a pit.\n\nSpare Change:\n\n\u2022 Paul\u2019s father, J. Paul Getty II (Michael Esper), who hadn\u2019t had much of a chance to shine yet, has one of the better emotional performances of Episode 2 as he sits at a bar, drunk, watching his dad explain in a news conference that he won\u2019t pay a single cent to the kidnappers. Talking to a woman he\u2019s hitting on, Paul Jr. says his father is the meanest man he\u2019s ever met. \u201cWhen you have everything you could ever dream of, what do you value?\u201d he asks her rhetorically, addressing the central crux of the show. \u201cNothing,\u201d he whispers. It\u2019s the first time you have pity for him and the plague that is money in his own life.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 One of the episode\u2019s strangest scenes is a conversation between Gail and a live statue, who tells Gail near the show\u2019s end that he witnessed Paul being hooded and whisked away by men. This feels like a narrative stretch, but it\u2019s no more jarring than Fraser\u2019s breaking of the fourth wall.", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: Don\u2019t Mess With Texas", "authors": ["Natalie Rinn"]} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 3: \u2018La Dolce Vita\u2019\n\nOh, the sweetness of questions answered. Therein lies the value of this week\u2019s episode of \u201cTrust.\u201d\n\nUntil now, a lot of mystery surrounded the kidnapping of J. Paul Getty\u2019s grandson, John Paul Getty III. Did Paul orchestrate all of it, or some of it, in order to get his grandpa to cough up some money and to finagle his way out of trouble with the Italian mob? Or was it more complicated than that \u2014 so as to have placed Paul in real danger? This week\u2019s episode, titled \u201cLa Dolce Vita\u201d (mockingly, it will turn out), serves mostly as a pragmatic answer to these questions. And unlikely as it might seem, the answer to both questions is \u201cyes.\u201d\n\nBut the episode\u2019s writer, Simon Beaufoy, and its director, Danny Boyle, make us work a little to figure that out. As they\u2019ve done from the first moments of the series \u2014 when we see an unexplained image of Paul\u2019s being chased through a field of sunflowers, his pursuer unknown \u2014 this episode hops and skips from one timeline to the next, retracing moments we\u2019ve already seen but from a different perspective, filling in bits of previously missing information along the way. So much of the sequencing is not chronological that it isn\u2019t until the very end that the full narrative picture coheres. Once we get there, the image of Paul among the sunflowers has context, and the reality behind it is more terrifying than one might have guessed.\n\nBecause so much of this episode is about looking back to give us answers to outstanding questions, here, in brief, are the CliffsNotes to the most important ones.\n\nWhy did Paul plan his own kidnapping?\n\nShort answer: Drugs and a woman.\n\nIn this episode, Paul says he never wanted, asked for, nor has any Getty money. Nonetheless, to everyone else in Rome, his name equals colossal sums of accessible cash. It turns out that Paul\u2019s girlfriend, her twin sister and their friend Marcello were using the Getty name (unbeknown to Paul, oddly) in order to purchase cocaine on credit and continue their freewheeling, squat-living existence. We know, however, that Paul has no money, and the cocaine dealers \u2014 who run their operation in the back of the restaurant where Paul often exchanged his paintings for a bite to eat \u2014 are getting antsy for the $6,000 they\u2019re owed. This is when Paul travels to Sutton Place to try and settle up.", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: Change of Management", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-15 00:00:00", "text": "He adds, \u201cNobody goes bankrupt, nobody dies, everybody walks away.\u201d Taken together with the fact that Getty\u2019s wallet is a \u201cclam shell,\u201d as Leonardo notes, they compromise on $17 million.\n\nBut every good hostage negotiation needs a good negotiator, and in the absence of that, apparently a relative with a fancy college degree and a lot to lose will do. To that end, Primo threatens his lawyer cousin (Niccol\u00f2 Senni) into becoming the negotiator. (For official business purposes, Primo gives him the code name Fifty.) Like most people, Fifty quakes in the mere presence of Primo.\n\nAgainst his will, Fifty takes Primo\u2019s marching orders and gets in touch with Paul\u2019s mom, Gail. This brings about a moment of rare comedy: Fifty \u2014 unwilling, frightened and angry for being in this predicament \u2014 tries various voices to disguise his identity when he dials Gail and then a local newspaper to pass along the ransom demand. Gail doesn\u2019t believe him (everybody claims to have Paul, she says), and the newspaper can\u2019t understand him as he muffles his voice with a pillow. At last, Fifty succeeds (he plays this frustrated triumph beautifully), and the demand lands on the front page: The kidnappers must have $17 million or Paul will be killed.\n\nEventually, Gail does believe the kidnappers\u2019 authenticity after Fifty shares the name of Paul\u2019s dogs \u2014 insider information that only the real kidnappers would know. (She\u2019s still erring on the side of caution, however: Anyone involved in a plan orchestrated by Paul could have that information, too.)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLater, Fifty gives her a Polaroid taken of Paul, tied up beside the dead, bloodied corpse of his first kidnapper, Bertolini. That image will prove to be enough to convince Getty Sr. that this might not be a hoax after all. But it is James Fletcher Chace \u2014 sharp and rational as ever \u2014 who gets him all the way there: \u201cWhat I\u2019m saying is that, when people start getting killed, whatever it is, it\u2019s not a hoax anymore,\u201d he tells Getty (who had just been shown saying he would pay untold amounts of money to buy land from Native Americans for his oil endeavors).\n\nGetty lets out a sigh; he seems genuinely concerned. He sends Chace back to Rome and instructs him to open ransom negations \u2014 \u201cwith the right people this time,\u201d he adds, letting out a muted chuckle. (He is apparently not that concerned.)\n\nAs Primo awaits Getty\u2019s counteroffer, he buys the local bar a round of expensive drinks, anticipating his future riches. But then, Fifty shares Getty\u2019s official response: $600, plus expenses. It\u2019s the most money Getty can pay before it turns into extortion under Italian law. Getty is still the consummate business man, and as he points out to one of his girlfriends, he can load the expenses side of the ledger \u201clike a packhorse.\u201d That amount should be enough to privately satisfy the kidnappers and ensure that the Gettys are seen publicly not to pay ransoms, and thus stay invulnerable to future kidnappings. (To his credit, Getty at least thinks he has figured out a way not to get his grandson killed.)\n\nPrimo, meanwhile \u2014 perhaps because he doesn\u2019t know the law \u2014 can only fixate on the $600, not fully grasping how lucrative those expenses could be. He\u2019s done with this affair, he decides, and immediately reverts back to his psychopathic killer personality. He orders his translator, Angelo (Andrea Arcangeli), and his henchman to shoot and bury Paul, who, he says, better be dead by the time he returns with gas \u2014 presumably to burn the evidence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut at the very end, a twist: Throughout the episode, Primo\u2019s translator, Angelo, is shown having empathy for Paul \u2014 asking if he has a girlfriend, wondering what his life was like in California \u2014 and Paul opens up to him. Paul would introduce him to Mick Jagger, if he could; he\u2019d even have him in his wedding. So when Angelo is sent to fetch Paul for the execution, he decides to save Paul\u2019s life instead. \u201cHippy,\u201d he says to him, while his partner waits outside with a gun, \u201cwe need to get out of here.\u201d\n\nAnd with that, the stage for another escape is set.\n\nSpare change:\n\nThere were some atypical, emotionally rich surprises in this episode. They\u2019re a little distracting from the main story, but they are entertaining, almost like Getty fan fiction:\n\n\u2022 Getty\u2019s Sutton Place gardener, Dennis (Jo Stone-Fewings), and Bullimore, Getty\u2019s dedicated servant, may be on the verge of an affair. Bullimore checks in on Dennis after Getty heartlessly releases his attack dogs on him, wondering if Dennis is gay. Dennis greets Bullimore at his door and invites him inside. Bullimore \u2014 a man who loves things arranged just so \u2014 is blown away by Dennis\u2019s plant-filled hide out. He relents to having a beer with him, and the chemistry ignites between them.\n\n\u2022 Getty\u2019s primarily girlfriend, Penelope (Anna Chancellor), is having an affair of her own, and Getty senses it. He makes mention, time and again throughout the episode, of how often she has been leaving Sutton Place for reasons she does not disclose. Again, we may be seeing real emotion from Getty (even if it takes the unimpressive form of jealousy) tucked somewhere beneath those cold layers.\n\n\u2022 Finally \u2014 the greatest shock of all \u2014 we learn Primo is scared of something: his uncle. When he shares news of his gift (Paul), he gets cocky about it. \u201cIf we\u2019re asking for peanuts,\u201d says Primo, \u201cI\u2019d rather do it alone.\u201d His uncle is outraged and slaps him, hard. \u201cYou dare to come here with a gift and take it away again?\u201d he asks. \u201cYour pardon, uncle,\u201d Primo says, twice. He appears to be under his uncle\u2019s thumb, which is unexpected from the man who willy-nilly shoots people in the head. In future episodes, I imagine we\u2019ll learn more about where that subservience comes from.", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Business, as Usual", "authors": ["Natalie Rinn"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 5: \u2018Silenzio\u2019\n\nAt 46 minutes, Episode 5 of \u201cTrust\u201d is the shortest yet. It is also the leanest, a crisp and unambiguous distillation of the players and stakes thus far. Its final scene alone, just seven minutes long, could stand as a short film in itself because of the way it embodies the series\u2019s central question: What is the relationship between wealth and value?\n\nThe scene takes place in an old farmhouse in the Calabrian countryside, where an old couple tends to some animals and lives a peaceful existence. It pulls you in from the start with its simple beauty, as juxtaposed with the tension introduced by Paul and his captor-turned-friend, Angelo. They show up to the farmhouse one afternoon, unannounced, and turn this scene of domestic tranquillity into one that ends in bloodshed.\n\nWritten by Alice Nutter and directed by Dawn Shadforth, the episode begins with 39 straightforward minutes of chase: Primo, Primo\u2019s uncle Don Salvatore, a good portion of their small village and a team of highly gifted dogs (why this mountainside hamlet has so many sniffer dogs is anyone\u2019s guess) are on the hunt for Paul and Angelo. The night before, those two had escaped from Primo\u2019s holding hut while he was on a drunken excursion to get gasoline in order to burn Paul\u2019s body. Primo had ordered his men to kill Paul after having received Getty Sr.\u2019s laughable counteroffer to his $17 million ransom demand \u2014 just $600, plus expenses. In his psychotic rage, Primo had failed to understand how lucrative those expenses could be, and just as Bertolini did before him, he decided that keeping Paul around was no longer worth the trouble.\n\nBut the trouble continues. Gas canister in hand, Primo learns that Paul and Angelo have escaped into the night, which means that Primo must break this news to his uncle Don Salvatore, the only human he fears. Primo tries to play it cool and assures his uncle that he\u2019ll find Paul. In return, Don Salvatore warns Primo: Don\u2019t you dare let word get out that the Golden Hippy has escaped.", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Last Supper", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 6: \u2018John, Chapter 11\u2019\n\nSo far, \u201cTrust\u201d has shown us that J. Paul Getty Sr. is not exactly what you\u2019d call \u201cgood with people,\u201d but his instincts for business are spot on. In this week\u2019s episode, however, those instincts are called into question for the first time. In the final moments of the previous episode, we don\u2019t know if little Paul has survived Primo\u2019s raid at the peaceful farmhouse, when Primo shoots Angelo in the face, and we hear a second shot go off before the episode cuts to black. For about half of this episode, the Gettys believe that Paul Sr.\u2019s paltry counteroffer to the kidnappers\u2019 $17 million demand was a tragic miscalculation \u2014 that, for once, Getty\u2019s outsized confidence in his \u201cbusiness\u201d acumen has misled him, only this time the cost was not a barrel of oil but his grandson\u2019s life.\n\nBut then Gail confirms that she initially misidentified Angelo\u2019s half-charred corpse as her son\u2019s (the kidnappers had intentionally placed Paul\u2019s Converse sneakers onto Angelo\u2019s feet as a twisted negotiating tactic), and news reaches Sutton Place: Little Paul is still alive.\n\nUntil then, Getty had been uncharacteristically shaken. The one thing he had faith in \u2014 his instinct for business, more than he ever had for any person in his life \u2014 had been proven fallible. And for just a moment, we see how being wrong might have been good for him. He is visibly downtrodden and seems self-reflective. He even becomes vulnerable in front of his secretary, Robina (Charlotte Riley), revealing tearfully that his own mother never loved or accepted him as a replacement for his older sister, who died of typhoid fever. Deep inside, he, too, is just an underappreciated child.\n\nAnd little Paul had always made him laugh. \u201cNo one does that,\u201d he says to Robina, who offers him her hand in comfort.
