He accepts it and holds it to his face as he experiences a feeling of actual emotional loss. Maybe he has to rethink everything.", "title": "\u2018Trust\u2019 Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: A Dead Body Focuses the Mind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "When Sara and Sadiq Juma arrived in Norway, Ayan was six and Leila three (the family also had three sons). Sara and Sadiq saw their daughters \u201cdabble in fundamentalism,\u201d as Seierstad puts it. They were taking Quran classes with a militant new teacher and begged to be allowed to wear niqabs. (\u201cYou both look like devils,\u201d their father said, forbidding them.) But they were otherwise tractable, polite \u2014 never in danger of becoming too Norwegian, Sara thought with satisfaction. Not that there was ever much risk of Norway embracing the girls that closely; their classmates either ignored or taunted them. Leila passed through school without making a single friend.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis is Seierstad\u2019s second investigation into radicalization. \u201cOne of Us\u201d (2015) told the story of Anders Behring Breivik, who murdered 77 people in Norway in 2011, most of them teenage members of a left-wing political youth organization. He said he was protesting Muslim immigration and Norway\u2019s embrace of feminism. \u201cOne of Us\u201d is a masterpiece of reportage, design and empathy \u2014 it shivers with feeling. By so scrupulously showing us what happened \u2014 to Breivik, to Norway \u2014 Seierstad enables us to understand why, how the seeds of grotesque political violence can so often be traced to decidedly apolitical, deeply private personal humiliations.\n\nSeierstad seems to set herself the same task in \u201cTwo Sisters.\u201d \u201cFor me, the most important question was: How could this happen?,\u201d she writes. But then, she demurs: \u201cI offer no explanation, neither of what attracted them to Islamic radicalism nor what propelled them out of Norway. I relate my findings. It is up to each reader to draw his or her own conclusions.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s a puzzling disclaimer, not least because any organization of facts, however simple, always requires \u2014 and reveals \u2014 an argument. And what we receive is, in fact, an elaborate narrative, full of explicit heroes and villains, written, she tells us, at the behest of the girls\u2019 father, Sadiq. \u201cI want people to recognize the danger signs,\u201d he said. \u201cWe were blind. We thought it would pass. Now we know better.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis admission is tucked away at the very end, in an afterword. It explains the prickling feeling you might have while reading the book that information is being withheld, that Seierstad knows more than she\u2019s telling. Sadiq\u2019s influence over the text also explains why he is such an outsize figure in the narrative, and perhaps why his account is not subject to more scrutiny, given what an unreliable narrator he is \u2014 particularly, Seierstad shows us, where journalists are concerned.\n\nAt one point, Sadiq interested documentary filmmakers in his story, telling them his daughters had begged him to rescue them (untrue). When the man he hired to kidnap them back refused the job, Sadiq concocted a fantastic story \u2014 that the hired man was caught, crucified and beheaded. It was easier than admitting to the filmmakers that he had lost control of his daughters, that \u201che had failed as a father and as a man.\u201d This sort of thing \u2014 these lies to save face \u2014 occur with troubling frequency, and it\u2019s strange that Seierstad refrains from commenting on them, especially since her own book is built on Sadiq\u2019s testimony.\n\nSeierstad is at her best when she pans out to consider the variety of reasons Western women join ISIS (by 2013, there were 3,000 Westerners in Syria, several hundred of them women), drawn by a hunger for sisterhood, adventure and membership in a society they felt was colorblind \u2014 where shared allegiances were more important than race. She evokes the life they find in ISIS-controlled territory in Syria \u2014 where boys are taken from their parents at 10 and placed in camps to be trained in combat, their final test being an execution. She quotes message boards where women wrote about their new lives: the houses given to fighters for free; groceries and stipends delivered monthly; free medical care. The sisters boasted to their brother about their large house and garden, their pet rabbits. As Sadiq survived imprisonment in a fetid latrine, the daughters he was risking everything to save were making pancakes in Raqqa, with sugar topping.\n\nBut in general, the sisters and their transformations remain hazy, especially the strong-willed Ayan. At one point, her school essays sound like outtakes from \u201cSCUM Manifesto,\u201d by the radical feminist Valerie Solanas. In a piece entitled \u201cWomen\u2019s Liberation,\u201d Ayan wrote: \u201cWhat\u2019s worse, we have to give birth to little rat males who we look after and hold dear, right up until they turn from boys into men who in turn go on to oppress yet another woman.\u201d And, yet, a few years later she defended the rape of Yazidi and Kurdish women by ISIS fighters: \u201cThey\u2019re not women,\u201d she told a friend. \u201cThey\u2019re spoils of war.\u201d\n\nIn her book \u201cThe Brothers,\u201d about the Boston bombers Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, Masha Gessen points out that religiosity has little to do with radicalization. Extremism more often follows crises in identity and in community, when other narratives of making sense of the self have fallen away. This is what becomes obvious every time the sisters in Seierstad\u2019s book flicker into focus, when their voices can be heard, unmediated. This story of theirs has yet to be told \u2014 despite the resonant clues they left along the way \u2014 and even as it promises to be repeated by others.\n\nAyan once wrote a fairy tale in school about \u201ctwo young girls who wanted to go out into the world and find themselves.\u201d \u201cAt home they had always got everything they wanted, attended the best school, worn the newest clothes, but had never been given the opportunity to decide anything for themselves, something young women strongly desire,\u201d she wrote. \u201cLate one summer evening, when their parents were not at home, they wrote a text message: \u2018Mom, Dad, we\u2019re going out for a while, don\u2019t wait up.\u2019\u201d", "title": "\u2018Two Sisters,\u2019 About Teenage Girls Who Left Norway to Fight With ISIS", "authors": ["Parul Sehgal", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-04-07 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The Russian Embassy in London on Saturday sought a meeting with Britain\u2019s foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, over the poisoning of a former Russian spy, saying its dealings with Britain over the issue had been \u201cutterly unsatisfactory.\u201d\n\nBritain replied that \u201cit\u2019s Russia\u2019s response that has been unsatisfactory,\u201d as the two countries continued a bitter public feud over the nerve-agent attack.\n\nThe Russian Embassy said in a statement that it was \u201chigh time\u201d for a meeting between Mr. Johnson and its ambassador, Alexander Yakovenko, to discuss the investigation into the poisoning of the spy, Sergei Skripal, and his daughter, Yulia, and \u201cthe whole range of bilateral issues.\u201d\n\nThe British Foreign Office said it had received the request and would respond \u201cin due course.\u201d But in a statement it accused Russia of employing a \u201cdiversionary tactic\u201d and refusing to \u201cengage constructively\u201d and answer questions about the attack.", "title": "\u2018Unsatisfactory\u2019: Britain and Russia Trade Charges in Poisoning Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Aghdam told the Mountain View officers that she had been having issues with her family, and that she had come to Northern California to find a job. She didn\u2019t appear to the police to be a danger, to herself or others, so they soon let her go.\n\nMs. Aghdam was in her late 30s. In several of her videos, she said she was born in Iran, in the city of Urmia, where most people also speak Turkish, as she does in some of her videos. Ms. Aghdam had YouTube pages in Persian, Turkish and English. She explained that she and her family were members of the Baha\u2019i faith, which faces persecution in Iran, a country with a Muslim majority.\n\nSeveral of her colorful \u2014 and sometimes bizarre \u2014 videos had gone viral in Iran. Her website, which said it was quoting Western news outlets, identified her as \u201cthe first Persian female vegan bodybuilder.\u201d\n\n\u201cNow the media will be faced with a new type of Iranian female which does not fit within any of their usual categorizations,\u201d a Twitter user named Katayoon said Wednesday.\n\n\u201cThis was shocking and saddening,\u201d one Iranian, Bahare, wrote on Twitter of Ms. Aghdam. \u201cWe laughed so much but now it turns out all those videos were so serious for herself.\u201d\n\nMs. Aghdam became especially famous for one clip in which she wears a revealing purple dress, showing cleavage, and begins to slowly strip off her clothes to reveal a pair of fake plastic breasts. \u201cDon\u2019t trust your eyes,\u201d read a caption in English on the clip.\n\nAfter letting her go, the Mountain View police spoke to Ms. Aghdam\u2019s father and brother and let them know she was safe. The police said there was no mention in that conversation of her issues with YouTube.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in a second call, her father said YouTube had recently done something that \u201chad caused her to become upset\u201d and that may have been why she was in the area. Still, the police said, the father did not seem concerned and \u201csimply wanted to let us know that may have been a reason for her to move up here.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLater Tuesday morning, Ms. Aghdam went to a nearby shooting range. Then, just after noon, she parked at a business near YouTube\u2019s offices. She walked into one of YouTube\u2019s parking garages, and then emerged into an outdoor courtyard where employees were eating lunch.\n\nEmergency officials arrived at YouTube\u2019s offices two minutes after the police received 911 calls about shots being fired. When they arrived, they found Ms. Aghdam dead. A 9-millimeter semiautomatic handgun, registered in her name, was found at the scene.\n\nBy Tuesday night, YouTube, as well as Instagram and Facebook, had taken down her pages and videos.\n\nEd Barberini, the chief of the San Bruno Police Department, said: \u201cAt this point in the investigation, it is believed that the suspect was upset at the policies and practices of YouTube. This appears to be the motive for this incident.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, two of the people who were shot were released from Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital. A third was still in the hospital, but his condition was upgraded to serious from critical.\n\nMs. Aghdam dedicated several of her videos to promoting animal rights, vegan diets and healthy living. In one video, she sat in front of a screen with a rabbit, as she tried to explain in Persian the differences between vegetarianism and veganism. In another, she presented her viewers with a papaya, extolling the benefits of the fruit. \u201cEat it when it turns yellow,\u201d she said, sporting dark sunglasses and a zebra-striped cowboy hat.\n\nBut Ms. Aghdam\u2019s activism was accompanied by anger at YouTube and frustration with living in the United States.\n\nHer personal website and videos posted to YouTube and elsewhere were filled with complaints about YouTube. \u201cWhen searching for my website in google, at top of link they add \u2018an error occurred\u2019 but there is no error!\u201d a website under Ms. Aghdam\u2019s name, NasimeSabz.com, said in February 2016. \u201cThey add it to keep you from my visiting my site.\u201d\n\nLife in the United States had not been good, she said in one video from March 30. \u201cThere they kill you by ax,\u201d she said of Iran. \u201cHere they kill you with cotton,\u201d referring to an Iranian expression meaning dying by something that you do not know is dangerous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn another video, she responded to viewers who had begun to wonder if she was mentally ill: \u201cI don\u2019t have any special mental or physical disease, but I live on a planet filled with disease, disorders, perversions and injustices.\u201d\n\nThe American dream appeared to be tarnished for her after she began to face hurdles in the United States.\n\n\u201cIf you are superficial, you will think it is heaven here, that you can go naked outside and have sex left and right like other animals without any morality,\u201d she said in one video in Persian. \u201cBut if you enter the system, you will see that it is worse than Iran,\u201d she said. \u201cThose who want to inform people against the system and big companies get censored.\u201d\n\nOn her channel on Telegram, a social media network extremely popular in Iran, her last post is a childhood picture of herself standing among flowers. It has no caption.", "title": "\u2018Vegan Bodybuilder\u2019: How YouTube Attacker, Nasim Aghdam, Went Viral in Iran", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi", "Thomas Erdbrink", "Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "They said Il Club dei 27 charges 350 euros a year in dues, about $430. That is far less than the Metropolitan Opera Club, whose subscribing members pay dues of $2,450 a year along with a \u201cseat charge\u201d of $2,950 for places in its block of box seats.\n\nBut there are opera fans who consider Il Club dei 27 more exclusive. Il Club dei 27 is limited to 27 people, 27 being the number of operas that members say Verdi wrote. Mr. Ventura compared getting into Il Club dei 27 to being elected pope: \u201cA member has to die before the next one gets in,\u201d he said.\n\nThe last time that happened was in 2016, when the club got a new Il Trovatore. With quotation marks, that is the name of one of Verdi\u2019s best-known operas.\n\nFalstaff said the club\u2019s Don Carlo had the longest tenure, 44 years. Outside the club, he is known as Alberto Michelotti, a retired soccer star and referee. I Vespri Siciliani, without quotation marks, is a retired automobile mechanic, and I Masnadieri is a lawyer. Mr. Ventura, chuckling sardonically but saying not a word about lawyers or the legal system, noted that in English, the rarely performed \u201cI Masnadieri\u201d is \u201cThe Robbers.\u201d\n\nMr. Ventura also said that, as with so much else in opera, the number 27 is open to debate. Some Verdi fans, counting revisions, put the number in the low 30s.\n\nAnd the 27 includes a Verdi work that it seems safe to say most people would not count as an opera. The club\u2019s Messa da Requiem, a lawyer named Antonio Giovati, said he gets that all the time.\n\nHe stood next to Falstaff and Un Giorno di Regno at a rose ceremony at Verdi Square, at 73rd Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue. Calling it a rose ceremony sounds like something from \u201cThe Bachelor.\u201d What happened will never happen on that show.\n\nPhoto\n\nFirst the trio from the club placed roses \u2014 27, of course \u2014 on the statue of Verdi. Then they joined a crowd of about 50 people (alerted by emails from Mr. Ventura) in a shaky but emotional rendition of \u201cVa, pensiero\u201d from \u201cNabucco,\u201d the opera that made Verdi famous.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLike the members of Il Club dei 27, Mr. Ventura, 61, has had a long love affair with opera. It began when he was an architecture student at Cooper Union in the 1970s. \u201cI\u2019d see classmates stumbling in at 9 in the morning because they\u2019d seen the Ramones at CBGB,\u201d he said. \u201cI was stumbling in because I had seen Jon Vickers and Leonie Rysanek at the Met.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Ventura found his calling during \u201cRigoletto\u201d in Parma in 2009. \u201cParma takes its opera so seriously that singers are reluctant to sing there,\u201d Mr. Ventura said. \u201cIf you get one thing wrong, they boo you. But the reverse is true. If you get it right, they embrace you.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt that performance of \u201cRigoletto,\u201d the baritone was booed and cheered at the same time \u2014 his fans cried \u201cbravo\u201d to drown out the hecklers, who booed all the louder. (Mr. Ventura said he had since become friends with the baritone who sang, whom he would not name: \u201cHe remembers he had a tough time.\u201d)\n\nSince then, Mr. Ventura\u2019s passion for Verdi has deepened. He said he was paraphrasing a book called \u201cVerdi With a Vengeance\u201d when he described Verdi\u2019s music as \u201cthe subtext of life.\u201d He said the author, William Berger, heard Verdi \u201cin every situation that life presents. I hear it in a co-op board meeting, I hear it when I\u2019m at a sale at Macy\u2019s, I heard the monk\u2019s chorus from \u2018Don Carlo\u2019 when I went to argue a parking ticket.\u201d\n\nThe usual urban soundtrack \u2014 car horns in the distance, rushed footsteps up close \u2014 was playing when Il Club dei 27 arrived at the Met for \u201cLuisa Miller.\u201d They were welcomed at the Metropolitan Opera Club by J. E. Raymond, a board member of the club and a co-chairman of its program committee. He spoke in English. \u201cMy Italian consists of menu Italian and a little opera Italian \u2014 \u2018maledizione\u2019 and \u2018vendetta,\u2019\u201d he said later.\n\nThe matter of the assigned names came up. Messa da Requiem wished he could have been Aida, and Un Giorno di Regno said he would not have chosen that name on his own. The opera \u201cUn Giorno di Regno,\u201d Verdi\u2019s second, bombed: It opened and closed on the same night in 1840. Un Giorno said that when he was finally admitted to the club and assigned the name, he had never seen \u201cUn Giorno.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s very seldom performed,\u201d Mr. Ventura explained, translating for Un Giorno, who was saying that he would have preferred to be Rigoletto in the club, even though his favorite opera is \u201cLa Forza del Destino.\u201d The club\u2019s Forza is a dentist.\n\nMr. Ventura had cautioned that the club members can be tough critics before he summarized the reviews of \u201cLuisa Miller\u201d from Falstaff, Messa da Requiem and Un Giorno de Regno. \u201cWhen they say \u2018very, very good,\u2019 that\u2019s equivalent to us jumping up and down,\u201d Mr. Ventura said. \u201cI was wondering if they don\u2019t get performances that good in their own opera houses.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe next night, Mr. Ventura arranged an evening screening of an all-but-forgotten documentary from 1963. It followed a staging of \u201cLuisa Miller\u201d at the opera house in Parma.\n\nFalstaff and Messa da Requiem ducked out during Act I. Falstaff said they had tickets to the New York Philharmonic and did not want to be late. The Philharmonic was playing Bruckner and Mozart.\n\nWhat? They listen to music by other composers?\n\nOh, yes, Falstaff said. They have been to Salzburg for \u201cDie Frau ohne Schatten\u201d by Richard Strauss and to London and Munich for \u201cAndrea Ch\u00e9nier\u201d by Umberto Giordano.\n\nWell, then: Why the passion for Verdi? Why not, say, Puccini?\n\nWhat heresy, Mr. Ventura declared: \u201cThey would throw you off the balcony if they heard you say that.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Viva Verdi,\u2019 Say Fans With Very Verdian Names", "authors": ["James Barron", "Grace Notes"]} {"date": "2018-04-18 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cNo Disclosure, but No Punishment, as Hannity Gets \u2018Full Support\u2019 From Fox\u201d (news article, April 18):\n\nWe learn that Fox News\u2019s support for Sean Hannity may be related to his popularity, 3.2 million viewers, \u201cthe envy of the industry.\u201d A few pages later, in Carl Kasell\u2019s obituary, we learn that NPR\u2019s \u201cWait Wait \u2026 Don\u2019t Tell Me!\u201d has six million listeners, far more than Mr. Hannity.\n\nThis news leaves me more hopeful than anything else I\u2019ve read in The Times since before November 2016.\n\nJOHN KAFKA, SAN DIEGO", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Wait Wait\u2019 Beats Sean Hannity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-27 00:00:00", "text": "MANAGUA, Nicaragua \u2014 The hundreds of hot dog buns, bananas and containers of instant soup stacked up at the Polytechnic University basketball court suggest that the young people hunkered down here are not planning to capitulate.\n\nThe students and young professionals who occupied the campus last week in a nationwide protest against the government, demanding the ouster of President Daniel Ortega, have enough donated medical supplies to stock a field hospital. Young men with T-shirts covering their faces carry homemade mortar-launchers as they patrol the grounds. A box of Molotov cocktails sits in the corner.\n\n\u201cThis is not a war; this a struggle we young people are doing,\u201d said Freddy Mart\u00ednez, one of the few people here who revealed his face and name. \u201cWe are not left or right. We are Nicaragua.\u201d\n\nThe Nicaraguan youth did something few people in this country thought possible. Incited by an unpopular change in the social security system that would not immediately affect them, they staged a spontaneous uprising that has loosened Mr. Ortega\u2019s sweeping grip on power.", "title": "\u2018We Are Nicaragua\u2019: Students Revolt, but Now Face a More Daunting Task", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-24 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 \u201c Anywhere they play in Bangkok, I\u2019ll be there,\u201d said Warin Nithihiranyakul , 73 , a dedicated fan of the Sai Yong Hong Chinese Opera troupe for more than 10 years. While waiting for his friends to arrive, he helps out by starting to set up plastic red chairs for the audience to watch the evening\u2019s performance in an area just south of Bangkok\u2019s Chinatown .\n\nA devotee of 11 years, Wandee Tengyodwanich, 62, unwraps several small plates of Chinese dough sticks and cake , passing them around to her friends in front of the stage before the show. She sa ys that Sai Yong Hong is the best Chinese opera in Thailand because it invests in very elaborate costumes. She and her friends go to see the group a couple of times a year. They eat and catch up as they reminisce about the first time they saw Chinese opera as children.", "title": "\u2018We Don\u2019t Perform for People, We Perform for the Gods\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "The wedding celebration of David Carter and Robert Parker was billed as a tea dance.\n\nThe couple was married on April 16, 2005, at the home of Mr. Carter\u2019s mother in Cambridge, Mass. (The New York Times began running announcements for civil unions in 2002; its first international gay wedding announcement was in 2003; and its first United States gay wedding was in 2004.) They kept the ceremony small, with close family and friends, but the tea dance that followed later that summer, a phrase traditionally used to describe both a social dance and a party for the gay community, allowed them to include nearly all the parts of their lives: their gay friends, their church friends and family.\n\n\u201cIt was important for us that it be a blending of our gay friends and our community,\u201d Mr. Carter said from the couple\u2019s home in New Haven. \u201cOur kids were there, and it was an opportunity to pay tribute to their dads. It was a really powerful moment.\u201d\n\nThe toasts from their children are some of their \u201cstrongest memories,\u201d Mr. Carter said. \u201cIt really honored their appreciation of us making a family with them.\u201d\n\n\u201cOur church knew us in that way, and because we were both previously married and had kids, we had a whole bunch of bus-stop parents in common, as well as the collection of gay couples that we had been friends with for years,\u201d Mr. Parker said. \u201cIt was the big wedding we might have had here.\u201d", "title": "\u2018We Have to Make Up Our Own Rules\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-16 00:00:00", "text": "Back in Tripoli, American diplomats watched the carnage in Benghazi with dismay and horror. The attacks were killing their Libyan interlocutors \u2014 including those who were helping investigate the 2012 attack.\n\nThe violence also paved the way for a would-be savior in Benghazi: a septuagenarian general named Khalifa Haftar, who had defected from Muammar el-Qaddafi\u2019s army in the 1980s and fled to the United States, before returning to Libya in 2011 during the revolution. Shunned by Libya\u2019s rebel leadership, General Haftar took center stage in May 2014 when he launched an assault on Benghazi\u2019s Islamist militias with a coalition of disaffected military units and tribal supporters. Operation Dignity, as it was called, marked the start of Libya\u2019s civil war, inviting intervention by competing regional powers and spawning fissures that have yet to close.\n\nThough Washington kept him at a distance, some welcomed his campaign. After all, he\u2019d pitched it as a war on terrorists who killed Americans. That was true to an extent. When American special operations forces grabbed Ahmed Abu Khatala, the principal suspect in the attack, outside of Benghazi in June 2014, he was fleeing General Haftar\u2019s forces. But the battle lines were not as clear as they seemed. His operation forced more moderate Islamists who\u2019d supported the Libyan state to close ranks with radicals \u2014 a process that was already underway. He targeted some of the very militiamen who\u2019d helped the Americans the night of the attack.\n\nOne of them was Mr. Obeidi. His militia, Libya Shield, was among those attacked by General Haftar, and it ended up on the front lines with more extreme groups. As weapons and funds from outside the country tilted the war in General Haftar\u2019s favor, Mr. Obeidi fled Benghazi.\n\nWhen he met me for coffee one evening last summer he was dressed in a white prayer gown and wearing tinted wire glasses. He seemed to me then an emissary of Libya\u2019s morass and an emblem of the tangled loyalties that had confounded America\u2019s policy. Critics have accused the Americans of misplacing their trust in militiamen the night of the attack. But given the absence of any real police or army that night, militiamen like Mr. Obeidi were the only option. There was no black and white; only shades of gray.\n\nAmerican policy in Libya today is again confronted by shades of gray and a counterterrorism narrative that tends to flatten and obscure complexities. That narrative continues to be pushed by the aspiring strongman General Haftar, in his dealings with the Trump administration. It suffered a blow when General Haftar was hospitalized in France last week. In truth, his value as a counterterrorism partner was always limited: His military coalition has been weakened by tribal and factional fissures and his political ambitions made him a deeply polarizing. His disappearance from the scene would herald a new chapter of uncertainty in Libya \u2014 but also opportunities for renewed American diplomacy.\n\nThe diminished American engagement is felt across Libya, but especially in Benghazi, where people lament the tarring of their city\u2019s image with negative portrayals of violence and terrorism. They long for the return of the Americans and for the outreach that was the hallmark of Chris Stevens, the American ambassador killed that night.\n\nElsewhere across the country, Libyans who fled Benghazi have similar views. When I saw Mr. Obeidi, he pleaded with me for help. \u201cWe helped you and now you\u2019ve abandoned us,\u201d he said. And then, to underscore his point, he showed me a scan of a certificate that the Americans had given him shortly after the 2012 attack, signed by American diplomats:\n\n\u201cFathi went above and beyond in order to provide security and facilitate movement for the American Rescue forces sent to evacuate all U.S. personnel in Benghazi. Fathi was committed and professional in every way, he continually risked his life and the life of his men. \u2026\u201d", "title": "Opinion | \u2018We Helped You and Now You\u2019ve Abandoned Us\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-20 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Moon\u2019s office also praised the announcement. \u201cWe view the North\u2019s decision as a significant step toward the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula the world has wished for,\u201d said Yoon Young-chan, a spokesman for Mr. Moon.\n\nDespite the enthusiasm, American officials have watched Mr. Kim with a mix of satisfaction and wariness.\n\nThe North Korean leader\u2019s move could be tactical \u2014 putting the United States on the defensive in advance of talks on its nuclear arsenal. By extending an olive branch, American officials said, North Korea is putting pressure on the United States to accept a deal before Mr. Kim agrees to give up North Korea\u2019s nuclear weapons.\n\nMr. Kim could also be trying to drive a wedge between the United States and South Korea, since President Moon has put great emphasis on ending more than six decades of conflict on the Korean Peninsula.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Moon said Mr. Kim had made a similar gesture, saying the North no longer insisted on the withdrawal of American troops from the Korean Peninsula. But White House officials privately dismissed the remarks, saying removal of the troops was never on the table.\n\nCaution toward Mr. Kim\u2019s peace overtures also punctuated the reaction of officials from Japan, which North Korea has long threatened with missile strikes. The defense minister, Itsunori Onodera, who was visiting Washington when Mr. Kim announced the suspension of nuclear and missile tests, said the move was \u201cnot sufficient\u201d because it did not clearly state whether the suspension included the short and midrange missiles that could hit Japan.\n\nMr. Onodera also emphasized that a suspension was far short of denuclearization. \u201cWhat the international community expects is that North Korea abandon all weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missiles in a complete verifiable and irreversible manner,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is not a time to relax pressure by the international community, but we must keep applying pressure with an aim that they abandon their nuclear weapons and missiles.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement after a meeting of the Central Committee of his ruling Workers\u2019 Party, Mr. Kim said his country required no further nuclear and long-range missile tests because it had already achieved a nuclear deterrent. It was now time to focus on rebuilding the economy, he said.\n\n\u201cFrom April 21, North Korea will stop nuclear tests and launches of intercontinental ballistic missiles,\u201d the Korean Central News Agency said, quoting Mr. Kim.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt also said the North would \u201cshut down a nuclear test site in the country\u2019s northern side to guarantee transparency in suspending nuclear tests.\u201d\n\nTo officials and analysts in South Korea, Mr. Kim\u2019s decision to shut down his country\u2019s only known nuclear test site, in Punggye-ri in northeastern North Korea, and his moratorium on long-range missile tests, are some of the \u201ctrust-building steps\u201d that they have hoped Mr. Kim would take to help improve the mood for dialogue in Washington.\n\nMr. Kim spent last year conducting a series of nuclear and intercontinental ballistic missile tests, raising tensions and a risk of war with the United States. But he has initiated a dramatic about-face since January with a sequence of diplomatic maneuvers, including a summit meeting with President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing last month in his first trip abroad as leader, and his invitations to Mr. Moon and Mr. Trump for summit talks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnalysts in the region are deeply divided over Mr. Kim\u2019s motives. Some argue that Mr. Kim just wanted to use negotiations to buy time and ease international sanctions, never intending to abandon his nuclear weapons. But others say that Mr. Kim would eventually give up his nuclear arsenal if he were provided with the right incentives, such as security guarantees, like a peace treaty and normalized ties with Washington, and the economic aid he needs to rebuild his economy.\n\nHis latest announcement came one day after North and South Korea installed what officials said was the first-ever hotline between their top leaders, another sign of improving relations on the divided Korean Peninsula.\n\nMr. Moon was expected to use the hotline, which was installed in his office, to talk with Mr. Kim before the two leaders hold their summit meeting on the Korean border next Friday. But no date has been set for their first call.\n\nThe two Koreas have run a telephone hotline at the so-called truce village of Panmunjom \u2014 the site for the inter-Korean meeting \u2014 for years. Duty officers from both sides man their telephones at Panmunjom daily in case one side calls the other. The line has been cut off at times when bilateral relations have soured, but communications there have been restored.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the two countries have never run a direct hotline linking their top leaders\u2019 offices, officials said.\n\nThe hotline telephones were installed on Mr. Moon\u2019s desk in Seoul, the South\u2019s capital, and in the State Affairs Commission in Pyongyang, the North\u2019s capital.\n\nWhen Mr. Moon\u2019s special envoys met with Mr. Kim in Pyongyang last month, the two Koreas agreed to install the hotline and arrange for Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon to use the phone before their summit meeting. In the same meeting, Mr. Kim said he was willing to negotiate with the United States on abandoning his country\u2019s nuclear weapons.\n\nPresident Trump recently dispatched the C.I.A. director, Mike Pompeo, to meet with Mr. Kim to lay the groundwork for their meeting, which will be the first-ever summit meeting between the two nations.\n\nSouth Korean officials hope the hotline will improve communications between the top leaders and pave the way for improved ties between the two Koreas. The hotline could also be used to avert unintended armed clashes between the sides, they said.\n\n\u201cNow, if working-level talks are deadlocked and if our officials act like arrogant blockheads, President Moon can just call me directly and the problem will be promptly solved,\u201d Mr. Kim was quoted as telling the visiting South Korean envoys last month.\n\nOn Friday, aides to Mr. Moon and Mr. Kim officially opened the line and checked the connection for about four minutes, said Youn Kun-young, director for the government situation room at Mr. Moon\u2019s presidential Blue House.\n\nDuring the line check, a South Korean and a North Korean caller briefly discussed the weather, according to Mr. Moon\u2019s office.\n\n\u201cThe connection was very good,\u201d Mr. Youn said. \u201cIt was as if talking to a neighbor right next door.\u201d", "title": "\u2018We No Longer Need\u2019 Nuclear or Missile Tests, North Korean Leader Says", "authors": ["Choe Sang-Hun"]} {"date": "2018-04-10 00:00:00", "text": "It seemed as though Jonathan Nolan and Lisa Joy, the creators of HBO\u2019s \u201cWestworld,\u201d had given up. No plot twist could ever escape the imagination of theorists, the element of surprise was dead, striving for a spoiler-free television show in 2018 was futile. Reddit had defeated them.\n\nSo, like a soon-to-be-exiled employee insisting \u201cYou can\u2019t fire me because I quit,\u201d they told their Reddit superfans on Monday they would reveal the entire plot of the second season in a 25-minute video, released less than two weeks before its premiere on April 22.\n\nYou can\u2019t spoil me because I spoil you.\n\nThe theory: If all the plot details were known ahead of time, the community\u2019s moderators could potentially squelch any open discussion of them, protecting the rest of the community from stumbling upon the truth. Everyone would get what they wanted.\n\nIf such a video were posted, it would upend every viewer expectation of secrecy and surprise in modern television serials. For those who chose to watch the video, spoilers wouldn\u2019t drip out through questionable sources \u2014 they\u2019d be confirmed, complete and present top-of-mind throughout the viewing experience.", "title": "\u2018Westworld\u2019 Creators Vowed to Spoil Their Own Show. Spoiler: They Did Not.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-22 00:00:00", "text": "And so, in effect, has \u201cWestworld.\u201d In the first season, the loops had as much of a stabilizing presence for viewers as they had for the hosts, guests and engineers at the park. Even when \u201cthe reveries\u201d were causing hosts to deviate from their routines, we at least had those routines as a point of comparison, like the control group in an experiment.\n\nNow that Dolores, Maeve and the others are busting out into the open, the possibilities are exciting for them and for the show, but everyone has to live with uncertainty, too. Dolores expresses herself with tremendous confidence (\u201cI have one last role to play: myself\u201d), but even she contains a continuum of competing influences, with the optimistic Sweetwater prairie gal on one end and the mass-murdering \u201cWyatt\u201d on the other. There\u2019s a path as wide as Monument Valley between those two poles, but there\u2019s no telling where, precisely, Dolores will ultimately walk.\n\nFor now, she\u2019s freaking Teddy out a bit. \u201cWe\u2019ve ridden 10 miles and all we\u2019ve seen is blood, Dolores,\u201d he tells her. \u201cIs this what you want?\u201d Given what humans have done to Dolores and the other hosts for decades in the park, she could make a sound argument that retribution is the appropriate response. But really, the fact that such moral considerations are even in play among the hosts signifies a departure from Season 1.\n\nUntil now, the hosts have been subjected to the programming of human keepers and the whims of human guests, so any action they\u2019ve taken outside of their loops could be considered a defensible part and consequence of their awakening. Now that they\u2019re awake, they\u2019re going to carry the weight of consequential decisions, on consciences that are still works in progress. In the opening scene, Bernard (Jeffrey Wright) tells Dolores she frightens him. That\u2019s the sound of Season 2 clearing its throat.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThere are indicators, however, that the revolution will be short-lived. Delos appears to have some experience in corporate catastrophe: The funniest line of the episode has one company man calling it \u201cthe single biggest loss of life on a Delos property,\u201d suggesting that such massacres are part of doing business. Delos has dispatched its own mercenary army to quell the uprising, and it appears to have contingency plans in place for securing their valuable intellectual property in the event that something like this happens. It\u2019s worth keeping in mind that Delos\u2019s endgame for the hosts has nothing to do with theme parks, so this situation could be less devastating to the company\u2019s plans than it seems.\n\nFor a show as orderly and worked-out as \u201cWestworld,\u201d the \u201cNow what?\u201d feeling that pervades the Season 2 premiere feels invigorating, as if the show itself had wriggled free of its own narrative patterns. Dolores doesn\u2019t know what the role of \u201cherself\u201d really is at this point, and Maeve (Thandie Newton), fiendishly clever and deadly as she is, has lost herself in a quest to find a \u201cdaughter\u201d who is real only to her. The hosts have the capacity to learn quickly, but there\u2019s so much they don\u2019t know about their own world, much less the wider world that exists beyond Westworld\u2019s borders. They may find new limits in place of the old ones.\n\nParanoid Androids:\n\n\u2022 Maeve and Lee Sizemore (Simon Quarterman) are an inspired pairing. Lee\u2019s dim, underhanded bargaining recalls the bearded Nakatomi executive who tries to negotiate with the hostage-takers in \u201cDie Hard.\u201d At the same time, Maeve seems to appreciate Lee\u2019s predictable absence of courage and nobility. After he tries to give her up with nod, she\u2019s neither surprised nor particularly angry about it. Like the scorpion, it\u2019s in his nature.\n\n\u2022 Bernard spent the entirety of one timeline attached to Delos reps, gathering information. (Once again, we\u2019re on two timelines, but the relationship between them is different \u2014 one during and one apparently after the better part of the uprising.) He\u2019s not the most exciting character on \u201cWestworld,\u201d but his actions behind the scenes were hugely consequential in the first season, as evidenced by the final shot here. He\u2019s already starting to get a better sense of the larger picture than the other hosts have.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The older William, better known as the Man in Black (Ed Harris), looks absolutely delighted by the mayhem that has erupted at the park. After spending decades digging for something real in an artificial environment, he\u2019s now experiencing real danger and real lead in his arm. Westworld has finally come alive for him.\n\n\u2022 \u201cI killed myself multiple times to get this level of security clearance. Multiple times.\u201d The hosts may be outmanned, but they\u2019re resilient.\n\n\u2022 The discovery of a Bengal tiger on Westworld territory hints at more worlds to come. Michael Crichton\u2019s original \u201cWestworld\u201d included glimpses into Medievalworld and Romanworld, where the same virus that altered host behavior in Westworld had spread to the other two, leaving mass casualties in all three places. It remains to be seen how far this android infection has reached.", "title": "\u2018Westworld\u2019 Season 2 Premiere: Truth and Consequences", "authors": ["Scott Tobias"]} {"date": "2018-04-29 00:00:00", "text": "The other key takeaway from the episode: Dolores has seen everything. There was reason to believe, as the season started, that the host revolt would be short-lived. Not only are the hosts hugely outnumbered, but we assume they don\u2019t know anything about the world outside the park, much less how they\u2019ll carve out a place for themselves in it. Over the multiple timelines in \u201cReunion,\u201d however, we see that Dolores has been absorbing information through multiple builds and an array of different experiences, some of them outside the park. In the opening scenes, as Bernard and (an offscreen) Ford are readying the androids for a demonstration for Delos, Dolores gets a clear view of the city. She even has some canned dialogue about how the city lights looks like \u201cthe stars have been scattered across the ground.\u201d\n\nThe pattern continues as the episode unfolds. Dolores witnesses the postcoital scene outside Logan\u2019s bedroom on the night of the demo, as Angela (Talulah Riley), the host who will later welcome William to the park, seals the deal. Dolores is frozen in her loop as William sells his father-in-law on the investment in Sweetwater, but the episode\u2019s director, Vincenzo Natali, makes certain to note her presence at the end of the conversation, unmoving but eyes open, listening. Dolores also appears in yet another timeline as the pianist at the father-in-law\u2019s retirement party, which doubles as William\u2019s \u201ccoronation\u201d as the head of the company. She listens to a drunk Logan bitterly predict the end of the species. And she turns up again behind the scenes with William, who unwittingly reveals the \u201cweapon\u201d she later intends to use against humanity.\n\nThat\u2019s a lot of timelines. The William/Man in Black timelines in the first season now seem like training wheels that have been taken off. In \u201cReunion,\u201d only two story lines \u2014 one following Dolores, Teddy and company as they assemble an army and have a run-in with Maeve, the other following the Man in Black and Lorenzo as they start their search for the Door \u2014 take place in what we might call \u201cthe present,\u201d unfolding in continuity with the revolt that began at the end of last season.\n\nAll other story lines, meanwhile, exist somewhere along a continuum of staggered flashbacks: We see Arnold with an early version of Dolores. We see William before and after he convinces his father-in-law to invest. We see Logan as the confident master-of-the-universe type who\u2019s wowed by the demonstration and then later at the retirement party, as the broken man who anticipates human extinction. Some of these story lines do or might already overlap, and some or all of their respective timelines may converge or disappear. But it may be wise to invest in graph paper in order to follow along at home.\n\nParanoid Androids:\n\n\u2022 The first two episodes have been filled with callbacks in the dialogue, which could be defended as a reminder of the host\u2019s loops or derided as indulgent self-reference. But Bernard\u2019s line about getting used to the city lights (\u201cAfter a while, it doesn\u2019t look like anything at all\u201d) cleverly brings us back to Dolores\u2019s father glitching over a picture of the outside world. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t look like anything at all\u201d is what hosts say when they don\u2019t understand something. But we know now that Dolores was absorbing more than perhaps even she realized.", "title": "\u2018Westworld\u2019 Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: No Judgment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-30 00:00:00", "text": "Coming just two episodes into a season that was nearly 17 months in the making, Dolores and William\u2019s reunion in this week\u2019s episode of \u201cWestworld\u201d was bound to prompt some questions. For starters, is fair to call it a reunion when it happens in flashbacks? More important: What, exactly, was their deal again?\n\nWe know that Dolores and William have history \u2014 a lot of history. But because the evolution of their relationship is presented out of sequence and across several timelines, it\u2019s hard sometimes to remember all the details: How did they fall in love? How did it sour? And why does it matter now? Let\u2019s backtrack.\n\nWhat was their story when they met?\n\nWestworld - Before He is \"The Man in Black\" Via YouTube\n\nWhen William first met Dolores, some thirty years before what we might loosely call the show\u2019s \u201cpresent,\u201d he was engaged to marry Juliet Delos. That\u2019s her photograph he lost in the park \u2014 taken in Times Square \u2014 which we\u2019ll come back to. And that\u2019s why William initially resisted the advances of both the greeter robot Angela and the prostitute host Clementine. (\u201cI have somebody, somebody real, waiting for me at home,\u201d William protested.)\n\nAnd Juliet was more than just his fianc\u00e9e: He worked for her father-in-law and her brother Logan. He\u2019s chivalrous to Dolores when they first meet in the Westworld town of Sweetwater \u2014 she drops a can, he helps by picking it up \u2014 but he wasn\u2019t smitten until she joined his first park adventure and he began to sense that she was different than the other hosts.\n\n0\n\nDolores at that time was struggling to remember her conversations with the rogue programmer Arnold, who had planted in her the now-germinating seeds of something like true human consciousness. What\u2019s more, alterations in her programming allowed her to recognize \u2014 if not completely understand \u2014 mentions of the real world, which the other hosts were programmed to ignore.\n\n\u201cI feel like she understands,\u201d William told Logan in one episode. \u201cShe remembers things,\u201d he also insisted later on. \u201cShe has her own thoughts and desires.\u201d\n\nThen what happened?\n\nWestworld Season 1 Episode 7 Dolores & William Kissing Train Scene Via YouTube\n\nWilliam began choosing to protect Dolores over Logan \u2014 and to prefer her company. (Granted, Logan was kind of a jerk). He wasn\u2019t so immersed in the park fantasy that he forgot the real world, or forgot that Dolores was a machine. Rather, when it seemed that she was able to circumvent her programming \u2014 \u201cI imagined a story where I didn\u2019t have to be the damsel\u201d \u2014 he was sold. He considered the ramifications of what it meant for a sentient being to be used as a plaything, or as a slave: \u201cTo keep her in a place like this, it isn\u2019t right.\u201d\n\nThe first time they kissed, she took him by surprise. He told Dolores about his fianc\u00e9e \u2014 \u201cI have a life waiting for me\u201d \u2014 but he soon succumbed to his feelings for Dolores after she seemed hurt by this news. In the real world, he decided, he had been pretending; with Dolores, he was finally himself. Even when Logan forced him to confront her mechanical insides, William didn\u2019t want to let go of her. \u201cRun,\u201d he told her. \u201cI\u2019ll find you.\u201d\n\nWhat went wrong?\n\nWestWorld What Happened To William | William's True Identity Part 2 Via YouTube\n\nWilliam\u2019s search for Dolores took him to the outer fringes of the park, all the way to the edge, and he became increasingly violent in his methods along the way. He had imagined a story where he didn\u2019t have to be the hero \u2014 where he could be the intimidating figure no one thought he could be in real life. Eventually, he gave up his search and went back to Sweetwater, where he finally found Dolores, her memory seemingly wiped, back on her story loop, dropping her can in the street all over again. This shattered William, although he recognized that she was being \u201ctrue\u201d to her programming.\n\nWhen we see him again in Episode 2 of Season 2, William convinces James Delos to bail out and take over the park. In one scene, we see William and Juliet together at his father-in-law\u2019s retirement party, married, with an adorable daughter, Emily. Dolores is there as a glorified party prop, beautifully dressed, hair down, playing piano to entertain the guests. She seems to register \u2026 something. Does she remember? William certainly does.\n\nIn yet another scene, on yet another timeline, William seems to take a bitter satisfaction in assessing a stripped-naked Dolores as she sits in the diagnostics lab, and in showing her an area of the park that is under construction \u2014 pulling back the curtain on her reality, as it were.\n\nWhere does the Man in Black come into play?\n\nWestWorld What Happened To William | Man In Black True Identity Via YouTube\n\nA jaded William, eventually the majority shareholder, continued to visit the park for decades, using it to take out his frustrations, trying to complete the game somehow by uncovering every secret and every level its creators, Arnold and Dr. Ford, had built into it. Over time, William becomes the \u201cMan in Black\u201d; they are the same man on different timelines.\n\nAs we know from a story told by the Man in Black in Season 1, Williams relationship with his wife deteriorated over time. Juliet became afraid of him, and she died after swallowing some pills in the bath \u2014 an apparent suicide. On the trip he began in Season 1 when we first meet him as the Man in Black \u2014 the trip he began in order to find the \u201cnext level\u201d of the game; the trip he\u2019s still on in this week\u2019s episode \u2014 he raped Dolores, perhaps trying to punish her for disappointing him, for killing a part of him. (Who knows if it\u2019s the first or one of many rapes? She doesn\u2019t.)\n\n0\n\nSoon after, she starts reliving their very first encounter, when they fell in love. Dr. Ford helped kick-start the process by leaving the gun for her to find, and other events fall into place that help trigger her self-awareness. Peter Abernathy shows her the photo of Juliet in Times Square. He utters the code phrase, \u201cThese violent delights have violent ends\u201d (a quote from \u201cRomeo and Juliet\u201d as well as Arnold\u2019s last words). And then there\u2019s the rape. (Past suffering and trauma helps awaken the hosts.) She embarks on a journey to retrace her earlier trip through the Maze \u2014 in a sense, a search to find William again, or what he unlocked in her, just as he once searched for her, or what she unlocked in him.\n\nWho is Wyatt in all this?\n\nWestWorld Delores Goes Ozymandias On Man in Black Season Finale 1x10 Via YouTube\n\nWhen William encounters her the second time on that same visit, he\u2019s shocked that she has any memory of his younger self at all: \u201cWell, I\u2019ll be damned, Dolores. You do remember some things after all.\u201d But just as William\u2019s disappointment back then helped him evolve (devolve?) into the Man in Black, her disappointment in the new black-hatted William \u2014 \u201cI thought you were different, you\u2019re just like all the rest\u201d \u2014 helps her recover her inner Wyatt, a murderous character Arnold fused with hers before he died, who grasps that she needs to destroy the way things are.\n\nNow, with clear eyes, and a fully-accessible memory bank, she\u2019s able to look back and call William \u201can old friend,\u201d a phrase he once used to refer to her. But it\u2019s not William she seeks now. He\u2019s off playing what he thinks is the next level of the game, but Dolores isn\u2019t playing anymore.", "title": "\u2018Westworld\u2019: What Was the Deal With William and Dolores Again?", "authors": ["Jennifer Vineyard"]} {"date": "2018-04-13 00:00:00", "text": "The first known epidemic of extensively drug-resistant typhoid is spreading through Pakistan, infecting at least 850 people in 14 districts since 2016, according to the National Institute of Health Islamabad.\n\nThe typhoid strain, resistant to five types of antibiotics, is expected to disseminate globally, replacing weaker strains where they are endemic. Experts have identified only one remaining oral antibiotic \u2014 azithromycin \u2014 to combat it; one more genetic mutation could make typhoid untreatable in some areas.\n\nResearchers consider the epidemic an international clarion call for comprehensive prevention efforts. If vaccination campaigns and modern sanitation systems don\u2019t outpace the pathogen, they anticipate a return to the pre-antibiotic era when mortality rates soared.\n\n\u201cThis isn\u2019t just about typhoid,\u201d said Dr. Rumina Hasan, a pathology professor at the Aga Khan University in Pakistan. \u201cAntibiotic resistance is a threat to all of modern medicine \u2014 and the scary part is, we\u2019re out of options.\u201d", "title": "\u2018We\u2019re Out of Options\u2019: Doctors Battle Drug-Resistant Typhoid Outbreak", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-05 00:00:00", "text": "On Sunday, Mr. Zhdanov was detained by the police and sentenced to 14 days of administrative arrest for hindering access to transport infrastructure by organizing an illegal rally.\n\nThe landfill crisis started in June, when residents of Balashikha, a large satellite town just outside Moscow, complained to President Vladimir V. Putin during his annual call-in show about the \u201cunbearable\u201d situation in their neighborhood, which stands 650 feet away from Kuchino, one of the largest landfill dumps in the region.\n\nMr. Putin, showing off his trademark Mr. Fix-It role, ordered the landfill closed. The government wanted to do so in 2021, allowing time to find and develop new locations to distribute Moscow\u2019s waste, but Mr. Putin was relentless.\n\n\u201cNow listen to me,\u201d Mr. Putin told Environment Minister Sergei Donskoy during a televised government meeting. \u201cClose this landfill within a month.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe landfill was closed, but the 1,000 or so truckloads of waste produced daily in Moscow had to go somewhere. The regional government distributed the extra waste among the few remaining landfills around Moscow, in some cases overwhelming their capacity. The one near Volokolamsk, in Yadrovo, has seen the lines of trucks in front of its gates increase by at least a quarter.\n\n\u201cIn the first half of 2017, I received 80,000 tons of waste; in the second half I had twice as much,\u201d said Maksim O. Konopko, one of the Yadrovo landfill\u2019s owners. \u201cIf it weren\u2019t for Kuchino, we would stay within our normal limits.\u201d\n\nIn a landfill dump, the incoming waste \u2014 most of it consisting of rotting food \u2014 is buried with soil. The waste then brews inside, producing biogas, a combination of methane, carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulfide and other components. In the absence of a collection system, the accumulated gas eventually bursts through the soil and vents in large quantities into the surrounding area. The Yadrovo landfill does not have such a system, though the owner plans to install one with the help of a Dutch company.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Konopko said that he wanted to restrict the volume of waste he was receiving, but that he was getting angry phone calls, pressuring him to take more.\n\n\u201cDo you know what country we live in?\u201d Mr. Konopko said, implying that these were orders he could not refuse.\n\nMr. Konopko denied accusations that he had a financial interest in handling as much garbage as he could, since he is paid about $2 per cubic meter, saying that the added revenues would be more than offset by the cost of the new gas reclamation system. Over all, the landfill representatives said they were just as much victims of this situation as anybody else.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat is debatable, given the apparent health effects, particularly for small children. Galina N. Dubrovskaya, a former accountant, said that her granddaughter, Uliana, had been a perfectly healthy child, but that this March the girl began to wake up at night suffering nausea, dizziness and headaches. These episodes seemed to coincide, she said, with the times when the landfill spewed stinking fumes.\n\nAt least 77 children were treated at the Volokolamsk hospital after one recent blast of fumes. The regional government denied that their symptoms had anything to do with the gas, and said no traces of it had been found in the children\u2019s blood.\n\nLocal residents have disagreed vehemently. Shura Y. Antipov, whose daughter Vika was covered with large red spots, was told by doctors that the girl was suffering from some allergy and hinted at \u201cexternal causes.\u201d But they refused to link the spots to the landfill gases.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAt the beginning, doctors were pointing at the dump, but did not write anything down,\u201d said Mr. Antipov, 25, who works in the construction industry. \u201cNow they say, \u2018Anything else but the landfill.\u2019\u201d\n\nExperts say Russia\u2019s waste problem is systemic and warrants complicated long-term solutions.\n\n\u201cIf you want to fix a leaking faucet, perhaps you shouldn\u2019t break the whole pipe with a sledgehammer,\u201d Aleksei Kiselyov, the head of Greenpeace Russia\u2019s toxics campaign, said of Mr. Putin\u2019s decision to close the big landfill. \u201cThe whole waste landfill problem has become subject to populism.\u201d\n\nTo solve the problem, Mr. Kiselyov said, the Russian government would need to do what it never likes doing: encourage grass-roots movements to propagate recycling among the population.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have all these grand ideas about making Russia great, but we cannot do some fundamental things,\u201d he said.\n\nSo far, the Kremlin has been characteristically reluctant to cover the problem on state-run television channels, enraging people in Volokolamsk.\n\n\u201cThe only things you hear are Ukraine and Syria, Ukraine and Syria,\u201d said Lidiya L. Ivanova, whose teenage grandson had his hands covered in eczema \u201cas though he were wearing gloves.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhy they never cover our own, Russian problems?\u201d said Ms. Ivanova, 59.\n\nThe regional government has announced that it will close the Yadrovo landfill by the middle of this month and start its reclamation. The problem is that the Moscow waste will then be transferred to other landfills, and people are already protesting against the smell in other cities around the capital.\n\n\u201cYou can move the waste from one pocket to another, but this doesn\u2019t solve the problem,\u201d said Aleskandr Zakondyrin, a member of the political party Green Alliance.\n\nDeni Tsugayev, 10, said he felt nauseated every time his mother opened up the balcony door at night. When they went to the hospital, an official told them he was faking the sickness.\n\nLast week, he went to the main square with his mother to protest. He carried a poster saying: \u201cThere are children in Syria, there are children in Ukraine! Who am I? I am only 10 and I want to live.\u201d", "title": "\u2018When a City of 40,000 People Gets Poisoned, They Don\u2019t Care\u2019", "authors": ["Ivan Nechepurenko"]} {"date": "2018-04-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat injury, I felt like it banished me from a relationship,\u201d he said in an interview last week. \u201cLike, that\u2019s it, you\u2019re done, you\u2019re by yourself for the rest of your life. I struggled with even viewing myself as a man for a long time.\u201d\n\nBut now, four weeks after the surgery, he said, \u201cI feel whole again.\u201d\n\nHe asked that his name not be published, because of the stigma associated with genital injuries. Except for his immediate family and a few close friends, he has told no one about the nature of his wounds, he said.\n\nDr. W.P. Andrew Lee, the chairman of plastic and reconstructive surgery at Johns Hopkins, said the goal of this type of transplant is \u201cto restore a person\u2019s sense of identity and manhood.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor most men, that means regaining the ability to urinate while standing up and to have sex. Dr. Lee thinks transplantation can make both possible, though healing and nerve regeneration will take time. Urination is expected first, within a few months. Nerves grow from the recipient into the transplant at the rate of about an inch a month.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re hopeful we can restore sexual function in terms of spontaneous erection and orgasm,\u201d Dr. Lee said.\n\nAlthough the scrotum was transplanted, the donor\u2019s testes had been removed for ethical reasons: Keeping them might enable the recipient to father children that belonged genetically to the organ donor, something not considered acceptable by medical guidelines.\n\nBecause the recipient\u2019s own reproductive tissue was destroyed, he will not be able to have biological children. He takes testosterone to compensate for the loss of his testes, and is being treated with another drug, Cialis, to encourage erectile function.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow many men might need this type of transplant is not known. Data from the Defense Department show that more than 1,300 men sustained so-called genitourinary injuries in Iraq and Afghanistan, and that 31 percent of those injuries involved the penis.\n\nAbout 20 percent of the penile injuries were considered severe \u2014 but how many might warrant a transplant is not clear. Women in the military have also suffered genitourinary and reproductive injuries, but they are less common.\n\nTeams at Johns Hopkins and at the Massachusetts General Hospital are both evaluating more candidates for the surgery \u2014 some hurt in the military, others affected by accidents or illness. But it can take a long time to find a matching donor \u2014 the Johns Hopkins patient waited more than a year on the transplant list \u2014 so no rush of operations is expected.\n\nThe Department of Defense has funded some of the research, but Johns Hopkins is paying for the first operation, which Dr. Lee estimated would cost from $300,000 to $400,000. The surgeons \u2014 nine plastic and reconstructive surgeons, and two urologists \u2014 worked for free.\n\nDr. Lee said he hoped for grants from the Pentagon to help pay for future operations, and also for insurance coverage, which is not available now for this type of transplant.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the explosion that injured the soldier, he remained conscious, he remembered, but knew he was sinking into shock. He passed out on the medevac helicopter. His next memory was waking up in the United States, relieved to be alive.\n\nSoon, the gravity of the damage hit. A military doctor told him it was permanent and irreparable.\n\n\u201cThat was crushing, but when he walked away I thought, he hasn\u2019t been a doctor long enough, he doesn\u2019t know what he\u2019s talking about,\u201d the patient said. \u201cYou got all this technology, how can you tell me this is permanent? There\u2019s got to be something.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe felt isolated, even in the hospital among other wounded soldiers.\n\n\u201cThere were times you\u2019d be hanging out and guys would be talking about getting hurt, and that\u2019s one of the first things when they get blown up, to check down there, and they would say things like, \u2018If I lost mine I\u2019d just kill myself,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I\u2019m sitting there. They didn\u2019t know, and I know they didn\u2019t mean any offense, but it kind of hits you in the gut.\u201d\n\nHe struggled with thoughts of suicide, he said: \u201cWhen I would actually think about killing myself, I would think, \u2018Am I really just gonna kill myself over a penis?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe learned to walk with prosthetic legs, left the hospital and lived on his own in an apartment. But he had trouble connecting with other people, and even when he no longer needed OxyContin for physical pain he kept taking it to numb his emotions.\n\nHe managed to wean himself off it. He saw a therapist. He earned a college degree and began making plans to attend medical school.\n\nBut relationships or even dating felt out of the question. If he got close to someone, he would have to disclose his wounds, and the thought filled him with anxiety.\n\n\u201cIt is a lonely injury,\u201d he said.\n\nIn 2012, he began consulting Dr. Richard J. Redett, the director of pediatric plastic and reconstructive surgery at Johns Hopkins, about a procedure to create a penis from his own tissue, possibly the skin on the inside of the forearm.\n\nThat operation makes urination possible, but requires an implant to achieve an erection. The procedure was appealing, but Dr. Redett also mentioned a future possibility that seemed much more promising: a transplant.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cBasically, if you do a transplant, you\u2019re going to have the real thing again,\u201d the patient said.\n\nHe decided to wait.\n\nHe passed an exhaustive screening process. Certain nerves and blood vessels have to be intact, along with the urethra, the tube that carries urine out of the body.\n\nCandidates also have to qualify psychologically \u2014 to be able to understand the risks and benefits and stick to their anti-rejection medicine, as well as have a family or other support network.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFamilies of organ donors are asked specifically for permission to use the penis, and past requests have been made for research purposes. Carisa M. Cooney, a clinical research manager in plastic and reconstructive surgery at Johns Hopkins, said that when families hear that the goal is to help wounded veterans, many consent.\n\nIn this case, the donor\u2019s family sent the soldier a message via New England Donor Services: \u201cWe are all very proud that our loved one was able to help a young man that served this country. We are so thankful to say that our loved one would be proud and honored to know he provided such a special gift to you. As a family, we are very supportive of all the men and women who serve our country and grateful for the job you did for this nation. Please know that this is truly a heartfelt statement, as we have several veterans in the family. We hope you can return to better health very soon and we continue to wish you a speedy recovery.\u201d\n\nThe donor was from another state, and three surgeons from Johns Hopkins \u2014 Dr. Redett, Dr. Damon Cooney and Dr. Gerald Brandacher \u2014 flew there by private jet to operate on him, an exacting procedure to remove precisely the tissue that would be needed.\n\nThey had to coordinate with teams from other institutions who were collecting other organs, and at times there were 25 people in the operating room, Dr. Brandacher said. Part of his role was to remove nine vertebrae from the donor, to provide stem cells that the Johns Hopkins team would infuse into the recipient to help prevent rejection and minimize the amount of anti-rejection medicine needed.\n\nThe patient said that before the surgery, he wondered if he would accept the new body parts, mentally and emotionally.\n\n\u201cWhat tripped me out at first is sometimes I would get a thought like, \u2018Am I going to be able to see it as my own?\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThat thought would creep in. But once I had it done, that\u2019s the only way I see it. It\u2019s mine.\u201d\n\nLooking ahead, he sketched out his hopes.\n\n\u201cDefinitely, to do well in school, to go to medical school and follow my career as a doctor, find my niche in the field and just excel at it. Maybe settle down and maybe eventually find someone, and get into a relationship, maybe. Just that normal stuff.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Whole Again\u2019: A Vet Maimed by an I.E.D. Receives a Transplanted Penis", "authors": ["Denise Grady"]} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Prime Minister Theresa May apologized on Tuesday for harsh treatment of some Caribbeans who have lived in Britain legally for decades but have trouble documenting their status, as her government reversed itself on an issue that had turned into a major embarrassment.\n\nThe handling of the Caribbean-born Britons had become an example \u2014 a shameful one, critics said \u2014 of the Conservative government\u2019s attempts to manage the anti-immigrant sentiment that helped fuel Britain\u2019s 2016 referendum to leave the European Union.\n\nThe controversy began after the publication of recent reports in the British press about longtime legal residents of West Indian and Caribbean ancestry who had lost their jobs, been denied medical care, been evicted or even detained and threatened with deportation \u2014 all because they could not prove that they had lived in the country since before 1973. Their stories have produced a storm of criticism aimed at the government.\n\nEven as Britain is confronting Russia over the nerve agent attack on a former spy in Salisbury, England, negotiating its divorce from the European Union and recently joined in missile strikes against Syria over accusations that the Syrian government used chemical weapons, the status of middle-aged and older Caribbean immigrants has taken up much of the government\u2019s time and attention.", "title": "\u2018Windrush Generation,\u2019 Fearful Over Status, Gets U.K. Apology", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-03 00:00:00", "text": "Fifty years ago, colorful, mustachioed cartoon versions of the Beatles traipsed across the surreal world of Pepperland to defeat the Blue Meanies in the film \u201cYellow Submarine.\u201d The movie will return to theaters across the United States, Britain and Ireland this summer to celebrate its anniversary.\n\nThe movie\u2019s psychedelic landscapes have been restored in 4k digital resolution; the animation was cleaned up by hand, frame by frame, rather than through automated digital software.
