The 34-year-old defense attorney had no challengers.\n\nBut for his supporters who packed into a Mexican restaurant that evening, there was still something impressive to celebrate. Many in the crowd were members of the Democratic Socialists of America, or D.S.A., a group that has experienced an enormous surge of interest since the election of President Trump, even in conservative states. And Mr. Bynum was one of their own \u2014 a socialist who, along with at least 16 others, appeared on the ballot in primary races across the state of Texas.\n\n\u201cYes, I\u2019m running as a socialist,\u201d Mr. Bynum said. \u201cI\u2019m a far-left candidate. What I\u2019m trying to do is be a Democrat who actually stands for something, and tells people, \u2018Here\u2019s how we are going to materially improve conditions in your life.\u2019\u201d\n\nRather than shy away from being called a socialist, a word conservatives have long wielded as a slur, candidates like Mr. Bynum are embracing the label. He is among dozens of D.S.A. members running in this fall\u2019s midterms for offices across the country at nearly every level. In Hawaii, Kaniela Ing, a state representative, is running for Congress. Gayle McLaughlin, a former mayor of Richmond, Calif., is running to be the state\u2019s lieutenant governor. In Tennessee, Dennis Prater, an adjunct professor at East Tennessee State University, is running to be a county commissioner.", "title": "\u2018Yes, I\u2019m Running as a Socialist.\u2019 Why Candidates Are Embracing the Label in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-08 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Zuckerberg has said the misuse of data represented a \u201cbreach of trust\u201d by the company. But even he has suggested that other app developers could have done the same.\n\nUntil April 2015, Facebook allowed some app developers to collect some private information from the profiles of users who downloaded apps, and from those of their friends. Facebook has said it allowed this kind of data collection to help developers improve the \u201cin-app\u201d experience for users. But Facebook appears to have done little to verify how developers were using the data or whether they were providing any kind of experience on Facebook at all.\n\nThe questionnaire used to collect data for Cambridge Analytica was not actually on Facebook. It was hosted by a company called Qualtrics, which provides a platform for online surveys. It consisted of dozens of questions often used by psychology researchers to assess personality, such as whether the respondent prefers to be alone, tries to lead others and loves large parties (the answer choices range from \u201cdisagree strongly\u201d to \u201cagree strongly\u201d). The questionnaire took about 10 to 20 minutes to complete.\n\nWhen respondents authorized access to their Facebook profiles, the app performed its sole function: to take the users\u2019 data and that of their friends. There was no \u201cin-app\u201d experience to speak of; this was not intended to be the sort of cute online quiz that tells users which \u201cFriends\u201d character they most resemble or how their brunch preferences reveal their inner Disney princess.\n\nFacebook has said that people who took the quiz were told that their data would be used only for academic purposes, claiming that it and its users were misled by Cambridge Analytica and the researcher it hired, Aleksandr Kogan, a 28-year-old Russian-American academic. But the fine print that accompanied the questionnaire may have told users that their data could be used for commercial purposes, according to a draft of the survey\u2019s terms of service that was reviewed by The Times.", "title": "\u2018You Are the Product\u2019: Targeted by Cambridge Analytica on Facebook", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-04 00:00:00", "text": "The sensationalization of this story and others like it seems to serve a common purpose for Mr. Trump and other immigration hard-liners: to highlight the twin dangers of freely roving migrants \u2014 especially those from Muslim countries \u2014 and lax immigration laws that grant them easy entry into Western nations.\n\nThe narrative on the right this week, for example, mostly omitted that many people in the caravan planned to resettle in Mexico, not the United States. And it ignored how many of those who did intend to come here would probably go through the legal process of requesting asylum at a border checkpoint \u2014 something miles of new wall and battalions of additional border patrol would not have stopped.\n\n\u201cThey end up in schools on Long Island, some of which are MS-13!\u201d declared Brian Kilmeade on the president\u2019s preferred morning news program, \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d referring to the predominantly Central American gang.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe coverage became so distorted that it prompted a reporter for Breitbart News who covers border migration, Brandon Darby, to push back. \u201cI\u2019m seeing a lot of right media cover this as \u2018people coming illegally\u2019 or as \u2018illegal aliens.\u2019 That is incorrect,\u201d he wrote on Twitter. \u201cThey are coming to a port of entry and requesting refugee status. That is legal.\u201d\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Darby said it was regrettable that the relatively routine occurrence of migrant caravans \u2014 which organizers rely on as a safety-in-numbers precaution against the violence that can happen along the trek \u2014 was being politicized. \u201cThe caravan isn\u2019t something that\u2019s a unique event,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I think people are looking at it wrong. If you\u2019re upset at the situation, it\u2019s easier to be mad at the migrant than it is to be mad at the political leaders on both sides who won\u2019t change the laws.\u201d\n\nAs tends to be the case in these stories, the humanitarian aspects get glossed over as migrants are collapsed into one maligned category: hostile foreign invaders.\n\nIn November, Mr. Trump touched off an international furor when he posted a series of videos on Twitter that purported to show the effects of mass Muslim migration in Europe. Initially circulated by a fringe ultranationalist in Britain who has railed against Islam, the videos included titles like \u201cMuslim migrant beats up Dutch boy on crutches!\u201d \u201cMuslim Destroys a Statue of Virgin Mary!\u201d and \u201cIslamist mob pushes teenage boy off roof and beats him to death!\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe assailant in one video the president shared, however, was not a \u201cMuslim migrant.\u201d And the other two videos depicted four-year-old events with no explanation.\n\nThese items tend to metastasize irrespective of the facts, but contain powerful visual elements to which Mr. Trump is known to viscerally respond.\n\nLast February, Mr. Trump insinuated that some kind of terror-related episode involving Muslim immigrants had taken place in Sweden. \u201cWho would believe this? Sweden,\u201d he said at a rally in Florida, leaving Swedes and Americans baffled because nothing out of the ordinary had happened at all. \u201cThey took in large numbers. They\u2019re having problems like they never thought possible.\u201d\n\nLike the caravan story, which apparently came to Mr. Trump\u2019s attention as he watched \u201cFox & Friends,\u201d the president was referring to something he had seen on cable news. And he later had to clarify that he was referring to a Fox News segment on issues Sweden was having with migrants generally, not any particular event.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe conservative National Review later called the piece in question \u201csensationalistic\u201d and pointed out that a lack of government data made it virtually impossible to determine whether crime rates in the country were related to immigration.\n\nWhen the president himself has not spread stories about immigration that were either misleading or turned out to be false, his White House aides have. Last year, the White House joined a pile-on by the conservative news media after it called attention to the account of a high school student in Montgomery County, Md., who said she was raped at school by two classmates, one of whom is an undocumented immigrant. The case became a national rallying cry on the right against permissive border policies and so-called sanctuary cities that treat undocumented immigrants more leniently. Fox News broadcast live outside the high school for days.\n\nProsecutors later dropped the charges after they said the evidence did not substantiate the girl\u2019s claims.\n\nThe story of the caravan has been similarly exaggerated. And the emotional outpouring from the right has been raw \u2014 that was the case on Fox this week when the TV host Tucker Carlson shouted \u201cYou hate America!\u201d at an immigrants rights activist after he defended the people marching through Mexico.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe facts of the caravan are not as straightforward as Mr. Trump or many conservative pundits have portrayed them. The story initially gained widespread attention after BuzzFeed News reported last week that more than 1,000 Central American migrants, mostly from Honduras, were making their way north toward the United States border. Yet the BuzzFeed article and other coverage pointed out that many in the group were planning to stay in Mexico.\n\nThat did not stop Mr. Trump from expressing dismay on Tuesday with a situation \u201cwhere you have thousands of people that decide to just walk into our country, and we don\u2019t have any laws that can protect it.\u201d\n\nThe use of disinformation in immigration debates is hardly unique to the United States. Misleading crime statistics, speculation about sinister plots to undermine national sovereignty and Russian propaganda have all played a role in stirring up anti-immigrant sentiment in places like Britain, Germany and Hungary. Some of the more fantastical theories have involved a socialist conspiracy to import left-leaning voters and a scheme by the Hungarian-born Jewish philanthropist George Soros to create a borderless Europe.\n\nAnyone watching Fox News this week would have heard about similar forces at work inside \u201cthe caravan.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis was an organized plan and deliberate attack on the sovereignty of the United States by a special interest group,\u201d said David Ward, whom the network identified as a former agent for Immigration and Customs Enforcement. \u201cThey rallied a bunch of foreign nationals to come north into the United States to test our resolve.\u201d", "title": "\u2018You Hate America!\u2019: How the \u2018Caravan\u2019 Story Exploded on the Right", "authors": ["Jeremy W. Peters"]} {"date": "2018-04-25 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump presidency has sparked a debate about which voices are \u2014 and aren\u2019t \u2014 reflected in the national media. Many publications have been criticized for publishing too narrow a range of opinions. And several publications, including The Times, The Atlantic and The Washington Post, have recently made high-profile conservative hires.\n\nI recently asked Times readers for their thoughts on the issue: Which opinions are underrepresented in the national media? And which if any should remain underrepresented because they\u2019re beyond the pale of productive discourse?\n\nWe have received almost 1,000 responses, via email and social media. Here, we describe some common themes from those replies:\n\nThe national media should expand the boundaries of the debate \u2014 to both the right and left, among other ways.\n\nThis was perhaps the most common response. There should be more writing from both pro-Trump conservatives and Jacobin-level socialists, as one reader, Andrew Ross, put it \u2014 \u201ceven though\u201d (or maybe especially because) \u201celite readers may find their arguments objectionable.\u201d Joshua Benton, director of the Nieman Journalism Lab, called for a better airing of the \u201cviews of people whose politics are more than one standard deviation from the national mean.\u201d A Twitter user named Rust Belt Jacobin summarized the missing as: \u201cLeftists; Trump supporters; Latinos; working-class people.\u201d\n\nIn the 2016 Democratic primaries, for example, Bernie Sanders excited millions of people and won about 43 percent of the popular vote. Yet most national publications employed few if any opinion writers who preferred him over Hillary Clinton. Only a smattering of editorial boards endorsed Sanders: The San Francisco Examiner, The Seattle Times, The Daily Iowan and several alternative weeklies.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018You never see that point of view in mainstream press.\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-17 00:00:00", "text": "Jane Perlez is the Beijing bureau chief. She has served as bureau chief in Kenya, Poland, Austria, Indonesia and Pakistan, and was a member of the team that won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize for reporting in Pakistan and Afghanistan.@JanePerlez", "title": "\u2018\uc8fd\uc744 \uac01\uc624 \ud558\uace0 \uc788\ub2e4.\u2019 \ub05d\ub0b4 \ud0c8\ubd81 \ubabb \ud55c 5\uba85\uc758 \uc774\uc57c\uae30", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-04-02 00:00:00", "text": "", "title": "\ub354\ub294 \uac04\uacfc\ud558\uc9c0 \uc54a\uaca0\uc2b5\ub2c8\ub2e4:\uc720\uad00\uc21c, \uc77c\uc81c \ud1b5\uce58\uc5d0 \uc800\ud56d\ud55c \ud55c\uad6d \ub3c5\ub9bd\uc6b4\ub3d9\uac00", "authors": []}
